
       
Barnaby
Rudge
:
<EOS>
A
Tale
of
the
Riots
of
'
Eighty
Barnaby
Rudge
 
Charles
Dickens
  
1840
<EOS>
-
-1841
  
<EOS>
Information
about
the
source
                   
Chapter
1
    
<EOS>
In
the
year
1775
,
there
stood
upon
the
borders
of
Epping
Forest
,
at
a
distance
of
about
twelve
miles
from
London
---
measuring
from
the
Standard
in
Cornhill
,
"
or
rather
from
the
spot
on
or
near
to
which
the
Standard
used
to
be
in
days
of
yore
---
a
house
of
public
entertainment
called
the
Maypole
;
which
fact
was
demonstrated
to
all
such
travellers
as
could
neither
read
nor
write
(
and
at
that
time
a
vast
number
both
of
travellers
and
stay
-
at
-
homes
were
in
this
condition
)
by
the
emblem
reared
on
the
roadside
over
against
the
house
,
which
,
if
not
of
those
goodly
proportions
that
Maypoles
were
wo
nt
to
present
in
olden
times
,
was
a
fair
young
ash
,
thirty
feet
in
height
,
and
straight
as
any
arrow
that
ever
English
yeoman
drew
.
  
<EOS>
The
Maypole
---
by
which
term
from
henceforth
is
meant
the
house
,
and
not
its
sign
---
the
Maypole
was
an
old
building
,
with
more
gable
ends
than
a
lazy
man
would
care
to
count
on
a
sunny
day
;
huge
zig
-
zag
chimneys
,
out
of
which
it
seemed
as
though
even
smoke
could
not
choose
but
come
in
more
than
naturally
fantastic
shapes
,
imparted
to
it
in
its
tortuous
progress
;
and
vast
stables
,
gloomy
,
ruinous
,
and
empty
.
 
<EOS>
The
place
was
said
to
have
been
built
in
the
days
of
King
Henry
the
Eighth
;
and
there
was
a
legend
,
not
only
that
Queen
Elizabeth
had
slept
there
one
night
while
upon
a
hunting
excursion
,
to
wit
,
in
a
certain
oak
-
panelled
room
with
a
deep
bay
window
,
but
that
next
morning
,
while
standing
on
a
mounting
block
before
the
door
with
one
foot
in
the
stirrup
,
the
virgin
monarch
had
then
and
there
boxed
and
cuffed
an
unlucky
page
for
some
neglect
of
duty
.
<EOS>
The
matter
-
of
-
fact
and
doubtful
folks
,
of
whom
there
were
a
few
among
the
Maypole
customers
,
as
unluckily
there
always
are
in
every
little
community
,
were
inclined
to
look
upon
this
tradition
as
rather
apocryphal
;
but
,
whenever
the
landlord
of
that
ancient
hostelry
appealed
to
the
mounting
block
itself
as
evidence
,
and
triumphantly
pointed
out
that
there
it
stood
in
the
same
place
to
that
very
day
,
the
doubters
never
failed
to
be
put
down
by
a
large
majority
,
and
all
true
believers
exulted
as
in
a
victory
.
  
<EOS>
Whether
these
,
and
many
other
stories
of
the
like
nature
,
were
true
or
untrue
,
the
Maypole
was
really
an
old
house
,
a
very
old
house
,
perhaps
as
old
as
it
claimed
to
be
,
and
perhaps
older
,
which
will
sometimes
happen
with
houses
of
an
uncertain
,
as
with
ladies
of
a
certain
,
age
.
 
<EOS>
Its
windows
were
old
diamond
-
pane
lattices
,
its
floors
were
sunken
and
uneven
,
its
ceilings
blackened
by
the
hand
of
time
,
and
heavy
with
massive
beams
.
 
<EOS>
Over
the
doorway
was
an
ancient
porch
,
quaintly
and
grotesquely
carved
;
and
here
on
summer
evenings
the
more
favoured
customers
smoked
and
drank
---
ay
,
and
sang
many
a
good
song
too
,
sometimes
---
reposing
on
two
grim
-
looking
high
-
backed
settles
,
which
,
like
the
twin
dragons
of
some
fairy
tale
,
guarded
the
entrance
to
the
mansion
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
chimneys
of
the
disused
rooms
,
swallows
had
built
their
nests
for
many
a
long
year
,
and
from
earliest
spring
to
latest
autumn
whole
colonies
of
sparrows
chirped
and
twittered
in
the
eaves
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
more
pigeons
about
the
dreary
stable
-
yard
and
out
-
buildings
than
anybody
but
the
landlord
could
reckon
up
.
 
<EOS>
The
wheeling
and
circling
flights
of
runts
,
fantails
,
tumblers
,
and
pouters
,
were
perhaps
not
quite
consistent
with
the
grave
and
sober
character
of
the
building
,
but
the
monotonous
cooing
,
which
never
ceased
to
be
raised
by
some
among
them
all
day
long
,
suited
it
exactly
,
and
seemed
to
lull
it
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
With
its
overhanging
stories
,
drowsy
little
panes
of
glass
,
and
front
bulging
out
and
projecting
over
the
pathway
,
the
old
house
looked
as
if
it
were
nodding
in
its
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
it
needed
no
very
great
stretch
of
fancy
to
detect
in
it
other
resemblances
to
humanity
.
 
<EOS>
The
bricks
of
which
it
was
built
had
originally
been
a
deep
dark
red
,
but
had
grown
yellow
and
discoloured
like
an
old
man
's
skin
;
the
sturdy
timbers
had
decayed
like
teeth
;
and
here
<EOS>
and
there
the
ivy
,
like
a
warm
garment
to
comfort
it
in
its
age
,
wrapt
its
green
leaves
closely
round
the
time
-
worn
walls
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
hale
and
hearty
age
though
,
still
:
and
in
the
summer
or
autumn
evenings
,
when
the
glow
of
the
setting
sun
fell
upon
the
oak
and
chestnut
trees
of
the
adjacent
forest
,
the
old
house
,
partaking
of
its
lustre
,
seemed
their
fit
companion
,
and
to
have
many
good
years
of
life
in
him
yet
.
  
<EOS>
The
evening
with
which
we
have
to
do
,
was
neither
a
summer
nor
an
autumn
one
,
but
the
twilight
of
a
day
in
March
,
when
the
wind
howled
dismally
among
the
bare
branches
of
the
trees
,
and
rumbling
in
the
wide
chimneys
and
driving
the
rain
against
the
windows
of
the
Maypole
Inn
,
gave
such
of
its
frequenters
as
chanced
to
be
there
at
the
moment
an
undeniable
reason
for
prolonging
their
stay
,
and
caused
the
landlord
to
prophesy
that
the
night
would
certainly
clear
at
eleven
o'clock
precisely
,
---
which
by
a
remarkable
coincidence
was
the
hour
at
which
he
always
closed
his
house
.
  
<EOS>
The
name
of
him
upon
whom
the
spirit
of
prophecy
thus
descended
was
John
Willet
,
a
burly
,
large
-
headed
man
with
a
fat
face
,
which
betokened
profound
obstinacy
and
slowness
of
apprehension
,
combined
with
a
very
strong
reliance
upon
his
own
merits
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
John
Willet
's
ordinary
boast
in
his
more
placid
moods
that
if
he
were
slow
he
was
sure
;
which
assertion
could
,
in
one
sense
at
least
,
be
by
no
means
gainsaid
,
seeing
that
he
was
in
everything
unquestionably
the
reverse
of
fast
,
and
withal
one
of
the
most
dogged
and
positive
fellows
in
existence
---
<EOS>
always
sure
that
what
he
thought
or
said
or
did
was
right
,
and
holding
it
as
a
thing
quite
settled
and
ordained
by
the
laws
of
nature
and
Providence
,
that
anybody
who
said
or
did
or
thought
otherwise
must
be
inevitably
and
of
necessity
wrong
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
walked
slowly
up
to
the
window
,
flattened
his
fat
nose
against
the
cold
glass
,
and
shading
his
eyes
that
his
sight
might
not
be
affected
by
the
ruddy
glow
of
the
fire
,
looked
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
walked
slowly
back
to
his
old
seat
in
the
chimney
-
corner
,
and
,
composing
himself
in
it
with
a
slight
shiver
,
such
as
a
man
might
give
way
to
<EOS>
and
so
acquire
an
additional
relish
for
the
warm
blaze
,
said
,
looking
round
upon
his
guests
:
  
<EOS>
"
It
'll
clear
at
eleven
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
No
sooner
and
no
later
.
 
<EOS>
Not
before
and
not
arterwards
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
make
out
that
?
"
said
a
little
man
in
the
opposite
corner
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
moon
is
past
the
full
,
and
she
rises
at
nine
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
John
looked
sedately
and
solemnly
at
his
questioner
until
he
had
brought
his
mind
to
bear
upon
the
whole
of
his
observation
,
and
then
made
answer
,
in
a
tone
which
seemed
to
imply
that
the
moon
was
peculiarly
his
business
and
nobody
else
's
:
  
<EOS>
"
Never
you
mind
about
the
moon
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
trouble
yourself
about
her
.
 
<EOS>
You
let
the
moon
alone
,
and
I
'll
let
you
alone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
offence
I
hope
?
"
said
the
little
man
.
  
<EOS>
Again
John
waited
leisurely
until
the
observation
had
thoroughly
penetrated
to
his
brain
,
and
then
replying
,
"
No
offence
as
YET
,
"
applied
a
light
to
his
pipe
and
smoked
in
placid
silence
;
now
and
then
casting
a
sidelong
look
at
a
man
wrapped
in
a
loose
riding
-
coat
with
huge
cuffs
ornamented
with
tarnished
silver
lace
and
large
metal
buttons
,
who
sat
apart
from
the
regular
frequenters
of
the
house
,
and
wearing
a
hat
flapped
over
his
face
,
which
was
still
further
shaded
by
the
hand
on
which
his
forehead
rested
,
looked
unsociable
enough
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
another
guest
,
who
sat
,
booted
and
spurred
,
at
some
distance
from
the
fire
also
,
and
whose
thoughts
---
to
judge
from
his
folded
arms
and
knitted
brows
,
and
from
the
untasted
liquor
before
him
---
were
occupied
with
other
matters
than
the
topics
under
discussion
or
the
persons
who
discussed
them
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
a
young
man
of
about
eight
-
and
-
twenty
,
rather
above
the
middle
height
,
and
though
of
somewhat
slight
figure
,
gracefully
and
strongly
made
.
 
<EOS>
He
wore
his
own
dark
hair
,
and
was
accoutred
in
a
riding
dress
,
which
together
with
his
large
boots
(
resembling
in
shape
and
fashion
those
worn
by
our
Life
Guardsmen
at
the
present
day
)
,
showed
indisputable
traces
of
the
bad
condition
of
the
roads
.
 
<EOS>
But
travel
-
stained
though
he
was
<EOS>
,
he
was
well
and
even
richly
attired
,
and
without
being
overdressed
looked
a
gallant
gentleman
.
  
<EOS>
Lying
upon
the
table
beside
him
,
as
he
had
carelessly
thrown
them
down
,
were
a
heavy
riding
-
whip
and
a
slouched
hat
,
the
latter
worn
no
doubt
as
being
best
suited
to
the
inclemency
of
the
weather
.
<EOS>
There
,
too
,
were
a
pair
of
pistols
in
a
holster
-
case
,
and
a
short
riding
-
cloak
.
 
<EOS>
Little
of
his
face
was
visible
,
except
the
long
dark
lashes
which
concealed
his
downcast
eyes
,
but
an
air
of
careless
ease
and
natural
gracefulness
of
demeanour
pervaded
the
figure
,
and
seemed
to
comprehend
even
those
slight
accessories
,
which
were
all
handsome
,
and
in
good
keeping
.
  
<EOS>
Towards
this
young
gentleman
the
eyes
of
Mr
Willet
wandered
but
once
,
and
then
as
if
in
mute
inquiry
whether
he
had
observed
his
silent
neighbour
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
plain
that
John
and
the
young
gentleman
had
often
met
before
.
 
<EOS>
Finding
that
his
look
was
not
returned
,
or
indeed
observed
by
the
person
to
whom
it
was
addressed
,
John
gradually
concentrated
the
whole
power
of
his
eyes
into
one
focus
,
and
brought
it
to
bear
upon
the
man
in
the
flapped
hat
,
at
whom
he
came
to
stare
in
course
of
time
with
an
intensity
so
remarkable
,
that
it
affected
his
fireside
cronies
,
who
all
,
as
with
one
accord
,
took
their
pipes
from
their
lips
,
and
stared
with
open
mouths
at
the
stranger
likewise
.
  
<EOS>
The
sturdy
landlord
had
a
large
pair
of
dull
fish
-
like
eyes
,
and
the
little
man
who
had
hazarded
the
remark
about
the
moon
(
and
who
was
the
parish
-
clerk
and
bell
-
ringer
of
Chigwell
,
a
village
hard
by
)
had
little
round
black
shiny
eyes
like
beads
;
moreover
this
little
man
wore
at
the
knees
of
his
rusty
black
breeches
,
and
on
his
rusty
black
coat
,
and
all
down
his
long
flapped
waistcoat
,
little
queer
buttons
like
nothing
except
his
eyes
;
<EOS>
but
so
like
them
,
that
as
they
twinkled
and
glistened
in
the
light
of
the
fire
,
which
shone
too
in
his
bright
shoe
-
buckles
,
he
seemed
all
eyes
from
head
to
foot
,
and
to
be
gazing
with
every
one
of
them
at
the
unknown
customer
.
 
<EOS>
No
wonder
that
a
man
should
grow
restless
under
such
an
inspection
as
this
,
to
say
nothing
of
the
eyes
belonging
to
short
Tom
Cobb
the
general
chandler
and
post
-
office
keeper
,
and
long
Phil
Parkes
the
ranger
,
both
of
whom
,
infected
by
the
example
of
their
companions
,
regarded
him
of
the
flapped
hat
no
less
attentively
.
  
<EOS>
The
stranger
became
restless
;
perhaps
from
being
exposed
to
this
raking
fire
of
eyes
,
perhaps
from
the
nature
of
his
previous
meditations
---
most
probably
from
the
latter
cause
,
for
as
he
changed
his
position
and
looked
hastily
round
,
he
started
to
find
himself
the
object
of
such
keen
regard
,
and
darted
an
angry
and
suspicious
glance
at
the
fireside
group
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
the
effect
of
immediately
diverting
all
eyes
to
the
chimney
,
except
those
of
John
Willet
,
who
finding
himself
as
it
were
,
caught
in
the
fact
,
and
not
being
(
as
has
been
already
observed
)
of
a
very
ready
nature
,
remained
staring
at
his
guest
in
a
particularly
awkward
and
disconcerted
manner
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
said
the
stranger
.
  
<EOS>
Well
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
not
much
in
well
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
long
speech
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
gave
an
order
,
"
said
the
landlord
,
after
a
pause
of
two
or
three
minutes
for
consideration
.
  
<EOS>
The
stranger
took
off
his
hat
,
and
disclosed
the
hard
features
of
a
man
of
sixty
or
thereabouts
,
much
weatherbeaten
and
worn
by
time
,
and
the
naturally
harsh
expression
of
which
was
not
improved
by
a
dark
handkerchief
which
was
bound
tightly
round
his
head
,
and
,
while
it
served
the
purpose
of
a
wig
,
shaded
his
forehead
,
and
almost
hid
his
eyebrows
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
were
intended
to
conceal
or
divert
attention
from
a
deep
gash
,
now
healed
into
an
ugly
seam
,
which
when
it
was
first
inflicted
must
have
laid
bare
his
cheekbone
,
the
object
was
but
indifferently
attained
,
<EOS>
for
it
could
scarcely
fail
to
be
noted
at
a
glance
.
 
<EOS>
His
complexion
was
of
a
cadaverous
hue
,
and
he
had
a
grizzly
jagged
beard
of
some
three
weeks
'
date
.
 
<EOS>
Such
was
the
figure
(
very
meanly
and
poorly
clad
)
that
now
rose
from
the
seat
,
and
stalking
across
the
room
sat
down
in
a
corner
of
the
chimney
,
which
the
politeness
or
fears
of
the
little
clerk
very
readily
assigned
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
highwayman
!
"
<EOS>
whispered
Tom
Cobb
to
Parkes
the
ranger
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
suppose
highwaymen
do
n't
dress
handsomer
than
that
?
"
replied
Parkes
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
better
business
than
you
think
for
,
Tom
,
and
highwaymen
<EOS>
do
n't
need
or
use
to
be
shabby
,
take
my
word
for
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Meanwhile
the
subject
of
their
speculations
had
done
due
honour
to
the
house
by
calling
for
some
drink
,
which
was
promptly
supplied
by
the
landlord
's
son
Joe
,
a
broad
-
shouldered
strapping
young
fellow
of
twenty
,
whom
it
pleased
his
father
still
to
consider
a
little
boy
,
and
to
treat
accordingly
.
 
<EOS>
Stretching
out
his
hands
to
warm
them
by
the
blazing
fire
,
the
man
turned
his
head
towards
the
company
,
and
after
running
his
eye
sharply
over
them
,
said
in
a
voice
well
suited
to
his
appearance
:
  
"
<EOS>
What
house
is
that
which
stands
a
mile
or
so
from
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Public
-
house
?
"
said
the
landlord
,
with
his
usual
deliberation
.
  
<EOS>
"
Public
-
house
,
father
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Joe
,
"
where
's
the
public
-
house
within
a
mile
or
so
of
the
Maypole
?
 
<EOS>
He
means
the
great
house
---
the
Warren
---
naturally
and
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
red
brick
house
,
sir
,
that
stands
in
its
own
grounds
---
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
"
said
the
stranger
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
that
fifteen
or
twenty
years
ago
stood
in
a
park
five
times
as
broad
,
which
with
other
and
richer
property
has
bit
by
bit
changed
hands
and
dwindled
away
---
<EOS>
more
's
the
pity
!
<EOS>
"
pursued
the
young
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
Maybe
,
"
was
the
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
my
question
related
to
the
owner
.
<EOS>
What
it
has
been
I
do
n't
care
to
know
,
and
<EOS>
what
it
is
I
can
see
for
myself
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
heir
-
apparent
to
the
Maypole
pressed
his
finger
on
his
lips
,
and
glancing
at
the
young
gentleman
already
noticed
,
who
had
changed
his
attitude
when
the
house
was
first
mentioned
,
replied
in
a
lower
tone
:
  
"
<EOS>
The
owner
's
name
is
Haredale
,
Mr
Geoffrey
Haredale
,
and
"
---
again
he
glanced
in
the
same
direction
as
before
---
"
and
a
worthy
gentleman
too
---
hem
!
"
  
<EOS>
Paying
as
little
regard
to
this
admonitory
cough
,
as
to
the
significant
gesture
that
had
preceded
it
,
the
stranger
pursued
his
questioning
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
turned
out
of
my
way
coming
here
,
and
took
the
footpath
that
crosses
the
grounds
.
 
<EOS>
Who
was
the
young
lady
that
I
saw
entering
a
carriage
?
 
<EOS>
His
daughter
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
should
I
know
,
honest
man
?
"
replied
Joe
,
contriving
in
the
course
of
some
arrangements
about
the
hearth
,
to
advance
close
to
his
questioner
and
pluck
him
by
the
sleeve
,
"
I
did
n't
see
the
young
lady
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
Whew
!
 
<EOS>
There
's
the
wind
again
---
AND
rain
---
 
<EOS>
well
it
IS
a
night
!
"
  
<EOS>
Rough
weather
indeed
!
"
observed
the
strange
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
used
to
it
?
"
said
Joe
,
catching
at
anything
which
seemed
to
promise
a
diversion
of
the
subject
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
,
"
returned
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
About
the
young
lady
---
has
Mr
Haredale
a
daughter
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
the
young
fellow
fretfully
,
"
he
's
a
single
gentleman
<EOS>
---
he
's
---
be
quiet
,
ca
n't
you
,
man
?
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
see
this
talk
is
not
relished
yonder
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Regardless
of
this
whispered
remonstrance
,
and
affecting
not
to
hear
it
,
his
tormentor
provokingly
continued
:
  
<EOS>
"
Single
men
have
had
daughters
before
now
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
she
may
be
his
daughter
,
though
he
is
not
married
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"
said
Joe
,
adding
in
an
undertone
as
he
approached
him
again
,
"
You
'll
come
in
for
it
presently
<EOS>
,
I
know
you
will
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
no
harm
"
---
returned
the
traveller
boldly
,
"
and
have
said
none
that
I
know
of
.
 
<EOS>
I
ask
a
few
questions
---
as
any
stranger
may
,
and
not
unnaturally
---
about
the
inmates
of
a
remarkable
house
in
a
neighbourhood
which
is
new
to
me
,
and
you
are
as
aghast
and
disturbed
as
if
I
were
talking
treason
against
King
George
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
can
tell
me
<EOS>
why
,
sir
,
for
(
as
I
say
)
I
am
a
stranger
,
and
this
is
Greek
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
latter
observation
was
addressed
to
the
obvious
cause
of
Joe
Willet
's
discomposure
,
who
had
risen
and
was
adjusting
his
riding
-
cloak
preparatory
to
sallying
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
Briefly
replying
that
he
could
give
him
no
information
,
the
young
man
beckoned
to
Joe
,
and
handing
him
a
piece
of
money
in
payment
of
his
reckoning
,
hurried
out
attended
by
young
Willet
himself
,
who
taking
up
a
candle
followed
to
light
him
to
the
house
-
door
.
  
<EOS>
While
Joe
was
absent
on
this
errand
,
the
elder
Willet
and
his
three
companions
continued
to
smoke
with
profound
gravity
,
and
in
a
deep
silence
,
each
having
his
eyes
fixed
on
a
huge
copper
boiler
that
was
suspended
over
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
After
some
time
John
Willet
slowly
shook
his
head
,
and
thereupon
his
friends
slowly
shook
theirs
;
but
no
man
withdrew
his
eyes
from
the
boiler
,
or
altered
the
solemn
expression
of
his
countenance
in
the
slightest
degree
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
Joe
returned
---
very
talkative
and
conciliatory
,
as
though
with
a
strong
presentiment
that
he
was
going
to
be
found
fault
with
.
  
<EOS>
"
Such
a
thing
as
love
is
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
drawing
a
chair
near
the
fire
,
and
looking
round
for
sympathy
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
set
off
to
walk
to
London
,
---
all
the
way
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
His
nag
gone
lame
in
riding
out
here
this
blessed
afternoon
,
and
comfortably
littered
down
in
our
stable
at
this
minute
;
and
he
giving
up
a
good
hot
supper
and
our
best
bed
,
because
Miss
Haredale
has
gone
to
a
masquerade
up
in
town
,
and
he
has
set
his
heart
upon
seeing
her
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
I
could
persuade
myself
to
do
that
,
beautiful
as
she
is
,
---
<EOS>
but
then
I
'm
not
in
love
(
at
least
I
do
n't
think
I
am
)
and
that
's
the
whole

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
in
love
then
?
"
said

stranger
.
  
<EOS>
"
Rather
,
"
replied
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
'll
never
be
more
in
love
,
and
may
very

be
less
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Silence
,
sir
!
"
cried
his
father
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
chap
you
are
,
Joe
!
"
said
Long
Parkes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Such
a
inconsiderate
lad
!
"
<EOS>
murmured
Tom
Cobb
.
  
<EOS>
"
Putting
himself
forward
and
wringing
the
very
nose
off
his
own
father
's
face
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
parish
-
clerk
,
metaphorically
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
HAVE
I
done
?
"
reasoned
poor
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
Silence
,
sir
!
"
returned
his
father
,
"
what
do
you
mean
by
talking
,
when
you
see

that
are
more
than
two
or
three
times
your
age
,
sitting

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
that
's

,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
proper

,

!
"

,
"
<EOS>
the
proper

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
to

!
"
<EOS>
muttered

,

other
two
who

,

that
that
was
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
proper

's

,

,
"

John
Willet
;
"
when
I
was
your
age
I
never

,

never

.
 
<EOS>
I
listened
and
improved

that
's
what
I
did
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
'd
find
your
father
rather
a
tough

,
Joe
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
For

o
'
<EOS>
that
,
Phil
!
"

,

,

;
"
For
the
matter
o
'
that
,
Phil
,
argeyment
is
a

Natur
.
 
<EOS>
If
Natur
has
gifted
a
man
with
powers
of
argeyment
,
a
man
has
a
right
to
make

'em
,

stand

,

;
for

Natur
,

,

,

's

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
landlord
pausing
here
for
a
very

,
Mr
Parkes
naturally
concluded
that
he
had

;

,

,

:
  
"
You

?
 
<EOS>
You

in
argeyment
<EOS>
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
IF
,
"

,

,

"
IF

Natur

,

<EOS>
Yes
,

,

AM

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
 
<EOS>
My

,

,

,
as
I

;

,
"

,

,
"
<EOS>
so

,
for
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
A

from

three

,
and

at

,
assured
John

that
they
had
had
good
experience
of
his

and
needed

to
assure

of
his
superiority
.
 
<EOS>
John
smoked
with
a
little
more

and
surveyed
them
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
very
fine
talking
,
"
muttered
Joe
,
who
had
been
fidgeting
in
his

with
divers
uneasy

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
if
you
mean
to
tell
me
that
I
'm
never

open

---
"
  
"
Silence
,

!
"
roared

father
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
you
never
are
.
 
<EOS>
When
your
opinion
's
wanted
,
you
give
it
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
're
spoke
to
,
you
speak
.
<EOS>
When
your
opinion
's
not
wanted
and
you
're
not
spoke
to
,
do
n't
you
give
an
opinion
and
do
n't
you
speak
.
 
<EOS>
The
world
's
undergone
a
nice
alteration
since
my
time
,

.
 
<EOS>
My
belief
is
that
there
an't
<EOS>
any
boys
left
---
that
there
is
n't
such
a
thing
as
a
boy
<EOS>
---
that

's

between

---
and
that

boys
went
out

his

Majesty
King
George
the
Second
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
very
true
observation
,
always
excepting
the
young
princes
,
"
said
the
parish
-
clerk
,
who
,
as
the
representative
of
church
and
state
in
that
company
,
held
himself
bound
to
the
nicest
loyalty
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
it
's
godly
and
righteous
for
boys
,
being
of
the
ages
of
boys
,
to
behave
themselves
like
boys
,
then
the
young
princes
must
be
boys
and
can
not
be
otherwise
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
ever
hear
tell
of
mermaids
,
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Willet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
I
have
,
"
replied
the
clerk
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"
said
Mr
Willet
.
 
<EOS>
"
According
to
the
constitution
of
mermaids
,
so
much
of
a
mermaid
as
is
not
a
woman
must
be
a
fish
.
<EOS>
According
to
the
constitution
of
young
princes
,
so
much
of
a
young
prince
(
if
anything
)
as
is
not
actually
an
angel
,
must
be
godly
and
righteous
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
if
it
's
becoming
and
godly
and
righteous
in
the
young
princes
(
as
it
is
at
their
ages
)
that
they
should
be
boys
,
they
are
and
must
be
boys
,
and
can
not
by
possibility
be
anything
else
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
elucidation
of
a
knotty
point
being
received
with
such
marks
of
approval
as
to
put
John
Willet
into
a
good
humour
,
he
contented
himself
with
repeating
to
his
son
his
command
of
silence
,
and
addressing
the
stranger
,
said
:
  
"
If
you
had
asked
your
questions
of
a
grown
-
up
person
---
of
me
or
any
of
these
gentlemen
---
you
'd
have
had
some
satisfaction
,
and
would
n't
have
wasted
breath
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Haredale
is
Mr
Geoffrey
Haredale
's
niece
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
her
father
alive
?
"
said
the
man
,
carelessly
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
rejoined
the
landlord
,
"
he
is
not
alive
,
and
he
is
not
dead
---
"
  
"
Not
dead
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
dead
in
a
common
sort
of
way
,
"
said
the
landlord
.
  
<EOS>
The
cronies
nodded
to
each
other
,
and
Mr
Parkes
remarked
in
an
undertone
,
shaking
his
head
meanwhile
as
who
should
say
,
"
let
no
man
contradict
me
,
for
I
wo
n't
believe

,
"
that
John
Willet
was
in
amazing
force
to
-
night
,
and
fit
to
tackle
a
Chief
Justice
.
  
<EOS>
The
stranger
suffered
a
short
pause
to
elapse
,
and
then
asked
abruptly
,
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
More
than
you
think
for
,
friend
,
"
returned
John
Willet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
there
's
more
meaning
in
them
words
than
you
suspect
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
there
is
,
"
said
the
strange
man
,
gruffly
;
"
but
what
the
devil
do
you
speak
in
such
mysteries
for
?
 
<EOS>
You
tell
me
,
first
,
that
a
man
is
not
alive
,
nor
yet
dead
---
then
,
that
he
's
not
dead
in
a
common

---
then
,

mean

.
 
<EOS>
To

,
you
may
do

;
for

I

,
you
mean
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
What
DO
you
mean
,
I
ask

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
,
"
returned
the
landlord
,
a
little
brought
down

the
stranger
's

,
"
is
a
Maypole
story
,
and
has
been
any
time
these
four
-

.
 
<EOS>
That
story
is
Solomon
Daisy
's
story
.
 
<EOS>
It
belongs
to
the
house
;
and
nobody
but
Solomon
Daisy
has
ever
told
it
under
this
roof
,
or
ever
shall
<EOS>
---
that
's
more
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
man
glanced
at
the
parish
-

,
whose
air
of
consciousness
and
importance
plainly
betokened
him
to
be
the
person
referred
to
,
and
,
observing
that
he
had
taken
his
pipe
from
his
lips
,
after
a
very
long
whiff
to
keep
it
alight
,
and
was
evidently
about
to
tell
his
story
without
further

,
gathered
his
large
coat
about
him
,
and
shrinking
further
back
was
almost
lost
in
the
gloom
of
the
spacious
chimney
-
corner
,
except
when
the
flame
,
struggling
from
under
a
great
faggot
,
whose
weight
almost
crushed
it
for
the
time
,
shot
upward
with
a
strong
and

,
and
illumining
his
figure
for
a

,
seemed
afterwards
to
cast
it
into
deeper

than
before
.
  
<EOS>
By
this
flickering
light
,
which
made
the
old
room
,
with
its
heavy

and
panelled

,
look
as
if

were
built
of
polished

---
the

and

without
,
now

the

and

of
the
stout
oaken

,
and

the

as

---
by
this

,
and

,
Solomon
Daisy
began
his

:
  
"
<EOS>
It
was
Mr
Reuben
Haredale
,
Mr
Geoffrey
's
elder
brother
---
"
  
Here

came
to
a

,
and
made
so
long

that
even
John
Willet
grew

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Cobb
,
"
said
Solomon
Daisy
,
dropping

and

the

;
"
what

the
month

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
The
nineteenth
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
March
,
"
said
the
clerk
,
bending

,
"
the
nineteenth
of
March
;
that
's
very
strange
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
a
low

they
all

,
and
Solomon
went
on
:
  
"
<EOS>
It
was
Mr
Reuben
Haredale
,
Mr
Geoffrey
's
elder
brother
,
that
twenty
-
two
years
ago
was
the
owner
of
the
Warren
,
which
,
as
Joe
has
said
---
not
that
you
remember
it
,
Joe
,
for
a
boy
like
you
ca
n't
do
that
,
but
because
you
have
often
heard
me
say
so
---
was
then
a
much
larger
and
better
place
,
and
a
much
more
valuable
property
than
it
is
now
.
 
<EOS>
His
lady
was
lately
dead
,
and
he
was
left
with
one

---
the
Miss
Haredale
you
have
been
inquiring
about
---
who
was
then
scarcely
a
year
old
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Although
the
speaker
addressed
himself
to
the
man
who
had
shown
so
much
curiosity
about
this
same
family
,
and
made
a
pause
here
as
if

,
the

made
no

,
nor

any

that

heard

was

in

.
 
<EOS>
Solomon
therefore
turned
to
his
old
companions
,
whose
noses
were
brightly
illuminated
by
the
deep
red
glow
from
the
bowls
of
their
pipes
;
assured
,
by
long
experience
,
of
their
attention
,
and
resolved
to
show
his
sense
of
such
indecent
behaviour
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Haredale
,
"
said
Solomon
,
turning
his
back
upon
the
strange
man
,
"
left
this
place
when
his
lady
died
,
feeling
it
lonely
like
,
and
went
up
to
London
,
where
he
stopped
some
months
;
but
finding
that
place
as
lonely
as
this
---
as
I
suppose
and
have
always
heard
say
---
he
suddenly
came
back
again
with
his
little
girl
to
the
Warren
,
bringing
with
him
besides
,
that
day
,
only
two
women
servants
,
and
his
steward
,
and
a
gardener
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Daisy
stopped
to
take
a
whiff
at
his
pipe
,
which
was
going
out
,
and
then
proceeded
---
at
first
in
a

,
occasioned
by
keen

of
the
tobacco
and
strong

,
and
afterwards
with
increasing

:
  
"
---
<EOS>
Bringing
with
him
two
women
servants
,
and
his
steward
,
and
a
gardener
.
 
<EOS>
The
rest
stopped
behind
up
in
London
,
and
were
to
follow
next
day
.
 
<EOS>
It
happened
that
that
night
,
an
old
gentleman
who
lived
at
Chigwell
Row
,
and
had
long
been
poorly
,
deceased
,
and
an
order
came
to
me
at
half
after

at
night
to
go
and
toll
the
passing
-
bell
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
movement
in
the
little
group
of
listeners
,
sufficiently
indicative
of
the
strong
repugnance
any
one
of
them
would
have
felt
to
have
turned
out
at
such

upon
such
an
errand
.
 
<EOS>
The
clerk
felt
and
understood
it
,
and
pursued
his
theme
accordingly
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
WAS
a
dreary
thing
,
especially
as
the
grave
-
digger
was
laid
up
in
his
bed
,
from
long
working
in
a
damp
soil
and
sitting
down
to
take
his
dinner
on
cold
tombstones
,
and
I
was
consequently
under
obligation
to
go
alone
,
for
it
was
too
late
to
hope
to
get
any
other

.
 
<EOS>
However
,
I
was
n't
unprepared
for
it
;
as
the
old

had
often

a
request
that
the
bell
should

soon

possible
after
the
breath
was
out
of
his

,
and
he
had
been
expected
to
go
for
some

.
 
<EOS>
I
put
as
good
a
face
upon
it
as
I
could
,
and

myself
up
(
for
it
was
mortal
cold
)
,
started
out
with
a
lighted
lantern
in

and
the
key
of
the
church
in

other
.
"
  
<EOS>
At
this

of

,
the
dress
of
the
strange
man
rustled
as
if
he
had
turned
himself
to
hear
more
distinctly
.
<EOS>
Slightly

over
his

,
Solomon
elevated

and
nodded
a
silent

to
Joe
whether
this
was
the
case
.
 
<EOS>
Joe
shaded
his
eyes
with
his
hand
and
peered
into
the
corner
,
but
could
make
out
nothing
,
and
so
shook
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
just
such
a
night
as
this
;
blowing
a
hurricane
,
raining
heavily
,
and
very
dark
---
I
often
think
now
,
darker
than
I
ever
saw
it
before
or
since
;
that
may
be
my
fancy
,
but
the
houses
were
all
close
shut
and
the
folks
in
doors
,
and
perhaps
there
is
only
one
other
man
who
knows
how
dark
it
really
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
got
into
the
church
,
chained
the
door
back
so
that
it
should
keep
ajar
---
for
,
to
tell
the
truth
<EOS>
,
I
did
n't
like
to
be
shut
in
there
alone
---
and
putting
my
lantern
on
the
stone
seat
in
the
little
corner
where
the
bell
-
rope
is
,
sat
down
beside
it
to
trim
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
sat
down
to
trim
the
candle
,
and
when
I
had
done
<EOS>
so
I
could
not
persuade
myself
to
get
up
again
,
and
go
about
my
work
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
it
was
,
but
<EOS>
I
thought
of
all
the
ghost
stories
I
had
ever
heard
,
even
those
that
I
had
heard
when
I
was
a
boy
at
school
,
and
had
forgotten
long
ago
;
and
they
did
n't
come
into
my
mind
one
after
another
,
but
all
crowding
at
once
,
like
.
 
<EOS>
I
recollected
one
story
there
was
in
the
village
,
how
that
on
a
certain
night
in
the
year
(
it
might
be
that
very
night
for
anything
I
knew
)
<EOS>
,
all
the
dead
people
came
out
of
the
ground
and
sat
at
the
heads
of
their
own
graves
till
morning
.
 
<EOS>
This
made
me
think
how
many
people
I
had
known
,
were
buried
between
the
church
-
door
and
the
churchyard
gate
,
and
what
a
dreadful
thing
it
would
be
to
have
to
pass
among
them
and
know
them
again
,
so
earthy
and
unlike
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
known
all
the
niches
and
arches
in
the
church
from
a
child
;
still
,
I
could
n't
persuade
myself
that
those
were
their
natural
shadows
which
I
saw
on
the
pavement
,
but
felt
sure
there
were
some
ugly
figures
hiding
among
'em
and
peeping
out
.
 
<EOS>
Thinking
on
in
this
way
,
I
began
to
think
of
the
old
gentleman
who
was
just
dead
,
and
I
could
have
sworn
,
as
I
looked
up
the
dark
chancel
,
that
I
saw
him
in
his
usual
place
,
wrapping
his
shroud
about
him
and
shivering
as
if
he
felt
it
cold
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
time
I
sat
listening
and
listening
,
and
hardly
dared
to
breathe
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
I
started
up
and
took
the
bell
-
rope
in
my
hands
.
 
<EOS>
At
that
minute
there
rang
---
not
that
bell
,
<EOS>
for
I
had
hardly
touched
the
rope
---
but
another
!
  
<EOS>
"
I
heard
the
ringing
of
another
bell
,
and
a
deep
bell
too
,
plainly
.
<EOS>
It
was
only
for
an
instant
,
and
even
then
the
wind
carried
the
sound
away
,
but
I
heard
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
listened
for
a
long
time
,
but
it
rang
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
heard
of
corpse
candles
,
and
at
last
I
persuaded
myself
that
this
must
be
a
corpse
bell
tolling
of
itself
at
midnight
for
the
dead
.
 
<EOS>
I
tolled
my
bell
---
<EOS>
how
,
or
how
long
,
I
do
n't
know
---
and
ran
home
to
bed
as
fast
as
I
could
touch
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
up
early
next
morning
after
a
restless
night
,
and
told
the
story
to
my
neighbours
.
 
<EOS>
Some
were
serious
and
some
made
light
of
it
;
I
do
n't
think
anybody
believed
it
real
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
that
morning
,
Mr
Reuben
Haredale
was
found
murdered
in
his
bedchamber
;
and
in
his
hand
was
a
piece
of
the
cord
attached
to
an
alarm
-
bell
outside
the
roof
,
which
hung
in
his
room
and
had
been
cut
asunder
,
no
doubt
by
the
murderer
,
when
he
seized
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
was
the
bell
I
heard
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
bureau
was
found
opened
,
and
a
cash
-
box
,
which
Mr
Haredale
had
brought
down
that
day
,
and
was
supposed
to
contain
a
large
sum
of
money
,
was
gone
.
 
<EOS>
The
steward
and
gardener
were
both
missing
and
both
suspected
for
a
long
time
,
but
they
were
never
found
,
though
hunted
far
and
wide
.
 
<EOS>
And
far
enough
they
might
have
looked
for
poor
Mr
Rudge
the
steward
,
whose
body
---
scarcely
to
be
recognised
by
his
clothes
and
the
watch
and
ring
he
wore
---
was
found
,
months
afterwards
,
at
the
bottom
of
a
piece
of
water
in
the
grounds
,
with
a
deep
gash
in
the
breast
where
he
had
been
stabbed
with
a
knife
.
<EOS>
He
was
only
partly
dressed
;
and
people
all
agreed
that
he
had
been
sitting
up
reading
in
his
own
room
,
where
there
were
many
traces
of
blood
,
and
was
suddenly
fallen
upon
and
killed
before
his
master
.
  
<EOS>
Everybody
now
knew
that
the
gardener
must
be
the
murderer
,
and
though
he
has
never
been
heard
of
from
that
day
to
this
,
he
will
be
,
mark
my
words
.
 
<EOS>
The
crime
was
committed
this
day
two
-
and
-
twenty
years
---
on
the
nineteenth
of
March
,
one
thousand
seven
hundred
and
fifty
-
three
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
nineteenth
of
March
in
some
year
---
no
matter
when
---
I
know
it
,
I
am
sure
of
it
,
for
we
have
always
,
in
some
strange
way
or
other
,
been
brought
back
to
the
subject
on
that
day
ever
since
---
on
the
nineteenth
of
March
in
some
year
,
sooner
or
later
,
that
man
will
be
discovered
.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
02
    
"
A
strange
story
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
man
who
had
been
the
cause
of
the
narration
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
"
Stranger
still
if
it
comes
about
as
you
predict
.
 
<EOS>
Is
that
all
?
"
  
<EOS>
A
question
so
unexpected
,
nettled
Solomon
Daisy
not
a
little
.
 
<EOS>
By
dint
of
relating
the
story
very
often
,
and
ornamenting
it
(
according
to
village
report
)
with
a
few
flourishes
suggested
by
the
various
hearers
from
time
to
time
,
he
had
come
by
degrees
to
tell
it
with
great
effect
;
and
"
Is
that
all
?
"
<EOS>
after
the
climax
,
was
not
what
he
was
accustomed
to
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
?
"
<EOS>
he
repeated
,
"
yes
,
that
's
all
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
And
enough
too
<EOS>
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
so
too
.
 
<EOS>
My
horse
,
young
man
!
 
<EOS>
He
is
but
a
hack
hired
from
a
roadside
posting
house
,
but
he
must
carry
me
to
London
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
-
night
!
"
said
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
-
night
,
"
returned
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
stare
at
?
 
<EOS>
This
tavern
would
seem
to
be
a
house
of
call
for
all
the
gaping
idlers
of
the
neighbourhood
!
"
  
<EOS>
At
this
remark
,
which
evidently
had
reference
to
the
scrutiny
he
had
undergone
,
as
mentioned
in
the
foregoing
chapter
,
the
eyes
of
John
Willet
and
his
friends
were
diverted
with
marvellous
rapidity
to
the
copper
boiler
again
.
 
<EOS>
Not
so
with
Joe
,
who
,
being
a
mettlesome
fellow
,
returned
the
stranger
's
angry
glance
with
a
steady
look
,
and
rejoined
:
  
"
It
is
not
a
very
bold
thing
to
wonder
at
your
going
on
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
Surely
you
have
been
asked
such
a
harmless
question
in
an
inn
before
,
and
in
better
weather
than
this
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
you
might
n't
know
the
way
,
as
you
seem
strange
to
this
part
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
way
---
"
repeated
the
other
,
irritably
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
DO
<EOS>
you
know
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
---
humph
!
<EOS>
---
I
'll
find
it
,
"
replied
the
nian
,
waving
his
hand
and
turning
on
his
heel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Landlord
,
take
the
reckoning
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
John
Willet
did
as
he
was
desired
;
for
on
that
point
he
was
seldom
slow
,
except
in
the
particulars
of
giving
change
,
and
testing
the
goodness
of
any
piece
of
coin
that
was
proffered
to
him
,
by
the
application
of
his
teeth
or
his
tongue
,
or
some
other
test
,
or
in
doubtful
cases
,
by
a
long
series
of
tests
terminating
in
its
rejection
.
 
<EOS>
The
guest
then
wrapped
his
garments
about
him
so
as
to
shelter
himself
as
effectually
as
he
could
from
the
rough
weather
,
and
without
any
word
or
sign
of
farewell
betook
himself
to
the
stableyard
.
 
<EOS>
Here
Joe
(
who
had
left
the
room
on
the
conclusion
of
their
short
dialogue
)
was
protecting
himself
and
the
horse
from
the
rain
under
the
shelter
of
an
old
penthouse
roof
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
pretty
much
of
my
opinion
,
"
said
Joe
,
patting
the
horse
upon
the
neck
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
wager
that
your
stopping
here
to
-
night
would
please
him
better
than
it
would
please
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
and
I
are
of
different
opinions
,
as
we
have
been
more
than
once
on
our
way
here
,
"
was
the
short
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
was
thinking
before
you
came
out
,
for
he
has
felt
your
spurs
,
poor
beast
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
stranger
adjusted
his
coat
-
collar
about
his
face
,
and
made
no
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
'll
know
me
again
,
I
see
,
"
he
said
,
marking
the
young
fellow
's
earnest
gaze
,
when
he
had
sprung
into
the
saddle
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
man
's
worth
knowing
,
master
,
who
travels
a
road
he
do
n't
know
,
mounted
on
a
jaded
horse
,
and
leaves
good
quarters
to
do
it
on
such
a
night
as
this
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
sharp
eyes
and
a
sharp
tongue
,
I
find
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Both
I
hope
by
nature
,
but
the
last
grows
rusty
sometimes
for
want
of
using
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Use
the
first
less
too
,
and
keep
their
sharpness
for
your
sweethearts
,
boy
,
"
said
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
So
saying
he
shook
his
hand
from
the
bridle
,
struck
him
roughly
on
the
head
with
the
butt
end
of
his
whip
,
and
galloped
away
;
dashing
through
the
mud
and
darkness
with
a
headlong
speed
,
which
few
badly
mounted
horsemen
would
have
cared
to
venture
,
even
had
they
been
thoroughly
acquainted
with
the
country
;
and
which
,
to
one
who
knew
nothing
of
the
way
he
rode
,
was
attended
at
every
step
with
great
hazard
and
danger
.
  
<EOS>
The
roads
,
even
within
twelve
miles
of
London
,
were
at
that
time
ill
paved
,
seldom
repaired
,
and
very
badly
made
.
 
<EOS>
The
way
this
rider
traversed
had
been
ploughed
up
by
the
wheels
of
heavy
waggons
,
and
rendered
rotten
by
the
frosts
and
thaws
of
the
preceding
winter
,
or
possibly
of
many
winters
.
 
<EOS>
Great
holes
and
gaps
had
been
worn
into
the
soil
,
which
,
being
now
filled
with
water
from
the
late
rains
,
were
not
easily
distinguishable
even
by
day
;
and
a
plunge
into
any
one
of
them
might
have
brought
down
a
surer
-
footed
horse
than
the
poor
beast
now
urged
forward
to
the
utmost
extent
of
his
powers
.
 
<EOS>
Sharp
flints
and
stones
rolled
from
under
his
hoofs
continually
;
the
rider
could
scarcely
see
beyond
the
animal
's
head
,
or
farther
on
either
side
than
his
own
arm
would
have
extended
.
 
<EOS>
At
that
time
,
too
,
all
the
roads
in
the
neighbourhood
of
the
metropolis
were
infested
by
footpads
or
highwaymen
,
and
it
was
a
night
,
of
all
others
,
in
which
any
evil
-
disposed
person
of
this
class
might
have
pursued
his
unlawful
calling
with
little
fear
of
detection
.
  
<EOS>
Still
,
the
traveller
dashed
forward
at
the
same
reckless
pace
,
regardless
alike
of
the
dirt
and
wet
which
flew
about
his
head
,
the
profound
darkness
of
the
night
,
and
the
probability
of
encountering
some
desperate
characters
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
At
every
turn
and
angle
,
even
where
a
deviation
from
the
direct
course
might
have
been
least
expected
,
and
could
not
possibly
be
seen
until
he
was
close
upon
it
<EOS>
,
he
guided
the
bridle
with
an
unerring
hand
,
and
kept
the
middle
of
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
he
sped
onward
,
raising
himself
in
the
stirrups
,
leaning
his
body
forward
until
it
almost
touched
the
horse
's
neck
,
and
flourishing
his
heavy
whip
above
his
head
with
the
fervour
of
a
madman
.
  
<EOS>
There
are
times
when
,
the
elements
being
in
unusual
commotion
,
those
who
are
bent
on
daring
enterprises
,
or
agitated
by
great
thoughts
,
whether
of
good
or
evil
,
feel
a
mysterious
sympathy
with
the
tumult
of
nature
,
and
are
roused
into
corresponding
violence
.
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
thunder
,
lightning
,
and
storm
,
many
tremendous
deeds
have
been
committed
;
men
,
self
-
possessed
before
,
have
given
a
sudden
loose
to
passions
they
could
no
longer
control
.
 
<EOS>
The
demons
of
wrath
and
despair
have
striven
to
emulate
those
who
ride
the
whirlwind
and
direct
the
storm
;
and
man
,
lashed
into
madness
with
the
roaring
winds
and
boiling
waters
,
has
become
for
the
time
as
wild
and
merciless
as
the
elements
themselves
.
  
<EOS>
Whether
the
traveller
was
possessed
by
thoughts
which
the
fury
of
the
night
had
heated
and
stimulated
into
a
quicker
current
,
or
was
merely
impelled
by
some
strong
motive
to
reach
his
journey
's
end
,
on
he
swept
more
like
a
hunted
phantom
than
a
man
,
nor
checked
his
pace
until
,
arriving
at
some
cross
roads
,
one
of
which
led
by
a
longer
route
to
the
place
<EOS>
whence
he
had
lately
started
,
he
bore
down
so
suddenly
upon
a
vehicle
which
was
coming
towards
him
,
that
in
the
effort
to
avoid
it
<EOS>
he
well
-
nigh
pulled
his
horse
upon
his
haunches
,
and
narrowly
escaped
being
thrown
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yoho
!
"
cried
the
voice
of
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
?
 
<EOS>
Who
goes
there
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
friend
!
"
replied
the
traveller
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
friend
!
"
repeated
the
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
calls
himself
a
friend
and
rides
like
that
,
abusing
Heaven
's
gifts
in
the
shape
of
horseflesh
,
and
endangering
,
not
only
his
own
neck
(
which
might
be
no
great

)
<EOS>
but
the
necks
of
other
people
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
lantern
there
,
I
see
,
"
said
the
traveller
dismounting
,
"
lend
it
me
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
wounded
my
horse
,
I
think
,
with
your
shaft
or
wheel
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wounded
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
other
,
"
<EOS>
if
I
have
n't
killed
him
,
it
's
no
fault
of
yours
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
by
galloping
along
the
king
's
highway
like
that
,
eh
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Give
me
the
light
,
"
returned
the
traveller
,
snatching
it
from
his
hand
,
"
and
do
n't
ask
idle
questions
of
a
man
who
is
in
no
mood
for
talking
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
said
you
were
in
no
mood
for
talking
before
,
I
should
perhaps
have
been
in
no
mood
for
lighting
,
"
said
the
voice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Hows'ever
<EOS>
as
it
's
the
poor
horse
that
's
damaged
and
not
you
,
one
of
you
is
welcome
to
the
light
at
all
events
---
but
it
's
not
the
crusty
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
traveller
returned
no
answer
to
this
speech
,
but
holding
the
light
near
to
his
panting
and
reeking
beast
,
examined
him
in
limb
and
carcass
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
the
other
man
sat
very
composedly
in
his
vehicle
,
which
was
a
kind
of
chaise
with
a
depository
for
a
large
bag
of
tools
,
and
watched
his
proceedings
with
a
careful
eye
.
  
<EOS>
The
looker
-
on
was
a
round
,
red
-
faced
,
sturdy
yeoman
,
with
a
double
chin
,
and
a
voice
husky
with
good
living
,
good
sleeping
,
good
humour
,
and
good
health
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
past
the
prime
of
life
,
but
Father
Time
is
not
always
a
hard
parent
,
and
,
though
he
tarries
for
none
of
his
children
,
often
lays
his
hand
lightly
upon
those
who
have
used
him
well
;
making
them
old
men
and
women
inexorably
enough
,
but
leaving
their
hearts
and
spirits
young
and
in
full
vigour
.
 
<EOS>
With
such
people
the
grey
head
is
but
the
impression
of
the
old
fellow
's
hand
in
giving
them
his
blessing
,
and
every
wrinkle
but
a
notch
in
the
quiet
calendar
of
a
well
-
spent
life
.
  
<EOS>
The
person
whom
the
traveller
had
so
abruptly
encountered
was
of
this
kind
:
bluff
,
hale
,
hearty
,
and
in
a
green
old
age
:
at
peace
with
himself
,
and
evidently
disposed
to
be
so
with
all
the
world
.
<EOS>
Although
muffled
up
in
divers
coats
and
handkerchiefs
---
one
of
which
,
passed
over
his
crown
,
and
tied
in
a
convenient
crease
of
his
double
chin
,
secured
his
three
-
cornered
hat
and
bob
-
wig
from
blowing
off
his
head
<EOS>
---
there
was
no
disguising
his
plump
and
comfortable
figure
;
neither
did
certain
dirty
finger
-
marks
upon
his
face
give
it
any
other
than
an
odd
and
comical
expression
,
through
which
its
natural
good
humour
shone
with
undiminished
lustre
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
not
hurt
,
"
said
the
traveller
at
length
,
raising
his
head
and
the
lantern
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
found
that
out
at
last
,
have
you
?
"
rejoined
the
old
man
.
<EOS>
"
My
eyes
have
seen
more
light
than
yours
,
but
I
would
n't
change
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mean
!
 
<EOS>
I
could
have
told
you
he
was
n't
hurt
,
five
minutes
ago
.
<EOS>
Give
me
the
light
,
friend
;
ride
forward
at
a
gentler
pace
;
and
good
night
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
handing
up
the
lantern
,
the
man
necessarily
cast
its
rays
full
on
the
speaker
's
face
.
 
<EOS>
Their
eyes
met
at
the
instant
.
 
<EOS>
He
suddenly
dropped
it
and
crushed
it
with
his
foot
.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
never
see
a
locksmith
before
,
that
you
start
as
if
you
had
come
upon
a
ghost
?
"
cried
the
old
man
in
the
chaise
,
"
or
is
this
,
"
he
added
hastily
,
thrusting
his
hand
into
the
tool
basket
and
drawing
out
a
hammer
,
"
a
scheme
for
robbing
me
?
 
<EOS>
I
know
these
roads
,
friend
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
travel
them
,
I
carry
nothing
but
a
few
shillings
,
and
not
a
crown
's
worth
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
plainly
,
to
save
us
both
trouble
,
that
there
's
nothing
to
be
got
from
me
but
a
pretty
stout
arm
considering
my
years
,
and
this
tool
,
which
,
mayhap
from
long
acquaintance
with
,
I
can
use
pretty
briskly
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
not
have
it
all
your
own
way
<EOS>
,
I
promise
you
,
if
you
play
at
that
game
.
 
<EOS>
With
these
words
he
stood
upon
the
defensive
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
what
you
take
me
for
,
Gabriel
Varden
,
"
replied
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
what
and
who
are
you
?
"
returned
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
my
name
,
it
seems
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
know
yours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
gained
the
information
from
any
confidence
of
yours
,
but
from
the
inscription
on
your
cart
which
tells
it
to
all
the
town
,
"
replied
the
traveller
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
better
eyes
for
that
than
you
had
for
your
horse
,
then
,
"
said
Varden
,
descending
nimbly
from
his
chaise
;
"
who
are
you
?
 
<EOS>
Let
me
see
your
face
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
While
the
locksmith
alighted
,
the
traveller
had
regained
his
saddle
,
from
which
he
now
confronted
the
old
man
,
who
,
moving
as
the
horse
moved
in
chafing
under
the
tightened
rein
,
kept
close
beside
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
your
face
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Stand
off
!
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
masquerading
tricks
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
"
and
tales
at
the
club
to
-
morrow
,
how
Gabriel
Varden
was
frightened
by
a
surly
voice
and
a
dark
night
.
 
<EOS>
Stand
<EOS>
---
let
me
see
your
face
.
"
  
<EOS>
Finding
that
further
resistance
would
only
involve
him
in
a
personal
struggle
with
an
antagonist
by
no
means
to
be
despised
,
the
traveller
threw
back
his
coat
,
and
stooping
down
looked
steadily
at
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
Perhaps
two
men
more
powerfully
contrasted
,
never
opposed
each
other
face
to
face
.
 
<EOS>
The
ruddy
features
of
the
locksmith
so
set
off
and
heightened
the
excessive
paleness
of
the
man
on
horseback
,
that
he
looked
like
a
bloodless
ghost
,
while
the
moisture
,
which
hard
riding
had
brought
out
upon
his
skin
,
hung
there
in
dark
and
heavy
drops
,
like
dews
of
agony
and
death
.
 
<EOS>
The
countenance
of
the
old
locksmith
lighted
up
with
the
smile
of
one
expecting
to
detect
in
this
unpromising
stranger
some
latent
roguery
of
eye
or
lip
,
which
should
reveal
a
familiar
person
in
that
arch
disguise
,
and
spoil
his
jest
.
 
<EOS>
The
face
of
the
other
,
sullen
and
fierce
,
but
shrinking
too
,
was
that
of
a
man
who
stood
at
bay
;
while
his
firmly
closed
jaws
,
his
puckered
mouth
,
and
more
than
all
a
certain
stealthy
motion
of
the
hand
within
his
breast
,
seemed
to
announce
a
desperate
purpose
very
foreign
to
acting
,
or
child
's
play
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
they
regarded
each
other
for
some
time
,
in
silence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
when
he
had
scanned
his
features
;
"
I
do
n't
know
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
desire
to
?
"
<EOS>
---
returned
the
other
,
muffling
himself
as
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
,
"
said
Gabriel
;
"
to
be
plain
with
you
,
friend
,
you
do
n't
carry
in
your
countenance
a
letter
of
recommendation
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
my
wish
,
"
said
the
traveller
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
humour
is
to
be
avoided
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
the
locksmith
bluntly
,
"
I
think
you
'll
have
your
humour
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
at
any
cost
,
"
rejoined
the
traveller
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
proof
of
it
,
lay
this
to
heart
---
that
you
were
never
in
such
peril
of
your

as
you
have

within
these
few

;
when
you
are
within
five

of
breathing
your
last
,
you
will
not
be
nearer
death
than
you
have
been
to
-
night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
"
said
the
sturdy
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
<EOS>
and
a
violent
death
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
From
whose
hand
?
"
  
"
From
mine
,
"
replied
the
traveller
.
  
<EOS>
With
that
he
put
spurs
to
his
horse
,
and
rode
away
;
at
first
plashing
heavily
through
the
mire
at
a
smart
trot
,
but
gradually
increasing
in
speed
until
the
last
sound
of
his
horse
's
hoofs
died
away
upon
the
wind
;
when
he
was
again
hurrying
on
at
the
same
furious
gallop
,
which
had
been
his
pace
when
the
locksmith
first
encountered
him
.
  
<EOS>
Gabriel
Varden
remained
standing
in
the
road
with
the
broken
lantern
in
his
hand
,
listening
in
stupefied
silence
until
no
sound
reached
his
ear
but
<EOS>
the
moaning
of
the
wind
,
and
the
fast
-
falling
rain
;
when
he
struck
himself
one
or
two
smart
blows
in
the
breast
by
way
of
rousing
himself
,
and
broke
into
an
exclamation
of
surprise
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
in
the
name
of
wonder
can
this
fellow
be
!
<EOS>
a
madman
?
<EOS>
a
highwayman
?
<EOS>
a
cut
-
throat
?
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
not
scoured
off
so
fast
,
we
'd
have
seen
who
was
in
most
danger
,
he
or
I.
 
I
never
nearer
death
than
I
have
been
to
-
night
!
 
<EOS>
I
hope
I
may
be
no
nearer
to
it
for
a
score
of
years
to
come
---
<EOS>
if
so
,
I
'll
be
content
to
be
no
farther
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
My
stars
!
<EOS>
---
a
pretty
brag
this
to
a
stout
man
---
pooh
,
pooh
!
"
  
<EOS>
Gabriel
resumed
his
seat
,
and
looked
wistfully
up
the
road
by
which
the
traveller
had
come
;
murmuring
in
a
half

:
  
"
The
Maypole
---
two
miles
to
the
Maypole
.
 
<EOS>
I
came
the
other
road
from
the
Warren
after
a
long
day
's
work
at
locks
and
bells
,
on
purpose
that
I
should
not
come
by
the
Maypole
and
break
my
promise
to
Martha
by
looking
in
<EOS>
---
there
's
resolution
!
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
dangerous
to
go
on
to
London
without
a
light
;
and
it
's
four
miles
,
and
a
good
half
mile
besides
,
to
the
Halfway
-
House
;
and
between
this
<EOS>
and
that
is
the
very
place
where
one
needs
a
light
most
.
 
<EOS>
Two
miles
to
the
Maypole
!
 
<EOS>
I
told
Martha
I
would
n't
;
I
said
I
would
n't
,
and
I
did
n't
<EOS>
---
there
's
resolution
!
"
  
<EOS>
Repeating
these
two
last
words
very
often
,
as
if
to
compensate
for
the
little
resolution
he
was
going
to
show
by
piquing
