on
the
great
resolution
he
had
shown
,
Gabriel
Varden
quietly
turned
back
,
determining
to
get
a
light
at
the
Maypole
,
and
to
take
nothing
but
a
light
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
got
to
the
Maypole
,
however
,
and
Joe
,
responding
to
his
well
-
known
hail
,
came
running
out
to
the
horse
's
head
,
leaving
the
door
open
behind
him
,
and
disclosing
a
delicious
perspective
of
warmth
and
brightness
---
when
the
ruddy
gleam
of
the
fire
,
streaming
through
the
old
red
curtains
of
the
common
room
,
seemed
to
bring
with
it
,
as
part
of
itself
,
a
pleasant
hum
of
voices
,
and
a
fragrant
odour
of
steaming
grog
and
rare
tobacco
,
all
steeped
as
it
were
in
the
cheerful
glow
---
when
the
shadows
,
flitting
across
the
curtain
,
showed
that
those
inside
had
risen
from
their
snug
seats
,
and
were
making
room
in
the
snuggest
corner
(
how
well
he
knew
that
corner
!
)
<EOS>
for
the
honest
locksmith
,
and
a
broad
glare
,
suddenly
streaming
up
,
bespoke
the
goodness
of
the
crackling
log
from
which
a
brilliant
train
of
sparks
was
doubtless
at
that
moment
whirling
up
the
chimney
in
honour
of
his
coming
---
when
,
superadded
to
these
enticements
,
there
stole
upon
him
from
the
distant
kitchen
a
gentle
sound
of
frying
,
with
a
musical
clatter
of
plates
and
dishes
,
and
a
savoury
smell
that
made
even
the
boisterous
wind
<EOS>
a
perfume
<EOS>
---
Gabriel
felt
his
firmness
oozing
rapidly
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
tried
to
look
stoically
at
the
tavern
,
but
his
features
would
relax
into
a
look
of
fondness
.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
his
head
the
other
way
,
and
the
cold
black
country
seemed
to
frown
him
off
,
and
drive
him
for
a
refuge
into
its
hospitable
arms
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
merciful
man
,
Joe
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
"
is
merciful
to
his
beast
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
get
out
for
a
little
while
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
how
natural
it
was
to
get
out
!
 
<EOS>
And
how
unnatural
it
seemed
for
a
sober
man
to
be
plodding
wearily
along
through
miry
roads
,
encountering
the
rude
buffets
of
the
wind
and
pelting
of
the
rain
,
when
there
was
a
clean
floor
covered
with
crisp
white
sand
,
a
well
swept
hearth
,
a
blazing
fire
,
a
table
decorated
with
white
cloth
,
bright
pewter
flagons
,
and
other
tempting
preparations
for
a
well
-
cooked
meal
---
when
there
were
these
things
,
and
company
disposed
to
make
the
most
of
them
,
all
ready
to
his
hand
,
and
entreating
him
to
enjoyment
!
    
<EOS>
Chapter
03
    
<EOS>
Such
were
the
locksmith
's
thoughts
when
first
seated
in
the
snug
corner
,
and
slowly
recovering
from
a
pleasant
defect
of
vision
---
 
<EOS>
pleasant
,
because
occasioned
by
the
wind
blowing
in
his
eyes
---
which
made
it
a
matter
of
sound
policy
and
duty
to
himself
,
that
he
should
take
refuge
from
the
weather
,
and
tempted
him
,
for
the
same
reason
,
to
aggravate
a
slight
cough
,
and
declare
he
felt
but
poorly
.
 
<EOS>
Such
were
still
his
thoughts
more
than
a
full
hour
afterwards
,
when
,
supper
over
,
he
still
sat
with
shining
jovial
face
in
the
same
warm
nook
,
listening
to
the
cricket
-
like
chirrup
of
little
Solomon
Daisy
,
and
bearing
no
unimportant
or
slightly
respected
part
in
the
social
gossip
round
the
Maypole
fire
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
he
may
be
an
honest
man
,
that
's
all
,
"
said
Solomon
,
winding
up
a
variety
of
speculations
relative
to
the
stranger
,
concerning
whom
Gabriel
had
compared
notes
with
the
company
,
and
so
raised
a
grave
discussion
;
"
I
wish
he
may
be
an
honest
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
we
all
do
,
I
suppose
,
do
n't
we
?
"
observed
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
,
"
said
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
cried
Gabriel
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
He
struck
me
with
his
whip
,
the
coward
,
when
he
was
mounted
and
I
afoot
,
and
I
should
be
better
pleased
that
he
turned
out
what
I
think
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
may
that
be
,
Joe
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
good
,
Mr
Varden
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
shake
your
head
,
father
,
but
I
say
no
good
,
and
will
say
no
good
,
and
<EOS>
I
would
say
no
good
a
hundred
times
over
,
if
that
would
bring
him
back
to
have
the
drubbing
he
deserves
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
tongue
,
sir
,
"
said
John
Willet
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
,
father
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
along
of
you
that
he
ventured
to
do
what
he
did
.
 
<EOS>
Seeing
me
treated
like
a
child
,
and
put
down
like
a
fool
,
HE
plucks
up
a
heart
and
has
a
fling
at
a
fellow
that
he
thinks
---
and
may
well
think
too
---
has
n't
a
grain
of
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
's
mistaken
,
as
I
'll
show
him
,
and
as
I
'll
show
all
of
you
before
long
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Does
the
boy
know
what
he
's
a
saying
of
!
"
cried
the
astonished
John
Willet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Father
,
"
returned
Joe
,
"
I
know
what
I
say
and
mean
,
<EOS>
well
---
better
than
you
do
when
you
hear
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
bear
with
you
,
but
I
can
not
bear
the
contempt
that
your
treating
me
in
the
way
you
do
,
brings
upon
me
from
others
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
other
young
men
of
my
age
.
<EOS>
Have
they
no
liberty
,
no
will
,
no
right
to
speak
?
 
<EOS>
Are
they
obliged
to
sit
mumchance
,
and
to
be
ordered
about
till
they
are
the
laughing
-
stock
of
young
and
old
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
bye
-
word
all
over
Chigwell
,
and
I
say
---
<EOS>
and
it
's
fairer
my
saying
<EOS>
so
now
,
than
waiting
till
you
are
dead
,
<EOS>
and
I
have
got
your
money
---
I
say
,
that
before
long
I
shall
be
driven
to
break
such
bounds
,
and
that
when
I
do
,
it
wo
n't
be
me
that
you
'll
have
to
blame
,
but
your
own
self
,
and
no
other
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
John
Willet
was
so
amazed
by
the
exasperation
and
boldness
of
his
hopeful
son
,
that
he
sat
as
one
bewildered
,
staring
in
a
ludicrous
manner
at
the
boiler
,
and
endeavouring
,
but
quite
ineffectually
,
to
collect
his
tardy
thoughts
,
and
invent
an
answer
.
 
<EOS>
The
guests
,
scarcely
less
disturbed
,
were
equally
at
a
loss
;
and
at
length
,
with
a
variety
of
muttered
,
half
-
expressed
condolences
,
and
pieces
of
advice
,
rose
to
depart
;
being
at
the
same
time
slightly
muddled
with
liquor
.
  
<EOS>
The
honest
locksmith
alone
addressed
a
few
words
of
coherent
and
sensible
advice
to
both
parties
,
urging
John
Willet
to
remember
that
Joe
was
nearly
arrived
at
man
's
estate
,
and
should
not
be
ruled
with
too
tight
a
hand
,
and
exhorting
Joe
himself
to
bear
with
his
father
's
caprices
,
and
rather
endeavour
to
turn
them
aside
by
temperate
remonstrance
than
by
ill
-
timed
rebellion
.
 
<EOS>
This
advice
was
received
as
such
advice
usually
is
.
 
<EOS>
On
John
Willet
it
made
almost
as
much
impression
as
on
the
sign
outside
the
door
,
while
Joe
,
who
took
it
in
the
best
part
,
avowed
himself
more
obliged
than
he
could
well
express
,
but
politely
intimated
his
intention
nevertheless
of
taking
his
own
course
uninfluenced
by
anybody
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
always
been
a
very
good
friend
to
me
,
Mr
Varden
<EOS>
,
"
he
said
,
as
they
stood
without
,
in
the
porch
,
and
the
locksmith
was
equipping
himself
for
his
journey
home
;
"
I
take
it
very
kind
of
you
to
say
all
this
,
but
the
time
's
nearly
come
when
the
Maypole
and
I
must
part
company
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Roving
stones
gather
no
moss
,
Joe
,
"
said
Gabriel
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
milestones
much
,
"
replied
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
little
better
than
one
here
,
and
see
as
much
of
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
what
would
you
do
,
Joe
?
<EOS>
"
pursued
the
locksmith
,
stroking
his
chin
reflectively
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
could
you
be
?
 
<EOS>
Where
could
you
go
,
you
see
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
trust
to
chance
,
Mr
Varden
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
A
bad
thing
to
trust
to
,
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
always
tell
my
girl
when
we
talk
about
a
husband
for
her
,
never
to
trust
to
chance
,
but
to
make
sure
beforehand
that
she
has
a
good
man
and
true
,
and
then
chance
will
neither
make
her
nor
break
her
.
 
<EOS>
What
are
you
fidgeting
about
there
,
Joe
?
 
<EOS>
Nothing
gone
in
the
harness
,
I
hope
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
no
,
"
said
Joe
---
finding
,
however
,
something
very
engrossing
to
do
in
the
way
of
strapping
and
buckling
---
"
Miss
Dolly
quite
well
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hearty
,
thankye
.
 
<EOS>
She
looks
pretty
enough
to
be
well
,
and
good
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
's
always
both
,
sir
"
---
   
<EOS>
"
So
she
is
,
thank
God
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
"
said
Joe
after
some
hesitation
,
"
that
you
wo
n't
tell
this
story
against
me
---
this
of
my
having
been
beat
like
the
boy
they
'd
make
of
me
---
at
all
events
,
till
I
have
met
this
man
again
and
settled
the
account
.
 
<EOS>
It
'll
be
a
better
story
then
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
who
should
I
tell
it
to
?
"
returned
Gabriel
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
know
it
here
,
and
I
'm
not
likely
to
come
across
anybody
else
who
would
care
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
true
enough
,
"
said
the
young
fellow
with
a
sigh
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
quite
forgot
that
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
that
's
true
!
"
  
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
raised
his
face
,
which
was
very
red
,
---
no
doubt
from
the
exertion
of
strapping
and
buckling
as
aforesaid
,
---
and
giving
the
reins
to
the
old
man
,
who
had
by
this
time
taken
his
seat
,
sighed
again
and
bade
him
good
night
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
"
cried
Gabriel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
think
better
of
what
we
have
just
been
speaking
of
;
and
do
n't
be
rash
,
there
's
a
good
fellow
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
an
interest
in
you
,
and
would
n't
have
you
cast
yourself
away
.
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Returning
his
cheery
farewell
with
cordial
goodwill
,
Joe
Willet
lingered
until
the
sound
of
wheels
ceased
to
vibrate
in
his
ears
,
and
then
,
shaking
his
head
mournfully
,
re
-
entered
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
Gabriel
Varden
went
his
way
towards
London
,
thinking
of
a
great
many
things
,
and
most
of
all
of
flaming
terms
in
which
to
relate
his
adventure
,
and
so
account
satisfactorily
to
Mrs
Varden
for
visiting
the
Maypole
,
despite
certain
solemn
covenants
between
himself
and
that
lady
.
 
<EOS>
Thinking
begets
,
not
only
thought
,
but
drowsiness
occasionally
,
and
the
more
the
locksmith
thought
,
the
more
sleepy
he
became
.
  
<EOS>
A
man
may
be
very
sober
---
or
at
least
firmly
set
upon
his
legs
on
that
neutral
ground
which
lies
between
the
confines
of
perfect
sobriety
and
slight
tipsiness
---
and
yet
feel
a
strong
tendency
to
mingle
up
present
circumstances
with
others
which
have
no
manner
of
connection
with
them
;
to
confound
all
consideration
of
persons
,
things
,
times
,
and
places
;
and
to
jumble
his
disjointed
thoughts
together
in
a
kind
of
mental
kaleidoscope
,
producing
combinations
as
unexpected
as
they
are
transitory
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
Gabriel
Varden
's
state
,
as
,
nodding
in
his
dog
sleep
,
and
leaving
his
horse
to
pursue
a
road
with
which
he
was
well
acquainted
,
he
got
over
the
ground
unconsciously
,
and
drew
nearer
and
nearer
home
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
roused
himself
once
,
when
the
horse
stopped
until
the
turnpike
gate
was
opened
,
and
had
cried
a
lusty
"
good
night
!
"
<EOS>
to
the
toll
-
keeper
;
but
then
he
awoke
out
of
a
dream
about
picking
a
lock
in
the
stomach
of
the
Great
Mogul
,
and
even
when
he
did
wake
,
mixed
up
the
turnpike
man
with
his
mother
-
in
-
law
who
had
been
dead
twenty
years
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
surprising
,
therefore
,
that
he
soon
relapsed
,
and
jogged
heavily
along
,
quite
insensible
to
his
progress
.
  
<EOS>
And
,
now
,
he
approached
the
great
city
,
which
lay
outstretched
before
him
like
a
dark
shadow
on
the
ground
,
reddening
the
sluggish
air
with
a
deep
dull
light
,
<EOS>
that
told
of
labyrinths
of
public
ways
and
shops
,
and
swarms
of
busy
people
.
 
<EOS>
Approaching
nearer
and
nearer
yet
,
this
halo
began
to
fade
,
and
the
causes
which
produced
it
slowly
to
develop
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
Long
lines
of
poorly
lighted
streets
might
be
faintly
traced
,
with
here
and
there
a
lighter
spot
,
where
lamps
were
clustered
round
a
square
or
market
,
or
round
some
great
building
;
after
a
time
these
grew
more
distinct
,
and
the
lamps
themselves
were
visible
;
slight
yellow
specks
,
that
seemed
to
be
rapidly
snuffed
out
,
one
by
one
,
as
intervening
obstacles
hid
them
from
the
sight
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
sounds
arose
---
the
striking
of
church
clocks
,
the
distant
bark
of
dogs
,
the
hum
of
traffic
in
the
streets
;
then
outlines
might
be
traced
---
tall
steeples
looming
in
the
air
,
and
piles
of
unequal
roofs
oppressed
by
chimneys
;
then
,
the
noise
swelled
into
a
louder
sound
,
and
forms
grew
more
distinct
and
numerous
still
,
and
London
---
visible
in
the
darkness
by
its
own
faint
light
,
and
not
by
that
of
Heaven
---
was
at
hand
.
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
,
however
,
all
unconscious
of
its
near
vicinity
,
still
jogged
on
,
half
sleeping
and
half
waking
,
when
a
loud
cry
at
no
great
distance
ahead
,
roused
him
with
a
start
.
  
<EOS>
For
a
moment
or
two
he
looked
about
him
like
a
man
who
had
been
transported
to
some
strange
country
in
his
sleep
,
but
soon
recognising
familiar
objects
,
rubbed
his
eyes
lazily
and
might
have
relapsed
again
,
but
that
the
cry
was
repeated
---
not
once
or
twice
or
thrice
,
but
many
times
,
and
each
time
,
if
possible
,
with
increased
vehemence
.
 
<EOS>
Thoroughly
aroused
,
Gabriel
,
who
was
a
bold
man
and
not
easily
daunted
,
made
straight
to
the
spot
,
urging
on
his
stout
little
horse
as
if
for
life
or
death
.
  
<EOS>
The
matter
indeed
looked
sufficiently
serious
,
for
,
coming
to
the
place
<EOS>
whence
the
cries
had
proceeded
<EOS>
,
he
descried
the
figure
of
a
man
extended
in
an
apparently
lifeless
state
upon
the
pathway
,
and
,
hovering
round
him
,
another
person
with
a
torch
in
his
hand
,
which
he
waved
in
the
air
with
a
wild
impatience
,
redoubling
meanwhile
those
cries
for
help
which
had
brought
the
locksmith
to
the
spot
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
here
to
do
?
"
said
the
old
man
,
alighting
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
's
this
---
 
<EOS>
what
---
Barnaby
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
bearer
of
the
torch
shook
his
long
loose
hair
back
from
his
eyes
,
and
thrusting
his
face
eagerly
into
that
of
the
locksmith
,
fixed
upon
him
a
look
which
told
his
history
at
once
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
me
,
Barnaby
?
"
said
Varden
.
  
<EOS>
He
nodded
---
not
once
or
twice
,
but
a
score
of
times
,
and
that
with
a
fantastic
exaggeration
which
would
have
kept
his
head
in
motion
for
an
hour
,
but
that
the
locksmith
held
up
his
finger
,
and
fixing
his
eye
sternly
upon
him
caused
him
to
desist
;
then
pointed
to
the
body
with
an
inquiring
look
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
blood
upon
him
,
"
said
Barnaby
with
a
shudder
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
makes
me
sick
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
came
it
there
?
"
demanded
Varden
.
  
<EOS>
"
Steel
,
steel
,
steel
!
"
<EOS>
he
replied
fiercely
,
imitating
with
his
hand
the
thrust
of
a
sword
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
he
robbed
?
"
said
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
caught
him
by
the
arm
,
and
nodded
"
Yes
;
"
then
pointed
towards
the
city
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
the
old
man
,
bending
over
the
body
and
looking
round
as
he
spoke
into
Barnaby
's
pale
face
,
strangely
lighted
up
by
something
that
was
NOT
intellect
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
robber
made
off
that
way
,
did
he
?
 
<EOS>
Well
,
well
,
never
mind
that
just
now
.
 
<EOS>
Hold
your
torch
this
way
---
a
little
farther
off
---
<EOS>
so
.
 
<EOS>
Now
stand
quiet
,
while
I
try
to
see
what
harm
is
done
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
he
applied
himself
to
a
closer
examination
of
the
prostrate
form
,
while
Barnaby
,
holding
the
torch
as
he
had
been
directed
,
looked
on
in
silence
,
fascinated
by
interest
or
curiosity
,
but
repelled
nevertheless
by
some
strong
and
secret
horror
which
convulsed
him
in
every
nerve
.
  
<EOS>
As
he
stood
,
at
that
moment
,
half
shrinking
back
and
half
bending
forward
,
both
his
face
and
figure
were
full
in
the
strong
glare
of
the
link
,
and
as
distinctly
revealed
as
though
it
had
been
broad
day
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
about
three
-
and
-
twenty
years
old
,
and
though
rather
spare
,
of
a
fair
height
and
strong
make
.
 
<EOS>
His
hair
,
of
which
he
had
a
great
profusion
,
was
red
,
and
hanging
in
disorder
about
his
face
and
shoulders
,
gave
to
his
restless
looks
an
expression
quite
unearthly
---
enhanced
by
the
paleness
of
his
complexion
,
and
the
glassy
lustre
of
his
large
protruding
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
Startling
as
his
aspect
was
,
the
features
were
good
,
and
there
was
something
even
plaintive
in
his
wan
and
haggard
aspect
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
the
absence
of
the
soul
is
far
more
terrible
in
a
living
man
than
in
a
dead
one
;
and
in
this
unfortunate
being
its
noblest
powers
were
wanting
.
  
<EOS>
His
dress
was
of
green
,
clumsily
trimmed
here
and
there
---
apparently
by
his
own
hands
---
with
gaudy
lace
;
brightest
where
the
cloth
was
most
worn
and
soiled
,
and
poorest
where
it
was
at
the
best
.
 
<EOS>
A
pair
of
tawdry
ruffles
dangled
at
his
wrists
,
while
his
throat
was
nearly
bare
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
ornamented
his
hat
with
a
cluster
of
peacock
's
feathers
,
but
they
were
limp
and
broken
,
and
now
trailed
negligently
down
his
back
.
 
<EOS>
Girt
to
his
side
was
the
steel
hilt
of
an
old
sword
without
blade
or
scabbard
;
and
some
particoloured
ends
of
ribands
and
poor
glass
toys
completed
the
ornamental
portion
of
his
attire
.
 
<EOS>
The
fluttered
and
confused
disposition
of
all
the
motley
scraps
that
formed
his
dress
,
bespoke
,
in
a
scarcely
less
degree
than
his
eager
and
unsettled
manner
,
the
disorder
of
his
mind
,
and
by
a
grotesque
contrast
set
off
and
heightened
the
more
impressive
wildness
of
his
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
Barnaby
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
after
a
hasty
but
careful
inspection
,
"
this
man
is
not
dead
,
but
he
has
a
wound
in
his
side
,
and
is
in
a
fainting
-
fit
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
him
,
I
know
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Barnaby
,
clapping
his
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
Know
him
?
"
repeated
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
said
Barnaby
,
laying
his
fingers
upon
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
went
out
to
-
day
a
wooing
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
for
a
light
guinea
that
he
should
never
go
a
wooing
again
,
for
,
if
he
did
,
some
eyes
would
grow
dim
that
are
now
as
bright
as
---
see
,
when
I
talk
of
eyes
,
the
stars
come
out
!
 
<EOS>
Whose
eyes
are
they
?
 
<EOS>
If
they
are
angels
'
eyes
,
why
do
they
look
down
here
and
see
good
men
hurt
,
and
only
wink
and
sparkle
all
the
night
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
Heaven
help
this
silly
fellow
,
"
murmured
the
perplexed
locksmith
;
"
can
he
know
this
gentleman
?
 
<EOS>
His
mother
's
house
is
not
far
off
;
I
had
better
see
if
she
can
tell
me
who
he
is
.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
,
my
man
,
help
me
to
put
him
in
the
chaise
,
and
we
'll
ride
home
together
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
touch
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
idiot
falling
back
,
and
shuddering
as
with
a
strong
spasm
;
he
's
bloody
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
in
his
nature
,
I
know
,
"
muttered
the
locksmith
,
"
it
's
cruel
to
ask
him
,
but
I
must
have
help
.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
---
good
Barnaby
---
<EOS>
dear
Barnaby
---
if
you
know
this
gentleman
,
for
the
sake
of
his
life
and
everybody
's
life
that
loves
him
,
help
me
to
raise
him
and
lay
him
down
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Cover
him
then
,
wrap
him
close
---
do
n't
let
me
see
it
---
<EOS>
smell
it
---
 
<EOS>
hear
the
word
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
speak
the
word
---
do
n't
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
I
'll
not
.
 
<EOS>
There
,
you
see
he
's
covered
now
.
 
<EOS>
Gently
.
 
<EOS>
Well
done
,
well
done
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
placed
him
in
the
carriage
with
great
ease
,
for
Barnaby
was
strong
and
active
,
but
all
the
time
they
were
so
occupied
he
shivered
from
head
to
foot
,
and
evidently
experienced
an
ecstasy
of
terror
.
  
<EOS>
This
accomplished
,
and
the
wounded
man
being
covered
with
Varden
's
own
greatcoat
which
he
took
off
for
the
purpose
,
they
proceeded
onward
at
a
brisk
pace
:
Barnaby
gaily
counting
the
stars
upon
his
fingers
,
and
Gabriel
inwardly
congratulating
himself
upon
having
an
adventure
now
,
which
would
silence
Mrs
Varden
on
the
subject
of
the
Maypole
,
for
that
night
,
or
there
was
no
faith
in
woman
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
04
    
<EOS>
In
the
venerable
suburb
---
it
was
a
suburb
once
---
of
Clerkenwell
,
towards
that
part
of
its
confines
which
is
nearest
to
the
Charter
House
,
and
in
one
of
those
cool
,
shady
Streets
,
of
which
a
few
,
widely
scattered
and
dispersed
,
yet
remain
in
such
old
parts
of
the
metropolis
,
---
each
tenement
quietly
vegetating
like
an
ancient
citizen
who
long
ago
retired
from
business
,
and
dozing
on
in
its
infirmity
until
in
course
of
time
it
tumbles
down
,
and
is
replaced
by
some
extravagant
young
heir
,
flaunting
in
stucco
and
ornamental
work
,
and
all
the
vanities
of
modern
days
,
---
in
this
quarter
,
and
in
a
street
of
this
description
,
the
business
of
the
present
chapter
lies
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
time
of
which
it
treats
,
though
only
six
-
and
-
sixty
years
ago
,
a
very
large
part
of
what
is
London
now
had
no
existence
.
<EOS>
Even
in
the
brains
of
the
wildest
speculators
,
there
had
sprung
up
no
long
rows
of
streets
connecting
Highgate
with
Whitechapel
,
no
assemblages
of
palaces
in
the
swampy
levels
,
nor
little
cities
in
the
open
fields
.
 
<EOS>
Although
this
part
of
town
was
then
,
as
now
,
parcelled
out
in
streets
,
and
plentifully
peopled
,
it
wore
a
different
aspect
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
gardens
to
many
of
the
houses
,
and
trees
by
the
pavement
side
;
with
an
air
of
freshness
breathing
up
and
down
,
which
in
these
days
would
be
sought
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
Fields
were
nigh
at
hand
,
through
which
the
New
River
took
its
winding
course
,
and
where
there
was
merry
haymaking
in
the
summer
time
.
 
<EOS>
Nature
was
not
so
far
removed
,
or
hard
to
get
at
,
as
in
these
days
;
and
although
there
were
busy
trades
in
Clerkenwell
,
and
working
jewellers
by
scores
,
it
was
a
purer
place
,
with
farm
-
houses
nearer
to
it
than
many
modern
Londoners
would
readily
believe
,
and
lovers
'
walks
at
no
great
distance
,
which
turned
into
squalid
courts
,
long
before
the
lovers
of
this
age
were
born
,
or
,
as
the
phrase
goes
,
thought
of
.
  
<EOS>
In
one
of
these
streets
,
the
cleanest
of
them
all
,
and
on
the
shady
side
of
the
way
---
for
good
housewives
know
that
sunlight
damages
their
cherished
furniture
,
and
so
choose
the
shade
rather
than
its
intrusive
glare
---
there
stood
the
house
with
which
we
have
to
deal
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
modest
building
,
not
very
straight
,
not
large
,
not
tall
;
not
bold
-
faced
,
with
great
staring
windows
,
but
a
shy
,
blinking
house
,
with
a
conical
roof
going
up
into
a
peak
over
its
garret
window
of
four
small
panes
of
glass
,
like
a
cocked
hat
on
the
head
of
an
elderly
gentleman
with
one
eye
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
built
of
brick
or
lofty
stone
,
but
of
wood
and
plaster
;
it
was
not
planned
with
a
dull
and
wearisome
regard
to
regularity
,
for
no
one
window
matched
the
other
,
or
seemed
to
have
the
slightest
reference
to
anything
besides
itself
.
  
<EOS>
The
shop
---
for
it
had
a
shop
---
was
,
with
reference
to
the
first
floor
,
where
shops
usually
are
;
and
there
all
resemblance
between
it
and
any
other
shop
stopped
short
and
ceased
.
 
<EOS>
People
who
went
in
and
out
did
n't
go
up
a
flight
of
steps
to
it
,
or
walk
easily
in
upon
a
level
with
the
street
,
but
dived
down
three
steep
stairs
,
as
into
a
cellar
.
 
<EOS>
Its
floor
was
paved
with
stone
and
brick
,
as
that
of
any
other
cellar
might
be
;
and
in
lieu
of
window
framed
and
glazed
it
had
a
great
black
wooden
flap
or
shutter
,
<EOS>
nearly
breast
high
from
the
ground
,
which
turned
back
in
the
day
-
time
,
admitting
as
much
cold
air
as
light
,
and
very
often
more
.
 
<EOS>
Behind
this
shop
was
a
wainscoted
parlour
,
looking
first
into
a
paved
yard
,
and
beyond
that
again
into
a
little
terrace
garden
,
raised
some
feet
above
it
.
 
<EOS>
Any
stranger
would
have
supposed
that
this
wainscoted
parlour
,
saving
for
the
door
of
communication
by
which
he
had
entered
,
was
cut
off
and
detached
from
all
the
world
;
and
indeed
most
strangers
on
their
first
entrance
were
observed
to
grow
extremely
thoughtful
,
as
weighing
and
pondering
in
their
minds
whether
the
upper
rooms
were
only
approachable
by
ladders
from
without
;
never
suspecting
that
two
of
the
most
unassuming
and
unlikely
doors
in
existence
,
which
the
most
ingenious
mechanician
on
earth
must
of
necessity
have
supposed
to
be
the
doors
of
closets
,
opened
out
of
this
room
---
each
without
the
smallest
preparation
,
or
so
much
as
a
quarter
of
an
inch
of
passage
---
upon
two
dark
winding
flights
of
stairs
,
the
one
upward
,
the
other
downward
,
which
were
the
sole
means
of
communication
between
that
chamber
and
the
other
portions
of
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
With
all
these
oddities
,
there
was
not
a
neater
,
more
scrupulously
tidy
,
or
more
punctiliously
ordered
house
,
in
Clerkenwell
,
in
London
,
in
all
England
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
not
cleaner
windows
,
or
whiter
floors
,
or
brighter
Stoves
,
or
more
highly
shining
articles
of
furniture
in
old
mahogany
;
there
was
not
more
rubbing
,
scrubbing
,
burnishing
and
polishing
,
in
the
whole
street
put
together
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
this
excellence
attained
without
some
cost
and
trouble
and
great
expenditure
of
voice
,
as
the
neighbours
were
frequently
reminded
when
the
good
lady
of
the
house
overlooked
and
assisted
in
its
being
put
to
rights
on
cleaning
days
---
which
were
usually
from
Monday
morning
till
Saturday
night
,
both
days
inclusive
.
  
<EOS>
Leaning
against
the
door
-
post
of
this
,
his
dwelling
,
the
locksmith
stood
early
on
the
morning
after
he
had
met
with
the
wounded
man
,
gazing
disconsolately
at
a
great
wooden
emblem
of
a
key
,
painted
in
vivid
yellow
to
resemble
gold
,
which
dangled
from
the
house
-
front
,
and
swung
to
and
fro
with
a
mournful
creaking
noise
,
as
if
complaining
that
it
had
nothing
to
unlock
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
he
looked
over
his
shoulder
into
the
shop
,
which
was
so
dark
and
dingy
with
numerous
tokens
of
his
trade
,
and
so
blackened
by
the
smoke
of
a
little
forge
,
near
which
his
'
prentice
was
at
work
,
that
it
would
have
been
difficult
for
one
unused
to
such
espials
to
have
distinguished
anything
but
<EOS>
various
tools
of
uncouth
make
and
shape
,
great
bunches
of
rusty
keys
,
fragments
of
iron
,
half
-
finished
locks
,
and
such
like
things
,
which
garnished
the
walls
and
hung
in
clusters
from
the
ceiling
.
  
<EOS>
After
a
long
and
patient
contemplation
of
the
golden
key
,
and
many
such
backward
glances
,
Gabriel
stepped
into
the
road
,
and
stole
a
look
at
the
upper
windows
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
them
chanced
to
be
thrown
open
at
the
moment
,
and
a
roguish
face
met
his
;
<EOS>
a
face
lighted
up
by
the
loveliest
pair
of
sparkling
eyes
that
ever
locksmith
looked
upon
;
the
face
of
a
pretty
,
laughing
,
girl
;
dimpled
and
fresh
,
and
healthful
---
the
very
impersonation
of
good
-
humour
and
blooming
beauty
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
<EOS>
she
whispered
,
bending
forward
and
pointing
archly
to
the
window
underneath
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
is
still
asleep
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Still
,
my
dear
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
in
the
same
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
talk
as
if
she
had
been
asleep
all
night
,
instead
of
little
more
than
half
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
'm
very
thankful
.
 
<EOS>
Sleep
's
a
blessing
---
no
doubt
about
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
last
few
words
he
muttered
to
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
cruel
of
you
to
keep
us
up
so
late
this
morning
,
and
never
tell
us
where
you
were
,
or
send
us
word
!
"
said
the
girl
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
Dolly
,
Dolly
!
"
returned
the
locksmith
,
shaking
his
head
,
and
smiling
,
"
how
cruel
of
you
to
run
upstairs
to
bed
!
 
<EOS>
Come
down
to
breakfast
,
madcap
,
and
come
down
lightly
,
or
you
'll
wake
your
mother
.
 
<EOS>
She
must
be
tired
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
---
I
am
.
"
  
<EOS>
Keeping
these
latter
words
to
himself
,
and
returning
his
daughter
's
nod
,
he
was
passing
into
the
workshop
,
with
the
smile
she
had
awakened
still
beaming
on
his
face
,
when
he
just
caught
sight
of
his
'
prentice
's
brown
paper
cap
ducking
down
to
avoid
observation
,
and
shrinking
from
the
window
back
to
its
former
place
,
which
the
wearer
no
sooner
reached
than
he
began
to
hammer
lustily
.
  
<EOS>
"
Listening
again
,
Simon
!
<EOS>
"
said
Gabriel
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
bad
.
<EOS>
What
in
the
name
of
wonder
does
he
expect
the
girl
to
say
,
that
I
always
catch
him
listening
when
SHE
speaks
,
and
never
at
any
other
time
!
 
<EOS>
A
bad
habit
,
Sim
,
a
sneaking
,
underhanded
way
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
you
may
hammer
,
but
you
wo
n't
beat
that
out
of
me
,
if
you
work
at
it
till
your
time
's
up
!
"
  
<EOS>
So
saying
,
and
shaking
his
head
gravely
,
he
re
-
entered
the
workshop
,
and
confronted
the
subject
of
these
remarks
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
enough
of
that
just
now
,
"
said
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
make
any
more
of
that
confounded
clatter
.
 
<EOS>
Breakfast
's
ready
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Sim
,
looking
up
with
amazing
politeness
,
and
a
peculiar
little
bow
cut
short
off
at
the
neck
,
"
I
shall
attend
you
immediately
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
,
"
muttered
Gabriel
,
"
that
's
out
of
the
'
Prentice
's
Garland
or
the
'
Prentice
's
Delight
,
or
the
'
Prentice
's
Warbler
,
or
the
Prentice
's
Guide
to
the
Gallows
,
or
some
such
improving
textbook
.
 
<EOS>
Now
he
's
going
to
beautify
himself
---
here
's
a
precious
locksmith
!
"
  
<EOS>
Quite
unconscious
that
his
master
was
looking
on
from
the
dark
corner
by
the
parlour
door
<EOS>
,
Sim
threw
off
the
paper
cap
,
sprang
from
his
seat
,
and
in
two

steps
,
something
between

and

,
bounded
to
a
washing

at
the
other

shop
,
and
there
removed
from
his

hands
all

of
his

---
practising

all

.
 
<EOS>
This
done
,
he
drew
from
some

place
a
little

of
looking
-
glass
,
and
with
its

arranged
his
hair
,
and
ascertained
the
exact
state
of
a
little

on
his
nose
.
 
<EOS>
Having
now
completed
his

,
he
placed
the
fragment
of
mirror
on
a
low

,
and
looked
over
his

at
so
much
of
his
legs
as
could
be
reflected
in
that
small
compass
,
with
the
greatest
possible
complacency
and
satisfaction
.
  
<EOS>
Sim
,
as
he
was
called
in
the
locksmith
's
family
,
or
Mr
Simon
Tappertit
,
as
he
called
himself
,
and
required

to
style
him
out

,
on

,
and

out
,
---
was
an
old
-
fashioned
,
thin

,

,
sharp

small

,
very

,
and
thoroughly

in
his
own
mind
that
he
was
above
the
middle

;
rather
tall
,
in

,
than

.
 
<EOS>
Of
his
figure
,
which
was
well
enough
formed
,
though
somewhat
of
the
leanest
,
he
entertained
the
highest

;
and
with
his
legs
,
which
,
in
knee

,
were
perfect
curiosities
of
littleness
<EOS>
,
he
was
enraptured
to
a

.
 
<EOS>
He
also
had
some

,
shadowy

,
which
had
never
been
quite

by
his

friends
,
concerning
the

of
his

.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
he
had
been
known
to
go

as
to
boast
that
he
could
utterly

,
which
he

"
eyeing
her
over
;
"
but
it
must

added
,
that
neither
of

,
through

,
of

,
had

.
  
<EOS>
It
may

,
that
in
the
small

of
Mr
Tappertit
there
was
locked

an
ambitious

.
<EOS>
As
certain

,
confined
in
casks

in

,
will
ferment
,
and

,

chafe

,

Tappertit
would

that

,
his
body
,
until
,

great

,
it

force

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
It

remark
,

,
that
his
soul

got

;
and

many

befell

,
which
he
had
frequently

from
his
worthy

.
  
<EOS>
Sim
Tappertit
,
among
the
other
fancies
upon
which
his
before

mentioned

was
for

(
and
which

,

,
grew

,

a

;
and

the
'

no
longer

clubs
wherewith
to
mace

:
that

his
strong

.
 
<EOS>
He
was

have
said
that

former

a

had
been
cast

the

George
Barnwell
,

,

---
 
temperately

.
 
<EOS>
These

always

what

the
'

might
yet

if

;

darkly
,

,

,

<EOS>
In

.
 
<EOS>
He
had

,
beyond

,

,

friendly

.
 
<EOS>
Add

that
he
was
in
years
<EOS>
just

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Fathers

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
There

.

<EOS>

errand
,
seeking
his
fortune
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Why
,
what
's
the
matter
,
Doll
?
 
<EOS>
YOU
are
making
faces
now
.
 
<EOS>
The
girls
are
as
bad
as
the
boys
every
bit
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
tea
,
"
said
Dolly
,
turning
alternately
very
red
and
very
white
,
which
is
no
doubt
the
effect
of
a
slight
scald
---
"
so
very
hot
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
looked
immensely
big
at
a
quartern
loaf
on
the
table
,
and
breathed
hard
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
?
"
returned
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Put
some
more
milk
in
it
.
<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
am
sorry
for
Joe
,
because
he
is
a
likely
young
fellow
,
and
gains
upon
one
every

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
'll
start
off
,
you
'll
find
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
he
told
me
as
much
himself
!
"
  
"
<EOS>
Indeed
!
"
cried
Dolly
in
a
faint

.
 
<EOS>
"
In
-
deed
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
the
tea
tickling
your
throat
still
,
my
dear
?
"
said
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
before
his
daughter
could

,
she
was
taken

,
and
it
was
such

,
that
,
when
she
left

,
the

were
starting

.
 
<EOS>
The
good
-
natured
locksmith
was
still
patting

on

,
when

from
Mrs
Varden
,
making

,
that
she
felt
too
much

to
rise

;
and
therefore

,

,

,

Manual
in

.
 
<EOS>
Like
some

who
in
remote

upon
this

,
Mrs
Varden
was
most

when

.
 
<EOS>
Whenever
she
and
her

were
at
unusual

,
then
the
Protestant
Manual
was
in
high

.
  
<EOS>
Knowing
from
experience
what
these

portended
,
the
triumvirate
broke
up
;
Dolly
,
to
see
the

executed
with

;
Gabriel
,

some

-
of
-
door

;
and
Sim
,
to

in
the

,
to
which

he
carried
the
big
look
,
although
the

remained
behind
.
  
<EOS>
Indeed
the
big
look
increased
immensely
,
and
when
he
had
tied
his
apron
on
,
became
quite

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
he
had
several
times

up

down

,
and
the
longest

be
could
take
,
and
had

many

,
that
his

began
to

.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
a

upon

,
and
he

;
uttering

with

the

"
Joe
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
eyed
her
over
,
while
he
talked
about
the
fellow
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
that
was
of
course
the
reason
of

.
 
<EOS>
Joe
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
walked
up
and
down
again
much

than
before
,
and
if
possible

;

,

sometimes

,
and
cast
from

,
another
"
Joe
!
"
 
<EOS>
In

.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
It

not

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

Tappertit
,

,
"
but

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Grinding
will

my
present

well
.
 
<EOS>
Joe
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Whirr
-
r
-
r
-
r
.
 
<EOS>
The
grindstone
was
soon

;
the

were

.
 
<EOS>
This
was
the

for
his
heated

.
  
<EOS>
Whirr
-
r
-
r
-
r
-
r
-
r
-
r
.
  
<EOS>
"
Something
will

!
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Something
will
come
of
this
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope

may
n't

human

!
"
  
<EOS>
Whirr
-
r
-
r
-
r
-
r
-
r
-
r
-
r
.
    
Chapter
05
    
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
business
of
the
day
was
over
,
the
locksmith
sallied
forth
,
alone
,
to
visit
the
wounded
gentleman
and
ascertain
the
progress
of
his
recovery
.
 
<EOS>
The
house
where
he
had
left
him
was
in
a
by
-
street
in
Southwark
,
not
far
from
London
Bridge
;
and
thither
he
hied
with
all
speed
,
bent
upon
returning
with
as
little
delay
as
might
be
,
and
getting
to
bed
betimes
.
  
<EOS>
The
evening
was
boisterous
---
scarcely
better
than
the
previous
night
had
been
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
easy
for
a
stout
man
like
Gabriel
to
keep
his
legs
at
the
street
corners
,
or
to
make
head
against
the
high
wind
,
which
often
fairly
got
the
better
of
him
,
and
drove
him
back
some
paces
,
or
,
in
defiance
of
all
his
energy
,
forced
him
to
take
shelter
in
an
arch
or
doorway
until
the
fury
of
the
gust
was
spent
.
<EOS>
Occasionally
a
hat
or
wig
,
or
both
,
came
spinning
and
trundling
past
him
,
like
a
mad
thing
;
while
the
more
serious
spectacle
of
falling
tiles
and
slates
,
or
of
masses
of
brick
and
mortar
or
fragments
of
stone
-
coping
rattling
upon
the
pavement
near
at
hand
,
and
splitting
into
fragments
,
did
not
increase
the
pleasure
of
the
journey
,
or
make
the
way
less
dreary
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
trying
night
for
a
man
like
me
to
walk
in
!
"
said
the
locksmith
,
as
he
knocked
softly
at
the
widow
's
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'd
rather
be
in
old
John
's
chimney
-
corner
,
faith
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
's
there
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
a
woman
's
voice
from
within
.
 
<EOS>
Being
answered
,
it
added
a
hasty
word
of
welcome
,
and
the
door
was
quickly
opened
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
about
forty
---
<EOS>
perhaps
two
or
three
years
older
---
with
a
cheerful
aspect
,
and
a
face
that
had
once
been
pretty
.
 
<EOS>
It
bore
traces
of
affliction
and
care
,
but
they
were
of
an
old
date
,
and
Time
had
smoothed
them
.
 
<EOS>
Any
one
who
had
bestowed
but
a
casual
glance
on
Barnaby
might
have
known
that
this
was
his
mother
,
from
the
strong
resemblance
between
them
;
but
where
in
his
face
there
was
wildness
and
vacancy
,
<EOS>
in
hers
there
was
the
patient
composure
of
long
effort
and
quiet
resignation
.
  
<EOS>
One
thing
about
this
face
was
very
strange
and
startling
.
 
<EOS>
You
could
not
look
upon
it
in
its
most
cheerful
mood
without
feeling
that
it
had
some
extraordinary
capacity
of
expressing
terror
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
on
the
surface
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
no
one
feature
that
it
lingered
.
<EOS>
You
could
not
take
the
eyes
or
mouth
,
or
lines
upon
the
cheek
,
and
say
,
if
this
or
that
were
otherwise
,
it
would
not
be
so
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
there
it
always
lurked
---
<EOS>
something
for
ever
dimly
seen
,
but
ever
there
,
and
never
absent
for

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
faintest
,
palest
shadow
of
some
look
,
to
which
an
instant
of
intense
and
most
unutterable

only
could
have
given
birth
;
but

feeble
as
it
was
,

did
suggest
what
that
look
must
have
been
,
and
fixed
it
in
the

as
if
it
had
had
existence
in

dream
.
  
<EOS>
More
faintly
imaged
,
and
wanting
force
and
purpose
,
as
it
were
,
because
of
his
darkened

,
there
was
this
same
stamp
upon
the
son
.
 
<EOS>
Seen
in
a
picture
,
it
must
have
had
some
legend
with
it
,
and
would

haunted
those
who

upon

.
 
<EOS>
They
who
knew
the
Maypole
story
,
and
could
remember
what
the
widow
was
,
before
her
husband
's
and
his
master
's

,
understood
it
well
.
<EOS>
They
recollected
how
the
change
had
come
,
and
could
call
to
mind
that
when
her
son
was
born
,
upon
the
very
day
the
deed
was
known
,
he
bore
upon
his
wrist
what
seemed
a
smear
of
blood
but
half
washed
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
God
save
you
,
neighbour
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
locksmith
,
as
he
followed
her
,
with
the
air
of
an
old
friend
,
into
a
little
parlour
where

was

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
,
"
she
answered

.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
kind
heart
has
brought
you
here

.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
will
keep

at
home
,
I
know
of
old
,
if

friends
to
serve
or

,
out

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tut
,
tut
,
"
returned

locksmith
,
rubbing

and

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
women
are
such
talkers
.
 
<EOS>
What
of
the
patient
,
neighbour
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
sleeping
now
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
very
restless
towards

,
and
for

and

.
 
<EOS>
But
the
fever
has
left

,

he
will

.
 
<EOS>
He
must
not

until

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
had
visitors
to
-
day
---
humph
?
"
said
Gabriel
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Old
Mr
Chester
has
been
here

since
we
sent

,
and
had

many

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
A

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
.
 
<EOS>
That
's

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Who

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Barnaby
,

.
"
  
"
Barnaby

!
<EOS>
"

;
"

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank

<EOS>

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
Ah
,

<EOS>

---

"
  
<EOS>
"

"

,

"

---

.
 
<EOS>
To

grows

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
will

"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

does

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
our

<EOS>
,
"

,

---
"
sharpest

sharp

ones
<EOS>
---

's

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
Barnaby
's
room
,
"

,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
He
's
a
knowing
blade
!
"
<EOS>
said
Varden
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

secrets
before

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
He
's

customer
.
 
<EOS>
I
've

read
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

?
 
<EOS>
Him

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
in

,

.
 
<EOS>
Hark
!
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
There
again
!
 
<EOS>
'
Tis
some
one
knocking
softly
at
the
shutter
.
<EOS>
Who
can
it
be
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
had
been
speaking
in
a
low
tone
,
for
the
invalid
lay
overhead
,
and
the
walls
and
ceilings
being
thin
and
poorly
built
,
the
sound
of
their

might
otherwise
have
disturbed
his
slumber
.
 
<EOS>
The
party
without
,
whoever
it
was
,
could
have
stood
close

the
shutter
without
hearing
anything
spoken
;
and
,
seeing
the
light
through
the
chinks
and
finding

so

,
might
have

that
only

.
  
<EOS>
"
Some
thief
or

maybe
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
the
light
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
she

.
 
<EOS>
"
Such
visitors
have

come

.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
stay
here
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
within
call
,

the
worst
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
rather
go
myself
---
alone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
said
the
locksmith
,
unwillingly
relinquishing
the
candle
he
had
caught
up
from
the
table
.
  
<EOS>
"
Because
---
I
do
n't
know
why
---
because
the
wish
is
so
strong
upon
me
,
"
she
rejoined
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
again
---
do
not
detain
me
,
I
beg
of
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
Gabriel
looked
at
her
,
in
great
surprise
to
see
one
who
was
usually
so
mild
and
quiet
thus
agitated
,
and
with
so
little
cause
.
 
<EOS>
She
left
the
room
and
closed
the
door
behind
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
stood
for
a
moment
as
if
hesitating
,
with
her
hand
upon
the
lock
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
short
interval
the
knocking
came
again
,
and
a
voice
close
to
the
window
---
a
voice
the
locksmith
seemed
to
recollect
,
and
to
have
some
disagreeable
association
with
---
whispered
"
Make
haste
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
words
were
uttered
in
that
low
distinct
voice
which
finds
its
way
so
readily
to
sleepers
'
ears
,
and
wakes
them
in
a
fright
.
 
<EOS>
For
a
moment
it
startled
even
the
locksmith
;
who
involuntarily
drew
back
from
the
window
,
and
listened
.
  
<EOS>
The
wind
rumbling
in
the
chimney
made
it
difficult
to
hear
what
passed
,
but
he
could
tell
that
the
door
was
opened
,
that
there
was
the
tread
of
a
man
upon
the
creaking
boards
,
and
then
a
moment
's
silence
---
broken
by
a
suppressed
something
which
was
not
a
shriek
,
or
groan
,
or
cry
for
help
,
and
yet
might
have
been
either
or
all
three
;
and
the
words
"
My
God
!
"
<EOS>
uttered
in
a
voice
it
chilled
him
to
hear
.
  
<EOS>
He
rushed
out
upon
the
instant
.
 
<EOS>
There
,
at
last
,
was
that
dreadful
look
---
the
very
one
<EOS>
he
seemed
to
know
so
well
and
yet
had
never
seen
before
---
upon
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
There
she
stood
,
frozen
to
the
ground
,
gazing
with
starting
eyes
,
and
livid
cheeks
,
and
every
feature
fixed
and
ghastly
,
upon
the
man
he
had
encountered
in
the
dark
last
night
.
 
<EOS>
His
eyes
met
those
of
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
but
a
flash
,
an
instant
,
a
breath
upon
a
polished
glass
,
and
<EOS>
he
was
gone
.
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
was
upon
him
---
had
the
skirts
of
his
streaming
garment
almost
in
his
grasp
---
when
his
arms
were
tightly
clutched
,
and
the
widow
flung
herself
upon
the
ground
before
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
other
way
---
the
other
way
,
"
she
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
went
the
other
way
.
<EOS>
Turn
---
turn
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
other
way
!
 
<EOS>
I
see
him
now
,
"
rejoined
the
locksmith
,
pointing
---
 
<EOS>
"
yonder
---
there
<EOS>
---
there
is
his
shadow
passing
by
that
light
.
 
<EOS>
What
---
 
<EOS>
who
is
this
?
 
<EOS>
Let
me
go
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Come
back
,
come
back
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
woman
,
clasping
him
;
"
Do
not
touch
him
on
your
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
charge
you
,
come
back
.
 
<EOS>
He
carries
other
lives
besides
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
Come
back
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
does
this
mean
?
"
cried
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
matter
what
it
means
,
do
n't
ask
,
do
n't
speak
,
do
n't
think
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
to
be
followed
,
checked
,
or
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
Come
back
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
man
looked
at
her
in
wonder
,
as
she
writhed
and
clung
about
him
;
and
,
borne
down
by
her
passion
,
suffered
her
to
drag
him
into
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
she
had
chained
and
double
-
locked
the
door
,
fastened
every
bolt
and
bar
with
the
heat
and
fury
of
a
maniac
,
and
drawn
him
back
into
the
room
,
that
she
turned
upon
him
,
once
again
,
that
stony
look
of
horror
,
and
,
sinking
down
into
a
chair
,
covered
her
face
,
and
shuddered
,
as
though
the
hand
of
death
were
on
her
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
06
    
<EOS>
Beyond
all
measure
astonished
by
the
strange
occurrences
which
had
passed
with
so
much
violence
and
rapidity
,
the
locksmith
gazed
upon
the
shuddering
figure
in
the
chair
like
one
half
stupefied
,
and
would
have
gazed
much
longer
,
<EOS>
had
not
his
tongue
been
loosened
by
compassion
and
humanity
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
ill
,
"
said
Gabriel
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
call
some
neighbour
in
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
for
the
world
,
"
she
rejoined
,
motioning
to
him
with
her
trembling
hand
,
and
holding
her
face
averted
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
enough
that
you
have
been
by
,
to
see
this
.
"
  
"
Nay
,
more
than
enough
---
or
less
,
"
said
Gabriel
.
  
<EOS>
"
Be
it
so
,
"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
you
like
.
 
<EOS>
Ask
me
no
questions
,
I
entreat
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Neighbour
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
after
a
pause
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
this
fair
,
or
reasonable
,
or
just
to
yourself
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
like
you
,
who
have
known
me
so
long
and
sought
my
advice
in
all
matters
---
<EOS>
like
you
,
who
from
a
girl
have
had
a
strong
mind
and
a
staunch
heart
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
need
of
them
,
"
she
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
growing
old
,
both
in
years
and
care
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
that
,
and
too
much
trial
,
have
made
them
weaker
than
they
used
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
speak
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
see
what
I
have
seen
,
and
hold
my
peace
!
"
returned
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
was
that
man
,
and
why
has
his
coming
made
this
change
in
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
silent
,
but
held
to
the
chair
as
though
to
save
herself
from
falling
on
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
take
the
licence
of
an
old
acquaintance
,
Mary
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
"
who
has
ever
had
a
warm
regard
for
you
,
and
maybe
has
tried
to
prove
it
when
he
could
.
 
<EOS>
Who
is
this
ill
-
favoured
man
,
and
what
has
he
to
do
with
you
?
 
<EOS>
Who
is
this
ghost
<EOS>
,
that
is
only
seen
in
the
black
nights
and
bad
weather
?
 
<EOS>
How
does
he
know
,
and
why
does
he
haunt
,
this
house
,
whispering
through
chinks
and
crevices
,
as
if
there
was
that
between
him
and
you
,
which
neither
durst
so
much
as
speak
aloud
of
?
 
<EOS>
Who
is
he
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
well
to
say
he
haunts
this
house
,
"
returned
the
widow
,
faintly
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
shadow
has
been
upon
it
and
me
,
in
light
and
darkness
,
at
noonday
and
midnight
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
at
last
,
he
has
come
in
the
body
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
would
n't
have
gone
in
the
body
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
with
some
irritation
,
"
if
you
had
left
my
arms
and
legs
at
liberty
.
<EOS>
What
riddle
is
this
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
one
,
"
she
answered
,
rising
as
she
spoke
,
"
that
must
remain
for
ever
as
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
dare
not
say
more
than
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Dare
not
!
"
repeated
the
wondering
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
not
press
me
,
"
she
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sick
and
faint
,
and
every
faculty
of
life
seems
dead
within
me
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
No
!
---
Do
not
touch
me
,
either
.
"
  
<EOS>
Gabriel
,
who
had
stepped
forward
to
render
her
assistance
,
fell
back
as
she
made
this
hasty
exclamation
,
and
regarded
her
in
silent
wonder
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
my
way
alone
,
"
she
said
in
a
low
voice
,
"
and
let
the
hands
of
no
honest
man
touch
mine
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
tottered
to
the
door
,
she
turned
,
and
added
with
a
stronger
effort
,
"
This
is
a
secret
,
which
,
of
necessity
,
I
trust
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
true
man
.
 
<EOS>
As
you
have
ever
been
good
and
kind
to
me
,
---
keep
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
noise
was
heard
above
,
make
some
excuse
---
say
anything
<EOS>
but
what
you
really
saw
,
and
never
let
a
word
or
look
between
us
,
recall
this
circumstance
.
 
<EOS>
I
trust
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Mind
,
I
trust
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
How
much
I
trust
,
you
never
can
conceive
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Casting
her
eyes
upon
him
for
an
instant
,
she
withdrew
,
and
left
him
there
alone
.
  
<EOS>
Gabriel
,
not
knowing
what
to
think
,
stood
staring
at
the
door
with
a
countenance
full
of
surprise
and
dismay
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
he
pondered
on
what
had
passed
,
the
less
able
he
was
to
give
it
any
favourable
interpretation
.
 
<EOS>
To
find
this
widow
woman
,
whose
life
for
so
many
years
had
been
supposed
to
be
one
of
solitude
and
retirement
,
and
who
,
in
her
quiet
suffering
character
,
had
gained
the
good
opinion
and
respect
of
all
who
knew
her
---
to
find
her
linked
mysteriously
with
an
ill
-
omened
man
,
alarmed
at
his
appearance
,
and
yet
favouring
his
escape
,
was
a
discovery
that
pained
as
much
as
startled
him
.
 
<EOS>
Her
reliance
on
his
secrecy
,
and
his
tacit
acquiescence
,
increased
his
distress
of
mind
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
spoken
boldly
,
persisted
in
questioning
her
,
detained
her
when
she
rose
to
leave
the
room
,
made
any
kind
of
protest
,
instead
of
silently
compromising
himself
,
as
he
felt
he
had
done
,
he
would
have
been
more
at
ease
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
did
I
let
her
say
it
was
a
secret
,
and
she
trusted
it
to
me
!
"
<EOS>
said
Gabriel
,
putting
his
wig
on
one
side
to
scratch
his
head
with
greater
ease
,
and
looking
ruefully
at
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
more
readiness
than
old
John
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Why
did
n't
I
say
firmly
,
"
You
have
no
right
to
such
secrets
,
and
I
demand
of
you
to
tell
me
what
this
means
,
"
instead
of
standing
gaping
at
her
,
like
an
old
moon
-
calf
as
I
am
!
 
<EOS>
But
there
's
my
weakness
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
be
obstinate
enough
with
men
<EOS>
if
need
be
,
but
women
may
twist
me
round
their
fingers
at
their
pleasure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
took
his
wig
off
outright
as
he
made
this
reflection
,
and
,
warming
his
handkerchief
at
the
fire
began
to
rub
and
polish
his
bald
head
with
it
,
until
it
glistened
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
yet
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
softening
under
this
soothing
process
,
and
stopping
to
smile
,
"
it
MAY
be
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Any
drunken
brawler
trying
to
make
his
way
into
the
house
,
would
have
alarmed
a
quiet
soul
like
her
.
 
<EOS>
But
then
"
---
and
here
was
the
vexation
<EOS>
---
"
how
came
it
to
be
that
man
<EOS>
;
how
comes
he
to
have
this
influence
over
her
;
how
came
she
to
favour
his
getting
away
from
me
;
and
,
more
than
all
,
how
came
she
not
to
say
it
was
a
sudden
fright
,
and
nothing
more
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
sad
thing
to
have
,
in
one
minute
,
reason
to
mistrust
a
person
I
have
known
so
long
,
and
an
old
sweetheart
into
the
bargain
;
but
what
else
can
I
do
,
with
all
this
upon
my
mind
!
<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>
Is
that
Barnaby
outside
there
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
looking
in
and
nodding
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sure
enough
it
's
Barnaby
---
how
did
you
guess
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
By
your
shadow
,
"
said
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oho
!
"
cried
Barnaby
,
glancing
over
his
shoulder
,
"
He
's
a
merry
fellow
,
that
shadow
,
and
keeps
close
to
me
,
though
I
AM
silly
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
such
pranks
,
such
walks
,
such
runs
,
such
gambols
on
the
grass
!
<EOS>
Sometimes
he
'll
be
half
as
tall
as
a
church

,
and
sometimes
no
bigger
than
a
dwarf
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
he
goes
on
before
,
and
now
behind
,
and
anon
he
'll
be
stealing
on
,
on
this
side
,
or
on
that
,
stopping
whenever
I
stop
,
and
thinking
I
ca
n't
see
him
,
though
I
have
my
eye
on
him
sharp
enough
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
he
's
a
merry
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
---
is
he
silly
too
?
 
<EOS>
I
think
he
is
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
asked
Gabriel
.
  
<EOS>
"
Because
be
never
tires
of
mocking
me
,
but
does
it
all
day
long
.
<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>
Why
do
n't
you
come
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
  
"
Upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
He
wants
you
.
 
<EOS>
Stay
<EOS>
---
where
's
HIS
shadow
?
 
<EOS>
Come
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
a
wise
man
;
tell
me
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Beside
him
,
Barnaby
;
beside
him
,
I
suppose
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
<EOS>
he
replied
,
shaking
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
Guess
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gone
out
a
walking
,
maybe
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
changed
shadows
with
a
woman
,
"
the
idiot

in
his
ear
,
and
then
fell
back
with
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
Her
shadow
's
always
with
him
,
and
his
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
sport
<EOS>
I
think
,
eh
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Barnaby
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
with
a
grave
look
;
"
come
hither
,
lad
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
you
want
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
replied
,
keeping
away
from
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
'm
cunning
,
I
'm
silent
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
say
so
much
to
you
---
are
you
ready
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
he
caught
up
the
light
,
and
waved
it
with
a
wild
laugh
above
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Softly
---
gently
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
exerting
all
his
influence
to
keep
him
calm
and
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
had
been
asleep
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
HAVE
been
asleep
,
"
he
rejoined
,
with
widely
-
opened
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
There
have
been
great
faces
coming
and
going
---
close
to
my
face
,
and
then
a
mile
away
---
low
places
to
creep
through
,
whether
I
would
or
no
---
high
churches
to
fall
down
from
---
strange
creatures
crowded
up
together
neck
and
heels
,
to
sit
upon
the
bed
---
that
's
sleep
,
eh
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dreams
,
Barnaby
,
dreams
,
"
said
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dreams
!
"
<EOS>
he
echoed
softly
,
drawing
closer
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Those
are
not
dreams
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
are
,
"
replied
the
locksmith
,
"
if
they
are
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
dreamed
,
"
said
Barnaby
,
passing
his
arm
through
Varden
's
,
and
peering
close
into
his
face
as
he
answered
in
a

,
"
I
dreamed
just
now
that
something
---
it
was
in
the
shape
of
a
man
---
followed
me
---
 
came
softly
after
me
---
would
n't
let
me
be
---
but
was
always
hiding
and
crouching
,
like
a
cat
in
dark

,
waiting
till
I
should
pass
;
when
it
crept
out
and
came
softly
after
me
.
<EOS>
---
Did
you
ever
see
me
run
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Many
a
time
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
never
saw
me
run
as
I
did
in
this

.
 
<EOS>
Still
it
came
creeping
on
to
worry
me
.
 
<EOS>
Nearer
,
nearer
,
nearer
<EOS>
---
I
ran
faster
---
 
leaped
---
<EOS>
sprung
out
of
bed
,
and
to
the
window
---
and
there
,
in
the
street
below
---
but
he
is
waiting
for
us
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
coming
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
in
the
street
below
,
Barnaby
?
"
said
Varden
,
imagining
that
he
traced
some
connection
between
this
vision
and
what
had
actually
occurred
.
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
looked
into
his
face
,
muttered
incoherently
,
waved
the
light
above
his
head
again
,
laughed
,
and
drawing
the
locksmith
's
arm
more
tightly
through
his
own
,
led
him
up
the
stairs
in
silence
.
  
<EOS>
They
entered
a
homely
bedchamber
,
garnished
in
a
scanty
way
with
chairs
,
whose
spindle
-
shanks
bespoke
their
age
,
and
other
furniture
of
very
little
worth
;
but
clean
and
neatly
kept
.
 
<EOS>
Reclining
in
an
easy
-
chair
before
the
fire
,
pale
and
weak
from
waste
of
blood
,
was
Edward
Chester
,
the
young
gentleman
who
had
been
the
first
to
quit
the
Maypole
on
the
previous
night
,
and
who
,
extending
his
hand
to
the
locksmith
,
welcomed
him
as
his
preserver
and
friend
.
  
<EOS>
"
Say
no
more
,
sir
,
say
no
more
,
"
said
Gabriel
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
would
have
done
at
least
as
much
for
any
man
in
such
a
strait
,
and
most
of
all
for
you
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
A
certain
young
lady
,
"
he
added
,
with
some

,
"
has
done
us
many
a
kind
turn
,
and
we
naturally
feel
---
I
hope
I
give
you
no
offence
in
saying
this
,
sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
young
man
smiled
and
shook
his
head
;
at
the
same
time
moving
in
his
chair
as
if
in
pain
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
no
great
matter
,
"
he
said
,
in

's

,
"
a
mere

arising
at
least

,

from

I

,
or

.
 
<EOS>
Be
seated
,
Mr
Varden
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
may
make
so
bold
,
Mr
Edward
,
as
to

chair
,
"

,

,
and
bending

,
"
<EOS>
I
'll
stand
here
for
the

speaking
low
.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
is
not
in
his
quietest
humour
to
-
night
,
and
at
such
times
talking
never
does
him
good
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
both
glanced
at
the
subject
of
this
remark
,
who
had
taken
a
seat
on
the
other
side
of
the
fire
,
and
,

,
was
making
puzzles
on
his

with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
tell
me
,
sir
,
"
said
Varden
,
dropping
his

still
lower
,
"
exactly
what
happened
last
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
my
reason
for
inquiring
.
<EOS>
You
left
the
Maypole
,
alone
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
walked
homeward
alone
,
until
I
had
nearly
reached
the
place
where
you
found
me
,
when
I
heard
the
gallop
of
a
horse
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Behind
you
?
"
said
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
yes
---
behind
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
single
rider
,
who
soon
overtook
me
,
and
checking
his
horse
,
inquired
the
way
to
London
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
on
the

,
sir
,
knowing
how
many
highwaymen
there
are
,
scouring

roads
in

?
"
said
Varden
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
,
but
I
had
only
a
stick
,

left
my

in
their
holster
-
case
with
the

's

.
 
<EOS>
I
directed
him
as
he
desired
.
 
<EOS>
Before
the

had
passed
my

,
he
rode
upon
me

,
as

on

down
beneath

horse
's

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
I

and

.
 
<EOS>
You
found
me
with
this
stab
and
an

,
and
without

---
in

he
found
little

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
Mr
Varden
,
"
he

,

,
"

,

"
  
<EOS>
"
Except
,
"
said
Gabriel
,

,

,
"
except
in
respect
of
the

.
 
<EOS>
What
like
was
he
,

?
 
<EOS>
Speak

,

.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
means
no

,
but
I
have
watched
him
oftener

you
,
and
I
know
,
little

you

,
that
he
's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It

's

to

to
this

,
for

Barnahy
possessed
,
seemed
to

game
,
to

all
other

.
 
<EOS>
Something

's

,
for

more

,
and
with

,
again

what
like

was
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
night
was
so
dark
,
"
said
Edward
,
"
the
attack
so

,
and
he
so
wrapped
and

,
that
I
can
hardly

.
 
<EOS>
It
seems
that
---
"
  
"
Do
n't
mention

,
sir
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
,
following

towards
Barnaby
;
"
I
know
HE
saw
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
know
what
YOU
saw
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
I
remember
is
,
"
said
Edward
,
"
that
as
he
checked
his
horse
his
hat
was
blown
off
.
 
<EOS>
He
caught
it
,
and
replaced
it
on
his
head
,
which
I
observed
was
bound
with
a
dark
handkerchief
.
 
<EOS>
A
stranger
entered
the
Maypole
while
I
was
there
,
whom
I
had
not
seen
---
<EOS>
for
I
had
sat
apart
for

my
own
---
and
when
I
rose
to

the
room
and
glanced

,
he
was
in
the

hidden

.
 
<EOS>
But
,
if
he
and
the
robber
were
two
different

,
their

were
strangely
and
most

;
for
directly
the
man
addressed

in

,
I
recognised
his
speech
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
as
I
feared
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
man
was
here
to
-
night
,
"
thought
the
locksmith
,
changing

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
dark
history
is
this
!
"
  
"
<EOS>
Halloa
!
"
cried
a
hoarse

in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Halloa
,
halloa
,
halloa
!
 
<EOS>
Bow
<EOS>
wow
<EOS>
wow
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
here
!
 
<EOS>
Hal
-
loa
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
speaker
---
who
made
the
locksmith
start
as
if

some

---
was
a
large

,
who
had

,

Edward
,
and
listened
with
a

and

,
to
all
they
had
said
up

this

;
turning
his

from
one
to
the
other
,
as
if
his
office
were
to
judge
between
them
,
and
it
were
of
the
very
last
importance
that
he
should
not
lose
a
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
at
him
!
"
<EOS>
said
Varden
,
divided
between
admiration
of
the
bird
and
a
kind
of
fear
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Was
there
ever
such
a
knowing
imp
as
that
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
he
's
a
dreadful
fellow
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
raven
,
with
his
head
very
much
on
one
side
,
and
his
bright

like

,
preserved
a

for
a

,
and
then

in

,
that

seemed
to
come
through

.
  
<EOS>
"
Halloa
,
halloa
,
halloa
!
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
here
!
 
<EOS>
Keep
up
your
spirits
.
 
<EOS>
Never
say
die
.
 
<EOS>
Bow
<EOS>
wow
<EOS>
wow
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
a
devil
<EOS>
,
I
'm
a
devil
,
I
'm
a
devil
.
 
<EOS>
Hurrah
!
"
<EOS>
---
And
then
,
as
if

in
his
infernal
character
,
he
began
to
whistle
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
more
than
half
believe
he
speaks
the
truth
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
I
do
,
"
said
Varden
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
see
how
he
looks
at
me
,
as
if
he
knew
what
I
was
saying
?
"
  
<EOS>
To
which
the
bird
,
balancing
himself
on
tiptoe
,
as
it
were
,
and
moving
his
body
up
and
down
in
a
sort

grave

,
rejoined
,
"
I
'm
a
devil
,
I
'm
a
devil
,
I
'm
a
devil
,
"
and
flapped
his
wings
against
his
sides
as
if
he
were
bursting
with
laughter
.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
clapped
his
hands
,
and
fairly
rolled
upon
the
ground
in
an
ecstasy
of
delight
.
  
<EOS>
"
Strange
companions
,
sir
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
shaking
his
head
,
and
looking
from
one
to
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
bird
has
all
the
wit
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Strange
indeed
!
<EOS>
"
said
Edward
,
holding
out
his
forefinger
to
the
raven
,
who
,
in
acknowledgment
of
the
attention
,
made
a
dive
at
it
immediately
with
his
iron
bill
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
he
old
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
mere
boy
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
hundred
and
twenty
,
or
thereabouts
.
 
<EOS>
Call
him
down
,
Barnaby
,
my
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Call
him
!
"
echoed
Barnaby
,
sitting
upright
upon
the
floor
,
and
staring
vacantly
at
Gabriel
,
as
he
thrust
his
hair
back
from
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
who
can
make
him
come
!
 
<EOS>
He
calls
me
,
and
makes
me
go
where
he
will
.
 
<EOS>
He
goes
on
before
,
and
I
follow
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
the
master
,
and
I
'm
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
Is
that
the
truth
,
Grip
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
raven
gave
a
short
,
comfortable
,
confidential
kind
of
croak
;
---
a
most
expressive
croak
,
which
seemed
to
say
,
"
You
need
n't
let
these
fellows
into
our
secrets
.
 
<EOS>
We
understand
each
other
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
right
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
make
HIM
come
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Barnaby
,
pointing
to
the
bird
.
 
<EOS>
"
Him
,
who
never
goes
to
sleep
,
or
so
much
as
winks
!
---
Why
,
any
time
of
night
,
you
may
see
his
eyes
in
my
dark
room
,
shining
like
two
sparks
.
 
<EOS>
And
every
night
,
and
all
night
too
,
he
's
broad
awake
,
talking
to
himself
,
thinking
what
he
shall
do
to
-
morrow
,
where
we
shall
go
,
and
what
he
shall
steal
,
and
hide
,
and
bury
.
 
<EOS>
I
make
HIM
come
!
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
"
  
<EOS>
On
second
thoughts
,
the
bird
appeared
disposed
to
come
of
himself
.
<EOS>
After
a
short
survey
of
the
ground
,
and
a
few

at

and
at
everybody
present
in
turn
,
he
fluttered
to
the
floor
,
and
went
to
Barnaby
---
not
in
a
hop
,
or
walk
,
or
run
,
but
in
a
pace
like
that
of
a
very
particular
gentleman
with

tight
boots
on
,
trying
to
walk
fast
over
loose

.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
stepping
into
his
extended
hand
,
and
condescending
to
be
held
out
at
arm
's
length
,
he
gave
vent
to
a
succession
of
sounds
,
not
unlike
the
drawing
of
some
eight
or
ten
dozen
of
long
corks
,
and
again
asserted
his
brimstone
birth
and

with
great
distinctness
.
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
shook
his
head
---
perhaps
in
some
doubt
of
the
creature
's
being
really
nothing
but
a

---
perhaps
in
pity
for
Bamaby
,
who
by
this
time

him
in

arms
,
and
was
rolling
about
,
with
him
,
on

.
 
<EOS>
As

from
the
poor
fellow

encountered

of
his
mother
,
who
had
entered
the
room
,
and
was
looking

.
  
<EOS>
She
was
quite
white
in
the

,
even
to

,
but
had
wholly

,
and

usual

.
 
<EOS>
Varden
fancied
as
he

that
she
shrunk
from
his
eye
;
and
that
she
busied

about
the
wounded
gentleman
to
avoid
him
the
better
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
time
he
went
to
bed
,
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
to
be
removed
to
his
own
home
on
the
morrow
,
and
he
had

,
by
a
full

.
 
<EOS>
Acting
on
this
hint
,
the
locksmith
prepared
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
By
the
bye
,
"
said
Edward
,
as

by

hand
,
and
looked

to
Mrs
Rudge
and
back

,
"
what
noise
was
that
below
?
<EOS>
I

,

should

.
 
<EOS>
What
was
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
looked
towards
her
,
and
bit
his
lip
.
 
<EOS>
She
leant

chair
,
and
bent

.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
too
---
 
<EOS>
he
was

.
   
<EOS>
---
"
Some
mad
or

fellow
,
sir
,
"
Varden
at

,
<EOS>
looking

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
mistook

,
and
tried

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
breathed

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
As

"
Good
night
,
"
and
Barnaby

,

,

---
 
with

than

slight

---
not

.
 
<EOS>
The
raven
followed
them
to

himself
that
all
was
right
below
,
and
when

the

,

.
  
<EOS>
With

unfastened

,
and
turned

.
 
<EOS>
As

her

,
the

,
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
told
a
lie
to
-
night
,
for
your

,
Mary
,
and

the

of
bygone

and
old

,
when
I
would
scorn
to
do
so
for
my
own
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
I
may
have
done
no
harm
,
or
led

none
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
help
the
suspicions
you
have
forced
upon
me
,
and
I

,
I
tell

,
to

Mr

here
.
 
<EOS>
Take

<EOS>
he
comes
to
no

.
 
<EOS>
I

the

of
this
roof
,
and
am

he
leaves
it
so
soon
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
let
me

.
"
  
<EOS>
For

hid

in

and

;
but
resisting

strong
impulse
which
evidently
moved

to

,
opened
the
door
---
no
wider
than
was
sufficient
for
the
passage
of
his

---
 
and
motioned

.
 
<EOS>
As
the
locksmith
stood
upon

step
,
it
was
chained

behind

,
and
the
raven
,
in

,
barked

.
  
<EOS>
"
In
league
with
that
ill
-
looking
figure
that
might
have
fallen
from
a
gibbet
---
he
listening
and
hiding
here
---
Barnaby
first
upon
the
spot
last
night
---
can
she
who
has
always
borne
so
fair
<EOS>
a
name
be
guilty
of
such

in
secret
!
"
said

,
musing
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heaven
forgive
me
if
I

,
and
send

just

;
but
she

,
the

may

great
,

we
daily
hear
of
things
as
strange
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Ay
,
bark

,
my

.
 
<EOS>
If
there
's
any
wickedness
going
on
,
that
raven
's
in
it
,
I
'll
be
sworn
.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
07
    
Mrs
Varden
was
a
lady
of
what
is
commonly
called
an
uncertain
temper
---
a
phrase
which
being
interpreted
signifies
a
temper
tolerably
certain
to
make
everybody
more
or
less
uncomfortable
.
<EOS>
Thus
it
generally
happened
,
that
when
other
people
were
merry
,
Mrs
Varden
was
dull
;
and
that
when
other
people
were
dull
,
Mrs
Varden
was
disposed
to
be
amazingly
cheerful
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
the
worthy
housewife
was
of
such
a
capricious
nature
,
that
she
not
only
attained
a
higher
pitch
of
genius
than
Macbeth
,
in
respect
of
her
ability
to
be
wise
,
amazed
,
temperate
and
furious
,
loyal
and
neutral
in
an
instant
,
but
would
sometimes
ring
the
changes
backwards
and
forwards
on
all
possible
moods
and
flights
in
one
short
quarter
of
an
hour
;
performing
,
as
it
were
,
a
kind
of
triple
bob
major
on
the
peal
of
instruments
in
the
female
belfry
,
with
a
skilfulness
and
rapidity
of
execution
that
astonished
all
who
heard
her
.
  
<EOS>
It
had
been
observed
in
this
good
lady
(
who
did
not
want
for
personal
attractions
,
being
plump
and
buxom
to
look
at
,
though
like
her
fair
daughter
,
somewhat
short
in
stature
)
that
this
uncertainty
of
disposition
strengthened
and
increased
with
her
temporal
prosperity
;
and
divers
wise
men
and
matrons
,
on
friendly
terms
with
the
locksmith
and
his
family
,
even
went
so
far
as
to
assert
,
that
a
tumble
down
some
half
-
dozen
rounds
in
the
world
's
ladder
---
such
as
the
breaking
of
the
bank
in
which
her
husband
kept
his
money
,
or
some
little
fall
of
that
kind
---
would
be
the
making
of
her
,
and
could
hardly
fail
to
render
her
one
of
the
most
agreeable
companions
in
existence
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
they
were
right
or
wrong
in
this
conjecture
,
certain
it
is
that
minds
,
like
bodies
,
will
often
fall
into
a
pimpled
ill
-
conditioned
state
from
mere
excess
of
comfort
,
and
like
them
,
are
often
successfully
cured
by
remedies
in
themselves
very
nauseous
and
unpalatable
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
's
chief
aider
and
abettor
,
and
at
the
same
time
her
principal
victim
and
object
of
wrath
,
was
her
single
domestic
servant
,
one
Miss
Miggs
;
or
as
she
was
called
,
in
conformity
with
those
prejudices
of
society
which
lop
and
top
from
poor
hand
-
maidens
<EOS>
all
such
genteel
excrescences
---
Miggs
.
 
<EOS>
This
Miggs
was
a
tall
young
lady
,
very
much
addicted
to
pattens
in
private
life
;
slender
and
shrewish
,
of
a
rather
uncomfortable
figure
,
and
though
not
absolutely
ill
-
looking
,
of
a
sharp
and
acid
visage
.
 
<EOS>
As
a
general
principle
and
abstract
proposition
,
Miggs
held
the
male
sex
to
be
utterly
contemptible
and
unworthy
of
notice
;
to
be
fickle
,
false
,
base
,
sottish
,
inclined
to
perjury
,
and
wholly
undeserving
.
<EOS>
When
particularly
exasperated
against
them
(
which
,
scandal
said
,
was
when
Sim
Tappertit
slighted
her
most
)
<EOS>
she
was
accustomed
to
wish
with
great
emphasis
that
the
whole
race
of
women
could
but
die
off
,
in
order
that
the
men
might
be
brought
to
know
the
real
value
of
the
blessings
by
which
they
set
so
little
store
;
nay
,
her
feeling
for
her
order
ran
so
high
,
that
she
sometimes
declared
,
if
she
could
only
have
good
security
for
a
fair
,
round
number
---
say
ten

---
of
young
virgins
following
her
example
,
she
would
,
to
spite
mankind
,
hang
,
drown
,
stab
,
or
poison
herself
,
with
a
joy
past
all
expression
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
voice
of
Miggs
that
greeted
the
locksmith
,
when
he

own

,

"
Who
's

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Me
,
girl
,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
What
,

,

!
"

<EOS>
"
We

.
 
<EOS>
Oh

!
"

's

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Master
's

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

"
<EOS>
---

"

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

Varden
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Here
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
,

,

,

,

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
Every

's

,

"
<EOS>
Yes
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
do

now
,

?
"

,

near

wife
(
who

)
,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're

,

?
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
,
that

not

,

!

<EOS>
"
My

---
"

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
turned

;

line
over
leaf

;
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

,
"

,

?
 
<EOS>
If

!
 
<EOS>
Why
,

the

,

,

?

<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Certainly

.
 
<EOS>
That
