you
would
be
hovering
round
me
like
a
vulture
,
waiting
till
the
breath
was
out
of
my
body
,
that
you
might
go
and
marry
somebody
else
.
"
  
<EOS>
Miggs
groaned
in
sympathy
---
a
little
short
groan
,
checked
in
its
birth
,
and
changed
into
a
cough
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
say
,
"
I
ca
n't
help
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
wrung
from
me
by
the
dreadful
brutality
of
that
monster
master
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
'll
break
my
heart
one
of
these
days
,
"
added
Mrs
Varden
,
with
more
resignation
,
"
and
then
we
shall
both
be
happy
.
 
<EOS>
My
only
desire
is
to
see
Dolly
comfortably
settled
,
and
when
she
is
,
you
may
settle
ME
as
soon
as
you
like
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Miggs
---
and
coughed
again
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
Gabriel
twisted
his
wig
about
in
silence
for
a
long
time
,
and
then
said
mildly
,
"
Has
Dolly
gone
to
bed
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
master
speaks
to
you
,
"
said
Mrs
Varden
,
looking
sternly
over
her
shoulder
at
Miss
Miggs
in
waiting
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
dear
,
I
spoke
to
you
,
"
suggested
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
hear
me
,
Miggs
?
"
cried
the
obdurate
lady
,
stamping
her
foot
upon
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
"
YOU
are
beginning
to
despise
me
now
,
are
you
?
 
<EOS>
But
this
is
example
!
"
  
<EOS>
At
this
cruel
rebuke
,
Miggs
,
whose
tears
were
always
ready
,
for
large
or
small
parties
,
on
the
shortest
notice
and
the
most
reasonable
terms
,
fell
a
crying
violently
;
holding
both
her
hands
tight
upon
her
heart
meanwhile
,
as
if
nothing
less
would
prevent
its
splitting
into
small
fragments
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
,
who
likewise
possessed
that
faculty
in
high
perfection
,
wept
too
,
against
Miggs
;
and
with
such
effect
that
Miggs
gave
in
after
a
time
,
and
,
except
for
an
occasional
sob
,
which
seemed
to
threaten
some
remote
intention
of
breaking
out
again
,
left
her
mistress
in
possession
of
the
field
.
 
<EOS>
Her
superiority
being
thoroughly
asserted
,
that
lady
soon
desisted
likewise
,
and
fell
into
a
quiet
melancholy
.
  
<EOS>
The
relief
was
so
great
,
and
the
fatiguing
occurrences
of
last
night
so
completely
overpowered
the
locksmith
,
that
he
nodded
in
his
chair
,
and
would
doubtless
have
slept
there
all
night
,
but
for
the
voice
of
Mrs
Varden
,
which
,
after
a
pause
of
some
five
minutes
,
awoke
him
with
a
start
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
am
ever
,
"
said
Mrs
V
---
not
scolding
,
but
in
a
sort
of
monotonous
remonstrance
---
"
in
spirits
,
<EOS>
if
I
am
ever
cheerful
,
if
I
am
ever
more
than
usually
disposed
to
be
talkative
and
comfortable
,
this
is
the
way
I
am
treated
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Such
spirits
as
you
was
in
too
,
mim
,
but
half
an
hour
ago
!
"
cried
Miggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
see
such
company
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
,
"
said
Mrs
Varden
,
"
because
I
never
interfere
or
interrupt
;
because
I
never
question
where
anybody
comes
or
goes
;
because
my
whole
mind
and
soul
is
bent
on
saving
where
I
can
save
,
and
labouring
in
this
house
;
---
therefore
,
they
try
me
as
they
do
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Martha
,
"
urged
the
locksmith
,
endeavouring
to
look
as
wakeful
as
possible
,
"
what
is
it
you
complain
of
?
 
<EOS>
I
really
came
home
with
every
wish
and
desire
to
be
happy
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
I
complain
of
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
a
chilling
thing
to
have
one
's
husband
sulking
and
falling
asleep
<EOS>
directly
he
comes
home
---
to
have
him
freezing
all
one
's
warm
-
heartedness
,
and
throwing
cold
water
over
the
fireside
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
natural
,
when
I
know
he
went
out
upon
a
matter
in
which
I
am
as
much
interested
as
anybody
can
be
,
that
I
should
wish
to
know
all
that
has
happened
,
or
that
he
should
tell
me
without
my
begging
and
praying
him
to
do
it
?
 
<EOS>
Is
that
natural
,
or
is
it
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sorry
,
Martha
,
"
said
the
good
-
natured
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
really
afraid
you
were
not
disposed
to
talk
pleasantly
;
I
'll
tell
you
everything
;
I
shall
only
be
too
glad
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Varden
,
"
returned
his
wife
,
rising
with
dignity
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
---
 
<EOS>
thank
you
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
not
a
child
to
be
corrected
one
minute
and
petted
the
next
---
I
'm
a
little
too
old
for
that
,
Varden
.
 
<EOS>
Miggs
,
carry
the
light
.
<EOS>
---
YOU
can
be
cheerful
,
Miggs
,
<EOS>
at
least
"
  
Miggs
,
who
,
to
this
moment
,
had
been
in
the
very
depths
of
compassionate
despondency
,
passed
instantly
into
the
liveliest
state
conceivable
,
and
tossing
her
head
as
she
glanced
towards
the
locksmith
,
bore
off
her
mistress
and
the
light
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
who
would
think
,
"
thought
Varden
,
shrugging
his
shoulders
and
drawing
his
chair
nearer
to
the
fire
,
"
that
that
woman
could
ever
be
pleasant
and
agreeable
?
 
<EOS>
And
yet
she
can
be
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
well
,
all
of
us
have
our
faults
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
not
be
hard
upon
hers
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
been
man
and
wife
too
long
for
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
dozed
again
---
not
the
less
pleasantly
,
perhaps
,
for
his
hearty
temper
.
 
<EOS>
While
his
eyes
were
closed
,
the
door
leading
to
the
upper
stairs
was
partially
opened
;
and
a
head
appeared
,
which
,
at
sight
of
him
,
hastily
drew
back
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
,
"
murmured
Gabriel
,
waking
at
the
noise
,
and
looking
round
the
room
,
"
I
wish
somebody
would
marry
Miggs
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
's
impossible
!
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
there
's
any
madman
alive
,
who
would
marry
Miggs
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
such
a
vast
speculation
that
he
fell
into
a
doze
again
,
and
slept
until
the
fire
was
quite
burnt
out
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
he
roused
himself
;
and
having
double
-
locked
the
street
-
door
according
to
custom
,
and
put
the
key
in
his
pocket
,
went
off
to
bed
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
left
the
room
in
darkness
many
minutes
,
when
the
head
again
appeared
,
and
Sim
Tappertit
entered
,
bearing
in
his
hand
a
little
lamp
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
business
has
he
to
stop
up
so
late
!
"
muttered
Sim
,
passing
into
the
workshop
,
and
setting
it
down
upon
the
forge
.
"
<EOS>
Here
's
half
the
night
gone
already
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
only
one
good
that
has
ever
come
to
me
,
out
of
this
cursed
old
rusty
mechanical
trade
,
and
that
's
this
piece
of
ironmongery
,
upon
my
soul
!
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
he
drew
from
the
right
hand
,
or
rather
right
leg
pocket
of
his
smalls
,
a
clumsy
large
-
sized
key
,
which
he
inserted
cautiously
in
the
lock
his
master
had
secured
,
and
softly
opened
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
That
done
,
he
replaced
his
piece
of
secret
workmanship
in
his
pocket
;
and
leaving
the
lamp
burning
,
and
closing
the
door
carefully
and
without
noise
,
stole
out
into
the
street
---
as
little
suspected
by
the
locksmith
in
his
sound
deep
sleep
,
as
by
Barnaby
himself
in
his
phantom
-
haunted
dreams
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
08
    
Clear
of
the
locksmith
's
house
<EOS>
,
Sim
Tappertit
laid
aside
his
cautious
manner
,
and
assuming
in
its
stead
that
of
a
ruffling
,
swaggering
,
roving
blade
,
who
would
rather
kill
a
man
than
otherwise
,
and
eat
him
too
if
needful
,
made
the
best
of
his
way
along
the
darkened
streets
.
  
<EOS>
Half
pausing
for
an
instant
now
and
then
to
smite
his
pocket
and
assure
himself
of
the
safety
of
his
master
key
,
he
hurried
on
to
Barbican
,
and
turning
into
one
of
the
narrowest
of
the
narrow
streets
which
diverged
from
that
centre
,
slackened
his
pace
and
wiped
his
heated
brow
,
as
if
the
termination
of
his
walk
were
near
at
hand
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
very
choice
spot
for
midnight
expeditions
,
being
in
truth
one
of
more
than
questionable
character
,
and
of
an
appearance
by
no
means
inviting
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
main
street
he
had
entered
,
itself
little
better
than
an
alley
,
a
low
-
browed
doorway
led
into
a
blind
court
,
or
yard
,
profoundly
dark
,
unpaved
,
and
reeking
with
stagnant
odours
.
 
<EOS>
Into
this
ill
-
favoured
pit
,
the
locksmith
's
vagrant
'
prentice
groped
his
way
;
and
stopping
at
a
house
from
whose
defaced
and
rotten
front
the
rude
effigy
of
a
bottle
swung
to
and
fro
like
some
gibbeted
malefactor
,
struck
thrice
upon
an
iron
grating
with
his
foot
.
 
<EOS>
After
listening
in
vain
for
some
response
to
his
signal
,
Mr
Tappertit
became
impatient
,
and
struck
the
grating
thrice
again
.
  
<EOS>
A
further
delay
ensued
,
but
it
was
not
of
long
duration
.
 
<EOS>
The
ground
seemed
to
open
at
his
feet
,
and
a
ragged
head
appeared
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
the
captain
?
"
said
a
voice
as
ragged
as
the
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
Mr
Tappertit
haughtily
,
descending
as
he
spoke
,
"
who
should
it
be
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
so
late
,
we
gave
you
up
,
"
returned
the
voice
,
as
its
owner
stopped
to
shut
and
fasten
the
grating
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
late
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lead
on
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
with
a
gloomy
majesty
,
"
and
make
remarks
when
I
require
you
.
 
<EOS>
Forward
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
latter
word
of
command
was
perhaps
somewhat
theatrical
and
unnecessary
,
inasmuch
as
the
descent
was
by
a
very
narrow
,
steep
,
and
slippery
flight
of
steps
,
and
any
rashness
or
departure
from
the
beaten
track
must
have
ended
in
a
yawning
water
-
butt
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Tappertit
being
,
like
some
other
great
commanders
,
favourable
to
strong
effects
,
and
personal
display
,
cried
"
Forward
!
"
<EOS>
again
,
in
the
hoarsest
voice
he
could
assume
;
and
led
the
way
,
with
folded
arms
and
knitted
brows
,
to
the
cellar
down
below
,
where
there
was
a
small
copper
fixed
in
one
corner
,
a
chair
or
two
,
a
form
and
table
,
a
glimmering
fire
,
and
a
truckle
-
bed
,
covered
with
a
ragged
patchwork
rug
.
  
<EOS>
"
Welcome
,
noble
captain
!
"
cried
a
lanky
figure
,
rising
as
from
a
nap
.
  
<EOS>
The
captain
nodded
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
throwing
off
his
outer
coat
,
he
stood
composed
in
all
his
dignity
,
and
eyed
his
follower
over
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
news
to
-
night
?
<EOS>
"
he
asked
,
when
he
had
looked
into
his
very
soul
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
particular
,
"
replied
the
other
,
stretching
himself
---
and
he
was
so
long
already
that
it
was
quite
alarming
to
see
him
do
it
<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>
"
how
come
you
to
be
so
late
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
matter
,
"
was
all
the
captain
deigned
to
say
in
answer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
the
room
prepared
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
replied
the
follower
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
comrade
---
is
he
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
And
a
sprinkling
of
the
others
---
you
hear
'
em
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Playing
skittles
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
captain
moodily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Light
-
hearted
revellers
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
no
doubt
respecting
the
particular
amusement
in
which
these
heedless
spirits
were
indulging
,
for
even
in
the
close
and
stifling
atmosphere
of
the
vault
,
the
noise
sounded
like
distant
thunder
.
 
<EOS>
It
certainly
appeared
,
at
first
sight
,
a
singular
spot
to
choose
,
for
that
or
any
other
purpose
of
relaxation
,
if
the
other
cellars
answered
to
the
one
in
which
this
brief
colloquy
took
place
;
for
the
floors
were
of
sodden
earth
,
the
walls
and
roof
of
damp
bare
brick
tapestried
with
the
tracks
of
snails
and
slugs
;
the
air
was
sickening
,
tainted
,
and
offensive
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
,
from
one
strong
flavour
which
was
uppermost
among
the
various
odours
of
the
place
,
that
it
had
,
at
no
very
distant
period
,
been
used
as
a
storehouse
for
cheeses
;
a
circumstance
which
,
while
it
accounted
for
the
greasy
moisture
that
hung
about
it
,
was
agreeably
suggestive
of
rats
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
naturally
damp
besides
,
and
little
trees
of
fungus
sprung
from
every
mouldering
corner
.
  
<EOS>
The
proprietor
of
this
charming
retreat
,
and
owner
of
the
ragged
head
before
mentioned
---
for
he
wore
an
old
tie
-
wig
as
bare
and
frowzy
as
a
stunted
hearth
-
broom
---
had
by
this
time
joined
them
;
and
stood
a
little
apart
,
rubbing
his
hands
,
wagging
his
hoary
bristled
chin
,
and
smiling
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
His
eyes
were
closed
;
but
had
they
been
wide
open
,
it
would
have
been
easy
to
tell
,
from
the
attentive
expression
of
the
face
he
turned
towards
them
---
pale
and
unwholesome
as
might
be
expected
in
one
of
his
underground
existence
---
and
from
a
certain
anxious
raising
and
quivering
of
the
lids
,
that
he
was
blind
.
  
<EOS>
"
Even
Stagg
hath
been
asleep
,
"
said
the
long
comrade
,
nodding
towards
this
person
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sound
,
captain
,
sound
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
blind
man
;
"
what
does
my
noble
captain
drink
---
is
it
brandy
,
rum
,
usquebaugh
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
soaked
gunpowder
,
or
blazing
oil
?
 
<EOS>
Give
it
a
name
,
heart
of
oak
,
and
we
'd
get
it
for
you
,
if
it
was
wine
from
a
bishop
's
cellar
,
or
melted
gold
from
King
George
's
mint
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
See
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
haughtily
,
"
that
it
's
something
strong
,
and
comes
quick
;
and
so
long
as
you
take
care
of
that
,
you
may
bring
it
from
the
devil
's
cellar
,
if
you
like
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Boldly
said
,
noble
captain
!
"
rejoined
the
blind
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Spoken
like
the
'
Prentices
'
Glory
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
From
the
devil
's
cellar
!
 
<EOS>
A
brave
joke
!
 
<EOS>
The
captain
joketh
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
  
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
,
my
fine
feller
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
eyeing
the
host
over
as
he
walked
to
a
closet
,
and
took
out
a
bottle
and
glass
as
carelessly
as
if
he
had
been
in
full
possession
of
his
sight
,
"
<EOS>
if
you
make
that
row
,
you
'll
find
that
the
captain
's
very
far
from
joking
,
and
so
I
tell
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
got
his
eyes
on
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Stagg
,
stopping
short
on
his
way
back
,
and
affecting
to
screen
his
face
with
the
bottle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
feel
'em
though
I
ca
n't
see
'em
.
 
<EOS>
Take
'em
off
,
noble
captain
.
 
<EOS>
Remove
'em
,
for
they
pierce
like
gimlets
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
smiled
grimly
at
his
comrade
;
and
twisting
out
one
more
look
---
a
kind
of
ocular
screw
---
under
the
influence
of
which
the
blind
man
feigned
to
undergo
great
anguish
and
torture
,
bade
him
,
in
a
softened
tone
,
approach
,
and
hold
his
peace
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
obey
you
,
captain
,
"
cried
Stagg
,
drawing
close
to
him
and
filling
out
a
bumper
without
spilling
a
drop
,
by
reason
that
he
held
his
little
finger
at
the
brim
of
the
glass
,
and
stopped
at
the
instant
the
liquor
touched
it
,
"
drink
,
noble
governor
.
 
<EOS>
Death
to
all
masters
,
life
to
all
'
prentices
,
and
love
to
all
fair
damsels
.
<EOS>
Drink
,
brave
general
,
and
warm
your
gallant
heart
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
condescended
to
take
the
glass
from
his
outstretched
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Stagg
then
dropped
on
one
knee
,
and
gently
smoothed
the
calves
of
his
legs
,
with
an
air
of
humble
admiration
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
I
had
but
eyes
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
"
to
behold
my
captain
's
symmetrical
proportions
!
 
<EOS>
That
I
had
<EOS>
but
eyes
,
to
look
upon
these
twin
invaders
of
domestic
peace
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Get
out
!
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
glancing
downward
at
his
favourite
limbs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
along
,
will
you
,
Stagg
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
touch
my
own
afterwards
,
"
cried
the
host
,
smiting
them
reproachfully
,
"
I
hate
'em
.
 
<EOS>
Comparatively
speaking
,
they
've
no
more
shape
than
wooden
legs
,
beside
these
models
of
my
noble
captain
's
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yours
!
"
exclaimed
Mr
Tappertit
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
should
think
not
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
talk
about
those
precious
old
toothpicks
in
the
same
breath
with
mine
;
that
's
rather
too
much
.
 
<EOS>
Here
.
 
<EOS>
Take
the
glass
.
 
<EOS>
Benjamin
.
<EOS>
Lead
on
.
 
<EOS>
To
business
!
"
  
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
he
folded
his
arms
again
;
and
frowning
with
a
sullen
majesty
,
passed
with
his
companion
through
a
little
door
at
the
upper
end
of
the
cellar
,
and
disappeared
;
leaving
Stagg
to
his
private
meditations
.
  
<EOS>
The
vault
they
entered
,
strewn
with
sawdust
and
dimly
lighted
,
was
between
the
outer
one
from
which
they
had
just
come
,
and
that
in
which
the
skittle
-
players
were
diverting
themselves
;
as
was
manifested
by
the
increased
noise
and
clamour
of
tongues
,
which
was
suddenly
stopped
,
however
,
and
replaced
by
a
dead
silence
,
at
a
signal
from
the
long
comrade
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
this
young
gentleman
,
going
to
a
little
cupboard
,
returned
with
a
thigh
-
bone
,
which
in
former
times
must
have
been
part
and
parcel
of
some
individual
at
least
as
long
as
himself
,
and
placed
the
same
in
the
hands
of
Mr
Tappertit
;
who
,
receiving
it
as
a
sceptre
and
staff
of
authority
,
cocked
his
three
-
cornered
hat
fiercely
on
the
top
of
his
head
,
and
mounted
a
large
table
,
whereon
a
chair
of
state
,
cheerfully
ornamented
with
a
couple
of
skulls
,
was
placed
ready
for
his
reception
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
no
sooner
assumed
this
position
,
than
another
young
gentleman
appeared
,
bearing
in
his
arms
a
huge
clasped
book
,
who
made
him
a
profound
obeisance
,
and
delivering
it
to
the
long
comrade
,
advanced
to
the
table
,
and
turning
his
back
upon
it
,
stood
there
Atlas
-
wise
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
the
long
comrade
got
upon
the
table
too
;
and
seating
himself
in
a
lower
chair
than
Mr
Tappertit
's
,
with
much
state
and
ceremony
,
placed
the
large
book
on
the
shoulders
of
their
mute
companion
as
deliberately
as
if
he
had
been
a
wooden
desk
,
and
prepared
to
make
entries
therein
with
a
pen
of
corresponding
size
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
long
comrade
had
made
these
preparations
,
he
looked
towards
Mr
Tappertit
;
and
Mr
Tappertit
,
flourishing
the
bone
,
knocked
nine
times
therewith
upon
one
of
the
skulls
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
ninth
stroke
,
a
third
young
gentleman
emerged
from
the
door
leading
to
the
skittle
ground
,
and
bowing
low
,
awaited
his
commands
.
  
<EOS>
"
'
Prentice
!
"
said
the
mighty
captain
,
"
who
waits
without
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
'
prentice
made
answer
that
a
stranger
was
in
attendance
,
who
claimed
admission
into
that
secret
society
of
'
Prentice
Knights
,
and
a
free
participation
in
their
rights
,
privileges
,
and
immunities
.
 
<EOS>
Thereupon
Mr
Tappertit
flourished
the
bone
again
,
and
giving
the
other
skull
a
prodigious
rap
on
the
nose
,
exclaimed
"
Admit
him
!
"
 
<EOS>
At
these
dread
words
the
'
prentice
bowed
once
more
,
and
so
withdrew
as
he
had
come
.
  
<EOS>
There
soon
appeared
at
the
same
door
,
two
other
'
prentices
,
having
between
them
a
third
,
whose
eyes
were
bandaged
,
and
who
was
attired
in
a
bag
-
wig
,
and
a
broad
-
skirted
coat
,
trimmed
with
tarnished
lace
;
and
who
was
girded
with
a
sword
,
in
compliance
with
the
laws
of
the
Institution
regulating
the
introduction
of
candidates
,
which
required
them
to
assume
this
courtly
dress
,
and
kept
it
constantly
in
lavender
,
for
their
convenience
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
the
conductors
of
this
novice
held
a
rusty
blunderbuss
pointed
towards
his
ear
,
and
the
other
a
very
ancient
sabre
,
with
which
he
carved
imaginary
offenders
as
he
came
along
in
a
sanguinary
and
anatomical
manner
.
  
<EOS>
As
this
silent
group
advanced
,
Mr
Tappertit
fixed
his
hat
upon
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
The
novice
then
laid
his
hand
upon
his
breast
and
bent
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
humbled
himself
sufficiently
,
the
captain
ordered
the
bandage
to
be
removed
,
and
proceeded
to
eye
him
over
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
"
said
the
captain
,
thoughtfully
,
when
he
had
concluded
this
ordeal
.
 
<EOS>
"
Proceed
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
long
comrade
read
aloud
as
follows
:
---
"
Mark
Gilbert
.
 
<EOS>
Age
,
nineteen
.
 
<EOS>
Bound
to
Thomas
Curzon
,
hosier
,
Golden
Fleece
,
Aldgate
.
<EOS>
Loves
Curzon
's
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
Can
not
say
that
Curzon
's
daughter
loves
him
.
 
<EOS>
Should
think
it
probable
.
 
<EOS>
Curzon
pulled
his
ears
last
Tuesday
week
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
!
"
cried
the
captain
,
starting
.
  
<EOS>
"
For
looking
at
his
daughter
,
please
you
,
"
said
the
novice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Write
Curzon
down
,
Denounced
,
"
said
the
captain
.
 
<EOS>
"
Put
a
black
cross
against
the
name
of
Curzon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
please
you
,
"
said
the
novice
,
<EOS>
"
that
's
not
the
worst
---
he
calls
his
'
prentice
idle
dog
,
and
stops
his
beer
unless
he
works
to
his
liking
.
 
<EOS>
He
gives
Dutch
cheese
,
too
,
eating
Cheshire
,
sir
,
himself
;
and
Sundays
out
,
are
only
once
a
month
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
gravely
,
"
is
a
flagrant
case
.
 
<EOS>
Put
two
black
crosses
to
the
name
of
Curzon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
the
society
,
"
said
the
novice
,
who
was
an
ill
-
looking
,
one
-
sided
,
shambling
lad
,
with
sunken
eyes
set
close
together
in
his
head
---
"
if
the
society
would
burn
his
house
down
---
for
he
's
not
insured
---
or
beat
him
as
he
comes
home
from
his
club
at
night
,
or
help
me
to
carry
off
his
daughter
,
and
marry
her
at
the
Fleet
,
whether
she
gave
consent
or
no
---
"
  
Mr
Tappertit
waved
his
grizzly
truncheon
as
an
admonition
to
him
not
to
interrupt
,
and
ordered
three
black
crosses
to
the
name
of
Curzon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Which
means
,
"
he
said
in
gracious
explanation
,
"
vengeance
,
complete
and
terrible
.
 
<EOS>
'
Prentice
,
do
you
love
the
Constitution
?
"
  
<EOS>
To
which
the
novice
(
being
to
that
end
instructed
by
his
attendant
sponsors
)
replied
"
I
do
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
Church
,
the
State
,
and
everything
established
---
but
the
masters
?
"
quoth
the
captain
.
  
<EOS>
Again
the
novice
said
"
I
do
.
"
  
<EOS>
Having
said
it
,
he
listened
meekly
to
the
captain
,
who
in
an
address
prepared
for
such
occasions
,
told
him
how
that
under
that
same
Constitution
(
which
was
kept
in
a
strong
box
somewhere
,
but
where
exactly
he
could
not
find
out
,
or
he
would
have
endeavoured
to
procure
a
copy
of
it
)
,
the
'
prentices
had
,
in
times
gone
by
,
had
frequent
holidays
of
right
,
broken
people
's
heads
by
scores
,
defied
their
masters
,
nay
,
even
achieved
some
glorious
murders
in
the
streets
,
which
privileges
had
gradually
been
wrested
from
them
,
and
in
all
which
noble
aspirations
they
were
now
restrained
;
how
the
degrading
checks
imposed
upon
them
were
unquestionably
attributable
to
the
innovating
spirit
of
the
times
,
and
how
they
united
therefore
to
resist
all
change
,
except
such
change
as
would
restore
those
good
old
English
customs
,
by
which
they
would
stand
or
fall
.
 
<EOS>
After
illustrating
the
wisdom
of
going
backward
,
by
reference
to
that
sagacious
fish
,
the
crab
,
and
the
not
unfrequent
practice
of
the
mule
and
donkey
,
he
described
their
general
objects
;
which
were
briefly
vengeance
on
their
Tyrant
Masters
(
of
whose
grievous
and
insupportable
oppression
no
'
prentice
could
entertain
a
moment
's
doubt
)
and
the
restoration
,
as
aforesaid
,
of
their
ancient
rights
and
holidays
;
for
neither
of
which
objects
were
they
now
quite
ripe
,
being
barely
twenty
strong
,
but
which
they
pledged
themselves
to
pursue
with
fire
and
sword
when
needful
.
<EOS>
Then
he
described
the
oath
which
every
member
of
that
small
remnant
of
a
noble
body
took
,
and
which
was
of
a
dreadful
and
impressive
kind
;
binding
him
,
at
the
bidding
of
his
chief
,
to
resist
and
obstruct
the
Lord
Mayor
,
sword
-
bearer
,
and
chaplain
;
to
despise
the
authority
of
the
sheriffs
;
and
to
hold
the
court
of
aldermen
as
nought
;
but
not
on
any
account
,
<EOS>
in
case
the
fulness
of
time
should
bring
a
general
rising
of
'
prentices
,
to
damage
or
in
any
way
disfigure
Temple
Bar
,
which
was
strictly
constitutional
and
always
to
be
approached
with
reverence
.
 
<EOS>
Having
gone
over
these
several
heads
with
great
eloquence
and
force
,
and
having
further
informed
the
novice
that
this
society
had
its
origin
in
his
own
teeming
brain
,
stimulated
by
a
swelling
sense
of
wrong
and
outrage
,
Mr
Tappertit
demanded
whether
he
had
strength
of
heart
to
take
the
mighty
pledge
required
,
or
whether
he
would
withdraw
while
retreat
was
yet
in
his
power
.
  
<EOS>
To
this
the
novice
made
rejoinder
,
that
he
would
take
the
vow
,
though
it
should
choke
him
;
and
it
was
accordingly
administered
with
many
impressive
circumstances
,
among
which
the
lighting
up
of
the
two
skulls
with
a
candle
-
end
inside
of
each
,
and
a
great
many
flourishes
with
the
bone
,
were
chiefly
conspicuous
;
not
to
mention
a
variety
of
grave
exercises
with
the
blunderbuss
and
sabre
,
and
some
dismal
groaning
by
unseen
'
prentices
without
.
 
<EOS>
All
these
dark
and
direful
ceremonies
being
at
length
completed
,
the
table
was
put
aside
,
the
chair
of
state
removed
,
the
sceptre
locked
up
in
its
usual
cupboard
,
the
doors
of
communication
between
the
three
cellars
thrown
freely
open
,
and
the
'
Prentice
Knights
resigned
themselves
to
merriment
.
  
<EOS>
But
Mr
Tappertit
,
who
had
a
soul
above
the
vulgar
herd
,
and
who
,
on
account
of
his
greatness
,
could
only
afford
to
be
merry
now
and
then
,
threw
himself
on
a
bench
with
the
air
of
a
man
who
was
faint
with
dignity
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
with
an
indifferent
eye
,
alike
on
skittles
,
cards
,
and
dice
,
thinking
only
of
the
locksmith
's
daughter
,
and
the
base
degenerate
days
on
which
he
had
fallen
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
noble
captain
neither
games
,
nor
sings
,
nor
dances
,
"
said
his
host
,
taking
a
seat
beside
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Drink
,
gallant
general
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
drained
the
proffered
goblet
to
the
dregs
;
then
thrust
his
hands
into
his
pockets
,
and
with
a
lowering
visage
walked
among
the
skittles
,
while
his
followers
(
such
is
the
influence
of
superior
genius
)
restrained
the
ardent
ball
,
and
held
his
little
shins
in
dumb
respect
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
been
born
a
corsair
or
a
pirate
,
a
brigand
,
genteel
highwayman
or
patriot
---
and
they
're
the
same
thing
,
"
thought
Mr
Tappertit
,
musing
among
the
nine
-
pins
,
"
I
should
have
been
all
right
.
 
<EOS>
But
to
drag
out
a
ignoble
existence
unbeknown
to
mankind
in
general
---
patience
!
 
<EOS>
I
will
be
famous
yet
.
 
<EOS>
A
voice
within
me
keeps
on
whispering
Greatness
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
burst
out
one
of
these
days
,
and
when
I
do
,
what
power
can
keep
me
down
?
 
<EOS>
I
feel
my
soul
getting
into
my
head
at
the
idea
.
 
<EOS>
More
drink
there
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
novice
,
"
pursued
Mr
Tappertit
,
not
exactly
in
a
voice
of
thunder
,
for
his
tones
,
to
say
the
truth
were
rather
cracked
and
shrill
---
but
very
impressively
,
notwithstanding
---
<EOS>
"
where
is
he
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Here
,
noble
captain
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Stagg
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
stands
beside
me
who
I
feel
is
a
stranger
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Have
you
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
letting
his

fall
on
the
party
<EOS>
indicated
,
who
was
indeed
the
new

,

to

own

;
"
Have

the
impression
of
your
street
-
door
key
in
wax
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
long
comrade
anticipated
the
reply
,
by
producing
it
from
the
shelf
on
which
it
had
been
deposited
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
scrutinising

,
while
a
breathless

reigned
around
;
for
he
had
constructed
secret
door
-
keys
for
the
whole
society
,
and
perhaps
owed
something
of
his
influence
to
that
mean
and
trivial
circumstance
---
on
such
slight
accidents
do
even
men
of
mind
depend
!
<EOS>
---
"
This
is
easily
made
.
 
<EOS>
Come
hither
,
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
,
he
beckoned
the
new
knight
apart
,
and
putting
the
pattern
in

,
motioned
to

to
walk
by

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
,
"
he

,
when
they

down
,
you
---
you
love
your
master
's
daughter
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
said
the
'
prentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Honour
bright
.
 
<EOS>
No
chaff
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Have
you
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Tappertit
,
catching

,
and
giving

which
would

expressive
of
the
most

,
but
for
an
accidental

rather

;
"

a
---
a
rival
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
as
I
know
on
,
"

the
'

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
now
---
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
---
"
what
would
you
---
eh
?
---
"
  
The
'
prentice
looked
fierce
and
clenched
his
fists
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
enough
,
"
cried
Mr
Tappertit
hastily
,
"
we
understand
each

.
 
<EOS>
We
are
observed
.
 
<EOS>
I
thank
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So

,
he
cast
him

;
and
calling

long
comrade
aside
after
taking
a

,
bade

immediately
write
and
post
against
the
wall
,
a

,
proscribing
one
Joseph
Willet
(
commonly
known
as
Joe
)
of
Chigwell
;
forbidding
all
'
Prentice
Knights
to

,

,

;
and
requiring

,
on
pain
of

,
to
molest
,
hurt
,
wrong
,
annoy
,
and
pick
quarrels
with
the
said
Joseph
,
whensoever
and
wheresoever
they
,
or
any
of
them
,
should
happen
to
encounter

.
  
<EOS>
Having
relieved
his
mind
by
this
energetic
proceeding
,
he
condescended
to
approach
the
festive
board
,
and
warming
by
degrees
,
at
length
deigned
to
preside
,
and
even
to
enchant
the
company
with
a
song
.
 
<EOS>
After
this
,
he
rose
to
such
a
pitch
as
to
consent
to
regale
the
society
with
a
hornpipe
,
which
be
actually
performed
to
the
music
of
a
fiddle
(
played
by
an
ingenious
member
)
with
such
surpassing
agility
and
brilliancy
of
execution
,
that
the
spectators
could
not
be
sufficiently
enthusiastic
in
their
admiration
;
and
their
host
protested
,
with
tears
in
his
eyes
,
that
he
had
never
truly
felt
his
blindness
until
that
moment
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
host
withdrawing
---
probably
to
weep
in
secret
---
soon
returned
with
the
information
that
it
wanted
little
more
than
an
hour
of
day
,
and
that
all
the
cocks
in
Barbican
had
already
begun
to
crow
,
as
if
their
lives
depended
on
it
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
intelligence
,
the
'
Prentice
Knights
arose
in
haste
,
and
marshalling
into
a
line
,
filed
off
one
by
one
and
dispersed
with
all
speed
to
their
several
homes
,
leaving
their
leader
to
pass
the
grating
last
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
noble
captain
,
"
whispered
the
blind
man
as
he
held
it
open
for
his
passage
out
;
"
Farewell
,
brave
general
.
 
<EOS>
Bye
,
bye
,
illustrious
commander
.
 
<EOS>
Good
luck
go
with
you
for
a
---
conceited
,
bragging
,
empty
-
headed
,
duck
-
legged
idiot
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
which
parting
words
,
coolly
added
as
he
listened
to
his
receding
footsteps
and
locked
the
grate
upon
himself
,
he
descended
the
steps
,
and
lighting
the
fire
below
the
little
copper
,
prepared
,
without
any
assistance
,
for
his
daily
occupation
;
which
was
to
retail
at
the
area
-
head
above
pennyworths
of
broth
and
soup
,
and
savoury
puddings
,
compounded
of
such
scraps
as
were
to
be
bought
in
the
heap
for
the
least
money
at
Fleet
Market
in
the
evening
time
;
and
for
the
sale
of
which
he
had
need
to
have
depended
chiefly
on
his
private
connection
,
for
the
court
had
no
thoroughfare
,
and
was
not
that
kind
of
place
in
which
many
people
were
likely
to
take
the
air
,
or
to
frequent
as
an
agreeable
promenade
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
09
    
Chronicler
's
are
privileged
to
enter
where
they
list
,
to
come
and
go
through
keyholes
,
to
ride
upon
the
wind
,
to
overcome
,
in
their
soarings
up
and
down
,
all
obstacles
of
distance
,
time
,
and
place
.
<EOS>
Thrice
blessed
be
this
last
consideration
,
since
it
enables
us
to
follow
the
disdainful
Miggs
even
into
the
sanctity
of
her
chamber
,
and
to
hold
her
in
sweet
companionship
through
the
dreary
watches
of
the
night
!
  
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
,
having
undone
her
mistress
,
as
she
phrased
it
(
which
means
,
assisted
to
undress
her
)
,
and
having
seen
her
comfortably
to
bed
in
the
back
room
on
the
first
floor
,
withdrew
to
her
own
apartment
,
in
the
attic
story
.
 
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
her
declaration
in
the
locksmith
's
presence
,
she
was
in
no
mood
for
sleep
;
so
,
putting
her
light
upon
the
table
and
withdrawing
the
little
window
curtain
,
she
gazed
out
pensively
at
the
wild
night
sky
.
  
<EOS>
Perhaps
she
wondered
what
star
was
destined
for
her
habitation
when
she
had
run
her
little
course
below
;
perhaps
speculated
which
of
those
glimmering
spheres
might
be
the
natal
orb
of
Mr
Tappertit
;
perhaps
marvelled
how
they
could
gaze
down
on
that
perfidious
creature
,
man
,
and
not
sicken
and
turn
green
as
chemists
'

;
perhaps
thought
of
nothing
in
particular
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
she
thought
about
,
there
she
sat
,
until
her
attention
,
alive
to
anything
connected
with
the
insinuating
'

,
was

by
a

in
the
next
room
to
her

---
his
room
;
the
room
in
which
he
slept
,
and
dreamed
---
it
might
be
,
sometimes
dreamed
of
her
.
  
<EOS>
That
he
was
not
dreaming
now
,
unless
he
was
taking
a
walk
in
his
sleep
,
was
clear
,
for
every
now
<EOS>
and
then
there
came
a
shuffling
noise
,
as
though
he
were
engaged
in
polishing
the
whitewashed
wall
;
then

of
his
door
;
then
the
faintest
indication
of
his
stealthy
footsteps
on
the
landing
-
place
outside
.
 
<EOS>
Noting
this
latter
circumstance
,
Miss
Miggs
turned
pale
and
shuddered
,
as
mistrusting
his
intentions
;
and
more
than
once
exclaimed
,
below
her

,
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
what
a
Providence
<EOS>
it
is
,
as
I
am
bolted
in
!
"
---
which
,
owing
doubtless
to
her
alarm
,
was
a

of
ideas
on
her
part
between
a
bolt
and
its
use
;
for
though
there
was
one
on
the
door
,
it
was
not
fastened
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
's
sense
of
hearing
,
however
,
having
as
sharp
an
edge
as
her
temper
,
and
being
of
the
same
snappish
and
suspicious
kind
,
very
soon
informed
her
that
the
footsteps
passed
her
door
,
and
appeared
to
have
some
object
quite
separate
and
disconnected
from
herself
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
discovery
she
became
more
alarmed
than
ever
,
and
was
about
to
give
utterance
to
those
cries
of
"
Thieves
!
"
and
"
Murder
!
"
<EOS>
which
she
had
hitherto
restrained
,
when
it
occurred
to
her
to
look
softly
out
,
and
see
that
her
fears
had
some
good
palpable
foundation
.
  
<EOS>
Looking
out
accordingly
,
and
stretching
her
neck
over
the
handrail
,
she
descried
,
to
her
great

,
Mr
Tappertit
completely
dressed
,
stealing
downstairs
,
<EOS>
one
step
at
a
time
,
with
his
shoes
in
one

and
a
lamp
in

other
.
 
<EOS>
Following

with
her
eyes
,
and
going
down
a
little
way
herself
to
get
the
better
of
an
intervening
angle
,
she
beheld
him
thrust
his
head
in
at
the
parlour
-
door
,
draw
it
back
again
with
great
swiftness
,
and
immediately
begin
a
retreat
upstairs
with
all
possible
expedition
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
's
mysteries
!
"
said
the
damsel
,
when
she
was
safe
in
her
own
room
again
,
quite
out
of
breath
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
gracious
,
here
's
mysteries
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
prospect
of
finding
anybody
out
in
anything
,
would
have
kept
Miss
Miggs
awake
under
the
influence
of
henbane
.
 
<EOS>
Presently
,
she
heard
the
step
again
,
as
she
would
have
done
if
it
had
been
that
of
a
feather
endowed
with

and

down
on

.
 
<EOS>
Then
gliding
out
as
before
,
she
again

the
retreating

of
the
'
prentice
;
again
he
looked
cautiously
in
at
the
parlour
-
door
,
but
this
time
instead
of
retreating
,
he
passed
in
and
disappeared
.
  
<EOS>
Miggs
was
back
in
her
room
,
and
had
her
head
out
of
the
window
,
before
an
elderly
gentleman
could
have
winked
and
recovered
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
Out
he
came
at
the
street
-
door
,
shut
it
carefully
behind
him
,
tried
it
with
his
knee
,
and
swaggered
off
,
putting
something
in
his
pocket
as
he
went
along
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
spectacle
Miggs
cried
"
Gracious
!
"
<EOS>
again
,
and
then
"
Goodness
gracious
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
"
Goodness
gracious
me
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
,
candle
in
hand
,
went
downstairs
as
he
had
done
.
<EOS>
Coming
to
the
workshop
,
she
saw
the
lamp
burning
on
the
forge
,
and
everything
as
Sim
had
left
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
I
wish
I
may
only
have
a
walking

,
and
never
be
buried
decent
with
a

-
coach
and
feathers
,
if
the
boy
has
n't
been
and
made
a
key
for
his
own
self
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Miggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
the
little
villain
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
conclusion
was
not
arrived
at
without
consideration
,
and
much
peeping
and
peering
about
;
nor
was
it
unassisted
by
the
recollection
that
she
had
on
several
occasions
<EOS>
come
upon
the
'
prentice
suddenly
,
and
found
him
busy
at
some

.
 
<EOS>
Lest

fact
of
Miss
Miggs
calling
him
,
on
whom

to
cast
a
favourable

,
a
boy
,
should
create
surprise
in
any
breast
,
it
may
be
observed
that
she
invariably
affected
to
regard
all
male
bipeds
under
thirty
as
mere
chits
and
infants
;
which
phenomenon
is
not
unusual
in
ladies
of
Miss
Miggs
's
temper
,
and
is
indeed
generally
found
to
be
the
associate
of
such
indomitable
and
savage
virtue
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
deliberated
within
herself
for
some
little
time
,
looking
hard
at
the
shop
-
door
while
she
did
so
,
as
though
her
eyes
and
thoughts
were
both
upon
it
;
and
then
,
taking
a
sheet
of
paper
from
a
drawer
,
twisted
it
into
a
long
thin
spiral
tube
.
 
<EOS>
Having
filled
this
instrument
with
a
quantity
of
small
coal
-
dust
from
the
forge
,
she
approached
the
door
,
and
dropping
on
one
knee
before
it
,
dexterously
blew
into
the
keyhole
as
much
of
these
fine
ashes
as
the
lock
would
hold
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
filled
it
to
the
brim
in
a
very
workmanlike
and
skilful
manner
,
she
crept
upstairs
again
,
and
chuckled
as
she
went
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
cried
Miggs
,
rubbing
her
hands
,
"
now
let
's
see
whether
you
wo
n't
be
glad
to
take
some
notice
of
me
,
mister
.
 
<EOS>
He
,
he
,
he
!
<EOS>
You
'll
have
eyes
for
somebody
besides
Miss
Dolly
now
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
A
fat
-
faced
puss
she
is
,
<EOS>
as
ever
I
come
across
!
"
  
<EOS>
As
she
uttered
this
criticism
,
she
glanced
approvingly
at
her
small
mirror
,
as
who
should
say
,
I
thank
my
stars
that
ca
n't
be
said
of
me
!
<EOS>
---
as
it
certainly
could
not
;
for
Miss
Miggs
's
style
of
beauty
was
of
that
kind
which
Mr
Tappertit
himself
had
not
inaptly
termed
,
in
private
,
"
scraggy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
go
to
bed
this
night
!
"
<EOS>
said
Miggs
,
wrapping
herself
in
a
shawl
,
and
drawing
a
couple
of
chairs
near
the
window
,
flouncing
down
upon
one
,
and
putting
her
feet
upon
the
other
,
"
till
you
come
home
,
my
lad
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
,
"
said
Miggs
viciously
,
"
no
,
not
for
five
-
and
-
forty
pound
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
,
and
with
an
expression
of
face
in
which
a
great
number
of
opposite
ingredients
,
such
as
mischief
,
cunning
,
malice
,
triumph
,
and
patient
expectation
,
were
all
mixed
up
together
in
a
kind
of
physiognomical
punch
,
Miss
Miggs
composed
herself
to
wait
and
listen
,
like
some
fair
ogress
who
had
set
a
trap
and
was
watching
for
a
nibble
from
a
plump
young
traveller
.
  
<EOS>
She
sat
there
,
with
perfect
composure
,
all
night
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
just
upon
break
of
day
,
there
was
a
footstep
in
the
street
,
and
presently
she
could
hear
Mr
Tappertit
stop
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
could
make
out
that
he
tried
his
key
---
that
he
was
blowing
into
it
---
 
that
he
knocked
it
on
the
nearest
post
to
beat
the
dust
out
---
that
he
took
it
under
a
lamp
to
look
at
it
---
that
he
poked
bits
of
stick
into
the
lock
to
clear
it
---
that
he
peeped
into
the
keyhole
,
first
with
one
eye
,
and
then
with
the
other
---
that
he
tried
the
key
again
---
 
that
he
could
n't
turn
it
,
and
what
was
worse
<EOS>
,
could
n't
get

out
---
 
that
he
bent
it
---
<EOS>
that
then
it
was
much
less
disposed
to
come
out
than
before
---
that

a
mighty

,
and
then
it
came
out
so

that
he

---
that

---
that
he

---
finally
,
that

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
When

had

,
Miss
Miggs
,

,
and

-

,
put

,
and
demanded
in
a
faint
voice
who
was
there
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
cried
"
Hush
!
"
<EOS>
and
,
backing
to
the
road
,
exhorted
her
in
frenzied

to

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
one
thing
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
thieves
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
---
no
---
no
!
"
cried
Mr
Tappertit
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
said
Miggs
,
more

,
"
it
's
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Where
is
it
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
near
this
room
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
a
good
conscience
,
sir
,
and
would
much
rather
die
than
go
down
a

.
 
<EOS>
All
I
wish
is
,
respecting

love

my

,
Golden
Lion
Court
,
number
twenty
-
sivin
,
second
bell
-

right

door

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Miggs
!
"
cried

Tappertit
,
"
do

?
 
<EOS>
Sim
,
you
know
---
 
Sim
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
what
about
him
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Is

?
 
<EOS>
Is

the

and

!
 
<EOS>
Oh

,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why

,

<EOS>
I
?
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

?
 
<EOS>
What

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
---
so
it
---
 
Goodness
,
what

the
meaning
of
---
<EOS>
If

,
mim
,

---
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
!
"
cried
Mr
Tappertit
,
standing

,
as
if
by
that
means
he
,
in

street
,
were
any

Miggs

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

!
<EOS>
---

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
Come

,

,
that

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
dursn't

,
Simmun
,
"
cried

---
for

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
dursn't
do
it
,

.
<EOS>
You
know

,

.
 
<EOS>
And
to
come
down
in
the
dead

,
when
the

is
wrapped
in

and

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
there

and

,
for
her

caught
cold

very

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
Miggs
,
"
cried
Mr
Tappertit
,
getting
under
the
lamp
,
that
she
might
see
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
My
darling
Miggs
---
"
  
Miggs
screamed
slightly
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
That
I
love
so
much
,
and
never
can
help
thinking
of
,
"
and
it
is

---
"
do
---

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
Simmun
,
"

,
"
this

.
 
<EOS>
I
know

I
come

,
you
'll

,

---
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
what
,
my

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

,
"
said

,

,
"
to
kiss

,
or
some
such

;
I

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

wo
n't
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
with

.
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
soul
I
wo
n't
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
getting
broad
day
,
and
the
watchman
's
waking
up
.
 
<EOS>
Angelic
Miggs
!
 
<EOS>
If
you
'll
only
come
and
let
me
in
,
I
promise
you
faithfully
and
truly
I
wo
n't
.
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
,
whose
gentle
heart
was
touched
,
did
not
wait
for
the
oath
(
knowing
how
strong

was
,
and
fearing

might
forswear

)
,

lightly

,
and
with
her
own
fair
hands
drew
back
the
rough

of
the
workshop
window
.
 
<EOS>
Having
helped
the
wayward
'
prentice
in
,
she
faintly
articulated
the
words
"
Simmun
is
safe
!
"
<EOS>
and
yielding
to
her
woman
's
nature
,
immediately
became
insensible
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
knew
I
should
quench
her
,
"
said
Sim
,
rather
embarrassed
by
this
circumstance
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
was
certain
it
would
come
to
this
,
but
there
was
nothing
else
to
be
done
---
if
I
had
n't
eyed
her
over
,
she
would
n't
have
come
down
.
 
<EOS>
Here
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
up
a
minute
,
Miggs
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
slippery
figure
she
is
!
 
<EOS>
There
's
no
holding
her
,
comfortably
.
 
<EOS>
Do
keep
up
a
minute
,
Miggs
,
will
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
As
Miggs
,
however
,
was
deaf
to
all
entreaties
,
Mr
Tappertit
leant
her
against
the
wall
as
one
might
dispose
of
a
walking
-
stick
or
umbrella
,
until
he
had
secured
the
window
,
when
he
took
her
in
his
arms
again
,
and
,
in
short
stages
and
with
great
difficulty
---
arising
from
her
being
tall
and
his
being
short
,
and
perhaps
in
some
degree
from
that
peculiar
physical
conformation
on
which
he
had
already
remarked
---
carried
her
upstairs
,
and
planting
her
,
in
the
same
umbrella
and
walking
-
stick
fashion
,
just
inside
her
own
door
,
left
her
to
her
repose
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
may
be
as
cool
as
he
likes
,
"
said
Miss
Miggs
,
recovering
as
soon
as
she
was
left
alone
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
'm
in
his
confidence
and
he
ca
n't
help
himself
,
nor
could
n't
if
he
was
twenty
Simmunses
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
10
    
<EOS>
It
was
on
one
of
those
mornings
,
common
in
early
spring
,
when
the
year
,
fickle
and
changeable
in
its
youth
like
all
other
created
things
,
is
undecided
whether
to
step
backward
into
winter
or
forward
into
summer
,
and
in
its
uncertainty
inclines
now
to
the
one
and
now
to
the
other
,
and
now
to
both
at
once
---
wooing
summer
in
the
sunshine
,
and
lingering
still
with
winter
in
the
shade
---
it
was
,
in
short
,
on
one
of
those
mornings
,
when
it
is
hot
and
cold
,
wet
and
dry
,
bright
and
lowering
,
sad
and
cheerful
,
withering
and
genial
,
in
the
compass
of
one
short
hour
,
that
old
John
Willet
,
who
was
dropping
asleep
over
the
copper
boiler
,
was
roused
by
the
sound
of
a
horse
's
feet
,
and
glancing
out
at
window
,
beheld
a
traveller
of
goodly
promise
,
checking
his
bridle
at
the
Maypole
door
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
none
of
your
flippant
young
fellows
,
who
would
call
for
a
tankard
of
mulled
ale
,
and
make
themselves
as
much
at
home
as
if
they
had
ordered
a
hogshead
of
wine
;
none
of
your
audacious
young
swaggerers
,
who
would
even
penetrate
into
the
bar
---
that
solemn
sanctuary
---
and
,
smiting
old
John
upon
the
back
,
inquire
if
there
was
never
a
pretty
girl
in
the
house
,
and
where
he
hid
his
little
chambermaids
,
with
a
hundred
other
impertinences
of
that
nature
;
none
of
your
free
-
and
-
easy
companions
,
who
would
scrape
their
boots
upon
the
firedogs
in
the
common
room
,
and
be
not
at
all
particular
on
the
subject
of
spittoons
;
none
of
your
unconscionable
blades
,
requiring
impossible
chops
,
and
taking
unheard
-
of
pickles
for
granted
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
staid
,
grave
,
placid
gentleman
,
something
past
the
prime
of
life
,
yet
upright
in
his
carriage
,
for
all
that
,
and
slim
as
a
greyhound
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
well
-
mounted
upon
a
sturdy
chestnut
cob
,
and
had
the
graceful
seat
of
an
experienced
horseman
;
while
his
riding
gear
,
though
free
from
such
fopperies
as
were
then
in
vogue
,
was
handsome
and
well
chosen
.
 
<EOS>
He
wore
a
riding
-
coat
of
a
somewhat
brighter
green
than
might
have
been
expected
to
suit
the
taste
of
a
gentleman
of
his
years
,
with
a
short
,
black
velvet
cape
,
and
laced
pocket
-
holes
and
cuffs
,
all
of
a
jaunty
fashion
;
his
linen
,
too
,
was
of
the
finest
kind
,
worked
in
a
rich
pattern
at
the
wrists
and
throat
,
and
scrupulously
white
.
 
<EOS>
Although
he
seemed
,
judging
from
the
mud
he
had
picked
up
on
the
way
,
to
have
come
from
London
,
his
horse
was
as
smooth
and
cool
as
his
own
iron
-
grey
periwig
and
pigtail
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
man
nor
beast
had
turned
a
single
hair
;
and
saving
for
his
soiled
skirts
and
spatter
-
dashes
,
this
gentleman
,
with
his
blooming
face
,
white
teeth
,
exactly
-
ordered
dress
,
and
perfect
calmness
,
might
have
come
from
making
an
elaborate
and
leisurely
toilet
,
to
sit
for
an
equestrian
portrait
at
old
John
Willet
's
gate
.
  
<EOS>
It
must
not
be
supposed
that
John
observed
these
several
characteristics
by
other
than
very
slow
degrees
,
or
that
he
took
in
more
than
half
a
one
at
a
time
,
or
that
he
even
made
up
his
mind
upon
that
,
without
a
great
deal
of
very
serious
consideration
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
if
he
had
been
distracted
in
the
first
instance
by
questionings
and
orders
,
it
would
have
taken
him
at
the
least
a
fortnight
to
have
noted
what
is
here
set
down
;
but
it
happened
that
the
gentleman
,
being
struck
with
the
old
house
,
or
with
the
plump
pigeons
which
were
skimming
and
curtseying
about
it
,
or
with
the
tall
maypole
,
on
the
top
of
which
a
weathercock
,
which
had
been
out
of
order
for
fifteen
years
,
performed
a
perpetual
walk
to
the
music
of
its
own
creaking
,
sat
for
some
little
time
looking
round
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
John
,
standing
with
his
hand
upon
the
horse
's
bridle
,
and
his
great
eyes
on
the
rider
,
<EOS>
and
with
nothing
passing
to
divert
his
thoughts
,
had
really
got
some
of
these
little
circumstances
into
his
brain
by
the
time
he
was
called
upon
to
speak
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
quaint
place
this
,
"
said
the
gentleman
---
and
his
voice
was
as
rich
as
his
dress
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
the
landlord
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
your
service
,
sir
,
"
replied
John
Willet
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
give
my
horse
good
stabling
,
<EOS>
can
you
,
and
me
an
early
dinner
(
I
am
not
particular
<EOS>
what
,
so
that
it
be
cleanly
served
)
,
and
a
decent
room
of
which
there
seems
to
be
no
lack
in
this
great
mansion
,
"
said
the
stranger
,
again
running
his
eyes
over
the
exterior
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
have
,
sir
,
"
returned
John
with
a
readiness
quite
surprising
,
"
anything
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
well
<EOS>
I
am
easily
satisfied
,
"
returned
the
other
with
a
smile
,
"
or
that
might
prove
a
hardy
pledge
,
my
friend
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
saying
so
,
he
dismounted
,
with
the
aid
of
the
block
before
the
door
,
in
a
twinkling
.
  
<EOS>
"
Halloa
there
!
 
<EOS>
Hugh
!
"
<EOS>
roared
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ask
your
pardon
,
sir
,
for
keeping
you
standing
in
the
porch
;
but
my
son
has
gone
to
town
on
business
,
and
the
boy
being
,
as
I
may
say
,
of
a
kind
of
use
to
me
,
I
'm
rather
put
out
when
he
's
away
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
!
---
<EOS>
a
dreadful
idle
vagrant
fellow
,
sir
,
half
a
gipsy
,
as
I
think
---
always
sleeping
in
the
sun
in
summer
,
and
in
the
straw
in
winter
time
,
sir
---
Hugh
!
 
<EOS>
Dear
Lord
,
to
keep
a
gentleman
a
waiting
here
through
him
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Hugh
!
 
<EOS>
I
wish
that
chap
was
dead
,
I
do
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Possibly
he
is
,
"
returned
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
if
he
were
living
,
he
would
have
heard
you
by
this
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
his
fits
of
laziness
,
he
sleeps
so
desperate
hard
,
"
said
the
distracted
host
,
"
that
if
you
were
to
fire
off
cannon
-
balls
into
his
ears
,
it
would
n't
wake
him
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
guest
made
no
remark
upon
this
novel
cure
for
drowsiness
,
and
recipe
for
making
people
lively
,
but
,
with
his
hands
clasped
behind
him
,
stood
in
the
porch
,
very
much
amused
to
see
old
John
,
with
the
bridle
in
his
hand
,
wavering
between
a
strong
impulse
to
abandon
the
animal
to
his
fate
,
and
a
half
disposition
to
lead
him
into
the
house
,
and
shut
him
up
in
the
parlour
,
while
he
waited
on
his
master
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pillory
the
fellow
,
here
he
is
at
last
!
"
<EOS>
cried
John
,
in
the
very
height
and
zenith
of
his
distress
.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
you
hear
me
a
calling
,
villain
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
figure
he
addressed
made
no
answer
,
but
putting
his
hand
upon
the
saddle
,
sprung
into
it
at
a
bound
,
turned
the
horse
's
head
towards
the
stable
,
and
was
gone
in
an
instant
.
  
<EOS>
"
Brisk
enough
when
he
is
awake
,
"
said
the
guest
.
  
<EOS>
"
Brisk
enough
,
sir
!
"
replied
John
,
looking
at
the
place
where
the
horse
had
been
,
as
if
not
yet
understanding
quite
,
what
had
become
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
melts
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
He
goes
like
a
drop
of
froth
.
 
<EOS>
You
look
at
him
,
and
there
he
is
.
 
<EOS>
You
look
at
him
again
,
and
---
there
he
is
n't
.
"
  
<EOS>
Having
,
in
the
absence
of
any
more
words
,
put
this
sudden
climax
to
what
he
had
faintly
intended
should
be
a
long
explanation
of
the
whole
life
and
character
of
his
man
,
the
oracular
John
Willet
led
the
gentleman
up
his
wide
dismantled
staircase
into
the
Maypole
's
best
apartment
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
spacious
enough
in
all
conscience
,
occupying
the
whole
depth
of
the
house
,
and
having
at
either
end
a
great
bay
window
<EOS>
,
as
large
as
many
modern
rooms
;
in
which
some
few
panes
of
stained
glass
,
emblazoned
with
fragments
of
armorial
bearings
,
though
cracked
,
and
patched
,
and
shattered
,
yet
remained
;
attesting
,
by
their
presence
,
that
the
former
owner
had
made
the
very
light
subservient
to
his
state
,
and
pressed
the
sun
itself
into
his
list
of
flatterers
;
bidding
it
,
when
it
shone
into
his
chamber
,
reflect
the
badges
of
his
ancient
family
,
and
take
new
hues
and
colours
from
their
pride
.
  
<EOS>
But
those
were
old
days
,
and
now
every
little
ray
came
and
went
as
it
would
;
telling
the
plain
,
bare
,
searching
truth
.
 
<EOS>
Although
the
best
room
of
the
inn
,
it
had
the
melancholy
aspect
of
grandeur
in
decay
,
and
was
much
too
vast
for
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
Rich
rustling
hangings
,
waving
on
the
walls
;
and
,
better
far
,
the
rustling
of
youth
and
beauty
's
dress
;
the
light
of
women
's
eyes
,
outshining
the
tapers
and
their
own
rich
jewels
;
the
sound
of
gentle
tongues
,
and
music
,
and
the
tread
of
maiden
feet
,
had
once
been
there
,
and
filled
it
with
delight
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
were
gone
,
and
with
them
all
its
gladness
.
<EOS>
It
was
no
longer
a
home
;
children
were
never
born
and
bred
there
;
the
fireside
had
become
mercenary
---
a
something
to
be
bought
and
sold
---
a
very
courtezan
:
let
who
would
die
,
or
sit
beside
,
or
leave
it
,
it
was
still
the
same
---
it
missed
nobody
,
cared
for
nobody
,
had
equal
warmth
and
smiles
for
all
.
 
<EOS>
God
help
the
man
whose
heart
ever
changes
with
the
world
,
as
an
old
mansion
when
it
becomes
an
inn
!
  
<EOS>
No
effort
had
been
made
to
furnish
this
chilly
waste
,
but
before
the
broad
chimney
a
colony
of
chairs
and
tables
had
been
planted
on
a
square
of
carpet
,
flanked
by
a
ghostly
screen
,
enriched
with
figures
,
grinning
and
grotesque
.
 
<EOS>
After
lighting
with
his
own
hands
the
faggots
which
were
heaped
upon
the
hearth
,
old
John
withdrew
to
hold
grave
council
with
his
cook
,
touching
the
stranger
's
entertainment
;
while
the
guest
himself
,
seeing
small
comfort
in
the
yet
unkindled
wood
,
opened
a
lattice
in
the
distant
window
,
and
basked
in
a
sickly
gleam
of
cold
March
sun
.
  
<EOS>
Leaving
the
window
now
and
then
,
to
rake
the
crackling
logs
together
,
or
pace
the
echoing
room
from
end
to
end
,
he
closed
it
when
the
fire
was
quite
burnt
up
,
and
having
wheeled
the
easiest
chair
into
the
warmest
corner
,
summoned
John
Willet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
John
.
  
<EOS>
He
wanted
pen
,
ink
,
and
paper
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
old
standish
on
the
mantelshelf
containing
a
dusty
apology
for
all
three
.
 
<EOS>
Having
set
this
before
him
,
the
landlord
was
retiring
,
when
he
motioned
him
to
stay
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
house
not
far
from
here
,
"
said
the
guest
when
he
had
written
a
few
lines
,
"
which
you
call
the
Warren
,
I
believe
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
this
was
said
in
the
tone
of
one
who
knew
the
fact
,
and
asked
the
question
as
a
thing
of
course
,
John
contented
himself
with
nodding
his
head
in
the
affirmative
;
at
the
same
time
taking
one
hand
out
of
his
pockets
to
cough
behind
,
and
then
putting
it
in
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
want
this
note
"
---
said
the
guest
,
glancing
on
what
he
had
written
,
and
folding
it
,
"
conveyed
there
without
loss
of
time
,
and
<EOS>
an
answer
brought
back
here
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
a
messenger
at
hand
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
John
was
thoughtful
for
a
minute
or
thereabouts
,
and
then
said
Yes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
him
,
"
said
the
guest
.
  
<EOS>
This
was
disconcerting
;
for
Joe
being
out
,
and
Hugh
engaged
in
rubbing
down
the
chestnut
cob
,
he
designed
sending
on
the
errand
,
Barnaby
,
who
had
just
then
arrived
in
one
of
his
rambles
,
and
who
,
so
that
he
thought
himself
employed
on
a
grave
and
serious
business
,
would
go
anywhere
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
the
truth
is
,
"
said
John
after
a
long
pause
,
"
that
the
person
who
'd
go
quickest
,
is
a
sort
of
natural
,
as
one
may
say
,
sir
;
and
though
quick
of
foot
,
and
as
much
to
be
trusted
as
the
post
itself
,
he
's
not
good
at
talking
,
being
touched
and
flighty
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
,
"
said
the
guest
,
raising
his
eyes
to
John
's
fat
face
<EOS>
,
"
you
do
n't
mean
---
what
's
the
fellow
's
name
---
you
do
n't
mean
Barnaby
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
do
,
"
returned
the
landlord
,
his
features
turning
quite
expressive
with
surprise
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
comes
he
to
be
here
?
"
inquired
the
guest
,
leaning
back
in
his
chair
;
speaking
in
the
bland
,
even
tone
,
from
which
he
never
varied
;
and
with
the
same
soft
,
courteous
,
never
-
changing
smile
upon
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
saw
him
in
London
last
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
,
for
ever
,
here
one
hour
,
and
there
the
next
,
"
returned
old
John
,
after
the
usual
pause
to
get
the
question
in
his
mind
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Sometimes
he
walks
,
and
sometimes
runs
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
known
along
the
road
by
everybody
,
and
sometimes
comes
here
in
a
cart
or
chaise
,
and
sometimes
riding
double
.
 
<EOS>
He
comes
and
goes
,
through
wind
,
rain
,
snow
,
and
hail
,
and
on
the
darkest
nights
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
hurts
HIM
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
goes
often
to
the
Warren
,
does
he
not
?
"
said
the
guest
carelessly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
seem
to
remember
his
mother
telling
me
something
to
that
effect
yesterday
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
was
not
attending
to
the
good
woman
much
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
right
,
sir
,
"
John
made
answer
,
"
he
does
.
 
<EOS>
His
father
,
sir
,
was
murdered
in
that
house
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
have
heard
,
"
returned
the
guest
,
taking
a
gold
toothpick
from
his
pocket
with
the
same
sweet
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
very
disagreeable
circumstance
for
the
family
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"
said
John
with
a
puzzled
look
,
as
if
it
occurred
to
him
,
dimly
and
afar
off
,
that
this
might
by
possibility
be
a
cool
way
of
treating
the
subject
.
  
<EOS>
"
All
the
circumstances
after
a
murder
,
"
said
the
guest
soliloquising
,
"
must
be
dreadfully
unpleasant
---
so
much
bustle
and
disturbance
---
no
repose
---
<EOS>
a
constant
dwelling
upon
one
subject
---
and
the
running
in
and
out
,
and
up
and
down
stairs
,
intolerable
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
such
a
thing
happen
to
anybody
<EOS>
I
was
nearly
interested
in
,
on
any
account
.
 
<EOS>
'
Twould
be
enough
to
wear
one
's
life
out
.
<EOS>
---
You
were
going
to
say
,
friend
---
"
he
added
,
turning
to
John
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Only
that
Mrs
Rudge
lives
on
a
little
pension
from
the
family
,
and
that
Barnaby
's
as
free
of
the
house
as
any
cat
or
dog
about
it
,
"
answered
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
he
do
your
errand
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
"
replied
the
guest
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
certainly
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
do
it
by
all
means
.
 
<EOS>
Please
to
bring
him
here
that
I
may
charge
him
to
be
quick
.
<EOS>
If
he
objects
to
come
you
may
tell
him
it
's
Mr
Chester
.
 
<EOS>
He
will
remember
my
name
,
I
dare
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
John
was
so
very
much
astonished
to
find
who
his
visitor
was
,
that
he
could
express
no
astonishment
at
all
,
by
looks
or
otherwise
,
but
left
the
room
as
if
he
were
in
the
most
placid
and
imperturbable
of
all
possible
conditions
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
reported
that
when
he
got
downstairs
,
he
looked
steadily
at
the
boiler
for
ten
minutes
by
the
clock
,
and
all
that
time
never
once
left
off
shaking
his
head
;
for
which
statement
there
would
seem
to
be
some
ground
of
truth
and
feasibility
,
inasmuch
as
that
interval
of
time
did
certainly
elapse
,
before
he
returned
with
Barnaby
to
the
guest
's
apartment
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
hither
,
lad
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
Mr
Geoffrey
Haredale
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
laughed
,
and
looked
at
the
landlord
as
though
he
would
say
,
"
You
hear
him
?
"
 
<EOS>
John
,
who
was
greatly
shocked
at
this
breach
of
decorum
,
clapped
his
finger
to
his
nose
,
and
shook
his
head
in
mute

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
knows
him
,
sir
,
"
said
John
,
frowning
aside
at
Barnaby
,
"
as
well
as
you
or
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
the
pleasure
of
much

with
the
gentleman
,
"
returned
his
guest
.
 
<EOS>
"
YOU
may
have
.
 
<EOS>
Limit
the
comparison
to
yourself
,
my
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Although
this
was
said
with
the
same

,
and
the

,
John
felt
himself
put
down
,
and
laying
the
indignity
at
Barnaby
's

,
determined
to
kick
his
raven
,
on
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Give
that
,
"
said
the
guest
,
who
had
by

,
and
who

towards
him
as
he

,
"
into

Haredale
's

.
 
<EOS>
Wait

<EOS>

,
tell

---
can

message

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
When

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
wo
n't
forget
this

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
sure

that
?
"
  
<EOS>
John
merely
pointed
to
him
as
he
stood
with
his

,
and
his

;
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell

,
Barnaby
,

engaged
,
"
said

Chester
,
"
that

,
and

(

.
<EOS>
---
At
the
worst
I
can
have
a
bed
here
,
Willet
,
I

?
<EOS>
"
  
Old
John
,
immensely
flattered
by
the

implied
in
this
familiar

,
answered
,
with
something

,
"
I
should
believe
you
could
,
sir
,
"
and
was
turning
over
in
his

various
forms

,
with
the
view
of
selecting

appropriate
to
the
qualities
of
his
best
bed
,
when
his

were
put
to
flight
by
Mr
Chester
giving
Barnaby
the
letter
,
and
bidding
him

.
  
<EOS>
"
Speed
!
<EOS>
"
said
Barnaby
,
folding
the
little
packet
in
his
breast
,
"
Speed
!
 
<EOS>
If
you
want
to
see
hurry
and
mystery
,
come
here
.
 
<EOS>
Here
!
"
  
With
that
,
he
put
his
hand
,
very
much
to
John
Willet
's
horror
,
on
the
guest
's
fine
broadcloth

,
and
led
him
stealthily
to
the
back

.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
down
there
,
"
he
said

;
"
do

they
whisper
in
each

's

;
then
dance
and

,
to
make

?
 
<EOS>
Do

they
stop

,
when

,
and
mutter

;
and
then
how
they
roll
and
gambol
,
delighted
with
the
mischief
they
've
been

?
 
<EOS>
Look
at
'em
now
.
 
<EOS>
See
how
they
whirl
and
plunge
.
<EOS>
And
now
they
stop
again
,
and
whisper
,
cautiously
together
---
<EOS>
little
thinking
,
mind
<EOS>
,
how
often
I
have
lain
upon
the
grass
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
say
what
is
it
that
they
plot
and
hatch
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
are
only
clothes
,
"
returned
the
guest
,
"
such
as
we
wear
;
hanging
on
those
lines
to
dry
,
and
fluttering
in
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Clothes
!
"
echoed
Barnaby
,
looking
close
into
his
face
,
and
falling
quickly

.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
how
much
better
to
be
silly
,
than
as
wise
as

!
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
see
shadowy
people
there
,
like
those
that
live
in

---
not
you
.
 
<EOS>
Nor

in

knotted

glass
,
nor
swift

when
it
blows
hard
,
nor

in

,

---
not

!
 
<EOS>
I
lead
a
merrier

than
you
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
You
're
the
dull

.
<EOS>
We
're
the
bright

.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
not
change
with
you
,
clever
as
you
are
,
---
not
I
!
"
  
<EOS>
With

,
he
waved

above

,
and
darted

.
  
<EOS>
"
A
strange

,
upon
my

!
"
said
the
guest
,
pulling

a
handsome

,
and
taking

of

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
wants
imagination
,
"
said
Mr
Willet
,
very

,
and
after

;
"
that
's
what
he
wants
.
 
<EOS>
I
've

into

,
many
and
many
's
the
time
;
but
"
---
John
added
this
in

---
 
<EOS>
"
he
an't
made
for
it
;
that
's
the
fact
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
To
record
that
Mr
Chester
smiled
at
John
's
remark
would
be
little
to
the
purpose
,
for
he
preserved
the
same

all

.
 
<EOS>
He
drew
his
chair
nearer
to
the
fire
though
,
as
a
kind

hint
that
he

prefer
to
be
alone
,
and
John
,
having
no

for

,
left
him
to

.
  
<EOS>
Very
thoughtful
old
John
Willet
was
,
while
the
dinner
was
preparing
;
and
if
his

were
ever
less

at

another
,

in

.
 
<EOS>
That
Mr
Chester
,
between
whom
and
Mr
Haredale
,
it

notorious
to
all
the
neighbourhood
,
a
deep

,

,

,
of

,

express
,
were

John
could
not

.
<EOS>
The

he
had
,
was
to
consult

,
and
wait

for

's

.
  
<EOS>
But

delayed
beyond
all

.
 
<EOS>
The
visitor
's
dinner
was
served
,
removed
,
his
wine

,
the

,
the

clean

;
the

without
,

,

,
and
still
no
Barnaby

.
 
<EOS>
Yet
,

John
Willet
was
full

,

sat
cross

the

,
to

as

---
<EOS>
the

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Barnaby
's

,
"

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

rather

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
John
coughed

.
  
<EOS>
"
As

no

,

's

,

,
"

,
"

---
which

chance

pick

up
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>
A

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Your

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
This

something

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
John

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

<EOS>
"

---

eat

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was

?
"

,

<EOS>

He

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
For

,

,

"

<EOS>
"

;

,
the
cats
<EOS>
---

,

.
 
<EOS>
Stay
.
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>
Do

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
bent

,

smoke
,
which
was

in

.
 
<EOS>
John
Willet
,
who
appeared
to
consider
himself
particularly
and
chiefly
referred
to
under
the
term

,
looked
that

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

go

,

,
"

;
"
eh
?
 
<EOS>
Why

,
and

always
in

---
which

,

I
only
take
pattern
by

?
 
<EOS>
More
of
'em
!
<EOS>
catching
to
each

's
skirts
;
and
as

go
,
others
come
!
 
<EOS>
What

!
 
<EOS>
I

that
Grip

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

in

?
"

was

bending

to

higher
up
the

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
In
this
?
"
he

,

,
before

Willet
could

---
 
shaking

as

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
In
this
!
 
<EOS>
What
is
there
here
?
 
<EOS>
Tell
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
devil
,
a
devil
,
a
devil
!
"
cried

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
's

!
"
said

,

in

,
"
money
for

,
Grip
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hurrah
!
 
<EOS>
Hurrah
!
 
<EOS>
Hurrah
!
<EOS>
"
replied

,
"
keep
up

.
 
<EOS>
Never
say

.
 
<EOS>
Bow
,
wow
,
<EOS>
wow
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
,
who
appeared
to
entertain
strong
doubts
whether
a
customer
in
a
laced

and
fine

could

supposed
to

even

as
the

,
took

at
this

,
with
the
view
of
preventing
any
other

,
and
quitted
the
room
with
his
very
best
bow
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
11
    
<EOS>
There
was
great
news
that
night
for
the
regular
Maypole
customers
,
to
each
of
whom
,
as
he
straggled
in
to
occupy
his
allotted
seat
in
the
chimney
-
corner
,
John
,
with
a
most
impressive
slowness
of
delivery
,
and
in
an
apoplectic
whisper
,
communicated
the
fact
that
Mr
Chester
was
alone
in
the
large
room
upstairs
,
and
was
waiting
the
arrival
of
Mr
Geoffrey
Haredale
,
to
whom
he
had
sent
a
letter
(
doubtless
of
a
threatening
nature
)
by
the
hands
of
Barnaby
,
then
and
there
present
.
  
<EOS>
For
a
little
knot
of
smokers
and
solemn

,
who
had
seldom
any
new
topics
of
discussion
,
this
was
a
perfect
Godsend
.
 
<EOS>
Here
was
a
good
,
dark
-
looking
mystery
progressing
under
that
very
roof
---
 
brought
home
to
the
fireside
,
as
it
were
,
and
enjoyable
without
the
smallest
pains
or
trouble
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
extraordinary
what
a
zest
and
relish
it
gave
to
the
drink
,
and
how
it
heightened
the
flavour
of
the
tobacco
.
 
<EOS>
Every
man
smoked
his
pipe
with
a
face
of
grave
and
serious

,
and
looked
at

.
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
it
was
felt
to
be
such

,
that
,
on
the

little
Solomon

,
every

(

John
himself
)

for
a

of
flip
,
which

was
brewed
with
all

,
and
set
down
in
the

on

;
both
that

,
and
that

,

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
The

room
seemed
to

in

;
the

,

;

high
,
and

hearthstone

.
  
<EOS>
There
were
present
two
,
however
,
who
showed
but

the

.
 
<EOS>
Of

,

was

,
who

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

,

,

a

.
 
<EOS>
Loosely

,

---
his
usual

---
 
clinging

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter

<EOS>

the
state
-
room
of
the
Maypole
,
as
Mr
Haredale
tried
the
lock
to
satisfy
himself
that
he
had
shut
the
door
securely
,
and
,
striding
up
the
dark
chamber
to
where
the
screen
inclosed
a
little
patch
of
light
and
warmth
,
presented
himself
,
abruptly
and
in
silence
,
before
the
smiling
guest
.
  
<EOS>
If
the
two
had
no
greater
sympathy
in
their
inward
thoughts
than
in
their
outward
bearing
and
appearance
,
the
meeting
did
not
seem
likely
to
prove
a
very
calm
or
pleasant
one
.
 
<EOS>
With
no
great
disparity
between
them
in
point
of
years
,
they
were
,
in
every
other
respect
,
as
unlike
and
far
removed
from
each
other
as
two
men
could
well
be
.
 
<EOS>
The
one
was
soft
-
spoken
,
delicately
made
,
precise
,
and
elegant
;
the
other
,
a
burly
square
-
built
man
,
negligently
dressed
,
rough
and
abrupt
in
manner
,
stern
,
and
,
in
his
present
mood
,
forbidding
both
in
look
and
speech
.
 
<EOS>
The
one
preserved
a
calm
and
placid
smile
;
the
other
,
a
distrustful
frown
.
 
<EOS>
The
new
-
comer
,
indeed
,
appeared
bent
on
showing
by
his
every
tone
and
gesture
his
determined
opposition
and
hostility
to
the
man
he
had
come
to
meet
.
<EOS>
The
guest
who
received
him
,
on
the
other
hand
,
seemed
to
feel
that
the
contrast
between
them
was
all
in
his
favour
,
and
to
derive
a
quiet
exultation
from
it
which
put
him
more
at
his
ease
than
ever
.
  
<EOS>
"
Haredale
,
"
said
this
gentleman
,
without
the
least
appearance
of
embarrassment
or
reserve
,
"
I
am
very
glad
to
see
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
us
dispense
with
compliments
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
misplaced
between
us
,
"
returned
the
other
,
waving
his
hand
,
"
and
say
plainly
what
we
have
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
asked
me
to
meet
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
here
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
we
stand
face
to
face
again
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Still
the
same
frank
and
sturdy
character
,
I
see
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
or
bad
,
sir
,
I
am
,
"
returned
the
other
,
leaning
his
arm
upon
the
chimney
-
piece
,
and
turning
a
haughty
look
upon
the
occupant
of
the
easy
-
chair
,
"
the
man
I
used
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
lost
no
old
likings
or
dislikings
;
my
memory
has
not
failed
me
by
a
hair's
-
breadth
.
<EOS>
You
ask
me
to
give
you
a
meeting
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
,
I
am
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Our
meeting
,
Haredale
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
tapping
his
snuff
-
box
,
and
following
with
a
smile
the
impatient
gesture
he
had
made
---
 
perhaps
unconsciously
---
towards
his
sword
,
"
is
one
of
conference
and
peace
,
I
hope
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
here
,
"
returned
the
other
,
"
at
your
desire
,
holding
myself
bound
to
meet
you
,
when
and
where
you
would
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
come
to
bandy
pleasant
speeches
,
or
hollow
professions
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
smooth
man
of
the
world
,
sir
,
and
at
such
play
have
me
at
a
disadvantage
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
last
man
on
this
earth
with
whom
I
would
enter
the
lists
to
combat
with
gentle
compliments
and
masked
faces
,
is
Mr
Chester
,
I
do
assure
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
his
match
at
such
weapons
,
and
have
reason
to
believe
that
few
men
are
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
me
a
great
deal
of
honour
Haredale
,
"
returned
the
other
,
most
composedly
,
"
and
I
thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
be
frank
with
you
---
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
beg
your
pardon
---
will
be
what
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Frank
---
open
---
perfectly
candid
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hab
!
"
cried
Mr
Haredale
,
drawing
his
breath
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
do
n't
let
me
interrupt
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
resolved
am
I
to
hold
this
course
,
"
returned
the
other
,
tasting
his
wine
with
great
deliberation
;
"
<EOS>
that
I
have
determined
not
to
quarrel
with
you
,
and
not
to
be
betrayed
into
a
warm
expression
or
a
hasty
word
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
again
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
you
have
me
at
a
great
advantage
.
<EOS>
Your
self
-
command
---
"
  
"
Is
not
to
be
disturbed
,
when
it
will
serve
my
purpose
,
you
would
say
"
---
rejoined
the
other
,
interrupting
him
with
the
same
complacency
.
 
<EOS>
"
Granted
.
 
<EOS>
I
allow
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
have
a
purpose
to
serve
now
.
 
<EOS>
So
have
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
our
object
is
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
attain
it
like
sensible
men
,
who
have
ceased
to
be
boys
some
time
.
<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>
Do
you
drink
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
With
my
friends
,
"
returned
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
least
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
"
you
will
be
seated
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
stand
,
"
returned
Mr
Haredale
impatiently
,
"
on
this
dismantled
,
beggared
hearth
,
and
not
pollute
it
,
fallen
as
it
is
,
with
mockeries
.
 
<EOS>
Go
on
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
wrong
,
Haredale
,
"
said
the
other
,
crossing
his
legs
,
and
smiling
as
he
held
his
glass
up
in
the
bright
glow
of
the
fire
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
really
very
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
The
world
is
a
lively
place
enough
,
in
which
we
must
accommodate
ourselves
to
circumstances
,
sail
with
the
stream
as
glibly
as
we
can
,
be
content
to
take
froth
for
substance
,
the
surface
for
the
depth
,
the
counterfeit
for
the
real
coin
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
no
philosopher
has
ever
established
that
our
globe
itself
is
hollow
.
 
<EOS>
It
should
be
,
if
Nature
is
consistent
in
her
works
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
YOU
think
it
is
,
perhaps
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
say
,
"
he
returned
,
sipping
his
wine
,
"
there
could
be
no
doubt
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
Well
;
we
,
in
trifling
with
this
jingling
toy
,
have
had
the
ill
-
luck
to
jostle
and
fall
out
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
not
what
the
world
calls
friends
;
but
we
are
as
good
and
true
and
loving
friends
for
all
that
,
as
nine
out
of
every
ten
of
those
on
whom
it
bestows
the
title
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
a
niece
,
and
I
a
son
---
a
fine
lad
,
Haredale
,
but
foolish
.
 
<EOS>
They
fall
in
love
with
each
other
,
and
form
what
this
same
world
calls
an
attachment
;
meaning
a
something
fanciful
and
false
like
the
rest
,
which
,
if
it
took
its
own
free
time
,
would
break
like
any
other
bubble
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
may
not
have
its
own
free
time
---
<EOS>
will
not
,
if
they
are
left
alone
---
and
the
question
is
,
shall
we
two
,
because
society
calls
us
enemies
,
stand
aloof
,
and
let
them
rush
into
each
other
's
arms
,
when
,
by
approaching
each
other
sensibly
,
as
we
do
now
,
we
can
prevent
it
,
and
part
them
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
love
my
niece
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
after
a
short
silence
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
may
sound
strangely
in
your
ears
;
but
I
love
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Strangely
,
my
good
fellow
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Chester
,
lazily
filling
his
glass
again
,
and
pulling
out
his
toothpick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
like
Ned
too
---
<EOS>
or
,
as
you
say
,
love
him
<EOS>
---
that
's
the
word
among
such
near
relations
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
very
fond
of
Ned
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
an
amazingly
good
fellow
,
and
a
handsome
fellow
---
foolish
and
weak
as
yet
;
that
's
all
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
thing
is
,
Haredale
---
<EOS>
for
I
'll
be
very
frank
,
as
I
told
you
I
would
at
first
---
independently
of
any
dislike
that
you
and
I
might
have
to
being
related
to
each
other
,
and
independently
of
the
religious
differences
between
us
---
and
damn
it
,
that
's
important
<EOS>
---
I
could
n't
afford
a
match
of
this
description
.
 
<EOS>
Ned
<EOS>
and
I
could
n't
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
impossible
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Curb
your
tongue
,
in
God
's
name
,
if
this
conversation
is
to
last
,
"
retorted
Mr
Haredale
fiercely
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
I
love
my
niece
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
think
that
,
loving
her
,
I
would
have
her
fling
her
heart
away
on
any
man
who
had
your
blood
in
his
veins
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
"
said
the
other
,
not
at
all
disturbed
,
"
the
advantage
of
being
so
frank
and
open
.
 
<EOS>
Just
what
I
was
about
to
add
,
upon
my
honour
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
amazingly
attached
to
Ned
---
<EOS>
quite
doat
upon
him
,
indeed
<EOS>
---
and
even
if
we
could
afford
to
throw
ourselves
away
,
that
very
objection
would
be
quite
insuperable
.
<EOS>
---
I
wish
you
'd
take
some
wine
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mark
me
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
striding
to
the
table
,
and
laying
his
hand
upon
it
heavily
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
any
man
believes
---
presumes
to
think
---
 
that
I
,
in
word
or
deed
,
or
in
the
wildest
dream
,
ever
entertained
remotely
the
idea
of
Emma
Haredale
's
favouring
the
suit
of
any
one
who
was
akin
to
you
---
in
any
way
---
I
care
not
<EOS>
what
---
he
lies
.
 
<EOS>
He
lies
,
and
does
me
grievous
wrong
,
in
the
mere
thought
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Haredale
,
"
returned
the
other
,
rocking
himself
to
and
fro
as
in
assent
,
and
nodding
at
the
fire
,
"
it
's
extremely
manly
,
and
really
very
generous
in
you
,
to
meet
me
in
this
unreserved
and
handsome
way
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
,
those
are
exactly
my
sentiments
,
only
expressed
with
much
more
force
and
power
than
I
could
use
---
you
know
my
sluggish
nature
,
and
will
forgive
me
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
While
I
would
restrain
her
from
all
correspondence
with
your
son
,
and
sever
their
intercourse
here
,
though
it
should
cause
her
death
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
who
had
been
pacing
to
and
fro
,
"
I
would
do
it
kindly
and
tenderly
if
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
trust
to
discharge
,
which
my
nature
is
not
formed
to
understand
,
and
,
for
this
reason
,
the
bare
fact
of
there
being
any
love
between
them
comes
upon
me
to
-
night
,
almost
for
the
first
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
more
delighted
than
I
can
possibly
tell
you
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Chester
with
the
utmost
blandness
,
"
to
find
my
own
impression
so
confirmed
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
the
advantage
of
our
having
met
.
 
<EOS>
We
understand
each
other
.
 
<EOS>
We
quite
agree
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
a
most
complete
and
thorough
explanation
,
and
we
know
what
course
to
take
.
<EOS>
---
Why
do
n't
you
taste
your
tenant
's
wine
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
really
very
good
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
who
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
have
aided
Emma
,
or
your
son
?
 
<EOS>
Who
are
their
go
-
betweens
,
and
agents
---
do
you
know
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
the
good
people
hereabouts
---
the
neighbourhood
in
general
,
I
think
,
"
returned
the
other
,
with
his
most
affable
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
messenger
I
sent
to
you
to
-
day
,
foremost
among
them
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
idiot
?
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
surprised
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
of
that
,
for
I
was
rather
so
myself
.
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
wrung
that
from
his
mother
---
a
very
decent
sort
of
woman
---
 
from
whom
,
indeed
,
I
chiefly
learnt
how
serious
the
matter
had
become
,
and
so
determined
to
ride
out
here
to
-
day
,
and
hold
a
parley
with
you
on
this
neutral
ground
.
<EOS>
---
You
're
stouter
than
you
used
to
be
,
Haredale
,
but
you
look
extremely
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Our
business
,
I
presume
,
is
nearly
at
an
end
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
with
an
expression
of
impatience
he
was
at
no
pains
to
conceal
.
<EOS>
"
Trust
me
,
Mr
Chester
,
my
niece
shall
change
from
this
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
appeal
,
"
he
added
in
a
lower
tone
,
"
to
her
woman
's
heart
,
her
dignity
,
her
pride
,
her
duty
---
"
  
"
I
shall
do
the
same
by
Ned
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
restoring
some
errant
faggots
to
their
places
in
the
grate
with
the
toe
of
his
boot
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
there
is
anything
real
in
this
world
,
it
is
those
amazingly
fine
feelings
and
those
natural
obligations
which
must
subsist
between
father
and
son
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
put
it
to
him
on
every
ground
of
moral
and
religious
feeling
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
represent
to
him
that
we
can
not
possibly
afford
it
---
that
I
have
always
looked
forward
to
his
marrying
well
,
for
a
genteel
provision
for
myself
in
the
autumn
of
life
---
that
there
are
a
great
many
clamorous
dogs
to
pay
,
whose
claims
are
perfectly
just
and
right
,
and
who
must
be
paid
out
of
his
wife
's
fortune
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
that
the
very
highest
and
most
honourable
feelings
of
our
nature
,
with
every
consideration
of
filial
duty
and
affection
,
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
,
imperatively
demand
that
he
should
run
away
with
an
heiress
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
break
her
heart
as
speedily
as
possible
?
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
drawing
on
his
glove
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
Ned
will
act
exactly
as
he
pleases
,
"
returned
the
other
,
sipping
his
wine
;
"
that
's
entirely
his
affair
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
for
the
world
<EOS>
interfere
with
my
son
,
Haredale
,
beyond
a
certain
point
.
 
<EOS>
The
relationship
between
father
and
son
,
you
know
,
is
positively
quite
a
holy
kind
of
bond
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
WON'T
<EOS>
you
let
me
persuade
you
to
take
one
glass
of
wine
?
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
as
you
please
,
as
you
please
,
"
he
added
,
helping
himself
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Chester
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
after
a
short
silence
,
during
which
he
had
eyed
his
smiling
face
from
time
to
time
intently
,
"
you
have
the
head
and
heart
of
an
evil
spirit
in
all
matters
of
deception
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
health
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
other
,
with
a
nod
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
interrupted
you
---
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
now
,
"
pursued
Mr
Haredale
,
"
we
should
find
it
difficult
to
separate
these
young
people
,
and
break
off
their

---
if
,
for
instance
,
you
find
it
difficult
on
your
side
,
what
course
do
you
intend
to
take
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
plainer
,
my
good
fellow
,
nothing
easier
,
"
returned
the
other
,
shrugging

and
stretching

more
comfortably
before

fire
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
then
exert
those
powers
on
which
you
flatter
me
so
highly
---
though
,
upon
my
word
,
I
do
n't
deserve
your
compliments
to
their
full

---
and
resort
to
a
few
little
trivial
subterfuges
for
rousing

and
resentment
.
<EOS>
You
see
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
In
short
,
justifying
the
means
by
the
end
,
we
are
,
as
a
last
resource
for
tearing
them
asunder
,
to
resort
to
treachery
and
---
and
lying
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
<EOS>
no
.
 
<EOS>
Fie
,
fie
!
<EOS>
"
returned
the
other
,
relishing
a
pinch
of
snuff
extremely
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
lying
.
 
<EOS>
Only
a
little
management
,
a
little
diplomacy
,
a
little
---
intriguing
<EOS>
,
that
's
the
word
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
moving
to
and
fro
,
and
stopping
,
and
moving
on
again
,
like
one
who
was
ill
at

,
"
that
this
could
have
been
foreseen
or
prevented
.
 
<EOS>
But
as

has
gone
so
far
,
and
it
is
necessary
for
us
to
act
,
it
is
of
no
use
shrinking
or

.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I
shall
second
your
endeavours
to
the
utmost

my
power
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
one
topic
in
the
whole
wide

of
human

on
which
we
both
agree
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
act
in

,
but
apart
.
 
<EOS>
There
will
be
no
need
,
I
hope
,
for

to
meet
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
?
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
rising
with
a
graceful

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Let
me
light
you
down
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
keep
your
seat
,
"
returned
the
other
drily
,
"
I
know
the
way
.
<EOS>
So
,
waving
his
hand
slightly
,
and
putting
on
his
hat
as
he
turned
upon

,

clanking
out
as
he
had
come
,
shut

door

,
and
tramped
down

echoing

.
  
<EOS>
"
Pah
!
 
<EOS>
A
very
coarse
animal
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
composing
himself
in
the
easy
-
chair
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
rough
brute
.
 
<EOS>
Quite
a
human
badger
!
"
  
<EOS>
John
Willet
and
his
friends
,
who
had
been
listening
intently
for
the
clash
of
swords
,
or
firing
of
pistols
in
the
great
room
,
and
had
indeed
settled
the
order
in
which
they
should
rush
in
when
summoned
---
in
which

old
John
had
carefully
arranged
that
he

bring

---
were
very

to
see
Mr
Haredale
come
down
without
a

,
call
for
his
horse
,
and
ride

thoughtfully
at
a
footpace
.
 
<EOS>
After
some
