,
it
was
decided
that
he
had
left
the
gentleman
above
,
for
dead
,
and
had
adopted
this
stratagem
to
divert
suspicion
or
pursuit
.
  
<EOS>
As
this
conclusion
involved
the
necessity
of
their
going
upstairs
forthwith
,
they
were
about
to
ascend
in
the
order
they
had
agreed
upon
,
when
a
smart
ringing
at
the
guest
's
bell
,
as
if
he
had
pulled
it
vigorously
,
overthrew
all
their
speculations
,
and
involved
them
in
great
uncertainty
and

.
 
<EOS>
At
length
Mr
Willet
agreed
to
go
upstairs
himself
,
escorted
by
Hugh
and
Barnaby
,
as
the
strongest
and
stoutest
fellows
on
the
premises
,
who
were
to
make
their
appearance
under
pretence
of
clearing
away
the
glasses
.
  
<EOS>
Under
this
protection
,
the
brave
and
broad
-
faced
John
boldly
entered
the
room
,
half
a
foot
in
advance
,
and
received
an
order
for
a
boot
-
jack
without
trembling
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
it
was
brought
,
and
he
leant
his
sturdy
shoulder
to
the
guest
,
Mr
Willet
was
observed
to
look
very
hard
into
his
boots
as
he
pulled
them
off
,
and
,
by
opening
his
eyes
much
wider
than
usual
,
to
appear
to
express
some
surprise
and
disappointment
at
not
finding
them
full
of
blood
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
occasion
,
too
,
to
examine
the
gentleman
as
closely
as
he
could
,
expecting
to
discover
sundry
loopholes
in
his
person
,
pierced
by
his
adversary
's

.
 
<EOS>
Finding
none
,
however
,
and
observing
in
course
of
time
that
his
guest
was
as
cool
and
unruffled
,
both
in
his
dress
and
temper
,
as
he
had
been
all
day
,
old
John
at
last
heaved
a
deep
sigh
,
and
began
to
think
no
duel
had
been
fought
that
night
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
Willet
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
"
if
the
room
's
well
aired
,
I
'll
try
the
merits
of
that
famous
bed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
room
,
sir
,
"
returned
John
,
taking
up
a

,
and
nudging
Barnaby
and
Hugh
to

,
in
case
<EOS>
the
gentleman
should
unexpectedly
drop
down
faint
or

from
some
internal

,
"
the
room
's
as
warm
as
any

in

.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
,
take

that
other

,

.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
!
 
<EOS>
Follow
up
,

,
with
the
easy
-

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
In
this
order
---
and
still
,
in
his

,
holding
his

very
close
to
the
guest
;
now
making
him
feel
extremely
warm
about
the
legs
,
now
threatening
to
set
his
wig
on
fire
,
and
constantly
begging
his

with
great

and

---
John
led
the
party
to
the
best

,
which
was
nearly
as
large
as
the
chamber
from
which
they
had
come
,
and
held
,
drawn

near
the
fire
for

,
a
great

,
hung

faded

,
and

,
at
the
top
of
each
carved
post
,
with
a

of

that
had
once
been
white
,
but
with
dust
and
age
had
now
grown
hearse
-
like
and
funereal
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
my
friends
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
with
a
sweet

,
seating

,
when

had

the
room
from
end
to
end
,
in
the
easy
-
chair
which
his

wheeled
before
the

.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
,
my
good

,
you
say
some

before
you
go

,
I

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
some
nonsense
that
he

,
sir
<EOS>
,
"
returned
old
John
,
officiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
afraid
there
an't
much
good
in

.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
Hugh
?
"
said
Mr
Chester
,

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
<EOS>
his
"
---
pointing

---
"
they
're
well
enough
.
 
<EOS>
He
sings
'em
sometimes
in

.
 
<EOS>
I
listen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
quite
a
animal
,
sir
,
"
John
whispered
in
his
ear
with

.
<EOS>
"
You
'll
excuse
him
,
I
'm
sure
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
has
any
soul
at

,

,
it

such

,

do

does
or
does
n't
in

.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
,
sir
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
guest
rejoined
"
God
bless
you
!
"
<EOS>
with
a
fervour
that
was
quite
affecting
;
and
John
,
beckoning
his
guards
to
go
before
,
bowed
himself
out
of
the
room
,
and
left
him
to
his
rest
in
the
Maypole
's
ancient
bed
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
13
    
<EOS>
If
Joseph
Willet
,
the
denounced
and
proscribed
of
'
prentices
,
had
happened
to
be
at
home
when
his
father
's
courtly
guest
presented
himself
before
the
Maypole
door
---
<EOS>
that
is
,
if
it
had
not
perversely
chanced
to
be
one
of
the
half
-
dozen
days
in
the
whole
year
on
which
he
was
at
liberty
to
absent
himself
for
as
many
hours
without
question
or
reproach
---
he
would
have
contrived
,
by
hook
or
crook
,
to
dive
to
the
very
bottom
of
Mr
Chester
's
mystery
,
and
to
come
at
his
purpose
with
as
much
certainty
as
though
he
had
been
his
confidential
adviser
.
 
<EOS>
In
that
fortunate
case
,
the
lovers
would
have
had
quick
warning
of
the
ills
that
threatened
them
,
and
the
aid
of
various
timely
and
wise
suggestions
to
boot
;
for
all
Joe
's
readiness
of
thought
and
action
,
and
all
his
sympathies
and
good
wishes
,
were
enlisted
in
favour
of
the
young
people
,
and
were
staunch
in
devotion
to
their
cause
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
this
disposition
arose
out
of
his
old
prepossessions
in
favour
of
the
young
lady
,
whose
history
had
surrounded
her
in
his
mind
,
almost
from
his
cradle
,
with
circumstances
of
unusual
interest
;
or
from
his
attachment
towards
the
young
gentleman
,
into
whose
confidence
he
had
,
through
his
shrewdness
and
alacrity
,
and
the
rendering
of
sundry
important
services
as
a
spy
and
messenger
,
almost
imperceptibly
glided
;
whether
they
had
their
origin
in
either
of
these
sources
,
or
in
the
habit
natural
to
youth
,
or
in
the
constant
badgering
and
worrying
of
his
venerable
parent
,
or
in
any
hidden
little
love
affair
of
his
own
which
gave
him
something
of
a
fellow
-
feeling
in
the
matter
,
it
is
needless
to
inquire
---
especially
as
Joe
was
out
of
the
way
,
and
had
no
opportunity
on
that
particular
occasion
of
testifying
to
his
sentiments
either
on
one
side
or
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
,
in
fact
,
the
twenty
-
fifth
of
March
,
which
,
as
most
people
know
to
their
cost
,
is
,
and
has
been
time
out
of
mind
,
one
of
those
unpleasant
epochs
termed
quarter
-
days
.
 
<EOS>
On
this
twenty
-
fifth
of
March
,
it
was
John
Willet
's
pride
annually
to
settle
,
in
hard
cash
,
<EOS>
his
account
with
a
certain
vintner
and
distiller
in
the
city
of
London
;
to
give
into
whose
hands
a
canvas
bag
containing
its
exact
amount
,
and
not
a
penny
more
or
less
,
was
the
end
and
object
of
a
journey
for
Joe
,
so
surely
as
the
year
and
day
came
round
.
  
<EOS>
This
journey
was
performed
upon
an
old
grey
mare
,
concerning
whom
John
had
an
indistinct
set
of
ideas
hovering
about
him
,
to
the
effect
that
she
could
win
a
plate
or
cup
if
she
tried
.
 
<EOS>
She
never
had
tried
,
and
probably
never
would
now
,
being
some
fourteen
or
fifteen
years
of
age
,
short
in
wind
,
long
in
body
,
and
rather
the
worse
for
wear
in
respect
of
her
mane
and
tail
.
 
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
these
slight
defects
,
John
perfectly
gloried
in
the
animal
;
and
when
she
was
brought
round
to
the
door
by
Hugh
,
actually
retired
into
the
bar
,
and
there
,
in
a
secret
grove
of
lemons
,
laughed
with
pride
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
bit
of
horseflesh
,
Hugh
!
"
said
John
,
when
he
had
recovered
enough
self
-
command
to
appear
at
the
door
again
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
comely
creature
!
 
<EOS>
There
's
high
mettle
!
 
<EOS>
There
's
bone
!
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
bone
enough
beyond
all
doubt
;
and
so
Hugh
seemed
to
think
,
as
he
sat
sideways
in
the
saddle
,
lazily
doubled
up
with
his
chin
nearly
touching
his
knees
;
and
heedless
of
the
dangling
stirrups
and
loose
bridle
-
rein
,
sauntered
up
and
down
on
the
little
green
before
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mind
you
take
good
care
of
her
,
sir
,
"
said
John
,
appealing
from
this
insensible
person
to
his
son
and
heir
,
who
now
appeared
,
fully
equipped
and
ready
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
ride
hard
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
puzzled
to
do
that
,
I
think
,
father
,
"
Joe
replied
,
casting
a
disconsolate
look
at
the
animal
.
  
<EOS>
"
None
of
your
impudence
,
sir
,
if
you
please
,
"
retorted
old
John
.
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
ride
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
A
wild
ass
or
zebra
would
be
too
tame
for
you
,
would
n't
he
,
eh
sir
?
 
<EOS>
You
'd
like
to
ride
a
roaring
lion
,
<EOS>
would
n't
you
,
sir
,
eh
sir
?
 
<EOS>
Hold
your
tongue
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Willet
,
in
his
differences
with
his
son
,
had
exhausted
all
the
questions
that
occurred
to
him
,
and
Joe
had
said
nothing
at
all
in
answer
,
he
generally
wound
up
by
bidding
him
hold
his
tongue
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
does
the
boy
mean
,
"
added
Mr
Willet
,
after
he
had
stared
at
him
for
a
little
time
,
in
a
species
of
stupefaction
,
"
by
cocking
his
hat
,
to
such
an
extent
!
 
<EOS>
Are
you
going
to
kill
the
wintner
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Joe
,
tartly
;
"
I
'm
not
.
 
<EOS>
Now
your
mind
's
at
ease
,
father
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
With
a
milintary
air
,
too
!
"
said
Mr
Willet
,
surveying
him
from
top
to
toe
;
"
with
a
swaggering
,
fire
-
eating
,
biling
-
water

sort
of
way
with
him
!
 
<EOS>
And
what
do
you
mean
by
pulling
up
the
crocuses
and
snowdrops
,
eh
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
only
a
little
nosegay
,
"
said
Joe
,
reddening
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
no
harm
in
that
,
I
hope
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
boy
of
business
,
you
are
,
sir
!
"
said
Mr
Willet
,
disdainfully
,
"
to
go
supposing
that
wintners
care
for
nosegays
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
suppose
anything
of
the
kind
,
"
returned
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
them
keep
their
red
noses
for
bottles
and
tankards
.
 
<EOS>
These
are
going
to
Mr
Varden
's
house
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
do
you
suppose
HE
minds
such
things
as
crocuses
?
"
demanded
John
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
and
to
say
the
truth
,
I
do
n't
care
,
"
said
Joe
.
<EOS>
"
Come
,
father
,
give
me
the
money
,
and
in
the
name
of
patience
let
me
go
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
it
is
,
sir
,
"
replied
John
;
"
and
take
care
of
it
;
and
mind
you
do
n't
make
too
much
haste
back
,
but
give
the
mare
a
long
rest
.
<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>
Do
you
mind
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
I
mind
,
"
returned
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
'll
need
it
,
Heaven
knows
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
do
n't
you
score
up
too
much
at
the
Black
Lion
,
"
said
John
.
<EOS>
"
Mind
that
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
do
n't
you
let
me
have
some
money
of
my
own
?
"
<EOS>
retorted
Joe
,
sorrowfully
;
"
<EOS>
why
do
n't
you
,
father
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
send
me
into
London
for
,
giving
me
only
the
right
to
call
for
my
dinner
at
the
Black
Lion
,
which
you
're
to
pay
for
next
time
you
go
,
as
if
I
was
not
to
be
trusted
with
a
few
shillings
?
 
<EOS>
Why
do
you
use
me
like
this
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
not
right
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
expect
me
to
be
quiet
under
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
him
have
money
!
"
<EOS>
cried
John
,
in
a
drowsy
reverie
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
does
he
call
money
---
guineas
?
 
<EOS>
Has
n't
he
got
money
?
 
<EOS>
Over
and
above
the
tolls
,
has
n't
he
one
and
sixpence
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
One
and
sixpence
!
"
repeated
his
son
contemptuously
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
returned
John
,
"
one
and
sixpence
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
was
your
age
,
I
had
never
seen
so
much
money
,
in
a
heap
.
 
<EOS>
A
shilling
of
it
is
in
case
of
accidents
---
the
mare
casting
a
shoe
,
or
the
like
of
that
.
<EOS>
The
other
sixpence
is
to
spend
in
the
diversions
of
London
;
and
the
diversion
I
recommend
is
going
to
the
top
of
the
Monument
,
and
sitting
there
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
no
temptation
there
,
sir
---
no
drink
---
<EOS>
no
young
women
---
no
bad
characters
of
any
sort
---
nothing
but
imagination
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
way
I
enjoyed
myself
when
I
was
your
age
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
To
this
,
Joe
made
no
answer
,
but
beckoning
Hugh
,
leaped
into
the
saddle
and
rode
away
;
and
a
very
stalwart
,
manly
horseman
he
looked
,
deserving
a
better
charger
than
it
was
his
fortune
to
bestride
.
 
<EOS>
John
stood
staring
after
him
,
or
rather
after
the
grey
mare
(
for
he
had
no
eyes
for
her
rider
)
,
until
man
and
beast
had
been
out
of
sight
some
twenty
minutes
,
when
he
began
to
think
they
were
gone
,
and
slowly
re
-
entering
the
house
,
fell
into
a
gentle
doze
.
  
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
grey
mare
,
who
was
the
agony
of
Joe
's
life
,
floundered
along
at
her
own
will
and
pleasure
until
the
Maypole
was
no
longer
visible
,
and
then
,
contracting
her
legs
into
what
in
a
puppet
would
have
been
looked
upon
as
a
clumsy
and
awkward
imitation
of
a
canter
,
mended
her
pace
all
at
once
,
and
did
it
of
her
own
accord
.
 
<EOS>
The
acquaintance
with
her
rider
's
usual
mode
of
proceeding
,
which
suggested
this
improvement
in
hers
,
impelled
her
likewise
to
turn
up
a
bye
-
way
,
leading
---
not
to
London
,
but
through
lanes
running
parallel
with
the
road
they
had
come
,
and
passing
within
a
few
hundred
yards
of
the
Maypole
,
which
led
finally
to
an
inclosure
surrounding
a
large
,
old
,
red
-
brick
mansion
---
the
same
of
which
mention
was
made
as
the
Warren
in
the
first
chapter
of
this
history
.
 
<EOS>
Coming
to
a
dead
stop
in
a
little
copse
thereabout
,
she
suffered
her
rider
to
dismount
with
right
goodwill
,
and
to
tie
her
to
the
trunk
of
a
tree
.
  
<EOS>
"
Stay
there
,
old
girl
,
"
said
Joe
,
"
and
let
us
see
whether
there
's
any
little
commission
for
me
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
left
her
to
browze
upon
such
stunted
grass
and
weeds
as
happened
to
grow
within
the
length
of
her
tether
,
and
passing
through
a
wicket
gate
,
entered
the
grounds
on
foot
.
  
<EOS>
The
pathway
,
after
a
very
few
minutes
'
walking
,
brought
him
close
to
the
house
,
towards
which
,
and
especially
towards
one
particular
window
,
he
directed
many
covert
glances
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
dreary
,
silent
building
,
with
echoing
courtyards
,
desolated
turret
-
chambers
,
and
whole
suites
of
rooms
shut
up
and
mouldering
to
ruin
.
  
<EOS>
The
terrace
-
garden
,
dark
with
the
shade
of
overhanging
trees
,
had
an
air
of
melancholy
that
was
quite
oppressive
.
 
<EOS>
Great
iron
gates
,
disused
for
many
years
,
and
red
with
rust
,
drooping
on
their
hinges
and
overgrown
with
long
rank
grass
,
seemed
as
though
they
tried
to
sink
into
the
ground
,
and
hide
their
fallen
state
among
the
friendly
weeds
.
 
<EOS>
The
fantastic
monsters
on
the
walls
,
green
with
age
and
damp
,
and
covered
here
and
there
with
moss
,
looked
grim
and
desolate
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
sombre
aspect
even
on
that
part
of
the
mansion
which
was
inhabited
and
kept
in
good
repair
,
that
struck
the
beholder
with
a
sense
of
sadness
;
of
something
forlorn
and
failing
,
whence
cheerfulness
was
banished
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
difficult
to
imagine
a
bright
fire
blazing
in
the
dull
and
darkened
rooms
,
or
to
picture
any
gaiety
of
heart
or
revelry
that
the
frowning
walls
shut
in
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
a
place
where
such
things
had
been
,
but
could
be
no
more
---
the
very
ghost
of
a
house
,
haunting
the
old
spot
in
its
old
outward
form
,
and
that
was
all
.
  
<EOS>
Much
of
this
decayed
and
sombre
look
was
attributable
,
no
doubt
,
to
the
death
of
its
former
master
,
and
the
temper
of
its
present
occupant
;
but
remembering
the
tale
connected
with
the
mansion
<EOS>
,
it
seemed
the
very
place
for
such
a
deed
,
and
one
that
might
have
been
its
predestined
theatre
years
upon
years
ago
.
 
<EOS>
Viewed
with
reference
to
this
legend
,
the
sheet
of
water
where
the
steward
's
body
had
been
found
appeared
to
wear
a
black
and
sullen
character
,
such
as
no
other
pool
might
own
;
the
bell
upon
the
roof
that
had
told
the
tale
of
murder
to
the
midnight
wind
,
became
a
very
phantom
whose
voice
would
raise
the
listener
's
hair
on
end
;
and
every
leafless
bough
that
nodded
to
another
,
had
its
stealthy
whispering
of
the
crime
.
  
<EOS>
Joe
paced
up
and
down
the
path
,
sometimes
stopping
in
affected
contemplation
of
the
building
or
the
prospect
,
sometimes
leaning
against
a
tree
with
an
assumed
air
of
idleness
and
indifference
,
but
always
keeping
an
eye
upon
the
window
he
had
singled
out
at
first
.
 
<EOS>
After
some
quarter
of
an
hour
's
delay
,
a
small
white
hand
was
waved
to
him
for
an
instant
from
this
casement
,
and
the
young
man
,
with
a
respectful
bow
,
departed
;
saying
under
his
breath
as
he
crossed
his
horse
again
,
"
No
errand
for
me
to
-
day
!
"
  
<EOS>
But
the
air
of
smartness
,
the
cock
of
the
hat
to
which
John
Willet
had
objected
,
and
the
spring
nosegay
,
all
betokened
some
little
errand
of
his
own
,
having
a
more
interesting
object
than
a
vintner
or
even
a
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
indeed
,
it
turned
out
;
for
when
he
had
settled
with
the
vintner
---
whose
place
of
business
was
down
in
some
deep
cellars
hard
by
Thames
Street
,
and
who
was
as
purple
-
faced
an
old
gentleman
as
if
he
had
all
his
life
supported
their
arched
roof
on
his
head
---
when
he
had
settled
the
account
,
and
taken
the
receipt
,
and
declined
tasting
more
than
three
glasses
of
old
sherry
,
to
the
unbounded
astonishment
of
the
purple
-
faced
vintner
,
who
,
gimlet
in
hand
,
had
projected
an
attack
upon
at
least
a
score
of
dusty
casks
,
and
who
stood
transfixed
,
or
morally
gimleted
as
it
were
,
to
his
own
wall
---
when
he
had
done
all
this
,
and
disposed
besides
of
a
frugal
dinner
at
the
Black
Lion
in
Whitechapel
;
spurning
the
Monument
and
John
's
advice
,
he
turned
his
steps
towards
the
locksmith
's
house
,
attracted
by
the
eyes
of
blooming
Dolly
Varden
.
  
<EOS>
Joe
was
by
no
means
a
sheepish
fellow
,
but
,
for
all
that
,
when
he
got
to
the
corner
of
the
street
in
which
the
locksmith
lived
,
he
could
by
no
means
make
up
his
mind
to
walk
straight
to
the
house
.
<EOS>
First
,
he
resolved
to
stroll
up
another
street
for
five
minutes
,
then
up
another
street
for
five
minutes
more
,
and
so
on
until
he
had
lost
full
half
an
hour
,
when
he
made
a
bold
plunge
and
found
himself
with
a
red
face
and
a
beating
heart
in
the
smoky
workshop
.
  
<EOS>
"
Joe
Willet
,
or
his
ghost
?
"
said
Varden
,
rising
from
the
desk
at
which
he
was
busy
with
his
books
,
and
looking
at
him
under
his
spectacles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Which
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
Joe
in
the
flesh
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
That
's
hearty
.
<EOS>
And
how
are
all
the
Chigwell
company
,
Joe
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Much
as
usual
,
sir
---
they
and
I
agree
as
well
as
ever
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
!
"
said
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
be
patient
,
Joe
,
and
bear
with
old
folks
'
foibles
.
 
<EOS>
How
's
the
mare
,
Joe
?
 
<EOS>
Does
she
do
the
four
miles
an
hour
as
easily
as
ever
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
<EOS>
Does
she
,
Joe
?
 
<EOS>
Eh
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
What
have
we
there
,
Joe
---
a
nosegay
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
very
poor
one
<EOS>
,
sir
---
I
thought
Miss
Dolly
---
"
  
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Gabriel
,
dropping
his
voice
,
and
shaking
his
head
,
"
not
Dolly
.
 
<EOS>
Give
'em
to
her
mother
,
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
A
great
deal
better
give
'em
to
her
mother
.
 
<EOS>
Would
you
mind
giving
'em
to
Mrs
Varden
,
Joe
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
sir
,
"
Joe
replied
,
and
endeavouring
,
but
not
with
the
greatest
possible
success
,
to
hide
his
disappointment
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
very
glad
<EOS>
,
I
'm
sure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
patting
him
on
the
back
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
do
n't
matter
who
has
'em
,
Joe
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
,
sir
.
"
---
Dear
heart
,
how
the
words
stuck
in
his
throat
!
  
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
"
said
Gabriel
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
just
been
called
to
tea
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
in
the
parlour
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
,
"
thought
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
"
Which
of
'em
I
wonder
---
<EOS>
Mrs
or
Miss
?
"
 
<EOS>
The
locksmith
settled
the
doubt
as

as

had
been
expressed

,
by

him

,

,
"
Martha
,
my
dear
,
here

young

Willet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Now
,
Mrs
Varden
,
regarding
the

as

,
or

;

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Wherefore
<EOS>
she
was

;
and

with

,

that

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
WOULD

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Joe

on

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
If

!
<EOS>
---
   
<EOS>
"
I

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
"
 
<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>
Joe

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're

,

,
"

V.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

Willet
,

,
does

.
 
<EOS>
His

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

"

;

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
This

was

in

,
and
included

,
upon

of

it
was

,
for
Gabriel
had

,
until

was

by
Mrs
Varden
herself
,
and

had
as

for

female

of
the

's

---
or

---
as

.
  
<EOS>
But
he
had
no

to

anything
in
his
own

,
for
at
that
moment
Dolly
herself
appeared
,
and
struck
him
quite

with
her

.
 
<EOS>
Never
had
Dolly
looked
so
handsome
as
she
did
then
,
in
all
the
glow
and
grace
of
youth
,
with
all
her
charms
increased
a
hundredfold
by
a
most
becoming
dress
,
by
a
thousand
little
coquettish
ways
which
nobody
could
assume
with
a
better
grace
,
and
all
the
sparkling
expectation
of
that
accursed
party
.
<EOS>
It
is
impossible
to
tell
how
Joe
hated
that
party
wherever
it
was
,
and
all
the
other
people
who
were
going
to
it
,
whoever
they
were
.
  
<EOS>
And
she
hardly
looked
at
him
---
<EOS>
no
,
hardly
looked
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
the
chair
was
seen
through
the
open
door
coming
blundering
into
the
workshop
,
she
actually
clapped
her

and
seemed

to

.
<EOS>
But
Joe
gave
her
his
arm
---
there
was
some
comfort
in
that
---
and
handed
her
into
it
.
 
<EOS>
To
see
her
seat
herself
inside
,
with
her
laughing
eyes
brighter
than
diamonds
,
and
her
hand
---
surely
she
had
the

in
the

---
on
the
ledge
of
the
open

,
and
her
little

provokingly
and

up
,
as
if

why
Joe
did

!
 
<EOS>
To
think
how
well

the
modest

would
have

that

,
and
how

!
 
<EOS>
To

all

was

,
and
of

in

,
and

saying
it
ai
n't
half
as
real

you

,
and
I

!
 
<EOS>
To

,

---
 
what

,
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
The

seemed

.
  
<EOS>
There

.
 
<EOS>
So

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
when
she
was
at

fluttering
about

---
with

,

.
<EOS>
Miggs
was
hovering

;
and
the

her

,

,
appeared
,
after
Dolly
,

.
 
<EOS>
It

impossible
to
talk
.
 
<EOS>
It

done
.
 
<EOS>
He

,
and

,
and
round
,
and
ruminate

all

of
the
locksmith
's
lovely
daughter
.
  
<EOS>
Gabriel
was
dull

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
that

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

;

I

.
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

,

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

!
"
 
<EOS>
Joe

,

"
Certainly
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank

,
Varden
,

,
"
returned

;
"
but
I

.
 
<EOS>
Tobacco

,

,

than
any
I
can

,
and
therefore
I

and

,
my

.
 
<EOS>
Good

,
Mr
Joseph
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm

seen

,
and
I
only
wish
I
could

provided
something
more

.
 
<EOS>
Remember

if

to

Willet
,
and
tell

that
whenever
he
comes
here
I

crow

.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Having
uttered
these
words
with
great
sweetness
of
manner
,
the
good
lady
dropped
a
curtsey
remarkable
for
its
condescension
,
and
serenely
withdrew
.
  
<EOS>
And
it
was
for
this
Joe
had
looked
forward
to
the
twenty
-
fifth
of
March
for
weeks
and
weeks
,
and
had
gathered
the
flowers
with
so
much
care
,
and
had
cocked
his
hat
,
and
made
himself
so
smart
!
 
<EOS>
This
was
the
end
of
all
his
bold
determination
,
resolved
upon
for
the
hundredth
time
,
to
speak
out
to
Dolly
and
tell
her
how
he
loved
her
!
 
<EOS>
To
see
her
for
a
minute
---
for
but
a
minute
---
to
find
her
going
out
to
a
party
and
glad
to
go
;
to
be
looked
upon
as
a
common
pipe
-
smoker
,
beer
-
bibber
,
spirit
-
guzzler
,
and
tosspot
!
 
<EOS>
He
bade
farewell
to
his
friend
the
locksmith
,
and
hastened
to
take
horse
at
the
Black
Lion
,
thinking
as
he
turned
towards
home
,
as
many
another
Joe
has
thought
before
and
since
,
that
here
was
an
end
to
all
his
hopes
---
that
the
thing
was
impossible
and
never
could
be
---
that
she
did
n't
care
for
him
---
that
he
was
wretched
for
life
---
and
that
the
only
congenial
prospect
left
him
,
was
to
go
for
a
soldier
or
a
sailor
,
and
get
some
obliging
enemy
to
knock
his
brains
out
as
soon
as
possible
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
14
    
Joe
Willet
rode
leisurely
along
in
his
desponding
mood
,
picturing
the
locksmith
's
daughter
going
down
long
country
-
dances
,
and
poussetting
dreadfully
with
bold
strangers
---
which
was
almost
too
much
to
bear
---
when
he
heard
the
tramp
of
a
horse
's
feet
behind
him
,
and
looking
back
,
saw
a
well
-
mounted
gentleman
advancing
at
a
smart
canter
.
 
<EOS>
As
this
rider
passed
,
he
checked
his
steed
,
and
called
him
of
the
Maypole
by
his
name
.
 
<EOS>
Joe
set
spurs
to
the
grey
mare
,
and
was
at
his
side
directly
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
it
was
you
,
sir
,
"
he
said
,
touching
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
fair
evening
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Glad
to
see
you
out
of
doors
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
gentleman
smiled
and
nodded
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
gay
doings
have
been
going
on
to
-
day
,
Joe
?
 
<EOS>
Is
she
as
pretty
as
ever
?
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
do
n't
blush
,
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
coloured
at
all
,
Mr
Edward
,
"
said
Joe
,
"
which
I
did
n't
know
I
did
,
it
was
to
think
I
should
have
been
such
a
fool
as
ever
to
have
any
hope
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
as
far
out
of
my
reach
as
---
as
Heaven
is
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Joe
,
I
hope
that
's
not
altogether
beyond
it
,
"
said
Edward
,
good
-
humouredly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Eh
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
sighed
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
very
fine
talking
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Proverbs
are
easily
made
in
cold
blood
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
ca
n't
be
helped
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
bound
for
our
house
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
am
not
quite
strong
yet
,
I
shall
stay
there
to
-
night
,
and
ride
home
coolly
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
're
in
no
particular
hurry
,
"
said
Joe
after
a
short
silence
,
"
and
will
bear
with
the
pace
of
this
poor
jade
,
I
shall
be
glad
to
ride
on
with
you
to
the
Warren
,
sir
,
and
hold
your
horse
when
you
dismount
.
 
<EOS>
It
'll
save
you
having
to
walk
from
the
Maypole
,
there
and
back
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
spare
the
time
well
,
sir
,
for
I
am
too
soon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
so
am
I
,
"
returned
Edward
,
"
though
I
was
unconsciously
riding
fast
just
now
,
in
compliment
I
suppose
to
the
pace
of
my
thoughts
,
which
were
travelling
post
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
keep
together
,
Joe
,
willingly
,
and
be
as
good
company
as
may
be
.
 
<EOS>
And
cheer
up
,
cheer
up
,
think
of
the
locksmith
's
daughter
with
a
stout
heart
,
and
you
shall
win
her
yet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Joe
shook
his
head
;
but
there
was
something
so
cheery
in
the
buoyant
hopeful
manner
of
this
speech
,
that
his
spirits
rose
under
its
influence
,
and
communicated
as
it
would
seem
some
new
impulse
even
to
the
grey
mare
,
who
,
breaking
from
her
sober
amble
into
a
gentle
trot
,
emulated
the
pace
of
Edward
Chester
's
horse
,
and
appeared
to
flatter
herself
that
he
was
doing
his
very
best
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
fine
dry
night
,
and
the
light
of
a
young
moon
,
which
was
then
just
rising
,
shed
around
that
peace
and
tranquillity
which
gives
to
evening
time
its
most
delicious
charm
.
 
<EOS>
The
lengthened
shadows
of
the
trees
,
softened
as
if
reflected
in
still
water
,
threw
their
carpet
on
the
path
the
travellers
pursued
,
and
the
light
wind
stirred
yet
more
softly
than
before
,
as
though
it
were
soothing
Nature
in
her
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
By
little
and
little
they
ceased
talking
,
and
rode
on
side
by
side
in
a
pleasant
silence
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
Maypole
lights
are
brilliant
to
-
night
,
"
said
Edward
,
as
they
rode
along
the
lane
from
which
,
while
the
intervening
trees
were
bare
of
leaves
,
that
hostelry
was
visible
.
  
<EOS>
"
Brilliant
indeed
,
sir
,
"
returned
Joe
,
rising
in
his
stirrups
to
get
a
better
view
.
 
<EOS>
"
Lights
in
the
large
room
,
and
a
fire
glimmering
in
the
best
bedchamber
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
what
company
can
this
be
for
,
I
wonder
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Some
benighted
horseman
wending
towards
London
,
and
deterred
from
going
on
to
-
night
by
the
marvellous
tales
of
my
friend
the
highwayman
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Edward
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
must
be
a
horseman
of
good
quality
to
have
such
accommodations
.
<EOS>
Your
bed
too
,
sir
---
!
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
matter
,
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
Any
other
room
will
do
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
come
<EOS>
---
there
's
nine
striking
.
 
<EOS>
We
may
push
on
.
"
  
<EOS>
They
cantered
forward
at
as
brisk
a
pace
as
Joe
's
charger
could
attain
,
and
presently
stopped
in
the
little
copse
where
he
had
left
her
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Edward
dismounted
,
gave
his
bridle
to
his
companion
,
and
walked
with
a
light
step
towards
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
A
female
servant
was
waiting
at
a
side
gate
in
the
garden
-
wall
,
and
admitted
him
without
delay
.
 
<EOS>
He
hurried
along
the
terrace
-
walk
,
and
darted
up
a
flight
of
broad
steps
leading
into
an
old
and
gloomy
hall
,
whose
walls
were
ornamented
with
rusty
suits
of
armour
,
antlers
,
weapons
of
the
chase
,
and
suchlike
garniture
.
 
<EOS>
Here
he
paused
,
but
not
long
;
for
as
he
looked
round
,
as
if
expecting
the
attendant
to
have
followed
,
and
wondering
she
had
not
done
so
,
a
lovely
girl
appeared
,
whose
dark
hair
next
moment
rested
on
his
breast
.
 
<EOS>
Almost
at
the
same
instant
a
heavy
hand
was
laid
upon
her
arm
,
Edward
felt
himself
thrust
away
,
and
Mr
Haredale
stood
between
them
.
  
<EOS>
He
regarded
the
young
man
sternly
without
removing
his
hat
;
with
one
hand
clasped
his
niece
,
and
with
the
other
,
in
which
he
held
his
riding
-
whip
,
motioned
him
towards
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
man
drew
himself
up
,
and
returned
his
gaze
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
well
done
of
you
,
sir
,
to
corrupt
my
servants
,
and
enter
my
house
unbidden
and
in
secret
,
like
a
thief
!
"
said
Mr
Haredale
.
"
<EOS>
Leave
it
,
sir
,
and
return
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Haredale
's
presence
,
"
returned
the
young
man
,
"
and
your
relationship
to
her
,
give
you
a
licence
which
,
if
you
are
a
brave
man
,
you
will
not
abuse
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
compelled
me
to
this
course
,
and
the
fault
is
yours
---
not
mine
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
neither
generous
,
nor
honourable
,
nor
the
act
of
a
true
man
,
sir
,
"
retorted
the
other
,
"
to
tamper
with
the
affections
of
a
weak
,
trusting
girl
,
while
you
shrink
,
in
your
unworthiness
,
from
her
guardian
and
protector
,
and
dare
not
meet
the
light
of
day
.
<EOS>
More
than
this
I
will
not
say
to
you
,
save
that
I
forbid
you
this
house
,
and
require
you
to
be
gone
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
neither
generous
,
nor
honourable
,
nor
the
act
of
a
true
man
to
play
the
spy
,
"
said
Edward
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
words
imply
dishonour
,
and
I
reject
them
with
the
scorn
they
merit
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
find
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
calmly
,
"
your
trusty
go
-
between
in
waiting
at
the
gate
by
which
you
entered
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
played
no
spy
's
part
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
chanced
to
see
you
pass
the
gate
,
and
followed
.
 
<EOS>
You
might
have
heard
me
knocking
for
admission
,
had
you
been
less
swift
of
foot
,
or
lingered
in
the
garden
.
 
<EOS>
Please
to
withdraw
.
 
<EOS>
Your
presence
here
is
offensive
to
me
and
distressful
to
my
niece
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
said
these
words
,
he
passed
his
arm
about
the
waist
of
the
terrified
and
weeping
girl
,
and
drew
her
closer
to
him
;
and
though
the
habitual
severity
of
his
manner
was
scarcely
changed
,
there
was
yet
apparent
in
the
action
<EOS>
an
air
of
kindness
and
sympathy
for
her
distress
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Haredale
,
"
said
Edward
,
"
your
arm
encircles
her
on
whom
I
have
set
my
every
hope
and
thought
,
and
to
purchase
one
minute
's
happiness
for
whom
I
would
gladly
lay
down
my
life
;
this
house
is
the
casket
that
holds
the
precious
jewel
of
my
existence
.
 
<EOS>
Your
niece
has
plighted
her
faith
to
me
,
and
I
have
plighted
mine
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
What
have
I
done
that
you
should
hold
me
in
this
light
esteem
,
and
give
me
these
discourteous
words
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
done
that
,
sir
,
"
answered
Mr
Haredale
,
"
which
must
he
undone
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
tied
a
lover'-knot
here
which
must
be
cut
asunder
.
 
<EOS>
Take
good
heed
of
what
I
say
.
 
<EOS>
Must
.
 
<EOS>
I
cancel
the
bond
between
ye
.
 
<EOS>
I
reject
you
,
and
all
of
your
kith
and
kin
---
all
the
false
,
hollow
,
heartless
stock
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
High
words
,
sir
,
"
said
Edward
,
scornfully
.
  
<EOS>
"
Words
of
purpose
and
meaning
,
as
you
will
find
,
"
replied
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
Lay
them
to
heart
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lay
you
then
,
these
,
"
said
Edward
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
cold
and
sullen
temper
,
which
chills
every
breast
about
you
,
which
turns
affection
into
fear
,
and
changes
duty
into
dread
,
has
forced
us
on
this
secret
course
,
repugnant
to
our
nature
and
our
wish
,
and
far
more
foreign
,
sir
,
to
us
than
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
a
false
,
a
hollow
,
or
a
heartless
man
;
the
character
is
yours
,
who
poorly
venture
on
these
injurious
terms
,
against
the
truth
,
and
under
the
shelter
whereof
I
reminded
you
just
now
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
not
cancel
the
bond
between
us
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
abandon
this
pursuit
.
 
<EOS>
I
rely
upon
your
niece
's
truth
and
honour
,
and
set
your
influence
at
nought
.
 
<EOS>
I
leave
her
with
a
confidence
in
her
pure
faith
,
which
you
will
never
weaken
,
and
with
no
concern
but
that
I
do
not
leave
her
in
some
gentler
care
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
,
he
pressed
her
cold
hand
to
his
lips
,
and
once
more
encountering
and
returning
Mr
Haredale
's
steady
look
,
withdrew
.
  
<EOS>
A
few
words
to
Joe
as
he
mounted
his
horse
sufficiently
explained
what
had
passed
,
and
renewed
all
that
young
gentleman
's
despondency
with
tenfold
aggravation
.
 
<EOS>
They
rode
back
to
the
Maypole
without
exchanging
a
syllable
,
and
arrived
at
the
door
with
heavy
hearts
.
  
<EOS>
Old
John
,
who
had
peeped
from
behind
the
red
curtain
as
they
rode
up
shouting
for
Hugh
,
was
out
directly
,
and
said
with
great
importance
as
he
held
the
young
man
's
stirrup
,
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
comfortable
in
bed
---
the
best
bed
.
 
<EOS>
A
thorough
gentleman
;
the
smilingest
,
affablest
gentleman
<EOS>
I
ever
had
to
do
with
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
,
Willet
?
"
said
Edward
carelessly
,
as
he
dismounted
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
worthy
father
,
sir
,
"
replied
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
honourable
,
venerable
father
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
does
he
mean
?
"
said
Edward
,
looking
with
a
mixture
of
alarm
and
doubt
,
at
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
DO
you
mean
?
"
said
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
see
Mr
Edward
does
n't
understand
,
father
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
did
n't
you
know
of
it
,
sir
?
"
said
John
,
opening
his
eyes
wide
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
very
singular
!
 
<EOS>
Bless
you
,
he
's
been
here
ever
since
noon
to
-
day
,
and
Mr
Haredale
has
been
having
a
long
talk
with
him
,
and
has
n't
been
gone
an
hour
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
father
,
Willet
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
he
told
me
so
---
a
handsome
,
slim
,
upright
gentleman
,
in
green
-
and
-
gold
.
 
<EOS>
In
your
old
room
up
yonder
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
No
doubt
you
can
go
in
,
sir
,
"
said
John
,
walking
backwards
into
the
road
and
looking
up
at
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
n't
put
out
his
candles
yet
<EOS>
,
I
see
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Edward
glanced
at
the
window
also
,
and
hastily
murmuring
that
he
had
changed
his
mind
---
forgotten
something
---
and
must
return
to
London
,
mounted
his
horse
again
and
rode
away
;
leaving
the
Willets
,
father
and
son
,
looking
at
each
other
in
mute
astonishment
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
15
    
<EOS>
At
noon
next
day
,
John
Willet
's
guest
sat
lingering
over
his
breakfast
in
his
own
home
,
surrounded
by
a
variety
of
comforts
,
which
left
the
Maypole
's
highest
flight
and
utmost
stretch
of
accommodation
at
an
infinite
distance
behind
,
and
suggested
comparisons
very
much
to
the
disadvantage
and
disfavour
of
that
venerable
tavern
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
broad
old
-
fashioned
window
-
seat
---
as
capacious
as
many
modern
sofas
,
and
cushioned
to
serve
the
purpose
of
a
luxurious
settee
---
in
the
broad
old
-
fashioned
window
-
seat
of
a
roomy
chamber
,
Mr
Chester
lounged
,
very
much
at
his
ease
,
over
a
well
-
furnished
breakfast
-
table
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
exchanged
his
riding
-
coat
for
a
handsome
morning
-
gown
,
his
boots
for
slippers
;
had
been
at
great
pains
to
atone
for
the
having
been
obliged
to
make
his
toilet
when
he
rose
without
the
aid
of
dressing
-
case
and
tiring

;
and
,
having
gradually
forgotten
through
these
means
the

of
an
indifferent
night
and
an
early
ride
,
was
in
a
state
of
perfect
complacency
,
indolence
,
and
satisfaction
.
  
<EOS>
The
situation
in
which
he
found
himself
,
indeed
,
was
particularly
favourable
to
the
growth
of
these
feelings
;
for
,
not
to
mention
the
lazy
influence
of
a
late
and
lonely
breakfast
,
with
the
additional
sedative
of
a
newspaper
<EOS>
,
there
was
an
air
of
repose
about
his
place
of
residence
peculiar
to
itself
,
and
which
hangs
about
it
,
even
in
these
times
,
when
it
is
more
bustling
and
busy
than
it
was
in
days
of
yore
.
  
<EOS>
There
are
,
still
,
worse
places
than
the
Temple
,
on
a
sultry
day
,
for
basking
in
the
sun
,
or
resting
idly
in
the
shade
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
yet
a
drowsiness
in
its
courts
,
and
a
dreamy
dulness
in
its
trees
and
gardens
;
those
who
pace
its
lanes
and
squares
may
yet
hear
the
echoes
of
their
footsteps
on
the
sounding
stones
,
and
read
upon
its
gates
,
in
passing
from
the
tumult
of
the
Strand
or
Fleet
Street
,
"
Who
enters
here
leaves
noise
behind
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
There
is
still
the
plash
of
falling
water
in
fair
Fountain
Court
,
and
there
are
yet
nooks
and
corners
where
dun
-
haunted
students
may
look
down
from
their
dusty
garrets
,
on
a
vagrant
ray
of
sunlight
patching
the
shade
of
the
tall
houses
,
and
seldom

to
reflect
a
passing

's
form
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
yet
,
in
the
Temple
,
something
of
a
clerkly
monkish
atmosphere
,
which
public
offices
of
law
have
not
disturbed
,
and
even
legal
firms
have
failed
to
scare
away
.
 
<EOS>
In
summer
time
,
its
pumps
suggest
to
thirsty
idlers
,
springs
cooler
,
and
more
sparkling
,
and
deeper
than
other
wells
;
and
as
they
trace
the
spillings
of
full
pitchers
on
the
heated
ground
,
they
snuff
the
freshness
,
and
,
sighing
,
cast
sad
looks
towards
the
Thames
,
and
think
of
baths
and
boats
,
and
saunter
on
,
despondent
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
in
a
room
in
Paper
Buildings
---
a
row
of
goodly
tenements
,
shaded
in
front

ancient
trees
,
and
looking
,
at
the
back
,
upon
the
Temple

---
that
this
,
our
idler
,
lounged
;
now
taking
up
again
the
paper
he
had
laid
down
a
hundred

;
now
trifling
with
the

of
his
meal
;
now
pulling

golden

,
and

,
or

trim

,
where

<EOS>
Here

;
there
a

-
maid
had

for
Templars
than

;

an

,
with

,
regarded
both

with

;

that
a

,
ogling
the

,
looked

like

upon
the

,
and
wondered
she
did

.
 
<EOS>
Apart

the
river
's

two

down
in

;
and
one

<EOS>
"
Ned
is
amazingly
patient
!
"
<EOS>

,
"
immensely

!
 
<EOS>
He

I

and
has

.
 
<EOS>
A
most

dog
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Really
,

"

<EOS>
"
Dear
Ned
!
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Have

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Three

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

What

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
That

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Edward

,

.
 
<EOS>
His

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
A

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
From
my

I
have
been
accustomed

luxury
and

,
and
have
been

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

of
wealth
has
been
familiarised
to

from
my

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
taught
to
look
upon
those

,

which

to

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

been
,
as
the
phrase

,
liberally

,
and
am

nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
find

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>

said
.
 
<EOS>
Oblige
me
with
the
milk
again
.
 
<EOS>
Listening
,
invariably
makes
me
feverish
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
I
would
say
then
,
tends
to
this
,
"
said
Edward
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
bear
this
absolute
dependence
,
sir
,
even
upon
you
.
 
<EOS>
Time
has
been
lost
and
opportunity
thrown
away
,
but
I
am
yet
a
young
man
,
and
may
retrieve
it
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
give
me
the
means
of
devoting
such
abilities
and
energies
as
I
possess
,
to
some
worthy
pursuit
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
let
me
try
to
make
for
myself
an
honourable
path
in
life
?
 
<EOS>
For
any
term
you
please
to
name
---
say
for
five
years
if
you
will
---
I
will
pledge
myself
to
move
no
further
in
the
matter
of
our
difference
without
your
fall
concurrence
.
 
<EOS>
During
that
period
,
I
will
endeavour
earnestly
and
patiently
,
if
ever
man
did
,
to
open
some
prospect
for
myself
,
and
free
you
from
the
burden
you
fear
I
should
become
if
I
married
one
<EOS>
whose
worth

her

.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
do
this
,

?
 
<EOS>
At
the

the
term

,

.
 
<EOS>
Till

,
unless
it

revived

you
,
let

never

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Ned
,
"

,

,
"
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
But

Ned
---
 
altogether

---
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Edward

<EOS>
"
You

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
Her

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Quite

,

<EOS>
He
stood

had

,

having
risen

nothing

---

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
We

<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
A

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

My

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A

<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
A

!
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>

;

"

<EOS>

,
"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
As

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
With

<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
Your

,

.
 
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

's

,
"

,
"

!
 
<EOS>
I
to

!
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

<EOS>
how

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

,

a

,
unless

?
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
 
<EOS>
Let

,
Ned
,

nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Even
if
one

set
that
objection
aside
,
which
is

,

come

another
which

.
 
<EOS>
The
very
idea
of
marrying
a
girl
whose
father
was
killed
,
like

!
 
<EOS>
Good
God
,
Ned
,
how
disagreeable
!
 
<EOS>
Consider
the
impossibility
of
having
any
respect
for
your
father
-
in

under
such

---
think

"
viewed
"

,

"

"

,
and

in

family

.
 
<EOS>
It

that
I
really

girl
ought

have

by

state
to

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
tease

perhaps
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
rather

alone
?
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Ned
,
most

.
 
<EOS>
God
bless

.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
be
going
out

,
but
we
shall
meet
to
-
night
,
or
if

-

,

.
<EOS>
Take

in

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
person
of

,

---

.
 
<EOS>
God

you
!
"
  
<EOS>
With

,
the
father
,
who
