<EOS>
The
son
,
who
had
appeared
so
lost
in
thought
as
not
to
hear
or
understand
them
,
remained
quite
still
and
silent
.
 
<EOS>
After
the
lapse
of
half
an
hour
or
so
,
the
elder
Chester
,
gaily
dressed
,
went
out
.
 
<EOS>
The
younger
still
sat
with
his
head
resting
on
his
hands
,
in
what
appeared
to
be
a
kind
of
stupor
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
16
    
A
series
of
pictures
representing
the
streets
of
London
in
the
night
,
even
at
the
comparatively
recent
date
of
this
tale
,
would
present
to
the
eye
something
so
very
different
in
character
from
the
reality
which
is
witnessed
in
these
times
,
that
it
would
be
difficult
for
the
beholder
to
recognise
his
most
familiar
walks
in
the
altered
aspect
of
little
more
than
half
a
century
ago
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
,
one
and
all
,
from
the
broadest
and
best
to
the
narrowest
and
least
frequented
,
very
dark
.
 
<EOS>
The
oil
and
cotton
lamps
,
though
regularly
trimmed
twice
or
thrice
in
the
long
winter
nights
,
burnt
feebly
at
the
best
;
and
at
a
late
hour
,
when
they
were
unassisted
by
the
lamps
and
candles
in
the
shops
,
cast
but
a
narrow
track
of
doubtful
light
upon
the
footway
,
leaving
the
projecting
doors
and
house
-
fronts
in
the
deepest
gloom
.
 
<EOS>
Many
of
the
courts
and
lanes
were
left
in
total
darkness
;
those
of
the
meaner
sort
,
where
one
glimmering
light
twinkled
for
a
score
of
houses
,
being
favoured
in
no
slight
degree
.
 
<EOS>
Even
in
these
places
,
the
inhabitants
had
often
good
reason
for
extinguishing
their
lamp
as
soon
as
it
was
lighted
;
and
the
watch
being
utterly
inefficient
and
powerless
to
prevent
them
,
they
did
so
at
their
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
in
the
lightest
thoroughfares
,
there
was
at
every
turn
some
obscure
and
dangerous
spot
whither
a
thief
might
fly
or
shelter
,
and
few
would
care
to
follow
;
and
the
city
being
belted
round
by
fields
,
green
lanes
,
waste
grounds
,
and
lonely
roads
,
dividing
it
at
that
time
from
the
suburbs
that
have
joined
it
since
,
escape
,
even
where
the
pursuit
was
hot
,
was
rendered
easy
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
no
wonder
that
with
these
favouring
circumstances
in
full
and
constant
operation
,
street
robberies
,
often
accompanied
by
cruel
wounds
,
and
not
unfrequently
by
loss
of
life
,
should
have
been
of
nightly
occurrence
in
the
very
heart
of
London
,
or
that
quiet
folks
should
have
had
great
dread
of
traversing
its
streets
after
the
shops
were
closed
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
unusual
for
those
who
wended
home
alone
at
midnight
,
to
keep
the
middle
of
the
road
,
the
better
to
guard
against
surprise
from
lurking
footpads
;
few
would
venture
to
repair
at
a
late
hour
to
Kentish
Town
or
Hampstead
,
or
even
to
Kensington
or
Chelsea
,
unarmed
and
unattended
;
while
he
who
had
been
loudest
and
most
valiant
at
the
supper
-
table
or
the
tavern
,
and
had
but
a
mile
or
so
to
go
,
was
glad
to
fee
a
link
-
boy
to
escort
him
home
.
  
<EOS>
There
were
many
other
characteristics
---
not
quite
so
disagreeable
---
 
about
the
thoroughfares
of
London
then
,
with
which
they
had
been
long
familiar
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
the
shops
,
especially
those
to
the
eastward
of
Temple
Bar
,
still
adhered
to
the
old
practice
of
hanging
out
a
sign
;
and
the
creaking
and
swinging
of
these
boards
in
their
iron
frames
on
windy
nights
,
formed
a
strange
and
mournfal
concert
for
the
ears
of
those
who
lay
awake
in
bed
or
hurried
through
the
streets
.
 
<EOS>
Long
stands
of
hackney
-
chairs
and
groups
of
chairmen
,
compared
with
whom
the
coachmen
of
our
day
are
gentle
and
polite
,
obstructed
the
way
and
filled
the
air
with
clamour
;
night
-
cellars
,
indicated
by
a
little
stream
of
light
crossing
the
pavement
,
and
stretching
out
half
-
way
into
the
road
,
and
by
the
stifled
roar
of
voices
from
below
,
yawned
for
the
reception
and
entertainment
of
the
most
abandoned
of
both
sexes
;
under
every
shed
and
bulk
small
groups
of
link
-
boys
gamed
away
the
earnings
of
the
day
;
or
one
more
weary
than
the
rest
,
gave
way
to
sleep
,
and
let
the
fragment
of
his
torch
fall
hissing
on
the
puddled
ground
.
  
<EOS>
Then
there
was
the
watch
with
staff
and
lantern
crying
the
hour
,
and
the
kind
of
weather
;
and
those
who
woke
up
at
his
voice
and
turned
them
round
in
bed
,
were
glad
to
hear
it
rained
,
or
snowed
,
or
blew
,
or
froze
,
for
very
comfort
's
sake
.
 
<EOS>
The
solitary
passenger
was
startled
by
the
chairmen
's
cry
of
"
By
your
leave
there
!
"
<EOS>
as
two
came
trotting
past
him
with
their
empty
vehicle
---
carried
backwards
to
show
its
being
disengaged
---
and
hurried
to
the
nearest
stand
.
<EOS>
Many
a
private
chair
,
too
,
inclosing
some
fine
lady
,
monstrously
hooped
and
furbelowed
,
and
preceded
by
running
-
footmen
bearing
flambeaux
---
for
which
extinguishers
are
yet
suspended
before
the
doors
of
a
few
houses
of
the
better
sort
---
made
the
way
gay
and
light
as
it
danced
along
,
and
darker
and
more
dismal
when
it
had
passed
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
unusual
for
these
running
gentry
,
who
carried
it
with
a
very
high
hand
,
to
quarrel
in
the
servants
'
hall
while
waiting
for
their
masters
and
mistresses
;
and
,
falling
to
blows
either
there
or
in
the
street
without
,
to
strew
the
place
of
skirmish
with
hair
-
powder
,
fragments
of
bag
-
wigs
,
and
scattered
nosegays
.
 
<EOS>
Gaming
,
the
vice
which
ran
so
high
among
all
classes
(
the
fashion
being
of
course
set
by
the
upper
)
,
was
generally
the
cause
of
these
disputes
;
for
cards
and
dice
were
as
openly
used
,
and
worked
as
much
mischief
,
and
yielded
as
much
excitement
below
stairs
,
as
above
.
 
<EOS>
While
incidents
like
these
,
arising
out
of
drums
and
masquerades
and
parties
at
quadrille
,
were
passing
at
the
west
end
of
the
town
,
heavy
stagecoaches
and
scarce
heavier
waggons
were
lumbering
slowly
towards
the
city
,
the
coachmen
,
guard
,
and
passengers
,
armed
to
the
teeth
,
and
the
coach
---
a
day
or
so
perhaps
behind
its
time
,
but
that
was
nothing
---
despoiled
by
highwaymen
;
who
made
no
scruple
to
attack
,
alone
and
single
-
handed
,
a
whole
caravan
of
goods
and
men
,
and
sometimes
shot
a
passenger
or
two
,
and
were
sometimes
shot
themselves
,
as
the
case
might
be
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
morrow
,
rumours
of
this
new
act
of
daring
on
the
road
yielded
matter
for
a
few
hours
'
conversation
through
the
town
,
and
a
Public
Progress
of
some
fine
gentleman
(
half
-
drunk
)
to
Tyburn
,
dressed
in
the
newest
fashion
,
and
damning
the
ordinary
with
unspeakable
gallantry
and
grace
,
furnished
to
the
populace
,
at
once
a
pleasant
excitement
and
a
wholesome
and
profound
example
.
  
<EOS>
Among
all
the
dangerous
characters
who
,
in
such
a
state
of
society
,
prowled
and
skulked
in
the
metropolis
at
night
,
there
was
one
man
from
whom
many
as
uncouth
and
fierce
as
he
,
shrunk
with
an
involuntary
dread
.
 
<EOS>
Who
he
was
,
or
<EOS>
whence
he
came
,
was
a
question
often
asked
,
but
which
none
could
answer
.
 
<EOS>
His
name
was
unknown
,
he
had
never
been
seen
until
within
about
eight
days
or
thereabouts
,
and
was
equally
a
stranger
to
the
old
ruffians
,
upon
whose
haunts
he
ventured
fearlessly
,
as
to
the
young
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
be
no
spy
,
for
he
never
removed
his
slouched
hat
to
look
about
him
,
entered
into
conversation
with
no
man
,
heeded
nothing
that
passed
,
listened
to
no
discourse
,
regarded
nobody
that
came
or
went
.
 
<EOS>
But
so
surely
as
the
dead
of
night
set
in
,
so
surely
this
man
was
in
the
midst
of
the
loose
concourse
in
the
night
-
cellar
where
outcasts
of
every
grade
resorted
;
and
there
he
sat
till
morning
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
not
only
a
spectre
at
their
licentious
feasts
;
a
something
in
the
midst
of
their
revelry
and
riot
that
chilled
and
haunted
them
;
but
out
of
doors
he
was
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
Directly
it
was
dark
,
he
was
abroad
---
never
in
company
with
any
one
,
but
always
alone
;
never
lingering
or
loitering
,
but
always
walking
swiftly
;
and
looking
(
so
they
said
who
had
seen
him
)
over
his
shoulder
from
time
to
time
,
and
as
he
did
so
quickening
his
pace
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
fields
,
the
lanes
,
the
roads
,
in
all
quarters
of
the
town
---
east
,
west
,
north
,
and
south
---
that
man
was
seen
gliding
on
like
a
shadow
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
always
hurrying
away
.
 
<EOS>
Those
who
encountered
him
,
saw
him
steal
past
,
caught
sight
of
the
backward
glance
,
and
so
lost
him
in
the
darkness
.
  
<EOS>
This
constant
restlessness
,
and
flitting
to
and
fro
,
gave
rise
to
strange
stories
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
seen
in
such
distant
and
remote
places
,
at
times
so
nearly
tallying
with
each
other
,
that
some
doubted
whether
there
were
not
two
of
them
,
or
more
---
some
,
whether
he
had
not
unearthly
means
of
travelling
from
spot
to
spot
.
 
<EOS>
The
footpad
hiding
in
a
ditch
had
marked
him
passing
like
a
ghost
along
its
brink
;
the
vagrant
had
met
him
on
the
dark
high
-
road
;
the
beggar
had
seen
him
pause
upon
the
bridge
to
look
down
at
the
water
,
and
then
sweep
on
again
;
they
who
dealt
in
bodies
with
the
surgeons
could
swear
he
slept
in
churchyards
,
and
that
they
had
beheld
him
glide
away
among
the
tombs
on
their
approach
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
they
told
these
stories
to
each
other
,
one
who
had
looked
about
him
would
pull
his
neighbour
by
the
sleeve
,
and
there
he
would
be
among
them
.
  
<EOS>
At
last
,
one
man
---
he
was
one
of
those
whose
commerce
lay
among
the
graves
---
resolved
to
question
this
strange
companion
.
 
<EOS>
Next
night
,
when
he
had
eat
his
poor
meal
voraciously
(
he
was
accustomed
to
do
that
,
they
had
observed
,
as
though
he
had
no
other
in
the
day
)
,
this
fellow
sat
down
at
his
elbow
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
black
night
,
master
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
black
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Blacker
than
last
,
though
that
was
pitchy
too
.
 
<EOS>
Did
n't
I
pass
you
near
the
turnpike
in
the
Oxford
Road
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
like
you
may
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Come
,
come
,
master
,
"
cried
the
fellow
,
urged
on
by
the
looks
of
his
comrades
,
and
slapping
him
on
the
shoulder
;
"
be
more
companionable
and
communicative
.
 
<EOS>
Be
more
the
gentleman
in
this
good
company
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
tales
among
us
that
you
have
sold
yourself
to
the
devil
,
and
I
know
not
what
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
all
have
,
have
we
not
?
"
returned
the
stranger
,
looking
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
we
were
fewer
in
number
,
perhaps
he
would
give
better
wages
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
goes
rather
hard
with
you
,
indeed
,
"
said
the
fellow
,
as
the
stranger
disclosed
his
haggard
unwashed
face
,
and
torn
clothes
.
<EOS>
"
What
of
that
?
 
<EOS>
Be
merry
,
master
.
 
<EOS>
A
stave
of
a
roaring
song
now
"
---
   
<EOS>
"
Sing
you
,
if
you
desire
to
hear
one
,
"
replied
the
other
,
shaking
him
roughly
off
;
"
and
do
n't
touch
me
if
you
're
a
prudent
man
;
I
carry
arms
which
go
off
easily
---
they
have
done
so
,
before
now
---
and
make
it
dangerous
for
strangers
who
do
n't
know
the
trick
of
them
,
to
lay
hands
upon
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
threaten
?
"
said
the
fellow
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
returned
the
other
,
rising
and
turning
upon
him
,
and
looking
fiercely
round
as
if
in
apprehension
of
a
general
attack
.
  
<EOS>
His
voice
,
and
look
,
and
bearing
---
all
expressive
of
the
wildest
recklessness
and
desperation
---
daunted
while
they
repelled
the
bystanders
.
 
<EOS>
Although
in
a
very
different
sphere
of
action
now
,
they
were
not
without
much
of
the
effect
they
had
wrought
at
the
Maypole
Inn
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
what
you
all
are
,
and
live
as
you
all
do
,
"
said
the
man
sternly
,
after
a
short
silence
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
in
hiding
here
like
the
rest
,
and
if
we
were
surprised
<EOS>
would
perhaps
do
my
part
with
the
best
of
ye
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
's
my
humour
to
be
left
to
myself
,
let
me
have
it
.
 
<EOS>
Otherwise
,
"
---
and
here
he
swore
a
tremendous
oath
---
"
there
'll
be
mischief
done
in
this
place
,
though
there
ARE
odds
of
a
score
against
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
low
murmur
,
having
its
origin
perhaps
in
a
dread
of
the
man
and
the
mystery
that
surrounded
him
,
or
perhaps
in
a
sincere
opinion
on
the
part
of
some
of
those
present
,
that
it
would
be
an
inconvenient
precedent
to
meddle
too
curiously
with
a
gentleman
's
private
affairs
if
he
saw
reason
to
conceal
them
,
warned
the
fellow
who
had
occasioned
this
discussion
that
he
had
best
pursue
it
no
further
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
short
time
the
strange
man
lay
down
upon
a
bench
to
sleep
,
and
when
they
thought
of
him
again
,
they
found
he
was
gone
.
  
<EOS>
Next
night
,
as
soon
as
it
was
dark
,
he
was
abroad
again
and
traversing
the
streets
;
he
was
before
the
locksmith
's
house
more
than
once
,
but
the
family
were
out
,
and
it
was
close
shut
.
 
<EOS>
This
night
he
crossed
London
Bridge
and
passed
into
Southwark
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
glided
down
a
bye
street
,
a
woman
with
a
little
basket
on
her
arm
,
turned
into
it
at
the
other
end
.
 
<EOS>
Directly
he
observed
her
,
he
sought
the
shelter
of
an
archway
,
and
stood
aside
until
she
had
passed
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
emerged
cautiously
from
his
hiding
-
place
,
and
followed
.
  
<EOS>
She
went
into
several
shops
to
purchase
various
kinds
of
household
necessaries
,
and
round
every
place
at
which
she
stopped
he
hovered
like
her
evil
spirit
;
following
her
when
she
reappeared
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
nigh
eleven
o'clock
,
and
the
passengers
in
the
streets
were
thinning
fast
,
when
she
turned
,
doubtless
to
go
home
.
 
<EOS>
The
phantom
still
followed
her
.
  
<EOS>
She
turned
into
the
same
bye
street
in
which
he
had
seen
her
first
,
which
,
being
free
from
shops
,
and
narrow
,
was
extremely
dark
.
 
<EOS>
She
quickened
her
pace
here
,
as
though
distrustful
of
being
stopped
,
and
robbed
of
such
trifling
property
as
she
carried
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
He
crept
along
on
the
other
side
of
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
Had
she
been
gifted
with
the
speed
of
wind
<EOS>
,
it
seemed
as
if
his
terrible
shadow
would
have
tracked
her
down
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
the
widow
---
for
she
it
was
---
reached
her
own
door
,
and
,
panting
for
breath
,
paused
to
take
the
key
from
her
basket
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
flush
and
glow
,
with
the
haste
she
had
made
,
and
the
pleasure
of
being
safe
at
home
,
she
stooped
to
draw
it
out
,
when
,
raising
her
head
,
she
saw
him
standing
silently
beside
her
:
<EOS>
the
apparition
of
a
dream
.
  
<EOS>
His
hand
was
on
her
mouth
,
but
that
was
needless
,
for
her
tongue
clove
to
its
roof
,
and
her
power
of
utterance
was
gone
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
looking
for
you
many
nights
.
 
<EOS>
Is
the
house
empty
?
 
<EOS>
Answer
me
.
<EOS>
Is
any
one
inside
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
could
only
answer
by
a
rattle
in
her
throat
.
  
<EOS>
"
Make
me
a
sign
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
indicate
that
there
was
no
one
there
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
the
key
,
unlocked
the
door
,
carried
her
in
,
and
secured
it
carefully
behind
them
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
17
    
<EOS>
It
was
a
chilly
night
,
and
the
fire
in
the
widow
's
parlour
had
burnt
low
.
 
<EOS>
Her
strange
companion
placed
her
in
a
chair
,
and
stooping
down
before
the
half
-
extinguished
ashes
,
raked
them
together
and
fanned
them
with
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
From
time
to
time
he
glanced
at
her
over
his
shoulder
,
as
though
to
assure
himself
of
her
remaining
quiet
and
making
no
effort
to
depart
;
and
that
done
,
busied
himself
about
the
fire
again
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
without
reason
that
he
took
these
pains
,
for
his
dress
was
dank
and
drenched
with
wet
,
his
jaws
rattled
with
cold
,
and
he
shivered
from
head
to
foot
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
rained
hard
during
the
previous
night
and
for
some
hours
in
the
morning
,
but
since
noon
it
had
been
fine
.
 
<EOS>
Wheresoever
he
had
passed
the
hours
of
darkness
,
his
condition
sufficiently
betokened
that
many
of
them
had
been
spent
beneath
the
open
sky
.
 
<EOS>
Besmeared
with
mire
;
his
saturated
clothes
clinging
with
a
damp
embrace
about
his
limbs
;
his
beard
unshaven
,
his
face
unwashed
,
his
meagre
cheeks
worn
into
deep
hollows
,
---
a
more
miserable
wretch
could
hardly
be
,
than
this
man
who
now
cowered
down
upon
the
widow
's
hearth
,
and
watched
the
struggling
flame
with
bloodshot
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
covered
her
face
with
her
hands
,
fearing
,
as
it
seemed
,
to
look
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
So
they
remained
for
some
short
time
in
silence
.
<EOS>
Glancing
round
again
,
he
asked
at
length
:
  
"
Is
this
your
house
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
in
the
name
of
Heaven
,
do
you
darken
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Give
me
meat
and
drink
,
"
he
answered
sullenly
,
"
or
I
dare
do
more
than
that
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
marrow
in
my
bones
is
cold
,
with
wet
and
hunger
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
have
warmth
and
food
,
and
I
will
have
them
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
the
robber
on
the
Chigwell
road
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
nearly
a
murderer
then
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
will
was
not
wanting
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
one
came
upon
me
and
raised
the
hue
-
and
-
cry
'
,
that
it
would
have
gone
hard
with
,
but
for
his
nimbleness
.
 
<EOS>
I
made
a
thrust
at
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
thrust
your
sword
at
HIM
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
widow
,
looking
upwards
.
<EOS>
"
You
hear
this
man
!
<EOS>
you
hear
and
saw
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
at
her
,
as
,
with
her
head
thrown
back
,
and
her
hands
tight
clenched
together
,
she
uttered
these
words
in
an
agony
of
appeal
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
starting
to
his
feet
as
she
had
done
,
he
advanced
towards
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Beware
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
in
a
suppressed
voice
,
whose
firmness
stopped
him
midway
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
so
much
as
touch
me
with
a
finger
,
or
you
are
lost
;
body
and
soul
,
you
are
lost
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
"
he
replied
,
menacing
her
with
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
,
that
in
the
form
of
a
man
live
the
life
of
a
hunted
beast
<EOS>
;
that
in
the
body
am
a
spirit
,
a
ghost
upon
the
earth
,
a
thing
from
which
all
creatures
shrink
,
save
those
curst
beings
of
another
world
,
who
will
not
leave
me
;
---
I
am
,
in
my
desperation
of
this
night
,
past
all
fear
but
that
of
the
hell
in
which
I
exist
from
day
to
day
.
 
<EOS>
Give
the
alarm
,
cry
out
,
refuse
to
shelter
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
hurt
you
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
be
taken
alive
;
and
so
surely
as
you
threaten
me
above
your
breath
,
I
fall
a
dead
man
on
this
floor
.
 
<EOS>
The
blood
with
which
I
sprinkle
it
,
be
on
you
and
yours
,
in
the
name
of
the
Evil
Spirit
that
tempts
men
to
their
ruin
!
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
he
took
a
pistol
from
his
breast
,
and
firmly
clutched
it
in
his
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
Remove
this
man
from
me
,
good
Heaven
!
"
cried
the
widow
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
thy
grace
and
mercy
,
give
him
one
minute
's
penitence
,
and
strike
him
dead
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
has
no
such
purpose
,
"
he
said
,
confronting
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
deaf
.
<EOS>
Give
me
to
eat
and
drink
,
lest
I
do
that
it
can
not
help
my
doing
,
and
will
not
do
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
leave
me
,
if
I
do
thus
much
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
leave
me
and
return
no
more
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
promise
nothing
,
"
he
rejoined
,
seating
himself
at
the
table
,
"
nothing
but
this
<EOS>
---
I
will
execute
my
threat
if
you
betray
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
rose
at
length
,
and
going
to
a
closet
or
pantry
in
the
room
,
brought
out
some
fragments
of
cold
meat
and
bread
and
put
them
on
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
He
asked
for
brandy
,
and
for
water
.
 
<EOS>
These
she
produced
likewise
;
and
he
ate
and
drank
with
the
voracity
of
a
famished
hound
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
time
he
was
so
engaged
she
kept
at
the
uttermost
distance
of
the
chamber
,
and
sat
there
shuddering
,
<EOS>
but
with
her
face
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
She
never
turned
her
back
upon
him
once
;
and
although
when
she
passed
him
(
as
she
was
obliged
to
do
in
going
to
and
from
the
cupboard
)
<EOS>
she
gathered
the
skirts
of
her
garment
about
her
,
as
if
even
its
touching
his
by
chance
were
horrible
to
think
of
,
still
,
in
the
midst
of
all
this
dread
and
terror
,
she
kept
her
face
towards
his
own
,
and
watched
his
every
movement
.
  
<EOS>
His
repast
ended
---
if
that
can
be
called
one
,
which
was
a
mere
ravenous
satisfying
of
the
calls
of
hunger
---
he
moved
his
chair
towards
the
fire
again
,
and
warming
himself
before
the
blaze
which
had
now
sprung
brightly
up
,
accosted
her
once
more
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
an
outcast
,
to
whom
a
roof
above
his
head
is
often
an
uncommon
luxury
,
and
the
food
a
beggar
would
reject
is
delicate
fare
.
 
<EOS>
You
live
here
at
your
ease
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
live
alone
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
,
"
she
made
answer
with
an
effort
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
dwells
here
besides
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
One
---
it
is
no
matter
who
.
 
<EOS>
You
had
best
begone
,
or
he
may
find
you
here
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
you
linger
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
For
warmth
,
"
he
replied
,
spreading
out
his
hands
before
the
fire
.
"
<EOS>
For
warmth
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
rich
,
perhaps
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"
she
said
faintly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
rich
.
 
<EOS>
No
doubt
I
am
very
rich
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
least
you
are
not
penniless
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
some
money
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
making
purchases
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
little
left
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
but
a
few
shillings
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Give
me
your
purse
.
 
<EOS>
You
had
it
in
your
hand
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Give
it
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
stepped
to
the
table
and
laid
it
down
.
 
<EOS>
He
reached
across
,
took
it
up
,
and
told
the
contents
into
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
was
counting
them
,
she
listened
for
a
moment
,
and
sprung
towards
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Take
what
there
is
,
take
all
,
take
more
if
more
were
there
,
but
go
before
it
is
too
late
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
heard
a
wayward
step
without
,
I
know
full
well
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
return
directly
.
 
<EOS>
Begone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
stop
to
ask
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
answer
.
 
<EOS>
Much
as
I
dread
to
touch
you
,
I
would
drag
you
to
the
door
if
I
possessed
the
strength
,
rather
than
you
should
lose
an
instant
.
 
<EOS>
Miserable
wretch
!
<EOS>
fly
from
this
place
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
there
are
spies
without
,
I
am
safer
here
,
"
replied
the
man
,
standing
aghast
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
remain
here
,
and
will
not
fly
till
the
danger
is
past
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
too
late
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
widow
,
who
had
listened
for
the
step
,
and
not
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hark
to
that
foot
upon
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
tremble
to
hear
it
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
my
son
,
my
idiot
son
!
"
  
<EOS>
As
she
said
this
wildly
,
there
came
a
heavy
knocking
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
He
looked
at
her
,
and
she
at
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
him
come
in
,
"
said
the
man
,
hoarsely
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
fear
him
less
than
the
dark
,
houseless
night
.
 
<EOS>
He
knocks
again
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
come
in
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
dread
of
this
hour
,
"
returned
the
widow
,
"
has
been
upon
me
all
my
life
,
and
I
will
not
.
 
<EOS>
Evil
will
fall
upon
him
,
if
you
stand
eye
to
eye
.
 
<EOS>
My
blighted
boy
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
all
good
angels
who
know
the
truth
---
 
hear
a
poor
mother
's
prayer
,
and
spare
my
boy
from
knowledge
of
this
man
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
rattles
at
the
shutters
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
calls
you
.
 
<EOS>
That
voice
and
cry
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
he
who
grappled
with
me
in
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
Was
it
he
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
had
sunk
upon
her
knees
,
and
so
knelt
down
,
moving
her
lips
,
but
uttering
no
sound
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
gazed
upon
her
,
uncertain
what
to
do
or
where
to
turn
,
the
shutters
flew
open
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
barely
time
to
catch
a
knife
from
the
table
,
sheathe
it
in
the
loose
sleeve
of
his
coat
,
hide
in
the
closet
,
and
do
all
with
the
lightning
's
speed
,
when
Barnaby
tapped
at
the
bare
glass
,
and
raised
the
sash
exultingly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
who
can
keep
out
Grip
and
me
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
thrusting
in
his
head
,
and
staring
round
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
there
,
mother
?
 
<EOS>
How
long
you
keep
us
from
the
fire
and
light
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
stammered
some
excuse
and
tendered
him
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
But
Barnaby
sprung
lightly
in
without
assistance
,
and
putting
his
arms
about
her
neck
,
kissed
her
a
hundred
times
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
have
been
afield
,
mother
---
leaping
ditches
,
scrambling
through
hedges
,
running
down
steep
banks
,
up
and
away
,
and
hurrying
on
.
<EOS>
The
wind
has
been
blowing
,
and
the
rushes
and
young
plants
bowing
and
bending
to
it
,
lest
it
should
do
them
harm
,
the
cowards
---
and
Grip
---
ha
ha
ha
!
---
<EOS>
brave
Grip
,
who
cares
for
nothing
,
and
when
the
wind
rolls
him
over
in
the
dust
,
turns
manfully
to
bite
it
---
Grip
,
bold
Grip
,
has
quarrelled
with
every
little
bowing
twig
---
thinking
,
he
told
me
,
that
it
mocked
him
---
and
has
worried
it
like
a
bulldog
.
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
raven
,
in
his
little
basket
at
his
master
's
back
,
hearing
this
frequent
mention
of
his
name
in
a
tone
of
exultation
,
expressed
his
sympathy
by
crowing
like
a
cock
,
and
afterwards
running
over
his
various
phrases
of
speech
with
such
rapidity
,
and
in
so
many
varieties
of
hoarseness
,
that
they
sounded
like
the
murmurs
of
a
crowd
of
people
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
takes
such
care
of
me
besides
!
"
said
Barnaby
.
 
<EOS>
"
Such
care
,
mother
!
 
<EOS>
He
watches
all
the
time
I
sleep
,
and
when
I
shut
my
eyes
and
make
-
believe
to
slumber
,
he
practises
new
learning
softly
;
but
he
keeps
his
eye
on
me
the
while
,
and
if
he
sees
me
laugh
,
though
never
so
little
,
stops
directly
.
 
<EOS>
He
wo
n't
surprise
me
till
he
's
perfect
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
raven
crowed
again
in
a
rapturous
manner
which
plainly
said
,
"
Those
are
certainly
some
of
my
characteristics
,
and
I
glory
in
them
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
Barnaby
closed
the
window
and
secured
it
,
and
coming
to
the
fireplace
,
prepared
to
sit
down
with
his
face
to
the
closet
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
mother
prevented
this
,
by
hastily
taking
that
side
herself
,
and
motioning
him
towards
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
pale
you
are
to
-
night
!
"
said
Barnaby
,
leaning
on
his
stick
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
been
cruel
,
Grip
,
and
made
her
anxious
!
"
  
<EOS>
Anxious
in
good
truth
,
and
sick
at
heart
!
 
<EOS>
The
listener
held
the
door
of
his
hiding
-
place
open
with
his
hand
,
and
closely
watched
her
son
.
 
<EOS>
Grip
---
alive
to
everything
his
master
was
unconscious
of
---
 
had
his
head
out
of
the
basket
,
and
in
return
was
watching
him
intently
with
his
glistening
eye
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
flaps
his
wings
,
"
said
Barnaby
,
turning
almost
quickly
enough
to
catch
the
retreating
form
and
closing
door
,
"
as
if
there
were
strangers
here
,
but
Grip
is
wiser
than
to
fancy
that
.
 
<EOS>
Jump
then
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Accepting
this
invitation
with
a
dignity
peculiar
to
himself
,
the
bird
hopped
up
on
his
master
's
shoulder
,
from
that
to
his
extended
hand
,
and
so
to
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
unstrapping
the
basket
and
putting
it
down
in
a
corner
with
the
lid
open
,
Grip
's
first
care
was
to
shut
it
down
with
all
possible
despatch
,
and
then
to
stand
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
Believing
,
no
doubt
,
that
he
had
now
rendered
it
utterly
impossible
,
and
beyond
the
power
of
mortal
man
,
to
shut
him
up
in
it
any
more
,
he
drew
a
great
many
corks
in
triumph
,
and
uttered
a
corresponding
number
of
hurrahs
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
!
"
said
Barnaby
,
laying
aside
his
hat
and
stick
,
and
returning
to
the
chair
from
which
he
had
risen
,
"
I
'll
tell
you
where
we
have
been
to
-
day
,
and
what
we
have
been
doing
,
---
shall
I
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
took
his
hand
in
hers
,
and
holding
it
,
nodded
the
word
she
could
not
speak
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
n't
tell
,
"
said
Barnaby
,
holding
up
his
finger
,
"
for
it
's
a
secret
,
mind
,
and
only
known
to
me
,
and
Grip
,
and
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
the
dog
with
us
,
but
he
's
not
like
Grip
,
clever
as
he
is
,
and
does
n't
guess
it
yet
,
I
'll
wager
.
<EOS>
---
Why
do
you
look
behind
me
so
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
?
"
she
answered
faintly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
know
I
did
.
 
<EOS>
Come
nearer
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
frightened
!
"
said
Barnaby
,
changing
colour
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
---
you
do
n't
see
"
---
   
<EOS>
"
See
what
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
---
there
's
none
of
this
about
,
is
there
?
"
<EOS>
he
answered
in
a
whisper
,
drawing
closer
to
her
and
clasping
the
mark
upon
his
wrist
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
there
is
,
somewhere
.
 
<EOS>
You
make
my
hair
stand
on
end
,
and
my
flesh
creep
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
you
look
like
that
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
in
the
room
as
I
have
seen
it
in
my
dreams
,
dashing
the
ceiling
and
the
walls
with
red
?
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
fell
into
a
shivering
fit
as
he
put
the
question
,
and
shutting
out
the
light
with
his
hands
,
sat
shaking
in
every
limb
until
it
had
passed
away
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
time
,
he
raised
his
head
and
looked
about
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
gone
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
has
been
nothing
here
,
"
rejoined
his
mother
,
soothing
him
.
<EOS>
"
Nothing
indeed
,
dear
Barnaby
.
 
<EOS>
Look
!
 
<EOS>
You
see
there
are
<EOS>
but
you
and
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
gazed
at
her
vacantly
,
and
,
becoming
reassured
by
degrees
,
burst
into
a
wild
laugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
let
us
see
,
"
he
said
,
thoughtfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Were
we
talking
?
 
<EOS>
Was
it
you
and
me
?
 
<EOS>
Where
have
we
been
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Nowhere
but
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
but
Hugh
,
and
I
,
"
said
Barnaby
,
---
"
that
's
it
.
 
<EOS>
Maypole
Hugh
,
and
I
,
you
know
,
and
Grip
---
we
have
been
lying
in
the
forest
,
and
among
the
trees
by
the
road
side
,
with
a
dark
lantern
after
night
came
on
,
and
the
dog
in
a
noose
ready
to
slip
him
when
the
man
came
by
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
man
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
robber
;
him
that
the
stars
winked
at
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
waited
for
him
after
dark
these
many
nights
,
and
we
shall
have
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
know
him
in
a
thousand
.
 
<EOS>
Mother
,
see
here
!
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
Look
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
twisted
his
handkerchief
round
his
head
,
pulled
his
hat
upon
his
brow
,
wrapped
his
coat
about
him
,
and
stood
up
before
her
:
<EOS>
so
like
the
original
he
counterfeited
,
that
the
dark
figure
peering
out
behind
him
might
have
passed
for
his
own
shadow
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
We
shall
have
him
,
"
he
cried
,
ridding
himself
of
the
semblance
as
hastily
as
he
had
assumed
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
see
him
,
mother
,
bound
hand
and
foot
,
and
brought
to
London
at
a
saddle
-
girth
;
and
you
shall
hear
of
him
at
Tyburn
Tree
if
we
have
luck
.
<EOS>
So
Hugh
says
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
pale
again
,
and
trembling
.
 
<EOS>
And
why
DO
you
look
behind
me
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
nothing
,
"
she
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
quite
well
.
 
<EOS>
Go
you
to
bed
,
dear
,
and
leave
me
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
bed
!
"
<EOS>
he
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
like
to
lie
before
the
fire
,
watching
the
prospects
in
the
burning
coals
---
the
rivers
,
hills
,
and
dells
,
in
the
deep
,
red
sunset
,
and
the
wild
faces
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
hungry
too
,
and
Grip
has
eaten
nothing
since
broad
noon
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
to
supper
.
 
<EOS>
Grip
!
 
<EOS>
To
supper
,
lad
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
raven
flapped
his
wings
,
and
,
croaking
his
satisfaction
,
hopped
to
the
feet
of
his
master
,
and
there
held
his
bill
open
,
ready
for
snapping
up
such
lumps
of
meat
as
he
should
throw
him
.
 
<EOS>
Of
these
he
received
about
a
score
in
rapid
succession
,
without
the
smallest
discomposure
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
,
"
said
Barnaby
.
  
<EOS>
"
More
!
"
cried
Grip
.
 
<EOS>
"
More
!
"
  
<EOS>
But
it
appearing
for
a
certainty
that
no
more
was
to
be
had
,
he
retreated
with
his
store
;
and
disgorging
the
morsels
one
by
one
from
his
pouch
,
hid
them
in
various
corners
---
taking
particular
care
,
however
,
to
avoid
the
closet
,
as
being
doubtful
of
the
hidden
man
's
propensities
and
power
of
resisting
temptation
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
concluded
these
arrangements
,
he
took
a
turn
or
two
across
the
room
with
an
elaborate
assumption
of
having
nothing
on
his
mind
(
<EOS>
but
with
one
eye
hard
upon
his
treasure
all
the
time
)
,
and
then
,
and
not
till
then
,
began
to
drag
it
out
,
piece
by
piece
,
and
eat
it
with
the
utmost
relish
.
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
,
for
his
part
,
having
pressed
his
mother
to
eat
in
vain
,
made
a
hearty
supper
too
.
 
<EOS>
Once
during
the
progress
of
his
meal
,
he
wanted
more
bread
from
the
closet
and
rose
to
get
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
hurriedly
interposed
to
prevent
him
,
and
summoning
her
utmost
fortitude
,
passed
into
the
recess
,
and
brought
it
out
herself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
"
said
Barnaby
,
looking
at
her
steadfastly
as
she
sat
down
beside
him
after
doing
so
;
"
is
to
-
day
my
birthday
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
-
day
!
"
<EOS>
she
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
recollect
it
was
<EOS>
but
a
week
or
so
ago
,
and
that
summer
,
autumn
,
and
winter
have
to
pass
before
it
comes
again
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
remember
that
it
has
been
so
till
now
,
"
said
Barnaby
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
think
to
-
day
must
be
my
birthday
too
,
for
all
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
asked
him
why
?
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
why
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
always
seen
you
---
<EOS>
I
did
n't
let
you
know
it
,
but
I
have
---
on
the
evening
of
that
day
grow
very
sad
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
you
cry
when
Grip
and
I
were
most
glad
;
and
look
frightened
with
no
reason
;
and
I
have
touched
your
hand
,
and
felt
that
it
was
cold
---
as
it
is
now
.
 
<EOS>
Once
,
mother
(
on
a
birthday
that
was
,
also
)
,
Grip
and
I
thought
of
this
after
we
went
upstairs
to
bed
,
and
when
it
was
midnight
,
striking
one
o'clock
,
we
came
down
to
your
door
to
see
if
you
were
well
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
on
your
knees
.
 
<EOS>
I
forget
what
it
was
you
said
.
 
<EOS>
Grip
,
what
was
it
<EOS>
we
heard
her
say
that
night
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
devil
!
"
rejoined
the
raven
promptly
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Barnaby
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
said
something
in
a
prayer
;
and
when
you
rose
and
walked
about
,
you
looked
(
as
you
have
done
ever
since
,
mother
,
towards
night
on
my
birthday
)
just
as
you
do
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
found
that
out
,
you
see
,
though
I
am
silly
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
say
you
're
wrong
;
and
this
must
be
my
birthday
---
my
birthday
,
Grip
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
bird
received
this
information
with
a
crow
of
such
duration
as
a
cock
,
gifted
with
intelligence
beyond
all
others
of
his
kind
,
might
usher
in
the
longest
day
with
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
as
if
he
had
well
considered
the
sentiment
,
and
regarded
it
as
apposite
to
birthdays
,
he
cried
,
"
Never
say
die
!
"
<EOS>
a
great
many
times
,
and
flapped
his
wings
for
emphasis
.
  
<EOS>
The
widow
tried
to
make
light
of
Barnaby
's
remark
,
and
endeavoured
to
divert
his
attention
to
some
new
subject
;
too
easy
a
task
at
all
times
,
as
she
knew
.
 
<EOS>
His
supper
done
,
Barnaby
,
regardless
of
her
entreaties
,
stretched
himself
on
the
mat
before
the
fire
;
Grip
perched
upon
his
leg
,
and
divided
his
time
between
dozing
in
the
grateful
warmth
,
and
endeavouring
(
as
it
presently
appeared
)
to
recall
a
new
accomplishment
he
had
been
studying
all
day
.
  
<EOS>
A
long
and
profound
silence
ensued
,
broken
only
by
some
change
of
position
on
the
part
of
Barnaby
,
whose
eyes
were
still
wide
open
and
intently
fixed
upon
the
fire
;
or
by
an
effort
of
recollection
on
the
part
of
Grip
,
who
would
cry
in
a
low
voice
from
time
to
time
,
"
Polly
put
the
ket
---
"
and
there
stop
short
,
forgetting
the
remainder
,
and
go
off
in
a
doze
again
.
  
<EOS>
After
a
long
interval
,
Barnaby
's
breathing
grew
more
deep
and
regular
,
and
his
eyes
were
closed
.
 
<EOS>
But
even
then
the
unquiet
spirit
of
the
raven
interposed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Polly
put
the
ket
---
"
cried
Grip
,
and
his
master
was
broad
awake
again
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
Barnaby
slept
soundly
,
and
the
bird
with
his
bill
sunk
upon
his
breast
,
his
breast
itself
puffed
out
into
a
comfortable
alderman
-
like
form
,
and
his
bright
eye
growing
smaller
and
smaller
,
really
seemed
to
be
subsiding
into
a
state
of
repose
.
 
<EOS>
Now
<EOS>
and
then
he
muttered
in
a
sepulchral
voice
,
"
<EOS>
Polly
put
the
ket
---
"
but
very
drowsily
,
and
more
like
a
drunken
man
than
a
reflecting
raven
.
  
<EOS>
The
widow
,
scarcely
venturing
to
breathe
,
rose
from
her
seat
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
glided
from
the
closet
,
and
extinguished
the
candle
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
tle
on
,
"
cried
Grip
,
suddenly
struck
with
an
idea
and
very
much
excited
.
 
<EOS>
"
---
tle
on
.
 
<EOS>
Hurrah
!
 
<EOS>
Polly
put
the
ket
-
tle
on
,
we
'll
all
have
tea
;
Polly
put
the
ket
-
tle
on
,
we
'll
all
have
tea
.
 
<EOS>
Hurrah
,
hurrah
,
hurrah
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
a
devil
<EOS>
,
I
'm
a
devil
,
I
'm
a
ket
-
tle
on
,
Keep
up
your
spirits
,
Never
say
die
,
Bow
,
wow
,
<EOS>
wow
,
I
'm
a
devil
,
I
'm
a
ket
-
tle
<EOS>
,
I
'm
a
---
<EOS>
Polly
put
the
ket
-
tle
on
,
we
'll
all
have
tea
.
"
  
<EOS>
They
stood
rooted
to
the
ground
,
as
though
it
had
been
a
voice
from
the
grave
.
  
<EOS>
But
even
this
failed
to
awaken
the
sleeper
.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
over
towards
the
fire
,
his
arm
fell
to
the
ground
,
and
his
head
drooped
heavily
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
widow
and
her
unwelcome
visitor
gazed
at
him
and
at
each
other
for
a
moment
,
and
then
she
motioned
him
towards
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
"
he
whispered
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
teach
your
son
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
taught
him
nothing
that
you
heard
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
Depart
instantly
,
or
I
will
rouse
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
free
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
rouse
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
dare
not
do
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
dare
do
anything
,
I
have
told
you
.
 
<EOS>
He
knows
me
well
,
it
seems
.
<EOS>
At
least
I
will
know
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Would
you
kill
him
in
his
sleep
?
"
cried
the
widow
,
throwing
herself
between
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
Woman
,
"
he
returned
between
his
teeth
,
as
he
motioned
her
aside
,
"
I
would
see
him
nearer
,
and
I
will
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
want
one
of
us
to
kill
the
other
,
wake
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
he
advanced
,
and
bending
down
over
the
prostrate
form
,
softly
turned
back
the
head
and
looked
into
the
face
.
 
<EOS>
The
light
of
the
fire
was
upon
it
,
and
its
every
lineament
was
revealed
distinctly
.
 
<EOS>
He
contemplated
it
for
a
brief
space
,
and
hastily
uprose
.
  
<EOS>
"
Observe
,
"
he
whispered
in
the
widow
's
ear
:
"
<EOS>
In
him
,
of
whose
existence
I
was
ignorant
until
to
-
night
,
I
have
you
in
my
power
.
<EOS>
Be
careful
how
you
use
me
.
 
<EOS>
Be
careful
how
you
use
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
destitute
and
starving
,
and
a
wanderer
upon
the
earth
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
take
a
sure
and
slow
revenge
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
some
dreadful
meaning
in
your
words
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
fathom
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
meaning
in
them
,
and
I
see
you
fathom
it
to
its
very
depth
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
anticipated
it
for
years
;
you
have
told
me
as
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
leave
you
to
digest
it
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
forget
my
warning
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
pointed
,
as
he
left
her
,
to
the
slumbering
form
,
and
stealthily
withdrawing
,
made
his
way
into
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
She
fell
on
her
knees
beside
the
sleeper
,
and
remained
like
one
stricken
into
stone
,
until
the
tears
which
fear
had
frozen
so
long
,
came
tenderly
to
her
relief
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
Thou
,
"
she
cried
,
"
who
hast
taught
me
such
deep
love
for
this
one
remnant
of
the
promise
of
a
happy
life
,
out
of
whose
affliction
,
even
,
perhaps
the
comfort
springs
that
he
is
ever
a
relying
,
loving
child
to
me
---
never
growing
old
or
cold
at
heart
,
but
needing
my
care
and
duty
in
his
manly
strength
as
in
his
cradle
-
time
---
help
him
,
in
his
darkened
walk
through
this
sad
world
,
or
he
is
doomed
,
and
my
poor
heart
is
broken
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
18
    
Gliding
along
the
silent
streets
,
and
holding
his
course
where
they
were
darkest
and
most
gloomy
,
the
man
who
had
left
the
widow
's
house
crossed
London
Bridge
,
and
arriving
in
the
City
,
plunged
into
the
backways
,
lanes
,
and
courts
,
between
Cornhill
and
Smithfield
;
with
no
more
fixedness
of
purpose
than
to
lose
himself
among
their
windings
,
and
baffle
pursuit
,
if
any
one
were
dogging
his
steps
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
dead
time
of
the
night
,
and
all
was
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
Now
<EOS>
and
then
a
drowsy
watchman
's
footsteps
sounded
on
the
pavement
,
or
the
lamplighter
on
his
rounds
went
flashing
past
,
leaving
behind
a
little
track
of
smoke
mingled
with
glowing
morsels
of
his
hot
red
link
.
 
<EOS>
He
hid
himself
even
from
these
partakers
of
his
lonely
walk
,
and
,
shrinking
in
some
arch
or
doorway
while
they
passed
,
issued
forth
again
when
they
were
gone
and
so
pursued
his
solitary
way
.
  
<EOS>
To
be
shelterless
and
alone
in
the
open
country
,
hearing
the
wind
moan
and
watching
for
day
through
the
whole
long
weary
night
;
to
listen
to
the
falling
rain
,
and
crouch
for
warmth
beneath
the
lee
of
some
old
barn
or
rick
,
or
in
the
hollow
of
a
tree
;
are
dismal
things
---
but
not
so
dismal
as
the
wandering
up
and
down
where
shelter
is
,
and
beds
and
sleepers
are
by
thousands
;
a
houseless
rejected
creature
.
 
<EOS>
To
pace
the
echoing
stones
from
hour
to
hour
,
counting
the
dull
chimes
of
the
clocks
;
to
watch
the
lights
twinkling
in
chamber
windows
,
to
think
what
happy
forgetfulness
each
house
shuts
in
;
that
here
are
children
coiled
together
in
their
beds
,
here
youth
,
here
age
,
here
poverty
,
here
wealth
,
all
equal
in
their
sleep
,
and
all
at
rest
;
to
have
nothing
in
common
with
the
slumbering
world
around
,
not
even
sleep
,
Heaven
's
gift
to
all
its
creatures
,
and
be
akin
to
nothing
but
despair
;
to
feel
,
by
the
wretched
contrast
with
everything
on
every
hand
,
more
utterly
alone
and
cast
away
than
in
a
trackless
desert
;
this
is
a
kind
of
suffering
,
on
which
the
rivers
of
great
cities
close
full
many
a
time
,
and
which
the
solitude
in
crowds
alone
awakens
.
  
<EOS>
The
miserable
man
paced
up
and
down
the
streets
---
so
long
,
so
wearisome
,
<EOS>
so
like
each
other
---
and
often
cast
a
wistful
look
towards
the
east
,
hoping
to
see
the
first
faint
streaks
of
day
.
<EOS>
But
obdurate
night
had
yet
possession
of
the
sky
,
and
his
disturbed
and
restless
walk
found
no
relief
.
  
<EOS>
One
house
in
a
back
street
was
bright
with
the
cheerful
glare
of
lights
;
there
was
the
sound
of
music
in
it
too
,
and
the
tread
of
dancers
,
and
there
were
cheerful
voices
,
and
many
a
burst
of
laughter
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
place
---
to
be
near
something
that
was
awake
and
glad
---
he
returned
again
and
again
;
and
more
than
one
of
those
who
left
it
when
the
merriment
was
at
its
height
,
felt
it
a
check
upon
their
mirthful
mood
to
see
him
flitting
to
and
fro
like
an
uneasy
ghost
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
the
guests
departed
,
one
and
all
;
and
then
the
house
was
close
shut
up
,
and
became
as
dull
and
silent
as
the
rest
.
  
<EOS>
His
wanderings
brought
him
at
one
time
to
the
city
jail
.
 
<EOS>
Instead
of
hastening
from
it
as
a
place
of
ill
omen
,
and
one
he
had
cause
to
shun
,
he
sat
down
on
some
steps
hard
by
,
and
resting
his
chin
upon
his
hand
,
gazed
upon
its
rough
and
frowning
walls
as
though
even
they
became
a
refuge
in
his
jaded
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
He
paced
it
round
and
round
,
came
back
to
the
same
spot
,
and
sat
down
again
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
this
often
,
and
once
,
with
a
hasty
movement
,
crossed
to
where
some
men
were
watching
in
the
prison
lodge
,
and
had
his
foot
upon
the
steps
as
though
determined
to
accost
them
.
 
<EOS>
But
looking
round
,
he
saw
that
the
day
began
to
break
,
and
failing
in
his
purpose
,
turned
and
fled
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
soon
in
the
quarter
he
had
lately
traversed
,
and
pacing
to
and
fro
again
as
he
had
done
before
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
passing
down
a
mean
street
,
when
from
an
alley
close
at
hand
some
shouts
of
revelry
arose
,
and
there
came
straggling
forth
a
dozen
madcaps
,
whooping
and
calling
to
each
other
,
who
,
parting
noisily
,
took
different
ways
and
dispersed
in
smaller
groups
.
  
<EOS>
Hoping
that
some
low
place
of
entertainment
which
would
afford
him
a
safe
refuge
might
be
near
at
hand
,
he
turned
into
this
court
when
they
were
all
gone
,
and
looked
about
for
a
half
-
opened
door
,
or
lighted
window
,
or
other
indication
of
<EOS>
the
place
whence
they
had
come
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
so
profoundly
dark
,
however
,
and
so
ill
-
favoured
,
that
he
concluded
they
had
but
turned
up
there
,
missing
their
way
,
and
were
pouring
out
again
when
he
observed
them
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
impression
,
and
finding
there
was
no
outlet
but
that
by
which
he
had
entered
,
he
was
about
to
turn
,
when
from
a
grating
near
his
feet
a
sudden
stream
of
light
appeared
,
and
the
sound
of
talking
came
.
 
<EOS>
He
retreated
into
a
doorway
to
see
who
these
talkers
were
,
and
to
listen
to
them
.
  
<EOS>
The
light
came
to
the
level
of
the
pavement
as
he
did
this
,
and
a
man
ascended
,
bearing
in
his
hand
a
torch
.
 
<EOS>
This
figure
unlocked
and
held
open
the
grating
as
for
the
passage
of
another
,
who
presently
appeared
,
in
the
form
of
a
young
man
of
small
stature
and
uncommon
self
-
importance
,
dressed
in
an
obsolete
and
very
gaudy
fashion
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
noble
captain
,
"
said
he
with
the
torch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Farewell
,
commander
.
 
<EOS>
Good
luck
,
illustrious
general
!
"
  
<EOS>
In
return
to
these
compliments
the
other
bade
him
hold
his
tongue
,
and
keep
his
noise
to
himself
,
and
laid
upon
him
many
similar
injunctions
,
with
great
fluency
of
speech
and
sternness
of
manner
.
  
<EOS>
"
Commend
me
,
captain
,
to
the
stricken
Miggs
,
"
returned
the
torch
-
bearer
in
a
lower
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
captain
flies
at
higher
game
than
Miggses
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
My
captain
is
an
eagle
,
both
as
respects
his
eye
and
soaring
wings
.
 
<EOS>
My
captain
breaketh
hearts
as
other
bachelors
break
eggs
at
breakfast
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
fool
you
are
,
Stagg
!
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
stepping
on
the
pavement
of
the
court
,
and
brushing
from
his
legs
the
dust
he
had
contracted
in
his
passage
upward
.
  
<EOS>
"
His
precious
limbs
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Stagg
,
clasping
one
of
his
ankles
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shall
a
Miggs
aspire
to
these
proportions
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
my
captain
.
<EOS>
We
will
inveigle
ladies
fair
,
and
we
d
them
in
our
secret
cavern
.
<EOS>
We
will
unite
ourselves
with
blooming
beauties
,
captain
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
,
my
buck
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
releasing
his
leg
;
"
I
'll
trouble
you
not
to
take
liberties
,
and
not
to
broach
certain
questions
unless
certain
questions
are
broached
to
you
.
<EOS>
Speak
when
you
're
spoke
to
on
particular
subjects
,
and
not
otherways
.
 
<EOS>
Hold
the
torch
up
till
I
've
got
to
the
end
of
the
court
,
and
then
kennel
yourself
,
do
you
hear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hear
you
,
noble
captain
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Obey
then
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
haughtily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
lead
on
!
"
<EOS>
With
which
word
of
command
(
addressed
to
an
imaginary
staff
or
retinue
)
<EOS>
he
folded
his
arms
,
and
walked
with
surpassing
dignity
down
the
court
.
  
<EOS>
His
obsequious
follower
stood
holding
the
torch
above
his
head
,
and
then
the
observer
saw
for
the
first
time
,
from
his
place
of
concealment
,
that
he
was
blind
.
 
<EOS>
Some
involuntary
motion
on
his
part
caught
the
quick
ear
of
the
blind
man
,
before
he
was
conscious
of
having
moved
an
inch
towards
him
,
for
he
turned
suddenly
and
cried
,
<EOS>
"
Who
's
there
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
man
,
"
said
the
other
,
advancing
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
stranger
!
<EOS>
"
rejoined
the
blind
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Strangers
are
not
my
friends
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
do
there
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
saw
your
company
come
out
,
and
waited
here
till
they
were
gone
.
<EOS>
I
want
a
lodging
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
lodging
at
this
time
!
"
returned
Stagg
,
pointing
towards
the
dawn
as
though
he
saw
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
the
day
is
breaking
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
,
"
rejoined
the
other
,
"
to
my
cost
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
traversing
this
iron
-
hearted
town
all
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
traverse
it
again
,
"
said
the
blind
man
,
preparing
to
descend
,
"
till
you
find
some
lodgings
suitable
to
your
taste
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
let
any
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
other
,
holding
him
by
the
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
beat
this
light
about
that
hangdog
face
of
yours
(
for
hangdog
it
is
,
if
it
answers
to
your
voice
)
,
and
rouse
the
neighbourhood
besides
,
if
you
detain
me
,
"
said
the
blind
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
YOU
hear
!
"
returned
the
other
,
chinking
a
few
shillings
together
,
and
hurriedly
pressing
them
into
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
beg
nothing
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
pay
for
the
shelter
you
give
me
.
 
<EOS>
Death
!
<EOS>
Is
it
much
to
ask
of
such
as
you
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
come
from
the
country
,
and
desire
to
rest
where
there
are
none
to
question
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
faint
,
exhausted
,
worn
out
,
almost
dead
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
lie
down
,
like
a
dog
,
before
your
fire
.
 
<EOS>
I
ask
no
more
than
that
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
would
be
rid
of
me
,
I
will
depart
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
a
gentleman
has
been
unfortunate
on
the
road
,
"
muttered
Stagg
,
yielding
to
the
other
,
who
,
pressing
on
him
,
had
already
gained
a
footing
on
the
steps
---
"
and
can
pay
for
his
accommodation
---
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
pay
you
with
all
I
have
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
just
now
past
the
want
of
food
,
God
knows
,
and
wish
but
to
purchase
shelter
.
 
<EOS>
What
companion
have
you
below
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
None
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
fasten
your
grate
there
,
and
show
me
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
Quick
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
blind
man
complied
after
a
moment
's
hesitation
,
and
they
descended
together
.
 
<EOS>
The
dialogue
had
passed
as
hurriedly
as
the
words
could
be
spoken
,
and
they
stood
in
his
wretched
room
before
he
had
had
time
to
recover
from
his
first
surprise
.
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
see
where
that
door
leads
to
,
and
what
is
beyond
?
"
said
the
man
,
glancing
keenly
round
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
mind
that
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
show
you
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Follow
me
,
or
go
before
.
 
<EOS>
Take
your
choice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
bade
him
lead
the
way
,
and
,
by
the
light
of
the
torch
which
his
conductor
held
up
for
the
purpose
,
inspected
all
three
cellars
narrowly
.
 
<EOS>
Assured
that
the
blind
man
had
spoken
truth
,
and
that
he
lived
there
alone
,
the
visitor
returned
with
him
to
the
first
,
in
which
a
fire
was
burning
,
and
flung
himself
with
a
deep
groan
upon
the
ground
before
it
.
  
<EOS>
His
host
pursued
his
usual
occupation
without
seeming
to
heed
him
any
further
.
 
<EOS>
But
directly
he
fell
asleep
---
and
he
noted
his
falling
into
a
slumber
,
as
readily
as
the
keenest
-
sighted
man
could
have
done
<EOS>
---
he
knelt
down
beside
him
,
and
passed
his
hand
lightly
but
carefully
over
his
face
and
person
.
  
<EOS>
His
sleep
was
checkered
with
starts
and
moans
,
and
sometimes
with
a
muttered
word
or
two
.
 
<EOS>
His
hands
were
clenched
,
his
brow
bent
,
and
his
mouth
firmly
set
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
,
the
blind
man
accurately
marked
;
and
as
if
his
curiosity
were
strongly
awakened
,
and
he
had
already
some
inkling
of
his
mystery
,
he
sat
watching
him
,
if
the
expression
may
be
used
,
and
listening
,
until
it
was
broad
day
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
19
    
Dolly
Varden
's
pretty
little
head
was
yet
bewildered
by
various
recollections
of
the
party
,
and
her
bright
eyes
were
yet
dazzled
by
a
crowd
of
images
,
dancing
before
them
like
motes
in
the
sunbeams
,
among
which
the
effigy
of
one
partner
in
particular
did
especially
figure
,
the
same
being
a
young
coachmaker
(
a
master
in
his
own
right
)
who
had
given
her
to
understand
,
when
he
handed
her
into
the
chair
at
parting
,
that
it
was
his
fixed
resolve
to
neglect
his
business
from
that
time
,
and
die
slowly
for
the
love
of
her
---
 
<EOS>
Dolly
's
head
,
and
eyes
,
and
thoughts
,
and
seven
senses
,
were
all
in
a
state
of
flutter
and
confusion
for
which
the
party
was
accountable
,
although
it
was
now
three
days
old
,
when
,
as
she
was
sitting
listlessly
at
breakfast
,
reading
all
manner
of
fortunes
(
that
is
to
say
,
of
married
and
flourishing
fortunes
)
<EOS>
in
the
grounds
of
her
teacup
,
a
step
was
heard
in
the
workshop
,
and
Mr
Edward
Chester
was
descried
through
the
glass
door
,
standing
among
the
rusty
locks
and
keys
,
like
love
among
the
roses
---
for
which
apt
comparison
the
historian
may
by
no
means
take
any
credit
to
himself
,
the
same
being
the
invention
,
in
a
sentimental
mood
,
of
the
chaste
and
modest
Miggs
,
who
,
beholding
him
from
the
doorsteps
<EOS>
she
was
then
cleaning
,
did
,
in
her
maiden
meditation
,
give
utterance
to
the
simile
.
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
,
who
happened
at
the
moment
to
have
his
eyes
thrown
upward
and
his
head
backward
,
in
an
intense
communing
with
Toby
,
did
not
see
his
visitor
,
until
Mrs
Varden
,
more
watchful
than
the
rest
,
had
desired
Sim
Tappertit
to
open
the
glass
door
and
give
him
admission
---
from
which
untoward
circumstance
the
good
lady
argued
(
for
she
could
deduce
a
precious
moral
from
the
most
trifling
event
)
<EOS>
that
to
take
a
draught
of
small
ale
in
the
morning
was
to
observe
a
pernicious
,
irreligious
,
and
Pagan
custom
,
the
relish
whereof
should
be
left
to
swine
,
and
Satan
,
or
at
least
to
Popish
persons
,
and
should
be
shunned
by
the
righteous
as
a
work
of
sin
and
evil
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
no
doubt
have
pursued
her
admonition
much
further
,
and
would
have
founded
on
it
a
long
list
of
precious
precepts
of
inestimable
value
,
but
that
the
young
gentleman
standing
by
in
a
somewhat
uncomfortable
and
discomfited
manner
while
she
read
her
spouse
<EOS>
this
lecture
,
occasioned
her
to
bring
it
to
a
premature
conclusion
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
you
'll
excuse
me
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Varden
,
rising
and

.
 
<EOS>
"
Varden
is
so
very
thoughtless
,
and
needs
so
much

---
<EOS>
Sim
,
bring
a

here
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
obeyed
,
with
a
flourish
implying
that
he
did
so
,
under
protest
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
can
go
,
Sim
,
"
said
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
obeyed
again
,
still
under
protest
;
and
betaking
himself
to
the
workshop
,
began
seriously
to
fear
that
he
might
find
it
necessary
to
poison
his
master
,
before
his
time
was
out
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
Edward
returned
suitable
replies
to
Mrs
Varden
's
courtesies
,
and
that
lady
brightened
up
very
much
;
so
that
when
he
accepted
a
dish
of
tea
from
the
fair
hands
of
Dolly
,
she
was
perfectly
agreeable
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
if
there
's
anything
we
can
do
,
---
Varden
,
or
I
,
or
Dolly

,
---
to
serve

,

,
at
any

,
you
have
only
to
say

,
and
it
shall

done
,
"
said
Mrs
V.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
much
obliged
to
you
,
I
am
sure
,
"
returned
Edward
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
encourage
me
to
say
that
I
have
come
here
now
,
to
beg
your
good
offices
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
was
delighted
beyond
measure
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
occurred
to
me
that
probably
your
fair
daughter
might
be
going
to
the
Warren
,
either
to
-
day
or
to
-
morrow
,
"
said
Edward
,

at

;
"
and
if

,
and
you

to
take

of
this

,
ma'am
,
you
will

me

I

.
 
<EOS>
The
truth
is
,
that
while
I
am
very
anxious
it
should
reach
its
destination
,
I
have
particular

to
any
other
conveyance
;
so
that
without
your
help
,
I
am
wholly

a
loss
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
was
not
going
that
way
,
sir
,
either
to
-
day
,
or
to
-
morrow
,
nor
indeed
<EOS>
all
next
week
,
"
the
lady

,
"
but
we
shall
be
very

to
put
ourselves
out

the
way
on
your

,
and
if
you
wish

,
you
may
depend
upon
its
going
to
-

.
 
<EOS>
You
might
suppose
,
"
said
Mrs
Varden
,
frowning
at

,
"
from
Varden
's
sitting
there
<EOS>
so
glum
and
silent
<EOS>
,
that
he
objected
to
this

;
but
you
must
not

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
his
way
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
Out
of
doors
,
he
can
be
cheerful
and
talkative
enough
.
"
  
<EOS>
Now
,
the
fact
was
,
that
the
unfortunate
locksmith
,
blessing
his
stars
to
find
his
helpmate
in
such

,
had
been
sitting
with
a
beaming
face
,
hearing
this
discourse
with
a
joy
past
all
expression
.
 
<EOS>
Wherefore
<EOS>
this
sudden
attack
quite
took
him
by
surprise
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Martha
---
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
I
dare
say
,
"
interrupted
Mrs
Varden
,
with
a

of

and

.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
dear
!
 
<EOS>
We
all
know
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
but
my
good
soul
,
"
said
Gabriel
,
"
you
are
quite
mistaken
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
delighted
to
find
you
so
kind

.
 
<EOS>
I
waited
,
<EOS>
my
dear
,
anxiously
,
I

you
,
to
hear
what
you
would

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

Mrs
V.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
Varden
.
<EOS>
You
waited
,
as
you
always
do
,
that
I
might
bear
the
blame
,
if
any
came
of

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
used
to
it
,
"
said
the
lady
with
a

,
"
and
that
's
my
comfort
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
give
you
my
word
,
Martha
---
"
said
Gabriel
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
give
you
MY
word
,
my
dear
,
"
interposed
his
wife
with
a
Christian
smile
,
"
that
such
discussions
as
these
between
married
people
,
are
much
better

alone
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,
if
you
please
,
Varden
,
we
'll
drop

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no

to
pursue
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
.
 
<EOS>
I
might
say
a
great
deal
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
would
rather
not
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
n't
say
any
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
to
say
any
more
,
"
rejoined
the
goaded
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
then
,
do

,
"
said
Mrs
Varden
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
did
I
begin

,
Martha
,
"
added
the
locksmith
,
good

,
"
I
must

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
did
not

,
Varden
!
"
exclaimed
his
wife
,
opening

very

and
looking

upon
the
company
,
as
though
she
would
say
,
You
hear
this

!
 
<EOS>
"
You
did
not

,
Varden
!
 
<EOS>
But
you
shall

I

.
 
<EOS>
No
,
you
did
not
begin
it
,
<EOS>
oh
dear
<EOS>
no
,
not
you
,
my

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
settled
then
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Oh

,
"

"
quite
.
 
<EOS>
If

say
Dolly
began

,

,

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
need

it
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
that

"

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
As

,

---

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

as

;

;

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
and

post
-

-

-
six
at
Dolly
,
out

and

,
and
the
constant
Miggs
,
and
<EOS>
the

was
gone
for

.
 
<EOS>
For
now

chaise
creaked
upon
its

,
and
Mrs
Varden
was
inside
;
and
now
it
creaked
again
,
and
more
than

,
and
the
locksmith
was
inside
;
and
now

bounded
once
,
as
if
its
heart
beat
lightly
,
and
Dolly
was
inside
;
and
now

was
gone
and
its

was

,
and

that
dreary
Miggs
were

.
  
<EOS>
The

was
in

as

to

,

all

,

Mrs

was
agreeable
beyond

.
 
<EOS>
As

through
the
streets
talking
of
this
thing
and
of
that
,
who
should
be
descried
upon
the

but
<EOS>
that
very
coachmaker
,
looking
so
genteel
that
nobody
would
have
believed
he
had
ever
had
anything
to
do
with

but
riding

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
To
be
sure
Dolly
was
confused
when
she

again
,
and
to

sure
the
cherry
-

ribbons
trembled
a
little
when
she
met

eye
,
which
seemed

,
"
I

,
I

,

is
going
to
the
devil
,
and
you
're
the
cause

it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
There

,
rooted

the

:
as

.
  
<EOS>
But

,

less

the

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
In

"

"
<EOS>
speedily

the

<EOS>

<EOS>
Joe

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

(

)
<EOS>

<EOS>
Old

,

.
 
<EOS>
All

,

the

's
was
the
very
snuggest
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Such

;

about

;

;

,
and

,

,

,

;

,

,

<EOS>
It

never

<EOS>
---

<EOS>
Mrs

.
 
<EOS>
She

<EOS>
The

too
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>
"
A

"
 
<EOS>
Something

!
 
<EOS>
The

!
 
<EOS>
To

.

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Waking

pain
,
in

.
  
<EOS>
Dolly

,

<EOS>
Chapter
20
    
<EOS>
The

her

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
So

's

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
the

.
 
<EOS>
The

the
rest

the
matter

that
,
but
the

youth

would

cheerful
(
saving

!
<EOS>
that

)
,

.
 
<EOS>
Birds

.
 
<EOS>
There

heart
in

room
;
and
who
that
has
a
heart
,
ever
fails
to
recognise
the
silent

of
another
!
  
<EOS>
Dolly
had
one
undoubtedly
,
and
it
was
not
a

,
though

little

,
such

sometimes

life
in

,

.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not

Edward
?
"
  
Dolly

,

(

)

,

,
at

.
 
<EOS>
As

and

,
Dolly
's
eyes
,
by
one
of
those

for

there

no

,
wandered
to
the
glass
again
.
 
<EOS>
She
could
not
help
wondering
whether
the
coach
-
maker
suffered
very
much
,
and
quite
pitied
the
poor
man
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
long
letter
---
a
very

,
written
close
on
all
four
sides
of
the
sheet
of

,
and
crossed

;
but

was
not

,
for
as
Emma
read
it
<EOS>
she
stopped
from
time
to
time
to
put
her
handkerchief
to
her
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
To

sure
Dolly
marvelled
greatly
to
see

in
so
much

,
for
to
her
thinking
a
love

ought
to
be
one
of
the
best

,
and
the
slyest
,

kind

.
 
<EOS>
But
she
set

down
in
her

came
from
Miss
Haredale
's
being
so

,

---
 
just

,
to
keep
her

---
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
that
's
what
I

do
if

was
me
,
"
thought
Dolly
.
<EOS>
"
To

well

and

,
but
to
be

's

!
"
  
<EOS>
However

would

do

,
and
therefore

sat
looking
on

.
 
<EOS>
She
needed
a
pretty
considerable
stretch
of
patience
,
for
when
the
long
letter
had
been
read
once
all
through
it
was
read
again
,
and
when
it
had
been
read
twice
all
through
it
was
read
again
.
 
<EOS>
During
this
tedious
process
,
Dolly
beguiled
the
time
in
the
most
improving
manner
that
occurred
to
her
,
by
curling
her

on

,
with
the
aid
of
the
looking
-
glass
before
mentioned
,
and
giving
it
some

.
  
<EOS>
Everything
has
an
end
.
 
<EOS>
Even
young
ladies
in
love
can
not
read
their
letters
for
ever
.
 
<EOS>
In
course
of
time
the
packet
was
folded
up
,
and
it
only
remained
to
write
the
answer
.
  
<EOS>
But
as
this
promised
to
be
a
work
of
time
likewise
,
Emma
said
she
would

it

until
after

,
and
that
Dolly
must
dine
with

.
 
<EOS>
As
Dolly
had
made
up
her
mind
to
do
so
beforehand
,
she
required
very
little
pressing
;
and
when
they
had
settled
this
point
,
they
went
to
walk
in
the
garden
.
  
<EOS>
They
strolled
up
and
down
the
terrace
walks
,
talking
incessantly
---
 
<EOS>
at
least
,
Dolly
never
left
off
once
---
and
making
that
quarter
of
the
sad
and
mournful
house
quite
gay
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
they
talked
loudly
or
laughed
much
,
but
they
were
both
so
very
handsome
,
and
it
was
such
a
breezy
day
,
and
their
light

and
dark
curls
appeared
so
free
and
joyous
in
their
abandonment
,
and
Emma
was
so
fair
,
and
Dolly
so
rosy
,
and
Emma
so
delicately
shaped
,
and
Dolly
so
plump
,
and
<EOS>
---
in
short
,
there
are
no
flowers
for
any
garden
like
such
flowers
,
<EOS>
let
horticulturists
say
what
they
may
,
and
both
house
and
garden
seemed
to
know
it
,
and
to
brighten
up

.
  
<EOS>
After
this
,
came
the
dinner
and
the
letter

,
and
some
more

,
in
the

which
Miss
Haredale
took
occasion
to
charge
upon

certain
flirtish
and

,
which

Dolly
seemed
to
think
very

indeed
,
and
to
be
mightily

with
.
 
<EOS>
Finding
her
quite
incorrigible

this

,
Emma
suffered
her

depart
;
but
not

confided
to
her
that
important
and
never
-
sufficiently
-
to

-

-
care
-
of
answer
,

moreover

.
 
<EOS>
Having

,

Joe
at
heart
(

!
<EOS>
and
so
forth
)
,
she

;
and

to

more

for
Edward
,
than

with

Dolly
Varden

,

.
  
<EOS>
Dolly

her

,
and
tripping
lightly
down
the
stairs
<EOS>
arrived
at
the
dreaded

,

,

,

!
<EOS>
there

Mr

.
<EOS>
Now
,

had
from
her

the

something

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

,
"

,

---
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
You

Emma
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
---

's

,

---
"
  
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Bring

,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
Dolly

"
  
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

have
but

.
 
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
Dolly

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.

<EOS>

---
<EOS>

<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
You

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

,
"

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

"

,

but

;
"
I
ca

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
.
 
<EOS>
There

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
None

,
"

<EOS>
"

Miss
Emma
of

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
That

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
Do

.
"
  
<EOS>
Dolly

,
nor

,
for
the
words
<EOS>
had

than

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
first

to
be
done
,
of

,
when

;
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

once

to

,
and

so

that
she

,

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

,
she
put
her

-
dress

,

,

at
the
Warren

,
which
were
just

,
and
resumed

.
  
<EOS>
The

had
come
on
,
and
it
was
quickly

,
but
the
path
was
so
familiar
to
her
from
frequent

that
she
hardly
thought
of
this
,
and
certainly

no

.
 
<EOS>
Moreover
,
there
was
the
bracelet
to

;
and
when
she
had
given

a

,

held

,

on

,
that

,
was

.
 
<EOS>
There

,

,

,

,
that

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Between

and

,

enough
to

;
and

Dolly

.
  
<EOS>
As

through

wicket

where
the
path
was
narrow
,
and
lay
between
two

here

there

,
she

a

close
at

,
which
brought

to
a

.
<EOS>
She
listened
.
 
<EOS>
All
was
very
quiet
,
and
she
went
on
again
---
not
absolutely

,
but
a
little

than
before
perhaps
,
and
possibly

her

,
for
a
check
of
that
kind
<EOS>
is
startling
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
no
sooner
moved
on
again
,
than
she
was
conscious
of
the
same
sound
,
which
was
like
that
of
a
person

among

and

.
 
<EOS>
Looking

whence

appeared

come
,

could
make

.
 
<EOS>
She
stopped
again
.
 
<EOS>
All
was
quiet
as
before
.
 
<EOS>
On
she
went
once
more
---
decidedly
faster
now
---
and
tried
to
sing
softly
to
herself
.
 
<EOS>
It
must
he
<EOS>
the
wind
.
  
<EOS>
But
how
came
the
wind
to
blow
only
when
she
walked
,
and
cease
when
she
stood
still
?
 
<EOS>
She
stopped
involuntarily
as
she
made

,
and
the

stopped
likewise
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
really

now
,
and
was
yet
hesitating
what
to
do
,
when
the
bushes
crackled
and
snapped
,
and
a

came

,
close

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
21
    
<EOS>
It
was
for
the
moment
an
inexpressible
relief
to
Dolly
,
to
recognise
in
the
person
who
forced

into
the
path
so

,
and
now
stood
directly
in
her
way
,
Hugh
of
the
Maypole
,
whose
name
she
uttered
in
a
tone
of
delighted
surprise
that
came
from
her
heart
.
  
<EOS>
"
Was
it
you
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
"
how
glad
I
am
to
see
you
!
<EOS>
and
how
could
you
terrify
me
so
!
"
  
<EOS>
In
answer
to
which
,
he
said
nothing
at
all
,
but
stood
quite
still
,
looking
at
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
come
to
meet
me
?
"
asked
Dolly
.
  
<EOS>
Hugh
nodded
,
and
muttered
something
to
the
effect
that
he
had
been
waiting
for
her
,
and
had
expected
her
sooner
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
it
likely
they
would
send
,
"
said
Dolly
,
greatly
reassured
by
this
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nobody
sent
me
,
"
was
his
sullen
answer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
came
of
my
own
accord
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
rough
bearing
of
this
fellow
,
and
his
wild
,
uncouth
appearance
,
had
often
filled
the
girl
with
a
vague
apprehension
even
when
other
people
were
by
,
and
had
occasioned
her
to
shrink
from
him
involuntarily
.
 
<EOS>
The
having
him
for
an
unbidden
companion
in
so
solitary
a
place
,
with
the
darkness
fast
gathering
about
them
,
renewed
and
even
increased
the
alarm
she
had
felt
at
first
.
  
<EOS>
If
his
manner
had
been
merely
dogged
and
passively
fierce
,
as
usual
,
she
would
have
had
no
greater
dislike
to
his
company
than
she
always
felt
---
<EOS>
perhaps
,
indeed
,
would
have
been
rather
glad
to
have
had
him
at
hand
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
something
of
coarse
bold
admiration
in
his
look
,
which
terrified
her
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
She
glanced
timidly
towards
him
,
uncertain
whether
to
go
forward
or
retreat
,
and
he
stood
gazing
at
her
like
a
handsome
satyr
;
and
so
they
remained
for
some
short
time
without
stirring
or
breaking
silence
.
<EOS>
At
length
Dolly
took
courage
,
shot
past
him
,
and
hurried
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
spend
so
much
breath
in
avoiding
me
?
"
said
Hugh
,
accommodating
his
pace
to
hers
,
and
keeping
close
at
her
side
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
to
get
back
as
quickly
as
I
can
,
and
you
walk
too
near
me
,
answered
Dolly
.
"
  
"
Too
near
!
"
<EOS>
said
Hugh
,
stooping
over
her
so
that
she
could
feel
his
breath
upon
her
forehead
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
too
near
?
 
<EOS>
You
're
always
proud
to
ME
,
mistress
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
proud
to
no
one
.
 
<EOS>
You
mistake
me
,
"
answered
Dolly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fall
back
,
if
you
please
,
or
go
on
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
mistress
,
"
he
rejoined
,
endeavouring
to
draw
her
arm
through
his
,
"
I
'll
walk
with
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
released
herself
and
clenching
her
little
hand
,
struck
him
with
right
good
will
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
,
Maypole
Hugh
burst
into
a
roar
of
laughter
,
and
passing
his
arm
about
her
waist
,
held
her
in
his
strong
grasp
as
easily
as
if
she
had
been
a
bird
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Well
done
,
mistress
!
 
<EOS>
Strike
again
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
beat
my
face
,
and
tear
my
hair
,
and
pluck
my
beard
up
by
the
roots
,
and
welcome
,
for
the
sake
of
your
bright
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
Strike
again
,
mistress
.
<EOS>
Do
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
I
like
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
,
"
she
cried
,
endeavouring
with
both
her
hands
to
push
him
off
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
this
moment
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
had
as
good
be
kinder
to
me
,
Sweetlips
,
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
,
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
Come
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
now
.
 
<EOS>
Why
are
you
always
so
proud
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
quarrel
with
you
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
love
you
when
you
're
proud
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
hide
your
beauty
from
a
poor
fellow
;
that
's
a
comfort
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
gave
him
no
answer
,
but
as
he
had
not
yet
checked
her
progress
,
continued
to
press
forward
as
rapidly
as
she
could
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
between
the
hurry
she
had
made
,
her
terror
,
and
the
tightness
of
his
embrace
,
her
strength
failed
her
,
and
she
could
go
no
further
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hugh
,
"
cried
the
panting
girl
,
"
good
Hugh
;
if
you
will
leave
me
I
will
give
you
anything
---
everything
I
have
---
and
never
tell
one
word
of
this
to
any
living
creature
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
had
best
not
,
"
he
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Harkye
,
little
dove
,
you
had
best
not
.
 
<EOS>
All
about
here
know
me
,
and
what
I
dare
do
if
I
have
a
mind
.
 
<EOS>
If
ever
you
are
going
to
tell
,
stop
when
the
words
are
on
your
lips
,
and
think
of
the
mischief
you
'll
bring
,
if
you
do
,
upon
some
innocent
heads
that
you
would
n't
wish
to
hurt
a
hair
of
.
<EOS>
Bring
trouble
on
me
,
and
I
'll
bring
trouble
and
something
more
on
them
in
return
.
 
<EOS>
I
care
no
more
for
them
than
for
so
many
dogs
;
not
so
much
---
why
should
I
?
 
<EOS>
I
'd
sooner
kill
a
man
than
a
dog
any
day
.
<EOS>
I
've
never
been
sorry
for
a
man
's
death
in
all
my
life
,
and
I
have
for
a
dog
's
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
something
so
thoroughly
savage
in
the
manner
of
these
expressions
,
and
the
looks
and
gestures
by
which
they
were
accompanied
,
that
her
great
fear
of
him
gave
her
new
strength
,
and
enabled
her
by
a
sudden
effort
to
extricate
herself
and
run
fleetly
from
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
Hugh
was
as
nimble
,
strong
,
and
swift
of
foot
,
as
any
man
in
broad
England
,
and
it
was
but
a
fruitless
expenditure
of
energy
,
for
he
had
her
in
his
encircling
arms
again
before
she
had
gone
a
hundred
yards
.
  
<EOS>
"
Softly
,
darling
---
gently
---
would
you
fly
from
rough
Hugh
<EOS>
,
that
loves
you
as
well
as
any
drawing
-
room
gallant
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
,
"
she
answered
,
struggling
to
free
herself
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
.
 
<EOS>
Help
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
fine
for
crying
out
,
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
A
fine
,
pretty
one
,
from
your
lips
.
 
<EOS>
I
pay
myself
!
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
"
  
"
Help
!
help
!
<EOS>
help
!
"
 
<EOS>
As
she
shrieked
with
the
utmost
violence
she
could
exert
,
a
shout
was
heard
in
answer
,
and
another
,
and
another
.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
Heaven
!
"
cried
the
girl
in
an
ecstasy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Joe
,
dear
Joe
,
this
way
.
 
<EOS>
Help
!
"
  
<EOS>
Her
assailant
paused
,
and
stood
irresolute
for
a
moment
,
but
the
shouts
drawing
nearer
and
coming
quick
upon
them
,
forced
him
to
a
speedy
decision
.
 
<EOS>
He
released
her
,
whispered
with
a
menacing
look
,
"
Tell
HIM
:
and
see
what
follows
!
"
and
leaping
the
hedge
,
was
gone
in
an
instant
.
 
<EOS>
Dolly
darted
off
,
and
fairly
ran
into
Joe
Willet
's
open
arms
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
<EOS>
are
you
hurt
?
<EOS>
what
was
it
?
<EOS>
who
was
it
?
<EOS>
where
is
he
?
<EOS>
what
was
he
like
?
"
<EOS>
with
a
great
many
encouraging
expressions
and
assurances
of
safety
,
were
the
first
words
Joe
poured
forth
.
<EOS>
But
poor
little
Dolly
was
so
breathless
and
terrified
that
for
some
time
she
was
quite
unable
to
answer
him
,
and
hung
upon
his
shoulder
,
sobbing
and
crying
as
if
her
heart
would
break
.
  
<EOS>
Joe
had
not
the
smallest
objection
to
have
her
hanging
on
his
shoulder
;
<EOS>
no
,
not
the
least
,
though
it
crushed
the
cherry
-
coloured
ribbons
sadly
,
and
put
the
smart
little
hat
out
of
all
shape
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
could
n't
bear
to
see
her
cry
;
it
went
to
his
very
heart
.
 
<EOS>
He
tried
to
console
her
,
bent
over
her
,
whispered
to
her
---
some
say
kissed
her
,
but
that
's
a
fable
.
 
<EOS>
At
any
rate
he
said
all
the
kind
and
tender
things
he
could
think
of
and
Dolly
let
him
go
on
and
did
n't
interrupt
him
once
,
and
it
was
a
good
ten
minutes
before
she
was
able
to
raise
her
head
and
thank
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
was
it
that
frightened
you
?
"
said
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
A
man
whose
person
was
unknown
to
her
had
followed
her
,
she
answered
;
he
began
by
begging
,
and
went
on
to
threats
of
robbery
,
which
he
was
on
the
point
of
carrying
into
execution
,
and
would
have
executed
,
but
for
Joe
's
timely
aid
.
 
<EOS>
The
hesitation
and
confusion
with
which
she
said
this
,
Joe
attributed
to
the
fright
she
had
sustained
,
and
no
suspicion
of
the
truth
occurred
to
him
for
a
moment
.
  
<EOS>
"
Stop
when
the
words
are
on
your
lips
.
"
 
<EOS>
A
hundred
times
that
night
,
and
very
often
afterwards
,
when
the
disclosure
was
rising
to
her
tongue
,
Dolly
thought
of
that
,
and
repressed
it
.
 
<EOS>
A
deeply
rooted
dread
of
the
man
<EOS>
;
the
conviction
that
his
ferocious
nature
,
once
roused
,
would
stop
at
nothing
;
and
the
strong
assurance
that
if
she
impeached
him
,
the
full

of
his

and
vengeance
would
be
wreaked
on
Joe
,
who
had
preserved
her
;
these
were
considerations
she
had
not
the
courage
to
overcome
,
and
inducements
to
secrecy
too
powerful
for
her
to
surmount
.
  
<EOS>
Joe
,
for
his
part
,
was
a
great
deal
too
happy
to
inquire
very
curiously
into
the
matter
;
and
Dolly
being
yet
too
tremulous
to
walk
without
assistance
,
they
went
forward
very
slowly
,
and
in
his
mind
very
pleasantly
,
until
the
Maypole
lights
were
near
at
hand
,
twinkling
their
cheerful
welcome
,
when
Dolly
stopped
suddenly
and
with
a
half

exclaimed
,
  
"
The
letter
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
letter
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
I
was
carrying
---
I
had
it
in
my
hand
.
 
<EOS>
My
bracelet
too
<EOS>
,
"
she
said
,
clasping
her
wrist
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
lost
them
both
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
just
now
?
"
said
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
Either
I
dropped
them
then
,
or
they
were
taken
from
me
,
"
answered
Dolly
,
vainly
searching
her
pocket
and
rustling
her
dress
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
gone
,
both
gone
.
 
<EOS>
What
an
unhappy
girl
I
am
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
these
words
poor
Dolly
,
who
to
do
her
justice
was
quite
as
sorry
for
the
loss
of
the
letter
as
for
her
bracelet
,
fell
a
-
crying
again
,
and
bemoaned
her
fate
most
movingly
.
  
<EOS>
Joe
tried
to
comfort
her
with
the
assurance
that
directly
he
had
housed
her
in
the
Maypole
,
he
would
return
to
the
spot
with
a
lantern
(
for
it
was
now
quite
dark
)
and
make
strict
search
for
the
missing
articles
,
which
there
was
great
probability
of
his
finding
,
as
it
was
not
likely
that
anybody
had
passed
that
way
since
,
and
she
was
not
conscious
that
they
had
been
forcibly
taken
from
her
.
<EOS>
Dolly
thanked
him
very
heartily
for
this
offer
,
though
with
no
great
hope
of
his
quest
being
successful
;
and
so
with
many

on
her

,
and
many

on
his
,
and
much

on
the

and
much

on
the
part

Joe
,
they
reached
the
Maypole
bar
at
last
,
where
the
locksmith
and
his
wife
and
old
John
were
yet
keeping
high
festival
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
received
the
intelligence
of
Dolly
's
trouble
with
that
surprising
presence
of
mind
and
readiness
of
speech
for
which
he
was
so
eminently
distinguished
above
all
other
men
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
expressed
her
sympathy
for
her
daughter
's
distress
by
scolding
her
roundly
for
being
so
late
;
and
the
honest
locksmith
divided
himself
between
condoling
with
and
kissing
Dolly
,
and
shaking
hands
heartily
with
Joe
,
whom
he
could
not
sufficiently
praise
or
thank
.
  
<EOS>
In
reference
to
this
latter
point
,
old
John
was
far
from
agreeing
with
his
friend
;
for
besides
that
he
by
no
means
approved
of
an
adventurous
spirit
in
the
abstract
,
it
occurred
to
him
that
if
his
son
and
heir
had
been
seriously
damaged
in
a
scuffle
,
the
consequences
would
assuredly
have
been
expensive
and
inconvenient
,
and
might
perhaps
have
proved
detrimental
to
the
Maypole
business
.
<EOS>
Wherefore
,
and
because
he
looked
with
no
favourable
eye
upon
young
girls
,
but
rather
considered
that
they
and
the
whole
female
sex
were
a
kind
of
nonsensical
mistake
on
the
part
of
Nature
,
he
took
occasion
to
retire
and
shake
his
head
in
private
at
the
boiler
;
inspired
by
which
silent
oracle
,
he
was
moved
to
give
Joe
various
stealthy
nudges
with
his
elbow
,
as
a
parental
reproof
and
gentle
admonition
to
mind
his
own
business
and
not
make
a
fool
of
himself
.
  
<EOS>
Joe
,
however
,
took
down
the
lantern
and
lighted
it
;
and
arming
himself
with
a
stout
stick
,
asked
whether
Hugh
was
in
the
stable
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
lying
asleep
before
the
kitchen
fire
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Willet
.
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
him
for
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
want
him
to
come
with
me
to
look
after
this
bracelet
and
letter
,
"
answered
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
"
Halloa
there
!
 
<EOS>
Hugh
!
"
  
<EOS>
Dolly
turned
pale
as
death
,
and
felt
as
if
she
must
faint
forthwith
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
few
moments
,
Hugh
came
staggering
in
,
stretching
himself
and
yawning
according
to
custom
,
and
presenting
every
appearance
of
having
been
roused
from
a
sound
nap
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
,
sleepy
-
head
,
"
said
Joe
,
giving
him
the
lantern
.
 
<EOS>
"
Carry
this
,
and
bring
the
dog
,
and
that
small
cudgel
of
yours
.
 
<EOS>
And
woe
betide
the
fellow
if
we
come
upon
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
fellow
?
<EOS>
"
growled
Hugh
,
rubbing
his
eyes
and
shaking
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
fellow
?
<EOS>
"
returned
Joe
,
who
was
in
a
state
of
great
valour
and
bustle
;
"
a
fellow
you
ought
to
know
of
and
be
more
alive
about
.
<EOS>
It
's
well
for
the
like
of
you
,
lazy
giant
that
you
are
,
to
be
snoring
your
time
away
in
chimney
-
corners
,
when
honest
men
's
daughters
ca
n't
cross
even
our
quiet
meadows
at
nightfall
without
being
set
upon
by
footpads
,
and
frightened
out
of
their
precious
lives
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
They
never
rob
me
,
"
cried
Hugh
with
a
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
got
nothing
to
lose
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
'd
as
lief
knock
them
at
head
as
any
other
men
.
 
<EOS>
How
many
are
there
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Only
one
,
"
said
Dolly
faintly
,
for
everybody
looked
at
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
was
he
like
,
mistress
?
"
said
Hugh
with
a
glance
at
young
Willet
,
so
slight
and
momentary
that
the
scowl
it
conveyed
was
lost
on
all
but
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
About
my
height
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
---
not
so
tall
,
"
Dolly
replied
,
scarce
knowing
what
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
His
dress
,
"
said
Hugh
,
looking
at
her
keenly
,
"
like
---
like
any
of
ours
now
?
 
<EOS>
I
know
all
the
people
hereabouts
,
and
maybe
could
give
a
guess
at
the
man
,
if
I
had
anything
to
guide
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Dolly
faltered
and
turned
paler
yet
;
then
answered
that
he
was
wrapped
in
a
loose
coat
and
had
his

hidden
by
a
handkerchief
and
that
she
could
give
no
other

of

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
would
n't
know
him
if
you
saw
him
then
,
belike
?
"
said
Hugh
with
a
malicious
grin
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
,
"
answered
Dolly
,
bursting
into
tears
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
wish
to
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
bear
to
think
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
talk
about
him
any
more
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
go
to
look
for
these
things
,
Mr
Joe
,
pray
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
I
entreat
you
not
to
go
with
that
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
to
go
with

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.

,

<EOS>
Mrs

<EOS>

---

<EOS>

<EOS>

Chapter

<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
complied
.
 
<EOS>
The
locksmith
followed
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
and
Mr
Tappertit
trundled
off
with

to
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
Martha
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the

,
when

,
"

look
to
Dolly
yourself

,
perhaps

will

only

.
 
<EOS>
She
has
been
frightened
,
you
know
,
and
is
not

well
to
-
night
.
"
  
<EOS>
In

,
Dolly
had
thrown
herself
upon
the
sofa
,
quite
regardless
of
all
the
little
finery
of
which
she
had
been
so
proud
in
the

,
and
with
her

in

was

.
  
<EOS>
At
first
sight
of
this

(
for

by

,
rather

<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
expressed
her

that
never

she
;
that
her

was

;
that

,

;

,

did

herself
<EOS>
so
she

.
 
<EOS>
To

.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Dolly
,

,
grew
none

,
but

,

;

ill
,

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
But

,

shaped

into

,
and

in

,

rendered
clear
to

,
that
Mrs

.
<EOS>
Thus

,
and

into
that

that

,

represented

,

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
Mrs

,

;
