(

.
 
<EOS>
She

to

in

,
that

(
Mrs
V
)

not
,
in

(

<EOS>
Miss

also
put
in

word
to

.
 
<EOS>
She
said
that
indeed
and

Miss
Dolly
might
take
pattern
by

mother
,
who
,

always

,

,

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
After

.
 
<EOS>
When

;

that

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Of

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
Oh

!
"

"

!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

.

"

<EOS>
"

.

,

;
to

.

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
His

numbered
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
Miggs

at

,
but
less

of

than

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

;
where
the
locksmith
,

by

and

,
had

,
and
was

to

.
 
<EOS>
But
Mrs
Varden
,
whose

(
as
is
not

)
was
usually
of
the

,
cut

by

on

,

.
 
<EOS>
To
bed
<EOS>
therefore
she

,
with

that
of
the
Maypole
's
own
state

;
and
to
bed
the
rest

the
establishment
soon

repaired
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
23
    
<EOS>
Twilight
had
given
place
to
night
some
hours
,
and
it
was
high
noon
in
those
quarters
of
the
town
in
which
"
the
world
"
condescended
to
dwell
---
the
world
being
then
,
as
now
,
of
very
limited
dimensions
and
easily
lodged
---
when
Mr
Chester
reclined
upon
a
sofa
in
his
dressing
-
room
in
the
Temple
,
entertaining
himself
with
a
book
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
dressing
,
as
it
seemed
,
by
easy
stages
,
and
having
performed
half
the
journey
was
taking
a
long
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Completely
attired
as
to
his
legs
and
feet
in
the
trimmest
fashion
of
the
day
,
he
had
yet
the
remainder
of
his
toilet
to
perform
.
 
<EOS>
The
coat
was
stretched
,
like
a
refined
scarecrow
,
on
its
separate
horse
;
the
waistcoat
was
displayed
to
the
best
advantage
;
the
various
ornamental
articles
of
dress
were
severally
set
out
in
most
alluring
order
;
and
yet
he
lay
dangling
his
legs
between
the
sofa
and
the
ground
,
as
intent
upon
his
book
as
if
there
were
nothing
but
bed
before
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
honour
,
"
he
said
,
at
length
raising
his
eyes
to
the
ceiling
with
the
air
of
a
man
who
was
reflecting
seriously
on
what
he
had
read
;
"
upon
my
honour
,
the
most
masterly
composition
,
the
most
delicate
thoughts
,
the
finest
code
of
morality
,
and
the
most
gentlemanly
sentiments
in
the
universe
!
 
<EOS>
Ah
Ned
,
Ned
,
if
you
would
but
form
your
mind
by
such
precepts
,
we
should
have
but
one
common
feeling
on
every
subject
that
could
possibly
arise
between
us
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
apostrophe
was
addressed
,
like
the
rest
of
his
remarks
,
to
empty
air
:
for
Edward
was
not
present
,
and
the
father
was
quite
alone
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
Lord
Chesterfield
,
"
he
said
,
pressing
his
hand
tenderly
upon
the
book
as
he
laid
it
down
,
"
if
I
could
but
have
profited
by
your
genius
soon
enough
to
have
formed
my
son
on
the
model
you
have
left
to
all
wise
fathers
,
both
he
and
I
would
have
been
rich
men
.
<EOS>
Shakespeare
was
undoubtedly
very
fine
in
his
way
;
Milton
good
,
though
prosy
;
Lord
Bacon
deep
,
and
decidedly
knowing
;
but
the
writer
who
should
be
his
country
's
pride
,
is
my
Lord
Chesterfield
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
became
thoughtful
again
,
and
the
toothpick
was
in
requisition
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
I
was
tolerably
accomplished
as
a
man
of
the
world
,
"
he
continued
,
"
I
flattered
myself
that
I
was
pretty
well
versed
in
all
those
little
arts
and
graces
which
distinguish
men
of
the
world
from
boors
and
peasants
,
and
separate
their
character
from
those
intensely
vulgar
sentiments
which
are
called
the
national
character
.
 
<EOS>
Apart
from
any
natural
prepossession
in
my
own
favour
,
I
believed
I
was
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
in
every
page
of
this
enlightened
writer
,
I
find
some
captivating
hypocrisy
which
has
never
occurred
to
me
before
,
or
some
superlative
piece
of
selfishness
to
which
I
was
utterly
a
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
quite
blush
for
myself
before
this
stupendous
creature
,
if
remembering
his
precepts
,
one
might
blush
at
anything
.
 
<EOS>
An
amazing
man
!
<EOS>
a
nobleman
indeed
!
<EOS>
any
King
or
Queen
may
make
a
Lord
,
but
only
the
Devil
himself
---
and
the
Graces
---
can
make
a
Chesterfield
.
"
  
<EOS>
Men
who
are
thoroughly
false
and
hollow
,
seldom
try
to
hide
those
vices
from
themselves
;
and
yet
in
the
very
act
of
avowing
them
,
they
lay
claim
to
the
virtues
they
feign
most
to
despise
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
,
"
say
they
,
"
this
is
honesty
,
this
is
truth
.
 
<EOS>
All
mankind
are
like
us
,
but
they
have
not
the
candour
to
avow
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
more
they
affect
to
deny
the
existence
of
any
sincerity
in
the
world
,
the
more
they
would
be
thought
to
possess
it
in
its
boldest
shape
;
and
this
is
an
unconscious
compliment
to
Truth
on
the
part
of
these
philosophers
,
which
will
turn
the
laugh
against
them
to
the
Day
of
Judgment
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Chester
,
having
extolled
his
favourite
author
,
as
above
recited
,
took
up
the
book
again
in
the
excess
of
his
admiration
and
was
composing
himself
for
a
further
perusal
of
its
sublime
morality
,
when
he
was
disturbed
by
a
noise
at
the
outer
door
;
occasioned
as
it
seemed
by
the
endeavours
of
his
servant
to
obstruct
the
entrance
of
some
unwelcome
visitor
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
late
hour
for
an
importunate
creditor
,
"
he
said
,
raising
his
eyebrows
with
as
indolent
an
expression
of
wonder
as
if
the
noise
were
in
the
street
,
and
one
with
which
he
had
not
the
smallest
possible
concern
.
 
<EOS>
"
Much
after
their
accustomed
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
usual
pretence
I
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
No
doubt
a
heavy
payment
to
make
up
tomorrow
.
<EOS>
Poor
fellow
,
he
loses
time
,
and
time
is
money
as
the
good
proverb
says
---
I
never
found
it
out
though
.
 
<EOS>
Well
.
 
<EOS>
What
now
?
 
<EOS>
You
know
I
am
not
at
home
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
man
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
servant
,
who
was
to
the
full
as
cool
and
negligent
in
his
way
as
his
master
,
"
has
brought
home
the
riding
-
whip
you
lost
the
other
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
you
were
out
,
but
he
said
he
was
to
wait
while
I
brought
it
in
,
and
would
n't
go
till
I
did
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
was
quite
right
,
"
returned
his
master
,
"
and
you
're
a
blockhead
,
possessing
no
judgment
or
discretion
whatever
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
him
to
come
in
,
and
see
that
he
rubs
his
shoes
for
exactly
five
minutes
first
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
man
laid
the
whip
on
a
chair
,
and
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
The
master
,
who
had
only
heard
his
foot
upon
the
ground
and
had
not
taken
the
trouble
to
turn
round
and
look
at
him
,
shut
his
book
,
and
pursued
the
train
of
ideas
his
entrance
had
disturbed
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
time
were
money
,
"
he
said
,
handling
his
snuff
-
box
,
"
I
would
compound
with
my
creditors
,
and
give
them
---
let
me
see
---
how
much
a
day
?
 
<EOS>
There
's
my
nap
after
dinner
---
an
hour
<EOS>
---
they
're
extremely
welcome
to
that
,
and
to
make
the
most
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
morning
,
between
my
breakfast
and
the
paper
,
I
could
spare
them
another
hour
;
in
the
evening
before
dinner
say
another
.
 
<EOS>
Three
hours
a
day
.
<EOS>
They
might
pay
themselves
in
calls
,
with
interest
,
in
twelve
months
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
shall
propose
it
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
my
centaur
,
are
you
there
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Here
I
am
,
"
replied
Hugh
,
striding
in
,
followed
by
a
dog
,
as
rough
and
sullen
as
himself
;
"
and
trouble
enough
I
've
had
to
get
here
.
<EOS>
What
do
you
ask
me
to
come
for
,
and
keep
me
out
when
I
DO
come
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
good
fellow
,
"
returned
the
other
,
raising
his
head
a
little
from
the
cushion
and
carelessly
surveying
him
from
top
to
toe
,
"
I
am
delighted
to
see
you
,
and
to
have
,
in
your
being
here
,
the
very
best
proof
that
you
are
not
kept
out
.
 
<EOS>
How
are
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
well
enough
,
"
said
Hugh
impatiently
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
look
a
perfect
marvel
of
health
.
 
<EOS>
Sit
down
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'd
rather
stand
,
"
said
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Please
yourself
my
good
fellow
<EOS>
,
"
returned
Mr
Chester
rising
,
slowly
pulling
off
the
loose
robe
he
wore
,
and
sitting
down
before
the
dressing
-
glass
.
 
<EOS>
"
Please
yourself
by
all
means
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Having
said
this
in
the
politest
and
blandest
tone
possible
,
he
went
on
dressing
,
and
took
no
further
notice
of
his
guest
,
who
stood
in
the
same
spot
as
uncertain
what
to
do
next
,
eyeing
him
sulkily
from
time
to
time
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
to
speak
to
me
,
master
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
after
a
long
silence
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
worthy
creature
,
"
returned
Mr
Chester
,
"
you
are
a
little
ruffled
and
out
of
humour
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
wait
till
you
're
quite
yourself
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
in
no
hurry
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
behaviour
had
its
intended
effect
.
 
<EOS>
It
humbled
and
abashed
the
man
,
and
made
him
still
more
irresolute
and
uncertain
.
 
<EOS>
Hard
words
he
could
have
returned
,
violence
he
would
have
repaid
with
interest
;
but
this
cool
,
complacent
,
contemptuous
,
self
-
possessed
reception
,
caused
him
to
feel
his
inferiority
more
completely
than
the
most
elaborate
arguments
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
contributed
to
this
effect
.
 
<EOS>
His
own
rough
speech
,
contrasted
with
the
soft
persuasive
accents
of
the
other
;
his
rude
bearing
,
and
Mr
Chester
's
polished
manner
;
the
disorder
and
negligence
of
his
ragged
dress
,
and
the
elegant
attire
he
saw
before
him
;
with
all
the
unaccustomed
luxuries
and
comforts
of
the
room
,
and
the
silence
that
gave
him
leisure
to
observe
these
things
,
and
feel
how
ill
at
ease
they
made
him
;
all
these
influences
,
which
have
too
often
some
effect
on
tutored
minds
and
become
of
almost
resistless
power
when
brought
to
bear
on
such
a
mind
as
his
,
quelled
Hugh
completely
.
 
<EOS>
He
moved
by
little
and
little
nearer
to
Mr
Chester
's
chair
,
and
glancing
over
his
shoulder
at
the
reflection
of
his
face
in
the
glass
,
as
if
seeking
for
some
encouragement
in
its
expression
,
said
at
length
,
with
a
rough
attempt
at
conciliation
,
  
"
ARE
you
going
to
speak
to
me
,
master
,
or
am
I
to
go
away
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Speak
you
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
"
speak
you
,
good
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
spoken
,
have
I
not
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
waiting
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
look'ee
,
sir
,
"
returned
Hugh
with
increased
embarrassment
,
"
am
I
the
man
that
you
privately
left
your
whip
with
before
you
rode
away
from
the
Maypole
,
and
told
to
bring
it
back
whenever
he
might
want
to
see
you
on
a
certain
subject
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
doubt
the
same
,
or
you
have
a
twin
brother
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
glancing
at
the
reflection
of
his
anxious
face
;
"
which
is
not
probable
,
I
should
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
have
come
,
sir
,
"
said
Hugh
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
have
brought
it
back
,
and
something
else
along
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
A
letter
,
sir
,
it
is
,
that
I
took
from
the
person
who
had
charge
of
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
he
laid
upon
the
dressing
-
table
,
Dolly
's
lost
epistle
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
letter
that
had
cost
her
so
much
trouble
.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
obtain
this
by
force
,
my
good
fellow
?
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
casting
his
eye
upon
it
without
the
least
perceptible
surprise
or
pleasure
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
quite
,
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Partly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
was
the
messenger
from
whom
you
took
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
woman
.
 
<EOS>
One
Varden
's
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
indeed
!
"
said
Mr
Chester
gaily
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
else
did
you
take
from
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
else
?
"
  
"
Yes
,
"
said
the
other
,
in
a
drawling
manner
,
for
he
was
fixing
a
very
small
patch
of
sticking
plaster
on
a
very
small
pimple
near
the
corner
of
his
mouth
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
else
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
a
kiss
,
"
replied
Hugh
,
after
some
hesitation
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
else
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nothing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
in
the
same
easy
tone
,
and
smiling
twice
or
thrice
to
try
if
the
patch
adhered
---
"
<EOS>
I
think
there
was
something
else
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
heard
a
trifle
of
jewellery
spoken
of
---
a
mere
trifle
---
a
thing
of
such
little
value
,
indeed
,
that
you
may
have
forgotten
it
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
remember
anything
of
the
kind
---
such
as
a
bracelet
now
,
for
instance
?
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
with
a
muttered
oath
thrust
his
hand
into
his
breast
,
and
drawing
the
bracelet
forth
,
wrapped
in
a
scrap
of
hay
,
was
about
to
lay
it
on
the
table
likewise
,
when
his
patron
stopped
his
hand
and
bade
him
put
it
up
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
took
that
for
yourself
my
excellent
friend
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
may
keep
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
neither
a
thief
nor
a
receiver
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
show
it
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
had
better
hide
it
again
,
and
lose
no
time
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
me
see
where
you
put
it
either
,
"
he
added
,
turning
away
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
a
receiver
!
"
said
Hugh
bluntly
,
despite
the
increasing
awe
in
which
he
held
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
call
THAT
,
master
?
"
striking
the
letter
with
his
heavy
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
call
that
quite
another
thing
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
coolly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
prove
it
presently
,
as
you
will
see
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
thirsty
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
  
Hugh
drew
his
sleeve
across
his
lips
,
and
gruffly
answered
yes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Step
to
that
closet
and
bring
me
a
bottle
you
will
see
there
,
and
a
glass
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
obeyed
.
 
<EOS>
His
patron
followed
him
with
his
eyes
,
and
when
his
back
was
turned
,
smiled
as
he
had
never
done
when
he
stood
beside
the
mirror
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
return
he
filled
the
glass
,
and
bade
him
drink
.
<EOS>
That
dram
despatched
,
he
poured
him
out
another
,
and
another
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
many
can
you
bear
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
filling
the
glass
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
As
many
as
you
like
to
give
me
.
 
<EOS>
Pour
on
.
 
<EOS>
Fill
high
.
 
<EOS>
A
bumper
with
a
bead
in
the
middle
!
 
<EOS>
Give
me
enough
of
this
,
"
he
added
,
as
he
tossed
it
down
his
hairy
throat
,
"
and
I
'll
do
murder
if
you
ask
me
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
I
do
n't
mean
to
ask
you
,
and
you
might
possibly
do
it
without
being
invited
if
you
went
on
much
further
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
with
great
composure
,
we
will
stop
,
if
agreeable
to
you
,
my
good
friend
,
at
the
next
glass
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
drinking
before
you
came
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
always
am
when
I
can
get
it
,
"
cried
Hugh
boisterously
,
waving
the
empty
glass
above
his
head
,
and
throwing
himself
into
a
rude
dancing
attitude
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
always
am
.
 
<EOS>
Why
not
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
What
's
so
good
to
me
as
this
?
 
<EOS>
What
ever
has
been
?
 
<EOS>
What
else
has
kept
away
the
cold
on
bitter
nights
,
and
driven
hunger
off
in
starving
times
?
<EOS>
What
else
has
given
me
the
strength
and
courage
of
a
man
,
when
men
would
have
left
me
to
die
,
a
puny
child
?
 
<EOS>
I
should
never
have
had
a
man
's
heart
but
for
this
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
died
in
a
ditch
.
 
<EOS>
Where
's
he
who
when
I
was
a
weak
and
sickly
wretch
,
with
trembling
legs
and
fading
sight
,
bade
me
cheer
up
,
as
this
did
?
 
<EOS>
I
never
knew
him
;
not
I.
 
<EOS>
I
drink
to
the
drink
,
master
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
"
  
"
You
are
an
exceedingly
cheerful
young
man
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
putting
on
his
cravat
with
great
deliberation
,
and
slightly
moving
his
head
from
side
to
side
to
settle
his
chin
in
its
proper
place
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite
a
boon
companion
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
you
see
this
hand
,
master
,
"
said
Hugh
,
"
and
this
arm
?
<EOS>
"
baring
the
brawny
limb
to
the
elbow
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
once
mere
skin
and
bone
,
and
would
have
been
dust
in
some
poor
churchyard
by
this
time
,
but
for
the
drink
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
cover
it
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
"
it
's
sufficiently
real
in
your
sleeve
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
never
have
been
spirited
up
to
take
a
kiss
from
the
proud
little
beauty
,
master
,
but
for
the
drink
,
"
cried
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
<EOS>
It
was
a
good
one
.
 
<EOS>
As
sweet
as
honeysuckle
,
I
warrant
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
thank
the
drink
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
drink
to
the
drink
again
,
master
.
<EOS>
Fill
me
one
more
.
 
<EOS>
Come
.
 
<EOS>
One
more
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
such
a
promising
fellow
,
"
said
his
patron
,
putting
on
his
waistcoat
with
great
nicety
,
and
taking
no
heed
of
this
request
,
"
that
I
must
caution
you
against
having
too
many
impulses
from
the
drink
,
and
getting
hung
before
your
time
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
your
age
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
"
you
are
young
enough
to
escape
what
I
may
call
a
natural
death
for
some
years
to
come
.
 
<EOS>
How
can
you
trust
yourself
in
my
hands
on
so
short
an
acquaintance
,
with
a
halter
round
your
neck
?
 
<EOS>
What
a
confiding
nature
yours
must
be
!
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
fell
back
a
pace
or
two
and
surveyed
him
with
a
look
of
mingled
terror
,
indignation
,
and
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
Regarding
himself
in
the
glass
with
the
same
complacency
as
before
,
and
speaking
as
smoothly
as
if
he
were
discussing
some
pleasant
chit
-
chat
of
the
town
,
his
patron
went
on
:
  
"
Robbery
on
the
king
's
highway
,
my
young
friend
,
is
a
very
dangerous
and
ticklish
occupation
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
pleasant
,
I
have
no
doubt
,
while
it
lasts
;
but
like
many
other
pleasures
in
this
transitory
world
,
it
seldom
lasts
long
.
 
<EOS>
And
really
if
in
the
ingenuousness
of
youth
,
you
open
your
heart
so
readily
on
the
subject
<EOS>
,
I
am
afraid
your
career
will
be
an
extremely
short
one
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
's
this
?
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
talk
of
master
?
 
<EOS>
Who
was
it
set
me
on
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
wheeling
sharply
round
,
and
looking
full
at
him
for
the
first
time
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
hear
you
.
 
<EOS>
Who
was
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
faltered
,
and
muttered
something
which
was
not
audible
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
was
it
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
curious
to
know
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
with
surpassing
affability
.
 
<EOS>
"
Some
rustic
beauty
perhaps
?
 
<EOS>
But
be
cautious
,
my
good
friend
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
not
always
to
be
trusted
.
 
<EOS>
Do
take
my
advice
now
,
and
be
careful
of
yourself
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
these
words
he
turned
to
the
glass
again
,
and
went
on
with
his
toilet
.
  
<EOS>
Hugh
would
have
answered
him
that
he
,
the
questioner
himself
had
set
him
on
,
but
the
words
stuck
in
his
throat
.
 
<EOS>
The
consummate
art
with
which
his
patron
had
led
him
to
this
point
,
and
managed
the
whole
conversation
,
perfectly
baffled
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
not
doubt
that
if
he
had
made
the
retort
which
was
on
his
lips
when
Mr
Chester
turned
round
and
questioned
him
so
keenly
,
he
would
straightway
have
given
him
into
custody
and
had
him
dragged
before
a
justice
with
the
stolen
property
upon
him
;
in
which
case
it
was
as
certain
he
would
have
been
hung
as
it
was
that
he
had
been
born
.
 
<EOS>
The
ascendency
which
it
was
the
purpose
of
the
man
of
the
world
to
establish
over
this
savage
instrument
,
was
gained
from
that
time
.
<EOS>
Hugh
's
submission
was
complete
.
 
<EOS>
He
dreaded
him
beyond
description
;
and
felt
that
accident
and
artifice
had
spun
a
web
about
him
,
which
at
a
touch
from
such
a
master
-
hand
as
his
,
would
bind
him
to
the
gallows
.
  
<EOS>
With
these
thoughts
passing
through
his
mind
,
and
yet
wondering
at
the
very
same
time
how
he
who
came
there
rioting
in
the
confidence
of
this
man
(
as
he
thought
)
,
should
be
so
soon
<EOS>
and
so
thoroughly
subdued
,
Hugh
stood
cowering
before
him
,
regarding
him
uneasily
from
time
to
time
,
while
he
finished
dressing
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
done
so
,
he
took
up
the
letter
,
broke
the
seal
,
and
throwing
himself
back
in
his
chair
,
read
it
leisurely
through
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
neatly
worded
upon
my
life
!
 
<EOS>
Quite
a
woman
's
letter
,
full
of
what
people
call
tenderness
,
and
disinterestedness
,
and
heart
,
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
!
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
he
twisted
it
up
,
and
glancing
lazily
round
at
Hugh
as
though
he
would
say
"
You
see
this
?
<EOS>
"
held
it
in
the
flame
of
the
candle
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
was
in
a
full
blaze
,
he
tossed
it
into
the
grate
,
and
there
it
smouldered
away
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
directed
to
my
son
,
"
he
said
,
turning
to
Hugh
,
"
and
you
did
quite
right
to
bring
it
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
opened
it
on
my
own
responsibility
,
and
you
see
what
I
have
done
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
Take
this
,
for
your
trouble
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
stepped
forward
to
receive
the
piece
of
money
he
held
out
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
put
it
in
his
hand
,
he
added
:
  
"
<EOS>
If
you
should
happen
to
find
anything
else
of
this

,

pick

information
you
may
think
I
would
like
to

,
bring

here
,
will

,
my
good
fellow
?
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
said
with
a
smile
which
implied
---
or
Hugh
thought
it
did
---
 
"
fail
to
do
so
at
your
peril
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
answered
that
he
would
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
do
n't
,
"
said
his
patron
,
with
an
air
of
the
very
kindest
patronage
,
"
do

be
at
all
downcast
or
uneasy
respecting
that

we
have

speaking

.
 
<EOS>
Your
neck
is
as
safe
in
my
hands
,
my

,
as
though
a

's

,
I
assure
you
.
<EOS>
---
Take
another
glass
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
quieter
now
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
accepted
it
from
his
hand
,
and
looking
stealthily
at
his
smiling

,
drank
the
contents
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
---
ha
,
ha
!
---
do
n't
you
drink
to
the
drink
any
more
?
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
in
his
most
winning

.
  
<EOS>
"
To
you
,
sir
,
"
was
the
sullen

,
with
something

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
drink
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
bye
,
what
is
your
name
,
my
good
soul
?
 
<EOS>
You
are
called
Hugh
,
I
know
,
of
course
---
your
other
name
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
other
name
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
very
strange
fellow
!
 
<EOS>
Do
you
mean
that
you
never
knew
one
,
or
that
you
do
n't
choose
to

?
 
<EOS>
Which
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'd
tell
it
if
I
could
,
"
said
Hugh
,
quickly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
always
called
Hugh
;
nothing
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
knew
,
nor
saw
,
nor
thought
about
a
father
;
and
I
was
a
boy
of
six
<EOS>
---
that
's
not
very

---
when
they
hung
my
mother
up
at
Tyburn
for
a

to

.
 
<EOS>
They
might
have
let
her
live
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
poor
enough
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
very
sad
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
his
patron
,
with
a

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
she
was
an
exceedingly
fine
woman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
see
that
dog
of
mine
?
"
said
Hugh
,
abruptly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Faithful
,
I
dare
say
?
<EOS>
"
rejoined
his
patron
,
looking
at
him
through
his
glass
;
"
and
immensely
clever
?
 
<EOS>
Virtuous
and
gifted
animals
,
whether
man
or
beast
,
always
are
so
very
hideous
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Such
a
dog
as
that
,
and
one
of
the
same
breed
,
was
the
only
living
thing
except
me
that
howled
that
day
,
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Out
of
the
two
thousand
odd
---
there
was
a
larger
crowd
for
its
being
a
woman
---
the
dog
and
I
alone
had
any
pity
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
'd
have
been
a
man
,
he
'd
have
been
glad
to
be
quit
of
her
,
for
she
had
been
forced
to
keep
him
lean

half
-

;
but
being
a
dog
,
and
not
having
a
man
's
sense
,
he
was
sorry
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
dull
of
the
brute
,
certainly
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
"
and
very
like
a
brute
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
made
no
rejoinder
,
but
whistling
to
his
dog
,
who
sprung
up
at
the
sound
and
came
jumping
and
sporting
about
him
,
bade
his
sympathising
friend
good
night
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
;
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Remember
;
you
're
safe
with
me
---
quite
safe
.
 
<EOS>
So
long
as
you
deserve
it
,
my
good
fellow
,
as
I
hope
you
always
will
,
you
have
a
friend
in
me
,
on
whose
silence
you
may
rely
.
 
<EOS>
Now
do
be
careful
of
yourself
,
pray
do
,
and
consider
what
jeopardy
you
might
have
stood
in
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
bless
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
truckled
before
the
hidden
meaning
of
these
words
as
much
as
such
a
being
could
,
and
crept
out
of
the
door
so
submissively
and
subserviently
---
with
an
air
,
in
short
,
so
different
from
that
with
which
he
had
entered
---
that
his
patron
on
being
left
alone
,
smiled
more
than
ever
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
took
a
pinch
of
snuff
,
"
I
do
not
like
their
having
hanged
his
mother
.
 
<EOS>
The
fellow
has
a
fine
eye
,
and
I
am
sure
she
was
handsome
.
 
<EOS>
But
very
probably
she
was
coarse
---
red
-
nosed
perhaps
,
and
had
clumsy
feet
.
 
<EOS>
Aye
,
it
was
all
for
the
best
,
no
doubt
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
this
comforting
reflection
,
he
put
on
his
coat
,
took
a
farewell
glance
at
the
glass
,
and
summoned
his
man
,
who
promptly
attended
,
followed
by
a
chair
and
its
two
bearers
.
  
<EOS>
"
Foh
!
"
said
Mr
Chester
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
very
atmosphere
that
centaur
has
breathed
,
seems
tainted
with
the
cart
and
ladder
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
Peak
.
<EOS>
Bring
some
scent
and
sprinkle
the
floor
;
and
take
away
the
chair
he
sat
upon
,
and
air
it
;
and
dash
a
little
of
that
mixture
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
stifled
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
man
obeyed
;
and
the
room
and
its
master
being
both
purified
,
nothing
remained
for
Mr
Chester
but
to
demand
his
hat
,
to
fold
it
jauntily
under
his
arm
,
to
take
his
seat
in
the
chair
and
be
carried
off
;
humming
a
fashionable
tune
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
24
    
<EOS>
How
the
accomplished
gentleman
spent
the
evening
in
the
midst
of
a
dazzling
and
brilliant
circle
;
how
he
enchanted
all
those
with
whom
he
mingled
by
the
grace
of
his
deportment
,
the
politeness
of
his
manner
,
the
vivacity
of
his
conversation
,
and
the
sweetness
of
his
voice
;
how
it
was
observed
in
every
corner
,
that
Chester
was
a
man
of
that
happy
disposition
that
nothing
ruffled
him
,
that
he
was
one
on
whom
the
world
's
cares
and
errors
sat
lightly
as
his
dress
,
and
in
whose
smiling
face
a
calm
and
tranquil
mind
was
constantly
reflected
;
how
honest
men
,
who
by
instinct
knew
him
better
,
bowed
down
before
him
nevertheless
,
deferred
to
his
every
word
,
and
courted
his
favourable
notice
;
how
people
,
who
really
had
good
in
them
,
went
with
the
stream
,
and
fawned
and
flattered
,
and
approved
,
and
despised
themselves
while
they
did
so
,
and
yet
had
not
the
courage
to
resist
;
how
,
in
short
,
he
was
one
of
those
who
are
received
and
cherished
in
society
(
as
the
phrase
is
)
by
scores
who
individually
would
shrink
from
and
be
repelled
by
the
object
of
their
lavish
regard
;
are
things
of
course
,
which
will
suggest
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
Matter
<EOS>
so
commonplace
needs
but
a
passing
glance
,
and
there
an
end
.
  
<EOS>
The
despisers
of
mankind
---
apart
from
the
mere
fools
and
mimics
,
of
that
creed
---
are
of
two
sorts
.
 
<EOS>
They
who
believe
their
merit
neglected
and
unappreciated
,
make
up
one
class
;
they
who
receive
adulation
and
flattery
,
knowing
their
own
worthlessness
,
compose
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
Be
sure
that
the
coldest
-
hearted
misanthropes
are
ever
of
this
last
order
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Chester
sat
up

,

,
and

with

,

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Private
.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

That

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
HAVE

<EOS>
He

,

;
and

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

.
"

:
---
subsided

,
that

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
25
    
Leaving
the
favoured
,
and
well
-
received
,
and
flattered
of
the
world
;
him
of
the
world
most
worldly
,
who
never
compromised
himself
by
an
ungentlemanly
action
,
and
never
was
guilty
of
a
manly
one
;
to
lie

---
for
even

,
working
but
<EOS>
little
change
in
his
dissembling
face
,
became
with
him
a
piece
of
cold
,
conventional
hypocrisy
---
we
follow
in
the
steps
of
two
slow
travellers
on
foot
,
making
towards
Chigwell
.
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
and
his
mother
.
 
<EOS>
Grip
in
their
company
,
of
course
.
  
<EOS>
The
widow
,
to
whom
each
painful
mile
seemed
longer
than
the
last
,
toiled
wearily
along
;
while
Barnaby
,
yielding
to
every
inconstant
impulse
,
fluttered
here
and
there
,
now
leaving
her
far
behind
,
now
lingering
far
behind
himself
,
now
darting
into
some
by
-
lane
or
path
and
leaving
her
to
pursue
her
way
alone
,
until
he
stealthily
emerged
again
and
came
upon
her
with
a
wild
shout
of
merriment
,
as
his
wayward
and
capricious
nature
prompted
.
 
<EOS>
Now
he
would
call
to
her
from
the
topmost
branch
of
some
high
tree
by
the
roadside
;
now
using
his
tall
staff
as
a
leaping
-
pole
,
come
flying
over
ditch
or
hedge
or
five
-
barred
gate
;
now
run
with
surprising
swiftness
for
a
mile
or
more
on
the
straight
road
,
and
halting
,
sport
upon
a
patch
of
grass
with
Grip
till
she
came
up
.
 
<EOS>
These
were
his
delights
;
and
when
his
patient
mother
heard
his
merry
voice
,
or
looked
into
his
flushed
and
healthy
face
,
she
would
not
have
abated
them
by
one
sad
word
or
murmur
,
though
each
had
been
to
her
a
source
of
suffering
in
the
same
degree
as
it
was
to
him
of
pleasure
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
something
to
look
upon
enjoyment
,
so
that
it
be
free
and
wild
and
in
the
face
of
nature
,
though
it
is
but
the
enjoyment
of
an
idiot
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
something
to
know
that
Heaven
has
left
the
capacity
of
gladness
in
such
a
creature
's
breast
;
it
is
something
to
be
assured
that
,
however
lightly
men
may
crush
that
faculty
in
their
fellows
,
the
Great
Creator
of
mankind
imparts
it
even
to
his
despised
and
slighted
work
.
 
<EOS>
Who
would
not
rather
see
a
poor
idiot
happy
in
the
sunlight
,
than
a
wise
man
pining
in
a
darkened
jail
!
  
<EOS>
Ye
men
of
gloom
and
austerity
,
who
paint
the
face
of
Infinite
Benevolence
with
an
eternal
frown
;
read
in
the
Everlasting
Book
,
wide
open
to
your
view
,
the
lesson
it
would
teach
.
 
<EOS>
Its
pictures
are
not
in
black
and
sombre
hues
,
but
bright
and
glowing
tints
;
its
music
---
save
when
ye
drown
it
---
is
not
in
sighs
and
groans
,
but
songs
and
cheerful
sounds
.
 
<EOS>
Listen
to
the
million
voices
in
the
summer
air
,
and
find
one
dismal
as
your
own
.
 
<EOS>
Remember
,
if
ye
can
,
the
sense
of
hope
and
pleasure
which
every
glad
return
of
day
awakens
in
the
breast
of
all
your
kind
who
have
not
changed
their
nature
;
and
learn
some
wisdom
even
from
the
witless
,
when
their
hearts
are
lifted
up
they
know
not
why
,
by
all
the
mirth
and
happiness
it
brings
.
  
<EOS>
The
widow
's
breast
was
full
of
care
,
was
laden
heavily
with
secret
dread
and
sorrow
;
but
her
boy
's
gaiety
of
heart
gladdened
her
,
and
beguiled
the
long
journey
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
he
would
bid
her
lean
upon
his
arm
,
and
would
keep
beside
her
steadily
for
a
short
distance
;
but
it
was
more
his
nature
to
be
rambling
to
and
fro
,
and
she
better
liked
to
see
him
free
and
happy
,
even
than
to
have
him
near
her
,
because
she
loved
him
better
than
herself
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
quitted
the
place
to
which
they
were
travelling
,
directly
after
the
event
which
had
changed
her
whole
existence
;
and
for
two
-
and
-
twenty
years
had
never
had
courage
to
revisit
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
her
native
village
.
 
<EOS>
How
many
recollections
crowded
on
her
mind
when
it
appeared
in
sight
!
  
<EOS>
Two
-
and
-
twenty
years
.
 
<EOS>
Her
boy
's
whole
life
and
history
.
 
<EOS>
The
last
time
she
looked
back
upon
those
roofs
among
the
trees
,
she
carried
him
in
her
arms
,
an
infant
.
 
<EOS>
How
often
since
that
time
had
she
sat
beside
him
night
and
day
,
watching
for
the
dawn
of
mind
that
never
came
;
how
had
she
feared
,
and
doubted
,
and
yet
hoped
,
long
after
conviction
forced
itself
upon
her
!
 
<EOS>
The
little
stratagems
she
had
devised
to
try
him
<EOS>
,
the
little
tokens
he
had
given
in
his
childish
way
---
not
of
dulness
but
of
something
infinitely
worse
,
<EOS>
so
ghastly
and
unchildlike
in
its
cunning
---
came
back
as
vividly
as
if
but
yesterday
had
intervened
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
in
which
they
used
to
be
;
the
spot
in
which
his
cradle
stood
;
he
,
old
and
elfin
-
like
in
face
,
but
ever
dear
to
her
,
gazing
at
her
with
a
wild
and
vacant
eye
,
and
crooning
some
uncouth
song
as
she
sat
by
and
rocked
him
;
every
circumstance
of
his
infancy
came
thronging
back
,
and
the
most
trivial
,
perhaps
,
the
most
distinctly
.
  
<EOS>
His
older
childhood
,
too
;
the
strange
imaginings
he
had
;
his
terror
of
certain
senseless
things
---
familiar
objects
he
endowed
with
life
;
the
slow
and
gradual
breaking
out
of
that
one
horror
,
in
which
,
before
his
birth
,
his
darkened
intellect
began
;
how
,
in
the
midst
of
all
,
she
had
found
some
hope
and
comfort
in
his
being
unlike
another
child
,
and
had
gone
on
almost
believing
in
the
slow
development
of
his
mind
until
he
grew
a
man
,
and
then
his
childhood
was
complete
and
lasting
;
one
after
another
,
all
these
old
thoughts
sprung
up
within
her
,
strong
after
their
long
slumber
and
bitterer
than
ever
.
  
<EOS>
She
took
his
arm
and
they
hurried
through
the
village
street
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
same
as
it
was
wo
nt
to
be
in
old
times
,
yet
different
too
,
and
wore
another
air
.
 
<EOS>
The
change
was
in
herself
,
not
it
;
but
she
never
thought
of
that
,
and
wondered
at
its
alteration
,
and
where
it
lay
,
and
what
it
was
.
  
<EOS>
The
people
all
knew
Barnaby
,
and
the
children
of
the
place
came
flocking
round
him
---
as
she
remembered
to
have
done
with
their
fathers
and
mothers
round
some
silly
beggarman
,
when
a
child
herself
.
 
<EOS>
None
of
them
knew
her
;
they
passed
each
well
-
remembered
house
,
and
yard
,
and
homestead
;
and
striking
into
the
fields
,
were
soon
alone
again
.
  
<EOS>
The
Warren
was
the
end
of
their
journey
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
was
walking
in
the
garden
,
and
seeing
them
as
they
passed
the
iron
gate
,
unlocked
it
,
and
bade
them
enter
that
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
length
you
have
mustered
heart
to
visit
the
old
place
,
"
he
said
to
the
widow
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
you
have
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
For
the
first
time
,
and
the
last
,
sir
,
"
she
replied
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
first
for
many
years
,
but
not
the
last
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
very
last
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
mean
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
regarding
her
with
some
surprise
,
"
that
having
made
this
effort
,
you
are
resolved
not
to
persevere
and
are
determined
to
relapse
?
 
<EOS>
This
is
unworthy
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
often
told
you
,
you
should
return
here
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
be
happier
here
than
elsewhere
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
Barnaby
,
it
's
quite
his
home
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
Grip
's
,
"
said
Barnaby
,
holding
the
basket
open
.
 
<EOS>
The
raven
hopped
gravely
out
,
and
perching
on
his
shoulder
and
addressing
himself
to
Mr
Haredale
,
cried
---
as
a
hint
,
perhaps
,
that
some
temperate
refreshment
would
be
acceptable
---
"
<EOS>
Polly
put
the
ket
-
tle
on
,
we
'll
all
have
tea
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
Mary
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
kindly
,
as
he
motioned
her
to
walk
with
him
towards
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
life
has
been
an
example
of
patience
and
fortitude
,
except
in
this
one
particular
which
has
often
given
me
great
pain
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
enough
to
know
that
you
were
cruelly
involved
in
the
calamity
which
deprived
me
of
an
only
brother
,
and
Emma
of
her
father
,
without
being
obliged
to
suppose
(
as
I
sometimes
am
)
that
you
associate
us
with
the
author
of
our
joint
misfortunes
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Associate
you
with
him
,
sir
!
<EOS>
"
she
cried
.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
I
think
you
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
almost
believe
that
because
your
husband
was
bound
by
so
many
ties
to
our
relation
,
and
died
in
his
service
and
defence
,
you
have
come
in
some
sort
to
connect
us
with
his
murder
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
"
<EOS>
she
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
little
know
my
heart
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
You
little
know
the
truth
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
natural
you
should
do
so
;
it
is
very
probable
you
may
,
without
being
conscious
of
it
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
speaking
more
to
himself
than
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
are
a
fallen
house
.
 
<EOS>
Money
,
dispensed
with
the
most
lavish
hand
,
would
be
a
poor
recompense
for
sufferings
like
yours
;
and
thinly
scattered
by
hands
so
pinched
and
tied
as
ours
,
it
becomes
a
miserable
mockery
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
it
so
<EOS>
,
God
knows
,
"
he
added
,
hastily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
wonder
if
she
does
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
me
wrong
,
dear
sir
,
indeed
,
"
she
rejoined
with
great
earnestness
;
"
and
yet
when
you
come
to
hear
what
I
desire
your
leave
to
say
---
"
  
"
I
shall
find
my
doubts
confirmed
?
<EOS>
"
he
said
,
observing
that
she
faltered
and
became
confused
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
quickened
his
pace
for
a
few
steps
,
but
fell
back
again
to
her
side
,
and
said
:
  
"
<EOS>
And
have
you
come
all
this
way
at
last
,
solely
to
speak
to
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
answered
,
"
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
curse
,
"
he
muttered
,
"
upon
the
wretched
state
of
us
proud
beggars
,
from
whom
the
poor
and
rich
are
equally
at
a
distance
;
the
one
being
forced
to
treat
us
with
a
show
of
cold

;
the
other
condescending
to
us
in
their
every
deed
and

,
and
keeping
more
aloof
,
the
nearer
they
approach
us
.
---
Why
,
if
it
were
pain
to
you
(
as
it
must
have
been
)
to
break
for
this
slight
purpose
the
chain
of
habit
forged
through
two
-

years
,
could
you
not
let
me
know
your
wish
,
and
beg
me
to
come
to
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
was
not
time
,
sir
,
"
she

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
took
my
resolution
but
last
night
,
and
taking
it
,
felt
that
I
must
not
lose
a
day
---
a
day
!
<EOS>
an
hour
---
in
having
speech
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
had
by
this
time
reached
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
paused
for
a
moment
,
and
looked
at
her
as
if

by
the
energy
of
her

.
 
<EOS>
Observing
,
however
,
that
she
took
no

,
but

up
,

,
at
the
old
walls
with
which
such

were
connected
in

,

led
her
by
a
private

into
his
library
,
where
Emma
was

in

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
young
lady
,
seeing
who
approached
,
hastily
rose
and
laid
aside
her
book
,
and
with
many
kind
words
,
and
not
without
tears
,
gave
her
a
warm

earnest

.
 
<EOS>
But
the
widow
shrunk
from
her
embrace
as
though
she
feared
her
,
and
sunk
down
trembling
on
a
chair
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
return
to
this
place
after
so
long
an

,
"
said
Emma
gently
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
ring
,
dear
uncle
---
or
stay
<EOS>
---
Barnaby
will
run
himself
and
ask
for
wine
---
"
  
"
Not
for
the
world
,
"
she

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
have
another
taste
---
I
could
not
touch
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
but
a
minute
's
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
but
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Haredale
stood
beside
her
chair
,
regarding
her
with
silent
pity
.
 
<EOS>
She
remained
for
a
little
time
quite
still
;
then
rose
and
turned
to
Mr
Haredale
,
who
had
sat
down
in
his
easy
chair
,
and
was
contemplating
her
with
fixed

.
  
<EOS>
The
tale
connected
with
the
mansion
borne
in
mind
,
it
seemed
,
as
has
been
already
said
,
the
chosen
theatre
for
such
a
deed
as
it
had
known
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
in
which
this
group
were
now
assembled
---
hard
by
the
very
chamber
where
the
act
was
done
---
dull
,
dark
,
and
sombre
;
heavy
with
worm
-
eaten
books
;
deadened
and
shut
in
by
faded

,
muffling
every

;
shadowed

by
trees
whose
rustling
boughs
gave
ever
and
anon
a
spectral
knocking
at
the
glass
;
wore
,
beyond
all
others
in
the
house
,
a
ghostly
,
gloomy
air
.
<EOS>
Nor
were
the
group
assembled
there
,
unfitting
tenants
of
the
spot
.
<EOS>
The
widow
,
with
her
marked
and
startling
face
and
downcast
eyes
;
Mr
Haredale
stern
and
despondent
ever
;
his
niece
beside
him
,
like
,
yet
most
unlike
,
the
picture
of
her
father
,
which
gazed
reproachfully
down
upon
them
from
the
blackened
wall
;
Barnaby
,
with
his
vacant
look
and
restless
eye
;
were
all
in
keeping
with
the
place
,
and
actors
in
the
legend
.
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
the
very
raven
,
who
had
hopped
upon
the
table
and
with
the
air
of
some
old
necromancer
appeared
to
be
profoundly
studying
a
great
folio
volume
that
lay
open
on
a
desk
,
was
strictly
in
unison
with
the
rest
,
and
looked
like
the
embodied
spirit
of
evil
biding
his
time
of
mischief
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
scarcely
know
,
"
said
the
widow
,
breaking
silence
,
"
how
to
begin
.
<EOS>
You
will
think
my
mind
disordered
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
whole
tenor
of
your
quiet
and
reproachless
life
since
you
were
last
here
,
"
returned
Mr
Haredale
,
mildly
,
"
shall
bear
witness
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
you
fear
to
awaken
such
a
suspicion
?
 
<EOS>
You
do
not
speak
to
strangers
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
not
to
claim
our
interest
or
consideration
for
the
first
time
.
 
<EOS>
Be
more
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
Take
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Any
advice
or
assistance
that
I
can
give
you
,
you
know
is
yours
of
right
,
and
freely
yours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
if
I
came
,
sir
,
"
she
rejoined
,
"
I
who
have
but
one
other
friend
on
earth
,
to
reject
your
aid
from
this
moment
,
and
to
say
that
henceforth
I
launch
myself
upon
the
world
,
alone
and
unassisted
,
to
sink
or
swim
as
Heaven
may
decree
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
would
have
,
if
you
came
to
me
for
such
a
purpose
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
calmly
,
"
some
reason
to
assign
for
conduct
so
extraordinary
,
which
---
if
one
may
entertain
the
possibility
of
anything
so
wild
and
strange
---
would
have
its
weight
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
,
sir
,
"
she
answered
,
"
is
the
misery
of
my
distress
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
give
no
reason
whatever
.
 
<EOS>
My
own
bare
word
is
all
that
I
can
offer
.
<EOS>
It
is
my
duty
,
my
imperative
and
bounden
duty
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
did
not
discharge
it
,
I
should
be
a
base
and
guilty
wretch
.
 
<EOS>
Having
said
that
,
my
lips
are
sealed
,
and
I
can
say
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
though
she
felt
relieved
at
having
said
so
much
,
and
had
nerved
herself
to
the
remainder
of
her
task
,
she
spoke
from
this
time
with
a
firmer
voice
and
heightened
courage
.
  
<EOS>
"
Heaven
is
my
witness
,
as
my
own
heart
is
---
and
yours
,
dear
young
lady
,
will
speak
for
me
,
I
know
---
that
I
have
lived
,
since
that
time
we
all
have
bitter
reason
to
remember
,
in
unchanging
devotion
,
and
gratitude
to
this
family
.
 
<EOS>
Heaven
is
my
witness
that
go
where
I
may
,
I
shall
preserve
those
feelings
unimpaired
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
is
my
witness
,
too
,
that
they
alone
impel
me
to
the
course
I
must
take
,
and
from
which
nothing
now
shall
turn
me
,
as
I
hope
for
mercy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
These
are
strange
riddles
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
this
world
,
sir
,
"
she
replied
,
"
they
may
,
perhaps
,
never
be
explained
.
 
<EOS>
In
another
,
the
Truth
will
be
discovered
in
its
own
good
time
.
 
<EOS>
And
may
that
time
,
"
she
added
in
a
low
voice
,
"
be
far
distant
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
be
sure
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
that
I
understand
you
,
for
I
am
doubtful
of
my
own
senses
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
mean
that
you
are
resolved
voluntarily
to
deprive
yourself
of
those
means
of
support
you
have
received
from
us
so
long
---
that
you
are
determined
to
resign
the
annuity
we
settled
on
you
twenty
years
ago
---
to
leave
house
,
and
home
,
and
goods
,
and
begin
life
anew
---
and
this
,
for
some
secret
reason
or
monstrous
fancy
which
is
incapable
of
explanation
,
which
only
now
exists
,
and
has
been
dormant
all
this
time
?
 
<EOS>
In
the
name
of
God
,
under
what
delusion
are
you
labouring
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
I
am
deeply
thankful
,
"
she
made
answer
,
"
for
the
kindness
of
those
,
alive
and
dead
,
who
have
owned
this
house
;
and
as
I
would
not
have
its
roof
fall
down
and
crush
me
,
or
its
very
walls
drip
blood
,
my
name
being
spoken
in
their
hearing
;
I
never
will
again
subsist
upon
their
bounty
,
or
let
it
help
me
to
subsistence
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
not
know
,
"
she
added
,
suddenly
,
"
to
what
uses
it
may
be
applied
;
into
what
hands
it
may
pass
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
,
and
I
renounce
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
its
uses
rest
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
did
.
 
<EOS>
They
rest
with
me
no
longer
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
---
it
IS
---
devoted
to
purposes
that
mock
the
dead
in
their
graves
.
 
<EOS>
It
never
can
prosper
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
bring
some
other
heavy
judgement
on
the
head
of
my
dear
son
,
whose
innocence
will
suffer
for
his
mother
's
guilt
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
words
are
these
!
"
cried
Mr
Haredale
,
regarding
her
with
wonder
.
 
<EOS>
"
Among
what
associates
have
you
fallen
?
 
<EOS>
Into
what
guilt
have
you
ever
been
betrayed
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
guilty
,
and
yet
innocent
;
wrong
,
yet
right
;
good
in
intention
,
though
constrained
to
shield
and
aid
the
bad
.
 
<EOS>
Ask
me
no
more
questions
,
sir
;
but
believe
that
I
am
rather
to
be
pitied
than
condemned
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
leave
my
house
to
-
morrow
,
for
while
I
stay
there
,
it
is
haunted
.
 
<EOS>
My
future
dwelling
,
if
I
am
to
live
in
peace
,
must
be
a
secret
.
 
<EOS>
If
my
poor
boy
should
ever
stray
this
way
,
do
not
tempt
him
to
disclose
it
or
have
him
watched
when
he
returns
;
for
if
we
are
hunted
,
we
must
fly
again
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
this
load
is
off
my
mind
,
I
beseech
you
---
and
<EOS>
you
,
dear
Miss
Haredale
,
too
---
to
trust
me
if
you
can
,
and
think
of
me
kindly
as
you
have
been
used
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
die
and
can
not
tell
my
secret
even
then
(
for
that
may
come
to
pass
)
,
it
will
sit
the
lighter
on
my
breast
in
that
hour
for
this
day
's
work
;
and
on
that
day
,
and
every
day
until
it
comes
,
I
will
pray
for
and
thank
you
both
,
and
trouble
you
no
more
.
  
<EOS>
With
that
,
she
would
have
left
them
,
but
they
detained
her
,
and
with
many
soothing
words
and
kind
entreaties
,
besought
her
to
consider
what
she
did
,
and
above
all
to
repose
more
freely
upon
them
,
and
say
what
weighed
so
sorely
on
her
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Finding
her
deaf
to
their
persuasions
,
Mr
Haredale
suggested
,
as
a
last
resource
,
that
she
should
confide
in
Emma
,
of
whom
,
as
a
young
person
and
one
of
her
own
sex
,
she
might
stand
in
less
dread
than
of
himself
.
<EOS>
From
this
proposal
,
however
,
she
recoiled
with
the
same
indescribable
repugnance
she
had
manifested
when
they
met
.
 
<EOS>
The
utmost
that
could
be
wrung
from
her
was
,
a
promise
that
she
would
receive
Mr
Haredale
at
her
own
house
next
evening
,
and
in
the
mean
time
reconsider
her
determination
and
their
dissuasions
---
though
any
change
on
her
part
,
as
she
told
them
,
was
quite
hopeless
.
 
<EOS>
This
condition
made
at
last
,
they
reluctantly
suffered
her
to
depart
,
since
she
would
neither
eat
nor
drink
within
the
house
;
and
she
,
and
Barnaby
,
and
Grip
,
accordingly
went
out
as
they
had
come
,
by
the
private
stair
and
garden
-
gate
;
seeing
and
being
seen
of
no
one
by
the
way
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
remarkable
in
the
raven
that
during
the
whole
interview
he
had
kept
his
eye
on
his
book
with
exactly
the
air
of
a
very
sly
human
rascal
,
who
,
under
the
mask
of
pretending
to
read
hard
,
was
listening
to
everything
.
 
<EOS>
He
still
appeared
to
have
the
conversation
very
strongly
in
his
mind
,
for
although
,
when
they
were
alone
again
,
he
issued
orders
for
the
instant
preparation
of
innumerable
kettles
for
purposes
of
tea
,
he
was
thoughtful
,
and
rather
seemed
to
do
so
from
an
abstract
sense
of
duty
,
than
with
any
regard
to
making
himself
agreeable
,
or
being
what
is
commonly
called
good
company
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
to
return
by
the
coach
.
 
<EOS>
As
there
was
an
interval
of
full
two
hours
before
it
started
,
and
they
needed
rest
and
some
refreshment
,
Barnaby
begged
hard
for
a
visit
to
the
Maypole
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
mother
,
who
had
no
wish
to
be
recognised
by
any
of
those
who
had
known
her
long
ago
,
and
who
feared
besides
that
Mr
Haredale
might
,
on
second
thoughts
,
despatch
some
messenger
to
that
place
of
entertainment
in
quest
of
her
,
proposed
to
wait
in
the
churchyard
instead
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
was
easy
for
Barnaby
to
buy
and
carry
thither
such
humble
viands
as
they
required
,
he
cheerfully
assented
,
and
in
the
churchyard
they
sat
down
to
take
their
frugal
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
Here
again
,
the
raven
was
in
a
highly
reflective
state
;
walking
up
and
down
when
he
had
dined
,
with
an
air
of
elderly
complacency
which
was
strongly
suggestive
of
his
having
his
hands
under
his
coat
-
tails
;
and
appearing
to
read
the
tombstones
with
a
very
critical
taste
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
after
a
long
inspection
of
an
epitaph
,
he
would
strop
his
beak
upon
the
grave
to
which
it
referred
,
and
cry
in
his
hoarse
tones
,
"
I
'm
a
devil
,
I
'm
a
devil
,
I
'm
a
devil
!
"
<EOS>
but
whether
he
addressed
his
observations
to
any
supposed
person
below
,
or
merely
threw
them
off
as
a
general
remark
,
is
matter
of
uncertainty
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
quiet
pretty
spot
,
but
<EOS>
a
sad
one
for
Barnaby
's
mother
;
for
Mr
Reuben
Haredale
lay
there
,
and
near
the
vault
in
which
his
ashes
rested
,
was
a
stone
to
the
memory
of
her
own
husband
,
with
a
brief
inscription
recording
<EOS>
how
and
when
he
had
lost
his
life
.
 
<EOS>
She
sat
here
,
thoughtful
and
apart
,
until
their
time
was
out
,
and
the
distant
horn
told
that
the
coach
was
coming
.
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
,
who
had
been
sleeping
on
the
grass
,
sprung
up
quickly
at
the
sound
;
and
Grip
,
who
appeared
to
understand
it
equally
well
,
walked
into
his
basket
straightway
,
entreating
society
in
general
(
as
though
he
intended
a
kind
of
satire
upon
them
in
connection
with
churchyards
)
never
to
say
die
on
any
terms
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
soon
on
the
coach
-
top
and
rolling
along
the
road
.
  
<EOS>
It
went
round
by
the
Maypole
,
and
stopped
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Joe
was
from
home
,
and
Hugh
came
sluggishly
out
to
hand
up
the
parcel
that
it
called
for
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
fear
of
old
John
coming
out
.
 
<EOS>
They
could
see
him
from
the
coach
-
roof
fast
asleep
in
his
cosy
bar
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
part
of
John
's
character
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
a
point
of
going
to
sleep
at
the
coach
's
time
.
 
<EOS>
He
despised
gadding
about
;
he
looked
upon
coaches
as
things
that
ought
to
be
indicted
;
as
disturbers
of
the
peace
of
mankind
;
as
restless
,
bustling
,
busy
,
horn
-
blowing
contrivances
,
quite
beneath
the
dignity
of
men
,
and
only
suited
to
giddy
girls
that
did
nothing
but
chatter
and
go
a
-
shopping
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
know
nothing
about
coaches
here
,
sir
,
"
John
would
say
,
if
any
unlucky
stranger
made
inquiry
touching
the
offensive
vehicles
;
"
we
do
n't
book
for
'em
;
we
'd
<EOS>
rather
not
<EOS>
;
they
're
more
trouble
than
they
're
worth
,
with
their
noise
and
rattle
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
like
to
wait
for
'em
you
can
;
but
we
do
n't
know
anything
about
'em
;
they
may
call
and
they
may
not
---
there
's
a
carrier
<EOS>
---
he
was
looked
upon
as
quite
good
enough
for
us
,
when
I
was
a
boy
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
dropped
her
veil
as
Hugh
climbed
up
,
and
while
he
hung
behind
,
and
talked
to
Barnaby
in
whispers
.
 
<EOS>
But
neither
he
nor
any
other
person
spoke
to
her
,
or
noticed
her
,
or
had
any
curiosity
about
her
;
and
so
,
an
alien
,
she
visited
and
left
the
village
where
she
had
been
born
,
and
had
lived
a
merry
child
,
a
comely
girl
,
a
happy
wife
---
where
she
had
known
all
her
enjoyment
of
life
,
and
had
entered
on
its
hardest
sorrows
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
26
    
"
<EOS>
And
you
're
not
surprised
to
hear
this
,
Varden
?
"
said
Mr
Haredale
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
You
and
<EOS>
she
have
always
been
the
best
friends
,
and
you
should
understand
her
if
anybody
does
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ask
your
pardon
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
say
I
understood
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
the
presumption
to
say
that
of
any
woman
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
not
so
easily
done
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
so
much
surprised
,
sir
,
as
you
expected
me
to
be
,
certainly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
why
not
,
my
good
friend
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
with
evident
reluctance
,
"
I
have
seen
in
connection
with
her
,
something
that
has
filled
me
with
distrust
and
uneasiness
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
made
bad
friends
,
how
,
or
when
,
I
do
n't
know
;
but
that
her
house
is
a
refuge
for
one
robber
and
cut
-
throat
<EOS>
at
least
,
I
am
certain
.
 
<EOS>
There
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
Now
it
's
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Varden
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
own
eyes
,
sir
,
are
my
witnesses
,
and
for
her
sake
I
would
be
willingly
half
-
blind
,
if
I
could
but
have
the
pleasure
of
mistrusting
'em
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
kept
the
secret
till
now
,
and
it
will
go
no
further
than
yourself
,
I
know
;
but
I
tell
you
that
with
my
own
eyes
---
broad
awake
---
I
saw
,
in
the
passage
of
her
house
one
evening
after
dark
,
the
highwayman
who
robbed
and
wounded
Mr
Edward
Chester
,
and
on
the
same
night
threatened
me
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
you
made
no
effort
to
detain
him
?
"
said
Mr
Haredale
quickly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
,
"
she
herself
prevented
me
---
held
me
,
with
all
her
strength
,
and
hung
about
me
until
he
had
got
clear
off
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
having
gone
so
far
,
he
related
circumstantially
all
that
had
passed
upon
the
night
in
question
.
  
<EOS>
This
dialogue
was
held
in
a
low
tone
in
the
locksmith
's
little
parlour
,
into
which
honest
Gabriel
had
shown
his
visitor
on
his
arrival
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
had
called
upon
him
to
entreat
his
company
to
the
widow
's
,
that
he
might
have
the
assistance
of
his
persuasion
and
influence
;
and
out
of
this
circumstance
the
conversation
had
arisen
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
forbore
,
"
said
Gabriel
,
"
from
repeating
one
word
of
this
to
anybody
,
as
it
could
do
her
no
good
and
might
do
her
great
harm
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
and
hoped
,
to
say
the
truth
,
that
she
would
come
to
me
,
and
talk
to
me
about
it
,
and
tell
me
how
it
was
;
but
though
I
have
purposely
put
myself
in
her
way
more
than
once
or
twice
,
she
has
never
touched
upon
the
subject
---
except
by
a
look
.
 
<EOS>
And
indeed
,
"
said
the
good
-
natured
locksmith
,
"
there
was
a
good
deal
in
the
look
,
more
than
could
have
been
put
into
a
great
many
words
.
 
<EOS>
It
said
among
other
matters
"
Do
n't
ask
me
anything
"
so
imploringly
,
that
I
did
n't
ask
her
anything
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
think
me
an
old
fool
,
I
know
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
's
any
relief
to
call
me
one
,
pray
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
greatly
disturbed
by
what
you
tell
me
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
after
a
silence
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
meaning
do
you
attach
to
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
shook
his
head
,
and
looked
doubtfully
out
of
window
at
the
failing
light
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
can
not
have
married
again
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
without
our
knowledge
surely
,
sir
.
"
  
"
She
may
have
done
so
,
in
the
fear
that
it
would
lead
,
if
known
,
to
some
objection
or
estrangement
.
 
<EOS>
Suppose
she
married
incautiously
---
 
<EOS>
it
is
not
improbable
,
for
her
existence
has
been
a
lonely
and
monotonous
one
for
many
years
---
and
the
man
turned
out
a
ruffian
,
she
would
be
anxious
to
screen
him
,
and
yet
would
revolt
from
his
crimes
.
 
<EOS>
This
might
be
.
 
<EOS>
It
bears
strongly
on
the
whole
drift
of
her
discourse
yesterday
,
and
would
quite
explain
her
conduct
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
suppose
Barnaby
is
privy
to
these
circumstances
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
impossible
to
say
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
,
shaking
his
head
again
:
"
and
next
to
impossible
to
find
out
from
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
what
you
suppose
is
really
the
case
,
I
tremble
for
the
lad
---
a
notable
person
,
sir
,
to
put
to
bad
uses
---
"
  
"
It
is
not
possible
,
Varden
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
in
a
still
lower
tone
of
voice
than
he
had
spoken
yet
,
"
that
we
have
been
blinded
and
deceived
by
this
woman
from
the
beginning
?
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
possible
that
this
connection
was
formed
in
her
husband
's
lifetime
,
and
led
to
his
and
my
brother
's
---
"
  
"
Good
God
,
sir
,
"
cried
Gabriel
,
interrupting
him
,
"
do
n't
entertain
such
dark
thoughts
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
Five
-
and
-
twenty
years
ago
,
where
was
there
a
girl
like
her
?
 
<EOS>
A
gay
,
handsome
,
laughing
,
bright
-
eyed
damsel
!
 
<EOS>
Think
what
she
was
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
It
makes
my
heart
ache
now
,
even
now
,
though
I
'm
an
old
man
,
with
a
woman
for
a
daughter
,
to
think
what
she
was
and
what
she
is
.
 
<EOS>
We
all
change
,
but
that
's
with
Time
;
Time
does
his
work
honestly
,
and
I
do
n't
mind
him
.
 
<EOS>
A
fig
for
Time
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Use
him
well
,
and
he
's
a
hearty
fellow
,
and
scorns
to
have
you
at
a
disadvantage
.
 
<EOS>
But
care
and
suffering
(
and
those
have
changed
her
)
are
devils
,
sir
---
<EOS>
secret
,
stealthy
,
undermining
devils
---
 
who
tread
down
the
brightest
flowers
in
Eden
,
and
do
more
havoc
in
a
month
than
Time
does
in
a
year
.
 
<EOS>
Picture
to
yourself
for
one
minute
<EOS>
what
Mary
was
before
they
went
to
work
with
her
fresh
heart
and
face
<EOS>
---
do
her
that
justice
---
and
say
whether
such
a
thing
is
possible
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
good
fellow
,
Varden
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
and
are
quite
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
brooded
on
that
subject
<EOS>
so
long
,
that
every
breath
of
suspicion
carries
me
back
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
quite
right
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
n't
,
sir
,
"
cried
the
locksmith
with
brightened
eyes
,
and
sturdy
,
honest
voice
;
"
it
is
n't
because
I
courted
her
before
Rudge
,
and
failed
,
that
I
say
she
was
too
good
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
have
been
as
much
too
good
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
WAS
too
good
for
him
;
he
was
n't
free
and
frank
enough
for
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
reproach
his
memory
with
it
,
poor
fellow
;
I
only
want
to
put
her
before
you
as
she
really
was
.
 
<EOS>
For
myself
,
I
'll
keep
her
old
picture
in
my
mind
;
and
thinking
of
that
,
and
what
has
altered
her
,
I
'll
stand
her
friend
,
and
try
to
win
her
back
to
peace
.
 
<EOS>
And
damme
,
sir
,
"
cried
Gabriel
,
"
with
your
pardon
for
the
word
,
I
'd
do
the
same
if
she
had
married
fifty
highwaymen
in
a
twelvemonth
;
and
think
it
in
the
Protestant
Manual
too
,
though
Martha
said
it
was
n't
,
tooth
and
nail
,
till
doomsday
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
If
the
dark
little
parlour
had
been
filled
with
a
dense
fog
,
which
,
clearing
away
in
an
instant
,
left
it
all
radiance
and
brightness
,
it
could
not
have
been
more
suddenly
cheered
than
by
this
outbreak
on
the
part
of
the
hearty
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
voice
nearly
as
full
and
round
as
his
own
,
Mr
Haredale
cried
"
Well
said
!
<EOS>
"
and
bade
him
come
away
without
more
parley
.
 
<EOS>
The
locksmith
complied
right
willingly
;
and
both
getting
into
a
hackney
coach
which
was
waiting
at
the
door
,
drove
off
straightway
.
  
<EOS>
They
alighted
at
the
street
corner
,
and
dismissing
their
conveyance
,
walked
to
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
To
their
first
knock
at
the
door
there
was
no
response
.
 
<EOS>
A
second
met
with
the
like
result
.
 
<EOS>
But
in
answer
to
the
third
,
which
was
of
a
more
vigorous
kind
,
the
parlour
window
-
sash
was
gently
raised
,
and
a
musical
voice
cried
:
  
"
Haredale
,
my
dear
fellow
,
I
am
extremely
glad
to
see
you
.
 
<EOS>
How
very
much
you
have
improved
in
your
appearance
since
our
last
meeting
!
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
you
looking
better
.
 
<EOS>
HOW
do
you
do
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
turned
his
eyes
towards
the
casement
whence
the
voice
proceeded
,
though
there
was
no
need
to
do
so
,
to
recognise
the
speaker
,
and
Mr
Chester
waved
his
hand
,
and
smiled
a
courteous
welcome
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
door
will
be
opened
immediately
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
nobody
but
a
very
dilapidated
female
to
perform
such
offices
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
excuse
her
infirmities
?
 
<EOS>
If
she
were
in
a
more
elevated
station
of
society
,
she
would
be
gouty
.
 
<EOS>
Being
but
a
hewer
of
wood
and
drawer
of
water
,
she
is
rheumatic
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Haredale
,
these
are
natural
class
distinctions
,
depend
upon
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
,
whose
face
resumed
its
lowering
and
distrustful
look
the
moment
he
heard
the
voice
,
inclined
his
head
stiffly
,
and
turned
his
back
upon
the
speaker
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
opened
yet
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
hope
the
aged
soul
has
not
caught
her
foot
in
some
unlucky
cobweb
by
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
there
at
last
!
 
<EOS>
Come
in
,
I
beg
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
entered
,
followed
by
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
Turning
with
a
look
of
great
astonishment
to
the
old
woman
who
had
opened
the
door
,
he
inquired
for
Mrs
Rudge
---
for
Barnaby
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
both
gone
,
she
replied
,
wagging
her
ancient
head
,
for
good
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
gentleman
in
the
parlour
,
who
perhaps
could
tell
them
more
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
all
SHE
knew
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
presenting
himself
before
this
new
tenant
,
"
where
is
the
person
whom
I
came
here
to
see
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
friend
,
"
he
returned
,
"
I
have
not
the
least
idea
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
trifling
is
ill
-
timed
,
"
retorted
the
other
in
a
suppressed
tone
and
voice
,
"
and
its
subject
ill
-
chosen
.
 
<EOS>
Reserve
it
for
those
who
are
your
friends
,
and
do
not
expend
it
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
lay
no
claim
to
the
distinction
,
and
have
the
self
-
denial
to
reject
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
good
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
"
you
are
heated
with
walking
.
<EOS>
Sit
down
,
I
beg
.
 
<EOS>
Our
friend
is
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
Is
but
a
plain
honest
man
,
"
returned
Mr
Haredale
,
"
and
quite
unworthy
of
your
notice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gabriel
Varden
by
name
,
sir
<EOS>
,
"
said
the
locksmith
bluntly
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
worthy
English
yeoman
!
"
said
Mr
Chester
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
most
worthy
yeoman
,
of
whom
I
have
frequently
heard
my
son
Ned
---
darling
fellow
---
 
speak
,
and
have
often
wished
to
see
.
 
<EOS>
Varden
,
my
good
friend
<EOS>
,
I
am
glad
to
know
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
wonder
now
,
"
he
said
,
turning
languidly
to
Mr
Haredale
,
"
to
see
me
here
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
am
sure
you
do
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
glanced
at
him
---
not
fondly
or
admiringly
---
smiled
,
and
held
his
peace
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
mystery
is
solved
in
a
moment
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
;
"
in
a
moment
.
<EOS>
Will
you
step
aside
with
me
one
instant
.
 
<EOS>
You
remember
our
little
compact
in
reference
to
Ned
,
and
your
dear
niece
,
Haredale
?
 
<EOS>
You
remember
the
list
of
assistants
in
their
innocent
intrigue
?
 
<EOS>
You
remember
these
two
people
being
among
them
?
 
<EOS>
My
dear
fellow
,
congratulate
yourself
,
and
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
bought
them
off
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
done
what
?
"
said
Mr
Haredale
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bought
them
off
,
"
returned
his
smiling
friend
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
found
it
necessary
to
take
some
active
steps
towards
setting
this
boy
and
girl
attachment
quite
at
rest
,
and
have
begun
by
removing
these
two
agents
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
surprised
?
 
<EOS>
Who
CAN
withstand
the
influence
of
a
little
money
!
 
<EOS>
They
wanted
it
,
and
have
been
bought
off
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
nothing
more
to
fear
from
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
gone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gone
!
"
echoed
Mr
Haredale
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
fellow
---
and
you
must
permit
me
to
say
again
,
that
you
never
looked
so
young
;
so
positively
boyish
as
you
do
to
-
night
<EOS>
---
the
Lord
knows
where
;
I
believe
Columbus
himself
would
n't
find
them
.
<EOS>
Between
you
and
me
they
have
their
hidden
reasons
,
but
upon
that
point
I
have
pledged
myself
to
secrecy
.
 
<EOS>
She
appointed
to
see
you
here
to
-
night
,
I
know
,
but
found
it
inconvenient
,
and
could
n't
wait
.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
the
key
of
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
you
'll
find
it
inconveniently
large
;
but
as
the
tenement
is
yours
,
your
good
-
nature
will
excuse
that
,
Haredale
,
I
am
certain
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
27
    
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
stood
in
the
widow
's
parlour
with
the
door
-
key
in
his
hand
,
gazing
by
turns
at
Mr
Chester
and
at
Gabriel
Varden
,
and
occasionally
glancing
downward
at
the
key
as
in
the
hope
that
of
its
own
accord
it
would
unlock
the
mystery
;
until
Mr
Chester
,
putting
on
his
hat
and
gloves
,
and
sweetly
inquiring
whether
they
were
walking
in
the
same
direction
,
recalled
him
to
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Our
roads
diverge
---
<EOS>
widely
,
as
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
present
,
I
shall
remain
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
hipped
,
Haredale
;
you
will
be
miserable
,
<EOS>
melancholy
,
utterly
wretched
,
"
returned
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
place
of
the
very
last
description
for
a
man
of
your
temper
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
it
will
make
you
very
miserable
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
it
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
sitting
down
;
"
and
thrive
upon
the
thought
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Feigning
to
be
wholly
unconscious
of
the
abrupt
wave
of
the
hand
which
rendered
this
farewell
tantamount
to
a
dismissal
,
Mr
Chester
retorted
with
a
bland
and
heartfelt
benediction
,
and
inquired
of
Gabriel
in
what
direction
HE
was
going
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yours
,
sir
,
would
be
too
much
honour
for
the
like
of
me
,
"
replied
the
locksmith
,
hesitating
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
to
remain
here
a
little
while
,
Varden
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
without
looking
towards
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
word
or
two
to
say
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
intrude
upon
your
conference
another
moment
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
with
inconceivable
politeness
.
 
<EOS>
"
May
it
be
satisfactory
to
you
both
!
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
and
bestowing
upon
the
locksmith
a
most
refulgent
smile
,
he
left
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
deplorably
constituted
creature
,
that
rugged
person
<EOS>
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
walked
along
the
street
;
"
he
is
an
atrocity
that
carries
its
own
punishment
along
with
it
---
a
bear
that
gnaws
himself
.
 
<EOS>
And
here
is
one
of
the
inestimable
advantages
of
having
a
perfect
command
over
one
's
inclinations
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
tempted
in
these
two
short
interviews
,
to
draw
upon
that
fellow
,
fifty
times
.
 
<EOS>
Five
men
in
six
would
have
yielded
to
the
impulse
.
 
<EOS>
By
suppressing
mine
,
I
wound
him
deeper
and
more
keenly
than
if
I
were
the
best
swordsman
in
all
Europe
,
and
he
the
worst
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
the
wise
man
's
very
last
resource
,
"
he
said
,
tapping
the
hilt
of
his
weapon
;
"
we
can
but
appeal
to
you
when
all
else
is
said
and
done
.
 
<EOS>
To
come
to
you
before
,
and
thereby
spare
our
adversaries
so
much
,
is
a
barbarian
mode
of
warfare
,
quite
unworthy
of
any
man
with
the
remotest
pretensions
to
delicacy
of
feeling
,
or
refinement
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
smiled
so
very
pleasantly
as
he
communed
with
himself
after
this
manner
,
that
a
beggar
was
emboldened
to
follow
for
alms
,
and
to
dog
his
footsteps
for
some
distance
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
gratified
by
the
circumstance
,
feeling
it
complimentary
to
his
power
of
feature
,
and
as
a
reward
suffered
the
man
to
follow
him
until
he
called
a
chair
,
when
he
graciously
dismissed
him
with
a
fervent
blessing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Which
is
as
easy
as
cursing
,
"
he
wisely
added
,
as
he
took
his
seat
,
"
and
more
becoming
to
the
face
.
<EOS>
---
To
Clerkenwell
,
my
good
creatures
,
if
you
please
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
chairmen
were
rendered
quite
vivacious
by
having
such
a
courteous
burden
,
and
to
Clerkenwell
they
went
at
a
fair
round
trot
.
  
<EOS>
Alighting
at
a
certain
point
he
had
indicated
to
them
upon
the
road
,
and
paying
them
something
less
than
they
expected
from
a
fare
of
such
gentle
speech
,
he
turned
into
the
street
in
which
the
locksmith
dwelt
,
and
presently
stood
beneath
the
shadow
of
the
Golden
Key
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
,
who
was
hard
at
work
by
lamplight
,
in
a
corner
of
the
workshop
,
remained
unconscious
of
his
presence
until
a
hand
upon
his
shoulder
made
him
start
and
turn
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Industry
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
"
is
the
soul
of
business
,
and
the
keystone
of
prosperity
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
,
I
shall
expect
you
to
invite
me
to
dinner
when
you
are
Lord
Mayor
of
London
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
returned
the
'
prentice
,
laying
down
his
hammer
,
and
rubbing
his
nose
on
the
back
of
a
very
sooty
hand
,
"
I
scorn
the
Lord
Mayor
and
everything
that
belongs
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
have
another
state
of
society
,
sir
,
before
you
catch
me
being
Lord
Mayor
.
 
<EOS>
How
de
do
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
better
,
Mr
Tappertit
,
for
looking
into
your
ingenuous
face
once
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
are
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
as
well
,
sir
,
"
said
Sim
,
standing
up
to
get
nearer
to
his
ear
,
and
whispering
hoarsely
,
"
as
any
man
can
be
under
the
aggrawations
to
which
I
am
exposed
.
 
<EOS>
My
life
's
a
burden
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
was
n't
for
wengeance
,
I
'd
play
at
pitch
and
toss
with
it
on
the
losing
hazard
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
Mrs
Varden
at
home
?
"
said
Mr
Chester
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
returned
Sim
,
eyeing
him
over
with
a
look
of
concentrated
expression
,
---
"
she
is
.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
wish
to
see
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Chester
nodded
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
come
this
way
,
sir
,
"
said
Sim
,
wiping
his
face
upon
his
apron
.
 
<EOS>
"
Follow
me
,
sir
.
---
Would
you
permit
me
to
whisper
in
your
ear
,
one
half
a
second
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
all
means
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
raised
himself
on
tiptoe
,
applied
his
lips
to
Mr
Chester
's
ear
,
drew
back
his
head
without
saying
anything
,
looked
hard
at
him
,
applied
them
to
his
ear
again
,
again
drew
back
,
and
finally
whispered
---
"
<EOS>
The
name
is
Joseph
Willet
.
 
<EOS>
Hush
!
 
<EOS>
I
say
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Having
said
that
much
,
he
beckoned
the
visitor
with
a
mysterious
aspect
to
follow
him
to
the
parlour
-
door
,
where
he
announced
him
in
the

of
a
gentleman
-

.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Chester
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
not
Mr
Ed'dard
,
mind
<EOS>
,
"
said
Sim
,
looking
into
the
door
again
,
and
adding
this
by

postscript
in
his
own

;
"
it
's
his
father
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
do
not
let
his
father
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
advancing
hat
in
hand
,
as
he
observed
the
effect
of
this
last
explanatory
announcement
<EOS>
,
"
do
not
let
his
father
be
any
check
or

on
your

,
Miss
Varden
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Now
!
 
<EOS>
There
!
 
<EOS>
An't
<EOS>
I
always
a
-
saying
it
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Miggs
,
clapping

.
 
<EOS>
"
If
he
an't
been
and
took
Missis
for
her
own
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
she
DO
look
like
it
,
that

.
 
<EOS>
Only

,
mim
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

,
"
said
Mr
Chester
in

,
"
that
this

Mrs
Varden
!
 
<EOS>
I
am

.
 
<EOS>
That
is
not
your
daughter
,
Mrs
Varden
?
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
Your
sister
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
daughter
,
indeed
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mrs
V
,
blushing
with
great

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Mrs
Varden
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
visitor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
ma'am
---
humanity
is
indeed
a
happy
lot
,
when
we
can
repeat
ourselves
in
others
,
and
still
be
young
as
they
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
allow
me
to
salute
you
---
the
custom
of
the
country
,
my
dear
madam
---
your
daughter
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Dolly
showed
some
reluctance
to
perform
this
ceremony
,
but
was
sharply
reproved
by
Mrs
Varden
,
who
insisted
on
her
undergoing
it
that
minute
.
 
<EOS>
For
pride
,
she
said
with
great
severity
,
was
one
of
the
seven
deadly
sins
,
and
humility
and
lowliness
of
heart
were
virtues
.
 
<EOS>
Wherefore
<EOS>
she
desired
that
Dolly
would
be
kissed
immediately
,
on
pain
of
her
just
displeasure
;
at
the
same
time
giving
her
to
understand
that
whatever
she
saw
her
mother
do
,
she
might
safely
do
herself
,
without
being
at
the
trouble
of
any
reasoning
or
reflection
on
the
subject
---
which
,
indeed
,
was
offensive
and
undutiful
,
and
in
direct
contravention
of
the
church
catechism
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
admonished
,
Dolly
complied
,
though
by
no
means
willingly
;
for
there
was
a
broad
,
bold
look
of
admiration
in
Mr
Chester
's
face
,
refined
and
polished
though
it
sought
to
be
,
which
distressed
her
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
As
she
stood
with
downcast
eyes
,
not
liking
to
look
up
and
meet
his
,
he
gazed
upon
her
with
an
approving
air
,
and
then
turned
to
her
mother
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
friend
Gabriel
(
whose
acquaintance
I
only
made
this
very
evening
)
should
be
a
happy
man
,
Mrs
Varden
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ah
!
"
sighed
Mrs
V
,
shaking
her
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
echoed
Miggs
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
the
case
?
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
compassionately
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Master
has
no
intentions
,
sir
,
"
murmured
Miggs
as
she
sidled
up
to
him
,
"
but
to
be
as
grateful
as
his
natur
will
let
him
,
for
everythink
he
owns
which
it
is
in
his
powers
to
appreciate
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
never
,
sir
"
---
said
Miggs
,
<EOS>
looking
sideways
at
Mrs
Varden
,
and
interlarding
her
discourse
with
a
sigh
---
"
we
never
know
the
full
value
of
SOME
wines
and
fig
-
trees
till
we
lose
'em
.
 
<EOS>
So
much
the
worse
,
sir
,
for
them
as
has
the
slighting
of
'em
on
their
consciences
when
they
're
gone
to
be
in
full
blow
elsewhere
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
Miss
Miggs
cast
up
her
eyes
to
signify
where
that
might
be
.
  
<EOS>
As
Mrs
Varden
distinctly
heard
,
and
was
intended
to
hear
,
all
that
Miggs
said
,
and
as
these
words
appeared
to
convey
in
metaphorical
terms
a
presage
or
foreboding
that
she
would
at
some
early
period
droop
beneath
her
trials
and
take
an
easy
flight
towards
the
stars
,
she
immediately
began
to
languish
,
and
taking
a
volume
of
the
Manual
from
a
neighbouring
table
,
leant
her
arm
upon
it
as
though
she
were
Hope
and
that
her
Anchor
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chester
perceiving
this
,
and
seeing
how
the
volume
was
lettered
on
the
back
,
took
it
gently
from
her
hand
,
and
turned
the
fluttering
leaves
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
favourite
book
,
dear
madam
.
 
<EOS>
How
often
,
how
very
often
in
his
early
life
---
before
he
can
remember
"
---
(
this
clause
was
strictly
true
)
"
have
I
deduced
little
easy
moral
lessons
from
its
pages
,
for
my
dear
son
Ned
!
 
<EOS>
You
know
Ned
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
had
that
honour
,
and
a
fine
affable
young
gentleman
he
was
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
mother
,
Mrs
Varden
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
taking
a
pinch
of
snuff
,
"
and
you
know
what
I
,
as
a
father
,
feel
,
when
he
is
praised
.
<EOS>
He
gives
me
some
uneasiness
---
much
uneasiness
<EOS>
---
he
's
of
a
roving
nature
,
ma'am
---
from
flower
to
flower
---
from
sweet
to
sweet
---
but
his
is
the
butterfly
time
of
life
,
and
we
must
not
be
hard
upon
such
trifling
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
glanced
at
Dolly
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
attending
evidently
to
what
he
said
.
<EOS>
Just
what
he
desired
!
  
<EOS>
"
The
only
thing
I
object
to
in
this
little
trait
of
Ned
's
,
is
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
"
---
and
the
mention
of
his
name
reminds
me
,
by
the
way
,
that
I
am
about
to
beg
the
favour
of
a
minute
's
talk
with
you
alone
---
<EOS>
the
only
thing
I
object
to
in
it
,
is
,
that
it
DOES
partake
of
insincerity
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
however
I
may
attempt
to
disguise
the
fact
from
myself
in
my
affection
for
Ned
,
still
I
always
revert
to
this
---
 
<EOS>
that
if
we
are
not
sincere
,
we
are
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
upon
earth
.
<EOS>
Let
us
be
sincere
,
my
dear
madam
---
"
  
"
---
and
Protestant
,
"
murmured
Mrs
Varden
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
and
Protestant
above
all
things
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
be
sincere
and
Protestant
,
strictly
moral
,
strictly
just
(
though
always
with
a
leaning
towards
mercy
)
,
strictly
honest
,
and
strictly
true
,
and
we
gain
---
it
is
a
slight
point
,
certainly
,
but
still
it
is
something
tangible
;
we
throw
up
a
groundwork
and
foundation
,
so
to
speak
,
of
goodness
,
on
which
we
may
afterwards
erect
some
worthy
superstructure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Now
,
to
be
sure
,
Mrs
Varden
thought
,
here
is
a
perfect
character
.
<EOS>
Here
is
a
meek
,
righteous
,
thoroughgoing
Christian
,
who
,
having
mastered
all
these
qualities
,
so
difficult
of
attainment
;
who
,
having
dropped
a
pinch
of
salt
on
the
tails
of
all
the
cardinal
virtues
,
and
caught
them
every
one
;
makes
light
of
their
possession
,
and
pants
for
more
morality
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
good
woman
never
doubted
(
as
many
good
men
and
women
never
do
)
,
that
this
slighting
kind
of
profession
,
this
setting
so
little
store
by
great
matters
,
this
seeming
to
say
,
"
I
am
not
proud
,
I
am
what
you
hear
,
but
I
consider
myself
no
better
than
other
people
;
let
us
change
the
subject
,
pray
"
---
was
perfectly
genuine
and
true
.
 
<EOS>
He
so
contrived
it
,
and
said
it
in
that
way
that
it
appeared
to
have
been
forced
from
him
,
and
its
effect
was
marvellous
.
  
<EOS>
Aware
of
the
impression
he
had
made
---
few
men
were
quicker
than
he
at
such
discoveries
---
Mr
Chester
followed
up
the
blow
by
propounding
certain
virtuous
maxims
,
somewhat
vague
and
general
in
their
nature
,
doubtless
,
and
occasionally
partaking
of
the
character
of
truisms
,
worn
a
little
out
at
elbow
,
but
delivered
in
so
charming
a
voice
and
with
such
uncommon
serenity
and
peace
of
mind
,
that
they
answered
as
well
as
the
best
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
is
this
to
be
wondered
at
;
for
as
hollow
vessels
produce
a
far
more
musical
sound
in
falling
than
those
which
are
substantial
,
so
it
will
oftentimes
be
found
that
sentiments
which
have
nothing
in
them
make
the
loudest
ringing
in
the
world
,
and
are
the
most
relished
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Chester
,
with
the
volume
gently
extended
in
one
hand
,
and
with
the
other
planted
lightly
on
his
breast
,
talked
to
them
in
the
most
delicious
manner
possible
;
and
quite
enchanted
all
his
hearers
,
notwithstanding
their
conflicting
interests
and
thoughts
.
 
<EOS>
Even
Dolly
,
who
,
between
his
keen
regards
and
her
eyeing
over
by
Mr
Tappertit
,
was
put
quite
out
of
countenance
,
could
not
help
owning
within
herself
that
he
was
the
sweetest
-
spoken
gentleman
she
had
ever
seen
.
 
<EOS>
Even
Miss
Miggs
,
who
was
divided
between
admiration
of
Mr
Chester
and
a
mortal
jealousy
of
her
young
mistress
,
had
sufficient
leisure
to
be
propitiated
.
 
<EOS>
Even
Mr
Tappertit
,
though
occupied
as
we
have
seen
in
gazing
at
his
heart
's
delight
,
could
not
wholly
divert
his
thoughts
from
the
voice
of
the
other
charmer
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
,
to
her
own
private
thinking
,
had
never
been
so
improved
in
all
her
life
;
and
when
Mr
Chester
,
rising
and
craving
permission
to
speak
with
her
apart
,
took
her
by
the
hand
and
led
her
at
arm
's
length
upstairs
to
the
best
sitting
-
room
<EOS>
,
she
almost
deemed
him
something
more
than
human
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
madam
,
"
he
said
,
pressing
her
hand
delicately
to
his
lips
;
"
be
seated
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
called
up
quite
a
courtly
air
,
and
became
seated
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
guess
my
object
?
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
drawing
a
chair
towards
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
divine
my
purpose
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
an
affectionate
parent
,
my
dear
Mrs
Varden
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
I
am
sure
you
are
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
V.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
returned
Mr
Chester
,
tapping
his
snuff
-
box
lid
.
<EOS>
"
Heavy
moral
responsibilities
rest
with
parents
,
Mrs
Varden
.
"
  
Mrs
Varden
slightly
raised
her
hands
,
shook
her
head
,
and
looked
at
the
ground
as
though
she
saw
straight
through
the
globe
,
out
at
the
other
end
,
and
into
the
immensity
of
space
beyond
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
may
confide
in
you
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
"
without
reserve
.
 
<EOS>
I
love
my
son
,
ma'am
,
dearly
;
and
loving
him
as
I
do
,
I
would
save
him
from
working
certain
misery
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
of
his
attachment
to
Miss
Haredale
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
abetted
him
in
it
,
and
very
kind
of
you
<EOS>
it
was
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
deeply
obliged
to
you
---
most
deeply
obliged
to
you
---
 
for
your
interest
in
his
behalf
;
but
my
dear
ma'am
,
it
is
a
mistaken
one
,
I
do
assure
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
stammered
that
she
was
sorry
---
"
  
"
Sorry
,
my
dear
ma'am
,
"
he
interposed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
be
sorry
for
what
is
so
very
amiable
,
so
very
good
in
intention
,
so
perfectly
like
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
are
grave
and
weighty
reasons
,
pressing
family
considerations
,
and
apart
even
from
these
,
points
of
religious
difference
,
which
interpose

,
and
render
their
union
impossible
;
utterly
im
-
possible
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
mentioned
these
circumstances
to
your
husband
;
but
he
has
---
you
will
excuse
my
saying
this
so
freely
---
he
has
NOT
your
quickness
of
apprehension
or
depth
of
moral
sense
.
 
<EOS>
What
an
extremely
airy
house
this
is
,
and
how
beautifully
kept
!
 
<EOS>
For
one
like
myself
---
a
widower
so
long
---
 
these
tokens
of
female
care
and
superintendence
have
inexpressible
charms
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
began
to
think
(
she
scarcely
knew
why
)
that
the
young
Mr
Chester
must
be
in
the
wrong
and
the
old
Mr
Chester
must
he
in
the
right
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
son
Ned
,
"
resumed
her
tempter
with
his
most
winning
air
,
"
has
had
,
I
am
told
,
your
lovely
daughter
's
aid
,
and
your
open
-
hearted
husband
's
.
"
  
"
---
Much
more
than
mine
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Varden
;
"
a
great
deal
more
.
<EOS>
I
have
often
had
my
doubts
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
---
"
  
"
A
bad
example
,
"
suggested
Mr
Chester
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
.
 
<EOS>
No
doubt
it
is
.
<EOS>
Your
daughter
is
at
that
age
when
to
set
before
her
an
encouragement
for
young
persons
to
rebel
against
their
parents
on
this
most
important
point
,
is
particularly
injudicious
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
quite
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
ought
to
have
thought
of
that
myself
,
but
it
escaped
me
<EOS>
,
I
confess
---
so
far
superior
are
your
sex
to
ours
,
<EOS>
dear
madam
,
in
point
of
penetration
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
looked
as
wise
as
if
she
had
really
said
something
to
deserve
this
compliment
---
firmly
believed
she
had
,
in
short
---
and
her
faith
in
her
own

increased
considerably
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
ma'am
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
"
you
embolden
me
to
be
plain
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
My
son
and
I
are
at
variance
on
this
point
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
lady
and
her
natural
guardian
differ
upon
it
,
also
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
closing
point
is
,
that
my
son
is
bound
by
his

to
me
,
by
his

,
by
every
