tie
and

,
to

some

else
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Engaged
to
marry
another
lady
!
"
<EOS>
quoth
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
,
holding
up
her
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
madam
,
brought
up
,
educated
,
and
trained
,
expressly
for
that
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
Expressly
for
that
purpose
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Miss
Haredale
,
I
am
told
,
is
a
very
charming
creature
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
her
foster
-
mother
,
and
should
know
---
the
best
young
lady
in
the
world
,
"
said
Mrs
Varden
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
the
smallest
doubt
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
she
is
.
 
<EOS>
And
you
,
who
have
stood
in
that
tender
relation
towards
her
,
are
bound
to
consult
her
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
can
I
---
as
I
have
said
to
Haredale
,
who
quite
agrees
---
can
I
possibly
stand
by
,
and
suffer
her
to
throw
herself
away
(
although
she
IS
of
a
Catholic
family
)
<EOS>
,
upon
a
young
fellow
who
,
as
yet
,
has
no
heart
at
all
?
 
<EOS>
It
is
no
imputation
upon
him
to
say
he
has
not
,
because
young
men
who
have
plunged
deeply
into
the
frivolities
and
conventionalities
of
society
,
very
seldom
have
.
 
<EOS>
Their
hearts
never
grow
,
my
dear
ma'am
,
till
after
thirty
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
believe
,
<EOS>
no
,
I
do
NOT

,
that
I
had
any
heart
myself
when
I
was
Ned
's
age
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

,
"
said
Mrs
Varden
,
"
I
think

must
have
had
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
impossible
that
you
,
who
have
so
much
now
,
can

without

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

,
"
I

a

;
I

,
a

---

!
 
<EOS>
But

;
I

thought
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
How

!
 
<EOS>
My

,
I

---
to

---

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
was
perfectly
aghast

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
,
if
he
honourably

---

,

,
or
he
is
no

---
a

.
 
<EOS>
He
is
of
most
expensive
,
ruinously

;
and

,

,

,

---
<EOS>

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
,

,
<EOS>

,

---

?
 
<EOS>
Is

?
 
<EOS>
Ask

own
,
my

.
 
<EOS>
Ask

own
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Truly
,
"
thought
Mrs
Varden
,
"
this

is
a

.
 
<EOS>
But
,
"
she

,

,
"

Miss
Emma
's
lover
away
,
sir
,
what
becomes
of
the
poor
thing
's

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
very
point
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
not
at

,
"
to
which
I
wished

.
 
<EOS>
A

with
my
son
,
whom
I

compelled

,
would
be
followed
by
years

;

would

,
my

,
in
a

.
 
<EOS>
To
break

this
attachment
,
which
is
more

than

,
as
you
and
I
know

,
will
cost
the
dear
girl
but

,
and
she
is
happy
again
.
 
<EOS>
Take
the
case
of
your
own
daughter
,
the
young
lady
downstairs
,
who
is
your
breathing
image
"
---
Mrs
Varden
coughed
and
simpered
---
"
there
is
a
young
man
(
I
am
sorry
to
say
,
a
dissolute
fellow
,
of
very
indifferent

)
of
whom
I
have
heard
Ned
speak
<EOS>
---
Bullet
was
it
---
Pullet
---
Mullet
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
There
is
a
young
man
of
the
name
of
Joseph
Willet
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Varden
,
folding

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
he
,
"
cried
Mr
Chester
.
 
<EOS>
"
Suppose
this
Joseph
Willet
now
,
were
to
aspire
to

affections
of
your
charming
daughter
,
and
were
to
engage

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
like

,
"
interposed
Mrs
Varden
,
bridling
,
"
to

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,
that
's

.
 
<EOS>
I

would
be

.
 
<EOS>
It
is

Ned
's

to

he

;
but
you
would
not
on

,
or
because

a
few

from
your

daughter
,
refrain

checking
their

in

.
 
<EOS>
I
meant
to
have
reasoned
thus
with
your
husband
when
I
saw
him
at
Mrs
Rudge
's
this

---
"
  
"
My
husband
,
"
said
Mrs
Varden
,

with

,
"
would
be
a
great
deal
better
at
home
than
going
to
Mrs
Rudge
's
so

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
he

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't

what
occasion

has
to

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

,
"
returned
Mr
Chester
,
"
quite
so
strongly
as
you
might
desire
,
it
is
because
his
being
there
,
my
dear
madam
,
and
not
proving
conversational
,
led
me
hither
,
and
procured
me
the
happiness
of
this
interview
with
one
,
in
whom
the
whole
management
,
conduct
,
and
prosperity
of
her
family
are
centred
,
I
perceive
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
he
took
Mrs
Varden
's
hand
again
,
and
having
pressed
it
to
his
lips
with
the
highflown
gallantry
of
the
day
---
a
little
burlesqued
to
render
it
the
more
striking
in
the
good
lady
's
unaccustomed
eyes
---
proceeded
in
the
same
strain
of
mingled
sophistry
,
cajolery
,
and
flattery
,
to
entreat
that
her
utmost

might

to
restrain

and

from

promotion
of
Edward
's
suit
to
Miss
Haredale
,
and
from
aiding
or
abetting
either
party
in
any
way
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
was
but
a
woman
,
and
had
her
share
of
vanity
,
obstinacy
,
and
love
of
power
.
 
<EOS>
She
entered
into
a
secret
treaty
of
alliance
,
offensive
and
defensive
,
with
her
insinuating
visitor
;
and
really
did
believe
,
as
many
others
would
have
done
who
saw

heard

,
that
in
so
doing
she
furthered
the
ends
of
truth
,
justice
,
and
morality
,
in
a
very
uncommon
degree
.
  
<EOS>
Overjoyed
by
the
success
of
his

,
and
mightily

within

,
Mr
Chester
conducted

in

and

,
by

if
"
this
young
lady
"
would

to
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
mim
,
"
said

,
returning

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh

me
,
mim
,
there
's
a

!
 
<EOS>
Was

such

angel

---

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

---
Oh

!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs

<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
For

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
of

!
"
  
<EOS>
What
a
very
uncertain

<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
's

!
    
<EOS>
Chapter
28
    
Repairing
to
a
noted
coffee
-
house
in
Covent
Garden
<EOS>
when
he
left
the
locksmith
's
,
Mr
Chester
sat
long
over
a
late
dinner
,
entertaining
himself
exceedingly
with
the
whimsical
recollection
of
his
recent
proceedings
,
and
congratulating
himself
very
much
on
his
great
cleverness
.
 
<EOS>
Influenced
by
these
thoughts
,
his
face
wore
an
expression
so
benign
and
tranquil
,
that
the
waiter
in
immediate
attendance
upon
him
felt
he
could
almost
have
died
in
his
defence
,
and
settled
in
his
own
mind
(
until
the
receipt
of
the
bill
,
and
a
very
small
fee
for
very
great
trouble
disabused
it
of
the
idea
)
that
such
an
apostolic
customer
was
worth
half
-
a
-
dozen
of
the
ordinary
run
of
visitors
,
at
least
.
  
<EOS>
A
visit
to
the
gaming
-
table
---
not
as
a
heated
,
anxious
venturer
,
but
one
whom
it
was
quite
a
treat
to
see
staking
his
two
or
three
pieces
in
deference
to
the
follies
of
society
,
and
smiling
with
equal
benevolence
on
winners
and
losers
---
made
it
late
before
he
reached
home
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
his
custom
to
bid
his
servant
<EOS>
go
to
bed
at
his
own
time
unless
he
had
orders
to
the
contrary
,
and
to
leave
a
candle
on
the
common
stair
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
lamp
on
the
landing
by
which
he
could
always
light
it
when
he
came
home
late
,
and
having
a
key
of
the
door
about
him
he
could
enter
and
go
to
bed
at
his
pleasure
.
  
<EOS>
He
opened
the
glass
of
the
dull
lamp
,
whose
wick
,
burnt
up
and
swollen
like
a
drunkard
's
nose
,
came
flying
off
in
little
carbuncles
at
the
candle
's
touch
,
and
scattering
hot
sparks
about
,
rendered
it
matter
of
some
difficulty
to
kindle
the
lazy
taper
;
when
a
noise
,
as
of
a
man
snoring
deeply
some
steps
higher
up
,
caused
him
to
pause
and
listen
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
heavy
breathing
of
a
sleeper
,
close
at
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Some
fellow
had
lain
down
on
the
open
staircase
,
and
was
slumbering
soundly
.
 
<EOS>
Having
lighted
the
candle
at
length
and
opened
his
own
door
,
he
softly
ascended
,
holding
the
taper
high
above
his
head
,
and
peering
cautiously
about
;
curious
to
see
what
kind
of
man
had
chosen
so
comfortless
a
shelter
for
his
lodging
.
  
<EOS>
With
his
head
upon
the
landing
and
his
great
limbs
flung
over
half
-
a
-
dozen
stairs
,
as
carelessly
as
though
he
were
a
dead
man
whom
drunken
bearers
had
thrown
down
by
chance
,
there
lay
Hugh
,
face
uppermost
,
his
long
hair
drooping
like
some
wild
weed
upon
his
wooden
pillow
,
and
his
huge
chest
heaving
with
the
sounds
which
so
unwontedly
disturbed
the
place
and
hour
.
  
<EOS>
He
who
came
upon
him
so
unexpectedly
was
about
to
break
his
rest
by
thrusting
him
with
his
foot
,
when
,
glancing
at
his
upturned
face
,
he
arrested
himself
in
the
very
action
,
and
stooping
down
and
shading
the
candle
with
his
hand
,
examined

features
closely
.
<EOS>
Close
as
his
first
inspection
was
,
it
did
not

,
for
he
passed
the
light
,
still
carefully
shaded
as
before
,
across
and
across
his
face
,
and
yet
observed
him
with
a

.
  
<EOS>
While
he
was
thus
engaged
,
the
sleeper
,
without
any

or

round
,
awoke
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
kind

fascination
in
meeting
his
steady

so
suddenly
,
which
took
from
the
other
the

to

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
So

,

Chester
at

,

,
why

.
  
<EOS>

I

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
the
grounds
before
the
house
.
<EOS>
---
Them
that
the
footpath
crosses
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
If
the
weather
should
be
fine
,
I
may
throw
myself
in
her
way
to
-
morrow
,
perhaps
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
as
coolly
as
if
she
were
one
of
his
ordinary
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Hugh
,
if
I
should
ride
up
to
the
Maypole
door
,
you
will
do
me
the
favour
only
to
have
seen
me
once
.
<EOS>
You
must
suppress
your
gratitude
,
and
endeavour
to
forget
my
forbearance
in
the
matter
of
the
bracelet
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
natural
it
should
break
out
,
and
it
does
you
honour
;
but
when
other
folks
are
by
,
you
must
,
for
your
own
sake
and
safety
,
be
as
like
your
usual
self
as
though
you
owed
me
no
obligation
whatever
,
and
had
never
stood
within
these
walls
.
 
<EOS>
You
comprehend
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
understood
him
perfectly
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
pause
he
muttered
that
he
hoped
his
patron
would
involve
him
in
no
trouble
about
this
last
letter
;
for
he
had
kept
it
back
solely
with
the
view
of
pleasing
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
continuing
in
this
strain
,
when
Mr
Chester
with
a
most
beneficent
and
patronising
air
cut
him
short
by
saying
:
  
"
My
good
fellow
,
you
have
my
promise
,
my
word
,
my
sealed
bond
(
for
a
verbal
pledge
with
me
is
quite
as
good
)
,
that
I
will
always
protect
you
so
long
as
you
deserve
it
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
do
set
your
mind
at
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
it
at
ease
,
I
beg
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
When
a
man
puts
himself
in
my
power
so
thoroughly
as
you
have
done
,
I
really
feel
as
though
he
had
a
kind
of
claim
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
more
disposed
to
mercy
and
forbearance
under
such
circumstances
than
I
can
tell
you
,
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
Do
look
upon
me
as
your
protector
,
and
rest
assured
<EOS>
,
I
entreat
you
,
that
on
the
subject
of
that
indiscretion
,
you
may
preserve
,
as
long
as
you
and
I
are
friends
,
the
lightest
heart
that
ever
beat
within
a
human
breast
.
 
<EOS>
Fill
that
glass
once
more
to
cheer
you
on
your
road
homewards
---
I
am
really
quite
ashamed
to
think
how
far
you
have
to
go
---
and
then
God
bless
you
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
They
think
,
"
said
Hugh
,
when
he
had
tossed
the
liquor
down
,
"
that
I
am
sleeping
soundly
in
the
stable
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
The
stable
door
is
shut
,
but
the
steed
's
gone
,
master
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
most
convivial
fellow
,
"
returned
his
friend
,
"
and
I
love
your
humour
of
all
things
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
!
 
<EOS>
Take
the
greatest
possible
care
of
yourself
,
for
my
sake
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
remarkable
that
during
the
whole
interview
,
each
had
endeavoured
to
catch
stolen
glances
of
the
other
's
face
,
and
had
never
looked
full
at
it
.
 
<EOS>
They
interchanged
one
brief
and
hasty
glance
as
Hugh
went
out
,
averted
their
eyes
directly
,
and
so
separated
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
closed
the
double
doors
behind
him
,
carefully
and
without
noise
;
and
Mr
Chester
remained
in
his
easy
-
chair
,
with
his
gaze
intently
fixed
upon
the
fire
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
after
meditating
for
a
long
time
---
and
said
with
a
deep
sigh
and
an
uneasy
shifting
of
his
attitude
,
as
though
he
dismissed
some
other
subject
from
his
thoughts
,
and
returned
to
that
which
had
held
possession
of
them
all
the
day
---
the
plot
thickens
;
I
have
thrown
the
shell
;
it
will
explode
,
I
think
,
in
eight
-
and
-
forty
hours
,
and
should
scatter
these
good
folks
amazingly
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
see
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
went
to
bed
and
fell
asleep
,
but
had
not
slept
long
when
he
started
up
and
thought
that
Hugh
was
at
the
outer
door
,
calling
in
a
strange
voice
,
very
different
from
his
own
,
to
be
admitted
.
 
<EOS>
The
delusion
was
so
strong
upon
him
,
and
was
so
full
of
that
vague
terror
of
the
night
in
which
such
visions
have
their
being
,
that
he
rose
,
and
taking
his
sheathed
sword
in
his
hand
,
opened
the
door
,
and
looked
out
upon
the
staircase
,
and
towards
the
spot
where
Hugh
had
lain
asleep
;
and
even
spoke
to
him
by
name
.
 
<EOS>
But
all
was
dark
and
quiet
,
and
creeping
back
to
bed
again
<EOS>
,
he
fell
,
after
an
hour
's
uneasy
watching
,
into
a
second
sleep
,
and
woke
no
more
till
morning
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
29
    
<EOS>
The
thoughts
of
worldly
men
are
for
ever
regulated
by
a
moral
law
of
gravitation
,
which
,
like
the
physical
one
,
holds
them
down
to
earth
.
 
<EOS>
The
bright
glory
of
day
,
and
the
silent
wonders
of
a
starlit
night
<EOS>
,
appeal
to
their
minds
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
no
signs
in
the
sun
,
or
in
the
moon
,
or
in
the
stars
,
for
their
reading
.
<EOS>
They
are
like
some
wise
men
,
who
,
learning
to
know
each
planet
by
its
Latin
name
,
have
quite
forgotten
such
small
heavenly
constellations
as
Charity
,
Forbearance
,
Universal
Love
,
and
Mercy
,
although
they
shine
by
night
and
day
so
brightly
that
the
blind
may
see
them
;
and
who
,
looking
upward
at
the
spangled
sky
,
see
nothing
there
<EOS>
but
the
reflection
of
their
own
great
wisdom
and
book
-
learning
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
curious
to
imagine
these
people
of
the
world
,
busy
in
thought
,
turning
their
eyes
towards
the
countless
spheres
that
shine
above
us
,
and
making
them
reflect
the
only
images
their
minds
contain
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
who
lives
<EOS>
but
in
the
breath
of
princes
,
has
nothing
his
sight
but
stars
for
courtiers
'
breasts
.
 
<EOS>
The
envious
man
beholds
his
neighbours
'
honours
even
in
the
sky
;
to
the
money
-
hoarder
,
and
the
mass
of
worldly
folk
,
the
whole
great
universe
above
glitters
with
sterling
coin
---
fresh
from
the
mint
---
stamped
with
the
sovereign
's
head
---
coming
always
between
them
and
heaven
,
turn
where
they
may
.
 
<EOS>
So
do
the
shadows
of
our
own
desires
stand
between
us
and
our
better
angels
,
and
thus
their
brightness
is
eclipsed
.
  
<EOS>
Everything
was
fresh
and
gay
,
as
though
the
world
were
but
that
morning
made
,
when
Mr
Chester
rode
at
a
tranquil
pace
along
the
Forest
road
.
 
<EOS>
Though
early
in
the
season
,
it
was
warm
and
genial
weather
;
the
trees
were
budding
into
leaf
,
the
hedges
and
the
grass
were
green
,
the
air
was
musical
with
songs
of
birds
,
and
high
above
them
<EOS>
all
the
lark
poured
out
her
richest
melody
.
 
<EOS>
In
shady
spots
,
the
morning
dew
sparkled
on
each
young
leaf
and
blade
of
grass
;
and
where
the
sun
was
shining
,
some
diamond
drops
yet
glistened
brightly
,
as
in
unwillingness
to
leave
so
fair
a
world
,
and
have
such
brief
existence
.
 
<EOS>
Even
the
light
wind
,
whose
rustling
was
as
gentle
to
the
ear
as
softly
-
falling
water
,
had
its
hope
and
promise
;
and
,
leaving
a
pleasant
fragrance
in
its
track
as
it
went
fluttering
by
,
whispered
of
its
intercourse
with
Summer
,
and
of
his
happy
coming
.
  
<EOS>
The
solitary
rider
went
glancing
on
among
the
trees
,
from
sunlight
into
shade
and
back
again
,
at
the
same
even
pace
---
looking
about
him
,
certainly
,
from
time
to
time
,
but
with
no
greater
thought
of
the
day
or
the
scene
through
which
he
moved
,
than
that
he
was
fortunate
(
being
choicely
dressed
)
to
have
such
favourable
weather
.
<EOS>
He
smiled
very
complacently
at
such
times
,
but
rather
as
if
he
were
satisfied
with
himself
than
with
anything
else
:
and
so
went
riding
on
,
upon
his
chestnut
cob
,
as
pleasant
to
look
upon
as
his
own
horse
,
and
probably
far
less
sensitive
to
the
many
cheerful
influences
by
which
he
was
surrounded
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
time
,
the
Maypole
's
massive
chimneys
rose
upon
his
view
:
but
he
quickened
not
his
pace
one
jot
,
and
with
the
same
cool
gravity
rode
up
to
the
tavern
porch
.
 
<EOS>
John
Willet
,
who
was
toasting
his
red
face
before
a
great
fire
in
the
bar
,
and
who
,
with
surpassing
foresight
and
quickness
of
apprehension
,
had
been
thinking
,
as
he
looked
at
the
blue
sky
,
that
if
that
state
of
things
lasted
much
longer
,
it
might
ultimately
become
necessary
to
leave
off
fires
and
throw
the
windows
open
,
issued
forth
to
hold
his
stirrup
;
calling
lustily
for
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
're
here
,
are
you
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
said
John
,
rather
surprised
by
the
quickness
with
which
he
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
this
here
valuable
animal
into
the
stable
,
and
have
more
than
particular
care
of
him
if
you
want
to
keep
your
place
.
 
<EOS>
A
mortal
lazy
fellow
,
sir
<EOS>
;
he
needs
a
deal
of
looking
after
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
have
a
son
,
"
returned
Mr
Chester
,
giving
his
bridle
to
Hugh
as
he
dismounted
,
and
acknowledging
his
salute
by
a
careless
motion
of
his
hand
towards
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
do
n't
you
make
HIM
useful
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
truth
is
,
sir
,
"
replied
John
with
great
importance
,
"
that
my
son
---
what
,
you
're
a
-
listening
<EOS>
are
you
,
villain
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
's
listening
?
"
returned
Hugh
angrily
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
treat
,
indeed
,
to
hear
YOU
speak
!
 
<EOS>
Would
you
have
me
take
him
in
till
he
's
cool
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Walk
him
up
and
down
further
off
then
,
sir
,
"
cried
old
John
,
"
and
when
you
see
me
and
a
noble
gentleman
entertaining
ourselves
with
talk
,
keep
your
distance
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
do
n't
know
your
distance
,
sir
,
"
added
Mr
Willet
,
after
an
enormously
long
pause
,
during
which
he
fixed
his
great
dull
eyes
on
Hugh
,
and
waited
with
exemplary
patience
for
any
little
property
in
the
way
of
ideas
that
might
come
to
him
,
"
we
'll
find
a
way
to
teach
you
,
pretty
soon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
shrugged
his
shoulders
scornfully
,
and
in
his
reckless
swaggering
way
,
crossed
to
the
other
side
of
the
little
green
,
and
there
,
with
the
bridle
slung
loosely
over
his
shoulder
,
led
the
horse
to
and
fro
,
glancing
at
his
master
every
now
and
then
from
under
his
bushy
eyebrows
,
with
as
sinister
an
aspect
as
one
would
desire
to
see
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Chester
,
who
,
without
appearing
to
do
so
,
had
eyed
him
attentively
during
this
brief
dispute
,
stepped
into
the
porch
,
and
turning
abruptly
to
Mr
Willet
,
said
,
  
"
You
keep
strange
servants
,
John
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Strange
enough
to
look
at
,
sir
,
certainly
,
"
answered
the
host
;
"
but
out
of
doors
;
for
horses
,
dogs
,
and
the
likes
of
that
;
there
an't
a
better
man
in
England
than
is
that
Maypole
Hugh
yonder
.
 
<EOS>
He
an't
fit
for
indoors
,
"
added
Mr
Willet
,
with
the
confidential
air
of
a
man
who
felt
his
own
superior
nature
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
that
;
but
if
that
chap
had
only
a
little
imagination
,
sir
---
"
  
"
He
's
an
active
fellow
now
<EOS>
,
I
dare
swear
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
in
a
musing
tone
,
which
seemed
to
suggest
that
he
would
have
said
the
same
had
there
been
nobody
to
hear
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Active
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
John
,
with
quite
an
expression
in
his
face
;
"
that
chap
!
 
<EOS>
Hallo
there
!
 
<EOS>
You
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
Bring
that
horse
here
,
and
go
and
hang
my
wig
on
the
weathercock
,
to
show
this
gentleman
whether
you
're
one
of
the
lively
sort
or
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
made
no
answer
,
but
throwing
the
bridle
to
his
master
,
and
snatching
his
wig
from
his
head
,
in
a
manner
so
unceremonious
and
hasty
that
the
action
discomposed
Mr
Willet
not
a
little
,
though
performed
at
his
own
special
desire
,
climbed
nimbly
to
the
very
summit
of
the
maypole
before
the
house
,
and
hanging
the
wig
upon
the
weathercock
,
sent
it
twirling
round
like
a
roasting
jack
.
<EOS>
Having
achieved
this
performance
,
he
cast
it
on
the
ground
,
and
sliding
down
the
pole
with
inconceivable
rapidity
,
alighted
on
his
feet
almost
as
soon
as
it
had
touched
the
earth
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
sir
,
"
said
John
,
relapsing
into
his
usual
stolid
state
,
"
you
wo
n't
see
that
at
many
houses
,
besides
the
Maypole
,
where
there
's
good
accommodation
for
man
and
beast
---
nor
that
neither
,
though
that
with
him
is
nothing
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
last
remark
bore
reference
to
his
vaulting
on
horseback
,
as
upon
Mr
Chester
's
first
visit
,
and
quickly
disappearing
by
the
stable
gate
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
with
him
is
nothing
,
"
repeated
Mr
Willet
,
brushing
his
wig
with
his
wrist
,
and
inwardly
resolving
to
distribute
a
small
charge
for
dust
and
damage
to
that
article
of
dress
,
through
the
various
items
of
his
guest
's
bill
;
"
he
'll
get
out

a'most
any

the

.
 
<EOS>
There
never

such
a
chap
for
flinging

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

not

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
we
was
a
-
talking
,

,
about
my
son
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
True
,
Willet
,
true
,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
My

,
what
about

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
has

that
Mr
Willet
,
previously
to

,
winked
.
 
<EOS>
But

was
never

,

<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"

,
with

,
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
We

no
love

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
My

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

window
<EOS>
but
this

,
"

,

naturally

that

on

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No

,

,
"

<EOS>
"
He

upon

,

.
 
<EOS>
Me

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

wo

for

come
,
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
When

,

pending

,
Mr

drew
back

his
guest
's

,

without

,

thrice

.
 
<EOS>
This
nearest
approach
to
a
laugh
in
which
he
ever
indulged
(
and
that
<EOS>
but
seldom
and
only
on
extreme
occasions
)
,
never
even
curled
his
lip
or
effected
the
smallest

---
no
,
not
so

as
a
slight

of
---
his
great
,
fat
,
double
chin
,
which
at

,

,

perfect
desert
in
the
broad
map
of
his

;
one
changeless
,
dull
,

blank
.
  
<EOS>
Lest

should
be
matter
of

any
,
that
Mr
Willet
adopted
this
bold
course
in
opposition
to
one
whom
he
had
often
entertained
,
and
who
had
always
paid
his
way
at
the
Maypole
gallantly
,
it
may
be
remarked
that
it
was
his
very

and

in
this
respect
,
which
occasioned

to

in

unusual

of

,
just
now
recorded
.
 
<EOS>
For
Mr
Willet
,
after
carefully
balancing
father
and
son
in
his
mental
scales
,
had
arrived
at
the
distinct
conclusion
that
the
old
gentleman
was
a
better
sort
of
a
customer
than
the
young

.
<EOS>
Throwing
his
landlord
into
the
same

,
which
was

turned
by
this

,
and
heaping
upon
him
,
again
,
his
strong

to
run
counter
to
the
unfortunate
Joe
,

his

as

to

,

down

,
and
sent

light
cause
of
the
younger

flying
upwards
to

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chester
was
not
the
kind
of
man
to
be
by
any

dim
-
sighted
to
Mr
Willet
's

,
but
he
thanked

as

had

one

ever
shone

;

,

on

,
to

whatever

he
might
deem
most
fitting

,
bent
his

towards
the
Warren
.
  
<EOS>
Dressed
with
more
than
his
usual

;
assuming
a

manner
,
which
,
though

,
sat

and

;
composing

into

most

;
and
setting

that
guard

,

,

;
he
entered
the
bounds
of
Miss
Haredale
's
usual

.
 
<EOS>
He

,
or

him

,

descried
coming

,
a

.
 
<EOS>
A

which

between

,
satisfied
him
that

whom

.
 
<EOS>
He
threw
himself
in
her
way
,
and
a
very

paces
brought
them
close

.
  
<EOS>
He
raised
his

,
and
yielding

,
suffered

to
pass

.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
as
if
the

had
but
that

,

back
and
said

:
  
"
I
beg

---
do
I
address
Miss
Haredale
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
stopped
in
some
confusion
at

accosted

;
and
answered
"
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Something
told
me
,
"
he

,
LOOKING
a

to
her

,
"
that
it
could
be
no
other
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Haredale
,
I
bear
a
name
which
is
not

---
which
it
is
a
pride
,
and
yet

pain

,
sounds

in

.
 
<EOS>
I

man
advanced

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
May
I
for

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Who
that

in

,
and

,

,

one
she

,

<EOS>
She

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
A

---

.
 
<EOS>
It

an
old

's
hand
,

;

,

.

<EOS>
She

"
You

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
It

I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>

<EOS>
You

"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
<EOS>
"
---

"

.
 
<EOS>
You

Edward
's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon

,

,

---
"
  
"
<EOS>
Nor

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
It

his

to
stab
in

,

to

such
deeds
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
rose
as

,
and
would

;
but
he
detained

with

,
and
besought

in

to
hear

but

,
that

was
easily
prevailed
upon
to

,
and
so
sat
down

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
it
is
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,

,

;
"
it

this
frank
,

,
noble

,
Ned
,
that
you
can
wound

.
 
<EOS>
Shame
<EOS>
---
shame
upon
you
,
boy
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
turned
towards
him
quickly
,
and
with

.
 
<EOS>
There

tears
in
Mr
Chester
's

,

dashed

away
,
as
though
unwilling
that
his
weakness
should
be
known
,
and
regarded

with

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
until
now
,
"
he

,
"
believed
,
that
the
frivolous

of
a
young
man
could
move

like
these
of
my
own
son
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
knew
till
now
,
the
worth
of
a
woman
's
heart
,
which
boys
so
lightly
win
,
and
lightly
fling

.
 
<EOS>
Trust
me
,
dear
young
lady
,
that
I
never
until
now
did
know
your
worth
;
and
though
an
abhorrence
of

and

has
impelled

to

,
and
would
have
done

<EOS>
had
you
been
the
poorest
and
least
gifted
of
your
sex
<EOS>
,
I
should

lacked
the
fortitude
to
sustain
this
interview
could
I
have
pictured
you
to
my
imagination
as
you
really

.
"
  
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
If
Mrs
Varden
could
have
seen
the
virtuous
gentleman
as
he
said
these
words
,
with
indignation

---
if

broken
,

---
if

as
he
stood
bareheaded
in
the

,
and
with
unwonted
energy
poured
forth
his
eloquence
!
  
<EOS>
With
a
haughty
face
,
but
pale
and
trembling
too
,
Emma
regarded
him
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
She
neither
spoke
nor
moved
,
but
gazed
upon
him
as
though
she
would
look
into
his
heart
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
throw
off
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
"
the
restraint
which
natural
affection
would
impose
on
some
men
,
and
reject
all
bonds
but
those
of
truth
and
duty
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Haredale
,
you
are
deceived
;
you
are
deceived
by
your
unworthy
lover
,
and
my
unworthy
son
.
"
  
<EOS>
Still
she
looked
at
him
steadily
,
and
still
said
not
one
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
ever
opposed
his
professions
of
love
for
you
;
you
will
do
me
the
justice
,
dear
Miss
Haredale
,
to
remember
that
.
 
<EOS>
Your
uncle
and
myself
were
enemies
in
early
life
,
and
if
I
had
sought
retaliation
,
I
might
have
found
it
here
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
we
grow
older
,
we
grow
wiser
---
bitter
,
I
would
fain
hope
---
and
from
the
first
,
I
have
opposed
him
in
this
attempt
.
 
<EOS>
I
foresaw
the
end
,
and
would
have
spared
you
,
if
I
could
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Speak
plainly
,
sir
,
"
she
faltered
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
deceive
me
,
or
are
deceived
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
believe
you
---
<EOS>
I
can
not
---
I
should
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
First
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
soothingly
,
"
for
there
may
be
in
your
mind
some
latent
angry
feeling
to
which
I
would
not
appeal
,
pray
take
this
letter
.
 
<EOS>
It
reached
my
hands
by
chance
,
and
by
mistake
,
and
should
have
accounted
to
you
(
as
I
am
told
)
for
my
son
's
not
answering
some
other
note
of
yours
.
 
<EOS>
God
forbid
,
Miss
Haredale
,
"
said
the
good
gentleman
,
with
great

,
"
that
there
should
be
in
your
gentle

one
causeless
ground

with

.
<EOS>
You
should
know
,
and
you
will

,
that
he
was
in
no
fault

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
appeared
something
so
very

,

,
so
very

and
just
in

something

,

that

,
for

first

,
sunk

.
<EOS>
She

and
burst
into

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
leaning
over
her
,
and
speaking
in
mild
and
quite
venerable
accents
;
"
I
would
,
<EOS>
dear
girl
,
it
were
my
task
to
banish
,
not
increase
,
those
tokens
of
your
grief
.
 
<EOS>
My
son
,
my
erring
son
,
---
I
will
not
call
him
deliberately
criminal
in
this
,
for
men
so
young
,
who
have
been
inconstant
twice
or
thrice
before
,
act
without
reflection
,
almost
without
a
knowledge
of
the
wrong
they
do
,
---
will
break
his
plighted
faith
to
you
;
has
broken
it
even
now
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
stop
here
,
and
having
given
you
this
warning
,
leave
it
to
be
fulfilled
;
or
shall
I
go
on
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
go
on
,
sir
,
"
she
answered
,
"
and
speak
more
plainly
yet
,
in
justice
both
to
him
and
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
girl
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
bending
over
her
more
affectionately
still
;
"
whom
I
would
call
my
daughter
,
but
the
Fates
forbid
,
Edward
seeks
to
break
with
you
upon
a
false
and
most
unwarrantable
pretence
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
it
on
his
own
showing
;
in
his
own
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Forgive
me
<EOS>
,
if
I
have
had
a
watch
upon
his
conduct
;
I
am
his
father
;
I
had
a
regard
for
your
peace
and
his
honour
,
and
no
better
resource
was
left
me
.
 
<EOS>
There
lies
on
his
desk
at
this
present
moment
,
ready
for
transmission
to
you
,
a
letter
,
in
which
he
tells
you
that
our
poverty
---
our
poverty
;
his
and
mine
,
Miss
Haredale
---
 
forbids
him
to
pursue
his
claim
upon
your
hand
;
in
which
he
offers
,
voluntarily

,
to
free
you
from

;
and
talks
magnanimously
(
men
do
so
,
very
commonly
,
in
such
cases
)
of
being
in
time
more
worthy
of
your

---
and
so
forth
.
 
<EOS>
A
letter
,
to
be
plain
,
in
which
he
not
only
jilts
you
<EOS>
---
pardon
the
word
;
I
would
summon
to
your
aid
your
pride
and

---
<EOS>
not

jilts
you
,
I
fear
,
in
favour
of
the
object
whose
slighting
treatment
first
inspired
his
brief

for
yourself
and
gave

birth
in

,
but
affects
to
make

merit

of

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
glanced

at
him
once
more
,
as
by
an

,
and
with
a

rejoined
,
"
If
what
you
say
be
true
,
he
takes
much

,
sir
,
to
compass

design
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
very
tender
of
my
peace
of
mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
quite
thank
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
truth
of
what
I
tell
you
,
dear
young
lady
,
"
he

,
"
you
will
test
by
the
receipt
or
non

of
the
letter
of

I
speak
.
 
<EOS>
Haredale
,
my
dear
fellow
<EOS>
,
I
am
delighted
to
see
you
,
although
we
meet
under
singular

,
and
upon
a

.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
are
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
At
these
words
the
young
lady
raised
her

,
which
were
filled
with
tears
;
and
seeing
that
her
uncle
indeed
stood
before
them
,
and
being
quite
unequal
to
the
trial
of
hearing
or
of
speaking
one

more
,
hurriedly
withdrew
,
and
left
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
stood
looking
at
each
other
,
and
at
her
retreating
figure
,
and
for
a
long
time
neither
of

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
does
this
mean
?
 
<EOS>
Explain
it
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
at
length
.
<EOS>
"
Why
are
you
here
,
and
why
with
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
friend
,
"
rejoined
the
other
,
resuming
his
accustomed
manner
with
infinite
readiness
,
and
throwing
himself
upon
the
bench
with
a
weary

,
"
you
told
me
not
very
long
ago
,
at
that
delightful
old
tavern
of
which
you
are
the
esteemed
proprietor
(
and
a
most
charming
establishment
it
is
for
persons
of
rural

and
in
robust
health
,
who
are
not
liable
to
take
cold
)
,
that
I
had
the
head
and
heart
of
an
evil
spirit
in
all

of
deception
.
<EOS>
I
thought
at
the
time
;
I
really
did
think
;
you
flattered
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
now
I
begin
to
wonder
at
your
discernment
,
and
<EOS>
vanity
apart
,
do
honestly
believe
you
spoke
the
truth
.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
counterfeit
extreme
ingenuousness
and

?
 
<EOS>
My
dear
fellow
,
you
have
no
conception
,
if
you
never
did
,
how
faint

effort
makes
one
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
surveyed

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
evade

,
I

,
"
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
must
have
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
wait
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Not
at
all
,
my
good
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
not
wait
a
moment
,
"
returned
his
friend
,
as
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
simplest
thing
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
It
lies
in
a
nutshell
.
 
<EOS>
Ned
has
written
her
a
letter
---
a
boyish
,
honest
,
sentimental
composition
,
which
remains
as
yet
in
his
desk
,
because
he
has
n't

the
heart
to
send
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
taken
a
liberty
,
for
which
my
parental
affection
and
anxiety
are
a
sufficient
excuse
,
and
possessed
myself
of
the
contents
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
described
them
to
your
niece
(
a
most
enchanting
person
,
Haredale
;
quite
an
angelic
creature
)
,
with
a
little
colouring
and
description
adapted
to
our
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
done
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
be
quite
easy
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
over
.
 
<EOS>
Deprived
of
their
adherents
and
mediators
;
her
pride
and

roused
to
the
utmost
;
with
nobody
to

her
,
and
you
to
confirm

;
you
will
find
that
their
intercourse
will
close
with
her

.
 
<EOS>
If

Ned
's

by
to

,
you

from

-

.
 
<EOS>
No
thanks
<EOS>
,
I
beg
;
you
owe
me
none
.
<EOS>
I
have
acted
for
myself
;
and
if
I
have
forwarded
our
compact
with
all
the

even

,
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
curse
the

,

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
made
in
an
evil

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
bound
myself
to
a
lie
;
I
have
leagued

;
and
though

,

such

as

,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
warm
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
with
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
AM
warm
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
maddened
by
your
coldness
.
 
<EOS>
"
Death
,
Chester
,
if
your
blood
ran
warmer
in
your

,
and
there
were
no

upon

,

that

---
<EOS>
well
;
it
is
done
;
you
tell

,

I
may

.
 
<EOS>
When
I

most

for
this

,
I
will
think

you
and
your
marriage
,
and
try
to
justify
myself
in
such
remembrances
,
for
having
torn
asunder
Emma
and
your
son
,
at
any

.
 
<EOS>
Our
bond
is
cancelled
now
,
and
we
may

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Chester
kissed
his
hand
gracefully
;
and
with
the
same
tranquil
face
he
had
preserved
throughout
---
even
when
he
had
seen
his
companion
so
tortured
and
transported
by

passion
that
his
whole

was

---
lay
in

on

and
watched

as

away
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
scapegoat
and
my
drudge
at
school
,
"
he
said
,
raising
his
head
to
look

him
;
"
my
friend
of
later
days
,
who
could
not
keep
his
mistress
when
he
had
won
her
,
and
threw
me
in
her
way
to
carry
off
the
prize
;
I
triumph
in
the
present
and
the
past
.
 
<EOS>
Bark
on
,
ill
-
favoured
,
ill
-
conditioned
cur
<EOS>
;
fortune
has
ever
been
with
me
---
I
like
to
hear
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
spot
where
they
had
met
,
was
in
an
avenue
of
trees
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
not
passing
out
on
either
hand
,
had
walked
straight
on
.
<EOS>
He
chanced
to
turn
his
head
when
at
some
considerable
distance
,
and
seeing
that
his
late
companion
had
by
that
time
risen
and
was
looking
after
him
,
stood
still
as
though
he
half
expected
him
to
follow
and
waited
for
his
coming
up
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
MAY
come
to
that
one
day
,
but
not
yet
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
waving
his
hand
,
as
though
they
were
the
best
of
friends
,
and
turning
away
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
yet
,
Haredale
.
 
<EOS>
Life
is
pleasant
enough
to
me
;
dull
and
full
of
heaviness
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
To
cross
swords
with
such
a
man
---
to
indulge
his
humour
unless
upon
extremity
---
would
be
weak
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
For
all
that
,
he
drew
his
sword
as
he
walked
along
,
and
in
an
absent
humour
ran
his
eye
from
hilt
to
point
full
twenty
times
.
<EOS>
But
thoughtfulness
begets
wrinkles
;
remembering
this
,
he
soon
put
it
up
,
smoothed
his
contracted
brow
,
hummed
a
gay
tune
with
greater
gaiety
of
manner
,
and
was
his
unruffled
self
again
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
30
    
A
homely
proverb
recognises
the
existence
of
a
troublesome
class
of
persons
who
,
having
an
inch
conceded
them
,
will
take
an
ell
.
 
<EOS>
Not
to
quote
the
illustrious
examples
of
those
heroic
scourges
of
mankind
,
whose
amiable
path
in
life
has
been
from
birth
to
death
through
blood
,
and
fire
,
and
ruin
,
and
who
would
seem
to
have
existed
for
no
better
purpose
than
to
teach
mankind
that
as
the
absence
of
pain
is
pleasure
,
so
the
earth
,
purged
of
their
presence
,
may
be
deemed
a
blessed
place
---
not
to
quote
such
mighty
instances
,
it
will
be
sufficient
to
refer
to
old
John
Willet
.
  
<EOS>
Old
John
having
long
encroached
a
good
standard
inch
,
full
measure
,
on
the
liberty
of
Joe
,
and
having
snipped
off
a
Flemish
ell
in
the
matter
of
the
parole
,
grew
so
despotic
and
so
great
,
that
his
thirst
for
conquest
knew
no
bounds
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
young
Joe
submitted
,
the
more
absolute
old
John
became
.
 
<EOS>
The
ell
soon
faded
into
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Yards
,
furlongs
,
miles
arose
;
and
on
went
old
John
in
the
pleasantest
manner
possible
,
trimming
off
an
exuberance
in
this
place
,
shearing
away
some
liberty
of
speech
or
action
in
that
,
and
conducting
himself
in
his
small
way
with
as
much
high
mightiness
and
majesty
,
as
the
most
glorious
tyrant
that
ever
had
his
statue
reared
in
the
public
ways
,
of
ancient
or
of
modern
times
.
  
<EOS>
As
great
men
are
urged
on
to
the
abuse
of
power
(
when
they
need
urging
,
which
is
not
often
)
,
by
their
flatterers
and
dependents
,
so
old
John
was
impelled
to
these
exercises
of
authority
by
the
applause
and
admiration
of
his
Maypole
cronies
,
who
,
in
the
intervals
of
their
nightly
pipes
and
pots
,
would
shake
their
heads
and
say
that
Mr
Willet
was
a
father
of
the
good
old
English
sort
;
that
there
were
no
new
-
fangled
notions
or
modern
ways
in
him
;
that
he
put
them
in
mind
of
what
their
fathers
were
when
they
were
boys
;
that
there
was
no
mistake
about
him
;
that
it
would
be
well
for
the
country
if
there
were
more
like
him
,
and
more
was
the
pity
that
there
were
not
;
with
many
other
original
remarks
of
that
nature
.
<EOS>
Then
they
would
condescendingly
give
Joe
to
understand
that
it
was
all
for
his
good
,
and
he
would
be
thankful
for
it
one
day
;
and
in
particular
,
Mr
Cobb
would
acquaint
him
,
that
when
he
was
his
age
,
his
father
thought
no
more
of
giving
him
a
parental
kick
,
or
a
box
on
the
ears
,
or
a
cuff
on
the
head
,
or
some
little
admonition
of
that
sort
,
than
he
did
of
any
other
ordinary
duty
of
life
;
and
he
would
further
remark
,
with
looks
of
great
significance
,
that
but
for
this
judicious
bringing
up
,
he
might
have
never
been
the
man
he
was
at
that
present
speaking
;
which
was
probable
enough
,
as
he
was
,
beyond
all
question
,
the
dullest
dog
of
the
party
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
between
old
John
and
old
John
's
friends
,
there
never
was
an
unfortunate
young
fellow
so
bullied
,
badgered
,
worried
,
fretted
,
and
brow
-
beaten
;
so
constantly
beset
,
or
made
so
tired
of
his
life
,
as
poor
Joe
Willet
.
  
<EOS>
This
had
come
to
be
the
recognised
and
established
state
of
things
;
but
as
John
was
very
anxious
to
flourish
his
supremacy
before
the
eyes
of
Mr
Chester
,
he
did
that
day
exceed
himself
,
and
did
so
goad
and
chafe
his
son
and
heir
,
that
but
for
Joe
's
having
made
a
solemn
vow
to
keep
his
hands
in
his
pockets
when
they
were
not
otherwise
engaged
,
it
is
impossible
to
say
what
he
might
have
done
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
longest
day
has
an
end
,
and
at
length
Mr
Chester
came
downstairs
to
mount
his
horse
,
which
was
ready
at
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
As
old
John
was
not
in
the
way
at
the
moment
,
Joe
,
who
was
sitting
in
the
bar
ruminating
on
his
dismal
fate
and
the
manifold
perfections
of
Dolly
Varden
,
ran
out
to
hold
the
guest
's
stirrup
and
assist
him
to
mount
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chester
was
scarcely
in
the
saddle
,
and
Joe
was
in
the
very
act
of
making
him
a
graceful
bow
,
when
old
John
came
diving
out
of
the
porch
,
and
collared
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
None
of
that
,
sir
,
"
said
John
,
"
none
of
that
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
No
breaking
of
patroles
.
 
<EOS>
How
dare
you
come
out
of
the
door
,
sir
,
without
leave
?
<EOS>
You
're
trying
to
get
away
,
sir
,
are
you
,
and
to
make
a
traitor
of
yourself
again
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
,
father
,
"
said
Joe
,
imploringly
,
as
he
marked
the
smile
upon
their
visitor
's
face
,
and
observed
the
pleasure
his
disgrace
afforded
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
too
bad
.
 
<EOS>
Who
wants
to
get
away
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
wants
to
get
away
!
"
<EOS>
cried
John
,
shaking
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
you
do
,
sir
,
you
do
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
the
boy
,
sir
,
"
added
John
,
collaring
with
one
band
,
and
aiding
the
effect
of
a
farewell
bow
to
the
visitor
with
the
other
,
"
that
wants
to
sneak
into
houses
,
and
stir
up
differences
between
noble
gentlemen
and
their
sons
<EOS>
,
are
you
,
eh
?
<EOS>
Hold
your
tongue
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Joe
made
no
effort
to
reply
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
crowning
circumstance
of
his
degradation
.
 
<EOS>
He
extricated
himself
from
his
father
's
grasp
,
darted
an
angry
look
at
the
departing
guest
,
and
returned
into
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
for
her
,
"
thought
Joe
,
as
he
threw
his
arms
upon
a
table
in
the
common
room
,
and
laid
his
head
upon
them
,
"
but
for
Dolly
,
who
I
could
n't
bear
should
think
me
the
rascal
<EOS>
they
would
make
me
out
to
be
if
I
ran
away
,
this
house
and
I
should
part
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
being
evening
by
this
time
,
Solomon
Daisy
,
Tom
Cobb
,
and
Long
Parkes
,
were
all
in
the
common
room
too
,
and
had
from
the
window
been
witnesses
of
what
had
just
occurred
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
joining
them
soon
afterwards
,
received
the
compliments
of
the
company
with
great
composure
,
and
lighting
his
pipe
,
sat
down
among
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
'll
see
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
<EOS>
John
,
after
a
long
pause
,
"
who
's
the
master
of
this
house
,
and
who
is
n't
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
see
whether
boys
are
to
govern
men
,
or
men
are
to
govern
boys
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
quite
right
too
,
"
assented
Solomon
Daisy
with
some
approving
nods
;
"
quite
right
,
Johnny
.
 
<EOS>
Very
good
,
Johnny
.
 
<EOS>
Well
said
,
Mr
Willet
.
 
<EOS>
Brayvo
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
John
slowly
brought
his
eyes
to
bear
upon
him
,
looked
at
him
for
a
long
time
,
and
finally
made
answer
,
to
the
unspeakable
consternation
of
his
hearers
,
"
When
I
want
encouragement
from
you
,
sir
,
I
'll
ask
you
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
let
me
alone
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
get
on
without
you
,
I
hope
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
tackle
me
,
sir
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
take
it
ill
,
Johnny
;
I
did
n't
mean
any
harm
,
"
pleaded
the
little
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
sir
,
"
said
John
,
more
than
usually
obstinate
after
his
late
success
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
stand
pretty
firm
of
myself
,
sir
,
I
believe
,
without
being
shored
up
by
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
having
given
utterance
to
this
retort
,
Mr
Willet
fixed
his
eyes
upon
the
boiler
,
and
fell
into
a
kind
of
tobacco
-
trance
.
  
<EOS>
The
spirits
of
the
company
being
somewhat
damped
by
this
embarrassing
line
of
conduct
on
the
part
of
their
host
,
nothing
more
was
said
for
a
long
time
;
but
at
length
Mr
Cobb
took
upon
himself
to
remark
,
as
he
rose
to
knock
the
ashes
out
of
his
pipe
,
that
he
hoped
Joe
would
thenceforth
learn
to
obey
his
father
in
all
things
;
that
he
had
found
,
that
day
,
he
was
not
one
of
the
sort
of
men
who
were
to
be
trifled
with
;
and
that
he
would
recommend
him
,
poetically
speaking
,
to
mind
his
eye
for
the
future
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'd
recommend
you
,
in
return
,
"
said
Joe
,
looking
up
with
a
flushed
face
,
"
not
to
talk
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
tongue
,
sir
,
"
cried
Mr
Willet
,
suddenly
rousing
himself
,
and
turning
round
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
,
father
,
"
cried
Joe
,
smiting
the
table
with
his
fist
,
so
that
the
jugs
and
glasses
rung
again
;
"
these
things
are
hard
enough
to
bear
from
you
;
from
anybody
else
I
never
will
endure
them
any
more
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
say
,
Mr
Cobb
,
do
n't
talk
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
who
are
you
,
"
said
Mr
Cobb
,
sneeringly
,
"
that
you
're
not
to
be
talked
to
,
eh
,
Joe
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
To
which
Joe
returned
no
answer
,
but
with
a
very
ominous
shake
of
the
head
,
resumed
his
old
position
,
which
he
would
have
peacefully
preserved
until
the
house
shut
up
at
night
,
but
that
Mr
Cobb
,
stimulated
by
the
wonder
of
the
company
at
the
young
man
's
presumption
,
retorted
with
sundry
taunts
,
which
proved
too
much
for
flesh
and
blood
to
bear
.
 
<EOS>
Crowding
into
one
moment
the
vexation
and
the
wrath
of
years
,
Joe
started
up
,
overturned
the
table
,
<EOS>
fell
upon
his
long
enemy
,
pummelled
him
with
all
his
might
and
main
,
and
finished
by
driving
him
with
surprising
swiftness
against
a
heap
of
spittoons
in
one
corner
;
plunging
into
which
,
head
foremost
,
with
a
tremendous
crash
,
he
lay
at
full
length
among
the
ruins
,
stunned
and
motionless
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
without
waiting
to
receive
the
compliments
of
the
bystanders
on
the
victory
be
had
won
,
he
retreated
to
his
own
bedchamber
,
and
considering
himself
in
a
state
of
siege
,
piled
all
the
portable
furniture
against
the
door
by
way
of
barricade
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
it
now
,
"
said
Joe
,
as
he
sat
down
upon
his
bedstead
and
wiped
his
heated
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
it
would
come
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
The
Maypole
and
I
must
part
company
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
a
roving
vagabond
---
she
hates
me
for
evermore
---
it
's
all
over
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
31
    
Pondering
on
his
unhappy
lot
,
Joe
sat
and
listened
for
a
long
time
,
expecting
every
moment
to
hear
their
creaking
footsteps
on
the
stairs
,
or
to
be
greeted
by
his
worthy
father
with
a
summons
to
capitulate
unconditionally
,
and
deliver
himself
up
straightway
.
<EOS>
But
neither
voice
nor
footstep
came
;
and
though
some
distant
echoes
,
as
of
closing
doors
and
people
hurrying
in
and
out
of
rooms
,
resounding
from
time
to
time
through
the
great
passages
,
and
penetrating
to
his
remote
seclusion
,
gave
note
of
unusual
commotion
downstairs
,
no
nearer
sound
disturbed
his
place
of
retreat
,
which
seemed
the
quieter
for
these
far
-
off
noises
,
and
was
as
dull
and
full
of
gloom
as
any
hermit
's
cell
.
  
<EOS>
It
came
on
darker
and
darker
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
-
fashioned
furniture
of
the
chamber
,
which
was
a
kind
of
hospital
for
all
the
invalided
movables
in
the
house
,
grew
indistinct
and
shadowy
in
its
many
shapes
;
chairs
and
tables
,
which
by
day
were
as
honest
cripples
as
need
be
,
assumed
a
doubtful
and
mysterious
character
;
and
one
old
leprous
screen
of
faded
India
leather
and
gold
binding
,
which
had
kept
out
many
a
cold
breath
of
air
in
days
of
yore
and
shut
in
many
a
jolly
face
,
frowned
on
him
with
a
spectral
aspect
,
and
stood
at
full
height
in
its
allotted
corner
,
like
some
gaunt
ghost
who
waited
to
be
questioned
.
 
<EOS>
A
portrait
opposite
the
window
---
a
queer
,
old
grey
-
eyed
general
,
in
an
oval
frame
---
seemed
to
wink
and
doze
as
the
light
decayed
,
and
at
length
,
when
the
last
faint
glimmering
speck
of
day
went
out
,
to
shut
its
eyes
in
good
earnest
,
and
fall
sound
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
such
a
hush
and
mystery
about
everything
,
that
Joe
could
not
help
following
its
example
;
and
so
went
off
into
a
slumber
likewise
,
and
dreamed
of
Dolly
,
till
the
clock
of
Chigwell
church
struck
two
.
  
<EOS>
Still
nobody
came
.
 
<EOS>
The
distant
noises
in
the
house
had
ceased
,
and
out
of
doors
<EOS>
all
was
quiet
;
save
for
the
occasional
barking
of
some
deep
-
mouthed
dog
,
and
the
shaking
of
the
branches
by
the
night
wind
.
 
<EOS>
He
gazed
mournfully
out
of
window
at
each
well
-
known
object
as
it
lay
sleeping
in
the
dim
light
of
the
moon
;
and
creeping
back
to
his
former
seat
,
thought
about
the
late
uproar
,
until
,
with
long
thinking
of
<EOS>
,
it
seemed
to
have
occurred
a
month
ago
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
between
dozing
,
and
thinking
,
and
walking
to
the
window
and
looking
out
,
the
night
wore
away
;
the
grim
old
screen
,
and
the
kindred
chairs
and
tables
,
began
slowly
to
reveal
themselves
in
their
accustomed
forms
;
the
grey
-
eyed
general
seemed
to
wink
and
yawn
and
rouse
himself
;
and
at
last
he
was
broad
awake
again
,
and
very
uncomfortable
and
cold
and
haggard
he
looked
,
in
the
dull
grey
light
of
morning
.
  
<EOS>
The
sun
had
begun
to
peep
above
the
forest
trees
,
and
already
flung
across
the
curling
mist
bright
bars
of
gold
,
when
Joe
dropped
from
his
window
on
the
ground
below
,
a
little
bundle
and
his
trusty
stick
,
and
prepared
to
descend
himself
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
very
difficult
task
;
for
there
were
so
many
projections
and
gable
ends
in
the
way
,
that
they
formed
a
series
of
clumsy
steps
,
with
no
greater
obstacle
than
a
jump
of
some
few
feet
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
Joe
,
with
his
stick
and
bundle
on
his
shoulder
,
quickly
stood
on
the
firm
earth
,
and
looked
up
at
the
old
Maypole
,
it
might
be
for
the
last
time
.
  
<EOS>
He
did
n't
apostrophise
it
,
for
he
was
no
great
scholar
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
n't
curse
it
,
for
he
had
little
ill
-
will
to
give
to
anything
on
earth
.
<EOS>
He
felt
more
affectionate
and
kind
to
it
than
ever
he
had
done
in
all
his
life
before
,
so
said
with
all
his
heart
,
"
God
bless
you
!
"
<EOS>
as
a
parting
wish
,
and
turned
away
.
  
<EOS>
He
walked
along
at
a
brisk
pace
,
big
with
great
thoughts
of
going
for
a
soldier
and
dying
in
some
foreign
country
where
it
was
very
hot
and
sandy
,
and
leaving
God
knows
what
unheard
-
of
wealth
in
prize
-
money
to
Dolly
,
who
would
be
very
much
affected
when
she
came
to
know
of
it
;
and
full
of
such
youthful
visions
,
which
were
sometimes
sanguine
and
sometimes
melancholy
,
but
always
had
her
for
their
main
point
and
centre
,
pushed
on
vigorously
until
the
noise
of
London
sounded
in
his
ears
,
and
the
Black
Lion
hove
in
sight
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
only
eight
o'clock
then
,
and
very
much
astonished
the
Black
Lion
was
,
to
see
him
come
walking
in
with
dust
upon
his
feet
at
that
early
hour
,
with
no
grey
mare
to
bear
him
company
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
he
ordered
breakfast
to
be
got
ready
with
all
speed
,
and
on
its
being
set
before
him
gave
indisputable
tokens
of
a
hearty
appetite
,
the
Lion
received
him
,
as
usual
,
with
a
hospitable
welcome
;
and
treated
him
with
those
marks
of
distinction
,
which
,
as
a
regular
customer
,
and
one
within
the
freemasonry
of
the
trade
,
he
had
a
right
to
claim
.
  
<EOS>
This
Lion
or
landlord
,
---
for
he
was
called
both
man
and
beast
,
by
reason
of
his
having
instructed
the
artist
who
painted
his
sign
,
to
convey
into
the
features
of
the
lordly
brute
whose
effigy
it
bore
,
as
near
a
counterpart
of
his
own
face
as
his
skill
could
compass
and
devise
,
---
was
a
gentleman
almost
as
quick
of
apprehension
,
and
of
almost
as
subtle
a
wit
,
as
the
mighty
John
himself
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
difference
between
them
lay
in
this
:
that
whereas
Mr
Willet
's
extreme
sagacity
and
acuteness
were
the
efforts
of
unassisted
nature
<EOS>
,
the
Lion
stood
indebted
,
in
no
small
amount
,
to
beer
;
of
which
he
swigged
such
copious
draughts
,
that
most
of
his
faculties
were
utterly
drowned
and
washed
away
,
except
the
one
great
faculty
of
sleep
,
which
he
retained
in
surprising
perfection
.
 
<EOS>
The
creaking
Lion
over
the
house
-
door
was
,
therefore
,
to
say
the
truth
,
rather
a
drowsy
,
tame
,
and
feeble
lion
;
and
as
these
social
representatives
of
a
savage
class
are
usually
of
a
conventional
character
(
being
depicted
,
for
the
most
part
,
in
impossible
attitudes
and
of
unearthly
colours
)
,
he
was
frequently
supposed
by
the
more
ignorant
and
uninformed
among
the
neighbours
,
to
be
the
veritable
portrait
of
the
host
as
he
appeared
on
the
occasion
of
some
great
funeral
ceremony
or
public
mourning
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
noisy
fellow
is
that
in
the
next
room
?
"
said
Joe
,
when
he
had
disposed
of
his
breakfast
,
and
had
washed
and
brushed
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
recruiting
serjeant
,
"
replied
the
Lion
.
  
<EOS>
Joe
started
involuntarily
.
 
<EOS>
Here
was
the
very
thing
he
had
been
dreaming
of
,
all
the
way
along
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
wish
,
"
said
the
Lion
,
"
he
was
anywhere
else
but
here
.
 
<EOS>
The
party
make
noise
enough
,
but
do
n't
call
for
much
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
great
cry
there
,
Mr
Willet
,
but
very
little

.
 
<EOS>
Your
father
would
n't
like
'em
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Perhaps
not
much

any

.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps

was

.
  
<EOS>
"
Is

---

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

an't
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
No

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
Those

are
---
supposing

's

---

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ah
!
"

,
"
but
you
do

for

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
For

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Glory
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
returned

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
.
<EOS>
You
're

in

,
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,
that
the
Glory
's
arms
would

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
These

.
 
<EOS>
Joe
walked
out
,
stopped
at
the
door

the
next

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
The
serjeant
was
describing
a
military
life
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
all
drinking
,
he
said
,
except
that
there
were
frequent

of
eating
and
love
-

.
 
<EOS>
A
battle
was
the
finest
thing
in
the
world
---
when
your
side
won

---
 
and
Englishmen
always
did

.
 
<EOS>
"
Supposing
you
should
be
killed
,

?
"
said
a

in
one

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
supposing
you
should
be

"
said
the
serjeant
,
"
<EOS>
what
then
?
 
<EOS>
Your
country
loves

,

;
his
Majesty
King
George

Third

;
your

,

.
 
<EOS>
Damme
,

<EOS>
,

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
  
<EOS>
Joe

into

.
 
<EOS>
A

half
-
a
-

had

,

.
 
<EOS>
One

,
a

in

,

and

to

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

by

,
strongly

to
do
so
<EOS>
(
according

mankind
)
,
backed
the

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
say
nothing
,
boys
,
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
For
lads
of
spirit
"
---
here

---
"
this

.
 
<EOS>
I
do

.
 
<EOS>
The

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
Brisk

;

.
 
<EOS>
We
wo

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

-

,

,

,

,

"
---
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

G
---
 
!
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Let

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Joe
did

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
just

,
"

Joe
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A

like
you
,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

---

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"
---

,
"
for

,
where

,

.
 
<EOS>
Look

.
 
<EOS>
You

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

<EOS>
,

---
"

"
eyes

.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank

,
"

,
"
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Do

?
"
  
<EOS>
The

rejoined

that
he
did

;
and
that

his
(

's

,

.
  
<EOS>
Joe

,

,
"
You

,

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

,

ca

.
 
<EOS>
Where

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
His

having
for

,

;

<EOS>

---

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

---

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tush
,

!
"

,
"
I
'm

.
 
<EOS>
Needs
must
when
the
devil
drives
;
and
the

that

is
an

.
 
<EOS>
For

,
good

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
For
king
and

!
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
For

and

!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
And
so
they
parted
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
very
little
money
in
his
pocket
;
so
little

,
that
after
paying
for
his

(
which

and
perhaps
too
proud
to
score
up
to

father
's

)
he
had
but
a

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
courage
,
notwithstanding
,
to
resist
all
the
affectionate
importunities
of
the
serjeant
,
who
waylaid
him
at
the
door
with
many

of
eternal

,
and
did
in
particular
request
that
he
would
do

the

to
accept
of
only
one

as

.
 
<EOS>
Rejecting
his

both
of
cash
and
credit
,
Joe
walked
away
with
stick
and
bundle
as
before
,
bent
upon
getting
through
the
day
as
he
best
could
,
and
going
down
to
the
locksmith
's
in
the
dusk
of
the
evening
;
for
it
should
go
hard
,
he
had
resolved
,
but
he
would
have
a
parting
word
with
charming
Dolly
Varden
.
  
<EOS>
He
went
out
by
Islington
and
so
on
to
Highgate
,
and
sat
on
many
stones
and
gates
,
but
there
were
no
voices
in
the
bells
to
bid
him
turn
.
 
<EOS>
Since
the
time
of
noble
Whittington
,
fair
flower
of
merchants
,
bells
have
come
to
have
less
sympathy
with
humankind
.
<EOS>
They
only
ring
for
money
and
on
state
occasions
.
 
<EOS>
Wanderers
have
increased
in
number
;
ships
leave
the
Thames
for
distant
regions
,
carrying
from
stem
to
stern
no
other
cargo
;
the
bells
are
silent
;
they
ring
out
no
entreaties
or
regrets
;
they
are
used
to
it
and
have
grown
worldly
.
  
<EOS>
Joe
bought
a
roll
,
and
reduced
his
purse
to
the
condition
(
with
a
difference
)
of
that
celebrated
purse
of
Fortunatus
,
which
,
whatever
were
its
favoured
owner
's
necessities
,
had
one
unvarying
amount
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
In
these
real
times
,
when
all
the
Fairies
are
dead
and

,
there
are
still
a
great
many
purses
which
possess
that
quality
.
 
<EOS>
The
sum
-
total
they
contain
is
expressed
in
arithmetic
by
a
circle
,
and
whether
it
be
added
to
or
multiplied
by
its
own
amount
,
the
result
of
the
problem
is
more
easily
stated
than
any
known
in
figures
.
  
<EOS>
Evening
drew
on
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
desolate
and
solitary
feeling
of
one
who
had
no
home
or

,
and
was
alone

in
the
world
for
the
first

,
he
bent
his

towards
the
locksmith
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
delayed
till
now
,
knowing
that
Mrs
Varden
sometimes
went
out
alone
,
or
with
Miggs
for
her
sole

,
to

in
the
evening
;
and
devoutly

that
this
might

her

.
  
<EOS>
He
had
walked
up
and
down

the
house
,
on
the

side
of
the
way
,
two
or

,
when

,
he

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
Dolly
's
---
to
whom
else
could
it
belong
?
<EOS>
no
dress
but
hers
had
such
a
flow
as
that
.
 
<EOS>
He
plucked
up
his
spirits
,
and
followed
it
into
the
workshop
of
the
Golden
Key
.
  
<EOS>
His
darkening
the
door
caused
her
to
look
round
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
that
face
!
<EOS>
"
If
it
had
n't
been
for
that
,
"
thought
Joe
,
"
I
should
never
have
walked
into
poor
Tom
Cobb
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
twenty
times
handsomer
than
ever
.
<EOS>
She
might
marry
a
Lord
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
did
n't
say
this
.
 
<EOS>
He
only
thought
it
---
perhaps
looked
it
also
.
<EOS>
Dolly
was
glad
to
see
him
,
and
was
SO

father
and

were
away

.
 
<EOS>
Joe
begged
she
would
n't
mention
it
on
any

.
  
<EOS>
Dolly
hesitated
to
lead

into
the

,
for

was
nearly

;
at

hesitated
to
stand

in
the

,

was
yet

and

to

.
 
<EOS>
They
had
got
by
some
means
,
too
,
before
the
little
forge
;
and
Joe
having
her

in

(

,
<EOS>
for
Dolly

,

,
that

the

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have

,
"

,
"
to
say

bye
<EOS>
---
to
say
<EOS>
good
-
bye
<EOS>
for
I
do
n't

years
;
perhaps

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
abroad
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Now
this
was
exactly
what
he
should
not

.
 
<EOS>
Here

was
,
talking

vowed

<EOS>
the

;
and

<EOS>
Dolly

"

!
"
 
<EOS>
She

that
it
was

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"
without

.
 
<EOS>
I
had

the

to
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Dolly
was
more

that

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
And
how
WAS
Mr
Willet
---
that

---
   
<EOS>
"
Is

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
All
!
 
<EOS>
Good

,
what

!
 
<EOS>
She

;
---

.
  
<EOS>
Joe
had
small

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
He

"

"

?
"

"

,

that

.
  
<EOS>
Dolly
in

,

,
and

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
At

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
"
---

---

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Come
,
"

,

,
"
Dolly
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

---

,

,
not

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

,
are

,

;
and

!
 
<EOS>
Heaven

<EOS>
I

;
but

.
 
<EOS>
Say
something
kind

.
 
<EOS>
I

no

to
expect

you
,
I

,

I

I

,

shall

all

.
 
<EOS>
Dolly
,

,

nothing

?
"
  
<EOS>
No
.
 
Nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Dolly
was
a

nature
,
and
a

.
<EOS>
She
had
no

of
being

by

in

.
 
<EOS>
The

would
have
been
dissolved
in

,
and
would

knelt

,
and
called

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Joe

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"
twice
.
 
<EOS>
Take

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Every

,

.
 
<EOS>
God

!
"
  
<EOS>
He

,

.
 
<EOS>
Dolly

,
thinking

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
that

<EOS>
She

.
  
<EOS>
"
Have

,
"

,
"

!
<EOS>
am

,
Fortun
'
,

---

?
"
  
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
"
If

,
"

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
Sleep

.
 
<EOS>
Tremble
,
Willet
,

.
 
<EOS>
She
's

!
<EOS>
She
's

!
"
  
<EOS>
With

,

.
 
<EOS>
That

,

even

,

,

,

and

.
  
<EOS>
Joe
,
disconsolate
and
down

,
but
full

,
on
leaving

locksmith
's
house
made

to
the

,
and
there

for

the

,
who
,

less
,

.
 
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
five
minutes
after
his

at
that
house
of

,
he
was
enrolled
among
the
gallant

of
his
native
land
;
and
within

,
was
regaled
with

of

and

,
prepared
,
as
his
friend
assured

more

,
at
the

of
his
most
Sacred
Majesty
the
King
.
 
<EOS>
To
this

,
which
tasted
very
savoury
after
his

,
he
did
ample
justice
;
and
when
he
had

it
up
,

,
with
a

,
he

to
a
straw

in

over

,
and
locked

for
the

.
  
<EOS>
The
next
morning
,
he
found
that
the
obliging
care
of
his
martial
friend
had
decorated
his
hat
with
sundry
particoloured

,
which
made
a
very
lively
appearance
;
and
in
company
with
that
officer
,
and
three
other
military
gentlemen
newly
enrolled
,
who
were
under
a
cloud
<EOS>
so
dense
that
it
only
left
three
shoes
,
a

,
and
a
coat
and
a
half
visible
among

,
repaired
to

.
 
<EOS>
Here
they
were
joined
by
a

and
four
more

,
of

were

and

,
and
two
sober

,
but
each
of
whom
,

Joe
,

and

.
 
<EOS>
The
party
embarked
in
a
passage
-
boat
bound
for
Gravesend
,
whence
<EOS>
they
were
to
proceed
on
foot
to
Chatham
;
the
wind
was
in
their
favour
,
and
they
soon
left
London
behind
them
,
a
mere
dark
mist
---
a
giant
phantom
in
the
air
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
32
    
Misfortunes
,
saith
the
adage
,
never
come
singly
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
little
doubt
that
troubles
are
exceedingly
gregarious
in
their
nature
,
and
flying
in
flocks
,
are
apt
to
perch
capriciously
;
crowding
on
the
heads
of
some
poor
wights
until
there
is
not
an
inch
of
room
left
on
their
unlucky
crowns
,
and
taking
no
more
notice
of
others
who
offer
as
good
resting
-
places
for
the
soles
of
their
feet
,
than
if
they
had
no
existence
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
have
happened
that
a
flight
of
troubles
brooding
over
London
,
and
looking
out
for
Joseph
Willet
,
whom
they
could
n't
find
,
darted
down
haphazard
on
the
first
young
man
that
caught
their
fancy
,
and
settled
on
him
instead
.
 
<EOS>
However
this
may
be
,
<EOS>
certain
it
is
that
on
the
very
day
of
Joe
's
departure
they
swarmed
about
the
ears
of
Edward
Chester
,
and
did
so
buzz
and
flap
their
wings
,
and
persecute
him
,
that
he
was
most
profoundly
wretched
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
evening
,
and
just
eight
o'clock
,
when
he
and
his
father
,
having
wine
and
dessert
set
before
them
,
were
left
to
themselves
for
the
first
time
that
day
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
dined
together
,
but
a
third
person
had
been
present
during
the
meal
,
and
until
they
met
at
table
they
had
not
seen
each
other
since
the
previous
night
.
  
<EOS>
Edward
was
reserved
and
silent
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chester
was
more
than
usually
gay
;
but
not
caring
,
as
it
seemed
,
to
open
a
conversation
with
one
whose
humour
was
so
different
,
he
vented
the
lightness
of
his
spirit
in
smiles
and
sparkling
looks
,
and
made
no
effort
to
awaken
his
attention
.
 
<EOS>
So
they
remained
for
some
time
:
the
father
lying
on
a
sofa
with
his
accustomed
air
of
graceful
negligence
;
the
son
seated
opposite
to
him
with
downcast
eyes
,
busied
<EOS>
,
it
was
plain
,
with
painful
and
uneasy
thoughts
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Edward
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
at
length
,
with
a
most
engaging
laugh
,
"
do
not
extend
your
drowsy
influence
to
the
decanter
.
<EOS>
Suffer
THAT
to
circulate
,
let
your
spirits
be
never
so
stagnant
.
"
  
<EOS>
Edward
begged
his
pardon
,
passed
it
,
and
relapsed
into
his
former
state
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
wrong
not
to
fill
your
glass
,
"
said
Mr
Chester
,
holding
up
his
own
before
the
light
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wine
in
moderation
---
not
in
excess
,
for
that
makes
men
ugly
---
has
a
thousand
pleasant
influences
.
 
<EOS>
It
brightens
the
eye
,
improves
the
voice
,
imparts
a
new
vivacity
to
one
's
thoughts
and
conversation
<EOS>
:
you
should
try
it
,
Ned
.
"
  
"
Ah
father
!
"
<EOS>

,
"
if
---
"
  
"
My

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
Have

.
 
<EOS>
Am

grey
,
or
wrinkled
<EOS>
,

,

?
 
<EOS>
Good

,
how
very

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

,
"
in
the

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now

,

"

,

"
talk

.
 
<EOS>
About
to

from

heart
.
 
<EOS>
Do

the

an

---
the

the

-

---

?
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
These

.
 
<EOS>
They

really

.
 
<EOS>
You

,
Ned
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
there

no

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
know
your
creed
,
sir
,
and
will

no

,
"
returned

.
  
<EOS>
"
There

,
"

Chester
,
sipping

,
"
you
are
wrong
.
<EOS>
I
distinctly
say
there
are
such

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
The

---

---

<EOS>
Men

;
but
as
to
speaking

,

the

,

,

<EOS>
pah
!
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

,
"

"
No

.
<EOS>
"

"

she

.
 
<EOS>
Yet

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
"
You

,

"

<EOS>
"
Poor

!
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
---

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

,

;

,

---
but

never

ourselves
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>

,

;

<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
Marriage

;

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
You

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"
Edward
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
I
remember

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
led
a

life
(
the
son
,
I

)
and
died
early
;
it
was

on

;

degraded

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
Edward
,
when

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"

Edward
,
"
and
it
is
sad

a
son
,
proffering

his

their

,
<EOS>
finds

,

.
 
<EOS>
Dear

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
Let

;

.
 
<EOS>
Hear

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

"
but

will
be
<EOS>
but
empty

.
 
<EOS>
I

---

.
 
<EOS>
Beware

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

,

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

.
 
<EOS>
Return

,

.
 
<EOS>
Go
,

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Good

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Edward
left

room
without
another

or

,
and
turned
his

upon

house
for

.
  
<EOS>
The
father
's
face
was
slightly
flushed
and
heated
,
but
his
manner
was
quite
unchanged
,
as
he
rang
the
bell
again
,
and
addressed
the
servant
on
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
Peak
---
if
that
gentleman
who
has
just
gone
out
---
"
  
"
I
beg
your

,

,
Mr
Edward
?
"
  
"
Were
there
more
than
one
,
dolt
,
that
you
ask
the
question
?
---
<EOS>
If
that
gentleman
should
send
here
for
his
wardrobe
,
let
him
have

,
do
you
hear
?
 
<EOS>
If
he
should
call
himself
at
any

,
I
'm
not
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
tell
him
so
,
and
shut
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
,
it
soon
got
whispered
about
,
that
Mr
Chester
was
very
unfortunate
in
his
son
,
who
had
occasioned
him
great
grief
and
sorrow
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
good
people
who
heard
this
and
told
it
again
,
marvelled
the
more
at
his
equanimity
and
even
temper
,
and
said
what
an
amiable
nature
that
man
must
have
,
who
,
having
undergone
so
much
,
could
be
so
placid
and
so
calm
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
Edward
's
name
was
spoken
,
Society
shook
its
head
,
and
laid
its
finger
on
its
lip
,
and
sighed
,
and
looked
very
grave
;
and
those
who
had
sons
about
his
age
,
waxed
wrathful
and
indignant
,
and
hoped
,
for
Virtue
's
sake
,
that
he
was
dead
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
world
went
on
turning
round
,
as
usual
,
for
five
years
,
concerning
which
this
Narrative
is
silent
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
33
    
<EOS>
One
wintry
evening
,
early
in
the
year
of
our
Lord
one
thousand
seven
hundred
and
eighty
,
<EOS>
a
keen
north
wind
arose
as
it
grew
dark
,
and
night
came
on
with
black
and
dismal
looks
.
 
<EOS>
A
bitter
storm
of
sleet
,
sharp
,
dense
,
and
icy
-
cold
,
swept
the
wet
streets
,
and
rattled
on
the
trembling
windows
.
 
<EOS>
Signboards
,
shaken
past
endurance
in
their
creaking
frames
,
fell
crashing
on
the
pavement
;
old
tottering
chimneys
reeled
and
staggered
in
the
blast
;
and
many
a
steeple
rocked
again
that
night
,
as
though
the
earth
were
troubled
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
time
for
those
who
could
by
any
means
get
light
and
warmth
,
to
brave
the
fury
of
the
weather
.
 
<EOS>
In
coffee
-
houses
of
the
better
sort
,
guests
crowded
round
the
fire
,
forgot
to
be
political
,
and
told
each
other
with
a
secret
gladness
that
the
blast
grew
fiercer
every
minute
.
 
<EOS>
Each
humble
tavern
by
the
water
-
side
,
had
its
group
of
uncouth
figures
round
the
hearth
,
who
talked
of
vessels
foundering
at
sea
,
and
all
hands
lost
;
related
many
a
dismal
tale
of
shipwreck
and
drowned
men
,
and
hoped
that
some
they
knew
were
safe
,
and
shook
their
heads
in
doubt
.
 
<EOS>
In
private
dwellings
,
children
clustered
near
the
blaze
;
listening
with
timid
pleasure
to
tales
of
ghosts
and
goblins
,
and
tall
figures
clad
in
white
standing
by
bed
-
sides
,
and
people
who
had
gone
to
sleep
in
old
churches
and
being
overlooked
had
found
themselves
alone
there
at
the
dead
hour
of
the
night
:
until
they
shuddered
at
the
thought
of
the
dark
rooms
upstairs
,
yet
loved
to
hear
the
wind
moan
too
,
and
hoped
it
would
continue
bravely
.
 
<EOS>
From
time
to
time
these
happy
indoor
people
stopped
to
listen
,
or
one
held
up
his
finger
and
cried
"
Hark
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
,
above
the
rumbling
in
the
chimney
,
and
the
fast
pattering
on
the
glass
,
was
heard
a
wailing
,
rushing
sound
,
which
shook
the
walls
as
though
a
giant
's
hand
were
on
them
;
then
a
hoarse
roar
as
if
the
sea
had
risen
;
then
such
a
whirl
and
tumult
that
the
air
seemed
mad
;
and
then
,
with
a
lengthened
howl
,
the
waves
of
wind
swept
on
,
and
left
a
moment
's
interval
of
rest
.
  
<EOS>
Cheerily
,
though
there
were
none
abroad
to
see
it
,
shone
the
Maypole
light
that
evening
.
 
<EOS>
Blessings
on
the
red
---
deep
,
ruby
,
glowing
red
---
old
curtain
of
the
window
;
blending
into
one
rich
stream
of
brightness
,
fire
and
candle
,
meat
,
drink
,
and
company
,
and
gleaming
like
a
jovial
eye
upon
the
bleak
waste
out
of
doors
!
<EOS>
Within
,
what
carpet
like
its
crunching
sand
,
what
music
merry
as
its
crackling
logs
,
what
perfume
like
its
kitchen
's
dainty
breath
,
what
weather
genial
as
its
hearty
warmth
!
 
<EOS>
Blessings
on
the
old
house
,
how
sturdily
it
stood
!
 
<EOS>
How
did
the
vexed
wind
chafe
and
roar
about
its
stalwart
roof
;
how
did
it
pant
and
strive
with
its
wide
chimneys
,
which
still
poured
forth
from
their
hospitable
throats
,
great
clouds
of
smoke
,
and
puffed
defiance
in
its
face
;
how
,
above
all
,
did
it
drive
and
rattle
at
the
casement
,
emulous
to
extinguish
that
cheerful
glow
,
which
would
not
be
put
down
and
seemed
the
brighter
for
the
conflict
!
  
<EOS>
The
profusion
too
,
the
rich
and
lavish
bounty
,
of
that
goodly
tavern
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
enough
that
one
fire
roared
and
sparkled
on
its
spacious
hearth
;
in
the
tiles
which
paved
and
compassed
it
,
five
hundred
flickering
fires
burnt
brightly
also
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
enough
that
one
red
curtain
shut
the
wild
night
out
,
and
shed
its
cheerful
influence
on
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
In
every
saucepan
lid
,
and
candlestick
,
and
vessel
of
copper
,
brass
,
or
tin
that
hung
upon
the
walls
,
were
countless
ruddy
hangings
,
flashing
and
gleaming
with
every
motion
of
the
blaze
,
and
offering
,
<EOS>
let
the
eye
wander
where
it
might
,
interminable
vistas
of
the
same
rich
colour
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
oak
wainscoting
,
the
beams
,
the
chairs
,
the
seats
,
reflected
it
in
a
deep
,
dull
glimmer
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
fires
and
red
curtains
in
the
very
eyes
of
the
drinkers
,
in
their
buttons
,
in
their
liquor
,
in
the
pipes
they
smoked
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
sat
in
what
had
been
his
accustomed
place
five
years
before
,
with
his
eyes
on
the
eternal
boiler
;
and
had
sat
there
since
the
clock
struck
eight
,
giving
no
other
signs
of
life
than
breathing
with
a
loud
and
constant
snore
(
though
he
was
wide
awake
)
,
and
from
time
to
time
putting
his
glass
to
his
lips
,
or
knocking
the
ashes
out
of
his
pipe
,
and
filling
it
anew
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
now
half
-
past
ten
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Cobb
and
long
Phil
Parkes
were
his
companions
,
as
of
old
,
and
for
two
mortal
hours
and
a
half
,
none
of
the
company
had
pronounced
one
word
.
  
<EOS>
Whether
people
,
by
dint
of
sitting
together
in
the
same
place
and
the
same
relative
positions
,
and
doing
exactly
the
same
things
for
a
great
many
years
,
acquire
a
sixth
sense
,
or
some
unknown
power
of
influencing
each
other
which
serves
them
in
its
stead
,
is
a
question
for
philosophy
to
settle
.
 
<EOS>
But
certain
it
is
that
old
John
Willet
,
Mr
Parkes
,
and
Mr
Cobb
,
were
one
and
all
firmly
of
opinion
that
they
were
very
jolly
companions
---
rather
choice
spirits
than
otherwise
;
that
they
looked
at
each
other
every
now
<EOS>
and
then
as
if
there
were
a
perpetual
interchange
of
ideas
going
on
among
them
;
that
no
man
considered
himself
or
his
neighbour
by
any
means
silent
;
and
that
each
of
them
nodded
occasionally
when
he
caught
the
eye
of
another
,
as
if
he
would
say
,
"
You
have
expressed
yourself
extremely
well
,
sir
,
in
relation
to
that
sentiment
,
and
I
quite
agree
with
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
room
was
so
very
warm
,
the
tobacco
so
very
good
,
and
the
fire
so
very
soothing
,
that
Mr
Willet
by
degrees
began
to
doze
;
but
as
he
had
perfectly
acquired
,
by
dint
of
long
habit
,
the
art
of
smoking
in
his
sleep
,
and
as
his
breathing
was
pretty
much
the
same
,
awake
or
asleep
,
saving
that
in
the
latter
case
he
sometimes
experienced
a
slight
difficulty
in
respiration
(
such
as
a
carpenter
meets
with
when
he
is
planing
and
comes
to
a
knot
)
,
neither
of
his
companions
was
aware
of
the
circumstance
,
until
he
met
with
one
of
these
impediments
and
was
obliged
to
try
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Johnny
's
dropped
off
,
"
said
Mr
Parkes
in
a
whisper
.
  
<EOS>
"
Fast
as
a
top
,
"
said
Mr
Cobb
.
  
<EOS>
Neither
of
them
said
any
more
until
Mr
Willet
came
to
another
knot
---
 
one
of
surpassing
obduracy
---
which
bade
fair
to
throw
him
into
convulsions
,
but
which
he
got
over
at
last
without
waking
,
by
an
effort
quite
superhuman
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
sleeps
uncommon
hard
,
"
said
Mr
Cobb
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Parkes
,
who
was
possibly
a
hard
-
sleeper
himself
,
replied
with
some
disdain
,
"
Not
a
bit
on
it
;
"
and
directed
his
eyes
towards
a
handbill
pasted
over
the
chimney
-
piece
,
which
was
decorated
at
the
top
with
a
woodcut
representing
a
youth
of
tender
years
running
away
very
fast
,
with
a
bundle
over
his
shoulder
at
the
end
of
a
stick
,
and
---
to
carry
out
the
idea
---
a
finger
-
post
and
a
milestone
beside
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Cobb
likewise
turned
his
eyes
in
the
same
direction
,
and
surveyed
the
placard
as
if
that
were
the
first
time
he
had
ever
beheld
it
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
this
was
a
document
which
Mr
Willet
had
himself
indited
on
the
disappearance
of
his
son
Joseph
,
acquainting
the
nobility
and
gentry
and
the
public
in
general
with
the
circumstances
of
his
having
left
his
home
;
describing
his
dress
and
appearance
;
and
offering
a
reward
of
five
pounds
to
any
person
or
persons
who
would
pack
him
up
and
return
him
safely
to
the
Maypole
at
Chigwell
,
or
lodge
him
in
any
of
his
Majesty
's
jails
until
such
time
as
his
father
should
come
and
claim
him
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
advertisement
Mr
Willet
had
obstinately
persisted
,
despite
the
advice
and
entreaties
of
his
friends
,
in
describing
his
son
as
a
"
young
boy
;
"
and
furthermore
as
being
from
eighteen
inches
to
a
couple
of
feet
shorter
than
he
really
was
;
two
circumstances
which
perhaps
accounted
,
in
some
degree
,
for
its
never
having
been
productive
of
any
other
effect
than
the
transmission
to
Chigwell
at
various
times
and
at
a
vast
expense
,
of
some
five
-
and
-
forty
runaways
varying
from
six
years
old
to
twelve
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Cobb
and
Mr
Parkes
looked
mysteriously
at
this
composition
,
at
each
other
,
and
at
old
John
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
time
he
had
pasted
it
up
with
his
own
hands
,
Mr
Willet
had
never
by
word
or
sign
alluded
to
the
subject
,
or
encouraged
any
one
else
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
had
the
least
notion
what
his
thoughts
or
opinions
were
,
connected
with
it
;
whether
he
remembered
it
or
forgot
it
;
whether
he
had
any
idea
that
such
an
event
had
ever
taken
place
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,
even
while
he
slept
,
no
one
ventured
to
refer
to
it
in
his
presence
;
and
for
such
sufficient
reasons
,
these
his
chosen
friends
were
silent
now
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
had
got
by
this
time
into
such
a
complication
of
knots
,
that
it
was
perfectly
clear
he
must
wake
or
die
.
 
<EOS>
He
chose
the
former
alternative
,
and
opened
his
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
he
do
n't
come
in
five
minutes
,
"
said
John
,
"
I
shall
have
supper
without
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
antecedent
of
this
pronoun
had
been
mentioned
for
the
last
time
at
eight
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
Messrs
Parkes
and
Cobb
being
used
to
this
style
of
conversation
,
replied
without
difficulty
that
to
be
sure
Solomon
was
very
late
,
and
they
wondered
what
had
happened
to
detain
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
an't
blown
away
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Parkes
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
enough
to
carry
a
man
of
his
figure
off
his
legs
,
and
easy
too
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
it
?
 
<EOS>
It
blows
great
guns
,
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
There
'll
be
many
a
crash
in
the
Forest
to
-
night
,
I
reckon
,
and
many
a
broken
branch
upon
the
ground
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
wo
n't
break
anything
in
the
Maypole
<EOS>
,
I
take
it
,
sir
,
"
returned
old
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
it
try
.
 
<EOS>
I
give
it
<EOS>
leave
---
<EOS>
what
's
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
wind
,
"
cried
Parkes
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
howling
like
a
Christian
,
and
has
been
all
night
long
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
ever
,
sir
,
"
asked
John
,
after
a
minute
's
contemplation
,
"
hear
the
wind
say
"
Maypole
"
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
man
ever
did
?
"
said
Parkes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
"
ahoy
,
"
perhaps
?
"
added
John
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
Nor
that
neither
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Very
good
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Willet
,
perfectly
unmoved
;
"
then
if
that
was
the
wind
just
now
,
<EOS>
and
you
'll
wait
a
little
time
without
speaking
<EOS>
,
you
'll
hear
it
say
both
words
very
plain
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
was
right
.
 
<EOS>
After
listening
for
a
few
moments
,
they
could
clearly
hear
,
above
the
roar
and
tumult
out
of
doors
,
this
shout
repeated
;
and
that
with
a
shrillness
and
energy
,
which
denoted
that
it
came
from
some
person
in
great
distress
or
terror
.
 
<EOS>
They
looked
at
each
other
,
turned
pale
,
and
held
their
breath
.
 
<EOS>
No
man
stirred
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
in
this
emergency
that
Mr
Willet
displayed
something
of
that
strength
of
mind
and
plenitude
of
mental
resource
,
which
rendered
him
the
admiration
of
all
his
friends
and
neighbours
.
 
<EOS>
After
looking
at
Messrs
Parkes
and
Cobb
for
some
time
in
silence
,
he
clapped
his
two
hands
to
his
cheeks
,
and
sent
forth
a
roar
which
made
the
glasses
dance
and
rafters
ring
---
a
long
-
sustained
,
discordant
bellow
,
that
rolled
onward
with
the
wind
,
and
startling
every
echo
,
made
the
night
a
hundred
times
more
boisterous
---
a
deep
,
loud
,
dismal
bray
,
that
sounded
like
a
human
gong
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
with
every
vein
in
his
head
and
face
swollen
with
the
great
exertion
,
and
his
countenance
suffused
with
a
lively
purple
,
he
drew
a
little
nearer
to
the
fire
,
and
turning
his
back
upon
it
,
said
with
dignity
:
  
<EOS>
"
If
that
's
any
comfort
to
anybody
,
they
're
welcome
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
an't
,
I
'm
sorry
for
'em
.
 
<EOS>
If
either
of
you
two
gentlemen
likes
to
go
out
and
see
what
's
the
matter
,
you
can
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
not
curious
,
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
While
he
spoke
the
cry
drew
nearer
and
nearer
,
footsteps
passed
the
window
,
the
latch
of
the
door
was
raised
,
it
opened
,
was
violently
shut
again
,
and
Solomon
Daisy
,
with
a
lighted
lantern
in
his
hand
,
and
the
rain
streaming
from
his
disordered
dress
,
dashed
into
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
A
more
complete
picture
of
terror
than
the
little
man
presented
,
it
would
be
difficult
to
imagine
.
 
<EOS>
The
perspiration
stood
in
beads
upon
his
face
,
his
knees
knocked
together
,
his
every
limb
trembled
,
the
power
of
articulation
was
quite
gone
;
and
there
he
stood
,
panting
for
breath
,
gazing
on
them
with
such
livid
ashy
looks
,
that
they
were
infected
with
his
fear
,
though
ignorant
of
its
occasion
,
and
,
reflecting
his
dismayed
and
horror
-
stricken
visage
,
stared
back
again
without
venturing
to
question
him
;
until
old
John
Willet
,
in
a
fit
of
temporary
insanity
,
made
a
dive
at
his
cravat
,
and
,
seizing
him
by
that
portion
of
his
dress
,
shook
him
to
and
fro
until
his
very
teeth
appeared
to
rattle
in
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
us
what
's
the
matter
,
sir
,
"
said
John
,
"
or
I
'll
kill
you
.
<EOS>
Tell
us
what
's
the
matter
,
sir
,
or
in
another
second
I
'll
have
your
head
under
the
biler
.
 
<EOS>
How
dare
you
look
like
that
?
 
<EOS>
Is
anybody
a
-
following
of
you
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
?
 
<EOS>
Say
something
,
or
I
'll
be
the
death
of
you
,
I
will
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
,
in
his
frenzy
,
was
so
near
keeping
his
word
to
the
very
letter
<EOS>
(
Solomon
Daisy
's
eyes
already
beginning
to
roll
in
an
alarming
manner
,
and
certain
guttural
sounds
,
as
of
a
choking
man
,
to
issue
from
his
throat
)
,
that
the
two
bystanders
,
recovering
in
some
degree
,
plucked
him
off
his
victim
by
main
force
,
and
placed
the
little
clerk
of
Chigwell
in
a
chair
.
 
<EOS>
Directing
a
fearful
gaze
all
round
the
room
,
he
implored
them
in
a
faint
voice
to
give
him
some
drink
;
and
above
all
to
lock
the
house
-
door
and
close
and
bar
the
shutters
of
the
room
,
without
a
moment
's
loss
of
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
request
did
not
tend
to
reassure
his
hearers
,
or
to
fill
them
with
the
most
comfortable
sensations
;
they
complied
with
it
,
however
,
with
the
greatest
expedition
;
and
having
handed
him
a
bumper
of
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
nearly
boiling
hot
,
waited
to
hear
what
he
might
have
to
tell
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Johnny
,
"
said
Solomon
,
shaking
him
by
the
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Parkes
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
Tommy
Cobb
.
 
<EOS>
Why
did
I
leave
this
house
to
-
night
!
 
<EOS>
On
the
nineteenth
of
March
---
of
all
nights
in
the
year
,
on
the
nineteenth
of
March
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
all
drew
closer
to
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Parkes
,
who
was
nearest
to
the
door
,
started
and
looked
over
his
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
,
with
great
indignation
,
inquired
what
the
devil
he
meant
by
that
---
and
then
said
,
"
God
forgive
me
,
"
and
glanced
over
his
own
shoulder
,
and
came
a
little
nearer
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
left
here
to
-
night
,
"
said
Solomon
Daisy
,
"
I
little
thought
what
day
of
the
month
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
gone
alone
into
the
church
after
dark
on
this
day
,
for
seven
-
and
-
twenty
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
heard
it
said
that
as
we
keep
our
birthdays
when
we
are
alive
,
so
the
ghosts
of
dead
people
,
who
are
not
easy
in
their
graves
,
keep
the
day
they
died
upon
.
<EOS>
---
How
the
wind
roars
!
"
  
<EOS>
Nobody
spoke
.
 
<EOS>
All
eyes
were
fastened
on
Solomon
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
might
have
known
,
"
he
said
,
"
what
night
it
was
,
by
the
foul
weather
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
no
such
night
in
the
whole
year
round
as
this
is
,
always
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
sleep
quietly
in
my
bed
on
the
nineteenth
of
March
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Go
on
,
"
said
Tom
Cobb
,
in
a
low
