.
 
<EOS>
"
Nor
I
neither
.
"
  
<EOS>
Solomon
Daisy
raised
his
glass
to
his
lips
;
put
it
down
upon
the
floor
with
such
a
trembling
hand
that
the
spoon
tinkled
in
it
like
a
little
bell
;
and
continued
thus
:
  
<EOS>
"
Have
I
ever
said
that
we
are
always
brought
back
to
this
subject
in
some
strange
way
,
when
the
nineteenth
of
this
month
comes
round
?
<EOS>
Do
you
suppose
it
was
by

,
I
forgot

wind

church
-
clock
?
 
<EOS>
I
never
forgot
it
at
any
other
time
,
though
it
's
such
a
clumsy
thing
that
it
has
to
be
wound
up
every

.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
it
escape
my
memory
on
this
day
of
all

?
  
<EOS>
"
I
made
as
much
haste
down
there
as
I
could
when
I
went
from
here
,
but
I
had
to
go
home
first
for
the
keys
;
and
the
wind
and
rain
being
dead
against
me
all
the
way
<EOS>
,
it
was
pretty
well
as
much
as
I
could
do
at
times
to
keep

.
 
<EOS>
I
got
there
at
last
,
opened
the
church
-

,
and
went
in
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
not
met
a
soul
all
the
way
,
and
you
may
judge
whether
it
was

or
not
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
of
you
would
bear
me
company
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
could
have
known
what
was
to
come
,
you
'd
have
been
in
the
right
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
wind
was
so
strong
,
that
it
was
as
much
as
I
could
do
to
shut
the
church

door
by
putting

against

;
and
even

,

twice
,
with

that
any

,
if

,

,
that

.
 
<EOS>
However
,
I
got
the
key

,
went
into

,
and
wound

clock
---
which
was
very

,
and
would

.
  
<EOS>
"
As

,

all
at

that
this
was
the
nineteenth
of
March
.
 
<EOS>
It

with
a
kind

shock
,
<EOS>
as

struck
the

;

,
I

outside

---
rising

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Here
old
John
precipitately

,
and

that

Mr
Parkes
(
who

)

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Parkes
apologised
,
and
remarked
that
he
was
only

;
to

Mr
Willet
angrily
retorted
,
that
his

with
that

,

could
n't

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Parkes
with
great

pledged
himself
to
do

,
if
again
required
,
and
John
Willet
turning

Solomon
desired

.
 
<EOS>
After

until
a

of
wind
and

,
which
seemed
to
shake
even
that
sturdy
house
to

,
had

,
the

:
  
"
<EOS>
Never
tell

that
it
was
my

,
or
that
it

any
other
sound
which
I
mistook
for
that
I

of
.
 
<EOS>
I

through
the

the

.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
the
steeple
strain
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
the
rain
as
it
came
driving
against

.
 
<EOS>
I

the

shake
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
the

to
and
fro
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
heard
that
voice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
did

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
;
I
do
n't

spoke
.
 
<EOS>
It
gave
a
kind

,
as
any

,

;
and

:

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

"

,

,

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

a

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
I
saw
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Saw
!
"
echoed

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
When

,
"

,

,
"

I

,

,

,

---

,

by

I

---
something

.
 
<EOS>
It

bare

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

---
 
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whose
?
"
they

<EOS>
In

(
for

.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Who

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
"

"

.
<EOS>
The
likeness
of
a

.
 
<EOS>
This

the
nineteenth
of
March
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
A

.
  
<EOS>
"
If

,
"

,
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Such

would
not

at

.
<EOS>
Let

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Whether

,

,

.
<EOS>
Right

,

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

do

,
"

,

,

,
"

,

in
such
weather
<EOS>
---
I

,

was

.
"
  
<EOS>
But
this
heretical
doctrine
was
strongly
opposed
by
the
other
three
,
who
quoted
a
great
many

to
show
that
bad

was

for
such

;
and
Mr
Parkes
(
who
had
had
a
ghost
in
his

,
by
the
mother
's

)
argued
the

with

and

of

,
that
John
was
only

from

to

by

of

,
to
which
they

themselves
with
a

.
 
<EOS>
Even
Solomon
Daisy
himself
,
by
dint
of
the
elevating

of
fire
,
lights
,
brandy
,
and
good
company
,
so
far

as
to
handle

in

,

a

both
of

and

,
such

banished
all
fear
of
his
having
sustained
any

from
his

.
  
<EOS>
Supper
done
,
they
crowded
round
the
fire
again
,
and
,
as
is
common
on
such
occasions
,
propounded
all
manner
of
leading
questions
calculated
to
surround
the
story
with
new

and
surprises
.
<EOS>
But
Solomon
Daisy
,
notwithstanding
these
temptations
,
adhered
so
steadily
to
his
original
account
,
and
repeated
it
so
often
,
with
such
slight
variations
,
and
with
such
solemn
asseverations
of
its
truth
and
reality
,
that
his
hearers
were
(
with

)
more

than

first
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
took
John
Willet
's
view
of
the
matter
in
regard
to
the
propriety
of
not
bruiting

tale
abroad
,
unless
the
spirit
should
appear
to

again
,
in

with

,
it
was
solemnly
resolved
that
it

and

.
<EOS>
And
as
most
men
like
to
have
a
secret
to
tell
which
may
exalt
their
own
importance
,
they
arrived
at
this
conclusion
with
perfect

.
  
<EOS>
As
it
was
by
this
time
growing
late
,
and
was
long
past
their
usual
hour
of
separating
,
the
cronies
parted
for
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
Solomon
Daisy
,
with
a
fresh

in
his
lantern
,
repaired
homewards
under
the
escort
of
long
Phil
Parkes
and
Mr
Cobb
,
who
were
rather
more
nervous
than
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
,
after
seeing
them
to
the
door
,
returned
to
collect
his
thoughts
with
the
assistance
of
the
boiler
,
and
to
listen
to
the
storm
of
wind
and
rain
,
which
had
not
yet
abated
one
jot
of
its
fury
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
34
    
Before
old
John
had
looked
at
the
boiler
quite
twenty
minutes
,
he
got
his
ideas
into
a
focus
,
and
brought
them
to
bear
upon
Solomon
Daisy
's
story
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
he
thought
of
it
,
the
more
impressed
he
became
with
a
sense
of
his
own
wisdom
,
and
a
desire
that
Mr
Haredale
should
be
impressed
with
it
likewise
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
to
the
end
that
he
might
sustain
a
principal
and
important
character
in
the
affair
;
and
might
have
the
start
of
Solomon
and
his
two
friends
,
through
whose
means
he
knew
the
adventure
,
with
a
variety
of
exaggerations
,
would
be
known
to
at
least
a
score
of
people
,
and
most
likely
to
Mr
Haredale
himself
,
by
breakfast
-
time
to
-
morrow
;
he
determined
to
repair
to
the
Warren
before
going
to
bed
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
my
landlord
,
"
thought
John
,
as
he
took
a
candle
in
his
hand
,
and
setting
it
down
in
a
corner
out
of
the
wind
's
way
,
opened
a
casement
in
the
rear
of
the
house
,
looking
towards
the
stables
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
n't
met
of
late
years
so
often
as
we
used
to
do
---
changes
are
taking
place
in
the
family
<EOS>
---
it
's
desirable
that
I
should
stand
as
well
with
them
,
in
point
of
dignity
,
as
possible
---
<EOS>
the
whispering
about
of
this
here
tale
will
anger
him
<EOS>
---
it
's
good
to
have
confidences
with
a
gentleman
of
his
natur
'
,
and
set
one's
-
self
right
besides
.
 
<EOS>
Halloa
there
!
 
<EOS>
Hugh
---
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
Hal
-
loa
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When
he
had
repeated
this
shout
a
dozen
times
,
and
startled
every
pigeon
from
its
slumbers
,
a
door
in
one
of
the
ruinous
old
buildings
opened
,
and
a
rough
voice
demanded
what
was
amiss
now
,
that
a
man
could
n't
even
have
his
sleep
in
quiet
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
Have
n't
you
sleep
enough
,
growler
,
that
you
're
not
to
be
knocked
up
for
once
?
"
said
John
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
the
voice
,
as
the
speaker
yawned
and
shook
himself
.
<EOS>
"
Not
half
enough
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
how
you
CAN
sleep
,
with
the
wind
a
bellowsing
and
roaring
about
you
,
making
the
tiles
fly
like
a
pack
of
cards
,
"
said
John
;
"
but
no
matter
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
Wrap
yourself
up
in
something
or
another
,
and
come
here
,
for
you
must
go
as
far
as
the
Warren
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
And
look
sharp
about
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
,
with
much
low
growling
and
muttering
,
went
back
into
his
lair
;
and
presently
reappeared
,
carrying
a
lantern
and
a
cudgel
,
and
enveloped
from
head
to
foot
in
an
old
,
frowzy
,
slouching
horse
-
cloth
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
received
this
figure
at
the
back
-
door
,
and
ushered
him
into
the
bar
,
while
he
wrapped
himself
in
sundry
greatcoats
and
capes
,
and
so
tied
and
knotted
his
face
in
shawls
and
handkerchiefs
,
that
how
he
breathed
was
a
mystery
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
take
a
man
out
of
doors
at
near
midnight
in
such
weather
,
without
putting
some
heart
into
him
,
do
you
,
master
?
"
said
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
I
do
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Willet
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
put
the
heart
(
as
you
call
it
)
into
him
when
he
has
brought
me
safe
home
again
,
and
his
standing
steady
on
his
legs
an't
of
so
much
consequence
.
 
<EOS>
So
hold
that
light
up
,
if
you
please
,
and
go
on
a
step
or
two
before
,
to
show
the
way
.
<EOS>
"
  
Hugh
obeyed
with
a
very
indifferent
grace
,
and
a
longing
glance
at
the
bottles
.
 
<EOS>
Old
John
,
laying
strict
injunctions
on
his
cook
to
keep
the
doors
locked
in
his
absence
,
and
to
open
to
nobody
but
himself
on
pain
of
dismissal
,
followed
him
into
the
blustering
darkness
out
of
doors
.
  
<EOS>
The
way
was
wet
and
dismal
,
and
the
night
so
black
,
that
if
Mr
Willet
had
been
his
own
pilot
,
he
would
have
walked
into
a
deep
horsepond
within
a
few
hundred
yards
of
his
own
house
,
and
would
certainly
have
terminated
his
career
in
that
ignoble
sphere
of
action
.
 
<EOS>
But
Hugh
,
who
had
a
sight
as
keen
as
any
hawk
's
,
and
,
apart
from
that
endowment
,
could
have
found
his
way
blindfold
to
any
place
within
a
dozen
miles
,
dragged
old
John
along
,
quite
deaf
to
his
remonstrances
,
and
took
his
own
course
without
the
slightest
reference
to
,
or
notice
of
,
his
master
.
 
<EOS>
So
they
made
head
against
the
wind
as
they
best
could
;
<EOS>
Hugh
crushing
the
wet
grass
beneath
his
heavy
tread
,
and
stalking
on
after
his
ordinary
savage
fashion
;
John
Willet
following
at
arm
's
length
,
picking
his
steps
,
and
looking
about
him
,
now
for
bogs
and
ditches
,
and
now
for
such
stray
ghosts
as
might
be
wandering
abroad
,
with
looks
of
as
much
dismay
and
uneasiness
as
his
immovable
face
was
capable
of
expressing
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
they
stood
upon
the
broad
gravel
-
walk
before
the
Warren
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
building
was
profoundly
dark
,
and
none
were
moving
near
it
save
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
From
one
solitary
turret
-
chamber
,
however
,
there
shone
a
ray
of
light
;
and
towards
this
speck
of
comfort
in
the
cold
,
cheerless
,
silent
scene
,
Mr
Willet
bade
his
pilot
lead
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
old
room
,
"
said
John
,
looking
timidly
upward
;
"
Mr
Reuben
's
own
apartment
<EOS>
,
God
be
with
us
!
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
his
brother
likes
to
sit
there
,
so
late
at
night
---
on
this
night
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
where
else
should
he
sit
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Hugh
,
holding
the
lantern
to
his
breast
,
to
keep
the
candle
from
the
wind
,
while
he
trimmed
it
with
his
fingers
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
snug
enough
,
an't
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Snug
!
"
said
John
indignantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
comfortable
idea
of
snugness
<EOS>
,
you
have
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
what
was
done
in
that
room
,
you
ruffian
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
is
it
the
worse
for
that
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
looking
into
John
's
fat
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
Does
it
keep
out
the
rain
,
and
snow
,
and
wind
,
the
less
for
that
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
less
warm
or
dry
,
because
a
man
was
killed
there
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
 
Never
believe
it
,
master
.
 
<EOS>
One
man
's
no
such
matter
as
that
comes
to
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
fixed
his
dull
eyes
on
his
follower
,
and
began
---
by
a
species
of
inspiration
---
to
think
it
just
barely
possible
that
he
was
something
of
a
dangerous
character
,
and
that
it
might
be
advisable
to
get
rid
of
him
one
of
these
days
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
too
prudent
to
say
anything
,
with
the
journey
home
before
him
;
and
therefore
turned
to
the
iron
gate
before
which
this
brief
dialogue
had
passed
,
and
pulled
the
handle
of
the
bell
that
hung
beside
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
turret
in
which
the
light
appeared
being
at
one
corner
of
the
building
,
and
only
divided
from
the
path
by
one
of
the
garden
-
walks
,
upon
which
this
gate
opened
<EOS>
,
Mr
Haredale
threw
up
the
window
directly
,
and
demanded
who
was
there
.
  
<EOS>
"
Begging
pardon
,
sir
,
"
said
John
,
"
I
knew
you
sat
up
late
,
and
made
bold
to
come
round
,
having
a
word
to
say
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Willet
---
is
it
not
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Of
the
Maypole
---
at
your
service
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
closed
the
window
,
and
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
He
presently
appeared
at
a
door
in
the
bottom
of
the
turret
,
and
coming
across
the
garden
-
walk
,
unlocked
the
gate
and
let
them
in
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
late
visitor
,
Willet
.
 
<EOS>
What
is
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
to
speak
of
,
sir
,
"
said
John
;
"
an
idle
tale
<EOS>
,
I
thought
you
ought
to
know
of
;
nothing
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
your
man
go
forward
with
the
lantern
,
and
give
me
your
hand
.
<EOS>
The
stairs
are
crooked
and
narrow
.
 
<EOS>
Gently
with
your
light
,
friend
.
<EOS>
You
swing
it
like
a
censer
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
,
who
had
already
reached
the
turret
,
held
it
more
steadily
,
and
ascended
first
,
turning
round
from
time
to
time
to
shed
his
light
downward
on
the
steps
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
following
next
,
eyed
his
lowering
face
with
no
great
favour
;
and
Hugh
,
looking
down
on
him
,
returned
his
glances
with
interest
,
as
they
climbed
the
winding
stairs
.
  
<EOS>
It
terminated
in
a
little
ante
-
room
adjoining
that
from
which
they
had
seen
the
light
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
entered
first
,
and
led
the
way
through
it
into
the
latter
chamber
,
where
he
seated
himself
at
a
writing
-
table
from
which
he
had
risen
when
they
had
rung
the
bell
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
"
he
said
,
beckoning
to
old
John
,
who
remained
bowing
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
you
,
friend
,
"
he
added
hastily
to
Hugh
,
who
entered
also
.
 
<EOS>
"
Willet
,
why
do
you
bring
that
fellow
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sir
,
"
returned
John
,
elevating
his
eyebrows
,
and
lowering
his
voice
to
the
tone
in
which
the
question
had
been
asked
him
,
"
he
's
a
good
guard
,
you
see
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
be
too
sure
of
that
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
looking
towards
him
as
he
spoke
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
doubt
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
an
evil
eye
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
no
imagination
in
his
eye
,
"
returned
Mr
Willet
,
glancing
over
his
shoulder
at
the
organ
in
question
,
"
certainly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
good
there
,
be
assured
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wait
in
that
little
room
,
friend
,
and
close
the
door
between
us
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
shrugged
his
shoulders
,
and
with
a
disdainful
look
,
which
showed
,
either
that
he
had
overheard
,
or
that
he
guessed
the
purport
of
their
whispering
,
did
as
he
was
told
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
was
shut
out
,
Mr
Haredale
turned
to
John
,
and
bade
him
go
on
with
what
he
had
to
say
,
but
not
to
speak
too
loud
,
for
there
were
quick
ears
yonder
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
cautioned
,
Mr
Willet
,
in
an
oily
whisper
,
recited
all
that
he
had
heard
and
said
that
night
;
laying
particular
stress
upon
his
own
sagacity
,
upon
his
great
regard
for
the
family
,
and
upon
his
solicitude
for
their
peace
of
mind
and
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
The
story
moved
his
auditor
much
more
than
he
had
expected
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
often
changed
his
attitude
,
rose
and
paced
the
room
,
returned
again
,
desired
him
to
repeat
,
as
nearly
as
he
could
,
the
very
words
that
Solomon
had
used
,
and
gave
so
many
other
signs
of
being
disturbed
and
ill
at
ease
,
that
even
Mr
Willet
was
surprised
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
did
quite
right
,
"
he
said
,
at
the
end
of
a
long
conversation
,
"
to
bid
them
keep
this
story
secret
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
foolish
fancy
on
the
part
of
this
weak
-
brained
man
,
bred
in
his
fears
and
superstition
.
<EOS>
But
Miss
Haredale
,
though
she
would
know
it
to
be
so
,
would
be
disturbed
by
it
if
it
reached
her
ears
;
it
is
too
nearly
connected
with
a
subject
very
painful
to
us
all
,
to
be
heard
with
indifference
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
most
prudent
,
and
have
laid
me
under
a
great
obligation
.
 
<EOS>
I
thank
you
very
much
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
equal
to
John
's
most
sanguine
expectations
;
but
he
would
have
preferred
Mr
Haredale
's
looking
at
him
when
he
spoke
,
as
if
he
really
did
thank
him
,
to
his
walking
up
and
down
,
speaking
by
fits
and
starts
,
often
stopping
with
his
eyes
fixed
on
the
ground
,
moving
hurriedly
on
again
,
like
one
distracted
,
and
seeming
almost
unconscious
of
what
he
said
or
did
.
  
<EOS>
This
,
however
,
was
his
manner
;
and
it
was
so
embarrassing
to
John
that
he
sat
quite
passive
for
a
long
time
,
not
knowing
what
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
rose
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
stared
at
him
for
a
moment
as
though
he
had
quite
forgotten
his
being
present
,
then
shook
hands
with
him
,
and
opened
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
,
who
was
,
or
feigned
to
be
,
fast
asleep
on
the
ante
-
chamber
floor
,
sprang
up
on
their
entrance
,
and
throwing
his
cloak
about
him
,
grasped
his
stick
and
lantern
,
and
prepared
to
descend
the
stairs
.
  
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
this
man
drink
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Drink
!
 
<EOS>
He
'd
drink
the
Thames
up
,
if
it
was
strong
enough
,
sir
,
replied
John
Willet
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
'll
have
something
when
he
gets
home
.
<EOS>
He
's
better
without
it
,
now
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nay
.
 
<EOS>
Half
the
distance
is
done
,
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
hard
master
you
are
!
 
<EOS>
I
shall
go
home
the
better
for
one
glassful
,
halfway
.
<EOS>
Come
!
"
  
<EOS>
As
John
made
no
reply
,
Mr
Haredale
brought
out
a
glass
of
liquor
,
and
gave
it
to
Hugh
,
who
,
as
he
took
it
in
his
hand
,
threw
part
of
it
upon
the
floor
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
splashing
your
drink
about
a
gentleman
's
house
,
sir
?
"
said
John
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
drinking
a
toast
,
"
Hugh
rejoined
,
holding
the
glass
above
his
head
,
and
fixing
his
eyes
on
Mr
Haredale
's
face
;
"
a
toast
to
this
house
and
its
master
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
that
he
muttered
something
to
himself
,
and
drank
the
rest
,
and
setting
down
the
glass
,
preceded
them
without
another
word
.
  
<EOS>
John
was
a
good
deal
scandalised
by
this
observance
,
but
seeing
that
Mr
Haredale
took
little
heed
of
what
Hugh
said
or
did
,
and
that
his
thoughts
were
otherwise
employed
,
he
offered
no
apology
,
and
went
in
silence
down
the
stairs
,
across
the
walk
,
and
through
the
garden
-
gate
.
 
<EOS>
They
stopped
upon
the
outer
side
for
Hugh
to
hold
the
light
while
Mr
Haredale
locked
it
on
the
inner
;
and
then
John
saw
with
wonder
(
as
he
often
afterwards
related
)
,
that
he
was
very
pale
,
and
that
his
face
had
changed
so
much
and
grown
so
haggard
since
their
entrance
,
that
he
almost
seemed
another
man
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
in
the
open
road
again
,
and
John
Willet
was
walking
on
behind
his
escort
,
as
he
had
come
,
thinking
very
steadily
of
what
be
had
just
now
seen
,
when
Hugh
drew
him
suddenly
aside
,
and
almost
at
the
same
instant
three
horsemen
swept
past
---
the
nearest
brushed
his
shoulder
even
then
---
who
,
checking
their
steeds
as
suddenly
as
they
could
,
stood
still
,
and
waited
for
their
coming
up
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
35
    
When
John
Willet
saw
that
the
horsemen
wheeled
smartly
round
,
and
drew
up
three
abreast
in
the
narrow
road
,
waiting
for
him
and
his
man
to
join
them
,
it
occurred
to
him
with
unusual
precipitation
that
they
must
be
highwaymen
;
and
had
Hugh
been
armed
with
a
blunderbuss
,
in
place
of
his
stout
cudgel
,
he
would
certainly
have
ordered
him
to
fire
it
off
at
a
venture
,
and
would
,
while
the
word
of
command
was
obeyed
,
have
consulted
his
own
personal
safety
in
immediate
flight
.
 
<EOS>
Under
the
circumstances
of
disadvantage
,
however
,
in
which
he
and
his
guard
were
placed
,
he
deemed
it
prudent
to
adopt
a
different
style
of
generalship
,
and
therefore
whispered
his
attendant
to
address
them
in
the
most
peaceable
and
courteous
terms
.
 
<EOS>
By
way
of
acting
up
to
the
spirit
and
letter
of
this
instruction
,
Hugh
stepped
forward
,
and
flourishing
his
staff
before
the
very
eyes
of
the
rider
nearest
to
him
,
demanded
roughly
what
he
and
his
fellows
meant
by
so
nearly
galloping
over
them
,
and
why
they
scoured
the
king
's
highway
at
that
late
hour
of
night
.
  
<EOS>
The
man
whom
be
addressed
was
beginning
an
angry
reply
in
the
same
strain
,
when
be
was
checked
by
the
horseman
in
the
centre
,
who
,
interposing
with
an
air
of
authority
,
inquired
in
a
somewhat
loud
but
not
harsh
or
unpleasant
voice
:
  
"
Pray
,
is
this
the
London
road
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
follow
it
right
,
it
is
,
"
replied
Hugh
roughly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
brother
,
"
said
the
same
person
,
"
you
're
but
a
churlish
Englishman
,
if
Englishman
you
be
---
<EOS>
which
I
should
much
doubt
but
for
your
tongue
.
 
<EOS>
Your
companion
,
I
am
sure
,
will
answer
me
more
civilly
.
 
<EOS>
How
say
you
,
friend
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
it
IS
the
London
road
,
sir
,
"
answered
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
wish
,
"
he
added
in
a
subdued
voice
,
as
he
turned
to
Hugh
,
"
that
you
was
in
any
other
road
,
you
vagabond
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
tired
of
your
life
,
sir
,
that
you
go
a
-
trying
to
provoke
three
great
neck
-
or
-
nothing
chaps
,
that
could
keep
on
running
over
us
,
back'ards
and
for'ards
,
till
we
was
dead
,
and
then
take
our
bodies
up
behind
'em
,
and
drown
us
ten
miles
off
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
far
is
it
to
London
?
"
inquired
the
same
speaker
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
from
here
,
sir
,
"
answered
John
,
persuasively
,
"
it
's
thirteen
very
easy
mile
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
adjective
was
thrown
in
,
as
an
inducement
to
the
travellers
to
ride
away
with
all
speed
;
but
instead
of
having
the
desired
effect
,
it
elicited
from
the
same
person
,
the
remark
,
"
Thirteen
miles
!
<EOS>
That
's
a
long
distance
!
"
<EOS>
which
was
followed
by
a
short
pause
of
indecision
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
"
are
there
any
inns
hereabouts
?
"
 
<EOS>
At
the
word
"
inns
,
"
John
plucked
up
his
spirit
in
a
surprising
manner
;
his
fears
rolled
off
like
smoke
;
all
the
landlord
stirred
within
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
are
no
inns
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Willet
,
with
a
strong
emphasis
on
the
plural
number
;
"
but
there
's
a
Inn
---
one
Inn
---
the
Maypole
Inn
.
<EOS>
That
's
a
Inn
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
see
the
like
of
that
Inn
often
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
keep
it
,
perhaps
?
"
said
the
horseman
,
smiling
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
sir
,
"
replied
John
,
greatly
wondering
how
he
had
found
this
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
far
is
the
Maypole
from
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
About
a
mile
"
---
John
was
going
to
add
that
it
was
the
easiest
mile
in
all
the
world
,
when
the
third
rider
,
who
had
hitherto
kept
a
little
in
the
rear
,
suddenly
interposed
:
  
"
And
have
you
one
excellent
bed
,
landlord
?
 
<EOS>
Hem
!
 
<EOS>
A
bed
that
you
can
recommend
---
a
bed
that
you
are
sure
is
well
aired
---
a
bed
that
has
been
slept
in
by
some
perfectly
respectable
and
unexceptionable
person
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
do
n't
take
in
no
tagrag
and
bobtail
at
our
house
,
sir
,
"
answered
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
as
to
the
bed
itself
---
"
  
"
Say
,
as
to
three
beds
,
"
interposed
the
gentleman
who
had
spoken
before
;
"
for
we
shall
want
three
if
we
stay
,
though
my
friend
only
speaks
of
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
my
lord
;
you
are
too
good
,
you
are
too
kind
;
but
your
life
is
of
far
too
much
importance
to
the
nation
in
these
portentous
times
,
to
be
placed
upon
a
level
with
one
so
useless
and
so
poor
as
mine
.
 
<EOS>
A
great
cause
,
my
lord
,
a
mighty
cause
,
depends
on
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
its
leader
and
its
champion
,
its
advanced
guard
and
its
van
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
cause
of
our
altars
and
our
homes
,
our
country
and
our
faith
.
 
<EOS>
Let
ME
sleep
on
a
chair
---
the
carpet
---
anywhere
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
will
repine
if
I
take
cold
or
fever
.
 
<EOS>
Let
John
Grueby
pass
the
night
beneath
the
open
sky
---
no
one
will
repine
for
HIM
.
 
<EOS>
But
forty
thousand
men
of
this
our
island
in
the
wave
(
exclusive
of
women
and
children
)
rivet
their
eyes
and
thoughts
on
Lord
George
Gordon
;
and
every
day
,
from
the
rising
up
of
the
sun
to
the
going
down
of
the
same
,
pray
for
his
health
and
vigour
.
 
<EOS>
My
lord
,
"
said
the
speaker
,
rising
in
his
stirrups
,
"
it
is
a
glorious
cause
,
and
must
not
be
forgotten
.
 
<EOS>
My
lord
,
it
is
a
mighty
cause
,
and
must
not
be
endangered
.
 
<EOS>
My
lord
,
it
is
a
holy
cause
,
and
must
not
be
deserted
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
IS
a
holy
cause
,
"
exclaimed
his
lordship
,
lifting
up
his
hat
with
great
solemnity
.
 
<EOS>
"
Amen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
John
Grueby
,
"
said
the
long
-
winded
gentleman
,
in
a
tone
of
mild
reproof
,
"
his
lordship
said
Amen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
heard
my
lord
,
sir
,
"
said
the
man
,
sitting
like
a
statue
on
his
horse
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
do
not
YOU
say
Amen
,
likewise
?
"
  
<EOS>
To
which
John
Grueby
made
no
reply
at
all
,
but
sat
looking
straight
before
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
surprise
me
,
Grueby
,
"
said
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
a
crisis
like
the
present
,
when
Queen
Elizabeth
,
that
maiden
monarch
,
weeps
within
her
tomb
,
and
Bloody
Mary
,
with
a
brow
of
gloom
and
shadow
,
stalks
triumphant
---
<EOS>
"
  
"
Oh
,
sir
,
"
cied
the
man
,
gruffly
,
"
where
's
the
use
of
talking
of
Bloody
Mary
,
under
such
circumstances
as
the
present
,
when
my
lord
's
wet
through
,
and
tired
with
hard
riding
?
 
<EOS>
Let
's
either
go
on
to
London
,
sir
,
or
put
up
at
once
;
or
that
unfort'nate
Bloody
Mary
will
have
more
to
answer
for
---
and
she
's
done
a
deal
more
harm
in
her
grave
than
she
ever
did
in
her
lifetime
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
"
  
By
this
time
Mr
Willet
,
who
had
never
beard
so
many
words
spoken
together
at
one
time
,
or
delivered
with
such
volubility
and
emphasis
as
by
the
long
-
winded
gentleman
;
and
whose
brain
,
being
wholly
unable
to
sustain
or
compass
them
,
had
quite
given
itself
up
for
lost
;
recovered
so
far
as
to
observe
that
there
was
ample
accommodation
at
the
Maypole
for
all
the
party
:
good
beds
;
neat
wines
;
excellent
entertainment
for
man
and
beast
;
private
rooms
for
large
and
small
parties
;
dinners
dressed
upon
the
shortest
notice
;
choice
stabling
,
and
a
lock
-
up
coach
-
house
;
and
,
in
short
,
to
run
over
such
recommendatory
scraps
of
language
as
were
painted
up
on
various
portions
of
the
building
,
and
which
<EOS>
in
the
course
of
some
forty
years
he
had
learnt
to
repeat
with
tolerable
correctness
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
considering
whether
it
was
at
all
possible
to
insert
any
novel
sentences
to
the
same
purpose
,
when
the
gentleman
who
had
spoken
first
,
turning
to
him
of
the
long
wind
,
exclaimed
,
"
What
say
you
,
Gashford
?
 
<EOS>
Shall
we
tarry
at
this
house
he
speaks
of
,
or
press
forward
?
 
<EOS>
You
shall
decide
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
submit
,
my
lord
,
then
,
"
returned
the
person
he
appealed
to
,
in
a
silky
tone
,
"
that
your
health
and
spirits
---
so
important
,
under
Providence
,
to
our
great
cause
,
our
pure
and
truthful
cause
"
---
 
here
his
lordship
pulled
off
his
hat
again
,
though
it
was
raining
hard
---
"
require
refreshment
and
repose
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Go
on
before
,
landlord
,
and
show
the
way
,
"
said
Lord
George
Gordon
;
"
we
will
follow
at
a
footpace
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
'll
give
me
leave
,
my
lord
,
"
said
John
Grueby
,
in
a
low
voice
,
"
I
'll
change
my
proper
place
,
and
ride
before
you
.
 
<EOS>
The
looks
of
the
landlord
's
friend
are
not
over
honest
,
and
it
may
be
as
well
to
be
cautious
with
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
John
Grueby
is
quite
right
,
"
interposed
Mr
Gashford
,
falling
back
hastily
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
a
life
so
precious
as
yours
must
not
be
put
in
peril
.
 
<EOS>
Go
forward
,
John
,
by
all
means
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
have
any
reason
to
suspect
the
fellow
,
blow
his
brains
out
.
"
  
<EOS>
John
made
no
answer
,
but
looking
straight
before
him
,
as
his
custom
seemed
to
be
when
the
secretary
spoke
,
bade
Hugh
push
on
,
and
followed
close
behind
him
.
 
<EOS>
Then
came
his
lordship
,
with
Mr
Willet
at
his
bridle
rein
;
and
,
last
of
all
,
his
lordship
's
secretary
---
for
that
,
it
seemed
,
was
Gashford
's
office
.
  
<EOS>
Hugh
strode
briskly
on
,
often
looking
back
at
the
servant
,
whose
horse
was
close
upon
his
heels
,
and
glancing
with
a
leer
at
his
bolster
case
of
pistols
,
by
which
he
seemed
to
set
great
store
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
square
-
built
,
strong
-
made
,
bull
-
necked
fellow
,
of
the
true
English
breed
;
and
as
Hugh
measured
him
with
his
eye
,
he
measured
Hugh
,
regarding
him
meanwhile
with
a
look
of
bluff
disdain
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
much
older
than
the
Maypole
man
,
being
to
all
appearance
five
-
and
-
forty
;
but
was
one
of
those
self
-
possessed
,
hard
-
headed
,
imperturbable
fellows
,
who
,
if
they
are
ever
beaten
at
fisticuffs
,
or
other
kind
of
warfare
,
never
know
it
,
and
go
on
coolly
till
they
win
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
led
you
wrong
now
,
"
said
Hugh
,
tauntingly
,
"
<EOS>
you
'd
---
ha
ha
ha
!
---
 
<EOS>
you
'd
shoot
me
through
the
head
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
  
John
Grueby
took
no
more
notice
of
this
remark
than
if
he
had
been
deaf
and
Hugh
dumb
;
but
kept
riding
on
quite
comfortably
,
with
his
eyes
fixed
on
the
horizon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
ever
try
a
fall
with
a
man
when
you
were
young
,
master
?
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Can
you
make
any
play
at
single
-
stick
?
"
  
<EOS>
John
Grueby
looked
at
him
sideways
with
the
same
contented
air
,
but
deigned
not
a
word
in
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
Like
this
?
"
said
Hugh
,
giving
his
cudgel
one
of
those
skilful
flourishes
,
in
which
the
rustic
of
that
time
delighted
.
 
<EOS>
"
Whoop
!
"
  
"
<EOS>
---
Or
that
,
"
returned
John
Grueby
,
beating
down
his
guard
with
his
whip
,
and
striking
him
on
the
head
with
its
butt
end
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
played
a
little
once
.
 
<EOS>
You
wear
your
hair
too
long
;
I
should
have
cracked
your
crown
if
it
had
been
a
little
shorter
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
pretty
smart
,
loud
-
sounding
rap
,
as
it
was
,
and
evidently
astonished
Hugh
;
who
,
for
the
moment
,
seemed
disposed
to
drag
his
new
acquaintance
from
his
saddle
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
face
betokening
neither
malice
,
triumph
,
rage
,
nor
any
lingering
idea
that
he
had
given
him
offence
;
his
eyes
gazing
steadily
in
the
old
direction
,
and
his
manner
being
as
careless
and
composed
as
if
he
had
merely
brushed
away
a
fly
;
Hugh
was
so
puzzled
,
and
so
disposed
to
look
upon
him
as
a
customer
of
almost
supernatural
toughness
,
that
he
merely
laughed
,
and
cried
"
Well
done
!
"
<EOS>
then
,
sheering
off
a
little
,
led
the
way
in
silence
.
  
<EOS>
Before
the
lapse
of
many
minutes
the
party
halted
at
the
Maypole
door
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
George
and
his
secretary
quickly
dismounting
,
gave
their
horses
to
their
servant
,
who
,
under
the
guidance
of
Hugh
,
repaired
to
the
stables
.
 
<EOS>
Right
glad
to
escape
from
the
inclemency
of
the
night
,
they
followed
Mr
Willet
into
the
common
room
,
and
stood
warming
themselves
and
drying
their
clothes
before
the
cheerful
fire
,
while
he
busied
himself
with
such
orders
and
preparations
as
his
guest
's
high
quality
required
.
  
<EOS>
As
he
bustled
in
and
out
of
the
room
,
intent
on
these
arrangements
,
he
had
an
opportunity
of
observing
the
two
travellers
,
of
whom
,
as
yet
,
he
knew
nothing
but
the
voice
.
 
<EOS>
The
lord
,
the
great
personage
who
did
the
Maypole
so
much
honour
,
was
about
the
middle
height
,
of
a
slender
make
,
and
sallow
complexion
,
with
an
aquiline
nose
,
and
long
hair
of
a
reddish
brown
,
combed
perfectly
straight
and
smooth
about
his
ears
,
and
slightly
powdered
,
but
without
the
faintest
vestige
of
a
curl
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
attired
,
under
his
greatcoat
,
in
a
full
suit
of
black
,
quite
free
from
any
ornament
,
and
of
the
most
precise
and
sober
cut
.
 
<EOS>
The
gravity
of
his
dress
,
together
with
a
certain
lankness
of
cheek
and
stiffness
of
deportment
,
added
nearly
ten
years
to
his
age
,
but
his
figure
was
that
of
one
not
yet
past
thirty
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
stood
musing
in
the
red
glow
of
the
fire
,
it
was
striking
to
observe
his
very
bright
large
eye
,
which
betrayed
a
restlessness
of
thought
and
purpose
,
singularly
at
variance
with
the
studied
composure
and
sobriety
of
his
mien
,
and
with
his
quaint
and
sad
apparel
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
nothing
harsh
or
cruel
in
its
expression
;
neither
had
his
face
,
which
was
thin
and
mild
,
and
wore
an
air
of
melancholy
;
but
it
was
suggestive
of
an
indefinable
uneasiness
;
which
infected
those
who
looked
upon
him
,
and
filled
them
with
a
kind
of
pity
for
the
man
:
<EOS>
though
why
it
did
so
,
they
would
have
had
some
trouble
to
explain
.
  
<EOS>
Gashford
,
the
secretary
,
was
taller
,
angularly
made
,
high
-
shouldered
,
bony
,
and
ungraceful
.
 
<EOS>
His
dress
,
in
imitation
of
his
superior
,
was
demure
and
staid
in
the
extreme
;
his
manner
,
formal
and
constrained
.
 
<EOS>
This
gentleman
had
an
overhanging
brow
,
great
hands
and
feet
and
ears
,
and
a
pair
of
eyes
that
seemed
to
have
made
an
unnatural
retreat
into
his
head
,
and
to
have
dug
themselves
a
cave
to
hide
in
.
 
<EOS>
His
manner
was
smooth
and
humble
,
but
very
sly
and
slinking
.
 
<EOS>
He
wore
the
aspect
of
a
man
who
was
always
lying
in
wait
for
something
that
WOULDN'T
come
to
pass
;
but
he
looked
patient
---
very
patient
---
and
fawned
like
a
spaniel
dog
.
 
<EOS>
Even
now
,
while
he
warmed
and
rubbed
his
hands
before
the
blaze
,
he
had
the
air
of
one
who
only
presumed
to
enjoy
it
in
his
degree
as
a
commoner
;
and
though
he
knew
his
lord
was
not
regarding
him
,
he
looked
into
his
face
from
time
to
time
,
and
with
a
meek
and
deferential
manner
,
smiled
as
if
for
practice
.
  
<EOS>
Such
were
the
guests
whom
old
John
Willet
,
with
a
fixed
and
leaden
eye
,
surveyed
a
hundred
times
,
and
to
whom
he
now
advanced
with
a
state
candlestick
in
each
hand
,
beseeching
them
to
follow
him
into
a
worthier
chamber
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
my
lord
,
"
said
John
<EOS>
---
it
is
odd
enough
,
but
certain
people
seem
to
have
as
great
a
pleasure
in
pronouncing
titles
as
their
owners
have
in
wearing
them
---
"
this
room
,
my
lord
,
is
n't
at
all
the
sort
of
place
for
your
lordship
,
and
I
have
to
beg
your
lordship
's
pardon
for
keeping
you
here
,
my
lord
,
one
minute
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
this
address
,
John
ushered
them
upstairs
into
the
state
apartment
,
which
,
like
many
other
things
of
state
,
was
cold
and
comfortless
.
 
<EOS>
Their
own
footsteps
,
reverberating
through
the
spacious
room
,
struck
upon
their
hearing
with
a
hollow
sound
;
and
its
damp
and
chilly
atmosphere
was
rendered
doubly
cheerless
by
contrast
with
the
homely
warmth
they
had
deserted
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
of
no
use
,
however
,
to
propose
a
return
to
the
place
they
had
quitted
,
for
the
preparations
went
on
so
briskly
that
there
was
no
time
to
stop
them
.
 
<EOS>
John
,
with
the
tall
candlesticks
in
his
hands
,
bowed
them
up
to
the
fireplace
;
Hugh
,
striding
in
with
a
lighted
brand
and
pile
of
firewood
,
cast
it
down
upon
the
hearth
,
and
set
it
in
a
blaze
;
John
Grueby
(
who
had
a
great
blue
cockade
in
his
hat
,
which
he
appeared
to
despise
mightily
)
brought
in
the
portmanteau
he
had
carried
on
his
horse
,
and
placed
it
on
the
floor
;
and
presently
all
three
were
busily
engaged
in
drawing
out
the
screen
,
laying
the
cloth
,
inspecting
the
beds
,
lighting
fires
in
the
bedrooms
,
expediting
the
supper
,
and
making
everything
as
cosy
and
as
snug
as
might
be
,
on
so
short
a
notice
.
 
<EOS>
In
less
than
an
hour
's
time
,
supper
had
been
served
,
and
ate
,
and
cleared
away
;
and
Lord
George
and
his
secretary
,
with
slippered
feet
,
and
legs
stretched
out
before
the
fire
,
sat
over
some
hot
mulled
wine
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
ends
,
my
lord
,
"
said
Gashford
,
filling
his
glass
with
great
complacency
,
"
the
blessed
work
of
a
most
blessed
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
of
a
blessed
yesterday
,
"
said
his
lordship
,
raising
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
---
and
here
the
secretary
clasped
his
hands
---
"
a
blessed
yesterday
indeed
!
 
<EOS>
The
Protestants
of
Suffolk
are
godly
men
and
true
.
 
<EOS>
Though
others
of
our
countrymen
have
lost
their
way
in
darkness
,
even
as
we
,
my
lord
,
did
lose
our
road
to
-
night
,
theirs
is
the
light
and
glory
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
move
them
,
Gashford
?
"
said
Lord
George
.
  
<EOS>
"
Move
them
,
my
lord
!
 
<EOS>
Move
them
!
 
<EOS>
They
cried
to
be
led
on
against
the
Papists
,
they
vowed
a
dreadful
vengeance
on
their
heads
<EOS>
,
they
roared
like
men
possessed
---
"
  
"
But
not
by
devils
,
"
said
his
lord
.
  
<EOS>
"
By
devils
!
<EOS>
my
lord
!
 
<EOS>
By
angels
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
---
oh
surely
---
by
angels
,
no
doubt
,
"
said
Lord
George
,
thrusting
his
hands
into
his
pockets
,
taking
them
out
again
to
bite
his
nails
,
and
looking
uncomfortably
at
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
by
angels
---
eh
Gashford
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
doubt
it
,
my
lord
?
"
said
the
secretary
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
---
No
,
"
returned
his
lord
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
I
?
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
it
would
be
decidedly
irreligious
to
doubt
it
---
would
n't
it
,
Gashford
?
<EOS>
Though
there
certainly
were
,
"
he
added
,
without
waiting
for
an
answer
,
"
some
plaguy
ill
-
looking
characters
among
them
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
you
warmed
,
"
said
the
secretary
,
looking
sharply
at
the
other
's
downcast
eyes
,
which
brightened
slowly
as
he
spoke
;
"
when
you
warmed
into
that
noble
outbreak
;
when
you
told
them
that
you
were
never
of
the
lukewarm
or
the
timid
tribe
,
and
bade
them
take
heed
that
they
were
prepared
to
follow
one
who
would
lead
them
on
,
though
to
the
very
death
;
when
you
spoke
of
a
hundred
and
twenty
thousand
men
across
the
Scottish
border
who
would
take
their
own
redress
at
any
time
,
if
it
were
not
conceded
;
when
you
cried
"
Perish
the
Pope
and
all
his
base
adherents
;
the
penal

against
them
shall
never
be
repealed
while
Englishmen
have
hearts
and
hands
"
---
and
waved
your
own
and
touched
your
sword
;
and
when
they
cried
"
No
Popery
!
"
<EOS>
and
you
cried
"
<EOS>
No
;
not
even
if
we
wade
in
blood
,
"
and
they
threw
up
their
hats
and
cried
"
Hurrah
!
<EOS>
not
even
if
we
wade
in
blood
;
No
Popery
!
 
<EOS>
Lord
George
!
 
<EOS>
Down
with
the
Papists
---
 
<EOS>
Vengeance
on
their
heads
:
"
when
this
was
said
and
done
,
and
a
word
from
you
,
my
lord
,
could
raise
or
still
the
tumult
---
ah
!
<EOS>
then
I
felt
what
greatness
was
indeed
,
and
thought
,
When
was
there
ever
power
like
this
of
Lord
George
Gordon
's
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
great
power
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
right
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
great
power
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
with
sparkling
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
---
dear
Gashford
---
did
I
really
say
all
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
much
more
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
secretary
,
looking
upwards
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
how
much
more
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
told
them
what
you
say
,
about
the
one
hundred
and
forty
thousand
men
in
Scotland
,
did
I
!
"
<EOS>
he
asked
with
evident
delight
.
<EOS>
"
That
was
bold
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Our
cause
is
boldness
.
 
<EOS>
Truth
is
always
bold
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Certainly
.
 
<EOS>
So
is
religion
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
bold
,
Gashford
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
true
religion
is
,
my
lord
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
that
's
ours
,
"
he
rejoined
,
moving
uneasily
in
his
seat
,
and
biting
his
nails
as
though
he
would
pare
them
to
the
quick
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
can
be
no
doubt
of
ours
being
the
true
one
.
 
<EOS>
You
feel
as
certain
of
that
as
I
do
,
Gashford
,
do
n't
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Does
my
lord
ask
ME
,
"
whined
Gashford
,
drawing
his
chair
nearer
with
an
injured
air
,
and

his

flat
hand
upon
the

;
"
ME
,
"
he

,
bending
the

upon

,
"
who
,
stricken
by
the
magic
of
his
eloquence
in
Scotland
but
a
year
ago
,
abjured
the
errors
of
the
Romish
church
,
and
clung
to
him
as
one
whose
timely

had
plucked
me
from

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
True
.
 
<EOS>
No
---
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
I
did
n't
mean
it
,
"
replied
the
other
,
shaking
him
by
the
hand
,
rising
from
his
seat
,
and
pacing
restlessly
about
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
proud
thing
to
lead
the
people
,
Gashford
,
"
he
added
as
he
made
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
By
force
of
reason
too
,
"
returned
the
pliant
secretary
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
to
be
sure
.
 
<EOS>
They
may
cough
and
jeer
,
and
groan
in
Parliament
,
and
call
me
fool
and
madman
,
but
which
of
them
can
raise
this
human
sea
and
make
it
swell
and
roar
at
pleasure
?
 
<EOS>
Not
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
one
,
"
repeated
Gashford
.
  
<EOS>
"
Which
of
them
can
say
for
his
honesty
,
what
I
can
say
for
mine
;
which
of
them
has
refused
a
minister
's
bribe
of
one
thousand
pounds
a
year
,
to
resign
his
seat
in
favour
of
another
?
 
<EOS>
Not
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
one
,
"
repeated
Gashford
again
---
taking
the
lion
's
share
of
the
mulled
wine
between
whiles
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
as
we
are
honest
,
true
,
and
in
a
sacred
cause
,
Gashford
,
"
said
Lord
George
with
a
heightened
colour
and
in
a
louder
voice
,
as
he
laid
his
fevered
hand
upon
his
shoulder
,
"
and
are
the
only
men
who
regard
the
mass
of
people
out

doors
,
or
are
regarded
by
them
,
we
will
uphold
them
to
the
last
;
and
will
raise
a
cry
against
these
un
-
English
Papists
which
shall
re
-
echo
through
the
country
,
and
roll
with
a
noise
like
thunder
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
be
worthy
of
the
motto
on
my
coat
of
arms
,
"
Called
and
chosen
and
faithful
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Called
,
"
said
the
secretary
,
"
by
Heaven
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Chosen
by
the
people
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Faithful
to
both
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
the
block
!
"
  
<EOS>
It
would
be
difficult
to
convey
an
adequate
idea
of
the
excited
manner
in
which
he
gave
these
answers
to
the
secretary
's
promptings
;
of
the
rapidity
of
his
utterance
,
or
the
violence
of
his
tone
and

;
in
which
,
struggling
through
his
Puritan
's
demeanour
,
was
something
wild
and
ungovernable
which
broke
through
all
restraint
.
 
<EOS>
For
some
minutes
he
walked
rapidly
up
and
down
the
room
,
then
stopping
suddenly
,
exclaimed
,
  
<EOS>
"
Gashford
---
YOU
moved
them
yesterday
too
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
yes
!
 
<EOS>
You
did
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shone
with
a
reflected
light
,
my
lord
,
"
replied
the
humble
secretary
,
laying
his
hand
upon
his
heart
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
my
best
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
did
well
,
"
said
his
master
,
"
and
are
a
great
and
worthy
instrument
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
will
ring
for
John
Grueby
to
carry
the
portmanteau
into
my
room
,
and
will
wait
here
while
I
undress
,
we
will
dispose
of
business
as
usual
,
if
you
're
not
too
tired
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Too
tired
,
my
lord
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
But
this
is
his
consideration
!
 
<EOS>
Christian
from
head
to
foot
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
which
soliloquy
,
the
secretary
tilted
the
jug
,
and
looked
very
hard
into
the
mulled
wine
,
to
see
how
much
remained
.
  
<EOS>
John
Willet
and
John
Grueby
appeared
together
.
 
<EOS>
The
one
bearing
the
great
candlesticks
,
and
the
other
the
portmanteau
,
showed
the
deluded
lord
into
his
chamber
;
and
left
the
secretary
alone
,
to
yawn
and
shake
himself
,
and
finally
to
fall
asleep
before
the
fire
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Gashford
sir
,
"
said
John
Grueby
in
his
ear
,
after
what
appeared
to
him
a
moment
of
unconsciousness
;
"
my
lord
's
abed
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
.
 
<EOS>
Very
good
,
John
,
"
was
his
mild
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
John
.
<EOS>
Nobody
need
sit
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
my
room
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
're
not
a
-
going
to
trouble
your
head
to
-
night
,
or
my
lord
's
head
neither
,
with
anything
more
about
Bloody
Mary
,
"
said
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
the
blessed
old
creetur
had
never
been
born
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
said
you
might
go
to
bed
,
John
,
"
returned
the
secretary
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
did
n't
hear
me
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Between
Bloody
Marys
,
and
blue
cockades
,
and
glorious
Queen
Besses
,
and
no
Poperys
,
and
Protestant
associations
,
and
making
of
speeches
,
"
pursued
John
Grueby
,
looking
,
as
usual
,
a
long
way
off
,
and
taking
no
notice
of
this
hint
,
"
my
lord
's
half
off
his
head
.
<EOS>
When
we
go
out
o
'
doors
,
such
a
set
of
ragamuffins
comes
a
-
shouting
after
us
,
"
Gordon
forever
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
that
I
'm
ashamed
of
myself
and
do
n't
know
where
to
look
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
're
indoors
,
they
come
a
-
roaring
and
screaming
about
the
house
like
so
many
devils
;
and
my
lord
instead
of
ordering
them
to
be
drove
away
,
goes
out
into
the
balcony
and
demeans
himself
by
making
speeches
to
'em
,
and
calls
'em
"
Men
of
England
,
"
and
"
Fellow
-
countrymen
,
"
as
if
he
was
fond
of
'em
and
thanked
'em
for
coming
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
make
it
out
,
but
they
're
all
mixed
up
somehow
or
another
with
that
unfort'nate
Bloody
Mary
,
and
call
her
name
out
till
they
're
hoarse
.
 
<EOS>
They
're
all
Protestants
too
---
<EOS>
every
man
and
boy
among
'em
:
and
Protestants
are
very
fond
of
spoons
,
I
find
,
and
silver
-
plate
in
general
,
whenever
area
-
gates
is
left
open
accidentally
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
that
was
the
worst
of
it
,
and
that
no
more
harm
might
be
to
come
;
but
if
you
do
n't
stop
these
ugly
customers
in
time
,
Mr
Gashford
<EOS>
(
and
I
know
you
;
you
're
the
man
that
blows
the
fire
)
,
you
'll
find
'em
grow
a
little
bit
too
strong
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
these
evenings
,
when
the
weather
gets
warmer
and
Protestants
are
thirsty
,
they
'll
be
pulling
London
down
,
---
and
I
never
heard
that
Bloody
Mary
went
as
far
as
THAT
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Gashford
had
vanished
long
ago
,
and
these
remarks
had
been
bestowed
on
empty
air
.
 
<EOS>
Not
at
all
discomposed
by
the
discovery
,
John
Grueby
fixed
his
hat
on
,
wrongside
foremost
that
he
might
be
unconscious
of
the
shadow
of
the
obnoxious
cockade
,
and
withdrew
to
bed
;
shaking
his
head
in
a
very
gloomy
and
prophetic
manner
until
he
reached
his
chamber
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
36
    
Gashford
,
with
a
smiling
face
,
but
still
with
looks
of
profound
deference
and
humility
,
betook
himself
towards
his
master
's
room
,
smoothing
his
hair
down
as
he
went
,
and
humming
a
psalm
tune
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
approached
Lord
George
's
door
,
he
cleared
his
throat
and
hummed
more
vigorously
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
remarkable
contrast
between
this
man
's
occupation
at
the
moment
,
and
the
expression
of
his
countenance
,
which
was
singularly
repulsive
and
malicious
.
 
<EOS>
His
beetling
brow
almost
obscured
his
eyes
;
his
lip
was
curled
contemptuously
;
his
very
shoulders
seemed
to
sneer
in
stealthy
whisperings
with
his
great
flapped
ears
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
<EOS>
he
muttered
softly
,
as
he
peeped
in
at
the
chamber
-
door
.
"
<EOS>
He
seems
to
be
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
Heaven
<EOS>
he
is
!
 
<EOS>
Too
much
watching
,
too
much
care
,
too
much
thought
---
ah
!
<EOS>
Lord
preserve
him
for
a
martyr
!
<EOS>
He
is
a
saint
,
if
ever
saint
drew
breath
on
this
bad
earth
.
"
  
<EOS>
Placing
his
light
upon
a
table
,
he
walked
on
tiptoe
to
the
fire
,
and
sitting
in
a
chair
before
it
with
his
back
towards
the
bed
,
went
on
communing
with
himself
like
one
who
thought
aloud
:
  
"
<EOS>
The
saviour
of
his
country
and
his
country
's
religion
,
the
friend
of
his
poor
countrymen
,
the
enemy
of
the
proud
and
harsh
;
beloved
of
the
rejected
and
oppressed
,
adored
by
forty
thousand
bold
and
loyal
English
hearts
---
what
happy
slumbers
his
should
be
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
here
he
sighed
,
and
warmed
his
hands
,
and
shook
his
head
as
men
do
when
their
hearts
are
full
,
and
heaved
another
sigh
,
and
warmed
his
hands
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Gashford
?
"
said
Lord
George
,
who
was
lying
broad
awake
,
upon
his
side
,
and
had
been
staring
at
him
from
his
entrance
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
---
my
lord
,
"
said
Gashford
,
starting
and
looking
round
as
though
in
great

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
disturbed
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
been
sleeping
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
sleeping
!
"
<EOS>
he
repeated
,
with
assumed

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
can
I
say
for
having
in
your
presence
<EOS>
given
utterance
to
thoughts
---
<EOS>
but
they
were
sincere
---
they
were
sincere
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
secretary
,
drawing
his
sleeve
in

hasty
way
across
his

;
"
and
why
should
I
regret
your
having
heard

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gashford
,
"
said
the
poor
lord
,
stretching

with
manifest

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
regret
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
love
me
well
,
I
know
---
 
too
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
deserve
such
homage
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Gashford
made
no
reply
,
but
grasped
the
hand
and
pressed
it
to
his

.
 
<EOS>
Then
rising
,
and
taking
from
the

a
little

,

placed
it
on
a
table
near
the
fire
,
unlocked
it
with
a
key
he

in

pocket
,
sat

before

,
took
out
a

,
and
,
before

in
the

,
sucked
it
---
to
compose
the
fashion
of
his
mouth
perhaps
,
on
which
a
smile
was
hovering
yet
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
our
numbers
stand
since
last
enrolling
-
night
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Lord
George
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are

,
or
do
we
still
speak
in
round

when

take

Association
at

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Our
total
now
exceeds
that

by

,
"
Gashford

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
The

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
VERY

;

there

some

in

,
my

.
 
<EOS>
Hem
!
 
<EOS>
On
Friday
night

widows
'

in
.
 
<EOS>
"
Forty

,
three

.
 
<EOS>
An

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

.
 
<EOS>
A
Protestant

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
United
Link
Boys
,
three
shillings
---
one

.
 
<EOS>
The
anti
-
popish
prisoners
in
Newgate
,
five
and

.
 
<EOS>
A
friend
in
Bedlam
,
half
-
a
-

.
 
<EOS>
Dennis
the
hangman
,
one
shilling
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
That
Dennis
,
"
said
his

,
"
is
an
earnest
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
marked
him
in

in
Welbeck
Street
,
last

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
good
man
,
"

,
"
a

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
should

,
"
said

George
.
 
<EOS>
"
Make

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
Gashford
obeyed
,
and
went
on
reading
from

:
  
"
"
The
Friends
of
Reason
,
half
-

-

.
 
<EOS>
The
Friends
of
Liberty
,
half
-

-

.
 
<EOS>
The
Friends
of
Peace
,
half
-
a
-

.
 
<EOS>
The
Friends
of

,

-

-

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

-

.
<EOS>

,

-

-

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

-

-

.
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
The
United

,
"

George
,
biting

,
"
are

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Formerly

'

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
President
,
"

,

,
"
Mr
Simon

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

<EOS>
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tappertit
is

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Eh
,

?
"
  
"
One

among

all
,

.
 
<EOS>
He
snuffs

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
throws
his

up

as

,
and

from

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Make
a
note

Tappertit
,
"
said

George
Gordon
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
may

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
That
,
"

,

"

---

Varden
's

(
fourteenth

)
,

(

)
,

.
"
  
"
Miggs
,
"

George
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
name

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Varden

?
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
She
is

,
"
said
Lord
George
.
 
<EOS>
"
Her
collection
goes
on
prosperously
,
and
is
pursued
with
fervour
.
 
<EOS>
Has
her
husband
joined
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
malignant
,
"
returned
the
secretary
,
folding
up
his
papers
.
"
<EOS>
Unworthy
such
a
wife
.
 
<EOS>
He
remains
in
outer
darkness
and
steadily
refuses
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
consequences
be
upon
his
own
head
!
<EOS>
---
Gashford
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
lord
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
think
,
"
he
turned
restlessly
in
his
bed
as
he
spoke
,
"
these
people
will
desert
me
,
when
the
hour
arrives
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
spoken
boldly
for
them
,
ventured
much
,
suppressed
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
not
fall
off
,
will
they
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
fear
of
that
,
my
lord
,
"
said
Gashford
,
with
a
meaning
look
,
which
was
rather
the
involuntary
expression
of
his
own
thoughts
than
intended
as
any
confirmation
of
his
words
,
for
the
other
's
face
was
turned
away
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
sure
there
is
no
fear
of
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
,
"
he
said
with
a
more
restless
motion
than
before
,
"
of
their
---
 
<EOS>
but
they
CAN
sustain
no
harm
from
leaguing
for
this
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
Right
is
on
our
side
,
though
Might
may
be
against
us
.
 
<EOS>
You
feel
as
sure
of
that
as
I
---
<EOS>
honestly
,
you
do
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
secretary
was
beginning
with
"
You
do
not
doubt
,
"
when
the
other
interrupted
him
,
and
impatiently
rejoined
:
  
"
Doubt
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Who
says
I
doubt
?
 
<EOS>
If
I
doubted
,
should
I
cast
away
relatives
,
friends
,
everything
,
for
this
unhappy
country
's
sake
;
this
unhappy
country
,
"
he
cried
,
springing
up
in
bed
,
after
repeating
the
phrase
"
unhappy
country
's
sake
"
to
himself
,
at
least
a
dozen
times
,
"
forsaken
of
God
and
man
,
delivered
over
to
a
dangerous
confederacy
of
Popish
powers
;
the
prey
of
corruption
,
idolatry
,
and
despotism
!
 
<EOS>
Who
says
I
doubt
?
 
<EOS>
Am
I
called
,
and
chosen
,
and
faithful
?
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
.
 
<EOS>
Am
I
,
or
am
I
not
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
God
,
the
country
,
and
yourself
,
"
cried
Gashford
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
be
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
again
<EOS>
,
I
will
be
:
to
the
block
.
 
<EOS>
Who
says
as
much
!
 
<EOS>
Do
you
?
 
<EOS>
Does
any
man
alive
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
secretary
drooped
his
head
with
an
expression
of
perfect
acquiescence
in
anything
that
had
been
said
or
might
be
;
and
Lord
George
gradually
sinking
down
upon
his
pillow
,
fell
asleep
.
  
<EOS>
Although
there
was
something
very
ludicrous
in
his
vehement
manner
,
taken
in
conjunction
with
his
meagre
aspect
and
ungraceful
presence
,
it
would
scarcely
have
provoked
a
smile
in
any
man
of
kindly
feeling
;
or
even
if
it
had
,
he
would
have
felt
sorry
and
almost
angry
with
himself
next
moment
,
for
yielding
to
the
impulse
.
<EOS>
This
lord
was
sincere
in
his
violence
and
in
his
wavering
.
 
<EOS>
A
nature
prone
to
false
enthusiasm
,
and
the
vanity
of
being
a
leader
,
were
the
worst
qualities
apparent
in
his
composition
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
rest
was
weakness
---
sheer
weakness
;
and
it
is
the
unhappy
lot
of
thoroughly
weak
men
,
that
their
very
sympathies
,
affections
,
confidences
---
all
the
qualities
which
in
better
constituted
minds
are
virtues
---
dwindle
into
foibles
,
or
turn
into
downright
vices
.
  
<EOS>
Gashford
,
with
many
a
sly
look
towards
the
bed
,
sat
chuckling
at
his
master
's
folly
,
until
his
deep
and
heavy
breathing
warned
him
that
he
might
retire
.
 
<EOS>
Locking
his
desk
,
and
replacing
it
within
the
trunk
(
but
not
before
he
had
taken
from
a
secret
lining
two
printed
handbills
)
,
he
cautiously
withdrew
;
looking
back
,
as
he
went
,
at
the
pale
face
of
the
slumbering
man
,
above
whose
head
the
dusty
plumes
that
crowned
the
Maypole
couch
,
waved
drearily
and
sadly
as
though
it
were
a
bier
.
  
<EOS>
Stopping
on
the
staircase
to
listen
that
all
was
quiet
,
and
to
take
off
his
shoes
lest
his
footsteps
should
alarm
any
light
sleeper
who
might
be
near
at
hand
,
he
descended
to
the
ground
floor
,
and
thrust
one
of
his
bills
beneath
the
great
door
of
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
That
done
,
he
crept
softly
back
to
his
own
chamber
,
and
from
the
window
let
another
fall
---
carefully
wrapt
round
a
stone
to
save
it
from
the
wind
---
into
the
yard
below
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
addressed
on
the
back
"
To
every
Protestant
into
whose
hands
this
shall
come
,
"
and
bore
within
what
follows
:
  
"
Men
and
Brethren
.
 
<EOS>
Whoever
shall
find
this
letter
,
will
take
it
as
a
warning
to
join
,
without
delay
,
the
friends
of
Lord
George
Gordon
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
great
events
at
hand
;
and
the
times
are
dangerous
and
troubled
.
 
<EOS>
Read
this
carefully
,
keep
it
clean
,
and
drop
it
somewhere
else
.
 
<EOS>
For
King
and
Country
.
 
<EOS>
Union
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
More
seed
,
more
seed
,
"
said
Gashford
as
he
closed
the
window
.
<EOS>
"
When
will
the
harvest
come
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
37
    
To
surround
anything
,
however
monstrous
or
ridiculous
,
with
an
air
of
mystery
,
is
to
invest
it
with
a
secret
charm
,
and
power
of
attraction
which
to
the
crowd
is
irresistible
.
 
<EOS>
False
priests
,
false
prophets
,
false
doctors
,
false
patriots
,
false
prodigies
of
every
kind
,
veiling
their
proceedings
in
mystery
,
have
always
addressed
themselves
at
an
immense
advantage
to
the
popular
credulity
,
and
have
been
,
perhaps
,
more
indebted
to
that
resource
in
gaining
and
keeping
for
a
time
the
upper
hand
of
Truth
and
Common
Sense
,
than
to
any
half
-
dozen
items
in
the
whole
catalogue
of
imposture
.
 
<EOS>
Curiosity
is
,
and
has
been
from
the
creation
of
the
world
,
a
master
-
passion
.
 
<EOS>
To
awaken
it
,
to
gratify
it
by
slight
degrees
,
and
yet
leave
something
always
in
suspense
,
is
to
establish
the
surest
hold
that
can
be
had
,
in
wrong
,
on
the
unthinking
portion
of
mankind
.
  
<EOS>
If
a
man
had
stood
on
London
Bridge
,
calling
till
he
was
hoarse
,
upon
the
passers
-
by
,
to
join
with
Lord
George
Gordon
,
although
for
an
object
which
no
man
understood
,
and
which
in
that
very
incident
had
a
charm
of
its
own
,
---
the
probability
is
,
that
he
might
have
influenced
a
score
of
people
in
a
month
.
 
<EOS>
If
all
zealous
Protestants
had
been
publicly
urged
to
join
an
association
for
the
avowed
purpose
of
singing
a
hymn
or
two
occasionally
,
and
hearing
some
indifferent
speeches
made
,
and
ultimately
of
petitioning
Parliament
not
to
pass
an
act
for
abolishing
the
penal
laws
against
Roman
Catholic
priests
,
the
penalty
of
perpetual
imprisonment
denounced
against
those
who
educated
children
in
that
persuasion
,
and
the
disqualification
of
all
members
of
the
Romish
church
to
inherit
real
property
in
the
United
Kingdom
by
right
of
purchase
or
descent
,
---
matters
so
far
removed
from
the
business
and
bosoms
of
the
mass
,
might
perhaps
have
called
together
a
hundred
people
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
vague
rumours
got
abroad
,
that
in
this
Protestant
association
a
secret
power
was
mustering
against
the
government
for
undefined
and
mighty
purposes
;
when
the
air
was
filled
with
whispers
of
a
confederacy
among
the
Popish
powers
to
degrade
and
enslave
England
,
establish
an
inquisition
in
London
,
and
turn
the
pens
of
Smithfield
market
into
stakes
and
cauldrons
;
when
terrors
and
alarms
which
no
man
understood
were
perpetually
broached
,
both
in
and
out
of
Parliament
,
by
one
enthusiast
who
did
not
understand
himself
,
and
bygone
bugbears
which
had
lain
quietly
in
their
graves
for
centuries
,
were
raised
again
to
haunt
the
ignorant
and
credulous
;
when
all
this
was
done
,
as
it
were
,
in
the
dark
,
and
secret
invitations
to
join
the
Great
Protestant
Association
in
defence
of
religion
,
life
,
and
liberty
,
were
dropped
in
the
public
ways
,
thrust
under
the
house
-
doors
,
tossed
in
at
windows
,
and
pressed
into
the
hands
of
those
who
trod
the
streets
by
night
;
when
they
glared
from
every
wall
,
and
shone
on
every
post
and
pillar
,
so
that
stocks
and
stones
appeared
infected
with
the
common
fear
,
urging
all
men
to
join
together
blindfold
in
resistance
of
<EOS>
they
knew
not
what
,
they
knew
not
why
;
---
then
the
mania
spread
indeed
,
and
the
body
,
still
increasing
every
day
,
grew
forty
thousand
strong
.
  
<EOS>
So
said
,
at
least
,
in
this
month
of
March
,
1780
,
Lord
George
Gordon
,
the
Association
's
president
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
it
was
the
fact
or
otherwise
,
few
men
knew
or
cared
to
ascertain
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
never
made
any
public
demonstration
;
had
scarcely
ever
been
heard
of
,
save
through
him
;
had
never
been
seen
;
and
was
supposed
by
many
to
be
the
mere
creature
of
his
disordered
brain
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
accustomed
to
talk
largely
about
numbers
of
men
<EOS>
---
stimulated
,
as
it
was
inferred
,
by
certain
successful
disturbances
,
arising
out
of
the
same
subject
,
which
had
occurred
in
Scotland
in
the
previous
year
;
was
looked
upon
as
a
cracked
-
brained
member
of
the
lower
house
,
who
attacked
all
parties
and
sided
with
none
,
and
was
very
little
regarded
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
known
that
there
was
discontent
abroad
<EOS>
---
there
always
is
;
he
had
been
accustomed
to
address
the
people
by
placard
,
speech
,
and
pamphlet
,
upon
other
questions
;
nothing
had
come
,
in
England
,
of
his
past
exertions
,
and
nothing
was
apprehended
from
his
present
.
 
<EOS>
Just
as
he
has
come
upon
the
reader
,
he
had
come
,
from
time
to
time
,
upon
the
public
,
and
been
forgotten
in
a
day
;
as
suddenly
as
he
appears
in
these
pages
,
after
a
blank
of
five
long
years
,
did
he
and
his
proceedings
begin
to
force
themselves
,
about
this
period
,
upon
the
notice
of
thousands
of
people
,
who
had
mingled
in
active
life
during
the
whole
interval
,
and
who
,
without
being
deaf
or
blind
to
passing
events
,
had
scarcely
ever
thought
of
him
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
"
said
Gashford
in
his
ear
,
as
he
drew
the
curtains
of
his
bed
betimes
;
"
my
lord
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
---
who
's
that
?
 
<EOS>
What
is
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
clock
has
struck
nine
,
"
returned
the
secretary
,
with
meekly
folded
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
slept
well
?
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
have
slept
well
?
<EOS>
If
my
prayers
are
heard
,
you
are
refreshed
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
say
the
truth
,
I
have
slept
so
soundly
,
"
said
Lord
George
,
rubbing
his
eyes
and
looking
round
the
room
,
"
that
I
do
n't
remember
quite
---
what
place
is
this
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
lord
!
"
cried
Gashford
,
with
a
smile
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
returned
his
superior
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
not
a
Jew
then
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
Jew
!
"
exclaimed
the
pious
secretary
,
recoiling
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
dreamed
that
we
were
Jews
,
Gashford
.
 
<EOS>
You
and
I
---
both
of
us
---
 
Jews
with
long
beards
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Heaven
forbid
,
my
lord
!
 
<EOS>
We
might
as
well
be
Papists
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
we
might
,
"
returned
the
other
,
very
quickly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Eh
?
 
<EOS>
You
really
think
so
,
Gashford
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Surely
I
do
,
"
the
secretary
cried
,
with
looks
of
great
surprise
.
  
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
"
<EOS>
he
muttered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
that
seems
reasonable
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
my
lord
---
"
the
secretary
began
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hope
!
"
<EOS>
he
echoed
,
interrupting
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
say
,
you
hope
?
<EOS>
There
's
no
harm
in
thinking
of
such
things
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
in
dreams
,
"
returned
the
Secretary
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
dreams
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
nor
waking
either
.
<EOS>
"
   
---
<EOS>
"
"
Called
,
and
chosen
,
and
faithful
,
"
"
said
Gashford
,
taking
up
Lord
George
's
watch
which
lay
upon
a
chair
,
and
seeming
to
read
the
inscription
on
the
seal
,
abstractedly
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
slightest
action
possible
,
not
obtruded
on
his
notice
,
and
apparently
the
result
of
a
moment
's
absence
of
mind
,
not
worth
remark
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
the
words
were
uttered
,
Lord
George
,
who
had
been
going
on
impetuously
,
stopped
short
,
reddened
,
and
was
silent
.
<EOS>
Apparently
quite
unconscious
of
this
change
in
his
demeanour
,
the
wily
Secretary
stepped
a
little
apart
,
under
pretence
of
pulling
up
the
window
-
blind
,
and
returning
when
the
other
had
had
time
to
recover
,
said
:
  
"
The
holy
cause
goes
bravely
on
,
my
lord
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
idle
,
even
last
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
dropped
two
of
the
handbills
before
I
went
to
bed
,
and
both
are
gone
this
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
in
the
house
has
mentioned
the
circumstance
of
finding
them
,
though
I
have
been
downstairs
full
half
-
an
-
hour
.
 
<EOS>
One
or
two
recruits
will
be
their
first
fruit
,
I
predict
;
and
who
shall
say
how
many
more
,
with
Heaven
's
blessing
on
your
inspired
exertions
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
famous
device
in
the
beginning
,
"
replied
Lord
George
;
"
an
excellent
device
,
and
did
good
service
in
Scotland
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
quite
worthy
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
remind
me
not
to
be
a
sluggard
,
Gashford
,
when
the
vineyard
is
menaced
with
destruction
,
and
may
be
trodden
down
by
Papist
feet
.
 
<EOS>
Let
the
horses
be
saddled
in
half
-
an
-
hour
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
be
up
and
doing
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
said
this
with
a
heightened
colour
,
and
in
a
tone
of
such
enthusiasm
,
that
the
secretary
deemed
all
further
prompting
needless
,
and
withdrew
.
   
<EOS>
---
"
Dreamed
he
was
a
Jew
,
"
he
said
thoughtfully
,
as
he
closed
the
bedroom
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
may
come
to
that
before
he
dies
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
like
enough
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
After
a
time
,
and
provided
I
lost
nothing
by
it
,
I
do
n't
see
why
that
religion
should
n't
suit
me
as
well
as
any
other
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
rich
men
among
the
Jews
;
shaving
is
very
troublesome
;
---
yes
,
it
would
suit
me
well
enough
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
present
,
though
,
we
must
be
Christian
to
the
core
.
 
<EOS>
Our
prophetic
motto
will
suit
all
creeds
in
their
turn
,
that
's
a
comfort
.
"
 
<EOS>
Reflecting
on
this
source
of
consolation
,
he
reached
the
sitting
-
room
,
and
rang
the
bell
for
breakfast
.
  
<EOS>
Lord
George
was
quickly
dressed
(
for
his
plain
toilet
was
easily
made
)
,
and
as
he
was
no
less
frugal
in
his
repasts
than
in
his
Puritan
attire
,
his
share
of
the
meal
was
soon
dispatched
.
 
<EOS>
The
secretary
,
however
,
more
devoted
to
the
good
things
of
this
world
,
or
more
intent
on
sustaining
his
strength
and
spirits
for
the
sake
of
the
Protestant
cause
,
ate
and
drank
to
the
last
minute
,
and
required
indeed
some
three
or
four
reminders
from
John
Grueby
,
before
he
could
resolve
to
tear
himself
away
from
Mr
Willet
's
plentiful
providing
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
he
came
downstairs
,
wiping
his
greasy
mouth
,
and
having
paid
John
Willet
's
bill
,
climbed
into
his
saddle
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
George
,
who
had
been
walking
up
and
down
before
the
house
talking
to
himself
with
earnest
gestures
,
mounted
his
horse
;
and
returning
old
John
Willet
's
stately
bow
,
as
well
as
the
parting
salutation
of
a
dozen
idlers
whom
the
rumour
of
a
live
lord
being
about
to
leave
the
Maypole
had
gathered
round
the
porch
,
they
rode
away
,
with
stout
John
Grueby
in
the
rear
.
  
<EOS>
If
Lord
George
Gordon
had
appeared
in
the
eyes
of
Mr
Willet
,
overnight
,
a
nobleman
of
somewhat
quaint
and
odd
exterior
,
the
impression
was
confirmed
this
morning
,
and
increased
a
hundredfold
.
<EOS>
Sitting
bolt
upright
upon
his
bony
steed
,
with
his
long
,
straight
hair
,
dangling
about
his
face
and
fluttering
in
the
wind
;
his
limbs
all
angular
and
rigid
,
his
elbows
stuck
out
on
either
side
ungracefully
,
and
his
whole
frame
jogged
and
shaken
at
every
motion
of
his
horse
's
feet
;
a
more
grotesque
or
more
ungainly
figure
can
hardly
be
conceived
.
 
<EOS>
In
lieu
of
whip
,
he
carried
in
his
hand
a
great
gold
-
headed
cane
,
as
large
as
any
footman
carries
in
these
days
,
and
his
various
modes
of
holding
this
unwieldy
weapon
---
now
upright
before
his
face
like
the
sabre
of
a
horse
-
soldier
,
now
over
his
shoulder
like
a
musket
,
now
between
his
finger
and
thumb
,
but
always
in
some
uncouth
and
awkward
fashion
---
contributed
in
no
small
degree
to
the
absurdity
of
his
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
Stiff
,
lank
,
and
solemn
,
dressed
in
an
unusual
manner
,
and
ostentatiously
exhibiting
---
whether
by
design
or
accident
---
all
his
peculiarities
of
carriage
,
gesture
,
and
conduct
,
all
the
qualities
,
natural
and
artificial
,
in
which
he
differed
from
other
men
<EOS>
;
he
might
have
moved
the
sternest
looker
-
on
to
laughter
,
and
fully
provoked
the
smiles
and
whispered
jests
which
greeted
his
departure
from
the
Maypole
inn
.
  
<EOS>
Quite
unconscious
,
however
,
of
the
effect
he
produced
,
he
trotted
on
beside
his
secretary
,
talking
to
himself
nearly
all
the
way
,
until
they
came
within
a
mile
or
two
of
London
,
when
now
and
then
some
passenger
went
by
who
knew
him
by
sight
,
and
pointed
him
out
to
some
one
else
,
and
perhaps
stood
looking
after
him
,
or
cried
in
jest
or
earnest
as
it
might
be
,
"
Hurrah
Geordie
!
 
<EOS>
No
Popery
!
"
 
<EOS>
At
which
he
would
gravely
pull
off
his
hat
,
and
bow
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
reached
the
town
and
rode
along
the
streets
,
these
notices
became
more
frequent
;
some
laughed
,
some
hissed
,
some
turned
their
heads
and
smiled
,
some
wondered
who
he
was
,
some
ran
along
the
pavement
by
his
side
and
cheered
.
 
<EOS>
When
this
happened
in
a
crush
of
carts
and
chairs
and
coaches
,
he
would
make
a
dead
stop
,
and
pulling
off
his
hat
,
cry
,
"
Gentlemen
,
No
Popery
!
"
to
which
the
gentlemen
would
respond
with
lusty
voices
,
and
with
three
times
three
;
and
then
,
on
he
would
go
again
with
a
score
or
so
of
the
raggedest
,
following
at
his
horse
's
heels
,
and
shouting
till
their
throats
were
parched
.
  
<EOS>
The
old
ladies
too
---
there
were
a
great
many
old
ladies
in
the
streets
,
and
these
all
knew
him
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
them
---
not
those
of
the
highest
rank
,
but
such
as
sold
fruit
from
baskets
and
carried
burdens
---
clapped
their
shrivelled
hands
,
and
raised
a
weazen
,
piping
,
shrill
"
Hurrah
,
my
lord
.
"
 
<EOS>
Others
waved
their
hands
or
handkerchiefs
,
or
shook
their
fans
or
parasols
,
or
threw
up
windows
and
called
in
haste
to
those
within
,
to
come
and
see
.
 
<EOS>
All
these
marks
of
popular
esteem
<EOS>
,
he
received
with
profound
gravity
and
respect
;
bowing
very
low
,
and
so
frequently
that
his
hat
was
more
off
his
head
than
on
;
and
looking
up
at
the
houses
as
he
passed
along
,
with
the
air
of
one
who
was
making
a
public
entry
,
and
yet
was
not
puffed
up
or
proud
.
  
<EOS>
So
they
rode
(
to
the
deep
and
unspeakable
disgust
of
John
Grueby
)
<EOS>
the
whole
length
of
Whitechapel
,
Leadenhall
Street
,
and
Cheapside
,
and
into
St
Paul
's
Churchyard
.
 
<EOS>
Arriving
close
to
the
cathedral
,
he
halted
;
spoke
to
Gashford
;
and
looking
upward
at
its
lofty
dome
,
shook
his
head
,
as
though
he
said
,
"
The
Church
in
Danger
!
"
 
<EOS>
Then
to
be
sure
,
the
bystanders
stretched
their
throats
indeed
;
and
he
went
on
again
with
mighty
acclamations
from
the
mob
,
and
lower
bows
than
ever
.
  
<EOS>
So
along
the
Strand
,
up
Swallow
Street
,
into
the
Oxford
Road
,
and
thence
to
his
house
in
Welbeck
Street
,
near
Cavendish
Square
,
whither
he
was
attended
by
a
few
dozen
idlers
;
of
whom
he
took
leave
on
the
steps
with
this
brief
parting
,
"
Gentlemen
,
No
Popery
.
<EOS>
Good
day
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
being
rather
a
shorter
address
than
they
expected
,
was
received
with
some
displeasure
,
and
cries
of
"
A
speech
!
<EOS>
a
speech
!
"
which
might
have
been
complied
with
,
but
that
John
Grueby
,
making
a
mad
charge
upon
them
with
all
three
horses
,
on
his
way
to
the
stables
,
caused
them
to
disperse
into
the
adjoining
fields
,
where
they
presently
fell
to
pitch
and
toss
,
chuck
-
farthing
,
odd
or
even
,
dog
-
fighting
,
and
other
Protestant
recreations
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
afternoon
Lord
George
came
forth
again
,
dressed
in
a
black
velvet
coat
,
and
trousers
and
waistcoat
of
the
Gordon
plaid
,
all
of
the
same
Quaker
cut
;
and
in
this
costume
,
which
made
him
look
a
dozen
times
more
strange
and
singular
than
before
,
went
down
on
foot
to
Westminster
.
 
<EOS>
Gashford
,
meanwhile
,
bestirred
himself
in
business
matters
;
with
which
he
was
still
engaged
when
,
shortly
after
dusk
,
John
Grueby
entered
and
announced
a
visitor
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
him
come
in
,
"
said
Gashford
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
!
come
in
!
"
<EOS>
growled
John
to
somebody
without
;
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
Protestant
,
an't
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
so
,
"
replied
a
deep
,
gruff
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
've
the
looks
of
it
,
"
said
John
Grueby
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'd
have
known
you
for
one
,
anywhere
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
which
remark
he
gave
the
visitor
admission
,
retired
,
and
shut
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
The
man
who
now
confronted
Gashford
,
was
a
squat
,
thickset
personage
,
with
a
low
,
retreating
forehead
,
a
coarse
shock
head
of
hair
,
and
eyes
so
small
and
near
together
,
that
his
broken
nose
alone
seemed
to
prevent
their
meeting
and
fusing
into
one
of
the
usual
size
.
 
<EOS>
A
dingy
handkerchief
twisted
like
a
cord
about
his
neck
,
left
its
great
veins
exposed
to
view
,
and
they
were
swollen
and
starting
,
as
though
with
gulping
down
strong
passions
,
malice
,
and
ill
-
will
.
 
<EOS>
His
dress
was
of
threadbare
velveteen
---
a
faded
,
rusty
,
whitened
black
,
like
the
ashes
of
a
pipe
or
a
coal
fire
after
a
day
's
extinction
;
discoloured
with
the
soils
of
many
a
stale
debauch
,
and
reeking
yet
with
pot
-
house
odours
.
 
<EOS>
In
lieu
of
buckles
at
his
knees
,
he
wore
unequal
loops
of
packthread
;
and
in
his
grimy
hands
he
held
a
knotted
stick
,
the
knob
of
which
was
carved
into
a
rough
likeness
of
his
own
vile
face
.
 
<EOS>
Such
was
the
visitor
who
doffed
his
three
-
cornered
hat
in
Gashford
's
presence
,
and
waited
,
leering
,
for
his
notice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
Dennis
!
"
cried
the
secretary
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
see
my
lord
down
yonder
---
"
cried
the
man
,
with
a
jerk
of
his
thumb
towards
the
quarter
that
he
spoke
of
,
"
and
he
says
to
me
,
says
my
lord
,
"
If
you
've
nothing
to
do
,
Dennis
,
go
up
to
my
house
and
talk
with
Muster
Gashford
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Of
course
I
'd
nothing
to
do
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
These
an't
<EOS>
my
working
hours
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
a
-
taking
the
air
<EOS>
when
I
see
my
lord
,
that
's
what
I
was
doing
.
 
<EOS>
I
takes
the
air
by
night
,
as
the
howls
does
,
Muster
Gashford
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
sometimes
in
the
day
-
time
,
eh
?
"
said
the
secretary
---
"
when
you
go
out
in
state
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
!
<EOS>
"
roared
the
fellow
,
smiting
his
leg
;
"
for
a
gentleman
as
"
ull
say
a
pleasant
thing
in
a
pleasant
way
,
give
me
Muster
Gashford
agin
'
all
London
and
Westminster
!
 
<EOS>
My
lord
an't
<EOS>
a
bad
'
un
at
that
,
<EOS>
but
he
's
a
fool
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
to
be
sure
,
---
when
I
go
out
in
state
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
have
your
carriage
,
"
said
the
secretary
;
"
and
your
chaplain
,
eh
?
<EOS>
and
all
the
rest
of
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
'll
be
the
death
of
me
,
"
cried
Dennis
,
with
another
roar
,
"
you
will
.
 
<EOS>
But
what
's
in
the
wind
now
<EOS>
,
Muster
Gashford
,
"
he
asked
hoarsely
,
"
Eh
?
 
<EOS>
Are
we
to
be
under
orders
to
pull
down
one
of
them
Popish
chapels
---
or
what
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Hush
!
"
said
the
secretary
,
suffering
the
faintest
smile
to
play
upon
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
 
<EOS>
God
bless
me
,
Dennis
!
 
<EOS>
We
associate
,
you
know
,
for
strictly
peaceable
and
lawful
purposes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
,
bless
you
,
"
returned
the
man
,
thrusting
his
tongue
into
his
cheek
;
"
I
entered
a
"
purpose
,
did
n't
I
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
"
said
Gashford
,
smiling
as
before
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
he
said
so
,
Dennis
roared
again
,
and
smote
his
leg
still
harder
,
and
falling
into
fits
of
laughter
,
wiped
his
eyes
with
the
corner
of
his
neckerchief
,
and
cried
,
"
Muster
Gashford
agin
'
all
England
hollow
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lord
George
and
I
were
talking
of
you
last
night
,
"
said
Gashford
,
after
a
pause
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
says
you
are
a
very
earnest
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Lookye

,
Muster

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"
  
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Parliament

---

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

!

<EOS>
Chapter
38

"

"

.

"

<EOS>
"
No

,
