!
"
cried
the
hangman
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
Property
,
brother
!
"
responded
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Popery
,
Popery
,
"
said
the
secretary
with
his
usual
mildness
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
the
same
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Dennis
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
right
.
 
<EOS>
Down
with
him
,
Muster
Gashford
.
 
<EOS>
Down
with
everybody
,
down
with
everything
!
<EOS>
Hurrah
for
the
Protestant
religion
!
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
time
of
day
,
Muster
Gashford
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
secretary
regarded
them
both
with
a
very
favourable
expression
of
countenance
,
while
they
gave
loose
to
these
and
other
demonstrations
of
their
patriotic
purpose
;
and
was
about
to
make
some
remark
aloud
,
when
Dennis
,
stepping
up
to
him
,
and
shading
his
mouth
with
his
hand
,
said
,
in
a
hoarse
whisper
,
as
he
nudged
him
with
his
elbow
:
  
"
Do
n't
split
upon
a
constitutional
officer
's
profession
,
Muster
Gashford
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
popular
prejudices
,
you
know
,
and
he
might
n't
like
it
.
 
<EOS>
Wait
till
he
comes
to
be
more
intimate
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
a
fine
-
built
chap
,
an't
he
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
powerful
fellow
indeed
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
ever
,
Muster
Gashford
,
"
whispered
Dennis
,
with
a
horrible
kind
of
admiration
,
such
as
that
with
which
a
cannibal
might
regard
his
intimate
friend
,
when
hungry
<EOS>
,
---
"
did
you
ever
---
and
here
he
drew
still
closer
to
his
ear
,
and
fenced
his
mouth
with
both
his
open
bands
---
"
see
such
a
throat
as
his
?
 
<EOS>
Do
but
cast
your
eye
upon
it
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
neck
for
stretching
,
Muster
Gashford
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
secretary
assented
to
this
proposition
with
the
best
grace
he
could
assume
---
it
is
difficult
to
feign
a
true
professional
relish
:
which
is
eccentric
sometimes
---
and
after
asking
the
candidate
a
few
unimportant
questions
,
proceeded
to
enrol
him
a
member
of
the
Great
Protestant
Association
of
England
.
 
<EOS>
If
anything
could
have
exceeded
Mr
Dennis
's
joy
on
the
happy
conclusion
of
this
ceremony
,
it
would
have
been
the
rapture
with
which
he
received
the
announcement
that
the
new
member
could
neither
read
nor
write
:
those
two
arts
being
(
as
Mr
Dennis
swore
)
the
greatest
possible
curse
a
civilised
community
could
know
,
and
militating
more
against
the
professional
emoluments
and
usefulness
of
the
great
constitutional
office
he
had
the
honour
to
hold
,
than
any
adverse
circumstances
that
could
present
themselves
to
his
imagination
.
  
<EOS>
The
enrolment
being
completed
,
and
Hugh
having
been
informed
by
Gashford
,
in
his
peculiar
manner
,
of
the
peaceful
and
strictly
lawful
objects
contemplated
by
the
body
to
which
he
now
belonged
---
 
during
which
recital
Mr
Dennis
nudged
him
very
much
with
his
elbow
,
and
made
divers
remarkable
faces
---
the
secretary
gave
them
both
to
understand
that
he
desired
to
be
alone
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
they
took
their
leaves
without
delay
,
and
came
out
of
the
house
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
walking
,
brother
?
"
said
Dennis
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
"
returned
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
you
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
social
,
"
said
his
new
friend
.
 
<EOS>
"
Which
way
shall
we
take
?
<EOS>
Shall
we
go
and
have
a
look
at
doors
that
we
shall
make
a
pretty
good
clattering
at
,
before
long
---
eh
,
brother
?
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
answering
in
the
affirmative
,
they
went
slowly
down
to
Westminster
,
where
both
houses
of
Parliament
were
then
sitting
.
<EOS>
Mingling
in
the
crowd
of
carriages
,
horses
,
servants
,
chairmen
,
link
-
boys
,
porters
,
and
idlers
of
all
kinds
,
they
lounged
about
;
while
Hugh
's
new
friend
pointed
out
to
him
significantly
the
weak
parts
of
the
building
,
how
easy
it
was
to
get
into
the
lobby
,
and
so
to
the
very
door
of
the
House
of
Commons
;
and
how
plainly
,
when
they
marched
down
there
in
grand
array
,
their
roars
and
shouts
would
be
heard
by
the
members
inside
;
with
a
great
deal
more
to
the
same
purpose
,
all
of
which
Hugh
received
with
manifest
delight
.
  
<EOS>
He
told
him
,
too
,
who
some
of
the
Lords
and
Commons
were
,
by
name
,
as
they
came
in
and
out
;
whether
they
were
friendly
to
the
Papists
or
otherwise
;
and
bade
him
take
notice
of
their
liveries
and
equipages
,
that
he
might
be
sure
of
them
,
in
case
of
need
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
he
drew
him
close
to
the
windows
of
a
passing
carriage
,
that
he
might
see
its
master
's
face
by
the
light
of
the
lamps
;
and
,
both
in
respect
of
people
and
localities
,
he
showed
so
much
acquaintance
with
everything
around
,
that
it
was
plain
he
had
often
studied
there
before
;
<EOS>
as
indeed
,
when
they
grew
a
little
more
confidential
,
he
confessed
he
had
.
  
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
most
striking
part
of
all
this
was
,
the
number
of
people
---
never
in
groups
of
more
than
two
or
three
together
---
who
seemed
to
be
skulking
about
the
crowd
for
the
same
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
To
the
greater
part
of
these
,
a
slight
nod
or
a
look
from
Hugh
's
companion
was
sufficient
greeting
;
but
,
now
<EOS>
and
then
,
some
man
would
come
and
stand
beside
him
in
the
throng
,
and
,
without
turning
his
head
or
appearing
to
communicate
with
him
<EOS>
,
would
say
a
word
or
two
in
a
low
voice
,
which
he
would
answer
in
the
same
cautious
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Then
they
would
part
,
like
strangers
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
these
men
often
reappeared
again
unexpectedly
in
the
crowd
close
to
Hugh
,
and
,
as
they
passed
by
,
pressed
his
hand
,
or
looked
him
sternly
in
the
face
;
but
they
never
spoke
to
him
,
nor
he
to
them
;
no
,
not
a
word
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
remarkable
,
too
,
that
whenever
they
happened
to
stand
where
there
was
any
press
of
people
,
and
Hugh
chanced
to
be
looking
downward
,
he
was
sure
to
see
an
arm
stretched
out
---
under
his
own
perhaps
,
or
perhaps
across
him
---
which
thrust
some
paper
into
the
hand
or
pocket
of
a
bystander
,
and
was
so
suddenly
withdrawn
that
it
was
impossible
to
tell
from
whom
it
came
;
nor
could
he
see
in
any
face
,
on
glancing
quickly
round
,
the
least
confusion
or
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
They
often
trod
upon
a
paper
like
the
one
he
carried
in
his
breast
,
but
his
companion
whispered
him
not
to
touch
it
or
to
take
it
up
,
---
not
even
to
look
towards
it
,
---
<EOS>
so
there
they
let
them
lie
,
and
passed
on
.
  
<EOS>
When
they
had
paraded
the
street
and
all
the
avenues
of
the
building
in
this
manner
for
near
two
hours
,
they
turned
away
,
and
his
friend
asked
him
what
he
thought
of
what
he
had
seen
,
and
whether
he
was
prepared
for
a
good
hot
piece
of
work
if
it
should
come
to
that
.
 
<EOS>
The
hotter
the
better
,
"
said
Hugh
,
"
I
'm
prepared
for
anything
.
"
<EOS>
---
"
So
am
I
,
"
said
his
friend
,
"
and
so
are
many
of
us
;
and
they
shook
hands
upon
it
with
a
great
oath
,
and
with
many
terrible
imprecations
on
the
Papists
.
  
<EOS>
As
they
were
thirsty
by
this
time
,
Dennis
proposed
that
they
should
repair
together
to
The
Boot
,
where
there
was
good
company
and
strong
liquor
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
yielding
a
ready
assent
,
they
bent
their
steps
that
way
with
no
loss
of
time
.
  
<EOS>
This
Boot
was
a
lone
house
of
public
entertainment
,
situated
in
the
fields
at
the
back
of
the
Foundling
Hospital
;
a
very
solitary
spot
at
that
period
,
and
quite
deserted
after
dark
.
 
<EOS>
The
tavern
stood
at
some
distance
from
any
high
road
,
and
was
approachable
only
by
a
dark
and
narrow
lane
;
so
that
Hugh
was
much
surprised
to
find
several
people
drinking
there
,
and
great
merriment
going
on
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
still
more
surprised
to
find
among
them
almost
every
face
that
had
caught
his
attention
in
the
crowd
;
but
his
companion
having
whispered
him
outside
the
door
,
that
it
was
not
considered
good
manners
at
The
Boot
to
appear
at
all
curious
about
the
company
,
he
kept
his
own
counsel
,
and
made
no
show
of
recognition
.
  
<EOS>
Before
putting
his
lips
to
the
liquor
which
was
brought
for
them
,
Dennis
drank
in
a
loud
voice
the
health
of
Lord
George
Gordon
,
President
of
the
Great
Protestant
Association
;
which
toast
Hugh
pledged
likewise
,
with
corresponding
enthusiasm
.
 
<EOS>
A
fiddler
who
was
present
,
and
who
appeared
to
act
as
the
appointed
minstrel
of
the
company
,
forthwith
struck
up
a
Scotch
reel
;
and
that
in
tones
so
invigorating
,
that
Hugh
and
his
friend
(
who
had
both
been
drinking
before
)
rose
from
their
seats
as
by
previous
concert
,
and
,
to
the
great
admiration
of
the
assembled
guests
,
performed
an
extemporaneous
No
-
Popery
Dance
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
39
    
<EOS>
The
applause
which
the
performance
of
Hugh
and
his
new
friend
elicited
from
the
company
at
The
Boot
,
had
not
yet
subsided
,
and
the
two
dancers
were
still
panting
from
their
exertions
,
which
had
been
of
a
rather
extreme
and
violent
character
,
when
the
party
was
reinforced
by
the
arrival
of
some
more
guests
,
who
,
being
a
detachment
of
United
Bulldogs
,
were
received
with
very
flattering
marks
of
distinction
and
respect
.
  
<EOS>
The
leader
of
this
small
party
---
for
,
including
himself
,
they
were
but
three
in
number
---
was
our
old
acquaintance
,
Mr
Tappertit
,
who
seemed
,
physically
speaking
,
to
have
grown
smaller
with
years
(
particularly
as
to
his
legs
,
which
were
stupendously
little
)
,
but
who
,
in
a
moral
point
of
view
,
in
personal
dignity
and
self
-
esteem
,
had
swelled
into
a
giant
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
it
by
any
means
difficult
for
the
most
unobservant
person
to
detect
this
state
of
feeling
in
the
quondam
'
prentice
,
for
it
not
only
proclaimed
itself
impressively
and
beyond
mistake
in
his
majestic
walk
and
kindling
eye
,
but
found
a
striking
means
of
revelation
in
his
turned
-
up
nose
,
which
scouted
all
things
of
earth
with
deep
disdain
,
and
sought
communion
with
its
kindred
skies
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
,
as
chief
or
captain
of
the
Bulldogs
,
was
attended
by
his
two
lieutenants
;
one
,
the
tall
comrade
of
his
younger
life
;
the
other
,
a
'
Prentice
Knight
in
days
of
yore
---
Mark
Gilbert
,
bound
in
the
olden
time
to
Thomas
Curzon
of
the
Golden
Fleece
.
 
<EOS>
These
gentlemen
,
like
himself
,
were
now
emancipated
from
their
'
prentice
thraldom
,
and
served
as
journeymen
;
but
they
were
,
in
humble
emulation
of
his
great
example
,
bold
and
daring
spirits
,
and
aspired
to
a
distinguished
state
in
great
political
events
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
their
connection
with
the
Protestant
Association
of
England
,
sanctioned
by
the
name
of
Lord
George
Gordon
;
and
hence
their
present
visit
to
The
Boot
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
!
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
taking
off
his
hat
as
a
great
general
might
in
addressing
his
troops
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
met
.
 
<EOS>
My
lord
does
me
and
you
the
honour
to
send
his
compliments
per
self
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
've
seen
my
lord
too
,
have
you
?
"
said
Dennis
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
see
him
this
afternoon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
duty
called
me
to
the
Lobby
when
our
shop
shut
up
;
and
I
saw
him
there
,
sir
,
"
Mr
Tappertit
replied
,
as
he
and
his
lieutenants
took
their
seats
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
YOU
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lively
,
master
,
lively
,
"
said
the
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
new
brother
,
regularly
put
down
in
black
and
white
by
Muster
Gashford
;
a
credit
to
the
cause
;
one
of
the
stick
-
at
-
nothing
sort
;
one
arter
my
own
heart
.
 
<EOS>
D'ye
see
him
?
 
<EOS>
Has
he
got
the
looks
of
a
man
that
'll
do
,
do
you
think
?
<EOS>
"
he
cried
,
as
he
slapped
Hugh
on
the
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
Looks
or
no
looks
,
"
said
Hugh
,
with
a
drunken
flourish
of
his
arm
,
"
I
'm
the
man
you
want
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
the
Papists
,
every
one
of
'em
.
 
<EOS>
They
hate
me
<EOS>
and
I
hate
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
do
me
all
the
harm
they
can
,
and
I
'll
do
them
all
the
harm
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
Hurrah
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
there
ever
,
"
said
Dennis
,
looking
round
the
room
,
when
the
echo
of
his
boisterous
voice
bad
died
away
;
"
was
there
ever
such
a
game
boy
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
I
mean
to
say
,
brothers
,
that
if
Muster
Gashford
had
gone
a
hundred
mile
and
got
together
fifty
men
of
the
common
run
,
they
would
n't
have
been
worth
this
one
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
greater
part
of
the
company
implicitly
subscribed
to
this
opinion
,
and
testified
their
faith
in
Hugh
by
nods
and
looks
of
great
significance
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
sat
and
contemplated
him
for
a
long
time
in
silence
,
as
if
he
suspended
his
judgment
;
then
drew
a
little
nearer
to
him
,
and
eyed
him
over
more
carefully
;
then
went
close
up
to
him
,
and
took
him
apart
into
a
dark
corner
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
he
began
,
with
a
thoughtful
brow
,
"
have
n't
I
seen
you
before
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
like
you
may
,
"
said
Hugh
,
in
his
careless
way
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
;
should
n't
wonder
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
<EOS>
but
it
's
very
easily
settled
,
"
returned
Sim
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
at
me
.
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
see
ME
before
?
 
<EOS>
You
would
n't
be
likely
to
forget
it
,
you
know
,
if
you
ever
did
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
afraid
;
I
wo
n't
do
you
any
harm
.
 
<EOS>
Take
a
good
look
---
steady
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
encouraging
way
in
which
Mr
Tappertit
made
this
request
,
and
coupled
it
with
an
assurance
that
he
need
n't
be
frightened
,
amused
Hugh
mightily
---
so
much
indeed
,
that
be
saw
nothing
at
all
of
the
small
man
before
him
,
through
closing
his
eyes
in
a
fit
of
hearty
laughter
,
which
shook
his
great
broad
sides
until
they
ached
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
<EOS>
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
growing
a
little
impatient
under
this
disrespectful
treatment
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
me
,
feller
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
I
,
"
cried
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Not
I
!
 
<EOS>
But
I
should
like
to
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
I
'd
have
wagered
a
seven
-
shilling
piece
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
folding
his
arms
,
and
confronting
him
with
his
legs
wide
apart
and
firmly
planted
on
the
ground
,
"
that
you
once
were
hostler
at
the
Maypole
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
opened
his
eyes
on
hearing
this
,
and
looked
at
him
in
great
surprise
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
And
so
you
were
,
too
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
pushing
him
away
with
a
condescending
playfulness
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
did
MY
eyes
ever
deceive
---
 
unless
it
was
a
young
woman
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
know
me
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
it
an't
---
"
Hugh
faltered
.
  
<EOS>
"
An't
it
?
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
sure
of
that
?
 
<EOS>
You
remember
G
Varden
,
do
n't
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
Certainly
Hugh
did
,
and
he
remembered
D
Varden
too
;
but
that
he
did
n't
tell
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
remember
coming
down
there
,
before
I
was
out
of
my
time
,
to
ask
after
a
vagabond
that
had
bolted
off
,
and
left
his
disconsolate
father
a
prey
to
the
bitterest
emotions
,
and
all
the
rest
of
it
---
 
do
n't
you
?
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
do
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
saw
you
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Saw
me
there
!
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
should
think
you
did
see
me
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
place
would
be
troubled
to
go
on
without
me
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
remember
my
thinking
you
liked
the
vagabond
,
and
on
that
account
going
to
quarrel
with
you
;
and
then
finding
you
detested
him
worse
than
poison
,
going
to
drink
with
you
?
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
remember
that
?
"
  
"
To
be
sure
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
and
are
you
in
the
same
mind
now
?
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
<EOS>
roared
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
speak
like
a
man
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
"
and
I
'll
shake
hands
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
these
conciliatory
expressions
he
suited
the
action
to
the
word
;
and
Hugh
meeting
his
advances
readily
,
they
performed
the
ceremony
with
a
show
of
great
heartiness
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
find
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
looking
round
on
the
assembled
guests
,
"
<EOS>
that
brother
What's
-
his
-
name
<EOS>
and
I
are
old
acquaintance
.
<EOS>
---
You
never
heard
anything
more
of
that
rascal
,
I
suppose
,
eh
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
a
syllable
,
"
replied
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
want
to
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
believe
I
ever
shall
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
dead
long
ago
,
I
hope
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
to
be
hoped
,
for
the
sake
of
mankind
in
general
and
the
happiness
of
society
,
that
he
is
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
rubbing
his
palm
upon
his
legs
,
and
looking
at
it
between
whiles
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
your
other
hand
at
all
cleaner
?
 
<EOS>
Much
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
'll
owe
you
another
shake
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
suppose
it
done
,
if
you
've
no
objection
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
laughed
again
,
and
with
such
thorough
abandonment
to
his
mad
humour
,
that
his
limbs
seemed
dislocated
,
and
his
whole
frame
in
danger
of
tumbling
to
pieces
;
but
Mr
Tappertit
,
so
far
from
receiving
this
extreme
merriment
with
any
irritation
,
was
pleased
to
regard
it
with
the
utmost
favour
,
and
even
to
join
in
it
,
so
far
as
one
of
his
gravity
and
station
could
,
with
any
regard
to
that
decency
and
decorum
which
men
in
high
places
are
expected
to
maintain
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
did
not
stop
here
,
as
many
public
characters
might
have
done
,
but
calling
up
his
brace
of
lieutenants
,
introduced
Hugh
to
them
with
high
commendation
;
declaring
him
to
be
a
man
who
,
at
such
times
as
those
in
which
they
lived
,
could
not
be
too
much
cherished
.
 
<EOS>
Further
,
he
did
him
the
honour
to
remark
,
that
he
would
be
an
acquisition
of
which
even
the
United
Bulldogs
might
be
proud
;
and
finding
,
upon
sounding
him
,
that
he
was
quite
ready
and
willing
to
enter
the
society
(
for
he
was
not
at
all
particular
,
and
would
have
leagued
himself
that
night
with
anything
,
or
anybody
,
for
any
purpose
whatsoever
)
,
caused
the
necessary
preliminaries
to
be
gone
into
upon
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
This
tribute
to
his
great
merit
delighted
no
man
more
than
Mr
Dennis
,
as
he
himself
proclaimed
with
several
rare
and
surprising
oaths
;
and
indeed
it
gave
unmingled
satisfaction
to
the
whole
assembly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Make
anything
you
like
of
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
flourishing
the
can
he
had
emptied
more
than
once
.
 
<EOS>
"
Put
me
on
any
duty
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
your
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
my
captain
---
here
's
my
leader
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Let
him
give
me
the
word
of
command
,
and
I
'll
fight
the
whole
Parliament
House
single
-
handed
,
or
set
a
lighted
torch
to
the
King
's
Throne
itself
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
that
,
he
smote
Mr
Tappertit
on
the
back
,
with
such
violence
that
his
little
body
seemed
to
shrink
into
a
mere
nothing
;
and
roared
again
until
the
very
foundlings
near
at
hand
were
startled
in
their
beds
.
  
<EOS>
In
fact
,
a
sense
of
something
whimsical
in
their
companionship
seemed
to
have
taken
entire
possession
of
his
rude
brain
.
 
<EOS>
The
bare
fact
of
being
patronised
by
a
great
man
whom
he
could
have
crushed
with
one
hand
,
appeared
in
his
eyes
so
eccentric
and
humorous
,
that
a
kind
of
ferocious
merriment
gained
the
mastery
over
him
,
and
quite
subdued
his
brutal
nature
.
 
<EOS>
He
roared
and
roared
again
;
toasted
Mr
Tappertit
a
hundred
times
;
declared
himself
a
Bulldog
to
the
core
;
and
vowed
to
be
faithful
to
him
to
the
last
drop
of
blood
in
his
veins
.
  
<EOS>
All
these
compliments
Mr
Tappertit
received
as
matters
of
course
---
 
flattering
enough
in
their
way
,
but
entirely
attributable
to
his
vast
superiority
.
 
<EOS>
His
dignified
self
-
possession
only
delighted
Hugh
the
more
;
and
in
a
word
,
this
giant
and
dwarf
struck
up
a
friendship
which
bade
fair
to
be
of
long
continuance
,
as
the
one
held
it
to
be
his
right
to
command
,
and
the
other
considered
it
an
exquisite
pleasantry
to
obey
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
Hugh
by
any
means
a
passive
follower
,
who
scrupled
to
act
without
precise
and
definite
orders
;
for
when
Mr
Tappertit
mounted
on
an
empty
cask
which
stood
by
way
of
rostrum
in
the
room
,
and
volunteered
a
speech
upon
the
alarming
crisis
then
at
hand
,
he
placed
himself
beside
the
orator
,
and
though
he
grinned
from
ear
to
ear
at
every
word
he
said
,
threw
out
such
expressive
hints
to
scoffers
in
the
management
of
his
cudgel
,
that
those
who
were
at
first
the
most
disposed
to
interrupt
,
became
remarkably
attentive
,
and
were
the
loudest
in
their
approbation
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
all
noise
and
jest
,
however
,
at
The
Boot
,
nor
were
the
whole
party
listeners
to
the
speech
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
some
men
at
the
other
end
of
the
room
(
which
was
a
long
,
low
-
roofed
chamber
)
in
earnest
conversation
all
the
time
;
and
when
any
of
this
group
went
out
,
fresh
people
were
sure
to
come
in
soon
afterwards
and
sit
down
in
their
places
,
as
though
the
others
had
relieved
them
on
some
watch
or
duty
;
which
it
was
pretty
clear
they
did
,
for
these
changes
took
place
by
the
clock
,
at
intervals
of
half
an
hour
.
<EOS>
These
persons
whispered
very
much
among
themselves
,
and
kept
aloof
,
and
often
looked
round
,
as
jealous
of
their
speech
being
overheard
;
some
two
or
three
among
them
entered
in
books
what
seemed
to
be
reports
from
the
others
;
when
they
were
not
thus
employed
)
<EOS>
one
of
them
would
turn
to
the
newspapers
which
were
strewn
upon
the
table
,
and
from
the
St
James
's
Chronicle
,
the
Herald
,
Chronicle
,
or
Public
Advertiser
,
would
read
to
the
rest
in
a
low
voice
some
passage
having
reference
to
the
topic
in
which
they
were
all
so
deeply
interested
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
great
attraction
was
a
pamphlet
called
The
Thunderer
,
which
espoused
their
own
opinions
,
and
was
supposed
at
that
time
to
emanate
directly
from
the
Association
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
always
in
request
;
and
whether
read
aloud
,
to
an
eager
knot
of
listeners
,
or
by
some
solitary
man
,
was
certain
to
be
followed
by
stormy
talking
and
excited
looks
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
all
his
merriment
,
and
admiration
of
his
captain
,
Hugh
was
made
sensible
by
these
and
other
tokens
,
of
the
presence
of
an
air
of
mystery
,
akin
to
that
which
had
so
much
impressed
him
out
of
doors
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
to
discard
a
sense
that
something
serious
was
going
on
,
and
that
under
the
noisy
revel
of
the
public
-
house
,
there
lurked
unseen
and
dangerous
matter
.
 
<EOS>
Little
affected
by
this
,
however
,
he
was
perfectly
satisfied
with
his
quarters
and
would
have
remained
there
till
morning
,
but
that
his
conductor
rose
soon
after
midnight
,
to
go
home
;
Mr
Tappertit
following
his
example
,
left
him
no
excuse
to
stay
.
 
<EOS>
So
they
all
three
left
the
house
together
:
roaring
a
No
-
Popery
song
until
the
fields
resounded
with
the
dismal
noise
.
  
<EOS>
Cheer
up
,
captain
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
when
they
had
roared
themselves
out
of
breath
.
 
<EOS>
"
Another
stave
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
,
nothing
loath
,
began
again
;
and
so
the
three
went
staggering
on
,
arm
-
in
-
arm
,
shouting
like
madmen
,
and
defying
the
watch
with
great
valour
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
this
did
not
require
any
unusual
bravery
or
boldness
,
as
the
watchmen
of
that
time
,
being
selected
for
the
office
on
account
of
excessive
age
and
extraordinary
infirmity
,
had
a
custom
of
shutting
themselves
up
tight
in
their
boxes
on
the
first
symptoms
of
disturbance
,
and
remaining
there
until
they
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
In
these
proceedings
,
Mr
Dennis
,
who
had
a
gruff
voice
and
lungs
of
considerable
power
,
distinguished
himself
very
much
,
and
acquired
great
credit
with
his
two
companions
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
queer
fellow
you
are
!
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
so
precious
sly
and
close
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
n't
you
ever
tell
what
trade
you
're
of
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Answer
the
captain
instantly
,
"
cried
Hugh
,
beating
his
hat
down
on
his
head
;
"
why
do
n't
you
ever
tell
what
trade
you
're
of
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
of
as
gen
-
teel
a
calling
,
brother
,
as
any
man
in
England
---
as
light
a
business
as
any
gentleman
could
desire
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
you
'
prenticed
to
it
?
"
asked
Mr
Tappertit
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Natural
genius
,
"
said
Mr
Dennis
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
'
prenticing
.
 
<EOS>
It
come
by
natur
'
.
 
<EOS>
Muster
Gashford
knows
my
calling
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
that
hand
of
mine
---
many
and
many
a
job
that
hand
has
done
,
with
a
neatness
and
dex
-
terity
,
never
known
afore
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
look
at
that
hand
,
"
said
Mr
Dennis
,
shaking
it
in
the
air
,
"
and
remember
the
helegant
bits
of
work
it
has
turned
off
,
I
feel
quite
molloncholy
to
think
it
should
ever
grow
old
and
feeble
.
 
<EOS>
But
sich
is
life
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
heaved
a
deep
sigh
as
he
indulged
in
these
reflections
,
and
putting
his

with
an
absent

on
Hugh
's
throat
,
and
particularly

left

,
as

were

of
that
part
of
his

,
shook

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
kind

artist
,
I
suppose
---
eh
!
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"

Dennis
;
"
yes
---
I
may

myself

---
a

---
art
improves
natur
"
---

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
taking

.
  
<EOS>
"
That

my
portrait
atop
,
"

;
"
d'ye

's

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why

it
's
a

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
did

?
<EOS>
You
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
!
"
<EOS>
repeated

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish

the
talent
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
carved
by
a

,
as

.
 
<EOS>
The

afore

,

cut

from

!
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll

game
,
"

,
"

my

to
making
Dennis
's

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
That
's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
WAS

,
"

,

"
but

one

,
stand

,

.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
He

would

a
bit
,
<EOS>
did
that
friend

mine
,
on
the
morning

he
died
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
with

?
"

Tappertit
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
he

with

,
"
I
was
there
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
yes
certainly
,
I
was
there
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
n't
have
gone
off
half
as
comfortable
without
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
with
three

four

.
 
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
must

you
,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
"

,

,
"

they

me

'em

.
 
<EOS>
I
come
in
for

wardrobes
too
.
 
<EOS>
This

handkecher
<EOS>
that

round

,

him
that
I
've
been
speaking
of
---
him
as

that

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
glanced

,
and
appeared

deceased
's

of
dress

.
 
<EOS>
He
made
no

the

,

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
These
smalls
,
"
said

,

;
"
these
very
smalls
---
 
<EOS>
they

's

sich
incumbrances
for

:
this

---
I
've

,
in

,

:
this

,
afore
my

,
full

:

,
"

"
Lord
!
<EOS>

---
ah

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Every

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Every

Jack
!
"
  
<EOS>
There

,

,

,

---

---
that

,

,

,

with

.
 
<EOS>
As

,
and
Mr

knew

turnkeys
in
the

with

he
could

,
and
discuss
professional

among

before

,

glass
,
he

without

,
and

Hugh
,
and

early

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's

,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
watching

's

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

.
 
<EOS>
Why
ca

have

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
But

.
 
<EOS>
The

's

.
 
<EOS>
On
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It
's
well
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"
No

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
England

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
Whereat
Hugh
cheered
and

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
man
will
prove

,
"

Simon
,

<EOS>
"
And

.
 
<EOS>
In

---

---
 
when

mine
,
Miggs

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
I

.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
40
    
Little
thinking
of
the
plan
for
his
happy
settlement
in
life
which
had
suggested
itself
to
the
teeming
brain
of
his
provident
commander
<EOS>
,
Hugh
made
no
pause
until
Saint
Dunstan
's
giants
struck
the
hour
above
him
,
when
he
worked
the
handle
of
a
pump
which
stood
hard
by
,
with
great
vigour
,
and
thrusting
his
head
under
the
spout
,
let
the
water
gush
upon
him
until
a
little
stream
ran
down
from
every
uncombed
hair
,
and
he
was
wet
to
the
waist
.
 
<EOS>
Considerably
refreshed
by
this
ablution
,
both
in
mind
and
body
,
and
almost
sobered
for
the
time
,
he
dried
himself
as
he
best
could
;
then
crossed
the
road
,
and
plied
the
knocker
of
the
Middle
Temple
gate
.
  
<EOS>
The
night
-
porter
looked
through
a
small
grating
in
the
portal
with
a
surly
eye
,
and
cried
"
Halloa
!
"
<EOS>
which
greeting
Hugh
returned
in
kind
,
and
bade
him
open
quickly
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
do
n't
sell
beer
here
,
"
cried
the
man
;
"
what
else
do
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
come
in
,
"
Hugh
replied
,
with
a
kick
at
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
to
go
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Paper
Buildings
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whose
chambers
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Sir
John
Chester
's
.
"
 
<EOS>
Each
of
which
answers
,
he
emphasised
with
another
kick
.
  
<EOS>
After
a
little
growling
on
the
other
side
,
the
gate
was
opened
,
and
he
passed
in
:
undergoing
a
close
inspection
from
the
porter
as
he
did
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
YOU
wanting
Sir
John
,
at
this
time
of
night
!
"
said
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
!
 
<EOS>
What
of
that
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
must
go
with
you
and
see
that
you
do
,
for
I
do
n't
believe
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Come
along
then
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Eyeing
him
with
suspicious

,
the
man
,
with
key
and

,
walked
on
at
his
side
,
and
attended
him
to
Sir
John
Chester
's
door
,
at
which
Hugh
gave
one

,
that
echoed
through

dark

like

ghostly
summons
,
and
made
the
dull

tremble
in
the
drowsy

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
he
wants
me
now
?
"
said
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
Before
the
man
had
time
to
answer
,
a
footstep
was
heard
within
,
a
light
appeared
,
and
Sir
John
,
in
his
dressing
-
gown
and

,
opened

door
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
ask
your
pardon
,
Sir
John
,
"
said
the
porter
,
pulling
off
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
young
man
says
he
wants
to
speak
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
late
for
strangers
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
it
best
to
see
that
all
was
right
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
"
cried
Sir

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
you
,
messenger
,
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
Go
in
.
 
<EOS>
Quite
right
,
friend
.
 
<EOS>
I
commend
your
prudence
highly
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
To
be
commended
,
thanked
,
God
-
blessed
,
and
bade
good
night
by
one
who
carried
"
Sir
"
before
his
name
,
and
wrote
himself
MP
to
boot
,
was
something
for
a
porter
.
 
<EOS>
He
withdrew
with
much
humility
and
reverence
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
John
followed
his
late
visitor
into
the
dressing
-
room
,
and
sitting
in
his
easy
-
chair
before
the
fire
,
and
moving
it
so
that
he
could
see
him
as
he
stood
,
hat
in
hand
,
beside
the
door
,
looked
at
him
from
head
to
foot
.
  
<EOS>
The
old
face
,
calm
and
pleasant
as
ever
;
the
complexion
,
quite
juvenile
in
its
bloom
and
clearness
;
the
same
smile
;
the
wonted
precision
and
elegance
of
dress
;
the
white
,
well
-
ordered
teeth
;
the
delicate
hands
;
the
composed
and
quiet
manner
;
everything
as
it
used
to
be
:
no
mark
of
age
or
passion
,
envy
,
hate
,
or
discontent
:
all
unruffled
and
serene
,
and
quite
delightful
to
behold
.
  
<EOS>
He
wrote
himself
MP
---
but
how
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
thus
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
proud
family
---
 
more
proud
,
indeed
,
than
wealthy
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
stood
in
danger
of
arrest
;
of
bailiffs
,
and
a
jail
---
a
vulgar
jail
,
to
which
the
common
people
with
small
incomes
went
.
 
<EOS>
Gentlemen
of
ancient
houses
have
no
privilege
of
exemption
from
such
cruel
laws
---
unless
they
are
of
one
great
house
,
and
then
they
have
.
 
<EOS>
A
proud
man
of
his
stock
and
kindred
had
the
means
of
sending
him
there
.
 
<EOS>
He
offered
---
not
indeed
to
pay
his
debts
,
but
<EOS>
to
let
him
sit
for
a
close
borough
until
his
own
son
came
of
age
,
which
,
if
he
lived
,
would
come
to
pass
in
twenty
years
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
quite
as
good
as
an
Insolvent
Act
,
and
infinitely
more
genteel
.
 
<EOS>
So
Sir
John
Chester
was
a
member
of
Parliament
.
  
<EOS>
But
how
Sir
John
?
 
<EOS>
Nothing
so
simple
,
or
so
easy
.
 
<EOS>
One
touch
with
a
sword
of
state
,
and
the
transformation
was
effected
.
 
<EOS>
John
Chester
,
Esquire
,
MP
,
attended
court
---
went
up
with
an
address
---
headed
a
deputation
.
 
<EOS>
Such
elegance
of
manner
,
so
many
graces
of
deportment
,
such
powers
of
conversation
,
could
never
pass
unnoticed
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
was
too
common
for
such
merit
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
so
gentlemanly
should
have
been
---
 
but
Fortune
is
capricious
---
born
a
Duke
:
just
as
some
dukes
should
have
been
born
labourers
.
 
<EOS>
He
caught
the
fancy
of
the
king
,
knelt
down
a
grub
,
and
rose
a
butterfly
.
 
<EOS>
John
Chester
,
Esquire
,
was
knighted
and
became
Sir
John
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
when
you
left
me
this
evening
,
my
esteemed
acquaintance
,
"
said
Sir
John
after
a
pretty
long
silence
,
"
that
you
intended
to
return
with
all
despatch
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
did
,
master
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
you
have
?
<EOS>
"
he
retorted
,
glancing
at
his
watch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
that
what
you
would
say
?
"
  
Instead
of
replying
,
Hugh
changed
the
leg
on
which
he
leant
,
shuffled
his
cap
from
one
hand
to
the
other
,
looked
at
the
ground
,
the
wall
,
the
ceiling
,
and
finally
at
Sir
John
himself
;
before
whose
pleasant
face
he
lowered
his
eyes
again
,
and
fixed
them
on
the
floor
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
have
you
been
employing
yourself
in
the
meanwhile
?
"
<EOS>
quoth
Sir
John
,
lazily
crossing
his
legs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
have
you
been
?
<EOS>
what
harm
have
you
been
doing
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
harm
at
all
,
master
,
"
growled
Hugh
,
with
humility
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
only
done
as
you
ordered
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
As
I
WHAT
?
"
returned
Sir
John
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
then
,
"
said
Hugh
uneasily
,
"
as
you
advised
,
or
said
I
ought
,
or
said
I
might
,
or
said
that
you
would
do
,
if
you
was
me
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
so
hard
upon
me
,
master
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Something
like
an
expression
of
triumph
in
the
perfect
control
he
had
established
over
this
rough
instrument
appeared
in
the
knight
's
face
for
an
instant
;
but
it
vanished
directly
,
as
he
said
---
paring
his
nails
while
speaking
:
  
<EOS>
"
When
you
say
I
ordered
you
,
my
good
fellow
,
you
imply
that
I
directed
you
to
do
something
for
me
---
<EOS>
something
I
wanted
done
---
 
something
for
my
own
ends
and
purposes
<EOS>
---
you
see
?
 
<EOS>
Now
I
am
sure
I
need
n't
enlarge
upon
the
extreme
absurdity
of
such
an
idea
,
however
unintentional
;
so
please
---
"
and
here
he
turned
his
eyes
upon
him
---
 
"
to
be
more
guarded
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
meant
to
give
you
no
offence
,
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
You
catch
me
up
so
very
short
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
caught
up
much
shorter
,
my
good
friend
---
infinitely
shorter
---
one
of
these
days
,
depend
upon
it
,
"
replied
his
patron
calmly
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
-
the
-
bye
,
instead
of
wondering
why
you
have
been
so
long
,
my
wonder
should
be
why
you
came
at

.
 
<EOS>
Why
did
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
master
,
"
said
Hugh
,
"
that
I
could
n't
read
the
bill
I
found
,
and
that
supposing
it
to
be
something
particular
from

,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
could
you
ask
no
one
else
to
read

,
Bruin
?
"
said
Sir
John
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
one
that
I
could
trust
with
secrets
,
master
.
 
<EOS>
Since
Barnaby
Rudge
was
lost
sight
of
for
good
and
all
---
and
that
's
five
years
ago
---
I
have
n't
talked
with
any
one
but
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
done
me
honour
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
to
and
fro
,
master
,
all
through
that
time
,
when
there
was
anything
to
tell
,
because
I
knew
that
you
'd
be
angry
with
me
if
I
stayed
away
,
"
said
Hugh
,
blurting
the
words
out
,
after
an
embarrassed

;
"
<EOS>
and
because
I
wished
to
please
you
if
I
could
,
and
not
to
have
you
go
against
me
.
 
<EOS>
There
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
true
reason
why
I
came
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
that
,
master
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
specious
fellow
,
"
returned
Sir
John
,
fixing
his
eyes
upon
him
,
"
and
carry
two
faces
under
your
hood
,
as
well
as
the
best
.
 
<EOS>
Did
n't
you
give
me
in
this
room
,
this
evening
,
any
other
reason
;
no
dislike
of
anybody
who
has
slighted
you
lately
,
on
all
occasions
,
abused
you
,
treated
you
with
rudeness
;
acted
towards
you
,
more
as
if
you
were
a
mongrel
dog
than
a
man
like
himself
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
be
sure
I
did
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
his
passion
rising
,
as
the
other
meant
it
should
;
"
and
I
say
it
all
over
now
,
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
do
anything
to
have
some
revenge
on
him
---
anything
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
you
told
me
that
he
and
all
the
Catholics
would
suffer
from
those
who
joined
together
under
that
handbill
,
I
said
I
'd
make
one
of
'em
,
if
their
master
was
the
devil
himself
.
 
<EOS>
I
AM
one
of
'em
.
 
<EOS>
See
whether
I
am
as
good
as
my
word
and
turn
out
to
be
among
the
foremost
,
or
no
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
n't
have
much
head
,
master
,
but
I
've
head
enough
to
remember
those
that
use
me
ill
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
see
,
and
so
shall
he
,
and
so
shall
<EOS>
hundreds
more
,
how
my
spirit
backs
me
when
the
time
comes
.
<EOS>
My
bark
is
nothing
to
my
bite
.
 
<EOS>
Some
that
I
know
had
better
have
a
wild
lion
among
'em
than
me
,
when
I
am
fairly
loose
---
they
had
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
knight
looked
at
him
with
a
smile
of
far
deeper
meaning
than
ordinary
;
and
pointing
to
the
old
cupboard
,
followed
him
with
his
eyes
while
he
filled
and
drank
a
glass
of
liquor
;
and
smiled
when
his
back
was
turned
,
with
deeper
meaning
yet
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
in
a
blustering
mood
,
my
friend
,
"
he
said
,
when
Hugh
confronted
him
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
I
,
master
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
say
half
<EOS>
I
mean
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
.
<EOS>
I
have
n't
got
the
gift
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
talkers
enough
among
us
;
I
'll
be
one
of
the
doers
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Oh
!
you
have
joined
those
fellows
then
?
"
said
Sir
John
,
with
an
air
of
most

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
up
to
the
house
you
told
me
of
;
and
got

down
upon
the

.
 
<EOS>
There
was
another
man
there
,
named
Dennis
---
"
  
"
Dennis
,
eh
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Sir
John
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
!
<EOS>
a
pleasant
fellow
,
I

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
A
roaring
dog
,
master
---
one

my
own
heart
---
hot
upon
the
matter
too
---
red

.
"
  
"
<EOS>
So
I
have
heard
,
"
replied
Sir
John
,
carelessly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
happen
to
know
his
trade
,
do

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
would
n't
say
,
"
cried
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
keeps
it
secret
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
!
"
laughed
Sir
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
strange
fancy
---
a
weakness
with
some
persons
<EOS>
---
you
'll
know
it
<EOS>
one
day
,
I
dare
swear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
're
intimate
already
,
"
said
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
natural
!
 
<EOS>
And
have
been
drinking
together
,
eh
?
<EOS>
"
pursued
Sir
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
you
say
what
place
you
went
to
in
company
,
when
you
left
Lord
George
's
?
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
had
not
said
or
thought
of
saying
,
but
he
told
him
;
and
this
inquiry
being
followed
by
a
long
train
of
questions
,
he
related
all
that
had
passed
both
in
and
out
of
doors
,
the
kind
of
people
he
had
seen
,
their
numbers
,
state
of
feeling
,
mode
of
conversation
,
apparent
expectations
and
intentions
.
 
<EOS>
His
questioning
was
so
artfully
contrived
,
that
he
seemed
even
in
his
own
eyes
to
volunteer
all
this
information
rather
than
to
have
it
wrested
from
him
;
and
he
was
brought
to
this
state
of
feeling
so
naturally
,
that
when
Mr
Chester
yawned
at
length
and
declared
himself
quite
wearied
out
,
he
made
a
rough
kind
of
excuse
for
having
talked
so
much
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
---
get
you
gone
,
"
said
Sir
John
,
holding
the
door
open
in
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
made
a
pretty
evening
's
work
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
you
not
to
do
this
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
get
into
trouble
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
have
an
opportunity
of
revenging
yourself
on
your
proud
friend
Haredale
,
though
,
and
for
that
,
you
'd
hazard
anything
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
would
,
"
retorted
Hugh
,
stopping
in
his
passage
out
and
looking
back
;
"
but
what
do
I
risk
!
 
<EOS>
What
do
I
stand
a
chance
of
losing
,
master
?
 
<EOS>
Friends
,
home
?
 
<EOS>
A
fig
for
'em
all
<EOS>
;
I
have
none
;
they
are
nothing
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
a
good
scuffle
;
let
me
pay
off
old
scores
in
a
bold
riot
where
there
are
men
to
stand
by
me
;
and
then
use
me
as
you
like
<EOS>
---
it
do
n't
matter
much
to
me
what
the
end
is
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
done
with
that
paper
?
"
said
Sir
John
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
it
here
,
master
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Drop
it
again
as
you
go
along
;
it
's
as
well
not
to
keep
such
things
about
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
nodded
,
and
touching
his
cap
with
an
air
of
as
much
respect
as
he
could
summon
up
,
departed
.
  
<EOS>
Sir
John
,
fastening
the
doors
behind
him
,
went
back
to
his
dressing
-
room
,
and
sat
down
once
again
before
the
fire
,
at
which
he
gazed
for
a
long
time
,
in
earnest
meditation
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
happens
fortunately
,
"
he
said
,
breaking
into
a
smile
,
"
and
promises
well
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
see
.
 
<EOS>
My
relative
and
I
,
who
are
the
most
Protestant
fellows
in
the
world
,
give
our
worst
wishes
to
the
Roman
Catholic
cause
;
and
to
Saville
,
who
introduces
their
bill
,
I
have
a
personal
objection
besides
;
but
as
each
of
us
has
himself
for
the
first
article
in
his
creed
,
we
can
not
commit
ourselves
by
joining
with
a
very
extravagant
madman
,
such
as
this
Gordon
most
undoubtedly
is
.
 
<EOS>
Now
really
,
to
foment
his
disturbances
in
secret
,
through
the
medium
of
such
a
very
apt
instrument
as
my
savage
friend
here
,
may
further
our
real
ends
;
and
to
express
at
all
becoming
seasons
,
in
moderate
and
polite
terms
,
a
disapprobation
of
his
proceedings
,
though
we
agree
with
him
in
principle
,
will
certainly
be
to
gain
a
character
for
honesty
and
uprightness
of
purpose
,
which
can
not
fail
to
do
us
infinite
service
,
and
to
raise
us
into
some
importance
.
 
<EOS>
Good
!
 
<EOS>
So
much
for
public
grounds
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
private
considerations
,
I
confess
that
if
these
vagabonds
WOULD
make
some
riotous
demonstration
(
which
does
not
appear
impossible
)
,
and
WOULD
inflict
some
little
chastisement
on
Haredale
as
a
not
inactive
man
among
his
sect
,
it
would
be
extremely
agreeable
to
my
feelings
,
and
would
amuse
me
beyond
measure
.
 
<EOS>
Good
again
!
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
better
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When
he
came
to
this
point
,
he
took
a
pinch
of
snuff
;
then
beginning
slowly
to
undress
,
he
resumed
his
meditations
,
by
saying
with
a
smile
:
  
<EOS>
"
I
fear
,
I
DO
fear
exceedingly
,
that
my
friend
is
following
fast
in
the
footsteps
of
his
mother
.
 
<EOS>
His
intimacy
with
Mr
Dennis
is
very
ominous
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
have
no
doubt
he
must
have
come
to
that
end
any
way
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
lend
him
a
helping
hand
,
the
only
difference
is
,
that
he
may
,
upon
the
whole
,
possibly
drink
a
few
gallons
,
or
puncheons
,
or
hogsheads
,
less
in
this
life
than
he
otherwise
would
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
no
business
of
mine
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
matter
of
very
small
importance
!
"
  
<EOS>
So
he
took
another
pinch
of
snuff
,
and
went
to
bed
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
41
    
From
the
workshop
of
the
Golden
Key
,
there
issued
forth
a
tinkling
sound
,
so
merry
and
good
-
humoured
,
that
it
suggested
the
idea
of
some
one
working
blithely
,
and
made
quite
pleasant
music
.
 
<EOS>
No
man
who
hammered
on
at
a
dull
monotonous
duty
,
could
have
brought
such
cheerful
notes
from
steel
and
iron
;
none
but
a
chirping
,
healthy
,
honest
-
hearted
fellow
,
who
made
the
best
of
everything
,
and
felt
kindly
towards
everybody
,
could
have
done
it
for
an
instant
.
 
<EOS>
He
might
have
been
a
coppersmith
,
and
still
been
musical
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
sat
in
a
jolting
waggon
,
full
of
rods
of
iron
,
it
seemed
as
if
he
would
have
brought
some
harmony
out
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
Tink
,
tink
,
tink
---
clear
as
a
silver
bell
,
and
audible
at
every
pause
of
the
streets
'
harsher
noises
,
as
though
it
said
,
"
I
do
n't
care
;
nothing
puts
me
out
;
I
am
resolved
to
he
happy
.
"
 
<EOS>
Women
scolded
,
children
squalled
,
heavy
carts
went
rumbling
by
,
horrible
cries
proceeded
from
the
lungs
of
hawkers
;
still
it
struck
in
again
,
no
higher
,
no
lower
,
no
louder
,
no
softer
;
not
thrusting
itself
on
people
's
notice
a
bit
the
more
for
having
been
outdone
by
louder
sounds
---
tink
,
tink
,
tink
,
tink
,
tink
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
perfect
embodiment
of
the
still
small
voice
,
free
from
all
cold
,
hoarseness
,
huskiness
,
or
unhealthiness
of
any
kind
;
foot
-
passengers
slackened
their
pace
,
and
were
disposed
to
linger
near
it
;
neighbours
who
had
got
up
splenetic
that
morning
,
felt
good
-
humour
stealing
on
them
as
they
heard
it
,
and
by
degrees
became
quite
sprightly
;
mothers
danced
their
babies
to
its
ringing
;
still
the
same
magical
tink
,
tink
,
tink
,
came
gaily
from
the
workshop
of
the
Golden
Key
.
  
<EOS>
Who
but
the
locksmith
could
have
made
such
music
!
 
<EOS>
A
gleam
of
sun
shining
through
the
unsashed
window
,
and
chequering
the
dark
workshop
with
a
broad
patch
of
light
,
fell
full
upon
him
,
as
though
attracted
by
his
sunny
heart
.
 
<EOS>
There
he
stood
working
at
his
anvil
,
his
face
all
radiant
with
exercise
and
gladness
,
his
sleeves
turned
up
,
his
wig
pushed
off
his
shining
forehead
---
the
easiest
,
freest
,
happiest
man
in
all
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
Beside
him
sat
a
sleek
cat
,
purring
and
winking
in
the
light
,
and
falling
every
now
and
then
into
an
idle
doze
,
as
from
excess
of
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
Toby
looked
on
from
a
tall
bench
hard
by
;
one
beaming
smile
,
from
his
broad
nut
-
brown
face
down
to
the
slack
-
baked
buckles
in
his
shoes
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
locks
that
hung
around
had
something
jovial
in
their
rust
,
and
seemed
like
gouty
gentlemen
of
hearty
natures
,
disposed
to
joke
on
their
infirmities
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
surly
or
severe
in
the
whole
scene
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
impossible
that
any
one
of
the
innumerable
keys
could
fit
a
churlish
strong
-
box
or
a
prison
-
door
.
 
<EOS>
Cellars
of
beer
and
wine
,
rooms
where
there
were
fires
,
books
,
gossip
,
and
cheering
laughter
---
 
<EOS>
these
were
their
proper
sphere
of
action
.
 
<EOS>
Places
of
distrust
and
cruelty
,
and
restraint
,
they
would
have
left
quadruple
-
locked
for
ever
.
  
<EOS>
Tink
,
tink
,
tink
.
 
<EOS>
The
locksmith
paused
at
last
,
and
wiped
his
brow
.
 
<EOS>
The
silence
roused
the
cat
,
who
,
jumping
softly
down
,
crept
to
the
door
,
and
watched
with
tiger
eyes
a
bird
-
cage
in
an
opposite
window
.
 
<EOS>
Gabriel
lifted
Toby
to
his
mouth
,
and
took
a
hearty
draught
.
  
<EOS>
Then
,
as
he
stood
upright
,
with
his
head
flung
back
,
and
his
portly
chest
thrown
out
,
you
would
have
seen
that
Gabriel
's
lower
man
was
clothed
in
military
gear
.
 
<EOS>
Glancing
at
the
wall
beyond
,
there
might
have
been
espied
,
hanging
on
their
several
pegs
,
a
cap
and
feather
,
broadsword
,
sash
,
and
coat
of
scarlet
;
which
any
man
learned
in
such
matters
would
have
known
from
their
make
and
pattern
to
be
the
uniform
of
a
serjeant
in
the
Royal
East
London
Volunteers
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
locksmith
put
his
mug
down
,
empty
,
on
the
bench
whence
it
had
smiled
on
him
before
,
he
glanced
at
these
articles
with
a
laughing
eye
,
and
looking
at
them
with
his
head
a
little
on
one
side
,
as
though
he
would
get
them
all
into
a
focus
,
said
,
leaning
on
his
hammer
:
  
<EOS>
"
Time
was
,
now
,
I
remember
,
when
I
was
like
to
run
mad
with
the
desire
to
wear
a
coat
of
that
colour
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
one
(
except
my
father
)
had
called
me
a
fool
for
my
pains
,
how
I
should
have
fired
and
fumed
!
 
<EOS>
But
what
a
fool
I
must
have
been
,
sure
-
ly
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
sighed
Mrs
Varden
,
who
had
entered
unobserved
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
fool
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
at
your
time
of
life
,
Varden
,
should
know
better
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
a
ridiculous
woman
you
are
,
Martha
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
turning
round
with
a
smile
.
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
replied
Mrs
V
with
great
demureness
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
that
,
Varden
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
---
"
began
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
his
wife
,
"
I
know
what
you
mean
.
 
<EOS>
You
speak
quite
plain
enough
to
be
understood
,
Varden
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
very
kind
of
you
to
adapt
yourself
to
my
capacity
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Tut
,
tut
,
Martha
,
"
rejoined
the
locksmith
;
"
do
n't
take
offence
at
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
mean
,
how
strange
it
is
of
you
to
run
down
volunteering
,
when
it
's
done
to
defend
you
and
all
the
other
women
,
and
our
own
fireside
and
everybody
else
's
,
in
case
of
need
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
unchristian
,
"
cried
Mrs
Varden
,
shaking
her
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Unchristian
!
"
said
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
the
devil
---
"
  
Mrs
Varden
looked
at
the
ceiling
,
as
in
expectation
that
the
consequence
of
this
profanity
would
be
the
immediate
descent
of
the
four
-
post
bedstead
on
the
second
floor
,
together
with
the
best
sitting
-
room
on
the
first
;
but
no
visible
judgment
occurring
,
she
heaved
a
deep
sigh
,
and
begged
her
husband
,
in
a
tone
of
resignation
,
to
go
on
,
and
by
all
means
to
blaspheme
as
much
as
possible
,
because
he
knew
she
liked
it
.
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
did
for
a
moment
seem
disposed
to
gratify
her
,
but
he
gave
a
great
gulp
,
and
mildly
rejoined
:
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
going
to
say
,
what
on
earth
do
you
call
it
unchristian
for
?
<EOS>
Which
would
be
most
unchristian
,
Martha
---
to
sit
quietly
down
and
let
our
houses
be
sacked
by
a
foreign
army
,
or
to
turn
out
like
men
and
drive
'em
off
?
 
<EOS>
Should
n't
I
be
a
nice
sort
of
a
Christian
,
if
I
crept
into
a
corner
of
my
own
chimney
and
looked
on
while
a
parcel
of
whiskered
savages
bore
off
Dolly
---
or
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When
he
said
"
or
you
,
"
Mrs
Varden
,
despite
herself
,
relaxed
into
a
smile
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
something
complimentary
in
the
idea
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
such
a
state
of
things
as
that
,
indeed
---
"
she
simpered
.
  
<EOS>
"
As
that
!
"
repeated
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
that
would
be
the
state
of
things
directly
.
 
<EOS>
Even
Miggs
would
go
.
 
<EOS>
Some
black
tambourine
-
player
,
with
a
great
turban
on
,
would
be
bearing
HER
off
,
and
,
unless
the
tambourine
-
player
was
proof
against
kicking
and
scratching
,
it
's
my
belief
<EOS>
he
'd
have
the
worst
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
<EOS>
I
'd
forgive
the
tambourine
-
player
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
him
interfered
with
on
any
account
,
poor
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
here
the
locksmith
laughed
again
so
heartily
,
that
tears
came
into
his
eyes
---
much
to
Mrs
Varden
's
indignation
,
who
thought
the
capture
of
so
sound
a
Protestant
and
estimable
a
private
character
as
Miggs
by
a
pagan
negro
,
a
circumstance
too
shocking
and
awful
for
contemplation
.
  
<EOS>
The
picture
Gabriel
had
drawn
,
indeed
,
threatened
serious
consequences
,
and
would
indubitably
have
led
to
them
,
but
luckily
at
that
moment
a
light
footstep
crossed
the
threshold
,
and
Dolly
,
running
in
,
threw
her
arms
round
her
old
father
's
neck
and
hugged
him
tight
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
she
is
at
last
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Gabriel
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
how
well
you
look
,
Doll
,
and
how
late
you
are
,
my
darling
!
"
  
<EOS>
How
well
she
looked
?
 
<EOS>
Well
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
if
he
had
exhausted
every
laudatory
adjective
in
the
dictionary
,
it
would
n't
have
been
praise
enough
.
 
<EOS>
When
and
where
was
there
ever
such
a
plump
,
roguish
,
comely
,
bright
-
eyed
,
enticing
,
bewitching
,
captivating
,
maddening
little
puss
in
all
this
world
,
as
Dolly
!
 
<EOS>
What
was
the
Dolly
of
five
years
ago
,
to
the
Dolly
of
that
day
!
 
<EOS>
How
many
coachmakers
,
saddlers
,
cabinet
-
makers
,
and
professors
of
other
useful
arts
,
had
deserted
their
fathers
,
mothers
,
sisters
,
brothers
,
and
,
most
of
all
,
their
cousins
,
for
the
love
of
her
!
 
<EOS>
How
many
unknown
gentlemen
---
supposed
to
be
of
mighty
fortunes
,
if
not
titles
---
had
waited
round
the
corner
after
dark
,
and
tempted
Miggs
the
incorruptible
,
with
golden
guineas
,
to
deliver
offers
of
marriage
folded
up
in
love
-
letters
!
 
<EOS>
How
many
disconsolate
fathers
and
substantial
tradesmen
had
waited
on
the
locksmith
for
the
same
purpose
,
with
dismal
tales
of
how
their
sons
had
lost
their
appetites
,
and
taken
to
shut
themselves
up
in
dark
bedrooms
,
and
wandering
in
desolate
suburbs
with
pale
faces
,
and
all
because
of
Dolly
Varden
's
loveliness
and
cruelty
!
 
<EOS>
How
many
young
men
,
in
all
previous
times
of
unprecedented
steadiness
,
had
turned
suddenly
wild
and
wicked
for
the
same
reason
,
and
,
in
an
ecstasy
of
unrequited
love
,
taken
to
wrench
off
door
-
knockers
,
and
invert
the
boxes
of
rheumatic
watchmen
!
 
<EOS>
How
had
she
recruited
the
king
's
service
,
both
by
sea
and
land
,
through
rendering
desperate
his
loving
subjects
between
the
ages
of
eighteen
and
twenty
-
five
!
 
<EOS>
How
many
young
ladies
had
publicly
professed
,
with
tears
in
their
eyes
,
that
for
their
tastes
she
was
much
too
short
,
too
tall
,
too
bold
,
too
cold
,
too
stout
,
too
thin
,
too
fair
,
too
dark
---
too
everything
but
handsome
!
 
<EOS>
How
many
old
ladies
,
taking
counsel
together
,
had
thanked
Heaven
their
daughters
were
not
like
her
,
and
had
hoped
she
might
come
to
no
harm
,
and
had
thought
she
would
come
to
no
good
,
and
had
wondered
what
people
saw
in
her
,
and
had
arrived
at
the
conclusion
that
she
was
"
going
off
"
in
her
looks
,
or
had
never
come
on
in
them
,
and
that
she
was
a
thorough
imposition
and
a
popular
mistake
!
  
<EOS>
And
yet
here
was
this
same
Dolly
Varden
,
so
whimsical
and
hard
to
please
that
she
was
Dolly
Varden
still
,
all
smiles
and
dimples
and
pleasant
looks
,
and
caring
no
more
for
the
fifty
or
sixty
young
fellows
who
at
that
very
moment
were
breaking
their
hearts
to
marry
her
,
than
if
so
many
oysters
had
been
crossed
in
love
and
opened
afterwards
.
  
<EOS>
Dolly
hugged
her
father
as
has
been
already
stated
,
and
having
hugged
her
mother
also
,
accompanied
both
into
the
little
parlour
where
the
cloth
was
already
laid
for
dinner
,
and
where
Miss
Miggs
---
 
a
trifle
more
rigid
and
bony
than
of
yore
---
received
her
with
a
sort
of
hysterical
gasp
,
intended
for
a
smile
.
 
<EOS>
Into
the
hands
of
that
young
virgin
,
she
delivered
her
bonnet
and
walking
dress
(
all
of
a
dreadful
,
artful
,
and
designing
kind
)
,
and
then
said
with
a
laugh
,
which
rivalled
the
locksmith
's
music
,
"
How
glad
I
always
am
to
be
at
home
again
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
glad
we
always
are
,
Doll
,
"
said
her
father
,
putting
back
the
dark
hair
from
her
sparkling
eyes
,
"
to
have
you
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
a
kiss
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
If
there
had
been
anybody
of
the
male
kind
there
to
see
her
do
it
---
 
<EOS>
but
there
was
not
---
it
was
a
mercy
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like
your
being
at
the
Warren
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
"
I
ca
n't
bear
to
have
you
out
of
my
sight
.
 
<EOS>
And
what
is
the
news
over
yonder
,
Doll
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
news
there
is
,
I
think
you
know
already
,
"
replied
his
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
you
do
though
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
?
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

"

<EOS>

Mr

---
<EOS>
oh

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
She

Miss
Miggs

Great

<EOS>
Miss

Mrs

<EOS>
That

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Miss

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

,

had
just
had
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
V
,

,

"
like

.
"
  
<EOS>

Royal
East
London
Volunteers
<EOS>
that

,

did

;

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

!
"

"

,

.
 
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
---
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Poor

!
"

,

;
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
old
John
made

his
way
of
acting
by
that
lad
---
a
great
mistake
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Have
you
nearly
tied
that
sash
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
What
an
ill
-
made
sash
it
was
!
 
<EOS>
There
it
was
,
loose
again
and
trailing
on
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Dolly
was
obliged
to
kneel
down
,
and
recommence
at
the
beginning
.
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
young
Willet
,
Varden
,
"
said
his
wife
frowning
;
"
you
might
find
some

more
deserving

talk
about
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
gave
a
great
sniff
to
the
same
effect
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
Martha
,
"
cried
the
locksmith
,
"
do
n't
let
us
bear
too
hard
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
lad
is
dead
indeed
,
we
'll
deal
kindly
by
his

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
runaway
and
a
vagabond
!
"
said
Mrs
Varden
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
expressed
her
concurrence
as
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
runaway
,
my
dear
,
but
not
a
vagabond
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
behaved
himself
well
,
did
Joe
---
always
---
and
was
a
handsome
,

fellow
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
call
him
a
vagabond
,
Martha
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
coughed
---
and
so
did
Miggs
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
tried
hard
to
gain
your
good
opinion
,
Martha
,
I
can
tell
you
,
"
said
the
locksmith
smiling
,
and
stroking

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
that
he
did
.
 
<EOS>
It
seems
but
yesterday
that
he
followed
me
out
to
the
Maypole
door
one

,
and

not

say
how
like

boy
they
used
him
---
say
here
,
at
home
,
he

,
though
at
the

,
I
recollect
,
I
did

.
 
<EOS>
"
And
how
's
Miss
Dolly
,
sir
?
"
says
Joe
,
"
pursued
the
locksmith
,
musing
sorrowfully
,
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Poor
Joe
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
declare
,
"
cried
Miggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
Goodness
gracious
me
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
now
?
"
said
Gabriel
,
turning

,
"
Why
,
if
here
an't
Miss
Dolly
,
"
said
the
handmaid
,
stooping

to
look
into

,
"
a
-
giving
way
to
floods

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
mim
!
<EOS>
oh
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Raly
<EOS>
it
's
give
me
such
a
turn
,
"
cried
the
susceptible
damsel
,
pressing
her

side
to
quell
the

of
her
heart
,
"
that
you
might
knock
me
down
with
a
feather
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
,
after
glancing
at
Miss
Miggs
as
if
he
could
have
wished
to
have
a
feather
brought

,
looked

while
Dolly

,
followed
by
that
sympathising
young
woman
:
then
turning
to

,
stammered

,
"
Is
Dolly
ill
?
 
<EOS>
Have
I
done
anything
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
my
fault
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Your
fault
!
"
cried
Mrs
V
reproachfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
---
you
had
better
make
haste
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
have
I
done
?
"
said
poor
Gabriel
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
agreed
that
Mr
Edward
's
name
was
never
to
be
mentioned
,
and
I
have
not
spoken

him
,
have
I
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
merely

that
she
had
no
