with
him
,
and
bounced
off
after
the
other
two
.
 
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
locksmith
wound
his
sash
about
him
,
girded
on
his
sword
,
put
on
his
cap
,
and
walked
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
much
of
a
dab
at
my
exercise
,
"
he
said
under
his
breath
,
"
but
I
shall
get
into
fewer
scrapes
at
that
work
than
at
this
.
<EOS>
Every
man
came
into
the
world
for
something
;
my
department
seems
to
be
to
make
every
woman
cry
without
meaning
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
rather
hard
!
"
  
<EOS>
But
he
forgot
it
before
he
reached
the
end
of
the
street
,
and
went
on
with
a
shining
face
,
nodding
to
the
neighbours
,
and
showering
about
his
friendly
greetings
like
mild
spring
rain
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
42
    
<EOS>
The
Royal
East
London
Volunteers
made
a
brilliant
sight
that
day
:
formed
into
lines
,
squares
,
circles
,
triangles
,
and
what
not
,
to
the
beating
of
drums
,
and
the
streaming
of
flags
;
and
performed
a
vast
number
of
complex
evolutions
,
in
all
of
which
Serjeant
Varden
bore
a
conspicuous
share
.
 
<EOS>
Having
displayed
their
military
prowess
to
the
utmost
in
these
warlike
shows
,
they
marched
in
glittering
order
to
the
Chelsea
Bun
House
,
and
regaled
in
the
adjacent
taverns
until
dark
.
 
<EOS>
Then
at
sound
of
drum
they
fell
in
again
,
and
returned
amidst
the
shouting
of
His
Majesty
's
lieges
to
the
place
from
whence
they
came
.
  
<EOS>
The
homeward
march
being
somewhat
tardy
,
---
owing
to
the
un
-
soldierlike
behaviour
of
certain
corporals
,
who
,
being
gentlemen
of
sedentary
pursuits
in
private
life
and
excitable
out
of
doors
,
broke
several
windows
with
their
bayonets
,
and
rendered
it
imperative
on
the
commanding
officer
to
deliver
them
over
to
a
strong
guard
,
with
whom
they
fought
at
intervals
as
they
came
along
,
---
it
was
nine
o'clock
when
the
locksmith
reached
home
.
 
<EOS>
A
hackney
-
coach
was
waiting
near
his
door
;
and
as
he
passed
it
,
Mr
Haredale
looked
from
the
window
and
called
him
by
his
name
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
sight
of
you
is
good
for
sore
eyes
,
sir
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
stepping
up
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
had
walked
in
though
,
rather
than
waited
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
nobody
at
home
,
I
find
,
"
Mr
Haredale
answered
;
"
besides
,
I
desired
to
be
as
private
as
I
could
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
"
muttered
the
locksmith
,
looking
round
at
his
house
.
"
<EOS>
Gone
with
Simon
Tappertit
to
that
precious
Branch
,
no
doubt
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
invited
him
to
come
into
the
coach
,
and
,
if
he
were
not
tired
or
anxious
to
go
home
,
to
ride
with
him
a
little
way
that
they
might
have
some
talk
together
.
 
<EOS>
Gabriel
cheerfully
complied
,
and
the
coachman
mounting
his
box
drove
off
.
  
<EOS>
"
Varden
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
after
a
minute
's
pause
,
"
you
will
be
amazed
to
hear
what
errand
I
am
on
;
it
will
seem
a
very
strange
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
it
's
a
reasonable
one
,
sir
,
and
has
a
meaning
in
it
,
"
replied
the
locksmith
;
"
or
it
would
not
be
yours
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
just
come
back
to
town
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
half
an
hour
ago
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bringing
no
news
of
Barnaby
,
or
his
mother
?
"
said
the
locksmith
dubiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
you
need
n't
shake
your
head
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
wild
-
goose
chase
.
 
<EOS>
I
feared
that
,
from
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
You
exhausted
all
reasonable
means
of
discovery
when
they
went
away
.
 
<EOS>
To
begin
again
after
so
long
a
time
has
passed
is
hopeless
,
sir
---
quite
hopeless
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
where
are
they
?
"
<EOS>
he
returned
impatiently
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
can
they
be
?
 
<EOS>
Above
ground
?
"
  
"
God
knows
,
"
rejoined
the
locksmith
,
"
many
that
I
knew
above
it
five
years
ago
,
have
their
beds
under
the
grass
now
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
world
is
a
wide
place
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
hopeless
attempt
,
sir
,
believe
me
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
leave
the
discovery
of
this
mystery
,
like
all
others
,
to
time
,
and
accident
,
and
Heaven
's
pleasure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Varden
,
my
good
fellow
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
I
have
a
deeper
meaning
in
my
present
anxiety
to
find
them
out
,
than
you
can
fathom
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
a
mere
whim
;
it
is
not
the
casual
revival
of
my
old
wishes
and
desires
;
but
an
earnest
,
solemn
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
My
thoughts
and
dreams
all
tend
to
it
,
and
fix
it
in
my
mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
rest
by
day
or
night
;
I
have
no
peace
or
quiet
;
I
am
haunted
.
"
  
<EOS>
His
voice
was
so
altered
from
its
usual
tones
,
and
his
manner
bespoke
so
much
emotion
,
that
Gabriel
,
in
his
wonder
,
could
only
sit
and
look
towards
him
in
the
darkness
,
and
fancy
the
expression
of
his
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
not
ask
me
,
"
continued
Mr
Haredale
,
"
to
explain
myself
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
were
to
do
so
,
you
would
think
me
the
victim
of
some
hideous
fancy
.
<EOS>
It
is
enough
that
this
is
so
,
and
that
I
can
not
---
<EOS>
no
,
I
can
not
---
lie
quietly
in
my
bed
,
without
doing
what
will
seem
to
you
incomprehensible
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Since
when
,
sir
,
"
said
the
locksmith
after
a
pause
,
"
has
this
uneasy
feeling
been
upon
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
hesitated
for
some
moments
,
and
then
replied
:
"
Since
the
night
of
the
storm
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
since
the
last
nineteenth
of
March
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
though
he
feared
that
Varden
might
express
surprise
,
or
reason
with
him
,
he
hastily
went
on
:
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
think
,
I
know
,
I
labour
under
some
delusion
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
do
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
is
not
a
morbid
one
;
it
is
a
wholesome
action
of
the
mind
,
reasoning
on
actual
occurrences
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
the
furniture
remains
in
Mrs
Rudge
's
house
,
and
that
it
has
been
shut
up
,
by
my
orders
,
since
she
went
away
,
save
once
a
-
week
or
so
,
when
an
old
neighbour
visits
it
to
scare
away
the
rats
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
on
my
way
there
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
For
what
purpose
?
"
asked
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
pass
the
night
there
,
"
he
replied
;
"
and
not
to
-
night
alone
,
but
many
nights
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
a
secret
which
I
trust
to
you
in
case
of
any
unexpected
emergency
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
not
come
,
unless
in
case
of
strong
necessity
,
to
me
;
from
dusk
to
broad
day
I
shall
be
there
.
 
<EOS>
Emma
,
your
daughter
,
and
the
rest
,
suppose
me
out
of
London
,
as
I
have
been
until
within
this
hour
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
undeceive
them
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
errand
I
am
bound
upon
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
I
may
confide
it
to
you
,
and
I
rely
upon
your
questioning
me
no
more
at
this
time
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
,
as
if
to
change
the
theme
,
he
led
the
astounded
locksmith
back
to
the
night
of
the
Maypole
highwayman
,
to
the
robbery
of
Edward
Chester
,
to
the
reappearance
of
the
man
at
Mrs
Rudge
's
house
,
and
to
all
the
strange
circumstances
which
afterwards
occurred
.
 
<EOS>
He
even
asked
him
carelessly
about
the
man
's
height
,
his
face
,
his
figure
,
whether
he
was
like
any
one
he
had
ever
seen
---
like
Hugh
,
for
instance
,
or
any
man
he
had
known
at
any
time
---
and
put
many
questions
of
that
sort
,
which
the
locksmith
,
considering
them
as
mere
devices
to
engage
his
attention
and
prevent
his
expressing
the
astonishment
he
felt
,
answered
pretty
much
at
random
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
,
they
arrived
at
the
corner
of
the
street
in
which
the
house
stood
,
where
Mr
Haredale
,
alighting
,
dismissed
the
coach
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
desire
to
see
me
safely
lodged
,
"
he
said
,
turning
to
the
locksmith
with
a
gloomy
smile
,
"
you
can
.
"
  
<EOS>
Gabriel
,
to
whom
all
former
marvels
had
been
nothing
in
comparison
with
this
,
followed
him
along
the
narrow
pavement
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
reached
the
door
,
Mr
Haredale
softly
opened
it
with
a
key
he
had
about
him
,
and
closing
it
when
Varden
entered
,
they
were
left
in
thorough
darkness
.
  
<EOS>
They
groped
their
way
into
the
ground
-
floor
room
.
 
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Haredale
struck
a
light
,
and
kindled
a
pocket
taper
he
had
brought
with
him
for
the
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
then
,
when
the
flame
was
full
upon
him
,
that
the
locksmith
saw
for
the
first
time
how
haggard
,
pale
,
and
changed
he
looked
;
how
worn
and
thin
he
was
;
how
perfectly
his
whole
appearance
coincided
with
all
that
he
had
said
so
strangely
as
they
rode
along
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
an
unnatural
impulse
in
Gabriel
,
after
what
he
had
heard
,
to
note
curiously
the
expression
of
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
perfectly
collected
and
rational
;
---
 
so
much
<EOS>
so
,
indeed
,
that
he
felt
ashamed
of
his
momentary
suspicion
,
and
drooped
his
own
when
Mr
Haredale
looked
towards
him
,
as
if
he
feared
they
would
betray
his
thoughts
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
walk
through
the
house
?
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
with
a
glance
towards
the
window
,
the
crazy
shutters
of
which
were
closed
and
fastened
.
 
<EOS>
"
Speak
low
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
kind
of
awe
about
the
place
,
which
would
have
rendered
it
difficult
to
speak
in
any
other
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Gabriel
whispered
"
Yes
,
"
and
followed
him
upstairs
.
  
<EOS>
Everything
was
just
as
they
had
seen
it
last
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
sense
of
closeness
from
the
exclusion
of
fresh
air
,
and
a
gloom
and
heaviness
around
,
as
though
long
imprisonment
had
made
the
very
silence
sad
.
 
<EOS>
The
homely
hangings
of
the
beds
and
windows
had
begun
to
droop
;
the
dust
lay
thick
upon
their
dwindling
folds
;
and
damps
had
made
their
way
through
ceiling
,
wall
,
and
floor
.
 
<EOS>
The
boards
creaked
beneath
their
tread
,
as
if
resenting
the
unaccustomed
intrusion
;
nimble
spiders
,
paralysed
by
the
taper
's
glare
,
checked
the
motion
of
their
hundred
legs
upon
the
wall
,
or
dropped
like
lifeless
things
upon
the
ground
;
the
death
-
watch
ticked
;
and
the
scampering
feet
of
rats
and
mice
rattled
behind
the
wainscot
.
  
<EOS>
As
they
looked
about
them
on
the
decaying
furniture
,
it
was
strange
to
find
how
vividly
it
presented
those
to
whom
it
had
belonged
,
and
with
whom
it
was
once
familiar
.
 
<EOS>
Grip
seemed
to
perch
again
upon
his
high
-
backed
chair
;
Barnaby
to
crouch
in
his
old
favourite
corner
by
the
fire
;
the
mother
to
resume
her
usual
seat
,
and
watch
him
as
of
old
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
they
could
separate
these
objects
from
the
phantoms
of
the
mind
which
they
invoked
,
the
latter
only
glided
out
of
sight
,
but
lingered
near
them
still
;
for
then
they
seemed
to
lurk
in
closets
and
behind
the
doors
,
ready
to
start
out
and
suddenly
accost
them
in
well
-
remembered
tones
.
  
<EOS>
They
went
downstairs
,
and
again
into
the
room
they
had
just
now
left
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
unbuckled
his
sword
and
laid
it
on
the
table
,
with
a
pair
of
pocket
pistols
;
then
told
the
locksmith
he
would
light
him
to
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
this
is
a
dull
place
,
sir
,
"
said
Gabriel
lingering
;
"
may
no
one
share
your
watch
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
shook
his
head
,
and
so
plainly
evinced
his
wish
to
be
alone
,
that
Gabriel
could
say
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
In
another
moment
the
locksmith
was
standing
in
the
street
,
whence
he
could
see
that
the
light
once
more
travelled
upstairs
,
and
soon
returning
to
the
room
below
,
shone
brightly
through
the
chinks
of
the
shutters
.
  
<EOS>
If
ever
man
were
sorely
puzzled
and
perplexed
,
the
locksmith
was
,
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
snugly
seated
by
his
own
fireside
,
with
Mrs
Varden
opposite
in
a
nightcap
and
night
-
jacket
,
and
Dolly
beside
him
(
in
a
most
distracting
dishabille
)
curling
her
hair
,
and
smiling
as
if
she
had
never
cried
in
all
her
life
and
never
could
---
 
even
then
,
with
Toby
at
his
elbow
and
his
pipe
in
his
mouth
,
and
Miggs
<EOS>
(
but
that
perhaps
was
not
much
)
falling
asleep
in
the
background
<EOS>
,
he
could
not
quite
discard
his
wonder
and
uneasiness
.
<EOS>
So
in
his
dreams
---
still
there
was
Mr
Haredale
,
haggard
and
careworn
,
listening
in
the
solitary
house
to
every
sound
that
stirred
,
with
the
taper
shining
through
the
chinks
until
the
day
should
turn
it
pale
and
end
his
lonely
watching
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
43
    
<EOS>
Next
morning
brought
no
satisfaction
to
the
locksmith
's
thoughts
,
nor
next
day
,
nor
the
next
,
nor
many
others
.
 
<EOS>
Often
after
nightfall
he
entered
the
street
,
and
turned
his
eyes
towards
the
well
-
known
house
;
and
as
surely
as
he
did
so
,
there
was
the
solitary
light
,
still
gleaming
through
the
crevices
of
the
window
-
shutter
,
while
all
within
was
motionless
,
noiseless
,
cheerless
,
as
a
grave
.
<EOS>
Unwilling
to
hazard
Mr
Haredale
's
favour
by
disobeying
his
strict
injunction
,
he
never
ventured
to
knock
at
the
door
or
to
make
his
presence
known
in
any
way
.
 
<EOS>
But
whenever
strong
interest
and
curiosity
attracted
him
to
the
spot
---
which
was
not
seldom
---
the
light
was
always
there
.
  
<EOS>
If
he
could
have
known
what
passed
within
,
the
knowledge
would
have
yielded
him
no
clue
to
this
mysterious
vigil
.
 
<EOS>
At
twilight
,
Mr
Haredale
shut
himself
up
,
and
at
daybreak
he
came
forth
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
missed
a
night
,
always
came
and
went
alone
,
and
never
varied
his
proceedings
in
the
least
degree
.
  
<EOS>
The
manner
of
his
watch
was
this
.
 
<EOS>
At
dusk
,
he
entered
the
house
in
the
same
way
as
when
the
locksmith
bore
him
company
,
kindled
a
light
,
went
through
the
rooms
,
and
narrowly
examined
them
.
 
<EOS>
That
done
,
he
returned
to
the
chamber
on
the
ground
-
floor
,
and
laying
his
sword
and
pistols
on
the
table
,
sat
by
it
until
morning
.
  
<EOS>
He
usually
had
a
book
with
him
,
and
often
tried
to
read
,
but
never
fixed
his
eyes
or
thoughts
upon
it
for
five
minutes
together
.
 
<EOS>
The
slightest
noise
without
doors
,
caught
his
ear
;
a
step
upon
the
pavement
seemed
to
make
his
heart
leap
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
not
without
some
refreshment
during
the
long
lonely
hours
;
generally
carrying
in
his
pocket
a
sandwich
of
bread
and
meat
,
and
a
small
flask
of
wine
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
diluted
with
large
quantities
of
water
,
he
drank
in
a
heated
,
feverish
way
,
as
though
his
throat
were
dried
;
but
he
scarcely
ever
broke
his
fast
,
by
so
much
as
a
crumb
of
bread
.
  
<EOS>
If
this
voluntary
sacrifice
of
sleep
and
comfort
had
its
origin
,
as
the
locksmith
on
consideration
was
disposed
to
think
,
in
any
superstitious
expectation
of
the
fulfilment
of
a
dream
or
vision
connected
with
the
event
on
which
he
had
brooded
for
so
many
years
,
and
if
he
waited
for
some
ghostly
visitor
who
walked
abroad
when
men
lay
sleeping
in
their
beds
,
he
showed
no
trace
of
fear
or
wavering
.
 
<EOS>
His
stern
features
expressed
inflexible
resolution
;
his
brows
were
puckered
,
and
his
lips
compressed
,
with
deep
and
settled
purpose
;
and
when
he
started
at
a
noise
and
listened
,
it
was
not
with
the
start
of
fear
but
hope
,
and
catching
up
his
sword
as
though
the
hour
had
come
at
last
,
he
would
clutch
it
in
his
tight
-
clenched
hand
,
and
listen
with
sparkling
eyes
and
eager
looks
,
until
it
died
away
.
  
<EOS>
These
disappointments
were
numerous
,
for
they
ensued
on
almost
every
sound
,
but
his
constancy
was
not
shaken
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
every
night
he
was
at
his
post
,
the
same
stern
,
sleepless
,
sentinel
;
and
still
night
passed
,
and
morning
dawned
,
and
he
must
watch
again
.
  
<EOS>
This
went
on
for
weeks
;
he
had
taken
a
lodging
at
Vauxhall
in
which
to
pass
the
day
and
rest
himself
;
and
from
this
place
,
when
the
tide
served
,
he
usually
came
to
London
Bridge
from
Westminster
by
water
,
in
order
that
he
might
avoid
the
busy
streets
.
  
<EOS>
One
evening
,
shortly
before
twilight
,
he
came
his
accustomed
road
upon
the
river
's
bank
,
intending
to
pass
through
Westminster
Hall
into
Palace
Yard
,
and
there
take
boat
to
London
Bridge
as
usual
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
pretty
large
concourse
of
people
assembled
round
the
Houses
of
Parliament
,
looking
at
the
members
as
they
entered
and
departed
,
and
giving
vent
to
rather
noisy
demonstrations
of
approval
or
dislike
,
according
to
their
known
opinions
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
made
his
way
among
the
throng
,
he
heard
once
or
twice
the
No
-
Popery
cry
,
which
was
then
becoming
pretty
familiar
to
the
ears
of
most
men
;
but
holding
it
in
very
slight
regard
,
and
observing
that
the
idlers
were
of
the
lowest
grade
,
he
neither
thought
nor
cared
about
it
,
but
made
his
way
along
,
with
perfect
indifference
.
  
<EOS>
There
were
many
little
knots
and
groups
of
persons
in
Westminster
Hall
:
some
few
looking
upward
at
its
noble
ceiling
,
and
at
the
rays
of
evening
light
,
tinted
by
the
setting
sun
,
which
streamed
in
aslant
through
its
small
windows
,
and
growing
dimmer
by
degrees
,
were
quenched
in
the
gathering
gloom
below
;
some
,
noisy
passengers
,
mechanics
going
home
from
work
,
and
otherwise
,
who
hurried
quickly
through
,
waking
the
echoes
with
their
voices
,
and
soon
darkening
the
small
door
in
the
distance
,
as
they
passed
into
the
street
beyond
;
some
,
in
busy
conference
together
on
political
or
private
matters
,
pacing
slowly
up
and
down
with
eyes
that
sought
the
ground
,
and
seeming
,
by
their
attitudes
,
to
listen
earnestly
from
head
to
foot
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
a
dozen
squabbling
urchins
made
a
very
Babel
in
the
air
;
there
,
a
solitary
man
,
half
clerk
,
half
mendicant
,
paced
up
and
down
with
hungry
dejection
in
his
look
and
gait
;
at
his
elbow
passed
an
errand
-
lad
,
swinging
his
basket
round
and
round
,
and
with
his
shrill
whistle
riving
the
very
timbers
of
the
roof
;
while
a
more
observant
schoolboy
,
half
-
way
through
,
pocketed
his
ball
,
and
eyed
the
distant
beadle
as
he
came
looming
on
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
that
time
of
evening
<EOS>
when
,
if
you
shut
your
eyes
and
open
them
again
,
the
darkness
of
an
hour
appears
to
have
gathered
in
a
second
.
 
<EOS>
The
smooth
-
worn
pavement
,
dusty
with
footsteps
,
still
called
upon
the
lofty
walls
to
reiterate
the
shuffle
and
the
tread
of
feet
unceasingly
,
save
when
the
closing
of
some
heavy
door
resounded
through
the
building
like
a
clap
of
thunder
,
and
drowned
all
other
noises
in
its
rolling
sound
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
,
glancing
only
at
such
of
these
groups
as
he
passed
nearest
to
,
and
<EOS>
then
in
a
manner
betokening
that
his
thoughts
were
elsewhere
,
had
nearly
traversed
the
Hall
,
when
two
persons
before
him
caught
his
attention
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
these
,
a
gentleman
in
elegant
attire
,
carried
in
his
hand
a
cane
,
which
he
twirled
in
a
jaunty
manner
as
he
loitered
on
<EOS>
;
the
other
,
an
obsequious
,
crouching
,
fawning
figure
,
listened
to
what
he
said
---
at
times
throwing
in
a
humble
word
himself
---
and
,
with
his
shoulders
shrugged
up
to
his
ears
,
rubbed
his
hands
submissively
,
or
answered
at
intervals
by
an
inclination
of
the
head
,
half
-
way
between
a
nod
of
acquiescence
,
and
a
bow
of
most
profound
respect
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
abstract
there
was
nothing
very
remarkable
in
this
pair
,
for
servility
waiting
on
a
handsome
suit
of
clothes
and
a
cane
---
not
to
speak
of
gold
and
silver
sticks
,
or
wands
of
office
---
is
common
enough
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
that
about
the
well
-
dressed
man
,
yes
,
and
about
the
other
likewise
,
which
struck
Mr
Haredale
with
no
pleasant
feeling
.
 
<EOS>
He
hesitated
,
stopped
,
and
would
have
stepped
aside
and
turned
out
of
his
path
,
but
at
the
moment
,
the
other
two
faced
about
quickly
,
and
stumbled
upon
him
before
he
could
avoid
them
.
  
<EOS>
The
gentleman
with
the
cane
lifted
his
hat
and
had
begun
to
tender
an
apology
,
which
Mr
Haredale
had
begun
as
hastily
to
acknowledge
and
walk
away
,
when
he
stopped
short
and
cried
,
"
Haredale
!
 
<EOS>
Gad
bless
me
,
this
is
strange
indeed
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
he
returned
impatiently
;
"
yes
---
a
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
My
dear
friend
,
"
cried
the
other
,
detaining
him
,
"
why
such
great
speed
?
 
<EOS>
One
minute
,
Haredale
,
for
the
sake
of
old
acquaintance
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
in
haste
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Neither
of
us
has
sought
this
meeting
.
<EOS>
Let
it
be
a
brief
one
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Fie
,
fie
!
"
<EOS>
replied
Sir
John
(
for
it
was
he
)
,
"
how
very
churlish
!
<EOS>
We
were
speaking
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
Your
name
was
on
my
lips
<EOS>
---
perhaps
you
heard
me
mention
it
?
 
<EOS>
No
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
really
sorry
.
<EOS>
---
You
know
our
friend
here
,
Haredale
?
 
<EOS>
This
is
really
a
most
remarkable
meeting
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
friend
,
plainly
very
ill
at
ease
,
had
made
bold
to
press
Sir
John
's
arm
,
and
to
give
him
other
significant
hints
that
he
was
desirous
of
avoiding
this
introduction
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
did
not
suit
Sir
John
's
purpose
,
however
,
that
it
should
be
evaded
,
he
appeared
quite
unconscious
of
these
silent
remonstrances
,
and
inclined
his
hand
towards
him
,
as
he
spoke
,
to
call
attention
to
him
more
particularly
.
  
<EOS>
The
friend
,
therefore
,
had
nothing
for
it
,
but
to
muster
up
the
pleasantest
smile
he
could
,
and
to
make
a
conciliatory
bow
,
as
Mr
Haredale
turned
his
eyes
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
Seeing
that
he
was
recognised
,
he
put
out
his
hand
in
an
awkward
and
embarrassed
manner
,
which
was
not
mended
by
its
contemptuous
rejection
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Gashford
!
"
said
Haredale
,
coldly
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
as
I
have
heard
then
.
<EOS>
You
have
left
the
darkness
for
the
light
,
sir
,
and
hate
those
whose
opinions
you
formerly
held
,
with
all
the
bitterness
of
a
renegade
.
<EOS>
You
are
an
honour
,
sir
,
to
any
cause
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
the
one
you
espouse
at
present
,
much
joy
of
the
acquisition
it
has
made
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
secretary
rubbed
his
hands
and
bowed
,
as
though
he
would
disarm
his
adversary
by
humbling
himself
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
John
Chester
again
exclaimed
,
with
an
air
of
great
gaiety
,
"
Now
,
really
,
this
is
a
most
remarkable
meeting
!
"
and
took
a
pinch
of
snuff
with
his
usual
self
-
possession
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Haredale
,
"
said
Gashford
,
stealthily
raising
his
eyes
,
and
letting
them
drop
again
when
they
met
the
other
's
steady
gaze
,
is
too
conscientious
,
too
honourable
,
too
manly
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
,
to
attach
unworthy
motives
to
an
honest
change
of
opinions
,
even
though
it
implies
a
doubt
of
those
he
holds
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
is
too
just
,
too
generous
,
too
clear
-
sighted
in
his
moral
vision
,
to
---
"
  
"
Yes
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
he
rejoined
with
a
sarcastic
smile
,
finding
the
secretary
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
saying
"
---
   
<EOS>
Gashford
meekly
shrugged
his
shoulders
,
and
looking
on
the
ground
again
,
was
silent
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
but
let
us
really
,
"
interposed
Sir
John
at
this
juncture
,
"
let
us
really
,
for
a
moment
,
contemplate
the
very
remarkable
character
of
this
meeting
.
 
<EOS>
Haredale
,
my
dear
friend
,
pardon
me
if
I
think
you
are
not
sufficiently
impressed
with
its
singularity
.
 
<EOS>
Here
we
stand
,
by
no
previous
appointment
or
arrangement
,
three
old
schoolfellows
,
in
Westminster
Hall
;
three
old
boarders
in
a
remarkably
dull
and
shady
seminary
at
Saint
Omer
's
,
where
you
,
being
Catholics
and
of
necessity
educated
out
of
England
,
were
brought
up
;
and
where
I
,
being
a
promising
young
Protestant
at
that
time
,
was
sent
to
learn
the
French
tongue
from
a
native
of
Paris
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Add
to
the
singularity
,
Sir
John
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
that
some
of
you
<EOS>
Protestants
of
promise
are
<EOS>
at
this
moment
leagued
in
yonder
building
,
to
prevent
our
having
the
surpassing
and
unheard
-
of
privilege
of
teaching
our
children
to
read
and
write
---
here
---
in
this
land
,
where
thousands
of
us
enter
your
service
every
year
,
and
to
preserve
the
freedom
of
which
,
we
die
in
bloody
battles
abroad
,
in
heaps
:
and
that
others
of
you
,
to
the
number
of
some
thousands
as
I
learn
,
are
led
on
to
look
on
all
men
of
my
creed
as
wolves
and
beasts
of
prey
,
by
this
man
Gashford
.
 
<EOS>
Add
to
it
besides
the
bare
fact
that
this
man
lives
in
society
,
walks
the
streets
in
broad
day
---
I
was
about
to
say
,
holds
up
his
head
,
but
that
he
does
not
---
 
and
it
will
be
strange
,
and
very
strange
,
I
grant
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
you
are
hard
upon
our
friend
,
"
replied
Sir
John
,
with
an
engaging

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
really
very
hard
upon
our
friend
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
him
go
on
,
Sir
John
,
"
said
Gashford
,
fumbling
with
his
gloves
.
<EOS>
"
Let
him
go
on
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
make
allowances
,
Sir
John
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
honoured
with
your
good
opinion
,
and
I
can
dispense
with
Mr
Haredale
's
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
is
a
sufferer
from
the
penal
laws
,
and
I
ca
n't
expect
his
favour
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
so
much
of
my
favour
,
sir
,
"
retorted
Mr
Haredale
,
with
a
bitter

at
the
third
party
in
their
conversation
,
"
that
I
am
glad
to
see
you
in
such
good
company
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
the
essence
of
your
great
Association
,
in
yourselves
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Now
,
there
you
mistake
,
"
said
Sir
John
,
in
his
most
benignant
way
.
<EOS>
"
There
---
which
is
a
most
remarkable
circumstance
for
a
man
of
your
punctuality
and
exactness
,
Haredale
---
you
fall
into
error
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
belong
to
the
body
;
I
have
an
immense
respect
for
its
members
,
but
I
do
n't
belong
to
it
;
although
I
am
,
it

certainly

,
the
conscientious
opponent
of
your
being
relieved
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
it
my
duty
to
be
so
;
it
is
a
most
unfortunate

;
and
cost
me
a
bitter

.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Will
you
try
this
box
?
 
<EOS>
If
you
do
n't
object
to
a
trifling
infusion
of
a
very
chaste
scent
,
you
'll
find
its
flavour
exquisite
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ask
your
pardon
,
Sir
John
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
declining
the

with

,
"
for
having
ranked
you
among
the
humble
instruments
who
are
obvious
and
in
all
men
's
sight
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
done
more
justice
to
your
genius
.
 
<EOS>
Men
of
your
capacity
plot
in
secrecy
and
safety
,
and
leave
exposed
posts
to
the
duller
wits
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
apologise
,
for
the
world
,
"
replied
Sir
John
sweetly
;
"
old
friends
like
you
and
I
,
may
be
allowed
some
freedoms
,
or
the
deuce
is
in
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Gashford
,
who
had
been
very
restless
all
this
time
,
but
had
not
once
looked
up
,
now
turned
to
Sir
John
,
and
ventured
to
mutter
something
to
the
effect
that
he
must
go
,
or
my
lord
would
perhaps
be
waiting
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
distress
yourself
,
good
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
I
'll
take
my
leave
,
and
put
you
at
your
ease
---
"
<EOS>
which
he
was
about
to
do
without
ceremony
,
when
he
was
stayed
by
a
buzz
and
murmur
at
the
upper
end
of
the
hall
,
and
,
looking
in
that
direction
,
saw
Lord
George
Gordon
coming
in
,
with
a
crowd
of
people
round
him
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
lurking
look
of
triumph
,
though
very
differently
expressed
,
in
the
faces
of
his
two
companions
,
which
made
it
a
natural
impulse
on
Mr
Haredale
's
part
not
to
give
way
before
this
leader
,
but
to
stand
there
while
he
passed
.
 
<EOS>
He
drew
himself
up
and
,
clasping
his
hands
behind
him
,
looked
on
with
a
proud
and
scornful
aspect
,
while
Lord
George
slowly
advanced
(
for
the
press
was
great
about
him
)
towards
the
spot
where
they
were
standing
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
left
the
House
of
Commons
but
that
moment
,
and
had
come
straight
down
into
the
Hall
,
bringing
with
him
,
as
his
custom
was
,
intelligence
of
what
had
been
said
that
night
in
reference
to
the
Papists
,
and
what
petitions
had
been
presented
in
their
favour
,
and
who
had
supported
them
,
and
when
the
bill
was
to
be
brought
in
,
and
when
it
would
be
advisable
to
present
their
own
Great
Protestant
petition
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
he
told
the
persons
about
him
in
a
loud
voice
,
and
with
great
abundance
of
ungainly
gesture
.
 
<EOS>
Those
who
were
nearest
him
made
comments
to
each
other
,
and
vented
threats
and
murmurings
;
those
who
were
outside
the
crowd
cried
,
"
Silence
,
"
and
Stand
back
,
"
or
closed
in
upon
the
rest
,
endeavouring
to
make
a
forcible
exchange
of
places
:
<EOS>
and
so
they
came
driving
on
in
a
very
disorderly
and
irregular
way
,
as
it
is
the
manner
of
a
crowd
to
do
.
  
<EOS>
When
they
were
very
near
to
where
the
secretary
,
Sir
John
,
and
Mr
Haredale
stood
,
Lord
George
turned
round
and
,
making
a
few
remarks
of
a
sufficiently
violent
and
incoherent
kind
,
concluded
with
the
usual
sentiment
,
and
called
for
three
cheers
to
back
it
.
 
<EOS>
While
these
were
in
the
act
of
being
given
with
great
energy
,
he
extricated
himself
from
the
press
,
and
stepped
up
to
Gashford
's
side
.
 
<EOS>
Both
he
and
Sir
John
being
well
known
to
the
populace
,
they
fell
back
a
little
,
and
left
the
four
standing
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Haredale
,
Lord
George
,
"
said
Sir
John
Chester
,
seeing
that
the
nobleman
regarded
him
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
A
Catholic
gentleman
unfortunately
---
most
unhappily
a
Catholic
---
but
an
esteemed
acquaintance
of
mine
,
and
once
of
Mr
Gashford
's
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Haredale
,
this
is
Lord
George
Gordon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
known
that
,
had
I
been
ignorant
of
his
lordship
's
person
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
there
is
but
one
gentleman
in
England
who
,

,
would
speak

-
subjects

as
I
heard
this

.
 
<EOS>
For
shame
,
my
lord
,
for
shame
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
talk
to
you
,
sir
,
"
replied
Lord
George
in

,
and

in

;
"
we
have
nothing
in
common
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
have
much
in
common
---
many
things
---
all
that
the
Almighty
gave
us
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
;
"
and
common
charity
,
not
to
say
common
sense
and
common

,
should
teach
you
to
refrain
from
these

.
 
<EOS>
If
every
one
of
those
men
had
arms
in

at
this

,
as
they
have
them
in
their
heads
,
I
would
not
leave
this

without

that
you
disgrace

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
hear

,

,
"
he

in
the
same

as

;
"
I
ca
n't
hear
you
.
 
<EOS>
It
is

me
what
you

.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
retort
,
Gashford
,
"
for
the

;
"
I
can
hold
no
communion
with
the

of

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
said

,

glanced
at
Sir
John
,
who
lifted
his
hands
and
eyebrows
,
as
if
deploring
the
intemperate

of
Mr
Haredale
,
and
smiled
in
admiration
of
the
crowd
and
of

.
  
<EOS>
"
HE
retort
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Haredale
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
you
here
,
my
lord
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
this
man
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lord
George
replied
by
laying
his
hand
upon
the
shoulder
of
his
cringing
secretary
,
and
viewing
him
with
a
smile
of
confidence
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
man
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
eyeing
him
from
top
to
toe
,
"
who
in
his
boyhood
was
a
thief
,
and
has
been
from
that
time
to
this
,
a
servile
,
false
,
and
truckling
knave
:
<EOS>
this
man
,
who
has
crawled
and
crept
through
life
,
wounding
the
hands
he
licked
,
and
biting
those
he
fawned
upon
:
this
sycophant
,
who
never
knew
what
honour
,
truth
,
or
courage
meant
;
who
robbed
his
benefactor
's
daughter
of
her
virtue
,
and
married
her
to
break
her
heart
,
and
did
it
,
with
stripes
and
cruelty
:
this
creature
,
who
has
whined
at
kitchen
windows
for
the
broken
food
,
and
begged
for
halfpence
at
our
chapel
doors
:
this
apostle
of
the
faith
,
whose
tender
conscience
can
not
bear
the
altars
where
his
vicious
life
was
publicly
denounced
---
<EOS>
Do
you
know
this
man
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
really
---
you
are
very
,
very
hard
upon
our
friend
!
"
exclaimed
Sir
John
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
Mr
Haredale
go
on
,
"
said
Gashford
,
upon
whose
unwholesome
face
the
perspiration
had
broken
out
during
this
speech
,
in
blotches
of
wet
;
"
I
do
n't
mind
him
,
Sir
John
;
it
's
quite
as
indifferent
to
me
what
he
says
,
as
it
is
to
my
lord
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
reviles
my
lord
,
as
you
have
heard
,
Sir
John
,
how
can
I
hope
to
escape
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
not
enough
,
my
lord
,
"
Mr
Haredale
continued
,
"
that
I
,
as
good
a
gentleman
as
you
,
must
hold
my
property
,
such
as
it
is
,
by
a
trick
at
which
the
state
connives
because
of
these
hard
laws
;
and
that
we
may
not
teach
our
youth
in
schools
the
common
principles
of
right
and
wrong
;
but
must
we
be
denounced
and
ridden
by
such
men
as
this
!
 
<EOS>
Here
is
a
man
to
head
your
No
-
Popery
cry
!
 
<EOS>
For
shame
.
 
<EOS>
For
shame
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
infatuated
nobleman
had
glanced
more
than
once
at
Sir
John
Chester
,
as
if
to
inquire
whether
there
was
any
truth
in
these
statements
concerning
Gashford
,
and
Sir
John
had
as
often
plainly
answered
by
a
shrug
or
look
,
"
<EOS>
Oh
dear
me
!
<EOS>
no
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
now
said
,
in
the
same
loud
key
,
and
in
the
same
strange
manner
as
before
:
  
"
I
have
nothing
to
say
,
sir
,
in
reply
,
and
no
desire
to
hear
anything
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
beg
you
wo
n't
obtrude
your
conversation
,
or
these
personal
attacks
,
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
not
be
deterred
from
doing
my
duty
to
my
country
and
my
countrymen
,
by
any
such
attempts
,
whether
they
proceed
from
emissaries
of
the
Pope
or
not
,
I
assure
you
.
<EOS>
Come
,
Gashford
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
had
walked
on
a
few
paces
while
speaking
,
and
were
now
at
the
Hall
-
door
,
through
which
they
passed
together
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
,
without
any
leave
-
taking
,
turned
away
to
the
river
stairs
,
which
were
close
at
hand
,
and
hailed
the
only
boatman
who
remained
there
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
throng
of
people
---
the
foremost
of
whom
had
heard
every
word
that
Lord
George
Gordon
said
,
and
among
all
of
whom
the
rumour
had
been
rapidly
dispersed
that
the
stranger
was
a
Papist
who
was
bearding
him
for
his
advocacy
of
the
popular
cause
---
came
pouring
out
pell
-
mell
,
and
,
forcing
the
nobleman
,
his
secretary
,
and
Sir
John
Chester
on
before
them
,
so
that
they
appeared
to
be
at
their
head
,
crowded
to
the
top
of
the
stairs
where
Mr
Haredale
waited
until
the
boat
was
ready
,
and
there
stood
still
,
leaving
him
on
a
little
clear
space
by
himself
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
not
silent
,
however
,
though
inactive
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
some
indistinct
mutterings
arose
among
them
,
which
were
followed
by
a
hiss
or
two
,
and
these
swelled
by
degrees
into
a
perfect
storm
.
<EOS>
Then
one
voice
said
,
"
Down
with
the
Papists
!
"
<EOS>
and
there
was
a
pretty
general
cheer
,
but
nothing
more
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
lull
of
a
few
moments
,
one
man
cried
out
,
"
Stone
him
;
"
another
,
"
Duck
him
;
"
<EOS>
another
,
in
a
stentorian
voice
,
"
No
Popery
!
"
 
<EOS>
This
favourite
cry
the
rest
re
-
echoed
,
and
the
mob
,
which
might
have
been
two
hundred
strong
,
joined
in
a
general
shout
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
had
stood
calmly
on
the
brink
of
the
steps
,
until
they
made
this
demonstration
,
when
he
looked
round
contemptuously
,
and
walked
at
a
slow
pace
down
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
pretty
near
the
boat
,
when
Gashford
,
as
if
without
intention
,
turned
about
,
and
directly
afterwards
a
great
stone
was
thrown
by
some
hand
,
in
the
crowd
,
which
struck
him
on
the
head
,
and
made
him
stagger
like
a
drunken
man
.
  
<EOS>
The
blood
sprung
freely
from
the
wound
,
and
trickled
down
his
coat
.
<EOS>
He
turned
directly
,
and
rushing
up
the
steps
with
a
boldness
and
passion
which
made
them
all
fall
back
,
demanded
:
  
"
Who
did
that
?
 
<EOS>
Show
me
the
man
who
hit
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Not
a
soul
moved
;
except
some
in
the
rear
who
slunk
off
,
and
,
escaping
to
the
other
side
of
the
way
,
looked
on
like
indifferent
spectators
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
did
that
?
"
he
repeated
.
 
<EOS>
"
Show
me
the
man
who
did
it
.
 
<EOS>
Dog
,
was
it
you
?
 
<EOS>
It
was
your
deed
,
if
not
<EOS>
your
hand
---
I
know
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
threw
himself
on
Gashford
as
he
said
the
words
,
and
hurled
him
to
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
sudden
motion
in
the
crowd
,
and
some
laid
hands
upon
him
,
but
his
sword
was
out
,
and
they
fell
off
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
lord
---
Sir
John
,
"
---
he
cried
,
"
draw
,
one
of
you
---
you
are
responsible
for
this
outrage
,
and
I
look
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Draw
,
if
you
are
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
that
he
struck
Sir
John
upon
the
breast
with
the
flat
of
his
weapon
,
and
with
a
burning
face
and
flashing
eyes
stood
upon
his
guard
;
alone
,
before
them
all
.
  
<EOS>
For
an
instant
,
for
the
briefest
space
of
time
the
mind
can
readily
conceive
,
there
was
a
change
in
Sir
John
's
smooth
face
,
such
as
no
man
ever
saw
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
next
moment
,
he
stepped
forward
,
and
laid
one
hand
on
Mr
Haredale
's
arm
,
while
with
the
other
he
endeavoured
to
appease
the
crowd
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
friend
,
my
good
Haredale
,
you
are
blinded
with
passion
---
 
it
's
very
natural
,
extremely
natural
---
but
you
do
n't
know
friends
from
foes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
them
all
,
sir
,
I
can
distinguish
well
<EOS>
---
"
he
retorted
,
almost
mad
with
rage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
John
,
Lord
George
---
do
you
hear
me
?
 
<EOS>
Are
you
cowards
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
,
sir
,
"
said
a
man
,
forcing
his
way
between
and
pushing
him
towards
the
stairs
with
friendly
violence
,
"
never
mind
asking
that
.
 
<EOS>
For
God
's
sake
,
get
away
.
 
<EOS>
What
CAN
you
do
against
this
number
?
 
<EOS>
And
there
are
as
many
more
in
the
next
street
,
who
'll
be
round
directly
,
"
---
<EOS>
indeed
they
began
to
pour
in
as
he
said
the
words
---
"
you
'd
be
giddy
from
that
cut
,
in
the
first
heat
of
a
scuffle
.
 
<EOS>
Now
do
retire
,
sir
,
or
take
my
word
for
it
<EOS>
you
'll
be
worse
used
than
you
would
be
if
every
man
in
the
crowd
was
a
woman
,
and
that
woman
Bloody
Mary
.
 
<EOS>
Come
,
sir
,
make
haste
---
as
quick
as
you
can
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
,
who
began
to
turn
faint
and
sick
,
felt
how
sensible
this
advice
was
,
and
descended
the
steps
with
his
unknown
friend
's
assistance
.
 
<EOS>
John
Grueby
(
for
John
it
was
)
helped
him
into
the
boat
,
and
giving
her
a
shove
off
,
which
sent
her
thirty
feet
into
the
tide
,
bade
the
waterman
pull
away
like
a
Briton
;
and
walked
up
again
as
composedly
as
if
he
had
just
landed
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
at
first
a
slight
disposition
on
the
part
of
the
mob
to
resent
this
interference
;
but
John
looking
particularly
strong
and
cool
,
and
wearing
besides
Lord
George
's
livery
<EOS>
,
they
thought
better
of
it
,
and
contented
themselves
with
sending
a
shower
of
small
missiles
after
the
boat
,
which
plashed
harmlessly
in
the
water
;
for
she
had
by
this
time
cleared
the
bridge
,
and
was
darting
swiftly
down
the
centre
of
the
stream
.
  
<EOS>
From
this
amusement
,
they
proceeded
to
giving
Protestant
knocks
at
the
doors
of
private
houses
,
breaking
a
few
lamps
,
and
assaulting
some
stray
constables
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
it
being
whispered
that
a
detachment
of
Life
Guards
had
been
sent
for
,
they
took
to
their
heels
with
great
expedition
,
and
left
the
street
quite
clear
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
44
    
<EOS>
When
the
concourse
separated
,
and
,
dividing
into
chance
clusters
,
drew
off
in
various
directions
,
there
still
remained
upon
the
scene
of
the
late
disturbance
,
one
man
.
 
<EOS>
This
man
was
Gashford
,
who
,
bruised
by
his
late
fall
,
and
hurt
in
a
much
greater
degree
by
the
indignity
he
had
undergone
,
and
the
exposure
of
which
he
had
been
the
victim
,
limped
up
and
down
,
breathing
curses
and
threats
of
vengeance
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
the
secretary
's
nature
to
waste
his
wrath
in
words
.
<EOS>
While
he
vented
the
froth
of
his
malevolence
in
those
effusions
,
he
kept
a
steady
eye
on
two
men
,
who
,
having
disappeared
with
the
rest
when
the
alarm
was
spread
,
had
since
returned
,
and
were
now
visible
in
the
moonlight
,
at
no
great
distance
,
as
they
walked
to
and
fro
,
and
talked
together
.
  
<EOS>
He
made
no
move
towards
them
,
but
waited
patiently
on
the
dark
side
of
the
street
,
until
they
were
tired
of
strolling
backwards
and
forwards
and
walked
away
in
company
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
followed
,
but
at
some
distance
:
keeping
them
in
view
,
without
appearing
to
have
that
object
,
or
being
seen
by
them
.
  
<EOS>
They
went
up
Parliament
Street
,
past
Saint
Martin
's
church
,
and
away
by
Saint
Giles
's
to
Tottenham
Court
Road
,
at
the
back
of
which
,
upon
the
western
side
,
was
then
a
place
called
the
Green
Lanes
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
a
retired
spot
,
not
of
the
choicest
kind
,
leading
into
the
fields
.
 
<EOS>
Great
heaps
of
ashes
;
stagnant
pools
,
overgrown
with
rank
grass
and
duckweed
;
broken
turnstiles
;
and
the
upright
posts
of
palings
long
since
carried
off
for
firewood
,
which
menaced
all
heedless
walkers
with
their
jagged
and
rusty
nails
;
were
the
leading
features
of
the
landscape
:
while
here
and
there
a
donkey
,
or
a
ragged
horse
,
tethered
to
a
stake
,
and
cropping
off
a
wretched
meal
from
the
coarse
stunted
turf
,
were
quite
in
keeping
with
the
scene
,
and
would
have
suggested
(
if
the
houses
had
not
done
so
,
sufficiently
,
of
themselves
)
<EOS>
how
very
poor
the
people
were
who
lived
in
the
crazy
huts
adjacent
,
and
how
foolhardy
it
might
prove
for
one
who
carried
money
,
or
wore
decent
clothes
,
to
walk
that
way
alone
,
unless
by
daylight
.
  
<EOS>
Poverty
has
its
whims
and
shows
of
taste
,
as
wealth
has
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
these
cabins
were
turreted
,
some
had
false
windows
painted
on
their
rotten
walls
;
one
had
a
mimic
clock
,
upon
a
crazy
tower
of
four
feet
high
,
which
screened
the
chimney
;
each
in
its
little
patch
of
ground
had
a
rude
seat
or
arbour
.
 
<EOS>
The
population
dealt
in
bones
,
in
rags
,
in
broken
glass
,
in
old
wheels
,
in
birds
,
and
dogs
.
<EOS>
These
,
in
their
several
ways
of
stowage
,
filled
the
gardens
;
and
shedding
a
perfume
,
not
of
the
most
delicious
nature
,
in
the
air
,
filled
it
besides
with
yelps
,
and
screams
,
and
howling
.
  
<EOS>
Into
this
retreat
,
the
secretary
followed
the
two
men
whom
he
had
held
in
sight
;
and
here
he
saw
them
safely
lodged
,
in
one
of
the
meanest
houses
,
which
was
but
a
room
,
and
that
of
small
dimensions
.
<EOS>
He
waited
without
,
until
the
sound
of
their
voices
,
joined
in
a
discordant
song
,
assured
him
they
were
making
merry
;
and
then
approaching
the
door
,
by
means
of
a
tottering
plank
which
crossed
the
ditch
in
front
,
knocked
at
it
with
his
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
Muster
Gashfordl
"
said
the
man
who
opened
it
,
taking
his
pipe
from
his
mouth
,
in
evident
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
who
'd
have
thought
of
this
here
honour
!
 
<EOS>
Walk
in
,
Muster
Gashford
---
walk
in
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Gashford
required
no
second
invitation
,
and
entered
with
a
gracious
air
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
fire
in
the
rusty
grate
(
for
though
the
spring
was
pretty
far
advanced
,
the
nights
were
cold
)
,
and
on
a
stool
beside
it
<EOS>
Hugh
sat
smoking
.
 
<EOS>
Dennis
placed
a
chair
,
his
only
one
,
for
the
secretary
,
in
front
of
the
hearth
;
and
took
his
seat
again
upon
the
stool
he
had
left
when
he
rose
to
give
the
visitor
admission
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
in
the
wind
now
,
Muster
Gashford
?
<EOS>
"
he
said
,
as
he
resumed
his
pipe
,
and
looked
at
him
askew
.
 
<EOS>
"
Any
orders
from
head
-
quarters
?
<EOS>
Are
we
going
to
begin
?
 
<EOS>
What
is
it
,
Muster
Gashford
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
nothing
,
nothing
,
"
rejoined
the
secretary
,
with
a
friendly
nod
to
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
broken
the
ice
,
though
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
a
little
spurt
to
-
day
---
eh
,
Dennis
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
very
little
one
,
"
growled
the
hangman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
half
enough
for
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
me
neither
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
us
something
to
do
with
life
in
it
---
with
life
in
it
,
master
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
"
  
"
Why
,
you
would
n't
,
"
said
the
secretary
,
with
his
worst
expression
of
face
,
and
in
his
mildest
tones
,
"
have
anything
to
do
,
with
---
with
death
in
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
,
"
replied
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
open
to
orders
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
care
;
not
I.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Nor
I
!
"
<EOS>
vociferated
Dennis
.
  
<EOS>
"
Brave
fellows
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
secretary
,
in
as
pastor
-
like
a
voice
as
if
he
were
commending
them
for
some
uncommon
act
of
valour
and
generosity
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
the
bye
"
---
and
here
he
stopped
and
warmed
his
hands
:
then
suddenly
looked
up
---
"
who
threw
that
stone
to
-
day
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dennis
coughed
and
shook
his
head
,
as
who
should
say
,
"
A
mystery
indeed
!
"
 
<EOS>
Hugh
sat
and
smoked
in
silence
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
well
done
!
"
said
the
secretary
,
warming
his
hands
again
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
know
that
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Would
you
?
"
said
Dennis
,
after
looking
at
his
face
to
assure
himself
that
he
was
serious
.
 
<EOS>
"
Would
you
like
to
know
that
man
,
Muster
Gashford
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
indeed
,
"
replied
the
secretary
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
then
,
Lord
love
you
,
"
said
the
hangman
,
in
his
hoarest

,
as
he

,
"
there
he
sits
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
My
stars
and
halters
,
Muster
Gashford
,
"
he

,
"
what

is
!
 
<EOS>
He
wants
as
much
holding
in
as

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

that
'

Roman
down
,

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
And

?
"
cried

in

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
's

?
 
<EOS>
Strike
<EOS>
while
the
iron
's

;
that
's

I
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ah
!
"
retorted

,

,

;
"

!
 
<EOS>
You

afore
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
There

<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dennis

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

.
 
<EOS>
Dennis

great
knowledge
of
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ought
to
have
,
Muster
Gashford
,
seeing
what

I
've
helped

,

?
"
grinned

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
secretary

at
this
jest

much
as
Dennis

,
and

,

<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,
for

<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Oh

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

!
"

,
"
you
went
down
very
quiet
,
Muster

---
and
very
flat

.
 
<EOS>
I
thinks
to
myself
at
the
time
<EOS>
"

's

Muster
Gashford
!
"
 
<EOS>
I

---

.
 
<EOS>
He

rough
'

with
<EOS>
,

'

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

's

as

on
Hugh
who

the
like
,
might

's

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

:
  
<EOS>
"
We

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

---
<EOS>
yes
,

---
as

.
 
<EOS>
It
's

;

.
 
<EOS>
If

---
and
we
ca
n't

,

---
this

"
---
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

I
've

!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Oh

!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Feeling

,

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
resumed

secretary
,
in

;
"
we
ca
n't

may

;
and
if

,
against

,
to

,
my

(
who
has

to
-

,
as
far

)

to

---
<EOS>
bearing

of
you

,
as
good

,
beyond
all
doubt
and

---
<EOS>
the
pleasant

punishing
this
Haredale
.
 
<EOS>
You

,

,

no

,

,

two

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

,

,

;
it

;
and
he
,

all

,
left
as

as
new
-
born
infants
whom

mothers
have
exposed
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
understand

?
"
said

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Understand

,

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
speak
plain

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
this

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said

,

;
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't

,
Dennis
:
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
may
have

make
other

here
,
and
it
's
pleasant
to
come
and

without

you
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
find
my
way
perfectly
well
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
was

,
and
had

door
behind

.
 
<EOS>
They
looked
at

other
,
and
nodded
approvingly
:
Dennis
stirred
up
the
fire
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
looks
a
little
more
like
business
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
indeed
!
"
cried
Hugh
;
"
this
suits
me
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
heerd
it
said
of
Muster
Gashford
,
"
said
the
hangman
,
"
that
he
'd
a
surprising

and

---
that
he
never
forgot
,
and
never

.
<EOS>
---
Let
's
drink

health
!
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
readily
complied
---
pouring
no
liquor
on
the
floor
when
he
drank
this
toast
---
and
they
pledged
the
secretary
as
a
man
after
their
own
hearts
,
in
a
bumper
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
45
    
<EOS>
While
the
worst
passions
of
the
worst
men
were
thus
working
in
the
dark
,
and
the
mantle
of
religion
,
assumed
to
cover
the
ugliest
deformities
,
threatened
to
become
the
shroud
of
all
that
was
good
and
peaceful
in
society
,
a
circumstance
occurred
which
once
more
altered
the
position
of
two
persons
from
whom
this
history
has
long
been
separated
,
and
to
whom
it
must
now
return
.
  
<EOS>
In
a
small
English
country
town
,
the
inhabitants
of
which
supported
themselves
by
the
labour
of
their
hands
in
plaiting
and
preparing
straw
for
those
who
made
bonnets
and
other
articles
of
dress
and
ornament
from
that
material
,
---
concealed
under
an
assumed
name
,
and
living
in
a
quiet
poverty
which
knew
no
change
,
no
pleasures
,
and
few
cares
but
that
of
struggling
on
from
day
to
day
in
one
great
toil
for
bread
,
---
dwelt
Barnaby
and
his
mother
.
 
<EOS>
Their
poor
cottage
had
known
no
stranger
's
foot
since
they
sought
the
shelter
of
its
roof
five
years
before
;
nor
had
they
in
all
that
time
held
any
commerce
or
communication
with
the
old
world
from
which
they
had
fled
.
 
<EOS>
To
labour
in
peace
,
and
devote
her
labour
and
her
life
to
her
poor
son
,
was
all
the
widow
sought
.
 
<EOS>
If
happiness
can
be
said
at
any
time
to
be
the
lot
of
one
on
whom
a
secret
sorrow
preys
,
she
was
happy
now
.
 
<EOS>
Tranquillity
,
resignation
,
and
her
strong
love
of
him
who
needed
it
so
much
,
formed
the
small
circle
of
her
quiet
joys
;
and
while
that
remained
unbroken
,
she
was
contented
.
  
<EOS>
For
Barnaby
himself
,
the
time
which
had
flown
by
,
had
passed
him
like
the
wind
.
 
<EOS>
The
daily
suns
of
years
had
shed
no
brighter
gleam
of
reason
on
his
mind
;
no
dawn
had
broken
on
his
long
,
dark
night
.
<EOS>
He
would
sit
sometimes
---
often
for
days
together
on
a
low
seat
by
the
fire
or
by
the
cottage
door
,
busy
at
work
(
for
he
had
learnt
the
art
his
mother
plied
)
,
and
listening
,
God
help
him
,
to
the
tales
she
would
repeat
,
as
a
lure
to
keep
him
in
her
sight
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
recollection
of
these
little
narratives
;
the
tale
of
yesterday
was
new
to
him
upon
the
morrow
;
but
he
liked
them
at
the
moment
;
and
when
the
humour
held
him
,
would
remain
patiently
within
doors
,
hearing
her
stories
like
a
little
child
,
and
working
cheerfully
from
sunrise
until
it
was
too
dark
to
see
.
  
<EOS>
At
other
times
,
---
and
then
their
scanty
earnings
were
barely
sufficient
to
furnish
them
with
food
,
though
of
the
coarsest
sort
,
---
 
he
would
wander
abroad
from
dawn
of
day
until
the
twilight
deepened
into
night
.
 
<EOS>
Few
in
that
place
,
even
of
the
children
,
could
be
idle
,
and
he
had
no
companions
of
his
own
kind
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
there
were
not
many
who
could
have
kept
up
with
him
in
his
rambles
,
<EOS>
had
there
been
a
legion
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
were
a
score
of
vagabond
dogs
belonging
to
the
neighbours
,
who
served
his
purpose
quite
as
well
.
<EOS>
With
two
or
three
of
these
,
or
sometimes
with
a
full
half
-
dozen
barking
at
his
heels
,
he
would
sally
forth
on
some
long
expedition
that
consumed
the
day
;
and
though
,
on
their
return
at
nightfall
,
the
dogs
would
come
home
limping
and
sore
-
footed
,
and
almost
spent
with
their
fatigue
,
Barnaby
was
up
and
off
again
at
sunrise
with
some
new
attendants
of
the
same
class
,
with
whom
he
would
return
in
like
manner
.
 
<EOS>
On
all
these
travels
,
Grip
,
in
his
little
basket
at
his
master
's
back
,
was
a
constant
member
of
the
party
,
and
when
they
set
off
in
fine
weather
and
in
high
spirits
,
no
dog
barked
louder
than
the
raven
.
  
<EOS>
Their
pleasures
on
these
excursions
were
simple
enough
.
 
<EOS>
A
crust
of
bread
and
scrap
of
meat
,
with
water
from
the
brook
or
spring
,
sufficed
for
their
repast
.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
's
enjoyments
were
,
to
walk
,
and
run
,
and
leap
,
till
he
was
tired
;
then
to
lie
down
in
the
long
grass
,
or
by
the
growing
corn
,
or
in
the
shade
of
some
tall
tree
,
looking
upward
at
the
light
clouds
as
they
floated
over
the
blue
surface
of
the
sky
,
and
listening
to
the
lark
as
she
poured
out
her
brilliant
song
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
wild
-
flowers
to
pluck
---
the
bright
red
poppy
,
the
gentle
harebell
,
the
cowslip
,
and
the
rose
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
birds
to
watch
;
fish
;
ants
;
worms
;
hares
or
rabbits
,
as
they
darted
across
the
distant
pathway
in
the
wood
and
so
were
gone
:
<EOS>
millions
of
living
things
to
have
an
interest
in
,
and
lie
in
wait
for
,
and
clap
hands
and
shout
in
memory
of
,
when
they
had
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
In
default
of
these
,
or
when
they
wearied
,
there
was
the
merry
sunlight
to
hunt
out
,
as
it
crept
in
aslant
through
leaves
and
boughs
of
trees
,
and
hid
far
down
---
deep
,
deep
,
in
hollow
places
---
 
like
a
silver
pool
,
where
nodding
branches
seemed
to
bathe
and
sport
;
sweet
scents
of
summer
air
breathing
over
fields
of
beans
or
clover
;
the
perfume
of
wet
leaves
or
moss
;
the
life
of
waving
trees
,
and
shadows
always
changing
.
 
<EOS>
When
these
or
any
of
them
tired
,
or
in
excess
of
pleasing
tempted
him
to
shut
his
eyes
,
there
was
slumber
in
the
midst
of
all
these
soft
delights
,
with
the
gentle
wind
murmuring
like
music
in
his
ears
,
and
everything
around
melting
into
one
delicious
dream
.
  
<EOS>
Their
hut
---
for
it
was
little
more
---
stood
on
the
outskirts
of
the
town
,
at
a
short
distance
from
the
high
road
,
but
in
a
secluded
place
,
where
few
chance
passengers
strayed
at
any
season
of
the
year
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
a
plot
of
garden
-
ground
attached
,
which
Barnaby
,
in
fits
and
starts
of
working
,
trimmed
,
and
kept
in
order
.
 
<EOS>
Within
doors
and
without
,
his
mother
laboured
for
their
common
good
;
and
hail
,
rain
,
snow
,
or
sunshine
,
found
no
difference
in
her
.
  
<EOS>
Though
so
far
removed
from
the
scenes
of
her
past
life
,
and
with
so
little
thought
or
hope
of
ever
visiting
them
again
,
she
seemed
to
have
a
strange
desire
to
know
what
happened
in
the
busy
world
.
 
<EOS>
Any
old
newspaper
,
or
scrap
of
intelligence
from
London
,
she
caught
at
with
avidity
.
 
<EOS>
The
excitement
it
produced
was
not
of
a
pleasurable
kind
,
for
her
manner
at
such
times
expressed
the
keenest
anxiety
and
dread
;
but
it
never
faded
in
the
least
degree
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
and
in
stormy
winter
nights
,
when
the
wind
blew
loud
and
strong
,
the
old
expression
came
into
her
face
,
and
she
would
be
seized
with
a
fit
of
trembling
,
like
one
who
had
an
ague
.
 
<EOS>
But
Barnaby
noted
little
of
this
;
and
putting
a
great
constraint
upon
herself
,
she
usually
recovered
her
accustomed
manner
before
the
change
had
caught
his
observation
.
  
<EOS>
Grip
was
by
no
means
an
idle
or
unprofitable
member
of
the
humble
household
.
 
<EOS>
Partly
by
dint
of
Barnaby
's
tuition
,
and
partly
by
pursuing
a
species
of
self
-
instruction
common
to
his
tribe
,
and
exerting
his
powers
of
observation
to
the
utmost
,
he
had
acquired
a
degree
of
sagacity
which
rendered
him
famous
for
miles
round
.
 
<EOS>
His
conversational
powers
and
surprising
performances
were
the
universal
theme
:
and
as
many
persons
came
to
see
the
wonderful
raven
,
and
none
left
his
exertions
unrewarded
---
when
he
condescended
to
exhibit
,
which
was
not
always
,
for
genius
is
capricious
---
his
earnings
formed
an
important
item
in
the
common
stock
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
bird
himself
appeared
to
know
his
value
well
;
for
though
he
was
perfectly
free
and
unrestrained
in
the
presence
of
Barnaby
and
his
mother
,
he
maintained
in
public
an
amazing
gravity
,
and
never
stooped
to
any
other
gratuitous
performances
than
biting
the
ankles
of
vagabond
boys
(
an
exercise
in
which
he
much
delighted
)
,
killing
a
fowl
or
two
occasionally
,
and
swallowing
the
dinners
of
various
neighbouring
dogs
,
of
whom
the
boldest
held
him
in
great
awe
and
dread
.
  
<EOS>
Time
had
glided
on
in
this
way
,
and
nothing
had
happened
to
disturb
or
change
their
mode
of
life
,
when
,
one
summer
's
night
in
June
,
they
were
in
their
little
garden
,
resting
from
the
labours
of
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
widow
's
work
was
yet
upon
her
knee
,
and
strewn
upon
the
ground
about
her
;
and
Barnaby
stood
leaning
on
his
spade
,
gazing
at
the
brightness
in
the
west
,
and
singing
softly
to
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
brave
evening
,
mother
!
 
<EOS>
If
we
had
,
chinking
in
our
pockets
,
but
a
few
specks
of
that
gold
which
is
piled
up
yonder
in
the
sky
,
we
should
be
rich
for
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
better
as
we
are
,
"
returned
the
widow
with
a
quiet
smile
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
be
contented
,
and
we
do
not
want
and
need
not
care
to
have
it
,
though
it
lay
shining
at
our
feet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
"
said
Barnaby
,
resting
with
crossed
arms
on
his
spade
,
and
looking
wistfully
at
the
sunset
<EOS>
,
that
's
well
enough
,
mother
;
but
gold
's
a
good
thing
to
have
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
that
I
knew
where
to
find
it
.
<EOS>
Grip
and
I
could
do
much
with
gold
,
be
sure
of
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
A
world
of
things
.
 
<EOS>
We
'd
dress
finely
---
you
and
I
,
I
mean
;
not
Grip
---
<EOS>
keep
horses
,
dogs
,
wear
bright
colours
and
feathers
,
do
no
more
work
,
live
delicately
and
at
our
ease
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
we
'd
find
uses
for
it
,
mother
,
and
uses
that
would
do
us
good
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
I
knew
where
gold
was
buried
.
 
<EOS>
How
hard
I
'd
work
to
dig
it
up
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
know
,
"
said
his
mother
,
rising
from
her
seat
and
laying
her
hand
upon
his
shoulder
,
"
what
men
have
done
to
win
it
,
and
how
they
have
found
,
too
late
,
that
it
glitters
brightest
at
a
distance
,
and
turns
quite
dim
and
dull
when
handled
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
;
so
you
say
;
so
you
think
,
"
he
answered
,
still
looking
eagerly
in
the
same
direction
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
all
that
,
mother
,
I
should
like
to
try
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
not
see
,
"
she
said
,
"
how
red
it
is
?
 
<EOS>
Nothing
bears
so
many
stains
of
blood
,
as
gold
.
 
<EOS>
Avoid
it
.
 
<EOS>
None
have
such
cause
to
hate
its
name
as
we
have
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
so
much
as
think
of
it
,
dear
love
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
brought
such
misery
and
suffering
on
your
head
and
mine
as
few
have
known
,
and
God
grant
<EOS>
few
may
have
to
undergo
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
rather
we
were
dead
and
laid
down
in
our
graves
,
than
you
should
ever
come
to
love
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
For
a
moment
Barnaby
withdrew
his
eyes
and
looked
at
her
with
wonder
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
glancing
from
the
redness
in
the
sky
to
the
mark
upon
his
wrist
as
if
he
would
compare
the
two
,
he
seemed
about
to
question
her
with
earnestness
,
when
a
new
object
caught
his
wandering
attention
,
and
made
him
quite
forgetful
of
his
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
This
was
a
man
with
dusty
feet
and
garments
,
who
stood
,
bare
-
headed
,
behind
the
hedge
that
divided
their
patch
of
garden
from
the
pathway
,
and
leant
meekly
forward
as
if
he
sought
to
mingle
with
their
conversation
,
and
waited
for
his
time
to
speak
.
 
<EOS>
His
face
was
turned
towards
the
brightness
,
too
,
but
the
light
that
fell
upon
it
showed
that
he
was
blind
,
and
saw
it
not
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
blessing
on
those
voices
!
"
said
the
wayfarer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
feel
the
beauty
of
the
night
more
keenly
,
when
I
hear
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
like
eyes
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Will
they
speak
again
,
and
cheer
the
heart
of
a
poor
traveller
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
no
guide
?
"
asked
the
widow
,
after
a
moment
's
pause
.
  
<EOS>
"
None
but
that
,
"
he
answered
,
pointing
with
his
staff
towards
the
sun
;
"
and
sometimes
a
milder
one
at
night
,
but
she
is
idle
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
travelled
far
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
weary
way
and
long
,
"
rejoined
the
traveller
as
he
shook
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
weary
,
weary
,
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
struck
my
stick
just
now
upon
the
bucket
of
your
well
---
be
pleased
to
let
me
have
a
draught
of
water
,
lady
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
call
me
lady
?
<EOS>
"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
as
poor
as
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
speech
is
soft
and
gentle
,
and
I
judge
by
that
,
"
replied
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
coarsest
stuffs
and
finest
silks
,
are
---
apart
from
the
sense
of
touch
---
alike
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
judge
you
by
your
dress
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Come
round
this
way
,
"
said
Barnaby
,
who
had
passed
out
at
the
garden
-
gate
and
now
stood
close
beside
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Put
your
hand
in
mine
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
blind
and
always
in
the
dark
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
Are
you
frightened
in
the
dark
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
see
great
crowds
of
faces
,
now
?
 
<EOS>
Do
they
grin
and
chatter
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
"
returned
the
other
,
"
I
see
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Waking
or
sleeping
,
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
looked
curiously
at
his
eyes
,
and
touching
them
with
his
fingers
,
as
an
inquisitive
child
might
,
led
him
towards
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
come
a
long
distance
,
"
said
the
widow
,
meeting
him
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
have
you
found
your
way
so
far
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Use
and
necessity
are
good
teachers
,
as
I
have
heard
---
the
best
of
any
,
"
said
the
blind
man
,
sitting
down
upon
the
chair
to
which
Barnaby
had
led
him
,
and
putting
his
hat
and
stick
upon
the
red
-
tiled
floor
.
 
<EOS>
"
May
neither
you
nor
your
son
ever
learn
under
them
.
<EOS>
They
are
rough
masters
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
wandered
from
the
road
,
too
,
"
said
the
widow
,
in
a
tone
of
pity
.
  
<EOS>
"
Maybe
,
maybe
,
"
returned
the
blind
man
with
a
sigh
,
and
yet
with
something
of
a
smile
upon
his
face
,
"
that
's
likely
.
 
<EOS>
Handposts
and
milestones
are
dumb
,
indeed
,
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
the
more
for
this
rest
,
and
this
refreshing
drink
!
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
he
raised
the
mug
of
water
to
his
mouth
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
clear
,
and
cold
,
and
sparkling
,
but
not
to
his
taste
nevertheless
,
or
his
thirst
was
not
very
great
,
for
he
only
wetted
his
lips
and
put
it
down
again
.
  
<EOS>
He
wore
,
hanging
with
a
long
strap
round
his
neck
,
a
kind
of
scrip
or
wallet
,
in
which
to
carry
food
.
 
<EOS>
The
widow
set
some
bread
and
cheese
before
him
,
but
he
thanked
her
,
and
said
that
through
the
kindness
of
the
charitable
he
had
broken
his
fast
once
since
morning
,
and
was
not
hungry
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
made
her
this
reply
,
he
opened
his
wallet
,
and
took
out
a
few
pence
,
which
was
all
it
appeared
to
contain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Might
I
make
bold
to
ask
,
"
he
said
,
turning
towards
where
Barnaby
stood
looking
on
,
"
that
one
who
has
the
gift
of
sight
,
would
lay
this
out
for
me
in
bread
to
keep
me
on
my
way
?
 
<EOS>
Heaven
's
blessing
on
the
young
feet
that
will
bestir
themselves
in
aid
of
one
so
helpless
as
a
sightless
man
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
looked
at
his
mother
,
who
nodded
assent
;
in
another
moment
he
was
gone
upon
his
charitable
errand
.
 
<EOS>
The
blind
man
sat
listening
with
an
attentive
face
,
until
long
after
the
sound
of
his
retreating
footsteps
was
inaudible
to
the
widow
,
and
then
said
,
suddenly
,
and
in
a
very
altered
tone
:
  
<EOS>
"
There
are
various
degrees
and
kinds
of
blindness
,
widow
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
the
connubial
blindness
,
ma'am
,
which
perhaps
you
may
have
observed
in
the
course
of
your
own
experience
,
and
which
is
a
kind
of
wilful
and
self
-
bandaging
blindness
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
the
blindness
of
party
,
ma'am
,
and
public
men
,
which
is
the
blindness
of
a
mad
bull
in
the
midst
of
a
regiment
of
soldiers
clothed
in
red
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
the
blind
confidence
of
youth
,
which
is
the
blindness
of
young
kittens
,
whose
eyes
have
not
yet
opened
on
the
world
;
and
there
is
that
physical
blindness
,
ma'am
,
of
which
I
am
,
contrairy
to
my
own
desire
,
a
most
illustrious
example
.
 
<EOS>
Added
to
these
,
ma'am
,
is
that
blindness
of
the
intellect
,
of
which
we
have
a
specimen
in
your
interesting
son
,
and
which
,
having
sometimes
glimmerings
and
dawnings
of
the
light
,
is
scarcely
to
be
trusted
as
a
total
darkness
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,
ma'am
,
I
have
taken
the
liberty
to
get
him
out
of
the
way
for
a
short
time
,
while
you
and
I
confer
together
,
and
this
precaution
arising
out
of
the
delicacy
of
my
sentiments
towards
yourself
,
you
will
excuse
me
,
ma'am
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Having
delivered
himself
of
this
speech
with
many
flourishes
of
manner
,
he
drew
from
beneath
his
coat
a
flat
stone
bottle
,
and
holding
the
cork
between
his
teeth
,
qualified
his
mug
of
water
with
a
plentiful
infusion
of
the
liquor
it
contained
.
 
<EOS>
He
politely
drained
the
bumper
to
her
health
,
and
the
ladies
,
and
setting
it
down
empty
,
smacked
his
lips
with
infinite
relish
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
citizen
of
the
world
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
blind
man
,
corking
his
bottle
,
"
and
if
I
seem
to
conduct
myself
with
freedom
,
it
is
therefore
.
 
<EOS>
You
wonder
who
I
am
,
ma'am
,
and
what
has
brought
me
here
.
 
<EOS>
Such
experience
of
human
nature
as
I
have
,
leads
me
to
that
conclusion
,
without
the
aid
of
eyes
by
which
to
read
the
movements
of
your
soul
as
depicted
in
your
feminine
features
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
satisfy
your
curiosity
immediately
,
ma'am
;
immediately
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
With
that
he
slapped
his
bottle
on
its
broad
back
,
and
having
put
it
under
his
garment
as
before
,
crossed
his
legs
and
folded
his
hands
,
and
settled
himself
in
his
chair
,
previous
to
proceeding
any
further
.
  
<EOS>
The
change
in
his
manner
was
so
unexpected
,
the
craft
and
wickedness
of
his
deportment
were
so
much
aggravated
by
his
condition
---
for
we
are
accustomed
to
see
in
those
who
have
lost
a
human
sense
,
something
in
its
place
almost
divine
---
and
this
alteration
bred
so
many
fears
in
her
whom
he
addressed
,
that
she
could
not
pronounce
one
word
.
 
<EOS>
After
waiting
,
as
it
seemed
,
for
some
remark
or
answer
,
and
waiting
in
vain
,
the
visitor
resumed
:
  
"
Madam
,
my
name
is
Stagg
.
 
<EOS>
A
friend
of
mine
who
has
desired
the
honour
of
meeting
with
you
any
time
these
five
years
past
,
has
commissioned
me
to
call
upon
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
be
glad
to
whisper
that
gentleman
's
name
in
your
ear
.
<EOS>
---
Zounds
,
ma'am
,
are
you
deaf
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
me
say
that
I
should
be
glad
to
whisper
my
friend
's
name
in
your
ear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
need
not
repeat
it
,
"
said
the
widow
,
with
a
stifled
groan
;
"
I
see
too
well
from
whom
you
come
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
as
a
man
of
honour
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
blind
man
,
striking
himself
on
the
breast
,
"
whose
credentials
must
not
be
disputed
<EOS>
,
I
take
leave
to
say
that
I
WILL
mention
that
gentleman
's
name
.
 
<EOS>
Ay
,
ay
,
"
he
added
,
seeming
to
catch
with
his
quick
ear
the
very
motion
of
her
hand
,
"
but
not
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
With
your
leave
,
ma'am
,
I
desire
the
favour
of
a
whisper
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
moved
towards
him
,
and
stooped
down
.
 
<EOS>
He
muttered
a
word
in
her
ear
;
and
,
wringing
her
hands
,
she
paced
up
and
down
the
room
like
one
distracted
.
 
<EOS>
The
blind
man
,
with
perfect
composure
,
produced
his
bottle
again
,
mixed
another
glassful
;
put
it
up
as
before
;
and
,
drinking
from
time
to
time
,
followed
her
with
his
face
in
silence
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
slow
in
conversation
,
widow
,
"
he
said
after
a
time
,
pausing
in
his
draught
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
have
to
talk
before
your
son
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
have
me
do
?
<EOS>
"
she
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
poor
,
widow
,
we
are
poor
,
"
he
retorted
,
stretching
out
his
right
hand
,
and
rubbing
his
thumb
upon
its
palm
.
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
what
am
I
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Comparisons
are
odious
,
"
said
the
blind
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
I
do
n't
care
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
that
we
are
poor
.
 
<EOS>
My
friend
's
circumstances
are
indifferent
,
and
so
are
mine
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
have
our
rights
,
widow
,
or
we
must
be
bought
off
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
know
that
,
as
well
as
I
,
so
where
is
the
use
of
talking
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
still
walked
wildly
to
and
fro
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
stopping
abruptly
before
him
,
she
said
:
  
"
Is
he
near
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
.
 
<EOS>
Close
at
hand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
am
lost
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
lost
,
widow
,
"
said
the
blind
man
,
calmly
;
"
only
found
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
call
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
for
the
world
,
"
she
answered
,
with
a
shudder
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"
he
replied
,
crossing
his
legs
again
,
for
he
had
made
as
though
he
would
rise
and
walk
to
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
you
please
,
widow
.
 
<EOS>
His
presence
is
not
necessary
that
I
know
of
.
 
<EOS>
But
both
he
and
I
must
live
;
to
live
,
we
must
eat
and
drink
;
to
eat
and
drink
,
we
must
have
money
:
<EOS>
---
I
say
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
how
pinched
and
destitute
<EOS>
I
am
?
"
<EOS>
she
retorted
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
think
you
do
,
or
can
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
had
eyes
,
and
could
look
around
you
on
this
poor
place
,
you
would
have
pity
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
let
your
heart
be
softened
by
your
own
affliction
,
friend
,
and
have
some
sympathy
with
mine
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
blind
man
snapped
his
fingers
as
he
answered
:
  
"
---
<EOS>
Beside
the
question
,
ma'am
,
beside
the
question
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
the
softest
heart
in
the
world
,
but
I
ca
n't
live
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
Many
a
gentleman
lives
well
upon
a
soft
head
,
who
would
find
a
heart
of
the
same
quality
a
very
great
drawback
.
 
<EOS>
Listen
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
a
matter
of
business
,
with
which
sympathies
and
sentiments
have
nothing
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
As
a
mutual
friend
,
I
wish
to
arrange
it
in
a
satisfactory
manner
,
if
possible
;
and
thus
the
case
stands
.
<EOS>
---
If
you
are
very
poor
now
,
it
's
your
own
choice
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
friends
who
,
in
case
of
need
,
are
always
ready
to
help
you
.
 
<EOS>
My
friend
is
in
a
more
destitute
and
desolate
situation
than
most
men
,
and
,
you
and
he
being
linked
together
in
a
common
cause
,
he
naturally
looks
to
you
to
assist
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
boarded
and
lodged
with
me
a
long
time
(
for
as
I
said
just
now
,
I
am
very
soft
-
hearted
)
,
and
I
quite
approve
of
his
entertaining
this
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
always
had
a
roof
over
your
head
;
he
has
always
been
an
outcast
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
your
son
to
comfort
and
assist
you
;
he
has
nobody
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
The
advantages
must
not
be
all
one
side
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
in
the
same
boat
,
and
we
must
divide
the
ballast
a
little
more
equally
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
about
to
speak
,
but
he
checked
her
,
and
went
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
only
way
of
doing
this
,
is
by
making
up
a
little
purse
now
and
then
for
my
friend
;
and
that
's
what
I
advise
.
 
<EOS>
He
bears
you
no
malice
that
I
know
of
,
<EOS>
ma'am
:
<EOS>
so
little
,
that
although
you
have
treated
him
harshly
more
than
once
,
and
driven
him
,
I
may
say
,
out
of
doors
,
he
has
that
regard
for
you
that
I
believe
even
if
you
disappointed
him
now
,
he
would
consent
to
take
charge
of
your
son
,
and
to
make
a
man
of
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
laid
a
great
stress
on
these
latter
words
,
and
paused
as
if
to
find
out
what
effect
they
had
produced
.
 
<EOS>
She
only
answered
by
her
tears
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
likely
lad
,
"
said
the
blind
man
,
thoughtfully
,
"
for
many
purposes
,
and
not
ill
-
disposed
to
try
his
fortune
in
a
little
change
and
bustle
,
if
I
may
judge
from
what
I
heard
of
his
talk
with
you
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
---
Come
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
my
friend
has
pressing
necessity
for
twenty
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
You
,
who
can
give
up
an
annuity
,
can
get
that
sum
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
pity
you
should
be
troubled
.
 
<EOS>
You
seem
very
comfortable
here
,
and
it
's
worth
that
much
to
remain
so
.
<EOS>
Twenty
pounds
,
widow
,
is
a
moderate
demand
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
where
to
apply
for
it
;
a
post
will
bring
it
you
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Twenty
pounds
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
about
to
answer
him
again
,
but
again
he
stopped
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
say
anything
hastily
;
you
might
be
sorry
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
Think
of
it
a
little
while
.
 
<EOS>
Twenty
pounds
---
of
other
people
's
money
---
how
easy
!
 
<EOS>
Turn
it
over
in
your
mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
in
no
hurry
.
 
<EOS>
Night
's
coming
on
,
and
if
I
do
n't
sleep
here
,
I
shall
not
go
far
.
 
<EOS>
Twenty
pounds
!
<EOS>
Consider
of
it
,
ma'am
,
for
twenty
minutes
;
give
each
pound
a
minute
;
that
's
a
fair
allowance
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
enjoy
the
air
the
while
,
which
is
very
mild
and
pleasant
in
these
parts
.
<EOS>
"
  
With
these
words
he
groped
his
way
to
the
door
,
carrying
his
chair
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
Then
seating
himself
,
under
a
spreading
honeysuckle
,
and
stretching
his
legs
across
the
threshold
so
that
no
person
could
pass
in
or
out
without
his
knowledge
,
he
took
from
his
pocket
a
pipe
,
flint
,
steel
and
tinder
-
box
,
and
began
to
smoke
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
lovely
evening
,
of
that
gentle
kind
,
and
at
that
time
of
year
,
when
the
twilight
is
most
beautiful
.
 
<EOS>
Pausing
now
and
then
to
let
his
smoke
curl
slowly
off
,
and
to
sniff
the
grateful
fragrance
of
the
flowers
,
he
sat
there
at
his
ease
---
as
though
the
cottage
were
his
proper
dwelling
,
and
he
had
held
undisputed
possession
of
it
all
his
life
---
waiting
for
the
widow
's
answer
and
for
Barnaby
's
return
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
46
    
<EOS>
When
Barnaby
returned
with
the
bread
,
the
sight
of
the
pious
old
pilgrim
smoking
his
pipe
and
making
himself
so
thoroughly
at
home
,
appeared
to
surprise
even
him
;
the
more
so
,
as
that
worthy
person
,
instead
of
putting
up
the
loaf
in
his
wallet
as
a
scarce
and
precious
article
,
tossed
it
carelessly
on
the
table
,
and
producing
his
bottle
,
bade
him
sit
down
and
drink
.
  
<EOS>
"
For
I
carry
some
comfort
,
you
see
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Taste
that
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
good
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
water
stood
in
Barnaby
's
eyes
as
he
coughed
from
the
strength
of
the
draught
,
and
answered
in
the
affirmative
.
  
<EOS>
"
Drink
some
more
,
"
said
the
blind
man
;
"
do
n't
be
afraid
of
it
.
<EOS>
You
do
n't
taste
anything
like
that
,
often
,
eh
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Often
!
"
cried
Barnaby
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Too
poor
?
"
returned
the
blind
man
with
a
sigh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ay
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
bad
.
<EOS>
Your
mother
,
poor
soul
,
would
be
happier
if
she
was
richer
,
Barnaby
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
so
I
tell
her
---
the
very
thing
I
told
her
just
before
you
came
to
-
night
,
when
all
that
gold
was
in
the
sky
,
"
said
Barnaby
,
drawing
his
chair
nearer
to
him
,
and
looking
eagerly
in
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
.
 
<EOS>
Is
there
any
way
of
being
rich
,
that
I
could
find
out
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Any
way
!
 
<EOS>
A
hundred
ways
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
?
<EOS>
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
say
so
?
 
<EOS>
What
are
they
?
---
<EOS>
Nay
,
mother
,
it
's
for
your
sake
<EOS>
I
ask
;
not
mine
;
---
for
yours
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
What
are
they
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
blind
man
turned
his
face
,
on
which
there
was
a
smile
of
triumph
,
to
where
the
widow
stood
in
great
distress
;
and
answered
,
  
"
Why
,
they
are
not
to
be
found
out
by
stay
-
at
-
homes
,
my
good
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
stay
-
at
-
homes
!
"
cried
Barnaby
,
plucking
at
his
sleeve
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
not
one
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
there
you
mistake
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
often
out
before
the
sun
,
and
travel
home
when
he
has
gone
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
away
in
the
woods
before
the
day
has
reached
the
shady
places
,
and
am
often
there
when
the
bright
moon
is
peeping
through
the
boughs
,
and
looking
down
upon
the
other
moon
that
lives
in
the
water
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
walk
along
,
I
try
to
find
,
among
the
grass
and
moss
,
some
of
that
small
money
for
which
she
works
so
hard
and
used
to
shed
so
many
tears
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
lie
asleep
in
the
shade
,
I
dream
of
it
---
<EOS>
dream
of
digging
it
up
in
heaps
;
and
spying
it
out
,
hidden
under
bushes
;
and
seeing
it
sparkle
,
as
the
dew
-
drops
do
,
among
the
leaves
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
never
find
it
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
where
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
go
there
,
if
the
journey
were
a
whole
year
long
,
because
I
know
she
would
be
happier
when
I
came
home
and
brought
some
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
Speak
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
listen
to
you
if
you
talk
all
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
blind
man
passed
his
hand
lightly
over
the
poor
fellow
's
face
,
and
finding
that
his
elbows
were
planted
on
the
table
,
that
his
chin
rested
on
his
two
hands
,
that
he
leaned
eagerly
forward
,
and
that
his
whole
manner
expressed
the
utmost
interest
and
anxiety
,
paused
for
a
minute
as
though
he
desired
the
widow
to
observe
this
fully
,
and
then
made
answer
:
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
in
the
world
,
bold
Barnaby
,
the
merry
world
;
not
in
solitary
places
like
those
you
pass
your
time
in
,
but
in
crowds
,
and
where
there
's
noise
and
rattle
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
!
good
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Barnaby
,
rubbing
his
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
I
love
that
.
 
<EOS>
Grip
loves
it
too
.
 
<EOS>
It
suits
us
both
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
brave
!
"
  
"
<EOS>
---
The
kind
of
places
,
"
said
the
blind
man
,
"
that
a
young
fellow
likes
,
and
in
which
a
good
son
may
do
more
for
his
mother
,
and
himself
to
boot
,
in

,
than
he
could
here

---
 
that

,
if
he
had
a
friend
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
hear
this
,
mother
?
"
<EOS>
cried

,
turning
to

with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
tell
me
we
should
n't
heed
it
,
if

lay

.
 
<EOS>
Why
do

heed

so

?
 
<EOS>
Why

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Surely
,
"

,
"
surely
.
 
<EOS>
Have

no

,

?
<EOS>
Is

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"
apart

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
Courage

.
 
<EOS>
We

this
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Now
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Rights
!
 
<EOS>
Do

"

,
"
that
a

---
"
  
"
Why

?
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

?
"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Bah
!
<EOS>
you

"

.
 
<EOS>
Have

,

?
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

have

sight

<EOS>

<EOS>
It

ca

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
You

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
He

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
That

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
"

,
"

<EOS>
"

?
"
  
"
They

the

,
"

,
"
of

.
 
<EOS>
Six

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

---

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"
though

,

.

.
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

week
,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
It

,
that

re

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gone
!
"
<EOS>
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
Which

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

<EOS>
"
You

-

.
 
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
?
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This

!
 
<EOS>
This

---
and

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
 
<EOS>
To
-

.
 
<EOS>
We
must
travel
to
London
;
lose

in
that

---
there
would

some
trace
of

in
any

---
then

,
and
find

.
"
  
<EOS>
Little
persuasion
was
required
to
reconcile

to
anything
that
promised

.
 
<EOS>
In
another
minute
,
he
was
wild
with

;
in
another
,
full
of
grief
at
the

with
his

the

;
in
another
,
wild

;
then
he
was
fearful
of
what
she
had
said
to
prevent
his
wandering
abroad
that
night
,
and
full
of
terrors
and
strange
