.
 
<EOS>
His
light
-
heartedness
in
the
end
surmounted
all
his
other
feelings
,
and
lying
down
in
his
clothes
to
the
end
that
he
might
be
ready
on
the
morrow
,
he
soon
fell
fast
asleep
before
the
poor
turf
fire
.
  
<EOS>
His
mother
did
not
close
her
eyes
,
but
sat
beside
him
,
watching
.
<EOS>
Every
breath
of
wind
sounded
in
her
ears
like
that
dreaded
footstep
at
the
door
,
or
like
that
hand
upon
the
latch
,
and
made
the
calm
summer
night
,
a
night
of
horror
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
the
welcome
day
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
made
the
little
preparations
which
were
needful
for
their
journey
,
and
had
prayed
upon
her
knees
with
many
tears
,
she
roused
Barnaby
,
who
jumped
up
gaily
at
her
summons
.
  
<EOS>
His
clothes
were
few
enough
,
and
to
carry
Grip
was
a
labour
of
love
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
sun
shed
his
earliest
beams
upon
the
earth
,
they
closed
the
door
of
their
deserted
home
,
and
turned
away
.
 
<EOS>
The
sky
was
blue
and
bright
.
 
<EOS>
The
air
was
fresh
and
filled
with
a
thousand
perfumes
.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
looked
upward
,
and
laughed
with
all
his
heart
.
  
<EOS>
But
it
was
a
day
he
usually
devoted
to
a
long
ramble
,
and
one
of
the
dogs
---
the
ugliest
of
them
all
---
came
bounding
up
,
and
jumping
round
him
in
the
fulness
of
his
joy
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
to
bid
him
go
back
in
a
surly
tone
,
and
his
heart
smote
him
while
he
did
so
.
 
<EOS>
The
dog
retreated
;
turned
with
a
half
-
incredulous
,
half
-
imploring
look
;
came
a
little
back
;
and
stopped
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
last
appeal
of
an
old
companion
and
a
faithful
friend
---
 
cast
off
.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
could
bear
no
more
,
and
as
he
shook
his
head
and
waved
his
playmate
home
,
he
burst
into
tears
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
mother
,
mother
,
how
mournful
he
will
be
when
he
scratches
at
the
door
,
and
finds
it
always
shut
!
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
such
a
sense
of
home
in
the
thought
,
<EOS>
that
though
her
own
eyes
overflowed
she
would
not
have
obliterated
the
recollection
of
it
,
either
from
her
own
mind
or
from
his
,
for
the
wealth
of
the
whole
wide
world
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
47
    
<EOS>
In
the
exhaustless
catalogue
of
Heaven
's
mercies
to
mankind
,
the
power
we
have
of
finding
some
germs
of
comfort
in
the
hardest
trials
must
ever
occupy
the
foremost
place
;
not
only
because
it
supports
and
upholds
us
when
we
most
require
to
be
sustained
,
but
because
in
this
source
of
consolation
there
is
something
,
we
have
reason
to
believe
,
of
the
divine
spirit
;
something
of
that
goodness
which
detects
amidst
our
own
evil
doings
,
a
redeeming
quality
;
something
which
,
even
in
our
fallen
nature
,
we
possess
in
common
with
the
angels
;
which
had
its
being
in
the
old
time
when
they
trod
the
earth
,
and
lingers
on
it
yet
,
in
pity
.
  
<EOS>
How
often
,
on
their
journey
,
did
the
widow
remember
with
a
grateful
heart
,
that
out
of
his
deprivation
Barnaby
's
cheerfulness
and
affection
sprung
!
 
<EOS>
How
often
did
she
call
to
mind
that
but
for
that
,
he
might
have
been
sullen
,
morose
,
unkind
,
far
removed
from
her
---
<EOS>
vicious
,
perhaps
,
and
cruel
!
 
<EOS>
How
often
had
she
cause
for
comfort
,
in
his
strength
,
and
hope
,
and
in
his
simple
nature
!
<EOS>
Those
feeble
powers
of
mind
which
rendered
him
so
soon
forgetful
of
the
past
,
save
in
brief
gleams
and
flashes
,
---
even
they
were
a
comfort
now
.
 
<EOS>
The
world
to
him
was
full
of
happiness
;
in
every
tree
,
and
plant
,
and
flower
,
in
every
bird
,
and
beast
,
and
tiny
insect
whom
a
breath
of
summer
wind
laid
low
upon
the
ground
,
he
had
delight
.
 
<EOS>
His
delight
was
hers
;
and
where
many
a
wise
son
would
have
made
her
sorrowful
,
this
poor
light
-
hearted
idiot
filled
her
breast
with
thankfulness
and
love
.
  
<EOS>
Their
stock
of
money
was
low
,
but
from
the
hoard
she
had
told
into
the
blind
man
's
hand
,
the
widow
had
withheld
one
guinea
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
with
the
few
pence
she
possessed
besides
,
was
to
two
persons
of
their
frugal
habits
,
a
goodly
sum
in
bank
.
 
<EOS>
Moreover
they
had
Grip
in
company
;
and
when
they
must
otherwise
have
changed
the
guinea
,
it
was
but
to
make
him
exhibit
outside
an
alehouse
door
,
or
in
a
village
street
,
or
in
the
grounds
or
gardens
of
a
mansion
of
the
better
sort
,
and
scores
who
would
have
given
nothing
in
charity
,
were
ready
to
bargain
for
more
amusement
from
the
talking
bird
.
  
<EOS>
One
day
---
for
they
moved
slowly
,
and
although
they
had
many
rides
in
carts
and
waggons
,
were
on
the
road
a
week
---
<EOS>
Barnaby
,
with
Grip
upon
his
shoulder
and
his
mother
following
,
begged
permission
at
a
trim
lodge
to
go
up
to
the
great
house
,
at
the
other
end
of
the
avenue
,
and
show
his
raven
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
within
was
inclined
to
give
them
admittance
,
and
was
indeed
about
to
do
so
,
when
a
stout
gentleman
with
a
long
whip
in
his
hand
,
and
a
flushed
face
which
seemed
to
indicate
that
he
had
had
his
morning
's
draught
,
rode
up
to
the
gate
,
and
called
in
a
loud
voice
and
with
more
oaths
than
the
occasion
seemed
to
warrant
to
have
it
opened
directly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
hast
thou
got
here
?
"
said
the
gentleman
angrily
,
as
the
man
threw
the
gate
wide
open
,
and
pulled
off
his
hat
,
"
who
are
these
?
<EOS>
Eh
?
<EOS>
art
<EOS>
a
beggar
,
woman
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
widow
answered
with
a
curtsey
,
that
they
were
poor
travellers
.
  
<EOS>
"
Vagrants
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
"
vagrants
and
vagabonds
.
 
<EOS>
Thee
wish
to
be
made
acquainted
with
the
cage
,
dost
thee
---
the
cage
,
the
stocks
,
and
the
whipping
-
post
?
 
<EOS>
Where
dost
come
from
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
told
him
in
a
timid
manner
,
---
for
he
was
very
loud
,
hoarse
,
and
red
-
faced
,
---
and
besought
him
not
to
be
angry
,
for
they
meant
no
harm
,
and
would
go
upon
their
way
that
moment
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
he
too
sure
of
that
<EOS>
,
"
replied
the
gentleman
,
"
we
do
n't
allow
vagrants
to
roam
about
this
place
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
what
thou
want'st
---
stray
linen
drying
on
hedges
,
and
stray
poultry
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
What
hast
got
in
that
basket
,
lazy
hound
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Grip
,
Grip
,
<EOS>
Grip
---
<EOS>
Grip
the
clever
,
Grip
<EOS>
the
wicked
,
Grip
<EOS>
the
knowing
---
Grip
,
Grip
,
Grip
,
"
cried
the
raven
,
whom
Barnaby
had
shut
up
on
the
approach
of
this
stern
personage
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
devil
<EOS>
I
'm
a
devil
<EOS>
I
'm
a
devil
,
Never
say
die
<EOS>
Hurrah
Bow
<EOS>
wow
<EOS>
wow
,
Polly
put
the
kettle
on
<EOS>
we
'll
all
have
tea
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Take
the
vermin
out
,
scoundrel
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
"
and
let
me
see
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
,
thus
condescendingly
addressed
,
produced
his
bird
,
but
not
without
much
fear
and
trembling
,
and
set
him
down
upon
the
ground
;
which
he
had
no
sooner
done
than
Grip
drew
fifty
corks
at
least
,
and
then
began
to
dance
;
at
the
same
time
eyeing
the
gentleman
with
surprising
insolence
of
manner
,
and
screwing
his
head
so
much
on
one
side
that
he
appeared
desirous
of
screwing
it
off
upon
the
spot
.
  
<EOS>
The
cork
-
drawing
seemed
to
make
a
greater
impression
on
the
gentleman
's
mind
,
than
the
raven
's
power
of
speech
,
and
was
indeed
particularly
adapted
to
his
habits
and
capacity
.
 
<EOS>
He
desired
to
have
that
done
again
,
but
despite
his
being
very
peremptory
,
and
notwithstanding
that
Barnaby
coaxed
to
the
utmost
,
Grip
turned
a
deaf
ear
to
the
request
,
and
preserved
a
dead
silence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bring
him
along
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
pointing
to
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
But
Grip
,
who
had
watched
the
action
,
anticipated
his
master
,
by
hopping
on
before
them
;
---
constantly
flapping
his
wings
,
and
screaming
"
cook
!
"
<EOS>
meanwhile
,
as
a
hint
perhaps
that
there
was
company
coming
,
and
a
small
collation
would
be
acceptable
.
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
and
his
mother
walked
on
,
on
either
side
of
the
gentleman
on
horseback
,
who
surveyed
each
of
them
from
time
to
time
in
a
proud
and
coarse
manner
,
and
occasionally
thundered
out
some
question
,
the
tone
of
which
alarmed
Barnaby
so
much
that
he
could
find
no
answer
,
and
,
as
a
matter
of
course
,
could
make
him
no
reply
.
 
<EOS>
On
one
of
these
occasions
,
when
the
gentleman
appeared
disposed
to
exercise
his
horsewhip
,
the
widow
ventured
to
inform
him
in
a
low
voice
and
with
tears
in
her
eyes
,
that
her
son
was
of
weak
mind
.
  
<EOS>
"
An
idiot
,
eh
?
"
said
the
gentleman
,
looking
at
Barnaby
as
he
spoke
.
<EOS>
"
And
how
long
hast
thou
been
an
idiot
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
knows
,
"
was
Barnaby
's
timid
answer
,
pointing
to
his
mother
---
 
<EOS>
"
I
---
always
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
From
his
birth
,
"
said
the
widow
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
it
,
"
cried
the
gentleman
,
"
not
a
bit
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
an
excuse
not
to
work
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
like
flogging
to
cure
that
disorder
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
make
a
difference
in
him
in
ten
minutes
,
I
'll
be
bound
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Heaven
has
made
none
in
more
than
twice
ten
years
,
sir
,
"
said
the
widow
mildly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
do
n't
you
shut
him
up
?
<EOS>
we
pay
enough
for
county
institutions
,
damn
'em
.
 
<EOS>
But
thou'd
rather
drag
him
about
to
excite
charity
---
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
Ay
,
I
know
thee
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Now
,
this
gentleman
had
various
endearing
appellations
among
his
intimate
friends
.
 
<EOS>
By
some
he
was
called
"
a
country
gentleman
of
the
true
school
,
"
by
some
"
a
fine
old
country
gentleman
,
"
by
some
"
a
sporting
gentleman
,
"
by
some
"
a
thorough
-
bred
Englishman
,
"
by
some
"
a
genuine
John
Bull
;
"
but
they
all
agreed
in
one
respect
,
and
that
was
,
that
it
was
a
pity
there
were
not
more
like
him
,
and
that
because
there
were
not
,
the
country
was
going
to
rack
and
ruin
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
in
the
commission
of
the
peace
,
and
could
write
his
name
almost
legibly
;
but
his
greatest
qualifications
were
,
that
he
was
more
severe
with
poachers
,
<EOS>
was
a
better
shot
,
a
harder
rider
,
had
better
horses
,
kept
better
dogs
,
could
eat
more
solid
food
,
drink
more
strong
wine
,
go
to
bed
every
night
more
drunk
and
get
up
every
morning
more
sober
,
than
any
man
in
the
county
.
 
<EOS>
In
knowledge
of
horseflesh
he
was
almost
equal
to
a
farrier
,
in
stable
learning
he
surpassed
his
own
head
groom
,
and
in
gluttony
not
a
pig
on
his
estate
was
a
match
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
seat
in
Parliament
himself
,
but
he
was
extremely
patriotic
,
and
usually
drove
his
voters
up
to
the
poll
with
his
own
hands
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
warmly
attached
to
church
and
state
,
and
never
appointed
to
the
living
in
his
gift
any
but
a
three
-
bottle
man
and
a
first
-
rate
fox
-
hunter
.
 
<EOS>
He
mistrusted
the
honesty
of
all
poor
people
who
could
read
and
write
,
and
had
a
secret
jealousy
of
his
own
wife
(
a
young
lady
whom
he
had
married
for
what
his
friends
called
"
the
good
old
English
reason
,
"
that
her
father
's
property
adjoined
his
own
)
for
possessing
those
accomplishments
in
a
greater
degree
than
himself
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
Barnaby
being
an
idiot
,
and
Grip
a
creature
of
mere
brute
instinct
,
it
would
be
very
hard
to
say
what
this
gentleman
was
.
  
<EOS>
He
rode
up
to
the
door
of
a
handsome
house
approached
by
a
great
flight
of
steps
,
where
a
man
was
waiting
to
take
his
horse
,
and
led
the
way
into
a
large
hall
,
which
,
spacious
as
it
was
,
was
tainted
with
the
fumes
of
last
night
's
stale
debauch
.
 
<EOS>
Greatcoats
,
riding
-
whips
,
bridles
,
top
-
boots
,
spurs
,
and
such
gear
,
were
strewn
about
on
all
sides
,
and
formed
,
with
some
huge
stags
'
antlers
,
and
a
few
portraits
of
dogs
and
horses
,
its
principal
embellishments
.
  
<EOS>
Throwing
himself
into
a
great
chair
(
in
which
,
by
the
bye
,
he
often
snored
away
the
night
,
when
he
had
been
,
according
to
his
admirers
,
a
finer
country
gentleman
than
usual
)
<EOS>
he
bade
the
man
to
tell
his
mistress
to
come
down
:
and
presently
there
appeared
,
a
little
flurried
,
as
it
seemed
,
by
the
unwonted
summons
,
a
lady
much
younger
than
himself
,
who
had
the
appearance
of
being
in
delicate
health
,
and
not
too
happy
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
!
 
<EOS>
Thou'st
<EOS>
no
delight
in
following
the
hounds
as
an
Englishwoman
should
have
,
"
said
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
See
to
this
here
.
 
<EOS>
That
'll
please
thee
perhaps
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
lady
smiled
,
sat
down
at
a
little
distance
from
him
,
and
glanced
at
Barnaby
with
a
look
of
pity
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
an
idiot
,
the
woman
says
,
"
observed
the
gentleman
,
shaking
his
head
;
"
I
do
n't
believe
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
his
mother
?
"
asked
the
lady
.
  
<EOS>
She
answered
yes
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
use
of
asking
HER
?
"
said
the
gentleman
,
thrusting
his
hands
into
his
breeches
pockets
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
'll
tell
thee
so
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
Most
likely
he
's
hired
,
at
so
much
a
day
.
 
<EOS>
There
.
 
<EOS>
Get
on
.
 
<EOS>
Make
him
do
something
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Grip
having
by
this
time
recovered
his
urbanity
,
condescended
,
at
Barnaby
's
solicitation
,
to
repeat
his
various
phrases
of
speech
,
and
to
go
through
the
whole
of
his
performances
with
the
utmost
success
.
 
<EOS>
The
corks
,
and
the
never
say
die
,
afforded
the
gentleman
so
much
delight
that
he
demanded
the
repetition
of
this
part
of
the
entertainment
,
until
Grip
got
into
his
basket
,
and
positively
refused
to
say
another
word
,
good
or
bad
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
too
,
was
much
amused
with
him
;
and
the
closing
point
of
his
obstinacy
so
delighted
her
husband
that
he
burst
into
a
roar
of
laughter
,
and
demanded
his
price
.
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
looked
as
though
he
did
n't
understand
his
meaning
.
<EOS>
Probably
he
did
not
.
  
<EOS>
"
His
price
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
rattling
the
money
in
his
pockets
,
"
what
dost
want
for
him
?
 
<EOS>
How
much
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
not
to
be
sold
,
"
replied
Barnaby
,
shutting
up
the
basket
in
a
great
hurry
,
and
throwing
the
strap
over
his
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
come
away
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thou
seest
how
much
of
an
idiot
he
is
,
book
-
learner
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
looking
scornfully
at
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
can
make
a
bargain
.
<EOS>
What
dost
want
for
him
,
old
woman
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
my
son
's
constant
companion
,
"
said
the
widow
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
not
to
be
sold
,
sir
,
indeed
.
"
  
"
Not
to
be
sold
!
"
cried
the
gentleman
,
growing
ten
times
redder
,
hoarser
,
and
louder
than
before
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
to
be
sold
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
no
,
"
she
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
never
thought
of
parting
with
him
,
sir
,
I
do
assure
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
evidently
about
to
make
a
very
passionate
retort
,
when
a
few
murmured
words
from
his
wife
happening
to
catch
his
ear
,
he
turned
sharply
round
,
and
said
,
"
Eh
?
 
What
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
can
hardly
expect
them
to
sell
the
bird
,
against
their
own
desire
,
"
she
faltered
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
they
prefer
to
keep
him
---
"
  
"
Prefer
to
keep
him
!
"
<EOS>
he
echoed
.
 
<EOS>
"
These
people
,
who
go
tramping
about
the
country
a
-
pilfering
and
vagabondising
on
all
hands
,
prefer
to
keep
a
bird
,
when
a
landed
proprietor
and
a
justice
asks
his
price
!
 
<EOS>
That
old
woman
's
been
to

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Do

no
<EOS>
,
"

"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
<EOS>
No

.
 
<EOS>
No

.
 
<EOS>
If

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
They

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
She

little

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
They

,

,

,

<EOS>
The

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
For

which
night

upon
such

had
already

,
and
the
sun
was

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
48
    
Uncertain
where
to
go
next
,
and
bewildered
by
the
crowd
of
people
who
were
already
astir
,
they
sat
down
in
one
of
the
recesses
on
the
bridge
,
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
They
soon
became
aware
that
the
stream
of
life
was
all
pouring
one
way
,
and
that
a
vast
throng
of
persons
were
crossing
the
river
from
the
Middlesex
to

Surrey

,
in
unusual

and
evident

.
 
<EOS>
They
were
,
for
the
most

,
in
knots
of
two
or
three
,
or
sometimes
half
-
a
-
dozen
;
they
spoke
little
together
---
many
of
them
were
quite
silent
;
and
hurried
on
as
if
they
had
one
absorbing
object
in
view
,
which
was
common
to
them
all
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
surprised
to
see
that
nearly
every
man
in
this
great
concourse
,
which
still
came
pouring
past
,
without
slackening
in
the
least
,
wore
in
his
hat
a
blue

;
and
that
the
chance

who
were
not
so
decorated
,
appeared
timidly
anxious
to
escape
observation
or
attack
,
and
gave
them
the
wall
as
if
they
would
conciliate
them
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
however
,
was
natural
enough
,
considering
their
inferiority
in
point
of
numbers
;
for
the
proportion
of
those
who
wore

,
to
those
who
were
dressed
as
usual
,
was

least

.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no

,
however
:
the
blue
cockades
went
swarming
on
,
passing
each
other
when
they
could
,
and
making
all
the
speed
that
was
possible
in
such

;
and
exchanged
nothing
more
than

,
and
very
often
not

,
with
such
of
the
passers
-
by
as

.
  
<EOS>
At
first
,
the
current
of
people
had
been
confined
to
the
two

,
and
but
a

more

.
 
<EOS>
But
after

,

was

up

great

,
which
,

together
,
and

it

,
moved
but

,
and

sometimes

.
  
<EOS>
After

,

,
and

,
by

,
left
the
bridge

,

that
,
now

,

friends

taken
,

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>
Come

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,
"

.
  
<EOS>

Who

?
"
<EOS>

"

.

"

.
 
<EOS>
He
knows
,
without
your
telling
,
whether
he
wears
the
sign
of
a
loyal
Englishman
or
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
,
trembling
with
impatience
,
cried
,
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
yes
,
yes
,
I
do
,
"
as
he
had
cried
a
dozen
times
already
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
threw
him
a
cockade
,
and
crying
,
"
Make
haste
to
St
George
's
Fields
,
"
ordered
the
coachman
to
drive
on
fast
;
and
left
them
.
  
<EOS>
With
hands
that
trembled
with
his
eagerness
to
fix
the
bauble
in
his
hat
,
Barnaby
was
adjusting
it
as
he
best
could
,
and
hurriedly
replying
to
the
tears
and
entreaties
of
his
mother
,
when
two
gentlemen
passed
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
Observing
them
,
and
seeing
how
Barnaby
was
occupied
,
they
stopped
,
whispered
together
for
an
instant
,
turned
back
,
and
came
over
to
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
are
you
sitting
here
?
"
said
one
of
them
,
who
was
dressed
in
a
plain
suit
of
black
,
wore
long
lank
hair
,
and
carried
a
great
cane
.
<EOS>
"
Why
have
you
not
gone
with
the
rest
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
,
sir
,
"
replied
Barnaby
,
finishing
his
task
,
and
putting
his
hat
on
with
an
air
of
pride
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
there
directly
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Say
"
my
lord
,
"
young
man
,
when
his
lordship
does
you
the
honour
of
speaking
to
you
,
"
said
the
second
gentleman
mildly
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
know
Lord
George
Gordon
when
you
see
him
,
it
's
high
time
you
should
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nay
,
Gashford
,
"
said
Lord
George
,
as
Barnaby
pulled
off
his
hat
again
and
made
him
a
low
bow
,
"
it
's
no
great
matter
on
a
day
like
this
,
which
every
Englishman
will
remember
with
delight
and
pride
.
<EOS>
Put
on
your
hat
,
friend
,
and
follow
us
,
for
you
lag
behind
and
are
late
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
past
ten
now
.
 
<EOS>
Did
n't
you
know
that
the
hour
for
assembling
was
ten
o'clock
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
shook
his
head
and
looked
vacantly
from
one
to
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
might
have
known
it
,
friend
,
"
said
Gashford
,
"
it
was
perfectly
understood
.
 
<EOS>
How
came
you
to
be
so
ill
informed
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
can
not
tell
you
,
sir
,
"
the
widow
interposed
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
of
no
use
to
ask
him
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
but
this
morning
come
from
a
long
distance
in
the
country
,
and
know
nothing
of
these
matters
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
cause
has
taken
a
deep
root
,
and
has
spread
its
branches
far
and
wide
,
"
said
Lord
George
to
his
secretary
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
pleasant
hearing
.
 
<EOS>
I
thank
Heaven
for
it
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Amen
!
"
cried
Gashford
with
a
solemn
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
understand
me
,
my
lord
,
"
said
the
widow
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
but
you
cruelly
mistake
my
meaning
.
 
<EOS>
We
know
nothing
of
these
matters
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
no
desire
or
right
to
join
in
what
you
are
about
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
my
son
,
my
poor
afflicted
son
,
dearer
to
me
than
my
own
life
.
 
<EOS>
In
mercy
's
name
,
my
lord
,
go
your
way
alone
,
and
do
not
tempt
him
into
danger
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
good
woman
,
"
said
Gashford
,
"
how
can
you
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Dear
me
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
by
tempting
,
and
by
danger
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
think
his
lordship
is
a
roaring
lion
,
going
about
and
seeking
whom
he
may
devour
?
 
<EOS>
God
bless
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
my
lord
,
forgive
me
,
"
implored
the
widow
,
laying
both
her
hands
upon
his
breast
,
and
scarcely
knowing
what
she
did
,
or
said
,
in
the
earnestness
of
her
supplication
,
"
but
there
are
reasons
why
you
should
hear
my
earnest
,
mother
's
prayer
,
and
leave
my
son
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
do
!
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
in
his
right
senses
,
he
is
not
,
indeed
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
bad
sign
of
the
wickedness
of
these
times
,
"
said
Lord
George
,
evading
her
touch
,
and
colouring
deeply
,
"
that
those
who
cling
to
the
truth
and
support
the
right
cause
,
are
set
down
as
mad
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
the
heart
to
say
this
of
your
own
son
,
unnatural
mother
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
astonished
at
you
!
"
<EOS>
said
Gashford
,
with
a
kind
of
meek
severity
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
very
sad
picture
of
female
depravity
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
surely
no
appearance
,
"
said
Lord
George
,
glancing
at
Barnaby
,
and
whispering
in
his
secretary
's
ear
,
"
of
being
deranged
?
<EOS>
And
even
if
he
had
,
we
must
not
construe
any
trifling
peculiarity
into
madness
.
 
<EOS>
Which
of
us
"
---
<EOS>
and
here
he
turned
red
again
---
"
would
be
safe
,
if
that
were
made
the
law
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
one
,
"
replied
the
secretary
;
"
in
that
case
,
the
greater
the
zeal
,
the
truth
,
and
talent
;
the
more
direct
the
call
from
above
;
the
clearer
would
be
the
madness
.
 
<EOS>
With
regard
to
this
young
man
,
my
lord
,
"
he
added
,
with
a
lip
that
slightly
curled
as
he
looked
at
Barnaby
,
who
stood
twirling
his
hat
,
and
stealthily
beckoning
them
to
come
away
,
"
he
is
as
sensible
and
self
-
possessed
as
any
one
I
ever
saw
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
desire
to
make
one
of
this
great
body
?
"
said
Lord
George
,
addressing
him
;
"
and
intended
to
make
one
,
did
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
---
yes
,
"
said
Barnaby
,
with
sparkling
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
I
did
!
<EOS>
I
told
her
so
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
see
,
"
replied
Lord
George
,
with
a
reproachful
glance
at
the
unhappy
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
so
.
 
<EOS>
Follow
me
and
this
gentleman
,
and
you
shall
have
your
wish
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
kissed
his
mother
tenderly
on
the
cheek
,
and
bidding
her
be
of
good
cheer
,
for
their
fortunes
were
both
made
now
,
did
as
he
was
desired
.
 
<EOS>
She
,
poor
woman
,
followed
too
---
with
how
much
fear
and
grief
it
would
be
hard
to
tell
.
  
<EOS>
They
passed
quickly
through
the
Bridge
Road
,
where
the
shops
were
all
shut
up
(
for
the
passage
of
the
great
crowd
and
the
expectation
of
their
return
had
alarmed
the
tradesmen
for
their
goods
and
windows
)
,
and
where
,
in
the
upper
stories
,
all
the
inhabitants
were
congregated
,
looking
down
into
the
street
below
,
with
faces
variously
expressive
of
alarm
,
of
interest
,
expectancy
,
and
indignation
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
these
applauded
,
and
some
hissed
;
but
regardless
of
these
interruptions
---
for
the
noise
of
a
vast
congregation
of
people
at
a
little
distance
,
sounded
in
his
ears
like
the
roaring
of
the
sea
---
Lord
George
Gordon
quickened
his
pace
,
and
presently
arrived
before
St
George
's
Fields
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
really
fields
at
that
time
,
and
of
considerable
extent
.
<EOS>
Here
an
immense
multitude
was
collected
,
bearing
flags
of
various
kinds
and
sizes
,
but
all
of
the
same
colour
---
blue
,
like
the
cockades
---
some
sections
marching
to
and
fro
in
military
array
,
and
others
drawn
up
in
circles
,
squares
,
and
lines
.
 
<EOS>
A
large
portion
,
both
of
the
bodies
which
paraded
the
ground
,
and
of
those
which
remained
stationary
,
were
occupied
in
singing
hymns
or
psalms
.
<EOS>
With
whomsoever
this
originated
,
it
was
well
done
;
for
the
sound
of
so
many
thousand
voices
in
the
air
must
have
stirred
the
heart
of
any
man
within
him
,
and
could
not
fail
to
have
a
wonderful
effect
upon
enthusiasts
,
however
mistaken
.
  
<EOS>
Scouts
had
been
posted
in
advance
of
the
great
body
,
to
give
notice
of
their
leader
's
coming
.
 
<EOS>
These
falling
back
,
the
word
was
quickly
passed
through
the
whole
host
,
and
for
a
short
interval
there
ensued
a
profound
and
deathlike
silence
,
during
which
the
mass
was
so
still
and
quiet
,
that
the
fluttering
of
a
banner
caught
the
eye
,
and
became
a
circumstance
of
note
.
 
<EOS>
Then
they
burst
into
a
tremendous
shout
,
into
another
,
and
another
;
and
the
air
seemed
rent
and
shaken
,
as
if
by
the
discharge
of
cannon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gashford
!
"
cried
Lord
George
,
pressing
his
secretary
's
arm
tight
within
his
own
,
and
speaking
with
as
much
emotion
in
his
voice
,
as
in
his
altered
face
,
<EOS>
"
I
arn
called
indeed
,
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
and
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
the
leader
of
a
host
.
 
<EOS>
If
they
summoned
me
at
this
moment
with
one
voice
to
lead
them
on
to
death
,
I
'd
do
it
---
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
fall
first
myself
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
proud
sight
,
"
said
the
secretary
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
noble
day
for
England
,
and
for
the
great
cause
throughout
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
Such
homage
,
my
lord
,
as
I
,
an
humble
but
devoted
man
,
can
render
---
"
  
"
What
are
you
doing
?
"
<EOS>
cried
his
master
,
catching
him
by
both
hands
;
for
he
had
made
a
show
of
kneeling
at
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
unfit
me
,
dear
Gashford
,
for
the
solemn
duty
of
this
glorious
day
---
"
the
tears
stood
in
the
eyes
of
the
poor
gentleman
as
he
said
the
words
.
<EOS>
---
"
Let
us
go
among
them
;
we
have
to
find
a
place
in
some
division
for
this
new
recruit
---
give
me
your
hand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Gashford
slid
his
cold
insidious
palm
into
his
master
's
grasp
,
and
so
,
hand
in
hand
,
and
followed
still
by
Barnaby
and
by
his
mother
too
,
they
mingled
with
the
concourse
.
  
<EOS>
They
had
by
this
time
taken
to
their
singing
again
,
and
as
their
leader
passed
between
their
ranks
,
they
raised
their
voices
to
their
utmost
.
 
<EOS>
Many
of
those
who
were
banded
together
to
support
the
religion
of
their
country
,
even
unto
death
,
had
never
heard
a
hymn
or
psalm
in
all
their
lives
.
 
<EOS>
But
these
fellows
having
for
the
most
part
strong
lungs
,
and
being
naturally
fond
of
singing
,
chanted
any
ribaldry
or
nonsense
that
occurred
to
them
,
feeling
pretty
certain
that
it
would
not
be
detected
in
the
general
chorus
,
and
not
caring
much
if
it
were
.
 
<EOS>
Many
of
these
voluntaries
were
sung
under
the
very
nose
of
Lord
George
Gordon
,
who
,
quite
unconscious
of
their
burden
,
passed
on
with
his
usual
stiff
and
solemn
deportment
,
very
much
edified
and
delighted
by
the
pious
conduct
of
his
followers
.
  
<EOS>
So
they
went
on
and
on
,
up
this
line
,
down
that
<EOS>
,
round
the
exterior
of
this
circle
,
and
on
every
side
of
that
hollow
square
;
and
still
there
were
lines
,
and
squares
,
and
circles
out
of
number
to
review
.
<EOS>
The
day
being
now
intensely
hot
,
and
the
sun
striking
down
his
fiercest
rays
upon
the
field
,
those
who
carried
heavy
banners
began
to
grow
faint
and
weary
;
most
of
the
number
assembled
were
fain
to
pull
off
their
neckcloths
,
and
throw
their
coats
and
waistcoats
open
;
and
some
,
towards
the
centre
,
quite
overpowered
by
the
excessive
heat
,
which
was
of
course
rendered
more
unendurable
by
the
multitude
around
them
,
lay
down
upon
the
grass
,
and
offered
all
they
had
about
them
for
a
drink
of
water
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
no
man
left
the
ground
,
not
even
of
those
who
were
so
distressed
;
still
Lord
George
,
streaming
from
every
pore
,
went
on
with
Gashford
;
and
still
Barnaby
and
his
mother
followed
close
behind
them
.
  
<EOS>
They
had
arrived
at
the
top
of
a
long
line
of
some
eight
hundred
men
in
single
file
,
and
Lord
George
had
turned
his
head
to
look
back
,
when
a
loud
cry
of
recognition
---
in
that
peculiar
and
half
-
stifled
tone
which
a
voice
has
,
when
it
is
raised
in
the
open
air
and
in
the
midst
of
a
great
concourse
of
persons
---
was
heard
,
and
a
man
stepped
with
a
shout
of
laughter
from
the
rank
,
and
smote
Barnaby
on
the
shoulders
with
his
heavy
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
now
!
"
he
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
Barnaby
Rudge
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
where
have
you
been
hiding
for
these
hundred
years
?
<EOS>
"
  
Barnaby
had
been
thinking
within
himself
that
the
smell
of
the
trodden
grass
brought
back
his
old
days
at
cricket
,
when
he
was
a
young
boy
and
played
on
Chigwell
Green
.
 
<EOS>
Confused
by
this
sudden
and
boisterous
address
,
he
stared
in
a
bewildered
manner
at
the
man
,
and
could
scarcely
say
"
What
!
<EOS>
Hugh
!
<EOS>
"
  
"
Hugh
!
"
echoed
the
other
;
"
ay
,
Hugh
---
Maypole
Hugh
!
 
<EOS>
You
remember
my
dog
?
 
<EOS>
He
's
alive
now
,
and
will
know
you
,
I
warrant
.
 
<EOS>
What
,
you
wear
the
colour
,
do
you
?
 
<EOS>
Well
done
!
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
"
  
"
You
know
this
young
man
,
I
see
,
"
said
Lord
George
.
  
<EOS>
"
Know
him
,
my
lord
!
<EOS>
as
well
as
I
know
my
own
right
hand
.
 
<EOS>
My
captain
knows
him
.
 
<EOS>
We
all
know

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
take
him
into
your

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
has
n't
in
it
<EOS>
a
better
,
nor
a

,
nor
a
more

,
than
Barnaby
Rudge
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Show
me
the
man
who
says
it
has
!
<EOS>
Fall
in
,
Barnaby
.
 
<EOS>
He
shall

,
my
lord
,
between

and
Dennis
;
and
he
shall
carry
,
"
he

,
taking
a

a

who

,
"
the
gayest
silken

in
this
valiant

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
the
name
of
God
,
no
!
"
shrieked
the
widow
,
darting
forward
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Barnaby
---
my
lord
---
see
---
he
'll
come
back
---
Barnaby
---
Barnaby
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Women
in
the
field
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
stepping
between
them
,
and
holding
her
off
.
 
<EOS>
"
Holloa
!
 
<EOS>
My
captain
there
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
here
?
"
cried
Simon
Tappertit
,
bustling
up
in
a
great
heat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
call
this
order
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
like
it
,
captain
,
"
answered
Hugh
,
still
holding
her
back
with
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
against
all
orders
.
 
<EOS>
Ladies
are
carrying
off
our
gallant
soldiers
from
their
duty
.
 
<EOS>
The
word
of
command
,
captain
!
 
<EOS>
They
're
filing
off
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Quick
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Close
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Simon
,
with
the
whole
power
of
his
lungs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Form
!
March
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
thrown
to
the
ground
;
the
whole
field
was
in
motion
;
Barnaby
was
whirled
away
into
the
heart
of
a
dense
mass
of
men
,
and
she
saw
him
no
more
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
49
    
<EOS>
The
mob
had
been
divided
from
its
first
assemblage
into
four
divisions
;
the
London
,
the
Westminster
,
the
Southwark
,
and
the
Scotch
.
 
<EOS>
Each
of
these
divisions
being
subdivided
into
various
bodies
,
and
these
bodies
being
drawn
up
in
various
forms
and
figures
,
the
general
arrangement
was
,
except
to
the
few
chiefs
and
leaders
,
as
unintelligible
as
the
plan
of
a
great
battle
to
the
meanest
soldier
in
the
field
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
without
its
method
,
however
;
for
,
in
a
very
short
space
of
time
after
being
put
in
motion
,
the
crowd
had
resolved
itself
into
three
great
parties
,
and
were
prepared
,
as
had
been
arranged
,
to
cross
the
river
by
different
bridges
,
and
make
for
the
House
of
Commons
in
separate
detachments
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
head
of
that
division
which
had
Westminster
Bridge
for
its
approach
to
the
scene
of
action
,
Lord
George
Gordon
took
his
post
;
with
Gashford
at
his
right
hand
,
and
sundry
ruffians
,
of
most
unpromising
appearance
,
forming
a
kind
of
staff
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
conduct
of
a
second
party
,
whose
route
lay
by
Blackfriars
,
was
entrusted
to
a
committee
of
management
,
including
perhaps
a
dozen
men
:
while
the
third
,
which
was
to
go
by
London
Bridge
,
and
through
the
main
streets
,
in
order
that
their
numbers
and
their
serious
intentions
might
be
the
better
known
and
appreciated
by
the
citizens
,
were
led
by
Simon
Tappertit
(
assisted
by
a
few
subalterns
,
selected
from
the
Brotherhood
of
United
Bulldogs
)
,
Dennis
<EOS>
the
hangman
,
Hugh
,
and
some
others
.
  
<EOS>
The
word
of
command
being
given
,
each
of
these
great
bodies
took
the
road
assigned
to
it
,
and
departed
on
its
way
,
in
perfect
order
and
profound
silence
.
 
<EOS>
That
which
went
through
the
City
greatly
exceeded
the
others
in
number
,
and
was
of
such
prodigious
extent
that
when
the
rear
began
to
move
,
the
front
was
nearly
four
miles
in
advance
,
notwithstanding
that
the
men
marched
three
abreast
and
followed
very
close
upon
each
other
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
head
of
this
party
,
in
the
place
where
Hugh
,
in
the
madness
of
his
humour
,
had
stationed
him
,
and
walking
between
that
dangerous
companion
and
the
hangman
,
went
Barnaby
;
as
many
a
man
among
the
thousands
who
looked
on
that
day
afterwards
remembered
well
.
 
<EOS>
Forgetful
of
all
other
things
in
the
ecstasy
of
the
moment
,
his
face
flushed
and
his
eyes
sparkling
with
delight
,
heedless
of
the
weight
of
the
great
banner
he
carried
,
and
mindful
only
of
its
flashing
in
the
sun
and
rustling
in
the
summer
breeze
,
on
he
went
,
proud
,
happy
,
elated
past
all
telling
:
---
the
only
light
-
hearted
,
undesigning
creature
,
in
the
whole
assembly
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
this
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Hugh
,
as
they
passed
through
the
crowded
streets
,
and
looked
up
at
the
windows
which
were
thronged
with
spectators
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
have
all
turned
out
to
see
our
flags
and
streamers
?
 
<EOS>
Eh
,
Barnaby
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
Barnaby
's
the
greatest
man
of
all
the
pack
!
 
<EOS>
His
flag
's
the
largest
of
the
lot
,
the
brightest
too
.
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
in
the
show
,
like
Barnaby
.
 
<EOS>
All
eyes
are
turned
on
him
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
"
  
"
Do
n't
make
that
din
,
brother
,
"
growled

hangman
,
glancing

no

at
Barnaby
as

:
"
<EOS>
I
hope

do

nothing

done
,
but

there

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

action
<EOS>
I

?
 
<EOS>
You
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

?
 
<EOS>
Why

?
<EOS>
"
  
Barnaby

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
,

.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
old

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

;
"
<EOS>
but
I
wish
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
See

?
"

Dennis
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
an't
in
love
<EOS>
I
hope
,
brother
?
 
<EOS>
That
an't
the
sort

thing

,

.
 
<EOS>
We
must
n't
have
no

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She

,
eh

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
Would

?
 
<EOS>
She
'd
cry
for
joy
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
Where
CAN

?
 
<EOS>
She

,

what

SHE
'S

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
We

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,

,
"

,
"
he
's
only

of

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Of

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
His
mother
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
have

combined

this
here

,
and

this
here
memorable

,
to

mothers
!
"
<EOS>
growled

with

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
notion
of
a
man
's
sweetheart
's
bad

,
but
a
man
's
mother
!
"
<EOS>
---
and
here
his
disgust
was
so
extreme
that
he
spat
upon

ground
,
and
could
say
no
more
.
  
<EOS>
"
Barnaby
's
right
,
"
cried
Hugh
with
a

,
"
and
I
say
it
.
 
<EOS>
Lookee
,
bold
lad
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
's
not
here
to
see
,
it
's
because
I
've
provided
for

,
and
sent
half
-
a
-
dozen

,
every

with

blue
flag
(
but

)
,

,
in
state
,
to

house
all

with

,
and
everything
else
you
please
,
where
she
'll
wait
till
you
come
,
and
want
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
"
said
Barnaby
,
his
face
beaming
with
delight
:
"
have
you
indeed
?
 
<EOS>
That
's
a
good
hearing
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
fine
!
 
<EOS>
Kind
Hugh
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
nothing
to
what
will
come
,
bless
you
,
"
retorted
Hugh
,
with
a
wink
at
Dennis
,
who
regarded
his
new
companion
in
arms
with
great

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
indeed
?
"
cried
Barnaby
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
at
all
,
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Money
,
cocked
hats
and
feathers
,
red
coats
and
gold
lace
;
all
the
fine
things
there
are
,
ever
were
,
or
will
be
;
will
belong
to
us
if
we
are
true
to
that
noble
gentleman
---
 
the
best
man
in
the
world
---
carry
our
flags
for
a
few
days
,
and
keep
'em
safe
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
we
've
got
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
?
"
cried
Barnaby
with
glistening

,
as
he
clutched
his
pole
the
tighter
;
"
I
warrant
you
<EOS>
I
keep
this
one
safe
,
then
.
<EOS>
You
have
put
it
in
good
hands
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
me
,
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
shall
wrest
this
flag
away
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
said
!
"
cried
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Nobly
said
!
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
old
stout
Barnaby
,
that
I
have
climbed
and
leaped
with
,
many
and
many
a
day
<EOS>
---
I
knew
I
was
not
mistaken
in
Barnaby
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
see
,
man
,
"
he
added
in
a
whisper
,
as
he
slipped
to
the
other
side
of
Dennis
,
"
that
the
lad
's
a
natural
,
and
can
be
got
to
do
anything
,
if
you
take
him
the
right
way
?
 
<EOS>
Letting
alone
<EOS>
the
fun
<EOS>
he
is
,
he
's
worth
a
dozen
men
,
in
earnest
,
as
you
'd
find
if
you
tried
a
fall
with
him
.
<EOS>
Leave
him
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
soon
see
whether
he
's
of
use
or
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dennis
received
these
explanatory
remarks
with
many
nods
and
winks
,
and
softened
his
behaviour
towards
Barnaby
from
that
moment
.
<EOS>
Hugh
,
laying
his
finger
on
his
nose
,
stepped
back
into
his
former
place
,
and
they
proceeded
in
silence
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
between
two
and
three
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
when
the
three
great
parties
met
at
Westminster
,
and
,
uniting
into
one
huge
mass
,
raised
a
tremendous
shout
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
not
only
done
in
token
of
their
presence
,
but
as
a
signal
to
those
on
whom
the
task
devolved
,
that
it
was
time
to
take
possession
of
the
lobbies
of
both
Houses
,
and
of
the
various
avenues
of
approach
,
and
of
the
gallery
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
To
the
last
-
named
place
,
Hugh
and
Dennis
,
still
with
their
pupil
between
them
,
rushed
straightway
;
Barnaby
having
given
his
flag
into
the
hands
of
one
of
their
own
party
,
who
kept
them
at
the
outer
door
.
 
<EOS>
Their
followers
pressing
on
behind
,
they
were
borne
as
on
a
great
wave
to
the
very
doors
of
the
gallery
,
whence
it
was
impossible
to
retreat
,
even
if
they
had
been
so
inclined
,
by
reason
of
the
throng
which
choked
up
the
passages
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
familiar
expression
in
describing
a
great
crowd
,
that
a
person
might
have
walked
upon
the
people
's
heads
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
case
it
was
actually
done
;
for
a
boy
who
had
by
some
means
got
among
the
concourse
,
and
was
in
imminent
danger
of
suffocation
,
climbed
to
the
shoulders
of
a
man
beside
him
and
walked
upon
the
people
's
hats
and
heads
into
the
open
street
;
traversing
in
his
passage
the
whole
length
of
two
staircases
and
a
long
gallery
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
the
swarm
without
less
dense
;
for
a
basket
which
had
been
tossed
into
the
crowd
,
was
jerked
from
head
to
head
,
and
shoulder
to
shoulder
,
and
went
spinning
and
whirling
on
above
them
,
until
it
was
lost
to
view
,
without
ever
once
falling
in
among
them
or
coming
near
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
Through
this
vast
throng
,
sprinkled
doubtless
here
and
there
with
honest
zealots
,
but
composed
for
the
most
part
of
the
very
scum
and
refuse
of
London
,
whose
growth
was
fostered
by
bad
criminal
laws
,
bad
prison
regulations
,
and
the
worst
conceivable
police
,
such
of
the
members
of
both
Houses
of
Parliament
as
had
not
taken
the
precaution
to
be
already
at
their
posts
,
were
compelled
to
fight
and
force
their
way
.
 
<EOS>
Their
carriages
were
stopped
and
broken
;
the
wheels
wrenched
off
;
the
glasses
shivered
to
atoms
;
the
panels
beaten
in
;
drivers
,
footmen
,
and
masters
,
pulled
from
their
seats
and
rolled
in
the
mud
.
 
<EOS>
Lords
,
commoners
,
and
reverend
bishops
,
with
little
distinction
of
person
or
party
,
were
kicked
and
pinched
and
hustled
;
passed
from
hand
to
hand
through
various
stages
of
ill
-
usage
;
and
sent
to
their
fellow
-
senators
at
last
with
their
clothes
hanging
in
ribands
about
them
,
their
bagwigs
torn
off
,
themselves
speechless
and
breathless
,
and
their
persons
covered
with
the
powder
which
had
been
cuffed
and
beaten
out
of
their
hair
.
<EOS>
One
lord
was
so
long
in
the
hands
of
the
populace
,
that
the
Peers
as
a
body
resolved
to
sally
forth
and
rescue
him
,
and
were
in
the
act
of
doing
so
,
when
he
happily
appeared
among
them
covered
with
dirt
and
bruises
,
and
hardly
to
be
recognised
by
those
who
knew
him
best
.
 
<EOS>
The
noise
and
uproar
were
on
the
increase
every
moment
.
 
<EOS>
The
air
was
filled
with
execrations
,
hoots
,
and
howlings
.
 
<EOS>
The
mob
raged
and
roared
,
like
a
mad
monster
as
it
was
,
unceasingly
,
and
each
new
outrage
served
to
swell
its
fury
.
  
<EOS>
Within
doors
,
matters
were
even
yet
more
threatening
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
George
---
 
preceded
by
a
man
who
carried
the
immense
petition
on
a
porter
's
knot
through
the
lobby
to
the
door
of
the
House
of
Commons
,
where
it
was
received
by
two
officers
of
the
house
who
rolled
it
up
to
the
table
ready
for
presentation
---
had
taken
his
seat
at
an
early
hour
,
before
the
Speaker
went
to
prayers
.
 
<EOS>
His
followers
pouring
in
at
the
same
time
,
the
lobby
and
all
the
avenues
were
immediately
filled
,
as
we
have
seen
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
the
members
were
not
only
attacked
in
their
passage
through
the
streets
,
but
were
set
upon
within
the
very
walls
of
Parliament
;
while
the
tumult
,
both
within
and
without
,
was
so
great
,
that
those
who
attempted
to
speak
could
scarcely
hear
their
own
voices
:
far
less
,
consult
upon
the
course
it
would
be
wise
to
take
in
such
extremity
,
or
animate
each
other
to
dignified
and
firm
resistance
.
 
<EOS>
So
sure
as
any
member
,
just
arrived
,
with
dress
disordered
and
dishevelled
hair
,
came
struggling
through
the
crowd
in
the
lobby
,
it
yelled
and
screamed
in
triumph
;
and
when
the
door
of
the
House
,
partially
and
cautiously
opened
by
those
within
for
his
admission
,
gave
them
a
momentary
glimpse
of
the
interior
,
they
grew
more
wild
and
savage
,
like
beasts
at
the
sight
of
prey
,
and
made
a
rush
against
the
portal
which
strained
its
locks
and
bolts
in
their
staples
,
and
shook
the
very
beams
.
  
<EOS>
The
strangers
'
gallery
,
which
was
immediately
above
the
door
of
the
House
,
had
been
ordered
to
be
closed
on
the
first
rumour
of
disturbance
,
and
was
empty
;
save
that
now
<EOS>
and
then
Lord
George
took
his
seat
there
,
for
the
convenience
of
coming
to
the
head
of
the
stairs
which
led
to
it
,
and
repeating
to
the
people
what
had
passed
within
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
on
these
stairs
that
Barnaby
,
Hugh
,
and
Dennis
were
posted
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
two
flights
,
short
,
steep
,
and
narrow
,
running
parallel
to
each
other
,
and
leading
to
two
little
doors
communicating
with
a
low
passage
which
opened
on
the
gallery
.
<EOS>
Between
them
was
a
kind
of
well
,
or
unglazed
skylight
,
for
the
admission
of
light
and
air
into
the
lobby
,
which
might
be
some
eighteen
or
twenty
feet
below
.
  
<EOS>
Upon
one
of
these
little
staircases
---
not
that
at
the
head
of
which
Lord
George
appeared
from
time
to
time
,
but
the
other
---
Gashford
stood
with
his
elbow
on
the
bannister
,
and
his
cheek
resting
on
his
hand
,
with
his
usual
crafty
aspect
.
 
<EOS>
Whenever
he
varied
this
attitude
in
the
slightest
degree
---
so
much
as
by
the
gentlest
motion
of
his
arm
---
the
uproar
was
certain
to
increase
,
not
merely
there
,
but
in
the
lobby
below
;
from
which
place
no
doubt
,
some
man
who
acted
as
fugleman
to
the
rest
,
was
constantly
looking
up
and
watching
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Order
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
in
a
voice
which
made
itself
heard
even
above
the
roar
and
tumult
,
as
Lord
George
appeared
at
the
top
of
the
staircase
.
 
<EOS>
"
News
!
 
<EOS>
News
from
my
lord
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
noise
continued
,
notwithstanding
his
appearance
,
until
Gashford
looked
round
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
silence
immediately
---
even
among
the
people
in
the
passages
without
,
and
on
the
other
staircases
,
who
could
neither
see
nor
hear
,
but
to
whom
,
notwithstanding
,
the
signal
was
conveyed
with
marvellous
rapidity
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
"
said
Lord
George
,
who
was
very
pale
and
agitated
,
we
must
be
firm
.
 
<EOS>
They
talk
of
delays
,
but
we
must
have
no
delays
.
<EOS>
They
talk
of
taking
your
petition
into
consideration
next
Tuesday
,
but
we
must
have
it
considered
now
.
 
<EOS>
Present
appearances
look
bad
for
our
success
,
but
we
must
succeed
and
will
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
must
succeed
and
will
!
"
echoed
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
among
their
shouts
and
cheers
and
other
cries
,
he
bowed
to
them
and
retired
,
and
presently
came
back
again
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
another
gesture
from
Gashford
,
and
a
dead
silence
directly
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
,
"
he
said
,
this
time
,
"
that
we
have
little
reason
,
gentlemen
,
to
hope
for
any
redress
from
the
proceedings
of
Parliament
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
must
redress
our
own
grievances
<EOS>
,
we
must
meet
again
,
we
must
put
our
trust
in
Providence
,
and
it
will
bless
our
endeavours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
speech
being
a
little
more
temperate
than
the
last
,
was
not
so
favourably
received
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
noise
and
exasperation
were
at
their
height
,
he
came
back
once
more
,
and
told
them
that
the
alarm
had
gone
forth
for
many
miles
round
;
that
when
the
King
heard
of
their
assembling
together
in
that
great
body
,
he
had
no
doubt
,
His
Majesty
would
send
down
private
orders
to
have
their
wishes
complied
with
;
and
---
with
the
manner
of
his
speech
as
childish
,
irresolute
,
and
uncertain
as
his
matter
---
was
proceeding
in
this
strain
,
when
two
gentlemen
suddenly
appeared
at
the
door
where
he
stood
,
and
pressing
past
him
and
coming
a
step
or
two
lower
down
upon
the
stairs
,
confronted
the
people
.
  
<EOS>
The
boldness
of
this
action
quite
took
them
by
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
not
the
less
disconcerted
,
<EOS>
when
one
of
the
gentlemen
,
turning
to
Lord
George
,
spoke
thus
---
in
a
loud
voice
that
they
might
hear
him
well
,
but
quite
coolly
and
collectedly
:
  
"
You
may
tell
these
people
,
if
you
please
,
my
lord
,
that
I
am
General
Conway
of
whom
they
have
heard
;
and
that
I
oppose
this
petition
,
and
all
their
proceedings
,
and
yours
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
soldier
,
you
may
tell
them
,
and
I
will
protect
the
freedom
of
this
place
with
my
sword
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
,
my
lord
,
that
the
members
of
this
House
are
all
in
arms
to
-
day
;
you
know
that
the
entrance
to
it
is
a
narrow
one
;
you
can
not
be
ignorant
that
there
are
men
within
these
walls
who
are
determined
to
defend
that
pass
to
the
last
,
and
<EOS>
before
whom
many
lives
must
fall
if
your
adherents
persevere
.
 
<EOS>
Have
a
care
what
you
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
my
Lord
George
,
"
said
the
other
gentleman
,
addressing
him
in
like
manner
,
"
I
desire
them
to
hear
this
,
from
me
---
<EOS>
Colonel
Gordon
---
 
your
near
relation
.
 
<EOS>
If
a
man
among
this
crowd
,
whose
uproar
strikes
us
deaf
,
crosses
the
threshold
of
the
House
of
Commons
,
I
swear
to
run
my
sword
that
moment
---
not
into
his
,
but
into
your
body
!
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
,
they
stepped
back
again
,
keeping
their
faces
towards
the
crowd
;
took
each
an
arm
of
the
misguided
nobleman
;
drew
him
into
the
passage
,
and
shut
the
door
;
which
they
directly
locked
and
fastened
on
the
inside
.
  
<EOS>
This
was
so
quickly
done
,
and
the
demeanour
of
both
gentlemen
---
who
were
not
young
men
either
---
was
so
gallant
and
resolute
,
that
the
crowd
faltered
and
stared
at
each
other
with
irresolute
and
timid
looks
.
 
<EOS>
Many
tried
to
turn
towards
the
door
;
some
of
the
faintest
-
hearted
cried
they
had
best
go
back
,
and
called
to
those
behind
to
give
way
;
and
the
panic
and
confusion
were
increasing
rapidly
,
when
Gashford
whispered
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
now
!
"
<EOS>
Hugh
roared
aloud
,
turning
towards
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
go
back
?
<EOS>
Where
can
you
do
better
than
here
,
boys
!
 
<EOS>
One
good
rush
against
these
doors
and
one
below
at
the
same
time
,
will
do
the
business
.
<EOS>
Rush
on
,
then
!
 
<EOS>
As
to
the
door
below
,
let
those
stand
back
who
are
afraid
.
 
<EOS>
Let
those
who
are
not
afraid
,
try
who
shall
be
the
first
to
pass
it
.
 
<EOS>
Here
goes
!
 
<EOS>
Look
out
down
there
!
"
  
<EOS>
Without
the
delay
of
an
instant
,
he
threw
himself
headlong
over
the
bannisters
into
the
lobby
below
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
hardly
touched
the
ground
when
Barnaby
was
at
his
side
.
 
<EOS>
The
chaplain
's
assistant
,
and
some
members
who
were
imploring
the
people
to
retire
,
immediately
withdrew
;
and
then
,
with
a
great
shout
,
both
crowds
threw
themselves
against
the
doors
pell
-
mell
,
and
besieged
the
House
in
earnest
.
  
<EOS>
At
that
moment
,
when
a
second
onset
must
have
brought
them
into
collision
with
those
who
stood
on
the
defensive
within
,
in
which
case
great
loss
of
life
and
bloodshed
would
inevitably
have
ensued
,
---
the
hindmost
portion
of
the
crowd
gave
way
,
and
the
rumour
spread
from
mouth
to
mouth
that
a
messenger
had
been
despatched
by
water
for
the
military
,
who
were
forming
in
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
Fearful
of
sustaining
a
charge
in
the
narrow
passages
in
which
they
were
so
closely
wedged
together
,
the
throng
poured
out
as
impetuously
as
they
had
flocked
in
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
whole
stream
turned
at
once
,
Barnaby
and
Hugh
went
with
it
:
and
<EOS>
so
,
fighting
and
struggling
and
trampling
on
fallen
men
and
being
trampled
on
in
turn
themselves
,
they
and
the
whole
mass
floated
by
degrees
into
the
open
street
,
where
a
large
detachment
of
the
Guards
,
both
horse
and
foot
,
came
hurrying
up
;
clearing
the
ground
before
them
so
rapidly
that
the
people
seemed
to
melt
away
as
they
advanced
.
  
<EOS>
The
word
of
command
to
halt
being
given
,
the
soldiers
formed
across
the
street
;
the
rioters
,
breathless
and
exhausted
with
their
late
exertions
,
formed
likewise
,
though
in
a
very
irregular
and
disorderly
manner
.
 
<EOS>
The
commanding
officer
rode
hastily
into
the
open
space
between
the
two
bodies
,
accompanied
by
a
magistrate
and
an
officer
of
the
House
of
Commons
,
for
whose
accommodation
a
couple
of
troopers
had
hastily
dismounted
.
 
<EOS>
The
Riot
Act
was
read
,
but
not
a
man
stirred
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
first
rank
of
the
insurgents
,
Barnaby
and
Hugh
stood
side
by
side
.
 
<EOS>
Somebody
had
thrust
into
Barnaby
's
hands
when
he
came
out
into
the
street
,
his
precious
flag
;
which
,
being
now
rolled
up
and
tied
round
the
pole
,
looked
like
a
giant
quarter
-
staff
as
he
grasped
it
firmly
and
stood
upon
his
guard
.
 
<EOS>
If
ever
man
believed
with
his
whole
heart
and
soul
that
he
was
engaged
in
a
just
cause
,
and
that
he
was
bound
to
stand
by
his
leader
to
the
last
,
poor
Barnaby
believed
it
of
himself
and
Lord
George
Gordon
.
  
<EOS>
After
an
ineffectual
attempt
to
make
himself
heard
,
the
magistrate
gave
the
word
and
the
Horse
Guards
came
riding
in
among
the
crowd
.
<EOS>
But
,
even
then
,
he
galloped
here
and
there
,
exhorting
the
people
to
disperse
;
and
,
although
heavy
stones
were
thrown
at
the
men
,
and
some
were
desperately
cut
and
bruised
,
they
had
no
orders
but
to
make
prisoners
of
such
of
the
rioters
as
were
the
most
active
,
and
to
drive
the
people
back
with
the
flat
of
their
sabres
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
horses
came
in
among
them
,
the
throng
gave
way
at
many
points
,
and
the
Guards
,
following
up
their
advantage
,
were
rapidly
clearing
the
ground
,
when
two
or
three
of
the
foremost
,
who
were
in
a
manner
cut
off
from
the
rest
by
the
people
closing
round
them
,
made
straight
towards
Barnaby
and
Hugh
,
who
had
no
doubt
been
pointed
out
as
the
two
men
who
dropped
into
the
lobby
:
laying
about
them
now
with
some
effect
,
and
inflicting
on
the
more
turbulent
of
their
opponents
,
a
few
slight
flesh
wounds
,
under
the
influence
of
which
a
man
dropped
,
here
and
there
,
into
the
arms
of
his
fellows
,
amid
much
groaning
and
confusion
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
sight
of
gashed
and
bloody
faces
,
seen
for
a
moment
in
the
crowd
,
then
hidden
by
the
press
around
them
,
Barnaby
turned
pale
and
sick
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
stood
his
ground
,
and
grasping
his
pole
more
firmly
yet
,
kept
his
eye
fixed
upon
the
nearest
soldier
---
nodding
his
head
meanwhile
,
as
Hugh
,
with
a
scowling
visage
,
whispered
in
his
ear
.
  
<EOS>
The
soldier
came
spurring
on
,
making
his
horse
rear
as
the
people
pressed
about
him
,
cutting
at
the
hands
of
those
who
would
have
grasped
his
rein
and
forced
his
charger
back
,
and
waving
to
his
comrades
to
follow
---
and
still
Barnaby
,
without
retreating
an
inch
,
waited
for
his
coming
.
 
<EOS>
Some
called
to
him
to
fly
,
and
some
were
in
the
very
act
of
closing
round
him
,
to
prevent
his
being
taken
,
when
the
pole
swept
into
the
air
above
the
people
's
heads
,
and
the
man
's
saddle
was
empty
in
an
instant
.
  
<EOS>
Then
,
he
and
Hugh
turned
and
fled
,
the
crowd
opening
to
let
them
pass
,
and
closing
up
again
so
quickly
that
there
was
no
clue
to
the
course
they
had
taken
.
 
<EOS>
Panting
for
breath
,
hot
,
dusty
,
and
exhausted
with
fatigue
,
they
reached
the
riverside
in
safety
,
and
getting
into
a
boat
with
all
despatch
were
soon
out
of
any
immediate
danger
.
  
<EOS>
As
they
glided
down
the
river
,
they
plainly
heard
the
people
cheering
;
and
supposing
they
might
have
forced
the
soldiers
to
retreat
,
lay
upon
their
oars
for
a
few
minutes
,
uncertain
whether
to
return
or
not
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
crowd
passing
along
Westminster
Bridge
,
soon
assured
them
that
the
populace
were
dispersing
;
and
Hugh
rightly
guessed
from
this
,
that
they
had
cheered
the
magistrate
for
offering
to
dismiss
the
military
on
condition
of
their
immediate
departure
to
their
several
homes
,
and
that
he
and
Barnaby
were
better
where
they
were
.
 
<EOS>
He
advised
,
therefore
,
that
they
should
proceed
to
Blackfriars
,
and
,
going
ashore
at
the
bridge
,
make
the
best
of
their
way
to
The
Boot
;
where
there
was
not
only
good
entertainment
and
safe
lodging
,
but
where
they
would
certainly
be
joined
by
many
of
their
late
companions
.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
assenting
<EOS>
,
they
decided
on
this
course
of
action
,
and
pulled
for
Blackfriars
accordingly
.
  
<EOS>
They
landed
at
a
critical
time
,
and
fortunately
for
themselves
at
the
right
moment
.
 
<EOS>
For
,
coming
into
Fleet
Street
,
they
found
it
in
an
unusual
stir
;
and
inquiring
the
cause
,
were
told
that
a
body
of
Horse
Guards
had
just
galloped
past
,
and
that
they
were
escorting
some
rioters
whom
they
had
made
prisoners
,
to
Newgate
for
safety
.
<EOS>
Not
at
all
ill
-
pleased
to
have
so
narrowly
escaped
the
cavalcade
<EOS>
,
they
lost
no
more
time
in
asking
questions
,
but
hurried
to
The
Boot
with
as
much
speed
as
Hugh
considered
it
prudent
to
make
,
without
appearing
singular
or
attracting
an
inconvenient
share
of
public
notice
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
50
    
<EOS>
They
were
among
the
first
to
reach
the
tavern
,
but
they
had
not
been
there
many
minutes
,
when
several
groups
of
men
who
had
formed
part
of
the
crowd
,
came
straggling
in
.
 
<EOS>
Among
them
were
Simon
Tappertit
and
Mr
Dennis
;
both
of
whom
,
but
especially
the
latter
,
greeted
Barnaby
with
the
utmost
warmth
,
and
paid
him
many
compliments
on
the
prowess
he
had
shown
.
  
<EOS>
"
Which
,
"
said
Dennis
,
with
an
oath
,
as
he
rested
his
bludgeon
in
a
corner
with
his
hat
upon
it
,
and
took
his
seat
at
the
same
table
with
them
,
"
it
does
me
good
to
think
of
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
opportunity
!
<EOS>
But
it
led
to
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
For
my
part
,
I
do
n't
know
what
would
.
<EOS>
There
's
no
spirit
among
the
people
in
these
here
times
.
 
<EOS>
Bring
something
to
eat
and
drink
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
disgusted
with
humanity
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
On
what
account
?
"
asked
Mr
Tappertit
,
who
had
been
quenching
his
fiery
face
in
a
half
-
gallon
<EOS>
can
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
consider
this
a
good
beginning
,
mister
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Give
me
security
that
it
an't
a
ending
,
"
rejoined
the
hangman
.
<EOS>
"
When
that
soldier
went
down
,
we
might
have
made
London
ours
;
but
no
;
---
we
stand
,
and
gape
,
and
look
on
---
the
justice
(
I
wish
he
had
had
a
bullet
in
each
eye
,
as
he
would
have
had
,
if
we
'd
gone
to
work
my
way
)
<EOS>
says
,
"
My
lads
,
if
you
'll
give
me
your
word
to
disperse
,
I
'll
order
off
the
military
,
"
our
people
sets
up
a
hurrah
,
throws
up
the
game
with
the
winning
cards
in
their
hands
,
and
skulks
away
like
a
pack
of
tame
curs
as
they
are
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
"
said
the
hangman
,
in
a
tone
of
deep
disgust
,
"
it
makes
me
blush
for
my
feller
creeturs
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
been
born
a
ox
,
I
do
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
'd
have
been
quite
as
agreeable
a
character
if
you
had
been
,
I
think
,
"
returned
Simon
Tappertit
,
going
out
in
a
lofty
manner
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
too
sure
of
that
,
"
rejoined
the
hangman
,
calling
after
him
;
"
if
I
was
a
horned
animal
at
the
present
moment
,
with
the
smallest
grain
of
sense
,
I
'd
toss
every
man
in
this
company
,
excepting
them
two
,
"
meaning
Hugh
and
Barnaby
,
"
for
his
manner
of
conducting
himself
this
day
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
which
mournful
review
of
their
proceedings
,
Mr
Dennis
sought
consolation
in
cold
boiled
beef
and
beer
;
but
without
at
all
relaxing
the
grim
and
dissatisfied
expression
of
his
face
,
the
gloom
of
which
was
rather
deepened
than
dissipated
by
their
grateful
influence
.
  
<EOS>
The
company
who
were
thus
libelled
might
have
retaliated
by
strong
words
,
if
not
by
blows
,
but
they
were
dispirited
and
worn
out
.
 
<EOS>
The
greater
part
of
them
had
fasted
since
morning
;
all
had
suffered
extremely
from
the
excessive
heat
;
and
between
the
day
's
shouting
,
exertion
,
and
excitement
,
many
had
quite
lost
their
voices
,
and
so
much
of
their
strength
that
they
could
hardly
stand
.
 
<EOS>
Then
they
were
uncertain
what
to
do
next
,
fearful
of
the
consequences
of
what
they
had
done
already
,
and
sensible
that
after
all
they
had
carried
no
point
,
but
had
indeed
left
matters
worse
than
they
had
found
them
.
 
<EOS>
Of
those
who
had
come
to
The
Boot
,
many
dropped
off
within
an
hour
;
such
of
them
as
were
really
honest
and
sincere
,
never
,
after
the
morning
's
experience
,
to
return
,
or
to
hold
any
communication
with
their
late
companions
.
 
<EOS>
Others
remained
but
to
refresh
themselves
,
and
then
went
home
desponding
;
others
who
had
theretofore
been
regular
in
their
attendance
,
avoided
the
place
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
The
half
-
dozen
prisoners
whom
the
Guards
had
taken
,
were
magnified
by
report
into
half
-
a
-
hundred
at
least
;
and
their
friends
,
being
faint
and
sober
,
so
slackened
in
their
energy
,
and
so
drooped
beneath
these
dispiriting
influences
,
that
by
eight
o'clock
in
the
evening
,
Dennis
,
Hugh
,
and
Barnaby
,
were
left
alone
.
<EOS>
Even
they
were
fast
asleep
upon
the
benches
,
when
Gashford
's
entrance
roused
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
you
ARE
here
then
?
"
said
the
Secretary
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
where
should
we
be
,
Muster
Gashford
!
"
<EOS>
Dennis
rejoined
as
he
rose
into
a
sitting
posture
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
nowhere
,
nowhere
,
"
he
returned
with
excessive
mildness
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
streets
are
filled
with
blue
cockades
.
 
<EOS>
I
rather
thought
you
might
have
been
among
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
you
are
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
orders
for
us
,
master
,
then
?
"
said
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
Not
I.
 
<EOS>
No
orders
,
my
good
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
What
orders
should
I
have
?
 
<EOS>
You
are
not
in
my
service
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Muster
Gashford
,
"
remonstrated
Dennis
,
"
we
belong
to
the
cause
,
do
n't
we
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
cause
!
<EOS>
"
repeated
the
secretary
,
looking
at
him
in
a
sort
of
abstraction
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
cause
.
 
<EOS>
The
cause
is
lost
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lost
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
heard
,
I
suppose
?
 
<EOS>
The
petition
is
rejected
by
a
hundred
and
ninety
-
two
,
to
six
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
quite
final
.
 
<EOS>
We
might
have
spared
ourselves
some
trouble
.
 
<EOS>
That
,
and
my
lord
's
vexation
,
are
the
only
circumstances
I
regret
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
quite
satisfied
in
all
other
respects
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
said
this
,
he
took
a
penknife
from
his
pocket
,
and
putting
his
hat
upon
his
knee
,
began
to
busy
himself
in
ripping
off
the
blue
cockade
which
he
had
worn
all
day
;
at
the
same
time
humming
a
psalm
tune
which
had
been
very
popular
in
the
morning
,
and
dwelling
on
it
with
a
gentle
regret
.
  
<EOS>
His
two
adherents
looked
at
each
other
,
and
at
him
,
as
if
they
were
at
a
loss
how
to
pursue
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
Hugh
,
after
some
elbowing
and
winking
between
himself
and
Mr
Dennis
,
ventured
to
stay
his
hand
,
and
to
ask
him
why
he
meddled
with
that
riband
in
his
hat
.
  
<EOS>
"
Because
,
"
said
the
secretary
,
looking
up
with
something
between
a
snarl
and
a
smile
;
"
because
to
sit
still
and
wear
it
,
or
to
fall
asleep
and
wear
it
,
is
a
mockery
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
,
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
have
us
do
,
master
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
returned
Gashford
,
shrugging
his
shoulders
,
"
nothing
.
<EOS>
When
my
lord
was
reproached
and
threatened
for
standing
by
you
,
I
,
as
a
prudent
man
,
would
have
had
you
do
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
soldiers
were
trampling
you
under
their
horses
'
feet
,
I
would
have
had
you
do
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
When
one
of
them
was
struck
down
by
a
daring
hand
,
and
I
saw
confusion
and
dismay
in
all
their
faces
,
I
would
have
had
you
do
nothing
---
<EOS>
just
what
you
did
,
in
short
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
young
man
who
had
so
little
prudence
and
so
much
boldness
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
for
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sorry
,
master
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sorry
,
Muster
Gashford
!
"
echoed
Dennis
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
case
there
should
be
a
proclamation
out
to
-
morrow
,
offering
five
hundred
pounds
,
or
some
such
trifle
,
for
his
apprehension
;
and
in
case
it
should
include
another
man
who
dropped
into
the
lobby
from
the
stairs
above
,
"
said
Gashford
,
coldly
;
"
still
,
do
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Fire
and
fury
,
master
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
starting
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
have
we
done
,
that
you
should
talk
to
us
like
this
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
returned
Gashford
with
a
sneer
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
are
cast
into
prison
;
if
the
young
man
---
"
here
he
looked
hard
at
Barnaby
's
attentive
face
---
"
is
dragged
from
us
and
from
his
friends
;
perhaps
from
people
whom
he
loves
,
and
whom
his
death
would
kill
;
is
thrown
into
jail
,
brought
out
and
hanged
before
their
eyes
;
still
,
do
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
find
it
your
best
policy
,
I
have
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Come
on
!
"
cried
Hugh
,
striding
towards
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dennis
---
 
Barnaby
---
come
on
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
?
 
<EOS>
To
do
what
?
<EOS>
"
said
Gashford
,
slipping
past
him
,
and
standing
with
his
back
against
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Anywhere
!
 
<EOS>
Anything
!
"
cried
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Stand
aside
,
master
,
or
the
window
will
serve
our
turn
as
well
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
out
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
of
such
---
of
such
an
impetuous
nature
,
"
said
Gashford
,
changing
his
manner
for
one
of
the
utmost
good
fellowship
and
the
pleasantest
raillery
;
"
you
are
such
an
excitable
creature
---
 
<EOS>
but
you
'll
drink
with
me
before
you
go
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
---
certainly
,
"
growled
Dennis
,
drawing
his
sleeve
across
his
thirsty
lips
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
malice
,
brother
.
 
<EOS>
Drink
with
Muster
Gashford
!
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
wiped
his
heated
brow
,
and
relaxed
into
a
smile
.
 
<EOS>
The
artful
secretary
laughed
outright
.
  
<EOS>
"
Some
liquor
here
!
 
<EOS>
Be
quick
,
or
he
'll
not
stop
,
even
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
man
of
such
desperate
ardour
!
"
said
the
smooth
secretary
,
whom
Mr
Dennis
corroborated
with
sundry

and
muttered

---
"
Once
roused
,
he
is
a
fellow
of
such
fierce
determination
!
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
poised
his
sturdy
arm
aloft
,
and
clapping
Barnaby
on

back
,
bade
him
fear
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
They
shook
hands
together
---
poor
Barnaby
evidently
possessed
with
the
idea
that
he
was
among
the
most

---
and
Gashford

again
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hear
,
"
he
said
smoothly
,
as
he

with

in

,
and
filled

as

,
"
I
hear
---
<EOS>
but
I
can

---
that

are

to
-
night

,

that

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

,
Golden

;

common

,

---
You

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
---
"
To

,
rnaster
,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
No

<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
Leaders

,

?
 
<EOS>
Now
boys
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
most
impetuous

!
"
cried

.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
A

,

,

!
 
<EOS>
A
man
who
---
"
  
There
was
no

the

,
for
they
had
rushed
out
of
the
house
,
and
were
far
beyond

.
 
<EOS>
He
stopped
in
the
middle

a

,
listened
,
drew
on
his

,
and
,
clasping

behind

,

for
a
long
time
,
then
bent
his

towards
the
busy
town
,
and
walked
into
the
streets
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
filled
with
people
,
for
the
rumour
of
that
day
's
proceedings
had
made
a
great
noise
.
 
<EOS>
Those
persons
who
did
not
care
to
leave
home
,
were
at
their
doors
or
windows
,
and
one
topic
of
discourse
prevailed
on
every
side
.
 
<EOS>
Some
reported
that
the
riots
were
effectually
put
down
;
others
that
they
had
broken
out
again
:
some
said
that
Lord
George
Gordon
had
been
sent
under
a
strong
guard
to
the
Tower
;
others
that
an
attempt
had
been

upon
the
King
's

,
that
the
soldiers
had
been
again
called
out
,
and
that
the

of

in
a

of
the
town
had
been
plainly
heard
within
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
grew
darker
,
these
stories
became
more
direful
and

;
and
often
,
when
some

ran
past
with

that
the
rioters
were
not
far

,
and
were
coming

,
the

were
shut
and
barred
,
lower

made
secure
,
and
as

,
as

.
  
<EOS>
Gashford
walked
stealthily
about
,
listening
to
all
he
heard
,
and
diffusing
or

,
whenever
he
had
an

,
such
false
intelligence
as
suited
his
own
purpose
;
and
,
busily

in
this

,
turned
into
Holborn
for
the
twentieth
time
,
when
a
great
many
women

came

the

---
often
panting
and

---
and
the
confused

of

.
 
<EOS>
Assured
by

,
and

the
red

which

houses
on
either

,
that
some

his
friends
were

a
moment
's

at
a
door
which
opened
as
he
passed
,
and
running
with

to

,
looked

the

.
  
<EOS>
They
had
torches
among
them
,
and
the
chief
faces
were
distinctly
visible
.
 
<EOS>
That
they
had
been
engaged
in
the
destruction
of
some
building
<EOS>
was
sufficiently
apparent
,
and
that
it
was
a
Catholic
place
of
worship
was
evident
from
the
spoils
they

as

,
which
were
easily
recognisable
for
the
vestments
of
priests
,
and
rich

of
altar

.
 
<EOS>
Covered
with
soot
,
and
dirt
,
and
dust
,
and

;
their

torn
to
rags
;
their

;
their

and

with
the

of
rusty

;
Barnaby
,
Hugh
,
and
Dennis

on

all
,
like

.
 
<EOS>
After
them
,
the
dense
throng
came
fighting
on
:
some
singing
;
<EOS>
some
shouting
in

;
some

themselves
;
some

the
spectators
as

passed
;
some
with
great

,
on

as

been

,
rending

,
and

the

high

;
some
in

,

from

,
and

,
and

;
one

,
in

,
covered

,

.
<EOS>
Thus
---
a

of
coarse
faces
,
with
here
<EOS>
and

a

flaring
,

;
a

,

in

,

;
a

,

so

seen
,

,

,

,

,

all

---

,

.
  
<EOS>
As

upon

,

.
 
<EOS>
A
knot
of

;
Gashford
,
who
just

,
among

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
on

outskirts
of
the
little

,
and
could
not
see

passed

;
but
one

,

that

descried

.
  
<EOS>
"
Is

all
?
"
said

secretary
,
turning

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I
think
this

like

!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
51
    
Promising
<EOS>
as
these
outrages
were
to
Gashford
's
view
,
and
much
like
business
as
they
looked
,
they
extended
that
night
no

.
 
<EOS>
The
soldiers
were
again
called
out
,
again
they
took
half
-
a
-
dozen

,
and
again
the
crowd
dispersed
after
a
short

.
 
<EOS>
Hot
and
drunken
though
they
were
,
they
had
not
yet
broken
all
bounds
and
set
all
law
and
government
at
defiance
.
<EOS>
Something
of
their
habitual
deference
to
the
authority
erected
by
society
for
its
own
preservation
yet
remained
among
them
,
and
had
its

been
vindicated
in
time
,
the
secretary
would
have
had
to
digest
a
bitter

.
  
<EOS>
By
midnight
,
the
streets
were
clear
and
quiet
,
and
,
save
that
there
stood
in
two
parts
of
the
town
a
heap
of
nodding

and
pile
of

,
where
there
had
been
at

a
rich

building
,
everything
wore
its
usual

.
 
<EOS>
Even
the
Catholic
gentry
and

,
of

there
were
many
resident
in
different

of
the
City
and
its

,
had
no

for
their

,
and
but

for
the
wrong
they
had
already

in

and

of

of

.
 
<EOS>
An
honest
confidence
in
the
government
under
whose
protection
they
had
lived
for
many
years
,
and
a
well
-
founded
reliance
on
the
good
feeling
and
right

of
the
great

of
the
community
,
with
whom
,
notwithstanding
their
religious

,
they
were
every

in

of
confidential
,
affectionate
,
and
friendly

,
reassured
them
,
even
under
the
excesses
that
had
been
committed
;
and
convinced
them
that
they
who
were
Protestants
in
anything
<EOS>
but
the
name
,
were
no
more

considered

,
than
they
themselves
were
chargeable
with
the
uses
of
the
block
,
the
rack
,
the
gibbet
,
and
the
stake
in
cruel
Mary
's
reign
.
  
<EOS>
The
clock
was
on
the
stroke
of
one
,
when
Gabriel
Varden
,
with
his
lady
and
Miss
Miggs
,
sat

.
 
<EOS>
This
fact
;
the

wicks
of
the
dull
,

;
the

that
prevailed
;
and
,
above

,
the
nightcaps
of
both
maid

,
were
sufficient

that
they
had
been
prepared
for
bed
some
time
ago
,
and
had
some
reason
for
sitting
up
so
far
beyond

.
  
<EOS>
If
any
other

had

,
it
would

abundantly

in
the
actions
of
Miss
Miggs
,
who
,

arrived
at
that
restless
state
and
sensitive

of
the

system
which
are
the
result

long

,
did
,
by
a
constant

and

of
her

,
a

position
(
arising

the

imaginary

)
,
a
frequent

of
her

,
the
incessant

of
a

,
a
small

,
a

,
a

,
a

,
a

,
and
by
other

of
that
nature
,
so
file
down
and
rasp
,
as
it
were
,
the
patience
of
the
locksmith
,
that
after
looking
at
her
in

some

,
he
at
last
broke
out
into
this
apostrophe
:
---
   
<EOS>
"
Miggs
,
my
good
girl
,
go
to
bed
---
do

to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
You
're

than

of
a

water

butts

,
or

as

.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't

.
 
<EOS>
Do

bed
,
Miggs
.
 
<EOS>
To

---
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have

untie
,

,
"

,
"
and

.
 
<EOS>
But
missis
has
---

<EOS>
while

,
mim
"
---

"

,

,
<EOS>

was

,
go

.
"
  
<EOS>
Having

,
Miss
Miggs
made
divers

to
rub

shoulders
in
an
impossible
place
,
and
shivered
from
head
to

;
thereby
giving
the
beholders
to
understand
that
the

was
still

,
but
that

sense

duty
upheld
her

all

,
and
nerved

to

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
being

,
and
Miss
Miggs
having
,
as
the
phrase
is
,
said
her
say
,
the
locksmith
had
nothing
for
it
but
to
sigh
and
be
as

as
he
could
.
  
<EOS>
But
to
be
quiet
with
such

basilisk
before
him
was
impossible
.
<EOS>
If
he
looked
another
way
,
it
was
worse
to
feel
that
she
was
rubbing
her

,
or
twitching
her

,
or
winking

,
or
making
all

of

,
than
to
see

do

.
<EOS>
If

was
for

free
from
any
of
these
complaints
,
it
was
only
because
of
her
foot
being
asleep
,
or

her
arm
having
got
the

,
or

doubled
up
with
the

,
or
of
some
other
horrible
disorder
which
racked

.
 
<EOS>
If

did

a
moment
's
ease
,
then
with
her

and
her

,

would

seen
to

;

,
and

;

,

another

;
then
to
recover

;
then
to
come
forward
again
---
lower
---
<EOS>
lower
---
lower
---
 
by
very
slow

,
until
,

,

,

,
which

,
"
I
've

closed
'em
since

,

I
'll

!
"
  
<EOS>
At
length
,
after
the
clock
had
struck
two
,
there
was
a
sound
at
the

door
,
as

.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs

,

,
"
<EOS>
Ally
Looyer
,

!
<EOS>
there
's
Simmuns
's
knock
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
's
there
?
"
said
Gabriel
.
  
<EOS>
"
Me
!
"
cried
the
well
-
known
