of
Mr
Tappertit
.
 
<EOS>
Gabriel
opened
the
door
,
and
gave
him
admission
.
  
<EOS>
He
did
not
cut
a
very
insinuating
figure
,
for
a
man
of
his
stature
suffers
in
a
crowd
;
and
having
been
active
in
yesterday
morning
's
work
,
his
dress
was
literally
crushed
from
head
to
foot
:
his
hat
being
beaten
out
of
all
shape
,
and
his
shoes
trodden
down
at
heel
like
slippers
.
 
<EOS>
His
coat
fluttered
in
strips
about
him
,
the
buckles
were
torn
away
both
from
his
knees
and
feet
,
half
his
neckerchief
was
gone
,
and
the
bosom
of
his
shirt
was
rent
to
tatters
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
notwithstanding
all
these
personal
disadvantages
;
despite
his
being
very
weak
from
heat
and
fatigue
;
and
so
begrimed
with
mud
and
dust
that
he
might
have
been
in
a
case
,
for
anything
of
the
real
texture
(
either
of
his
skin
or
apparel
)
that
the
eye
could
discern
;
he
stalked
haughtily
into
the
parlour
,
and
throwing
himself
into
a
chair
,
and
endeavouring
to
thrust
his
hands
into
the
pockets
of
his
small
-
clothes
,
which
were
turned
inside
out
and
displayed
upon
his
legs
,
like
tassels
,
surveyed
the
household
with
a
gloomy
dignity
.
  
<EOS>
"
Simon
,
"
said
the
locksmith
gravely
,
"
how
comes
it
that
you
return
home
at
this
time
of
night
,
and
in
this
condition
?
 
<EOS>
Give
me
an
assurance
that
you
have
not
been
among
the
rioters
,
and
I
am
satisfied
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Tappertit
,
with
a
contemptuous
look
,
"
I
wonder
at
YOUR
assurance
in
making
such
demands
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
drinking
,
"
said
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
As
a
general
principle
,
and
in
the
most
offensive
sense
of
the
words
,
sir
,
"
returned
his
journeyman
with
great
self
-
possession
,
"
I
consider
you
a
liar
.
 
<EOS>
In
that
last
observation
you
have
unintentionally
---
unintentionally
,
sir
,
---
struck
upon
the
truth
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Martha
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
turning
to
his
wife
,
and
shaking
his
head
sorrowfully
,
while
a
smile
at
the
absurd
figure
beside
him
still
played
upon
his
open
face
,
"
I
trust
it
may
turn
out
that
this
poor
lad
is
not
the
victim
of
the
knaves
and
fools
we
have
so
often
had
words
about
,
and
who
have
done
so
much
harm
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
has
been
at
Warwick
Street
or
Duke
Street
to
-
night
---
"
  
"
He
has
been
at
neither
,
sir
,
"
cried
Mr
Tappertit
in
a
loud
voice
,
which
he
suddenly
dropped
into
a
whisper
as
he
repeated
,
with
eyes
fixed
upon
the
locksmith
,
"
he
has
been
at
neither
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
of
it
,
with
all
my
heart
,
"
said
the
locksmith
in
a
serious
tone
;
"
for
if
he
had
been
,
and
it
could
be
proved
against
him
,
Martha
,
your
Great
Association
would
have
been
to
him
the
cart
that
draws
men
to
the
gallows
and
leaves
them
hanging
in
the
air
.
<EOS>
It
would
,
as
sure
as
we
're
alive
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
was
too
much
scared
by
Simon
's
altered
manner
and
appearance
,
and
by
the
accounts
of
the
rioters
which
had
reached
her
ears
that
night
,
to
offer
any
retort
,
or
to
have
recourse
to
her
usual
matrimonial
policy
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
wrung
her
hands
,
and
wept
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
was
not
at
Duke
Street
,
or
at
Warwick
Street
,
G
Varden
,
"
said
Simon
,
sternly
;
"
but
he
WAS
at
Westminster
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
sir
,
he
kicked
a
county
member
,
perhaps
,
sir
,
he
tapped
a
lord
---
you
may
stare
,
<EOS>
sir
,
I
repeat
it
---
blood
flowed
from
noses
,
and
perhaps
he
tapped
a
lord
.
 
<EOS>
Who
knows
?
 
<EOS>
This
<EOS>
,
"
he
added
,
putting
his
hand
into
his
waistcoat
-
pocket
,
and
taking
out
a
large
tooth
,
at
the
sight
of
which
both
Miggs
and
Mrs
Varden
screamed
,
"
this
was
a
bishop
's
.
<EOS>
Beware
,
G
Varden
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
would
rather
,
"
said
the
locksmith
hastily
,
"
have
paid
five
hundred
pounds
,
than
had
this
come
to
pass
.
 
<EOS>
You
idiot
<EOS>
,
do
you
know
what
peril
you
stand
in
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
,
sir
,
"
replied
his
journeyman
,
"
and
it
is
my
glory
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
there
,
everybody
saw
me
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
conspicuous
,
and
prominent
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
abide
the
consequences
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
,
really
disturbed
and
agitated
,
paced
to
and
fro
in
silence
---
glancing
at
his
former
'
prentice
every
now
and
then
---
and
at
length
stopping
before
him
,
said
:
  
"
Get
to
bed
,
and
sleep
for
a
couple
of
hours
that
you
may
wake
penitent
,
and
with
some
of
your
senses
about
you
.
 
<EOS>
Be
sorry
for
what
you
have
done
,
and
we
will
try
to
save
you
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
call
him
by
five
o'clock
,
"
said
Varden
,
turning
hurriedly
to
his
wife
,
and
he
washes
himself
clean
and
changes
his
dress
,
he
may
get
to
the
Tower
Stairs
,
and
away
by
the
Gravesend
tide
-
boat
,
before
any
search
is
made
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
From
there
he
can
easily
get
on
to
Canterbury
,
where
your
cousin
will
give
him
work
till
this
storm
has
blown
over
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
sure
that
I
do
right
in
screening
him
from
the
punishment
he
deserves
,
but
he
has
lived
in
this
house
,
man
and
boy
,
for
a
dozen
years
,
and
I
should
be
sorry
if
for
this
one
day
's
work
he
made
a
miserable
end
.
 
<EOS>
Lock
the
front
-
door
,
Miggs
,
and
show
no
light
towards
the
street
when
you
go
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
Quick
,
Simon
!
<EOS>
Get
to
bed
!
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
do
you
suppose
,
sir
,
"
retorted
Mr
Tappertit
,
with
a
thickness
and
slowness
of
speech
which
contrasted
forcibly
with
the
rapidity
and
earnestness
of
his
kind
-
hearted
master
---
"
and
<EOS>
do
you
suppose
,
sir
,
that
I
am
base
and
mean
enough
to
accept
your
servile
proposition
?
---
<EOS>
Miscreant
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whatever
you
please
,
Sim
,
but
get
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
Every
minute
is
of
consequence
.
 
<EOS>
The
light
here
,
Miggs
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
yes
,
oh
do
!
 
<EOS>
Go
to
bed
directly
,
"
cried
the
two
women
together
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
stood
upon
his
feet
,
and
pushing
his
chair
away
to
show
that
he
needed
no
assistance
,
answered
,
swaying
himself
to
and
fro
,
and
managing
his
head
as
if
it
had
no
connection
whatever
with
his
body
:
  
<EOS>
"
You
spoke
of
Miggs
,
sir
---
Miggs
may
be
smothered
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
Simmun
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
that
young
lady
in
a
faint
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
mim
!
<EOS>
Oh
sir
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
goodness
gracious
,
what
a
turn
he
has
give
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
family
may
ALL
be
smothered
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Tappertit
,
after
glancing
at
her
with
a
smile
of
ineffable
disdain
,
"
excepting
Mrs
V.
 
<EOS>
I
have
come
here
,
sir
,
for
her
sake
,
this
night
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
,
take
this
piece
of
paper
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
protection
,
ma'am
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
need
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
these
words
he
held
out
at
arm
's
length
,
a
dirty
,
crumpled
scrap
of
writing
.
 
<EOS>
The
locksmith
took
it
from
him
,
opened
it
,
and
read
as
follows
:
  
<EOS>
"
All
good
friends
to
our
cause
,
I
hope
will
be
particular
,
and
do
no
injury
to
the
property
of
any
true
Protestant
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
well
assured
that
the
proprietor
of
this
house
is
a
staunch
and
worthy
friend
to
the
cause
.
  
<EOS>
GEORGE
GORDON
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
this
!
"
said
the
locksmith
,
with
an
altered
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
Something
that
'll
do
you
good
service
,
young
feller
,
"
replied
his
journeyman
,
"
as
you
'll
find
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
that
safe
,
and
where
you
can
lay
your
hand
upon
it
in
an
instant
.
 
<EOS>
And
chalk
"
No
Popery
"
on
your
door
to
-
morrow
night
,
and
for
a
week
to
come
<EOS>
---
that
's
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
genuine
document
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
"
I
know
,
for
I
have
seen
the
hand
before
.
 
<EOS>
What
threat
does
it
imply
?
 
<EOS>
What
devil
is
abroad
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
fiery
devil
,
"
retorted
Sim
;
"
a
flaming
,
furious
devil
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
put
yourself
in
its
way
,
or
you
're
done
for
,
my
buck
.
 
<EOS>
Be
warned
in
time
,
G
Varden
.
 
<EOS>
Farewell
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
here
the
two
women
threw
themselves
in
his
way
---
especially
Miss
Miggs
,
who
fell
upon
him
with
such
fervour
that
she
pinned
him
against
the
wall
---
and
conjured
him
in
moving
words
not
to
go
forth
till
he
was
sober
;
to
listen
to
reason
;
to
think
of
it
;
to
take
some
rest
,
and
then
determine
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
"
said
Mr
Tappertit
,
"
that
my
mind
is
made
up
.
 
<EOS>
My
bleeding
country
calls
me
<EOS>
and
I
go
!
 
<EOS>
Miggs
,
if
you
do
n't
get
out
of
the
way
,
I
'll
pinch
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
,
still
clinging
to
the
rebel
,
screamed
once
vociferously
---
but
whether
in
the
distraction
of
her
mind
,
or
because
of
his
having
executed
his
threat
,
is
uncertain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Release
me
,
"
said
Simon
,
struggling
to
free
himself
from
her
chaste
,
but
spider
-
like
embrace
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
made
arrangements
for
you
in
an
altered
state
of
society
,
and
mean
to
provide
for
you
comfortably
in
life
---
there
!
 
<EOS>
Will
that
satisfy
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
Simmun
!
"
cried
Miss
Miggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
my
blessed
Simmun
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
mim
!
<EOS>
what
are
my
feelings
at
this
conflicting
moment
!
"
  
<EOS>
Of
a
rather
turbulent
description
,
it
would
seem
;
for
her
nightcap
had
been
knocked
off
in
the
scuffle
,
and
she
was
on
her
knees
upon
the
floor
,
making
a
strange
revelation
of
blue
and
yellow
curl
-
papers
,
straggling
locks
of
hair
,
tags
of
staylaces
,
and
strings
of
it
's
impossible
to
say
what
;
panting
for
breath
,
clasping
her
hands
,
turning
her
eyes
upwards
,
shedding
abundance
of
tears
,
and
exhibiting
various
other
symptoms
of
the
acutest
mental
suffering
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
leave
,
"
said
Simon
,
turning
to
his
master
,
with
an
utter
disregard
of
Miggs
's
maidenly
affliction
,
"
a
box
of
things
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
Do
what
you
like
with
'em
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
'em
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
never
coming
back
here
,
any
more
.
 
<EOS>
Provide
yourself
,
sir
,
with
a
journeyman
;
I
'm
my
country
's
journeyman
;
henceforward
that
's
MY
line
of
business
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Be
what
you
like
in
two
hours
'
time
,
but
now
go
up
to
bed
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
,
planting
himself
in
the
doorway
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hear
me
?
 
<EOS>
Go
to
bed
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hear
you
,
and
defy
you
,
Varden
,
"
rejoined
Simon
Tappertit
.
"
<EOS>
This
night
,
sir
,
I
have
been
in
the
country
,
planning
an
expedition
which
shall
fill
your
bell
-
hanging
soul
with
wonder
and
dismay
.
 
<EOS>
The
plot
demands
my
utmost
energy
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
pass
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
knock
you
down
if
you
come
near
the
door
,
"
replied
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
go
to
bed
!
"
  
<EOS>
Simon
made
no
answer
,
but
gathering
himself
up
as
straight
as
he
could
,
plunged
head
foremost
at
his
old
master
,
and
the
two
went
driving
out
into
the
workshop
together
,
plying
their
hands
and
feet
so
briskly
that
they
looked
like
half
-
a
-
dozen
,
while
Miggs
and
Mrs
Varden
screamed
for
twelve
.
  
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
easy
for
Varden
to
knock
his
old
'
prentice
down
,
and
bind
him
hand
and
foot
;
but
as
he
was
loth
to
hurt
him
in
his
then
defenceless
state
,
he
contented
himself
with
parrying
his
blows
when
he
could
,
taking
them
in
perfect
good
part
when
he
could
not
,
and
keeping
between
him
and
the
door
,
until
a
favourable
opportunity
should
present
itself
for
forcing
him
to
retreat
up
-
stairs
,
and
shutting
him
up
in
his
own
room
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
in
the
goodness
of
his
heart
,
he
calculated
too
much
upon
his
adversary
's
weakness
,
and
forgot
that
drunken
men
who
have
lost
the
power
of
walking
steadily
,
can
often
run
.
 
<EOS>
Watching
his
time
,
Simon
Tappertit
made
a
cunning
show
of
falling
back
,
staggered
unexpectedly
forward
,
brushed
past
him
,
opened
the
door
(
he
knew
the
trick
of
that
lock
well
)
,
and
darted
down
the
street
like
a
mad
dog
.
 
<EOS>
The
locksmith
paused
for
a
moment
in
the
excess
of
his
astonishment
,
and
then
gave
chase
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
an
excellent
season
for
a
run
,
for
at
that
silent
hour
the
streets
were
deserted
,
the
air
was
cool
,
and
the
flying
figure
before
him
distinctly
visible
at
a
great
distance
,
as
it
sped
away
,
with
a
long
gaunt
shadow
following
at
its
heels
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
short
-
winded
locksmith
had
no
chance
against
a
man
of
Sim
's
youth
and
spare
figure
,
though
the
day
had
been
when
he
could
have
run
him
down
in
no
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
space
between
them
rapidly
increased
,
and
as
the
rays
of
the
rising
sun
streamed
upon
Simon
in
the
act
of
turning
a
distant
corner
,
Gabriel
Varden
was
fain
to
give
up
,
and
sit
down
on
a
doorstep
to
fetch
his
breath
.
 
<EOS>
Simon
meanwhile
,
without
once
stopping
,
fled
at
the
same
degree
of
swiftness
to
The
Boot
,
where
,
as
he
well
knew
,
some
of
his
company
were
lying
,
and
at
which
respectable
hostelry
---
for
he
had
already
acquired
the
distinction
of
being
in
great
peril
of
the
law
---
a
friendly
watch
had
been
expecting
him
all
night
,
and
was
even
now
on
the
look
-
out
for
his
coming
.
  
<EOS>
"
Go
thy
ways
,
Sim
,
go
thy
ways
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
as
soon
as
he
could
speak
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
my
best
for
thee
,
poor
lad
,
and
would
have
saved
thee
,
but
the
rope
is
round
thy
neck
,
I
fear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
saying
,
and
shaking
his
head
in
a
very
sorrowful
and
disconsolate
manner
,
he
turned
back
,
and
soon
re
-
entered
his
own
house
,
where
Mrs
Varden
and
the
faithful
Miggs
had
been
anxiously
expecting
his
return
.
  
<EOS>
Now
Mrs
Varden
(
and
by
consequence
Miss
Miggs
likewise
)
was
impressed
with
a
secret
misgiving
that
she
had
done
wrong
;
that
she
had
,
to
the
utmost
of
her
small
means
,
aided
and
abetted
the
growth
of
disturbances
,
the
end
of
which
it
was
impossible
to
foresee
;
that
she
had
led
remotely
to
the
scene
which
had
just
passed
;
and
that
the
locksmith
's
time
for
triumph
and
reproach
had
now
arrived
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
strongly
did
Mrs
Varden
feel
this
,
and
so
crestfallen
was
she
in
consequence
,
that
while
her
husband
was
pursuing
their
lost
journeyman
,
she
secreted
under
her
chair
the
little
red
-
brick
dwelling
-
house
with
the
yellow
roof
,
lest
it
should
furnish
new
occasion
for
reference
to
the
painful
theme
;
and
now
hid
the
same
still
more
,
with
the
skirts
of
her
dress
.
  
<EOS>
But
it
happened
that
the
locksmith
had
been
thinking
of
this
very
article
on
his
way
home
,
and
that
,
coming
into
the
room
and
not
seeing
it
,
he
at
once
demanded
where
it
was
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
had
no
resource
but
to
produce
it
,
which
she
did
with
many
tears
,
and
broken
protestations
that
if
she
could
have
known
---
   
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
"
said
Varden
,
"
<EOS>
of
course
---
I
know
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mean
to
reproach
you
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
But
recollect
from
this
time
that
all
good
things
perverted
to
evil
purposes
,
are
worse
than
those
which
are
naturally
bad
.
 
<EOS>
A
thoroughly
wicked
woman
,
is
wicked
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
When
religion
goes
wrong
,
she
is
very
wrong
,
for
the
same
reason
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
say
no
more
about
it
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
he
dropped
the
red
-
brick
dwelling
-
house
on
the
floor
,
and
setting
his
heel
upon
it
,
crushed
it
into
pieces
.
 
<EOS>
The
halfpence
,
and
sixpences
,
and
other
voluntary
contributions
,
rolled
about
in
all
directions
,
but
nobody
offered
to
touch
them
,
or
to
take
them
up
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
"
is
easily
disposed
of
,
and
I
would
to
Heaven
that
everything
growing
out
of
the
same
society
could
be
settled
as
easily
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
happens
very
fortunately
,
Varden
,
"
said
his
wife
,
with
her
handkerchief
to
her
eyes
,
"
that
in
case
any
more
disturbances
should
happen
---
which
I
hope
not
<EOS>
;
I
sincerely
hope
not
---
"
  
"
I
hope
so
too
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
---
That
in
case
any
should
occur
,
we
have
the
piece
of
paper
which
that
poor
misguided
young
man
brought
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
to
be
sure
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
turning
quickly
round
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
is
that
piece
of
paper
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
stood
aghast
as
he
took
it
from
her
outstretched
band
,
tore
it
into
fragments
,
and
threw
them
under
the
grate
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
use
it
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Use
it
!
"
cried
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
Let
them
come
and
pull
the
roof
about
our
ears
<EOS>
;
let
them
burn
us
out
of
house
and
home
;
I
'd
neither
have
the
protection
of
their
leader
,
nor
chalk
their
howl
upon
my
door
,
though
,
for
not
doing
it
,
they
shot
me
on
my
own
threshold
.
 
<EOS>
Use
it
!
 
<EOS>
Let
them
come
and
do
their
worst
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
man
who
crosses
my
doorstep
on
such
an
errand
as
theirs
,
had
better
be
a
hundred
miles
away
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
look
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
others
may
have
their
will
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
beg
or
buy
them
off
,
if
,
instead
of
every
pound
of
iron
in
the
place
<EOS>
,
there
was
a
hundred
weight
of
gold
.
<EOS>
Get
you
to
bed
,
Martha
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
take
down
the
shutters
and
go
to
work
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
early
!
"
said
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
"
replied
the
locksmith
cheerily
,
"
so
early
.
 
<EOS>
Come
when
they
may
,
they
shall
not
find
us
skulking
and
hiding
,
as
if
we
feared
to
take
our
portion
of
the
light
of
day
,
and
left
it
all
to
them
.
 
<EOS>
So
pleasant
dreams
to
you
,
my
dear
,
and
cheerful
sleep
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
he
gave
his
wife
a
hearty
kiss
,
and
bade
her
delay
no
longer
,
or
it
would
be
time
to
rise
before
she
lay
down
to
rest
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Varden
quite
amiably
and
meekly
walked
upstairs
,
followed
by
Miggs
,
who
,
although
a
good
deal
subdued
,
could
not
refrain
from
sundry
stimulative
coughs
and
sniffs
by
the
way
,
or
from
holding
up
her
hands
in
astonishment
at
the
daring
conduct
of
master
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
52
    
<EOS>
A
mob
is
usually
a
creature
of
very
mysterious
existence
,
particularly
in
a
large
city
.
 
<EOS>
Where
it
comes
from
or
whither
<EOS>
it
goes
,
few
men
can
tell
.
 
<EOS>
Assembling
and
dispersing
with
equal
suddenness
,
it
is
as
difficult
to
follow
to
its
various
sources
as
the
sea
itself
;
nor
does
the
parallel
stop
here
,
for
the
ocean
<EOS>
is
not
more
fickle
and
uncertain
,
more
terrible
when
roused
,
more
unreasonable
,
or
more
cruel
.
  
<EOS>
The
people
who
were
boisterous
at
Westminster
upon
the
Friday
morning
,
and
were
eagerly
bent
upon
the
work
of
devastation
in
Duke
Street
and
Warwick
Street
at
night
,
were
,
in
the
mass
,
the
same
.
<EOS>
Allowing
for
the
chance
accessions
of
which
any
crowd
is
morally
sure
in
a
town
where
there
must
always
be
a
large
number
of
idle
and
profligate
persons
,
one
and
the
same
mob
was
at
both
places
.
<EOS>
Yet
they
spread
themselves
in
various
directions
when
they
dispersed
in
the
afternoon
,
made
no
appointment
for
reassembling
,
had
no
definite
purpose
or
design
,
and
indeed
,
for
anything
they
knew
,
were
scattered
beyond
the
hope
of
future
union
.
  
<EOS>
At
The
Boot
,
which
,
as
has
been
shown
,
was
in
a
manner
the
head
-
quarters
of
the
rioters
,
there
were
not
,
upon
this
Friday
night
,
a
dozen
people
.
 
<EOS>
Some
slept
in
the
stable
and
outhouses
,
some
in
the
common
room
,
some
two
or
three
in
beds
.
 
<EOS>
The
rest
were
in
their
usual
homes
or
haunts
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
not
a
score
in
all
lay
in
the
adjacent
fields
and
lanes
,
and
under
haystacks
,
or
near
the
warmth
of
brick
-
kilns
,
who
had
not
their
accustomed
place
of
rest
beneath
the
open
sky
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
the
public
ways
within
the
town
,
they
had
their
ordinary
nightly
occupants
,
and
no
others
;
the
usual
amount
of
vice
and
wretchedness
,
but
no
more
.
  
<EOS>
The
experience
of
one
evening
,
however
,
had
taught
the
reckless
leaders
of
disturbance
,
that
they
had
but
to
show
themselves
in
the
streets
,
to
be
immediately
surrounded
by
materials
which
they
could
only
have
kept
together
when
their
aid
was
not
required
,
at
great
risk
,
expense
,
and
trouble
.
 
<EOS>
Once
possessed
of
this
secret
,
they
were
as
confident
as
if
<EOS>
twenty
thousand
men
,
devoted
to
their
will
,
had
been
encamped
about
them
,
and
assumed
a
confidence
which
could
not
have
been
surpassed
,
though
that
had
really
been
the
case
.
 
<EOS>
All
day
,
Saturday
,
they
remained
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
On
Sunday
,
they
rather
studied
how
to
keep
their
men
within
call
,
and
in
full
hope
,
than
to
follow
out
,
by
any
fierce
measure
,
their
first
day
's
proceedings
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
"
said
Dennis
,
as
,
with
a
loud
yawn
,
he
raised
his
body
from
a
heap
of
straw
on
which
he
had
been
sleeping
,
and
supporting
his
head
upon
his
hand
,
appealed
to
Hugh
on
Sunday
morning
,
"
that
Muster
Gashford
allows
some
rest
?
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
'd
have
us
at
work
again
already
,
eh
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
his
way
to
let
matters
drop
,
you
may
be
sure
of
that
,
"
growled
Hugh
in
answer
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
in
no
humour
to
stir
yet
,
though
.
<EOS>
I
'm
as
stiff
as
a
dead
body
,
and
as
full
of
ugly
scratches
as
if
I
had
been
fighting
all
day
yesterday
with
wild

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
've
so
much
enthusiasm
,
that
's
it
,
"
said
Dennis
,
looking
with
great

at
the
uncombed

,
matted

,
and

and
face
of
the
wild
figure
before

;
"
you
're
such
a
devil
of
a
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
You
hurt
yourself
a
hundred
times
more
than
you
need
,
because
you
will
be
foremost
in
everything
,
and
will
do
more
than
the
rest
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
For
the
matter
of
that
,
"
returned
Hugh
,
shaking

and

the
door
of
the
stable
in
which
they
lay
;
"
there
's
one
yonder
as
good
as
me
.
 
<EOS>
What
did
I
tell
you
about
him
?
<EOS>
Did
I
say
he
was
worth
a
dozen
,
when
you
doubted
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dennis
rolled
lazily
over
upon
his
breast
,
and
resting
his
chin
upon
his
hand
in
imitation
of
the
attitude
in
which
Hugh
lay
,
said
,
as
he
too
looked
towards
the
door
:
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
,
you
knew
him
,
brother
,
you
knew
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
who
'd
suppose
to
look
at
that
chap
now
,
that
he
could
be
the
man
he
is
!
 
<EOS>
Is
n't
it
a
thousand
cruel
pities
,
brother
,
that
instead
of
taking
his
nat'ral
rest
and
qualifying
himself
for
further
exertions
in
this
here
honourable
cause
,
he
should
be
playing
at
soldiers
like
a
boy
?
 
<EOS>
And
his
cleanliness
too
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Dennis
,
who
certainly
had
no
reason
to
entertain
a
fellow
feeling
with
anybody
who
was
particular
on
that
score
;
"
what
weaknesses
he
's
guilty
of
;
with
respect
to
his
cleanliness
!
 
<EOS>
At
five
o'clock
this
morning
,
there
he
was
at
the
pump
,
though
any
one
would
think
he
had
gone
through
enough
,
the
day
before
yesterday
,
to
be
pretty
fast

.
 
<EOS>
But
no
---
when
I
woke
for
a
minute
or
two
,
there
he
was
at
the
pump
,
and
if
you
'd
seen
him
sticking
them
peacock
's
feathers
into
his
hat
when
he
'd
done
washing
---
ah
!
<EOS>
I
'm
sorry
<EOS>
he
's
such
a
imperfect
character
,
but
the
best
on
us
is
incomplete
in
some
pint
of
view
or
another
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
subject
of
this
dialogue
and
of
these
concluding
remarks
,
which
were
uttered
in
a
tone
of
philosophical
meditation
,
was
,
as
the
reader
will
have
divined
,
no
other
than
Barnaby
,
who
,
with
his
flag
in
hand
,
stood
sentry
in
the
little
patch
of
sunlight
at
the
distant
door
,
or
walked
to
and
fro
outside
,
singing
softly
to
himself
;
and
keeping
time
to
the
music
of
some
clear
church
bells
.
<EOS>
Whether
he
stood
still
,
leaning
with
both
hands
on
the
flagstaff
,
or
,
bearing
it
upon
his
shoulder
,
paced
slowly
up
and
down
,
the
careful
arrangement
of
his
poor
dress
,
and
his
erect
and
lofty
bearing
,
showed
how
high
a
sense
he
had
of
the
great
importance
of
his
trust
,
and
how
happy
and
how
proud
it
made
him
.
 
<EOS>
To
Hugh
and
his
companion
,
who
lay
in
a
dark
corner
of
the
gloomy
shed
,
<EOS>
he
,
and
the
sunlight
,
and
the
peaceful
Sabbath
sound
to
which
he
made
response
,
seemed
like
a
bright
picture
framed
by
the
door
,
and
set
off
by
the
stable
's
blackness
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
formed
such
a
contrast
to
themselves
,
as
they
lay
wallowing
,
like
some
obscene
animals
,
in
their
squalor
and
wickedness
on
the
two
heaps
of
straw
,
that
for
a
few
moments
they
looked
on
without
speaking
,
and
felt
almost
ashamed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Hugh
at
length
,
carrying
it
off
with
a
laugh
:
"
<EOS>
He
's
a
rare
fellow
is
Barnaby
,
and
can
do
more
,
with
less
rest
,
or
meat
,
or
drink
,
than
any
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
his
soldiering
,
I
put
him
on
duty
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
there
was
a
object
in
it
,
and
a
proper
good
one
too
,
I
'll
be
sworn
,
"
retorted
Dennis
with
a
broad
grin
,
and
an
oath
of
the
same
quality
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
was
it
,
brother
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
see
,
"
said
Hugh
,
crawling
a
little
nearer
to
him
,
"
that
our
noble
captain
yonder
,
came
in
yesterday
morning
rather
the
worse
for
liquor
,
and
was
---
like
you
and
me
---
<EOS>
ditto
last
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Dennis
looked
to
where
Simon
Tappertit
lay
coiled
upon
a
truss
of
hay
,
snoring
profoundly
,
and
nodded
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
our
noble
captain
,
"
continued
Hugh
with
another
laugh
,
"
<EOS>
our
noble
captain
and
I
,
have
planned
for
to
-
morrow
a
roaring
expedition
,
with
good
profit
in
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Again
the
Papists
?
"
asked
Dennis
,
rubbing
his
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
against
the
Papists
---
against
one
of
'em
at
least
,
that
some
of
us
,
and
I
for
one
,
owe
a
good
heavy
grudge
to
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
Muster
Gashford
's
friend
that
he
spoke
to
us
about
in
my
house
,
eh
?
"
said
Dennis
,
brimfull
of
pleasant
expectation
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
same
man
,
"
said
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
your
sort
,
"
cried
Mr
Dennis
,
gaily
shaking
hands
with
him
,
"
<EOS>
that
's
the
kind
of
game
.
 
<EOS>
Let
's
have
revenges
and
injuries
,
and
all
that
,
and
we
shall
get
on
twice
as
fast
.
 
<EOS>
Now
you
talk
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
The
captain
,
"
added
Hugh
,
"
has
thoughts
of
carrying
off
a
woman
in
the
bustle
,
and
---
ha
ha
ha
!
<EOS>
---
and
so
have
I
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dennis
received
this
part
of
the
scheme
with
a
wry
face
,
observing
that
as
a
general
principle
he
objected
to
women
altogether
,
as
being
unsafe
and
slippery
persons
on
whom
there
was
no
calculating
with
any
certainty
,
and
who
were
never
in
the
same
mind
for
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
at
a
stretch
.
 
<EOS>
He
might
have
expatiated
on
this
suggestive
theme
at
much
greater
length
,
but
that
it
occurred
to
him
to
ask
what
connection
existed
between
the
proposed
expedition
and
Barnaby
's
being
posted
at
the
stable
-
door
as
sentry
;
to
which
Hugh
cautiously
replied
in
these
words
:
  
"
Why
,
the
people
we
mean
to
visit
,
were
friends
of
his
,
once
upon
a
time
,
and
I
know
that
much
of
him
to
feel
pretty
sure
that
if
he
thought
we
were
going
to
do
them
any
harm
,
he
'd
be
no
friend
to
our
side
,
but
would
lend
a
ready
hand
to
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
've
persuaded
him
(
for
I
know
him
of
old
)
that
Lord
George
has
picked
him
out
to
guard
this
place
to
-
morrow
while
we
're
away
,
and
that
it
's
a
great
honour
---
and
so
he
's
on
duty
now
,
<EOS>
and
as
proud
of
it
as
if
he
was
a
general
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
say
to
me
for
a
careful
man
as
well
as
a
devil
of
a
one
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dennis
exhausted
himself
in
compliments
,
and
then
added
,
  
"
<EOS>
But
about
the
expedition
itself
---
"
  
"
About
that
,
"
said
Hugh
,
"
you
shall
hear
all
particulars
from
me
and
the
great
captain
conjointly
and
both
together
---
for
see
,
he
's
waking
up
.
 
<EOS>
Rouse
yourself
,
lion
-
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Put
a
good
face
upon
it
,
and
drink
again
.
 
<EOS>
Another
hair
of
the
dog
that
bit
you
,
captain
!
 
<EOS>
Call
for
drink
!
 
<EOS>
There
's
enough
of
gold
and
silver
cups
and
candlesticks
buried
underneath
my
bed
,
"
he
added
,
rolling
back
the
straw
,
and
pointing
to
where
the
ground
was
newly
turned
,
"
to
pay
for
it
,
if
it
was
a
score
of
casks
full
.
 
<EOS>
Drink
,
captain
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
received
these
jovial
promptings
with
a
very
bad
grace
,
being
much
the
worse
,
both
in
mind
and
body
,
for
his
two
nights
of
debauch
,
and
but
indifferently
able
to
stand
upon
his
legs
.
 
<EOS>
With
Hugh
's
assistance
,
however
,
he
contrived
to
stagger
to
the
pump
;
and
having
refreshed
himself
with
an
abundant
draught
of
cold
water
,
and
a
copious
shower
of
the
same
refreshing
liquid
on
his
head
and
face
,
he
ordered
some
rum
and
milk
to
be
served
;
and
upon
that
innocent
beverage
and
some
biscuits
and
cheese
made
a
pretty
hearty
meal
.
 
<EOS>
That
done
,
he
disposed
himself
in
an
easy
attitude
on
the
ground
beside
his
two
companions
(
who
were
carousing
after
their
own
tastes
)
,
and
proceeded
to
enlighten
Mr
Dennis
in
reference
to
to
-
morrow
's
project
.
  
<EOS>
That
their
conversation
was
an
interesting
one
,
was
rendered
manifest
by
its
length
,
and
by
the
close
attention
of
all
three
.
<EOS>
That
it
was
not
of
an
oppressively
grave
character
,
but
was
enlivened
by
various
pleasantries
arising
out
of
the
subject
,
was
clear
from
their
loud
and
frequent
roars
of
laughter
,
which
startled
Barnaby
on
his
post
,
and
made
him
wonder
at
their
levity
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
not
summoned
to
join
them
,
until
they
had
eaten
,
and
drunk
,
and
slept
,
and
talked
together
for
some
hours
;
<EOS>
not
,
indeed
,
until
the
twilight
;
when
they
informed
him
that
they
were
about
to
make
a
slight
demonstration
in
the
streets
---
just
to
keep
the
people
's
hands
in
,
as
it
was
Sunday
night
,
and
the
public
might
otherwise
be
disappointed
---
and
that
he
was
free
to
accompany
them
if
he
would
.
  
<EOS>
Without
the
slightest
preparation
,
saving
that
they
carried
clubs
and
wore
the
blue
cockade
,
they
sallied
out
into
the
streets
;
and
,
with
no
more
settled
design
than
that
of
doing
as
much
mischief
as
they
could
,
paraded
them
at
random
.
 
<EOS>
Their
numbers
rapidly
increasing
,
they
soon
divided
into
parties
;
and
agreeing
to
meet
by
-
and
-
by
,
in
the
fields
near
Welbeck
Street
,
scoured
the
town
in
various
directions
.
 
<EOS>
The
largest
body
,
and
that
which
augmented
with
the
greatest
rapidity
,
was
the
one
to
which
Hugh
and
Barnaby
belonged
.
 
<EOS>
This
took
its
way
towards
Moorfields
,
where
there
was
a
rich
chapel
,
and
in
which
neighbourhood
several
Catholic
families
were
known
to
reside
.
  
<EOS>
Beginning
with
<EOS>
the
private
houses
so
occupied
,
they
broke
open
the
doors
and
windows
;
and
while
they
destroyed
the
furniture
and
left
but
the
bare
walls
,
made
a
sharp
search
for
tools
and
engines
of
destruction
,
such
as
hammers
,
pokers
,
axes
,
saws
,
and
such
like
instruments
.
 
<EOS>
Many
of
the
rioters
made
belts
of
cord
,
of
handkerchiefs
,
or
any
material
they
found
at
hand
,
and
wore
these
weapons
as
openly
as
pioneers
upon
a
field
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
not
the
least
disguise
or
concealment
---
indeed
,
on
this
night
,
very
little
excitement
or
hurry
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
chapels
,
they
tore
down
and
took
away
the
very
altars
,
benches
,
pulpits
,
pews
,
and
flooring
;
from
the
dwelling
-
houses
,
the
very
wainscoting
and
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
This
Sunday
evening
's
recreation
<EOS>
they
pursued
like
mere
workmen
who
had
a
certain
task
to
do
,
and
did
it
.
 
<EOS>
Fifty
resolute
men
might
have
turned
them
at
any
moment
;
a
single
company
of
soldiers
could
have
scattered
them
like
dust
;
but
no
man
interposed
,
no
authority
restrained
them
,
and
,
except
by
the
terrified
persons
who
fled
from
their
approach
,
they
were
as
little
heeded
as
if
they
were
pursuing
their
lawful
occupations
with
the
utmost
sobriety
and
good
conduct
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
same
manner
,
they
marched
to
the
place
of
rendezvous
agreed
upon
,
made
great
fires
in
the
fields
,
and
reserving
the
most
valuable
of
their
spoils
,
burnt
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Priestly
garments
,
images
of
saints
,
rich
stuffs
and
ornaments
,
altar
-
furniture
and
household
goods
,
were
cast
into
the
flames
,
and
shed
a
glare
on
the
whole
country
round
;
but
they
danced
and
howled
,
and
roared
about
these
fires
till
they
were
tired
,
and
were
never
for
an
instant
checked
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
main
body
filed
off
from
this
scene
of
action
,
and
passed
down
Welbeck
Street
,
they
came
upon
Gashford
,
who
had
been
a
witness
of
their
proceedings
,
and
was
walking
stealthily
along
the
pavement
.
 
<EOS>
Keeping
up
with
him
,
and
yet
not
seeming
to
speak
,
Hugh
muttered
in
his
ear
:
  
"
<EOS>
Is
this
better
,
master
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Gashford
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
have
?
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fevers
are
never
at
their
height
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
They
must
get
on
by
degrees
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
have
you
,
"
said
Gashford
,
pinching
his
arm
with
such
malevolence
that
his
nails
seemed
to
meet
in
the
skin
;
"
I
would
have
you
put
some
meaning
into
your
work
.
 
<EOS>
Fools
!
 
<EOS>
Can
you
make
no
better
bonfires
than
of
rags
and
scraps
?
 
<EOS>
Can
you
burn
nothing
whole
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
A
little
patience
,
master
,
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Wait
but
a
few
hours
,
and
you
shall
see
.
 
<EOS>
Look
for
a
redness
in
the
sky
,
to
-
morrow
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
,
he
fell
back
into
his
place
beside
Barnaby
;
and
when
the
secretary
looked
after
him
,
both
were
lost
in
the
crowd
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
53
    
<EOS>
The
next
day
was
ushered
in
by
merry
peals
of
bells
,
and
by
the
firing
of
the
Tower
guns
;
flags
were
hoisted
on
many
of
the
church
-
steeples
;
the
usual
demonstrations
were
made
in
honour
of
the
anniversary
of
the
King
's
birthday
;
and
every
man
went
about
his
pleasure
or
business
as
if
the
city
were
in
perfect
order
,
and
there
were
no
half
-
smouldering
embers
in
its
secret
places
,
which
,
on
the
approach
of
night
,
would
kindle
up
again
and
scatter
ruin
and
dismay
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
The
leaders
of
the
riot
,
rendered
still
more
daring
by
the
success
of
last
night
and
by
the
booty
they
had
acquired
,
kept
steadily
together
,
and
only
thought
of
implicating
the
mass
of
their
followers
so
deeply
that
no
hope
of
pardon
or
reward
might
tempt
them
to
betray
their
more
notorious
confederates
into
the
hands
of
justice
.
  
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
sense
of
having
gone
too
far
to
be
forgiven
,
held
the
timid
together
no
less
than
the
bold
.
 
<EOS>
Many
who
would
readily
have
pointed
out
the
foremost
rioters
and
given
evidence
against
them
,
felt
that
escape
by
that
means
was
hopeless
,
when
their
every
act
had
been
observed
by
scores
of
people
who
had
taken
no
part
in
the
disturbances
;
who
had
suffered
in
their
persons
,
peace
,
or
property
,
by
the
outrages
of
the
mob
;
who
would
be
most
willing
witnesses
;
and
whom
the
government
would
,
no
doubt
,
prefer
to
any
King
's
evidence
that
might
be
offered
.
 
<EOS>
Many
of
this
class
had
deserted
their
usual
occupations
on
the
Saturday
morning
;
some
had
been
seen
by
their
employers
active
in
the
tumult
;
others
knew
they
must
be
suspected
,
and
that
they
would
be
discharged
if
they
returned
;
others
had
been
desperate
from
the
beginning
,
and
comforted
themselves
with
the
homely
proverb
,
that
,
being
hanged
at
all
,
they
might
as
well
be
hanged
for
a
sheep
as
a
lamb
.
 
<EOS>
They
all
hoped
and
believed
,
in
a
greater
or
less
degree
,
that
the
government
they
seemed
to
have
paralysed
,
would
,
in
its
terror
,
come
to
terms
with
them
in
the
end
,
and
suffer
them
to
make
their
own
conditions
.
 
<EOS>
The
least
sanguine
among
them
reasoned
with
himself
that
,
at
the
worst
,
they
were
too
many
to
be
all
punished
,
and
that
he
had
as
good
a
chance
of
escape
as
any
other
man
.
 
<EOS>
The
great
mass
never
reasoned
or
thought
at
all
,
but
were
stimulated
by
their
own
headlong
passions
,
by
poverty
,
by
ignorance
,
by
the
love
of
mischief
,
and
the
hope
of
plunder
.
  
<EOS>
One
other
circumstance
is
worthy
of
remark
;
and
that
is
,
that
from
the
moment
of
their
first
outbreak
at
Westminster
,
every
symptom
of
order
or
preconcerted
arrangement
among
them
vanished
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
divided
into
parties
and
ran
to
different
quarters
of
the
town
,
it
was
on
the
spontaneous
suggestion
of
the
moment
.
 
<EOS>
Each
party
swelled
as
it
went
along
,
like
rivers
as
they
roll
towards
the
sea
;
new
leaders
sprang
up
as
they
were
wanted
,
disappeared
when
the
necessity
was
over
,
and
reappeared
at
the
next
crisis
.
 
<EOS>
Each
tumult
took
shape
and
form
from
the
circumstances
of
the
moment
;
sober
workmen
,
going
home
from
their
day
's
labour
,
were
seen
to
cast
down
their
baskets
of
tools
and
become
rioters
in
an
instant
<EOS>
;
mere
boys
on
errands
did
the
like
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
a
moral
plague
ran
through
the
city
.
 
<EOS>
The
noise
,
and
hurry
,
and
excitement
,
had
for
hundreds
and
hundreds
an
attraction
they
had
no
firmness
to
resist
.
 
<EOS>
The
contagion
spread
like
a
dread
fever
:
an
infectious
madness
,
as
yet
not
near
its
height
,
seized
on
new
victims
every
hour
,
and
society
began
to
tremble
at
their
ravings
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
between
two
and
three
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
when
Gashford
looked
into
the
lair
described
in
the
last
chapter
,
and
seeing
only
Barnaby
and
Dennis
there
,
inquired
for
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
out
,
Barnaby
told
him
;
had
gone
out
more
than
an
hour
ago
;
and
had
not
yet
returned
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dennis
!
"
said
the
smiling
secretary
,
in
his
smoothest
voice
,
as
he
sat
down
cross
-
legged
on
a
barrel
,
"
Dennis
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
hangman
struggled
into
a
sitting
posture
directly
,
and
with
his
eyes
wide
open
,
looked
towards
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
Dennis
?
"
said
Gashford
,
nodding
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
have
suffered
no
inconvenience
from
your
late
exertions
,
Dennis
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
always
will
say
of
you
,
Muster
Gashford
,
"
returned
the
hangman
,
staring
at
him
,
"
that
that
'
ere
quiet
way
of
yours
might
almost
wake
a
dead
man
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
,
"
he
added
,
with
a
muttered
oath
---
still
staring
at
him
in
a
thoughtful
manner
---
"
so
awful
sly
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
distinct
,
eh
Dennis
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Distinct
!
"
<EOS>
he
answered
,
scratching
his
head
,
and
keeping
his
eyes
upon
the
secretary
's
face
;
"
I
seem
to
hear
it
,
Muster
Gashford
,
in
my
wery
bones
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
glad
your
sense
of
hearing
is
so
sharp
,
and
that
I
succeed
in
making
myself
so
intelligible
,
"
said
Gashford
,
in
his
unvarying
,
even
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
your
friend
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dennis
looked
round
as
in
expectation
of
beholding
him
asleep
upon
his
bed
of
straw
;
then
remembering
he
had
seen
him
go
out
,
replied
:
  
"
I
ca
n't
say
where
he
is
,
Muster
Gashford
,
I
expected
him
back
afore
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
it
is
n't
time
that
we
was
busy
,
Muster
Gashford
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nay
,
"
said
the
secretary
,
"
who
should
know
that
as
well
as
you
?
<EOS>
How
can
I
tell
you
,
Dennis
?
 
<EOS>
You
are
perfect
master
of
your
own
actions
,
you
know
,
and
accountable
to
nobody
---
except
sometimes
to
the
law
,
eh
?
"
  
<EOS>
Dennis
,
who
was
very
much
baffled
by
the
cool
matter
-
of
-
course
manner
of
this
reply
,
recovered
his
self
-
possession
on
his
professional
pursuits
being
referred
to
,
and
pointing
towards
Barnaby
,
shook
his
head
and
frowned
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
cried
Barnaby
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Do
hush
about
that
,
Muster
Gashford
,
"
said
the
hangman
in
a
low
voice
,
"
pop'lar
prejudices
<EOS>
---
you
always
forget
---
<EOS>
well
,
Barnaby
,
my
lad
,
what
's
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hear
him
coming
,
"
he
answered
:
"
<EOS>
Hark
!
 
<EOS>
Do
you
mark
that
?
 
<EOS>
That
's
his
foot
!
 
<EOS>
Bless
you
<EOS>
,
I
know
his
step
,
and
his
dog
's
too
.
 
<EOS>
Tramp
,
tramp
,
pit
-
pat
,
on
they
come
together
,
and
,
ha
ha
ha
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and
here
they
are
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
joyfully
welcoming
Hugh
with
both
hands
,
and
then
patting
him
fondly
on
the
back
,
as
if
instead
of
being
the
rough
companion
he
was
,
he
had
been
one
of
the
most
prepossessing
of
men
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is
,
and
safe
too
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
to
see
him
back
again
,
old
Hugh
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
Turk
if
he
do
n't
give
me
a
warmer
welcome
always
than
any
man
of
sense
,
"
said
Hugh
,
shaking
hands
with
him
with
a
kind
of
ferocious
friendship
,
strange
enough
to
see
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
,
boy
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hearty
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Barnaby
,
waving
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
And
merrry
too
,
Hugh
!
 
<EOS>
And
ready
to
do
anything
for
the
good
cause
,
and
the
right
,
and
to
help
the
kind
,
mild
,
pale
-
faced
gentleman
---
the
lord
they
used
<EOS>
so
ill
---
eh
,
Hugh
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
"
returned
his
friend
,
dropping
his
hand
,
and
looking
at
Gashford
for
an
instant
with
a
changed
expression
before
he
spoke
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
day
,
master
!
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
good
day
to
you
,
"
replied
the
secretary
,
nursing
his
leg
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
many
good
days
---
whole
years
of
them
,
I
hope
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
heated
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
would
you
have
been
,
master
,
"
said
Hugh
,
wiping
his
face
,
"
if
you
'd
been
running
here
as
fast
as
I
have
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
the
news
,
then
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
supposed
you
would
have
heard
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
News
!
<EOS>
what
news
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Gashford
,
raising
his
eyebrows
with
an
exclamation
of
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
Come
;
then
I
AM
the
first
to
make
you
acquainted
with
your
distinguished
position
,
after
all
.
<EOS>
Do
you
see
the
King
's
Arms
a
-
top
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
smilingly
asked
,
as
he
took
a
large
paper
from
his
pocket
,
unfolded
it
,
and
held
it
out
for
Hugh
's
inspection
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Much
.
 
<EOS>
A
great
deal
,
"
replied
the
secretary
.
 
<EOS>
"
Read
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
,
the
first
time
I
saw
you
,
that
I
could
n't
read
,
"
said
Hugh
,
impatiently
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
in
the
Devil
's
name
's
inside
of
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
proclamation
from
the
King
in
Council
,
"
said
Gashford
,
"
dated
to
-
day
,
and
offering
a
reward
of
five
hundred
pounds
---
five
hundred
pounds
is
a
great
deal
of
money
,
and
a
large
temptation
to
some
people
---
to
any
one
who
will
discover
the
person
or
persons
most
active
in
demolishing
those
chapels
on
Saturday
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
with
an
indifferent
air
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
of
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Truly
I
might
have
known
you
did
,
"
said
Gashford
,
smiling
,
and
folding
up
the
document
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
friend
,
I
might
have
guessed
---
 
indeed
I
did
guess
---
was
sure
to
tell
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
friend
!
"
stammered
Hugh
,
with
an
unsuccessful
effort
to
appear
surprised
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
friend
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tut
tut
<EOS>
---
do
you
suppose
I
do
n't
know
where
you
have
been
?
"
<EOS>
retorted
Gashford
,
rubbing
his
hands
,
and
beating
the
back
of
one
on
the
palm
of
the
other
,
and
looking
at
him
with
a
cunning
eye
.
<EOS>
"
How
dull
you
think
me
!
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
say
his
name
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Hugh
,
with
a
hasty
glance
towards
Dennis
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
also
heard
from
him
,
no
doubt
,
"
resumed
the
secretary
,
after
a
moment
's
pause
,
"
that
the
rioters
who
have
been
taken
(
poor
fellows
)
are
committed
for
trial
,
and
that
some
very
active
witnesses
have
had
the
temerity
to
appear
against
them
.
 
<EOS>
Among
others
---
"
and
here
he
clenched
his
teeth
,
as
if
he
would
suppress
by
force
some
violent
words
that
rose
upon
his
tongue
;
and
spoke
very
slowly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Among
others
,
a
gentleman
who
saw
the
work
going
on
in
Warwick
Street
;
a
Catholic
gentleman
;
one
Haredale
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
would
have
prevented
his
uttering
the
word
,
but
it
was
out
already
.
 
<EOS>
Hearing
the
name
,
Barnaby
turned
swiftly
round
.
  
<EOS>
"
Duty
,
duty
,
bold
Barnaby
!
"
cried
Hugh
,
assuming
his
wildest
and
most
rapid
manner
,
and
thrusting
into
his
hand
his
staff
and
flag
which
leant
against
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mount
guard
without
loss
of
time
,
for
we
are
off
upon
our
expedition
.
 
<EOS>
Up
,
Dennis
,
and
get
ready
!
<EOS>
Take
care
that
no
one
turns
the
straw
upon
my
bed
,
brave
Barnaby
;
we
know
what
's
underneath
it
---
eh
?
 
<EOS>
Now
,
master
,
quick
!
 
<EOS>
What
you
have
to
say
,
say
speedily
,
for
the
little
captain
and
a
cluster
of
'em
are
in
the
fields
,
and
only
waiting
for
us
.
 
<EOS>
Sharp
's
the
word
,
and
strike
's
the
action
.
 
<EOS>
Quick
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
was
not
proof
against
this
bustle
and
despatch
.
 
<EOS>
The
look
of
mingled
astonishtnent
and
anger
which
had
appeared
in
his
face
when
he
turned
towards
them
,
faded
from
it
as
the
words
passed
from
his
memory
,
like
breath
from
a
polished
mirror
;
and
grasping
the
weapon
which
Hugh
forced
upon
him
,
he
proudly
took
his
station
at
the
door
,
beyond
their
hearing
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
might
have
spoiled
our
plans
,
master
,
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
YOU
,
too
,
of
all
men
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
would
have
supposed
that
HE
would
be
so
quick
?
"
urged
Gashford
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
as
quick
sometimes
---
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mean
with
his
hands
,
for
that
you
know
,
but
with
his
head
---
as
you
or
any
man
,
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dennis
,
it
's
time
we
were
going
;
they
're
waiting
for
us
;
I
came
to
tell
you
.
 
<EOS>
Reach
me
my
stick
and
belt
.
 
<EOS>
Here
!
 
<EOS>
Lend
a
hand
,
master
.
<EOS>
Fling
this
over
my
shoulder
,
and
buckle
it
behind
,
will
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Brisk
as
ever
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
secretary
,
adjusting
it
for
him
as
he
desired
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
man
need
be
brisk
to
-
day
;
there
's
brisk
work
a
-
foot
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
,
is
there
?
"
said
Gashford
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
it
with
such
a
provoking
assumption
of
ignorance
,
that
Hugh
,
looking
over
his
shoulder
and
angrily
down
upon
him
,
replied
:
  
"
Is
there
!
 
<EOS>
You
know
there
is
!
 
<EOS>
Who
knows
better
than
you
,
master
,
that
the
first
great
step
to
be
taken
is
to
make
examples
of
these
witnesses
,
and
frighten
all
men
from
appearing
against
us
or
any
of
our
body
,
any
more
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
one
we
know
of
,
"
returned
Gashford
,
with
an
expressive
smile
,
"
who
is
at
least
as
well
informed
upon
that
subject
as
you
or
I.
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
we
mean
the
same
gentleman
,
as
I
suppose
we
do
,
"
Hugh
rejoined
softly
,
"
I
tell
you
this
<EOS>
---
he
's
as
good
and
quick
information
about
everything
as
---
<EOS>
"
here
he
paused
and
looked
round
,
as
if
to
make
sure
that
the
person
in
question
was
not
within
hearing
,
"
as
Old
Nick
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
done
that
,
master
?
 
<EOS>
How
slow
you
are
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
quite
fast
now
,
"
said
Gashford
,
rising
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
say
---
<EOS>
you
did
n't
find
that
your
friend
disapproved
of
to
-
day
's
little
expedition
?
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
fortunate
it
jumps
so
well
with
the
witness
policy
;
for
,
once
planned
,
it
must
have
been
carried
out
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
you
are
going
,
eh
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
we
are
going
,
master
!
"
<EOS>
Hugh
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Any
parting
words
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
,
no
,
"
said
Gashford
sweetly
.
 
<EOS>
"
None
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
sure
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
nudging
the
grinning
Dennis
.
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
sure
,
eh
,
Muster
Gashford
?
"
chuckled
the
hangman
.
  
<EOS>
Gashford
paused
a
moment
,
struggling
with
his
caution
and
his
malice
;
then
putting
himself
between
the
two
men
,
and
laying
a
hand
upon
the
arm
of
each
,
said
,
in
a
cramped
whisper
:
  
"
Do
not
,
my
good
friends
<EOS>
---
I
am
sure
you
will
not
---
forget
our
talk
one
night
---
in
your
house
,
Dennis
---
about
this
person
.
 
<EOS>
No
mercy
,
no
quarter
<EOS>
,
no
two
beams
of
his
house
to
be
left
standing
where
the
builder
placed
them
!
 
<EOS>
Fire
,
the
saying
goes
,
is
a
good
servant
,
but
a
bad
master
.
 
<EOS>
Makes
it
HIS
master
;
he
deserves
no
better
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
sure
you
will
be
firm
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
you
will
be
very
resolute
,
I
am
sure
you
will
remember
that
he
thirsts
for
your
lives
,
and
those
of
all
your
brave
companions
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
ever
acted
like
staunch
fellows
,
you
will
do
so
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
Wo
n't
you
,
Dennis
---
wo
n't
you
,
Hugh
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
two
looked
at
him
,
and
at
each
other
;
then
bursting
into
a
roar
of
laughter
,
brandished
their
staves
above
their
heads
,
shook
hands
,
and
hurried
out
.
  
<EOS>
When
they
had
been
gone
a
little
time
,
Gashford
followed
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
yet
in
sight
,
and
hastening
to
that
part
of
the
adjacent
fields
in
which
their
fellows
had
already
mustered
;
Hugh
was
looking
back
,
and
flourishing
his
hat
to
Barnaby
,
who
,
delighted
with
his
trust
,
replied
in
the
same
way
,
and
then
resumed
his
pacing
up
and
down
before
the
stable
-
door
,
where
his
feet
had
worn
a
path
already
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
Gashford
himself
was
far
distant
,
and
looked
back
for
the
last
time
,
he
was
still
walking
to
and
fro
,
with
the
same
measured
tread
;
the
most
devoted
and
the
blithest
champion
that
ever
maintained
a
post
,
and
felt
his
heart
lifted
up
with
a
brave
sense
of
duty
,
and
determination
to
defend
it
to
the
last
.
  
<EOS>
Smiling
at
the
simplicity
of
the
poor
idiot
,
Gashford
betook
himself
to
Welbeck
Street
by
a
different
path
from
that
which
he
knew
the
rioters
would
take
,
and
sitting
down
behind
a
curtain
in
one
of
the
upper
windows
of
Lord
George
Gordon
's
house
,
waited
impatiently
for
their
coming
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
so
long
,
that
although
he
knew
it
had
been
settled
they
should
come
that
way
,
he
had
a
misgiving
they
must
have
changed
their
plans
and
taken
some
other
route
.
 
<EOS>
But
at
length
the
roar
of
voices
was
heard
in
the
neighbouring
fields
,
and
soon
afterwards
they
came
thronging
past
,
in
a
great
body
.
  
<EOS>
However
,
they
were
not
all
,
nor
nearly
all
,
in
one
body
,
but
were
,
as
he
soon
found
,
divided
into
four
parties
,
each
of
which
stopped
before
the
house
to
give
three
cheers
,
and
then
went
on
;
the
leaders
crying
out
in
what
direction
they
were
going
,
and
calling
on
the
spectators
to
join
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
detachment
,
carrying
,
by
way
of
banners
,
some
relics
of
the
havoc
they
had
made
in
Moorfields
,
proclaimed
that
they
were
on
their
way
to
Chelsea
,
whence
they
would
return
in
the
same
order
,
to
make
of
the
spoil
they
bore
,
a
great
bonfire
,
near
at
hand
.
 
<EOS>
The
second
gave
out
that
they
were
bound
for
Wapping
,
to
destroy
a
chapel
;
the
third
,
that
their
place
of
destination
was
East
Smithfield
,
and
their
object
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
was
done
in
broad
,
bright
,
summer
day
.
 
<EOS>
Gay
carriages
and
chairs
stopped
to
let
them
pass
,
or
turned
back
to
avoid
them
;
people
on
foot
stood
aside
in
doorways
,
or
perhaps
knocked
and
begged
permission
to
stand
at
a
window
,
or
in
the
hall
,
until
the
rioters
had
passed
:
but
nobody
interfered
with
them
;
and
when
they
had
gone
by
,
everything
went
on
as
usual
.
  
<EOS>
There
still
remained
the
fourth
body
,
and
for
that
the
secretary
looked
with
a
most
intense
eagerness
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
it
came
up
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
numerous
,
and
composed
of
picked
men
;
for
as
he
gazed
down
among
them
,
he
recognised
many
upturned
faces
which
he
knew
well
---
those
of
Simon
Tappertit
,
Hugh
,
and
Dennis
in
the
front
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
They
halted
and
cheered
,
as
the
others
had
done
;
but
when
they
moved
again
,
they
did
not
,
like
them
,
proclaim
what
design
they
had
.
<EOS>
Hugh
merely
raised
his
hat
upon
the
bludgeon
he
carried
,
and
glancing
at
a
spectator
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
way
,
was
gone
.
  
<EOS>
Gashford
followed
the
direction
of
his
glance
instinctively
,
and
saw
,
standing
on
the
pavement
,
and
wearing
the
blue
cockade
,
Sir
John
Chester
.
 
<EOS>
He
held
his
hat
an
inch
or
two
above
his
head
,
to
propitiate
the
mob
;
and
,
resting
gracefully
on
his
cane
,
smiling
pleasantly
,
and
displaying
his
dress
and
person
to
the
very
best
advantage
,
looked
on
in
the
most
tranquil
state
imaginable
.
 
<EOS>
For
all
that
,
and
quick
and
dexterous
as
he
was
,
Gashford
had
seen
him
recognise
Hugh
with
the
air
of
a
patron
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
longer
any
eyes
for
the
crowd
,
but
fixed
his
keen
regards
upon
Sir
John
.
  
<EOS>
He
stood
in
the
same
place
and
posture
until
the
last
man
in
the
concourse
had
turned
the
corner
of
the
street
;
then
very
deliberately
took
the
blue
cockade
out
of
his
hat
;
put
it
carefully
in
his
pocket
,
ready
for
the
next
emergency
;
refreshed
himself
with
a
pinch
of
snuff
;
put
up
his
box
;
and
was
walking
slowly
off
,
when
a
passing
carriage
stopped
,
and
a
lady
's
hand
let
down
the
glass
.
<EOS>
Sir
John
's
hat
was
off
again
immediately
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
minute
's
conversation
at
the
carriage
-
window
,
in
which
it
was
apparent
that
he
was
vastly
entertaining
on
the
subject
of
the
mob
,
he
stepped
lightly
in
,
and
was
driven
away
.
  
<EOS>
The
secretary
smiled
,
but
he
had
other
thoughts
to
dwell
upon
,
and
soon
dismissed
the
topic
.
 
<EOS>
Dinner
was
brought
him
,
but
he
sent
it
down
untasted
;
and
,
in
restless
pacings
up
and
down
the
room
,
and
constant
glances
at
the
clock
,
and
many
futile
efforts
to
sit
down
and
read
,
or
go
to
sleep
,
or
look
out
of
the
window
,
consumed
four
weary
hours
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
dial
told
him
thus
much
time
had
crept
away
,
he
stole
upstairs
to
the
top
of
the
house
,
and
coming
out
upon
the
roof
sat
down
,
with
his
face
towards
the
east
.
  
<EOS>
Heedless
of
the
fresh
air
that
blew
upon
his
heated
brow
,
of
the
pleasant
meadows
from
which
he
turned
,
of
the
piles
of
roofs
and
chimneys
upon
which
he
looked
,
of
the
smoke
and
rising
mist
he
vainly
sought
to
pierce
,
of
the
shrill
cries
of
children
at
their
evening
sports
,
<EOS>
the
distant
hum
and
turmoil
of
the
town
,
the
cheerful
country
breath
that
rustled
past
to
meet
it
,
and
to
droop
,
and
die
;
he
watched
,
and
watched
,
till
it
was
dark
save
for
the
specks
of
light
that
twinkled
in
the
streets
below
and
far
away
---
 
and
,
as
the
darkness
deepened
,
strained
his
gaze
and
grew
more
eager
yet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
but
gloom
in
that
direction
,
still
!
"
he
muttered
restlessly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dog
!
<EOS>
where
is
the
redness
in
the
sky
,
you
promised
me
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
54
    
Rumours
of
the
prevailing
disturbances
had
,
by
this
time
,
begun
to
be
pretty
generally
circulated
through
the
towns
and
villages
round
London
,
and
the
tidings
were
everywhere
received
with
that
appetite
for
the
marvellous
and
love
of
the
terrible
which
have
probably
been
among
the
natural
characteristics
of
mankind
since
the
creation
of
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
These
accounts
,
however
,
appeared
,
to
many
persons
at
that
day
---
as
they
would
to
us
at
the
present
,
but
that
we
know
them
to
be
matter
of
history
---
so
monstrous
and
improbable
,
that
a
great
number
of
those
who
were
resident
at
a
distance
,
and
who
were
credulous
enough
on
other
points
,
were
really
unable
to
bring
their
minds
to
believe
that
such
things
could
be
;
and
rejected
the
intelligence
they
received
on
all
hands
,
as
wholly
fabulous
and
absurd
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
---
not
so
much
,
perhaps
,
on
account
of
his
having
argued
and
settled
the
matter
with
himself
,
as
by
reason
of
his
constitutional
obstinacy
---
was
one
of
those
who
positively
refused
to
entertain
the
current
topic
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
On
this
very
evening
,
and
perhaps
at
the
very
time
when
Gashford
kept
his
solitary
watch
,
old
John
was
so
red
in
the
face
with
perpetually
shaking
his
head
in
contradiction
of
his
three
ancient
cronies
and
pot
companions
,
that
he
was
quite
a
phenomenon
to
behold
,
and
lighted
up
the
Maypole
Porch
<EOS>
wherein
they
sat
together
,
like
a
monstrous
carbuncle
in
a
fairy
tale
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Willet
,
looking
hard
at
Solomon
Daisy
---
for
it
was
his
custom
in
cases
of
personal
altercation
to
fasten
upon
the
smallest
man
in
the
party
---
"
do
you
think
,
sir
,
that
I
'm
a
born
fool
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
no
,
Johnny
,
"
returned
Solomon
,
looking
round
upon
the
little
circle
of
which
he
formed
a
part
:
"
We
all
know
better
than
that
.
<EOS>
You
're
no
fool
,
Johnny
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Cobb
and
Mr
Parkes
shook
their
heads
in
unison
,
muttering
,
"
No
,
no
,
Johnny
,
not
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
But
as
such
compliments
had
usually
the
effect
of
making
Mr
Willet
rather
more
dogged
than
before
,
he
surveyed
them
with
a
look
of
deep
disdain
,
and
returned
for
answer
:
  
"
<EOS>
Then
what
do
you
mean
by
coming
here
,
and
telling
me
that
this
evening
you
're
a
-
going
to
walk
up
to
London
together
---
you
three
---
 
you
---
and
have
the
evidence
of
your
own
senses
?
 
<EOS>
An't
,
"
said
Mr
Willet
,
putting
his
pipe
in
his
mouth
with
an
air
of
solemn
disgust
,
"
<EOS>
an't
<EOS>
the
evidence
of
MY
senses
enough
for
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
we
have
n't
got
it
,
Johnny
,
"
pleaded
Parkes
,
humbly
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
n't
got
it
,
sir
?
"
repeated
Mr
Willet
,
eyeing
him
from
top
to
toe
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
n't
got
it
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
You
HAVE
got
it
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
I
tell
you
that
His
blessed
Majesty
King
George
the
Third
would
no
more
stand
a
rioting
and
rollicking
in
his
streets
,
than
he
'd
stand
being
crowed
over
by
his
own
Parliament
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Johnny
,
but
that
's
your
sense
---
not
your
senses
,
"
said
the
adventurous
Mr
Parkes
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
?
 
<EOS>
"
retorted
John
with
great
dignity
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
contradicting
pretty
free
,
you
are
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
How
do
YOU
know
which
it
is
?
 
<EOS>
I
'm
not
aware
I
ever
told
you
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Parkes
,
finding
himself
in
the
position
of
having
got
into
metaphysics
without
exactly
seeing
his
way
out
of
them
,
stammered
forth
an
apology
and
retreated
from
the
argument
.
 
<EOS>
There
then
ensued
a
silence
of
some
ten
minutes
or
a
quarter
of
an
hour
,
at
the
expiration
of
which
period
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
was
observed
to
rumble
and
shake
with
laughter
,
and
presently
remarked
,
in
reference
to
his
late
adversary
,
"
that
he
hoped
he
had
tackled
him
enough
.
"
<EOS>
Thereupon
Messrs
Cobb
and
Daisy
laughed
,
and
nodded
,
and
Parkes
was
looked
upon
as
thoroughly
and
effectually
put
down
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
suppose
if
all
this
was
true
,
that
Mr
Haredale
would
be
constantly
away
from
home
,
as
he
is
?
"
said
John
,
after
another
silence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
he
would
n't
be
afraid
to
leave
his
house
with
them
two
young
women
in
it
,
and
only
a
couple
of
men
,
or
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
but
then
you
know
,
"
returned
Solomon
Daisy
,
"
his
house
is
a
goodish
way
out
of
London
,
and
they
do
say
that
the
rioters
wo
n't
go
more
than
two
miles
,
or
three
at
the
farthest
,
off
the
stones
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
you
know
,
some
of
the
Catholic
gentlefolks
have
actually
sent
trinkets
and
suchlike
down
here
for
safety
---
at
least
,
so
the
story
goes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
story
goes
!
"
said
Mr
Willet
testily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
The
story
goes
that
you
saw
a
ghost
last
March
.
 
<EOS>
But
nobody
believes
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
"
said
Solomon
,
rising
,
to
divert
the
attention
of
his
two
friends
,
who
tittered
at
this
retort
:
"
believed
or
disbelieved
,
it
's
true
;
and
true
or
not
,
if
we
mean
to
go
to
London
,
we
must
be
going
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
So
shake
hands
,
Johnny
,
and
good
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
shake
hands
,
"
returned
the
landlord
,
putting
his
into
his
pockets
,
"
with
no
man
as
goes
to
London
on
such
nonsensical
errands
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
three
cronies
were
therefore
reduced
to
the
necessity
of
shaking
his
elbows
;
having
performed
that
ceremony
,
and
brought
from
the
house
their
hats
,
and
sticks
,
and
greatcoats
,
they
bade
him
good
night
and
departed
;
promising
to
bring
him
on
the
morrow
full
and
true
accounts
of
the
real
state
of
the
city
,
and
if
it
were
quiet
,
to
give
him
the
full
merit
of
his
victory
.
  
<EOS>
John
Willet
looked
after
them
,
as
they
plodded
along
the
road
in
the
rich
glow
of
a
summer
evening
;
and
knocking
the
ashes
out
of
his
pipe
,
laughed
inwardly
at
their
folly
,
until
his
sides
were
sore
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
quite
exhausted
himself
---
which
took
some
time
,
for
he
laughed
as
slowly
as
he
thought
and
spoke
---
he
sat
himself
comfortably
with
his
back
to
the
house
,
put
his
legs
upon
the
bench
,
then
his
apron
over
his
face
,
and
fell
sound
asleep
.
  
<EOS>
How
long
he
slept
,
matters
not
;
but
it
was
for
no
brief
space
,
for
when
he
awoke
,
the
rich
light
had
faded
<EOS>
,
the
sombre
hues
of
night
were
falling
fast
upon
the
landscape
,
and
a
few
bright
stars
were
already
twinkling
overhead
.
 
<EOS>
The
birds
were
all
at
roost
,
the
daisies
on
the
green
had
closed
their
fairy
hoods
,
the
honeysuckle
twining
round
the
porch
exhaled
its
perfume
in
a
twofold
degree
,
as
though
it
lost
its
coyness
at
that
silent
time
and
loved
to
shed
its
fragrance
on
the
night
;
the
ivy
scarcely
stirred
its
deep
green
leaves
.
 
<EOS>
How
tranquil
,
and
how
beautiful
it
was
!
  
<EOS>
Was
there
no
sound
in
the
air
,
besides
the
gentle
rustling
of
the
trees
and
the
grasshopper
's
merry
chirp
?
 
<EOS>
Hark
!
 
<EOS>
Something
very
faint
and
distant
,
not
unlike
the
murmuring
in
a
sea
-
shell
.
 
<EOS>
Now
it
grew
louder
,
fainter
now
,
and
now
it
altogether
died
away
.
<EOS>
Presently
,
it
came
again
,
subsided
,
came
once
more
,
grew
louder
,
fainter
---
swelled
into
a
roar
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
on
the
road
,
and
varied
with
its
windings
.
 
<EOS>
All
at
once
it
burst
into
a
distinct
sound
---
the
voices
,
and
the
tramping
feet
of
many
men
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
questionable
whether
old
John
Willet
,
even
then
,
would
have
thought
of
the
rioters
but
for
the
cries
of
his
cook
and
housemaid
,
who
ran
screaming
upstairs
and
locked
themselves
into
one
of
the
old
garrets
,
---
shrieking
dismally
when
they
had
done
so
,
by
way
of
rendering
their
place
of
refuge
perfectly
secret
and
secure
.
 
<EOS>
These
two
females
did
afterwards
depone
that
Mr
Willet
in
his
consternation
uttered
but
one
word
,
and
called
that
up
the
stairs
in
a
stentorian
voice
,
six
distinct
times
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
this
word
was
a
monosyllable
,
which
,
however
inoffensive
when
applied
to
the
quadruped
it
denotes
,
is
highly
reprehensible
when
used
in
connection
with
females
of
unimpeachable
character
,
many
persons
were
inclined
to
believe
that
the
young
women
laboured
under
some
hallucination
caused
by
excessive
fear
;
and
that
their
ears
deceived
them
.
  
<EOS>
Be
this
as
it
may
,
John
Willet
,
in
whom
the
very
uttermost
extent
of
dull
-
headed
perplexity
supplied
the
place
of
courage
,
stationed
himself
in
the
porch
,
and
waited
for
their
coming
up
.
 
<EOS>
Once
,
it
dimly
occurred
to
him
that
there
was
a
kind
of
door
to
the
house
,
which
had
a
lock
and
bolts
;
and
at
the
same
time
some
shadowy
ideas
of
shutters
to
the
lower
windows
,
flitted
through
his
brain
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
stood
stock
still
,
looking
down
the
road
in
the
direction
in
which
the
noise
was
rapidly
advancing
,
and
did
not
so
much
as
take
his
hands
out
of
his
pockets
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
to
wait
long
.
 
<EOS>
A
dark
mass
,
looming
through
a
cloud
of
dust
,
soon
became
visible
;
the
mob
quickened
their
pace
;
shouting
and
whooping
like
savages
,
they
came
rushing
on
pell
mell
;
and
in
a
few
seconds
he
was
bandied
from
hand
to
hand
,
in
the
heart
of
a
crowd
of
men
.
  
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
"
cried
a
voice
he
knew
,
as
the
man
who
spoke
came
cleaving
through
the
throng
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
?
 
<EOS>
Give
him
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
hurt
him
.
 
<EOS>
How
now
,
old
Jack
!
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
looked
at
him
,
and
saw
it
was
Hugh
;
but
he
said
nothing
,
and
thought
nothing
.
  
<EOS>
"
These
lads
are
thirsty
and
must
drink
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
thrusting
him
back
towards
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bustle
,
Jack
,
bustle
.
 
<EOS>
Show
us
the
best
---
 
the
very
best
---
the
over
-
proof
that
you
keep
for
your
own
drinking
,
Jack
!
"
  
<EOS>
John
faintly
articulated
the
words
,
"
Who
's
to
pay
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
says
"
Who
's
to
pay
?
"
<EOS>
"
cried
Hugh
,
with
a
roar
of
laughter
which
was
loudly
echoed
by
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
Then
turning
to
John
,
he
added
,
"
Pay
!
<EOS>
Why
,
nobody
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
John
stared
round
at
the
mass
of
faces
---
some
grinning
,
<EOS>
some
fierce
,
some
lighted
up
by
torches
,
some
indistinct
,
some
dusky
and
shadowy
:
<EOS>
some
looking
at
him
,
some
at
his
house
,
some
at
each
other
---
and
while
he
was
,
as
he
thought
,
in
the
very
act
of
doing
so
,
found
himself
,
without
any
consciousness
of
having
moved
,
in
the
bar
;
sitting
down
in
an
arm
-
chair
,
and
watching
the
destruction
of
his
property
,
as
if
it
were
some
queer
play
or
entertainment
,
of
an
astonishing
and
stupefying
nature
,
but
having
no
reference
to
himself
---
that
he
could
make
out
---
at
all
.
  
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Here
was
the
bar
---
the
bar
that
the
boldest
never
entered
without
special
invitation
---
the
sanctuary
,
the
mystery
,
the
hallowed
ground
:
here
it
was
,
crammed
with
men
,
clubs
,
sticks
,
torches
,
pistols
;
filled
with
a
deafening
noise
,
oaths
,
shouts
,
screams
,
hootings
;
changed
all
at
once
into
a
bear
-
garden
,
a
madhouse
,
an
infernal
temple
:
<EOS>
men
darting
in
and
out
,
by
door
and
window
,
smashing
the
glass
,
turning
the
taps
,
drinking
liquor
out
of
China
punchbowls
,
sitting
astride
of
casks
,
smoking
private
and
personal
pipes
,
cutting
down
the
sacred
grove
of
lemons
,
hacking
and
hewing
at
the
celebrated
cheese
,
breaking
open
inviolable
drawers
,
putting
things
in
their
pockets
which
did
n't
belong
to
them
,
dividing
his
own
money
before
his
own
eyes
,
wantonly
wasting
,
breaking
,
pulling
down
and
tearing
up
:
nothing
quiet
,
nothing
private
:
men
everywhere
---
above
,
below
,
overhead
,
in
the
bedrooms
,
in
the
kitchen
,
in
the
yard
,
in
the
stables
---
clambering
in
at
windows
when
there
were
doors
wide
open
;
dropping
out
of
windows
when
the
stairs
were
handy
;
leaping
over
the
bannisters
into
chasms
of
passages
:
new
faces
and
figures
presenting
themselves
every
instant
---
some
yelling
,
some
singing
,
some
fighting
,
some
breaking
glass
and
crockery
,
some
laying
the
dust
with
the
liquor
they
could
n't
drink
,
some
ringing
the
bells
till
they
pulled
them
down
,
others
beating
them
with
pokers
till
they
beat
them
into
fragments
:
more
men
still
---
more
,
more
,
more
---
swarming
on
like
insects
:
<EOS>
noise
,
smoke
,
light
,
darkness
,
frolic
,
anger
,
laughter
,
groans
,
plunder
,
fear
,
and
ruin
!
  
<EOS>
Nearly
all
the
time
while
John
looked
on
at
this
bewildering
scene
,
Hugh
kept
near
him
;
and
though
he
was
the
loudest
,
wildest
,
most
destructive
villain
there
,
he
saved
his
old
master
's
bones
a
score
of
times
.
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
even
when
Mr
Tappertit
,
excited
by
liquor
,
came
up
,
and
in
assertion
of
his
prerogative
politely
kicked
John
Willet
on
the
shins
,
Hugh
bade
him
return
the
compliment
;
and
if
old
John
had
had
sufficient
presence
of
mind
to
understand
this
whispered
direction
,
and
to
profit
by
it
,
he
might
no
doubt
,
under
Hugh
's
protection
,
have
done
so
with
impunity
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
the
band
began
to
reassemble
outside
the
house
,
and
to
call
to
those
within
,
to
join
them
,
for
they
were
losing
time
.
<EOS>
These
murmurs
increasing
,
and
attaining
a
high
pitch
,
Hugh
,
and
some
of
those
who
yet
lingered
in
the
bar
,
and
who
plainly
were
the
leaders
of
the
troop
,
took
counsel
together
,
apart
,
as
to
what
was
to
be
done
with
John
,
to
keep
him
quiet
until
their
Chigwell
work
was
over
.
 
<EOS>
Some
proposed
to
set
the
house
on
fire
and
leave
him
in
it
;
others
,
that
he
should
be
reduced
to
a
state
of
temporary
insensibility
,
by
knocking
on
the
head
;
others
,
that
he
should
be
sworn
to
sit
where
he
was
until
to
-
morrow
at
the
same
hour
;
others
again
,
that
he
should
be
gagged
and
taken
off
with
them
,
under
a
sufficient
guard
.
 
<EOS>
All
these
propositions
being
overruled
,
it
was
concluded
,
at
last
,
to
bind
him
in
his
chair
,
and
the
word
was
passed
for
Dennis
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look'ee
here
,
Jack
!
"
said
Hugh
,
striding
up
to
him
:
"
We
are
going
to
tie
you
,
hand
and
foot
,
but
otherwise
you
wo
n't
be
hurt
.
 
<EOS>
D'ye
hear
?
"
  
<EOS>
John
Willet
looked
at
another
man
,
as
if
he
did
n't
know
which
was
the
speaker
,
and
muttered
something
about
an
ordinary
every
Sunday
at
two
o'clock
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
be
hurt
<EOS>
I
tell
you
,
Jack
---
<EOS>
do
you
hear
me
?
"
<EOS>
roared
Hugh
,
impressing
the
assurance
upon
him
by
means
of
a
heavy
blow
on
the
back
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
so
dead
scared
,
he
's
woolgathering
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
Give
him
a
drop
of
something
to
drink
here
.
 
<EOS>
Hand
over
,
one
of
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
glass
of
liquor
being
passed
forward
,
Hugh
poured
the
contents
down
old
John
's
throat
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
feebly
smacked
his
lips
,
thrust
his
hand
into
his
pocket
,
and
inquired
what
was
to
pay
;
adding
,
as
he
looked
vacantly
round
,
that
he
believed
there
was
a
trifle
of
broken
glass
---
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
out
of
his
senses
for
the
time
,
it
's
my
belief
,
"
said
Hugh
,
after
shaking
him
,
without
any
visible
effect
upon
his
system
,
until
his
keys
rattled
in
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
's
that
Dennis
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
word
was
again
passed
,
and
presently
Mr
Dennis
,
with
a
long
cord
bound
about
his
middle
,
something
after
the
manner
of
a
friar
,
came
hurrying
in
,
attended
by
a
body
-
guard
of
half
-
a
-
dozen
of
his
men
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Be
alive
here
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
stamping
his
foot
upon
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
"
Make
haste
!
"
  
<EOS>
Dennis
,
with
a
wink
and
a
nod
,
unwound
the
cord
from
about
his
person
,
and
raising
his
eyes
to
the
ceiling
,
looked
all
over
it
,
and
round
the
walls
and
cornice
,
with
a
curious
eye
;
then
shook
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Move
,
man
,
ca
n't
you
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
with
another
impatient
stamp
of
his
foot
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
we
to
wait
here
,
<EOS>
till
the
cry
has
gone
for
ten
miles
round
,
and
our
work
's
interrupted
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
very
fine
talking
,
brother
,
"
answered
Dennis
,
stepping
towards
him
;
"
but
unless
---
"
and
here
he
whispered
in
his
ear
---
 
"
unless
we
do
it
over
the
door
,
it
ca
n't
be
done
at
all
in
this
here
room
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
ca
n't
?
"
<EOS>
Hugh
demanded
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
ca
n't
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Dennis
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
old
man
ca
n't
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
were
n't
going
to
hang
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
brother
?
"
returned
the
hangman
with
a
stare
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
else
?
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
made
no
answer
,
but
snatching
the
rope
from
his
companion
's
hand
,
proceeded
to
bind
old
John
himself
;
but
his
very
first
move
was
so
bungling
and
unskilful
,
that
Mr
Dennis
entreated
,
almost
with
tears
in
his
eyes
,
that
he
might
be
permitted
to
perform
the
duty
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
consenting
,
be
achieved
it
in
a
twinkling
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
"
he
said
,
looking
mournfully
at
John
Willet
,
who
displayed
no
more
emotion
in
his
bonds
than
he
had
shown
out
of
them
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
what
I
call
pretty
and
workmanlike
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
quite
a
picter
now
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
brother
,
just
a
word
with
you
---
now
that
he
's
ready
trussed
,
as
one
may
say
,
would
n't
it
be
better
for
all
parties
if
we
was
to
work
him
off
?
 
<EOS>
It
would
read
uncommon
well
in
the
newspapers
,
it
would
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
The
public
would
think
a
great
deal
more
on
us
!
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
,
inferring
what
his
companion
meant
,
rather
from
his
gestures
than
his
technical
mode
of
expressing
himself
(
to
which
,
as
he
was
ignorant
of
his
calling
,
he
wanted
the
clue
)
,
rejected
this
proposition
for
the
second
time
,
and
gave
the
word
"
Forward
!
"
<EOS>
which
was
echoed
by
a
hundred
voices
from
without
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
the
Warren
!
"
shouted
Dennis
as
he
ran
out
,
followed
by
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
witness
's
house
,
my
lads
!
"
  
<EOS>
A
loud
yell
followed
,
and
the
whole
throng
hurried
off
,
mad
for
pillage
and
destruction
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
lingered
behind
for
a
few
moments
to
stimulate
himself
with
more
drink
,
and
to
set
all
the
taps
running
,
a
few
of
which
had
accidentally
been
spared
;
then
,
glancing
round
the
despoiled
and
plundered
room
,
through
whose
shattered
window
the
rioters
had
thrust
the
Maypole
itself
,
---
for
even
that
had
been
sawn
down
,
---
<EOS>
lighted
a
torch
,
clapped
the
mute
and
motionless
John
Willet
on
the
back
,
and
waving
his
light
above
his
head
,
and
uttering
a
fierce
shout
,
hastened
after
his
companions
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
55
    
John
Willet
,
left
alone
in
his
dismantled
bar
,
continued
to
sit
staring
about
him
;
awake
as
to
his
eyes
,
certainly
,
but
with
all
his
powers
of
reason
and
reflection
in
a
sound
and
dreamless
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
round
upon
the
room
which
had
been
for
years
,
and
was
within
an
hour
ago
,
the
pride
of
his
heart
;
and
not
a
muscle
of
his
face
was
moved
.
 
<EOS>
The
night
,
without
,
looked
black
and
cold
through
the
dreary
gaps
in
the
casement
;
the
precious
liquids
,
now
nearly
leaked
away
,
dripped
with
a
hollow
sound
upon
the
floor
;
the
Maypole
peered
ruefully
in
through
the
broken
window
,
like
the
bowsprit
of
a
wrecked
ship
;
the
ground
might
have
been
the
bottom
of
the
sea
,
it
was
so
strewn
with
precious
fragments
.
 
<EOS>
Currents
of
air
rushed
in
,
as
the
old
doors
jarred
and
creaked
upon
their
hinges
;
the
candles
flickered
and
guttered
down
,
and
made
long
winding
-
sheets
;
the
cheery
deep
-
red
curtains
flapped
and
fluttered
idly
in
the
wind
;
even
the
stout
Dutch
kegs
,
overthrown
and
lying
empty
in
dark
corners
,
seemed
the
mere
husks
of
good
fellows
whose
jollity
had
departed
,
and
who
could
kindle
with
a
friendly
glow
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
John
saw
this
desolation
,
and
yet
saw
it
not
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
perfectly
contented
to
sit
there
,
staring
at
it
,
and
felt
no
more
indignation
or
discomfort
in
his
bonds
than
if
they
had
been
robes
of
honour
.
 
<EOS>
So
far
as
he
was
personally
concerned
,
old
Time
lay
snoring
,
and
the
world
stood
still
.
  
<EOS>
Save
for
the
dripping
from
the
barrels
,
the
rustling
of
such
light
fragments
of
destruction
as
the
wind
affected
,
and
the
dull
creaking
of
the
open
doors
,
all
was
profoundly
quiet
:
<EOS>
indeed
,
these
sounds
,
like
the
ticking
of
the
death
-
watch
in
the
night
,
only
made
the
silence
they
invaded
deeper
and
more
apparent
.
 
<EOS>
But
quiet
or
noisy
,
it
was
all
one
to
John
.
 
<EOS>
If
a
train
of
heavy
artillery
could
have
come
up
and
commenced
ball
practice
outside
the
window
,
it
would
have
been
all
the
same
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
long
way
beyond
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
A
ghost
could
n't
have
overtaken
him
.
  
<EOS>
By
and
by
he
heard
a
footstep
---
a
hurried
,
and
yet
cautious
footstep
---
coming
on
towards
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
It
stopped
,
advanced
again
,
then
seemed
to
go
quite
round
it
.
 
<EOS>
Having
done
that
,
it
came
beneath
the
window
,
and
a
head
looked
in
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
strongly
relieved
against
the
darkness
outside
by
the
glare
of
the
guttering
candles
.
 
<EOS>
A
pale
,
worn
,
withered
face
;
the
eyes
---
 
but
that
was
owing
to
its
gaunt
condition
---
unnaturally
large
and
bright
;
the
hair
,
a
grizzled
black
.
 
<EOS>
It
gave
a
searching
glance
<EOS>
all
round
the
room
,
and
a
deep
voice
said
:
  
"
Are
you
alone
in
this
house
?
"
  
<EOS>
John
made
no
sign
,
though
the
question
was
repeated
twice
,
and
he
heard
it
distinctly
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
moment
's
pause
,
the
man
got
in
at
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
John
was
not
at
all
surprised
at
this
,
either
.
 
<EOS>
There
had
been
so
much
getting
in
and
out
of
window
in
the
course
of
the
last
hour
or
so
,
that
he
had
quite
forgotten
the
door
,
and
seemed
to
have
lived
among
such
exercises
from
infancy
.
  
<EOS>
The
man
wore
a
large
,
dark
,
faded
cloak
,
and
a
slouched
hat
;
he
walked
up
close
to
John
,
and
looked
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
John
returned
the
compliment
with
interest
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
long
have
you
been
sitting
thus
?
"
said
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
John
considered
,
but
nothing
came
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Which
way
have
the
party
gone
?
"
  
<EOS>
Some
wandering
speculations
relative
to
the
fashion
of
the
stranger
's
boots
,
got
into
Mr
Willet
's
mind
by
some
accident
or
other
,
but
they
got
out
again
in
a
hurry
,
and
left
him
in
his
former
state
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
would
do
well
to
speak
,
"
said
the
man
;
"
you
may
keep
a
whole
skin
,
though
you
have
nothing
else
left
that
can
be
hurt
.
 
<EOS>
Which
way
have
the
party
gone
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
That
!
"
said
John
,
finding
his
voice
all
at
once
,
and
nodding
with
perfect
good
faith
---
he
could
n't
point
;
he
was
so
tightly
bound
---
in
exactly
the
opposite
direction
to
the
right
one
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
lie
!
"
said
the
man
angrily
,
and
with
a
threatening
gesture
.
<EOS>
"
I
came
that
way
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
betray
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
so
evident
that
John
's
imperturbability
was
not
assumed
,
but
was
the
result
of
the
late
proceedings
under
his
roof
,
that
the
man
stayed
his
hand
in
the
very
act
of
striking
him
,
and
turned
away
.
  
<EOS>
John
looked
after
him
without
so
much
as
a
twitch
in
a
single
nerve
of
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
He
seized
a
glass
,
and
holding
it
under
one
of
the
little
casks
until
a
few
drops
were
collected
,
drank
them
greedily
off
;
then
throwing
it
down
upon
the
floor
impatiently
,
he
took
the
vessel
in
his
hands
and
drained
it
into
his
throat
.
 
<EOS>
Some
scraps
of
bread
and
meat
were
scattered
about
,
and
on
these
he
fell
next
;
eating
them
with
voracity
,
and
pausing
every
now
and
then
to
listen
for
some
fancied
noise
outside
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
refreshed
himself
in
this
manner
with
violent
haste
,
and
raised
another
barrel
to
his
lips
,
he
pulled
his
hat
upon
his
brow
as
though
he
were
about
to
leave
the
house
,
and
turned
to
John
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
are
your
servants
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
indistinctly
remembered
to
have
heard
the
rioters
calling
to
them
to
throw
the
key
of
the
room
in
which
they
were
,
out
of
window
,
for
their
keeping
.
 
<EOS>
He
therefore
replied
,
"
Locked
up
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
for
them
if
they
remain
quiet
,
and
well
for
you
if
you
do
the
like
,
"
said
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
show
me
the
way
the
party
went
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
time
Mr
Willet
indicated
it
correctly
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
was
hurrying
to
the
door
,
when
suddenly
there
came
towards
them
on
the
wind
,
the
loud
and
rapid
tolling
of
an
alarm
-
bell
,
and
then
a
bright
and
vivid
glare
streamed
up
,
which
illumined
,
not
only
the
whole
chamber
,
but
all
the
country
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
the
sudden
change
from
darkness
to
this
dreadful
light
,
it
was
not
the
sound
of
distant
shrieks
and
shouts
of
triumph
,
it
was
not
this
dread
invasion
of
the
serenity
and
peace
of
night
,
that
drove
the
man
back
as
though
a
thunderbolt
had
struck
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
Bell
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
ghastliest
shape
the
human
mind
has
ever
pictured
in
its
wildest
dreams
had
risen
up
before
him
,
he
could
not
have
staggered
backward
from
its
touch
,
as
he
did
from
the
first
sound
of
that
loud
iron
voice
.
 
<EOS>
With
eyes
that
started
from
his
head
,
his
limbs
convulsed
,
his
face
most
horrible
to
see
,
he
raised
one
arm
high
up
into
the
air
,
and
holding
something
visionary
back
and
down
,
with
his
other
hand
,
drove
at
it
as
though
he
held
a
knife
and
stabbed
it
to
the
heart
.
 
<EOS>
He
clutched
his
hair
,
and
stopped
his
ears
,
and
travelled
madly
round
and
round
;
then
gave
a
frightful
cry
,
and
with
it
rushed
away
:
still
,
still
,
the
Bell
tolled
on
and
seemed
to
follow
him
---
louder
and
louder
,
hotter
and
hotter
yet
.
 
<EOS>
The
glare
grew
brighter
,
the
roar
of
voices
deeper
;
the
crash
of
heavy
bodies
falling
,
shook
the
air
;
bright
streams
of
sparks
rose
up
into
the
sky
;
but
louder
than
them
all
---
 
rising
faster
far
,
to
Heaven
---
a
million
times
more
fierce
and
furious
---
pouring
forth
dreadful
secrets
after
its
long
silence
---
 
speaking
the
language
of
the
dead
---
the
Bell
---
the
Bell
!
  
<EOS>
What
hunt
of
spectres
could
surpass
that
dread
pursuit
and
flight
!
<EOS>
Had
there
been
a
legion
of
them
on
his
track
,
he
could
have
better
borne
it
.
 
<EOS>
They
would
have
had
a
beginning
and
an
end
,
but
here
all
space
was
full
.
 
<EOS>
The
one
pursuing
voice
was
everywhere
:
it
sounded
in
the
earth
,
the
air
;
shook
the
long
grass
,
and
howled
among
the
trembling
trees
.
 
<EOS>
The
echoes
caught
it
up
,
the
owls
hooted
as
it
flew
upon
the
breeze
,
the
nightingale
was
silent
and
hid
herself
among
the
thickest
boughs
:
it
seemed
to
goad
and
urge
the
angry
fire
,
and
lash
it
into
madness
;
everything
was
steeped
in
one
prevailing
