what
they
had
seen
and
undergone
---
struck
her
dumb
;
and
,
lost
in
the
horrors
they
had
witnessed
,
and
those
they
might
be
yet
reserved
for
,
she
sat
incapable
of
thought
,
or
speech
,
or
outward
show
of
grief
:
as
rigid
,
and
almost
as
white
and
cold
,
as
marble
.
  
<EOS>
Oh
,
how
many
,
many
times
,
in
that
long
ride
,
did
Dolly
think
of
her
old
lover
,
---
poor
,
fond
,
slighted
Joe
!
 
<EOS>
How
many
,
many
times
,
did
she
recall
that
night
when
she
ran
into
his
arms
from
the
very
man
now
projecting
his
hateful
gaze
into
the
darkness
where
she
sat
,
and
leering
through
the
glass
in
monstrous
admiration
!
 
<EOS>
And
when
she
thought
of
Joe
,
and
what
a
brave
fellow
he
was
,
and
how
he
would
have
rode
boldly
up
,
and
dashed
in
among
these
villains
now
,
<EOS>
yes
,
though
they
were
double
the
number
---
and
here
she
clenched
her
little
hand
,
and
pressed
her
foot
upon
the
ground
---
the
pride
she
felt
for
a
moment
in
having
won
his
heart
,
faded
in
a
burst
of
tears
,
and
she
sobbed
more
bitterly
than
ever
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
night
wore
on
,
and
they
proceeded
by
ways
which
were
quite
unknown
to
them
---
for
they
could
recognise
none
of
the
objects
of
which
they
sometimes
caught
a
hurried
glimpse
---
their
fears
increased
;
nor
were
they
without
good
foundation
;
it
was
not
difficult
for
two
beautiful
young
women
to
find
,
<EOS>
in
their
being
borne
they
knew
not
whither
by
a
band
of
daring
villains
who
eyed
them
as
some
among
these
fellows
did
,
reasons
for
the
worst
alarm
.
<EOS>
When
they
at
last
entered
London
,
by
a
suburb
with
which
they
were
wholly
unacquainted
,
it
was
past
midnight
,
and
the
streets
were
dark
and
empty
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
this
the
worst
,
for
the
carriage
stopping
in
a
lonely
spot
,
Hugh
suddenly
opened
the
door
,
jumped
in
,
and
took
his
seat
between
them
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
they
cried
for
help
.
 
<EOS>
He
put
his
arm
about
the
neck
of
each
,
and
swore
to
stifle
them
with
kisses
if
they
were
not
as
silent
as
the
grave
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
come
here
to
keep
you
quiet
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
that
's
the
means
I
shall
take
.
 
<EOS>
So
do
n't
be
quiet
,
pretty
mistresses
---
make
a
noise
---
 
<EOS>
do
---
<EOS>
and
I
shall
like
it
<EOS>
all
the
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
were
proceeding
at
a
rapid
pace
,
and
apparently
with
fewer
attendants
than
before
,
though
it
was
so
dark
(
the
torches
being
extinguished
)
that
this
was
mere
conjecture
.
 
<EOS>
They
shrunk
from
his
touch
,
each
into
the
farthest
corner
of
the
carriage
;
but
shrink
as
Dolly
would
,
his
arm
encircled
her
waist
,
and
held
her
fast
.
 
<EOS>
She
neither
cried
nor
spoke
,
for
terror
and
disgust
deprived
her
of
the
power
;
but
she
plucked
at
his
hand
as
though
she
would
die
in
the
effort
to
disengage
herself
;
and
crouching
on
the
ground
,
with
her
head
averted
and
held
down
,
repelled
him
with
a
strength
she
wondered
at
as
much
as
he
.
 
<EOS>
The
carriage
stopped
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lift
this
one
out
,
"
said
Hugh
to
the
man
who
opened
the
door
,
as
he
took
Miss
Haredale
's
hand
,
and
felt
how
heavily
it
fell
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
's
fainted
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
much
the
better
,
"
growled
Dennis
---
it
was
that
amiable
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
's
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
I
always
like
'em
to
faint
,
unless
they
're
very
tender
and
composed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Can
you
take
her
by
yourself
?
"
asked
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
till
I
try
.
 
<EOS>
I
ought
to
be
able
to
;
I
've
lifted
up
a
good
many
in
my
time
,
"
said
the
hangman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Up
then
!
 
<EOS>
She
's
no
small
weight
,
brother
;
none
of
these
here
fine
gals
are
.
 
<EOS>
Up
again
!
 
<EOS>
Now
we
have
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Having
by
this
time
hoisted
the
young
lady
into
his
arms
,
he
staggered
off
with
his
burden
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
ye
,
pretty
bird
,
"
said
Hugh
,
drawing
Dolly
towards
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Remember
what
I
told
you
---
a
kiss
for
every
cry
.
 
<EOS>
Scream
,
if
you
love
me
,
darling
.
 
<EOS>
Scream
once
,
mistress
.
 
<EOS>
Pretty
mistress
,
only
once
,
if
you
love
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Thrusting
his
face
away
with
all
her
force
,
and
holding
down
her
head
,
Dolly
submitted
to
be
carried
out
of
the
chaise
,
and
borne
after
Miss
Haredale
into
a
miserable
cottage
,
where
Hugh
,
after
hugging
her
to
his
breast
,
set
her
gently
down
upon
the
floor
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
Dolly
!
 
<EOS>
Do
what
she
would
,
she
only
looked
the
better
for
it
,
and
tempted
them
the
more
.
 
<EOS>
When
her
eyes
flashed
angrily
,
and
her
ripe
lips
slightly
parted
,
to
give
her
rapid
breathing
vent
,
who
could
resist
it
?
 
<EOS>
When
she
wept
and
sobbed
as
though
her
heart
would
break
,
and
bemoaned
her
miseries
in
the
sweetest
voice
that
ever
fell
upon
a
listener
's
ear
,
who
could
be
insensible
to
the
little
winning
pettishness
which
now
and
then
displayed
itself
,
even
in
the
sincerity
and
earnestness
of
her
grief
?
 
<EOS>
When
,
forgetful
for
a
moment
of
herself
,
as
she
was
now
,
she
fell
on
her
knees
beside
her
friend
,
and
bent
over
her
,
and
laid
her
cheek
to
hers
,
and
put
her
arms
about
her
,
what
mortal
eyes
could
have
avoided
wandering
to
the
delicate
bodice
,
the
streaming
hair
,
the
neglected
dress
,
the
perfect
abandonment
and
unconsciousness
of
the
blooming
little
beauty
?
 
<EOS>
Who
could
look
on
and
see
her
lavish
caresses
and
endearments
,
and
not
desire
to
be
in
Emma
Haredale
's
place
;
to
be
either
her
or
Dolly
;
either
the
hugging
or
the
hugged
?
<EOS>
Not
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
Not
Dennis
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
what
it
is
,
young
women
,
"
said
Mr
Dennis
,
"
I
an't
much
of
a
lady
's
man
myself
,
nor
am
I
a
party
in
the
present
business
further
than
lending
a
willing
hand
to
my
friends
:
<EOS>
but
if
I
see
much
more
of
this
here
sort
of
thing
,
I
shall
become
a
principal
instead
of
a
accessory
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
candid
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
have
you
brought
us
here
?
"
said
Emma
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
we
to
be
murdered
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Murdered
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Dennis
,
sitting
down
upon
a
stool
,
and
regarding
her
with
great
favour
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
dear
,
who
'd
murder
sich
chickabiddies
as
you
?
 
<EOS>
If
you
was
to
ask
me
,
now
,
whether
you
was
brought
here
to
be
married
,
there
might
be
something
in
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
And
here
he
exchanged
a
grin
with
Hugh
,
who
removed
his
eyes
from
Dolly
for
the
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Dennis
,
"
there
'll
be
no
murdering
,
my
pets
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
of
that
sort
.
 
<EOS>
Quite
the
contrairy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
an
older
man
than
your
companion
,
sir
,
"
said
Emma
,
trembling
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
no
pity
for
us
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
not
consider
that
we
are
women
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
indeed
,
my
dear
,
"
retorted
Dennis
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
very
hard
not
to
,
with
two
such
specimens
afore
my
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
yes
,
I
consider
that
.
 
<EOS>
We
all
consider
that
,
miss
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
shook
his
head
waggishly
,
leered
at
Hugh
again
,
and
laughed
very
much
,
as
if
he
had
said
a
noble
thing
,
and
rather
thought
he
was
coming
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
'll
be
no
murdering
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
bit
on
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
what
though
,
brother
,
"
said
Dennis
,
cocking
his
hat
for
the
convenience
of
scratching
his
head
,
and
looking
gravely
at
Hugh
<EOS>
,
"
it
's
worthy
of
notice
,
as
a
proof
of
the
amazing
equalness
and
dignity
of
our
law
,
that
it
do
n't
make
no
distinction
between
men
and
women
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
heerd
the
judge
say
,
sometimes
,
to
a
highwayman
or
housebreaker
as
had
tied
the
ladies
neck
and
heels
<EOS>
---
you
'll
excuse
me
making
mention
of
it
,
my
darlings
---
and
put
'em
in
a

,
that
he
showed
no

to
women
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
say
that
there
judge
did
n't
know
his
business
,
brother
;
and
that
if
I
had
been
that
there
highwayman
or
housebreaker
<EOS>
,
I
should
have
made
answer
:
"
<EOS>
What
are
you
a
talking
of
,
my
lord
?
 
<EOS>
I
showed
the
women
as
much
consideration
as
the
law
does
,
and
what
more

you
have
me

?
<EOS>
"
If
you
was
to
count
up

the
number

females
as
have

worked
off
in
this
here
city

,
in

ten

,
"
said
Mr
Dennis

,
"
you
'd
be
surprised

the
total
---
quite

<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
There

;

!
 
<EOS>
But

've

.
<EOS>
Now

've

here
Papists
,
I
should
n't

if
they
went

altered
even
THAT
,
one

.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
soul
,
I
should
n't
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
subject
,
perhaps
from
being
of
too
exclusive
and
professional

,
failed
to

Hugh
as

.
 
<EOS>
But

had
no

to

,
for

Mr
Tappertit
entered
precipitately
;
at
sight
of
whom
Dolly
uttered
a

of
joy
,
and
fairly
threw
herself
into
his
arms
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
knew
it
,
I
was
sure
of
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Dolly
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
father
's
at

door
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
God
,
thank
God
!
 
<EOS>
Bless
you
,
Sim
.
 
<EOS>
Heaven
bless
you
for
this
!
"
  
<EOS>
Simon
Tappertit
,
who
had
at
first
implicitly
believed
that
the
locksmith
's
daughter
,
unable
any
longer
to
suppress
her
secret
passion
for
himself
,
was
about
to
give
it
full
vent
in

,
and
to

she
was
his
for

,
looked

when
she
said
these

;
---
the
more
so
,
as
they
were
received
by
Hugh
and
Dennis
with
a

,
which
made
her
draw
back
,
and
regard

with
a
fixed
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Haredale
,
"
said
Sim
,
after
a
very
awkward

,
"
I
hope
you
're
as
comfortable
as
circumstances
will
permit

.
 
<EOS>
Dolly
Varden
,
my
darling
---
my
own
,
my
lovely
one
<EOS>
---
I
hope
YOU'RE
pretty
comfortable
likewise
.
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
little
Dolly
!
 
<EOS>
She
saw
how
it
was
;
hid
her
face
in
her
hands
;
and
sobbed
more
bitterly
than
ever
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
meet
in
me
,
Miss
V
,
"
said
Simon
,
laying
his
hand
upon
his
breast
,
"
not
a
"
prentice
,
not
a
workman
,
not

slave
,
not
the
wictim
of
your
father
's

,
but
the

of

,
the

of

noble

,
in
which
these
gentlemen
are
,
as
I
may
say
,
corporals
and

.
 
<EOS>
You
behold
in
me
,
not

private

,

a
public
character
;
not
a
mender
of
locks
,
but
a

of
the

of
his

.
 
<EOS>
Dolly
V
,
sweet
Dolly
V
,
for
how
many
years
<EOS>
have
I

to
this
present

!
 
<EOS>
For

my

!
 
<EOS>
I
redeem
it
.
 
<EOS>
Behold
in
me
,
your

.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
beautiful
Dolly
---
charmer
---
enslaver
<EOS>
---
S
Tappertit
is
all
your
own
!
"
  
<EOS>
As
he

these
words
he
advanced
towards
her
.
 
<EOS>
Dolly
retreated
till
she
could
go
no
farther
,
and
then
sank
down
upon
the
floor
.
<EOS>
Thinking
it
very
possible
that
this
might
be
maiden

,
Simon
essayed
to
raise
her
;
on

Dolly
,
goaded
to

,
wound
her
hands
in
his

,
and
crying
out
amidst
her

that
he
was
a
dreadful
little
wretch
,
and
always
had
been
,
shook
,
and
pulled
,
and
beat
him
,
until
he
was
fain
to
call
for
help
,
most
lustily
.
<EOS>
Hugh
had
never
admired
her
half
so
much
as
at
that
moment
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
's
in
an
excited
state
to
-
night
,
"
said
Simon
,
as
he
smoothed
his
rumpled

,
"
and
do
n't
know
when
she
's
well
off
.
 
<EOS>
Let
her
be
by
herself
till
to
-
morrow
,
and
that
'll
bring
her
down
a
little
.
<EOS>
Carry
her
into
the
next
house
!
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
had
her
in

.
 
<EOS>
It
might

Mr
Tappertit
's

really

,

some

indecorous
that

should

in

.
 
<EOS>
He
commanded

,
on

,
to
put

,
and

on
as

Miss
Haredale
's

,
and

her

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
They

,
"

,
who

---
"
till
to
-

.
 
<EOS>
Come
away
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
"
cried
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
away
,
captain
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
"
  
"
What

laughing

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
captain
,
nothing
<EOS>
,
"
Hugh

;
and

,

,
for
some

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
surveyed
him
from

with

(
this
only

)
,

"
You

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

---
both

---
<EOS>
more
of

to

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
do

,

any

the

you

pass

;

,

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
With

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

,

,

;
fastening

,
and
setting

good

upon

,
and
indeed
all

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"

,

,
"
that

.
 
<EOS>
Muster
Gashford
's

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

you
mention

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
bad

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would

HIM
,

(

do

)
,
when
he

;
that

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
She

one

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
afore

.
<EOS>
I

was
worked

,

---

---
<EOS>
that

,

,

:
"
<EOS>
Dennis
,
I
'm

,

;
"
---
<EOS>
ah

---
<EOS>
and
she

!
"
  
<EOS>
Strike
who
dead
?
"
demanded
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
should
I
know
,
brother
?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
SHE
never
said
;
not
she
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh

,

,

;
but

,
who

,

a

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hugh
!
"
said
Sim
.
 
<EOS>
"
You

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
---
There

YOU

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
N
---
<EOS>
no
,
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
None
in

,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"

;
"

.
 
<EOS>
As

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

(
her

within

.
 
<EOS>
Mind
.
<EOS>
I
pass

.
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
thanked
him
heartily
;
and
as
he
did
so
,
his
laughing
fit
returned
with
such
violence
that
he
was
obliged
to
hold
his
side
with
one
hand
,
and
to
lean
with
the
other
on
the
shoulder
of
his
small
captain
,
without
whose
support
he
would
certainly
have
rolled
upon
the
ground
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
60
    
<EOS>
The
three
worthies
turned
their
faces
towards
The
Boot
,
with
the
intention
of
passing
the
night
in
that
place
of
rendezvous
,
and
of
seeking
the
repose
they
so
much
needed
in
the
shelter
of
their
old
den
;
for
now
that
the
mischief
and
destruction
they
had
purposed
were
achieved
,
and
their
prisoners
were
safely
bestowed
for
the
night
,
they
began
to
be
conscious
of
exhaustion
,
and
to
feel
the
wasting
effects
of
the
madness
which
had
led
to
such
deplorable
results
.
  
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
the
lassitude
and
fatigue
which
oppressed
him
now
,
in
common
with
his
two
companions
,
and
indeed
with
all
who
had
taken
an
active
share
in
that
night
's
work
,
Hugh
's
boisterous
merriment
broke
out
afresh
whenever
he
looked
at
Simon
Tappertit
,
and
vented
itself
---
much
to
that
gentleman
's
indignation
---
in
such
shouts
of
laughter
as
bade
fair
to
bring
the
watch
upon
them
,
and
involve
them
in
a
skirmish
,
to
which
in
their
present
worn
-
out
condition
they
might
prove
by
no
means
equal
.
 
<EOS>
Even
Mr
Dennis
,
who
was
not
at
all
particular
on
the
score
of
gravity
or
dignity
,
and
who
had
a
great
relish
for
his
young
friend
's
eccentric
humours
,
took
occasion
to
remonstrate
with
him
on
this
imprudent
behaviour
,
which
he
held
to
be
a
species
of
suicide
,
tantamount
to
a
man
's
working
himself
off
without
being
overtaken
by
the
law
,
than
which
he
could
imagine
nothing
more
ridiculous
or
impertinent
.
  
<EOS>
Not
abating
one
jot
of
his
noisy
mirth
for
these
remonstrances
,
Hugh
reeled
along
between
them
,
having
an
arm
of
each
,
until
they
hove
in
sight
of
The
Boot
,
and
were
within
a
field
or
two
of
that
convenient
tavern
.
 
<EOS>
He
happened
by
great
good
luck
to
have
roared
and
shouted
himself
into
silence
by
this
time
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
proceeding
onward
without
noise
,
when
a
scout
who
had
been
creeping
about
the
ditches
all
night
,
to
warn
any
stragglers
from
encroaching
further
on
what
was
now
such
dangerous
ground
,
peeped
cautiously
from
his
hiding
-
place
,
and
called
to
them
to
stop
.
  
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
<EOS>
and
why
?
<EOS>
"
said
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
Because
(
the
scout
replied
)
<EOS>
the
house
was
filled
with
constables
and
soldiers
;
having
been
surprised
that
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
The
inmates
had
fled
or
been
taken
into
custody
,
he
could
not
say
which
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
prevented
a
great
many
people
from
approaching
nearer
,
and
he
believed
they
had
gone
to
the
markets
and
such
places
to
pass
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
seen
the
distant
fires
,
but
they
were
all
out
now
.
<EOS>
He
had
heard
the
people
who
passed
and
repassed
,
speaking
of
them
too
,
and
could
report
that
the
prevailing
opinion
was
one
of
apprehension
and
dismay
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
heard
a
word
of
Barnaby
---
 
<EOS>
did
n't
even
know
his
name
---
but
it
had
been
said
in
his
hearing
that
some
man
had
been
taken
and
carried
off
to
Newgate
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
this
was
true
or
false
,
he
could
not
affirm
.
  
<EOS>
The
three
took
counsel
together
,
on
hearing
this
,
and
debated
what
it
might
be
best
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
,
deeming
it
possible
that
Barnaby
was
in
the
hands
of
the
soldiers
,
and
at
that
moment
under
detention
at
The
Boot
,
was
for
advancing
stealthily
,
and
firing
the
house
;
but
his
companions
,
who
objected
to
such
rash
measures
unless
they
had
a
crowd
at
their
backs
,
represented
that
if
Barnaby
were
taken
he
had
assuredly
been
removed
to
a
stronger
prison
;
they
would
never
have
dreamed
of
keeping
him
all
night
in
a
place
so
weak
and
open
to
attack
.
 
<EOS>
Yielding
to
this
reasoning
,
and
to
their
persuasions
,
Hugh
consented
to
turn
back
and
to
repair
to
Fleet
Market
;
for
which
place
,
it
seemed
,
a
few
of
their
boldest
associates
had
shaped
their
course
,
on
receiving
the
same
intelligence
.
  
<EOS>
Feeling
their
strength
recruited
and
their
spirits
roused
,
now
that
there
was
a
new
necessity
for
action
,
they
hurried
away
,
quite
forgetful
of
the
fatigue
under
which
they
had
been
sinking
but
a
few
minutes
before
;
and
soon
arrived
at
their
new
place
of
destination
.
  
<EOS>
Fleet
Market
,
at
that
time
,
was
a
long
irregular
row
of
wooden
sheds
and
penthouses
,
occupying
the
centre
of
what
is
now
called
Farringdon
Street
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
jumbled
together
in
a
most
unsightly
fashion
,
in
the
middle
of
the
road
;
to
the
great
obstruction
of
the
thoroughfare
and
the
annoyance
of
passengers
,
who
were
fain
to
make
their
way
,
as
they
best
could
,
among
carts
,
baskets
,
barrows
,
trucks
,
casks
,
bulks
,
and
benches
,
and
to
jostle
with
porters
,
hucksters
,
waggoners
,
and
a
motley
crowd
of
buyers
,
sellers
,
pick
-
pockets
,
vagrants
,
and
idlers
.
 
<EOS>
The
air
was
perfumed
with
the
stench
of
rotten
leaves
and
faded
fruit
;
the
refuse
of
the
butchers
'
stalls
,
and
offal
and
garbage
of
a
hundred
kinds
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
indispensable
to
most
public
conveniences
in
those
days
,
that
they
should
be
public
nuisances
likewise
;
and
Fleet
Market
maintained
the
principle
to
admiration
.
  
<EOS>
To
this
place
,
perhaps
because
its
sheds
and
baskets
were
a
tolerable
substitute
for
beds
,
or
perhaps
because
it
afforded
the
means
of
a
hasty
barricade
in
case
of
need
,
many
of
the
rioters
had
straggled
,
not
only
that
night
,
but
for
two
or
three
nights
before
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
broad
day
,
but
the
morning
being
cold
,
a
group
of
them
were
gathered
round
a
fire
in
a
public
-
house
,
drinking
hot
purl
,
and
smoking
pipes
,
and
planning
new
schemes
for
to
-
morrow
.
  
<EOS>
Hugh
and
his
two
friends
being
known
to
most
of
these
men
,
were
received
with
signal
marks
of
approbation
,
and
inducted
into
the
most
honourable
seats
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
-
door
was
closed
and
fastened
to
keep
intruders
at
a
distance
,
and
then
they
proceeded
to
exchange
news
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
soldiers
have
taken
possession
of
The
Boot
,
I
hear
,
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
knows
anything
about
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
Several
cried
that
they
did
;
but
the
majority
of
the
company
having
been
engaged
in
the
assault
upon
the
Warren
,
and
all
present
having
been
concerned
in
one
or
other
of
the
night
's
expeditions
,
it
proved
that
they
knew
no
more
than
Hugh
himself
;
having
been
merely
warned
by
each
other
,
or
by
the
scout
,
and
knowing
nothing
of
their
own
knowledge
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
left
a
man
on
guard
there
to
-
day
,
"
said
Hugh
,
looking
round
him
,
"
who
is
not
here
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
who
it
is
---
Barnaby
,
who
brought
the
soldier
down
,
at
Westminster
.
 
<EOS>
Has
any
man
seen
or
heard
of
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
shook
their
heads
,
and
murmured
an
answer
in
the
negative
,
as
each
man
looked
round
and
appealed
to
his
fellow
;
when
a
noise
was
heard
without
,
and
a
man
was
heard
to
say
that
he
wanted
Hugh
---
that
he
must
see
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
but
one
man
,
"
cried
Hugh
to
those
who
kept
the
door
;
"
let
him
come
in
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
!
"
muttered
the
others
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
him
come
in
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
come
in
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
door
was
accordingly
unlocked
and
opened
.
 
<EOS>
A
one
-
armed
man
,
with
his
head
and
face
tied
up
with
a
bloody
cloth
,
as
though
he
had
been
severely
beaten
,
his
clothes
torn
,
and
his
remaining
hand
grasping
a
thick
stick
,
rushed
in
among
them
,
and
panting
for
breath
,
demanded
which
was
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is
,
"
replied
the
person
he
inquired
for
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
Hugh
.
<EOS>
What
do
you
want
with
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
message
for
you
,
"
said
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
one
Barnaby
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
of
him
?
 
<EOS>
Did
he
send
the
message
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
taken
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
in
one
of
the
strong
cells
in
Newgate
.
 
<EOS>
He
defended
himself
as
well
as
he
could
,
but
was
overpowered
by
numbers
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
his
message
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
did
you
see
him
?
"
asked
Hugh
,
hastily
.
  
<EOS>
"
On
his
way
to
prison
,
where
he
was
taken
by
a
party
of
soldiers
.
<EOS>
They
took
a
by
-
road
,
and
not
the
one
we
expected
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
one
of
the
few
who
tried
to
rescue
him
,
and
he
called
to
me
,
and
told
me
to
tell
Hugh
where
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
We
made
a
good
struggle
,
though
it
failed
.
 
<EOS>
Look
here
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
pointed
to
his
dress
and
to
his
bandaged
head
,
and
still
panting
for
breath
,
glanced
round
the
room
;
then
faced
towards
Hugh
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
you
by
sight
,
"
he
said
,
"
for
I
was
in
the
crowd
on
Friday
,
and
on
Saturday
,
and
yesterday
,
but
I
did
n't
know
your
name
.
<EOS>
You
're
a
bold
fellow
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
So
is
he
.
 
<EOS>
He
fought
like
a
lion
tonight
,
but
it
was
of
no
use
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
my
best
,
considering
that
I
want
this
limb
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Again
he
glanced
inquisitively
round
the
room
or
seemed
to
do
so
,
for
his
face
was
nearly
hidden
by
the
bandage
---
and
again
facing
sharply
towards
Hugh
,
grasped
his
stick
as
if
he
half
expected
to
be
set
upon
,
and
stood
on
the
defensive
.
  
<EOS>
If
he
had
any
such
apprehension
,
however
,
he
was
speedily
reassured
by
the
demeanour
of
all
present
.
 
<EOS>
None
thought
of
the
bearer
of
the
tidings
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
lost
in
the
news
he
brought
.
 
<EOS>
Oaths
,
threats
,
and
execrations
,
were
vented
on
all
sides
.
 
<EOS>
Some
cried
that
if
they
bore
this
tamely
,
another
day
would
see
them
all
in
jail
;
some
,
that
they
should
have
rescued
the
other
prisoners
,
and
this
would
not
have
happened
.
 
<EOS>
One
man
cried
in
a
loud
voice
,
"
Who
'll
follow
me
to
Newgate
!
"
<EOS>
and
there
was
a
loud
shout
and
general
rush
towards
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
But
Hugh
and
Dennis
stood
with
their
backs
against
it
,
and
kept
them
back
,
until
the
clamour
had
so
far
subsided
that
their
voices
could
be
heard
,
when
they
called
to
them
together
that
to
go
now
,
in
broad
day
,
would
be
madness
;
and
that
if
they
waited
until
night
and
arranged
a
plan
of
attack
,
they
might
release
,
not
only
their
own
companions
,
but
all
the
prisoners
,
and
burn
down
the
jail
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
that
jail
alone
,
"
cried
Hugh
,
"
but
every
jail
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
They
shall
have
no
place
to
put
their
prisoners
in
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
burn
them
all
down
;
make
bonfires
of
them
every
one
!
 
<EOS>
Here
!
"
he
cried
,
catching
at
the
hangman
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
all
who
're
men
here
,
join
with
us
.
<EOS>
Shake
hands
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
out
of
jail
,
and
not
a
jail
left
standing
!
 
<EOS>
Who
joins
?
"
  
<EOS>
Every
man
there
.
 
<EOS>
And
they
swore
a
great
oath
to
release
their
friends
from
Newgate
next
night
;
to
force
the
doors
and
burn
the
jail
;
or
perish
in
the
fire
themselves
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
61
    
<EOS>
On
that
same
night
---
events
so
crowd
upon
each
other
in
convulsed
and
distracted
times
,
that
more
than
the
stirring
incidents
of
a
whole
life
often
become
compressed
into
the
compass
of
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
---
on
that
same
night
,
Mr
Haredale
,
having
strongly
bound
his
prisoner
,
with
the
assistance
of
the
sexton
,
and
forced
him
to
mount
his
horse
,
conducted
him
to
Chigwell
;
bent
upon
procuring
a
conveyance
to
London
from
that
place
,
and
carrying
him
at
once
before
a
justice
.
 
<EOS>
The
disturbed
state
of
the
town
would
be
,
he
knew
,
a
sufficient
reason
for
demanding
the
murderer
's
committal
to
prison
before
daybreak
,
as
no
man
could
answer
for
the
security
of
any
of
the
watch
-
houses
or
ordinary
places
of
detention
;
and
to
convey
a
prisoner
through
the
streets
when
the
mob
were
again
abroad
,
would
not
only
be
a
task
of
great
danger
and
hazard
,
but
would
be
to
challenge
an
attempt
at
rescue
.
 
<EOS>
Directing
the
sexton
to
lead
the
horse
,
he
walked
close
by
the
murderer
's
side
,
and
in
this
order
they
reached
the
village
about
the
middle
of
the
night
.
  
<EOS>
The
people
were
all
awake
and
up
,
for
they
were
fearful
of
being
burnt
in
their
beds
,
and
sought
to
comfort
and
assure
each
other
by
watching
in
company
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
of
the
stoutest
-
hearted
were
armed
and
gathered
in
a
body
on
the
green
.
 
<EOS>
To
these
,
who
knew
him
well
,
Mr
Haredale
addressed
himself
,
briefly
narrating
what
had
happened
,
and
beseeching
them
to
aid
in
conveying
the
criminal
to
London
before
the
dawn
of
day
.
  
<EOS>
But
not
a
man
among
them
dared
to
help
him
by
so
much
as
the
motion
of
a
finger
.
 
<EOS>
The
rioters
,
in
their
passage
through
the
village
,
had
menaced
with
their
fiercest
vengeance
,
any
person
who
should
aid
in
extinguishing
the
fire
,
or
render
the
least
assistance
to
him
,
or
any
Catholic
whomsoever
.
 
<EOS>
Their
threats
extended
to
their
lives
and
all
they
possessed
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
assembled
for
their
own
protection
,
and
could
not
endanger
themselves
by
lending
any
aid
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
This
they
told
him
,
not
without
hesitation
and
regret
,
as
they
kept
aloof
in
the
moonlight
and
glanced
fearfully
at
the
ghostly
rider
,
who
,
with
his
head
drooping
on
his
breast
and
his
hat
slouched
down
upon
his
brow
,
neither
moved
nor
spoke
.
  
<EOS>
Finding
it
impossible
to
persuade
them
,
and
indeed
hardly
knowing
how
to
do
so
after
what
they
had
seen
of
the
fury
of
the
crowd
,
Mr
Haredale
besought
them
that
at
least
they
would
leave
him
free
to
act
for
himself
,
and
would
suffer
him
to
take
the
only
chaise
and
pair
of
horses
that
the
place
afforded
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
not
acceded
to
without
some
difficulty
,
but
in
the
end
they
told
him
to
do
what
he
would
,
and
go
away
from
them
in
heaven
's
name
.
  
<EOS>
Leaving
the
sexton
at
the
horse
's
bridle
,
he
drew
out
the
chaise
with
his
own
hands
,
and
would
have
harnessed
the
horses
,
but
that
the
post
-
boy
of
the
village
---
a
soft
-
hearted
,
good
-
for
-
nothing
,
vagabond
kind
of
fellow
---
was
moved
by
his
earnestness
and
passion
,
and
,
throwing
down
a
pitchfork
with
which
he
was
armed
,
swore
that
the
rioters
might
cut
him
into
mincemeat
if
they
liked
,
but
he
would
not
stand
by
and
see
an
honest
gentleman
who
had
done
no
wrong
,
reduced
to
such
extremity
,
without
doing
what
he
could
to
help
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
shook
him
warmly
by
the
hand
,
and
thanked
him
from
his
heart
.
 
<EOS>
In
five
minutes
'
time
the
chaise
was
ready
,
and
this
good
scapegrace
in
his
saddle
.
 
<EOS>
The
murderer
was
put
inside
,
the
blinds
were
drawn
up
,
the
sexton
took
his
seat
upon
the
bar
,
Mr
Haredale
mounted
his
horse
and
rode
close
beside
the
door
;
and
so
they
started
in
the
dead
of
night
,
and
in
profound
silence
,
for
London
.
  
<EOS>
The
consternation
was
so
extreme
that
even
the
horses
which
had
escaped
the
flames
at
the
Warren
,
could
find
no
friends
to
shelter
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
passed
them
on
the
road
,
browsing
on
the
stunted
grass
;
and
the
driver
told
them
,
that
the
poor
beasts
had
wandered
to
the
village
first
,
but
had
been
driven
away
,
lest
they
should
bring
the
vengeance
of
the
crowd
on
any
of
the
inhabitants
.
  
<EOS>
Nor
was
this
feeling
confined
to
such
small
places
,
where
the
people
were
timid
,
ignorant
,
and
unprotected
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
came
near
London
they
met
,
in
the
grey
light
of
morning
,
more
than
one
poor
Catholic
family
who
,
terrified
by
the
threats
and
warnings
of
their
neighbours
,
were
quitting
the
city
on
foot
,
and
who
told
them
they
could
hire
no
cart
or
horse
for
the
removal
of
their
goods
,
and
had
been
compelled
to
leave
them
behind
,
at
the
mercy
of
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
Near
Mile
End
they
passed
a
house
,
the
master
of
which
<EOS>
,
a
Catholic
gentleman
of
small
means
,
having
hired
a
waggon
to
remove
his
furniture
by
midnight
,
had
had
it
all
brought
down
into
the
street
,
to
wait
the
vehicle
's
arrival
,
and
save
time
in
the
packing
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
man
with
whom
he
made
the
bargain
,
alarmed
by
the
fires
that
night
,
and
by
the
sight
of
the
rioters
passing
his
door
,
had
refused
to
keep
it
:
and
the
poor
gentleman
,
with
his
wife
and
servant
and
their
little
children
,
were
sitting
trembling
among
their
goods
in
the
open
street
,
dreading
the
arrival
of
day
and
not
knowing
where
to
turn
or
what
to
do
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
same
,
they
heard
,
with
the
public
conveyances
.
 
<EOS>
The
panic
was
so
great
that
the
mails
and
stage
-
coaches
were
afraid
to
carry
passengers
who
professed
the
obnoxious
religion
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
drivers
knew
them
,
or
they
admitted
that
they
held
that
creed
,
they
would
not
take
them
,
no
,
though
they
offered
large
sums
;
and
yesterday
,
people
had
been
afraid
to
recognise
Catholic
acquaintance
in
the
streets
,
lest
they
should
be
marked
by
spies
,
and
burnt
out
,
as
it
was
called
,
in
consequence
.
 
<EOS>
One
mild
old
man
---
 
a
priest
,
whose
chapel
was
destroyed
;
a
very
feeble
,
patient
,
inoffensive
creature
---
who
was
trudging
away
,
alone
,
designing
to
walk
some
distance
from
town
,
and
then
try
his
fortune
with
the
coaches
,
told
Mr
Haredale
that
he
feared
he
might
not
find
a
magistrate
who
would
have
the
hardihood
to
commit
a
prisoner
to
jail
,
on
his
complaint
.
 
<EOS>
But
notwithstanding
these
discouraging
accounts
they
went
on
,
and
reached
the
Mansion
House
soon
after
sunrise
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
threw
himself
from
his
horse
,
but
he
had
no
need
to
knock
at
the
door
,
for
it
was
already
open
,
and
there
stood
upon
the
step
a
portly
old
man
,
with
a
very
red
,
or
rather
purple
face
,
who
with
an
anxious
expression
of
countenance
,
was
remonstrating
with
some
unseen
personage
upstairs
,
while
the
porter
essayed
to
close
the
door
by
degrees
and
get
rid
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
intense
impatience
and
excitement
natural
to
one
in
his
condition
,
Mr
Haredale
thrust
himself
forward
and
was
about
to
speak
,
when
the
fat
old
gentleman
interposed
:
  
"
My
good
sir
,
"
said
he
,
"
pray
let
me
get
an
answer
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
sixth
time
I
have
been
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
here
five
times
yesterday
.
 
<EOS>
My
house
is
threatened
with
destruction
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
to
be
burned
down
to
-
night
,
and
was
to
have
been
last
night
,
but
they
had
other
business
on
their
hands
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
let
me
get
an
answer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
good
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Haredale
,
shaking
his
head
,
"
<EOS>
my
house
is
burned
to
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
But
heaven
forbid
that
yours
should
be
.
<EOS>
Get
your
answer
.
 
<EOS>
Be
brief
,
in
mercy
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
you
hear
this
,
my
lord
?
"
---
said
the
old
gentleman
,
calling
up
the
stairs
,
to
where
the
skirt
of
a
dressing
-
gown
fluttered
on
the
landing
-
place
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
is
a
gentleman
here
,
whose
house
was
actually
burnt
down
last
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
dear
me
,
"
replied
a
testy
voice
,
"
I
am
very
sorry
for
it
,
but
what
am
I
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
build
it
up
again
.
 
<EOS>
The
chief
magistrate
of
the
city
ca
n't
go
and
be
a
rebuilding
of
people
's
houses
,
my
good
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Stuff
and
nonsense
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
the
chief
magistrate
of
the
city
can
prevent
people
's
houses
from
having
any
need
to
be
rebuilt
,
if
the
chief
magistrate
's
a
man
,
and
not
a
dummy
---
ca
n't
he
,
my
lord
?
"
cried
the
old
gentleman
in
a
choleric
manner
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
disrespectable
,
sir
,
"
said
the
Lord
Mayor
---
"
leastways
,
disrespectful
I
mean
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Disrespectful
,
my
lord
!
"
returned
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
respectful
five
times
yesterday
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
be
respectful
for
ever
.
<EOS>
Men
ca
n't
stand
on
being
respectful
when
their
houses
are
going
to
be
burnt
over
their
heads
,
with
them
in
'em
.
 
<EOS>
What
am
I
to
do
,
my
lord
?
 
<EOS>
AM
I
to
have
any
protection
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
yesterday
,
sir
,
"
said
the
Lord
Mayor
,
"
that
you
might
have
an
alderman
in
your
house
,
if
you
could
get
one
to
come
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
's
the
good
of
an
alderman
?
"
returned
the
choleric
old
gentleman
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
To
awe
the
crowd
,
sir
,
"
said
the
Lord
Mayor
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
Lord
ha
'
mercy
!
"
whimpered
the
old
gentleman
,
as
he
wiped
his
forehead
in
a
state
of
ludicrous
distress
,
"
to
think
of
sending
an
alderman
to
awe
a
crowd
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
my
lord
,
if
they
were
even
so
many
babies
,
fed
on
mother
's
milk
,
what
do
you
think
they
'd
care
for
an
alderman
!
 
<EOS>
Will
YOU
come
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
!
"
said
the
Lord
Mayor
,
most
emphatically
:
"
Certainly
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
what
,
"
returned
the
old
gentleman
,
"
what
am
I
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
Am
I
a
citizen
of
England
?
 
<EOS>
Am
I
to
have
the
benefit
of
the
laws
?
 
<EOS>
Am
I
to
have
any
return
for
the
King
's
taxes
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
I
am
sure
,
"
said
the
Lord
Mayor
;
"
what
a
pity
it
is
you
're
a
Catholic
!
 
<EOS>
Why
could
n't
you
be
a
Protestant
,
and
then
you
would
n't
have
got
yourself
into
such
a
mess
?
 
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
I
do
n't
know
what
's
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
---
There
are
great
people
at
the
bottom
of
these
riots
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Oh
dear
me
,
what
a
thing
it
is
to
be
a
public
character
!
<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>
You
must
look
in
again
in
the
course
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
---
Would
a
javelin
-
man
do
?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Or
there
's
Philips
the
constable
,
---
<EOS>
HE
'S
disengaged
<EOS>
,
---
he
's
not
very
old
for
a
man
at
his
time
of
life
,
except
in
his
legs
,
and
if
you
put
him
up
at
a
window
he
'd
look
quite
young
by
candle
-
light
,
and
might
frighten
'em
very
much
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Oh
dear
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
well
!
---
we
'll
see
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Haredale
,
pressing
the
door
open
as
the
porter
strove
to
shut
it
,
and
speaking
rapidly
<EOS>
,
"
My
Lord
Mayor
,
I
beg
you
not
to
go
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
man
here
,
who
committed
a
murder
eight
-
and
-
twenty
years
ago
.
 
<EOS>
Half
-
a
-
dozen
words
from
me
,
on
oath
,
will
justify
you
in
committing
him
to
prison
for
re
-
examination
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
seek
,
just
now
,
to
have
him
consigned
to
a
place
of
safety
.
 
<EOS>
The
least
delay
may
involve
his
being
rescued
by
the
rioters
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
me
!
"
cried
the
Lord
Mayor
.
 
<EOS>
"
God
bless
my
soul
---
and
body
---
 
<EOS>
oh
Lor
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
well
I
!
<EOS>
---
there
are
great
people
at
the
bottom
of
these
riots
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
---
You
really
must
n't
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
<EOS>
the
murdered
gentleman
was
my
brother
;
I
succeeded
to
his
inheritance
;
there
were
not
wanting
slanderous
tongues
at
that
time
,
to
whisper
that
the
guilt
of
this
most
foul
and
cruel
deed
was
mine
---
mine
,
who
loved
him
,
as
he
knows
,
in
Heaven
,
dearly
.
 
<EOS>
The
time
has
come
,
after
all
these
years
of
gloom
and
misery
,
for
avenging
him
,
and
bringing
to
light
a
crime
so
artful
and
so
devilish
that
it
has
no
parallel
.
 
<EOS>
Every
second
's
delay
on
your
part
loosens
this
man
's
bloody
hands
again
,
and
leads
to
his
escape
.
 
<EOS>
My
lord
,
I
charge
you
hear
me
,
and
despatch
this
matter
on
the
instant
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
me
!
"
cried
the
chief
magistrate
;
"
these
an't
business
hours
,
you
know
---
I
wonder
at
you
---
how
ungentlemanly
it
is
of
you
---
 
<EOS>
you
must
n't
---
you
really
must
n't
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
And
I
suppose
you
are
a
Catholic
too
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
.
  
<EOS>
"
God
bless
my
soul
<EOS>
,
I
believe
people
turn
Catholics
a'purpose
to
vex
and
worrit
me
,
"
cried
the
Lord
Mayor
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
would
n't
come
here
;
they
'll
be
setting
the
Mansion
House
afire
next
,
and
we
shall
have
you
to
thank
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
lock
your
prisoner
up
,
sir
---
give
him
to
a
watchman
---
and
---
call
again
at
a
proper
time
.
<EOS>
Then
we
'll
see
about
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
Before
Mr
Haredale
could
answer
,
the
sharp
closing
of
a
door
and
drawing
of
its
bolts
,
gave
notice
that
the
Lord
Mayor
had
retreated
to
his
bedroom
,
and
that
further
remonstrance
would
be
unavailing
.
<EOS>
The
two
clients
retreated
likewise
,
and
the
porter
shut
them
out
into
the
street
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
way
he
puts
me
off
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
,
"
I
can
get
no
redress
and
no
help
.
 
<EOS>
What
are
you
going
to
do
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
try
elsewhere
,
"
answered
Mr
Haredale
,
who
was
by
this
time
on
horseback
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
feel
for
you
,
I
assure
you
---
<EOS>
and
well
I
may
,
for
we
are
in
a
common
cause
,
"
said
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
may
not
have
a
house
to
offer
you
to
-
night
;
let
me
tender
it
while
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
On
second
thoughts
though
,
"
he
added
,
putting
up
a
pocket
-
book
he
had
produced
while
speaking
,
"
I
'll
not
give
you
a
card
,
for
if
it
was
found
upon
you
,
it
might
get
you
into
trouble
.
 
<EOS>
Langdale
<EOS>
---
that
's
my
name
---
vintner
and
distiller
---
Holborn
Hill
<EOS>
---
you
're
heartily
welcome
,
if
you
'll
come
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
bowed
,
and
rode
off
,
close
beside
the
chaise
as
before
;
determining
to
repair
to
the
house
of
Sir
John
Fielding
,
who
had
the
reputation
of
being
a
bold
and
active
magistrate
,
and
fully
resolved
,
<EOS>
in
case
the
rioters
should
come
upon
them
,
to
do
execution
on
the
murderer
with
his
own
hands
,
rather
than
suffer
him
to
be
released
.
  
<EOS>
They
arrived
at
the
magistrate
's
dwelling
,
however
,
without
molestation
(
for
the
mob
,
as
we
have
seen
,
were
then
intent
on
deeper
schemes
)
,
and
knocked
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
had
been
pretty
generally
rumoured
that
Sir
John
was
proscribed
by
the
rioters
,
a
body
of
thief
-
takers
had
been
keeping
watch
in
the
house
all
night
.
<EOS>
To
one
of
them
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
stated
his
business
,
which
appearing
to
the
man
of
sufficient
moment
to
warrant
his
arousing
the
justice
,
procured
him
an
immediate
audience
.
  
<EOS>
No
time
was
lost
in
committing
the
murderer
to
Newgate
;
then
a
new
building
,
recently
completed
at
a
vast
expense
,
and
considered
to
be
of
enormous
strength
.
 
<EOS>
The
warrant
being
made
out
,
three
of
the
thief
-
takers
bound
him
afresh
(
he
had
been
struggling
,
it
seemed
,
in
the
chaise
,
and
had
loosened
his
manacles
)
;
gagged
him
lest
they
should
meet
with
any
of
the
mob
,
and
he
should
call
to
them
for
help
;
and
seated
themselves
,
along
with
him
,
in
the
carriage
.
<EOS>
These
men
being
all
well
armed
,
made
a
formidable
escort
;
but
they
drew
up
the
blinds
again
,
as
though
the
carriage
were
empty
,
and
directed
Mr
Haredale
to
ride
forward
,
that
he
might
not
attract
attention
by
seeming
to
belong
to
it
.
  
<EOS>
The
wisdom
of
this
proceeding
was
sufficiently
obvious
,
for
as
they
hurried
through
the
city
they
passed
among
several
groups
of
men
,
who
,
if
they
had
not
supposed
the
chaise
to
be
quite
empty
,
would
certainly
have
stopped
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
those
within
keeping
quite
close
,
and
the
driver
tarrying
to
be
asked
no
questions
,
they
reached
the
prison
without
interruption
,
and
,
once
there
,
had
him
out
,
and
safe
within
its
gloomy
walls
,
in
a
twinkling
.
  
<EOS>
With
eager
eyes
and
strained
attention
,
Mr
Haredale
saw
him
chained
,
and
locked
and
barred
up
in
his
cell
.
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
when
he
had
left
the
jail
,
and
stood
in
the
free
street
,
without
,
he
felt
the
iron
plates
upon
the
doors
,
with
his
hands
,
and
drew
them
over
the
stone
wall
,
to
assure
himself
that
it
was
real
;
and
to
exult
in
its
being
so
strong
,
and
rough
,
and
cold
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
he
turned
his
back
upon
the
jail
,
and
glanced
along
the
empty
streets
,
so
lifeless
and
quiet
in
the
bright
morning
,
that
he
felt
the
weight
upon
his
heart
;
that
he
knew
he
was
tortured
by
anxiety
for
those
he
had
left
at
home
;
and
that
home
itself
was
but
another
bead
in
the
long
rosary
of
his
regrets
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
62
    
<EOS>
The
prisoner
,
left
to
himself
,
sat
down
upon
his
bedstead
:
and
resting
his
elbows
on
his
knees
,
and
his
chin
upon
his
hands
,
remained
in
that
attitude
for
hours
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
hard
to
say
,
of
what
nature
his
reflections
were
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
no
distinctness
,
and
,
saving
for
some
flashes
now
<EOS>
and
then
,
no
reference
to
his
condition
or
the
train
of
circumstances
by
which
it
had
been
brought
about
.
<EOS>
The
cracks
in
the
pavement
of
his
cell
,
the
chinks
in
the
wall
where
stone
was
joined
to
stone
,
the
bars
in
the
window
,
the
iron
ring
upon
the
floor
,
---
such
things
as
these
,
subsiding
strangely
into
one
another
,
and
awakening
an
indescribable
kind
of
interest
and
amusement
,
engrossed
his
whole
mind
;
and
although
at
the
bottom
of
his
every
thought
there
was
an
uneasy
sense
of
guilt
,
and
dread
of
death
,
he
felt
no
more
than
that
vague
consciousness
of
it
,
which
a
sleeper
has
of
pain
.
 
<EOS>
It
pursues
him
through
his
dreams
,
gnaws
at
the
heart
of
all
his
fancied
pleasures
,
robs
the
banquet
of
its
taste
,
music
of
its
sweetness
,
makes
happiness
itself
unhappy
,
and
yet
is
no
bodily
sensation
,
but
a
phantom
without
shape
,
or
form
,
or
visible
presence
;
pervading
everything
,
but
having
no
existence
;
recognisable
everywhere
,
but
nowhere
seen
,
or
touched
,
or
met
with
face
to
face
,
until
the
sleep
is
past
,
and
waking
agony
returns
.
  
<EOS>
After
a
long
time
the
door
of
his
cell
opened
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
up
;
saw
the
blind
man
enter
;
and
relapsed
into
his
former
position
.
  
<EOS>
Guided
by
his
breathing
,
the
visitor
advanced
to
where
he
sat
;
and
stopping
beside
him
,
and
stretching
out
his
hand
to
assure
himself
that
he
was
right
,
remained
,
for
a
good
space
,
silent
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
bad
,
Rudge
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
bad
,
"
he
said
at
length
.
  
<EOS>
The
prisoner
shuffled
with
his
feet
upon
the
ground
in
turning
his
body
from
him
,
but
made
no
other
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
were
you
taken
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
where
?
 
<EOS>
You
never
told
me
more
than
half
your
secret
.
 
<EOS>
No
matter
;
I
know
it
now
.
 
<EOS>
How
was
it
,
and
where
,
eh
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
again
,
coming
still
nearer
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
Chigwell
,
"
said
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
Chigwell
!
 
<EOS>
How
came
you
there
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
went
there
to
avoid
the
man
I
stumbled
on
,
"
he
answered
.
<EOS>
"
Because
I
was
chased
and
driven
there
,
by
him
and
Fate
.
 
<EOS>
Because
I
was
urged
to
go
there
,
by
something
stronger
than
my
own
will
.
<EOS>
When
I
found
him
watching
in
the
house
she
used
to
live
in
,
night
after
night
,
I
knew
I
never
could
escape
him
---
never
!
<EOS>
and
when
I
heard
the
Bell
---
"
  
He
shivered
;
muttered
that
it
was
very
cold
;
paced
quickly
up
and
down
the
narrow
cell
;
and
sitting
down
again
,
fell
into
his
old
posture
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
saying
,
"
said
the
blind
man
,
after
another
pause
,
"
that
when
you
heard
the
Bell
---
"
  
"
Let
it
be
,
will
you
?
"
<EOS>
he
retorted
in
a
hurried
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
hangs
there
yet
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
blind
man
turned
a
wistful
and
inquisitive
face
towards
him
,
but
he
continued
to
speak
,
without
noticing
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
went
to
Chigwell
,
in
search
of
the
mob
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
so
hunted
and
beset
by
this
man
<EOS>
,
that
I
knew
my
only
hope
of
safety
lay
in
joining
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
gone
on
before
;
I
followed
them
when
it
left
off
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
what
left
off
?
"
  
"
The
Bell
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
quitted
the
place
.
 
<EOS>
I
hoped
that
some
of
them
might
be
still
lingering
among
the
ruins
,
and
was
searching
for
them
when
I
heard
---
"
he
drew
a
long
breath
,
and
wiped
his
forehead
with
his
sleeve
---
"
his
voice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Saying
what
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
matter
what
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
then
at
the
foot
of
the
turret
,
where
I
did
the
---
"
  
"
Ay
,
"
said
the
blind
man
,
nodding
his
head
with
perfect
composure
,
"
I
understand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
climbed
the
stair
,
or
so
much
of
it
as
was
left
;
<EOS>
meaning
to
hide
till
he
had
gone
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
heard
me
;
and
followed
almost
as
soon
as
I
set
foot
upon
the
ashes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
might
have
hidden
in
the
wall
,
and
thrown
him
down
,
or
stabbed
him
,
"
said
the
blind
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
Might
I
?
 
<EOS>
Between
that
man
and
me
,
was
one
who
led
him
on
---
<EOS>
I
saw
it
,
though
he
did
not
---
and
raised
above
his
head
a
bloody
hand
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
the
room
above
that
HE
<EOS>
and
I
stood
glaring
at
each
other
on
the
night
of
the
murder
,
and
before
he
fell
he
raised
his
hand
like
that
,
and
fixed
his
eyes
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
the
chase
would
end
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
strong
fancy
,
"
said
the
blind
man
,
with
a
smile
.
  
<EOS>
"
Strengthen
yours
with
blood
,
and
see
what
it
will
come
to
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
groaned
,
and
rocked
himself
,
and
looking
up
for
the
first
time
,
said
,
in
a
low
,
hollow
voice
:
  
"
Eight
-
and
-
twenty
years
!
 
<EOS>
Eight
-
and
-
twenty
years
!
 
<EOS>
He
has
never
changed
in
all
that
time
,
never
grown
older
,
nor
altered
in
the
least
degree
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
before
me
in
the
dark
night
,
and
the
broad
sunny
day
;
in
the
twilight
,
the
moonlight
,
the
sunlight
,
the
light
of
fire
,
and
lamp
,
and
candle
;
and
in
the
deepest
gloom
.
<EOS>
Always
the
same
!
 
<EOS>
In
company
,
in
solitude
,
on
land
,
on
shipboard
;
sometimes
leaving
me
alone
for
months
,
and
sometimes
always
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
him
,
at
sea
,
come
gliding
in
the
dead
of
night
along
the
bright
reflection
of
the
moon
in
the
calm
water
;
and
I
have
seen
him
,
on
quays
and
market
-
places
,
with
his
hand
uplifted
,
towering
,
the
centre
of
a
busy
crowd
,
unconscious
of
the
terrible
form
that
had
its
silent
stand
among
them
.
 
<EOS>
Fancy
!
 
<EOS>
Are
you
real
?
<EOS>
Am
I
?
 
<EOS>
Are
these
iron
fetters
,
riveted
on
me
by
the
smith
's
hammer
,
or
are
they
fancies
I
can
shatter
at
a
blow
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
blind
man
listened
in
silence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Fancy
!
 
<EOS>
Do
I
fancy
that
I
killed
him
?
 
<EOS>
Do
I
fancy
that
as
I
left
the
chamber
where
he
lay
,
I
saw
the
face
of
a
man
peeping
from
a
dark
door
,
who
plainly
showed
me
by
his
fearful
looks
that
he
suspected
what
I
had
done
?
 
<EOS>
Do
I
remember
that
I
spoke
fairly
to
him
---
that
I
drew
nearer
---
nearer
yet
---
with
the
hot
knife
in
my
sleeve
?
 
<EOS>
Do
I
fancy
how
HE
died
?
 
<EOS>
Did
he
stagger
back
into
the
angle
of
the
wall
into
which
I
had
hemmed
him
,
and
,
bleeding
inwardly
,
stand
,
not
fail
,
a
corpse
before
me
?
 
<EOS>
Did
I
see
him
,
for
an
instant
,
as
I
see
you
now
,
erect
and
on
his
feet
---
but
dead
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
blind
man
,
who
knew
that
he
had
risen
,
motioned
him
to
sit
down
again
upon
his
bedstead
;
but
he
took
no
notice
of
the
gesture
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
then
I
thought
,
for
the
first
time
,
of
fastening
the
murder
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
then
I
dressed
him
in
my
clothes
,
and
dragged
him
down
the
back
-
stairs
to
the
piece
of
water
.
 
<EOS>
Do
I
remember
listening
to
the
bubbles
that
came
rising
up
when
I
had
rolled
him
in
?
 
<EOS>
Do
I
remember
wiping
the
water
from
my
face
,
and
because
the
body
splashed
it
there
,
in
its
descent
,
feeling
as
if
it
MUST
be
blood
?
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
go
home
when
I
had
done
?
 
<EOS>
And
oh
,
my
God
!
<EOS>
how
long
it
took
to
do
!
 
<EOS>
Did
I
stand
before
my
wife
,
and
tell
her
?
 
<EOS>
Did
I
see
her
fall
upon
the
ground
;
and
,
when
I
stooped
to
raise
her
,
did
she
thrust
me
back
with
a
force
that
cast
me
off
as
if
I
had
been
a
child
,
staining
the
hand
with
which
she
clasped
my
wrist
?
 
<EOS>
Is
THAT
fancy
?
  
<EOS>
"
Did
she
go
down
upon
her
knees
,
and
call
on
Heaven
to
witness
that
she
and
her
unborn
child
renounced
me
from
that
hour
;
and
did
she
,
in
words
so
solemn
that
they
turned
me
cold
---
me
,
fresh
from
the
horrors
my
own
hands
had
made
---
warn
me
to
fly
while
there
was
time
;
for
though
she
would
be
silent
,
being
my
wretched
wife
,
she
would
not
shelter
me
?
 
<EOS>
Did
I
go
forth
that
night
,
abjured
of
God
and
man
,
and
anchored
deep
in
hell
,
to
wander
at
my
cable
's
length
about
the
earth
,
and
surely
be
drawn
down
at
last
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
did
you
return
?
 
<EOS>
said
the
blind
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
is
blood
red
?
 
<EOS>
I
could
no
more
help
it
,
than
I
could
live
without
breath
.
 
<EOS>
I
struggled
against
the
impulse
,
but
I
was
drawn
back
,
through
every
difficult
and
adverse
circumstance
,
as
by
a
mighty
engine
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
could
stop
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
day
and
hour
were
none
of
my
choice
.
 
<EOS>
Sleeping
and
waking
<EOS>
,
I
had
been
among
the
old
haunts
for
years
---
had
visited
my
own
grave
.
 
<EOS>
Why
did
I
come
back
?
 
<EOS>
Because
this
jail
was
gaping
for
me
,
and
he
stood
beckoning
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
not
known
?
"
said
the
blind
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
a
man
who
had
been
twenty
-
two
years
dead
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
known
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
have
kept
your
secret
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
MY
secret
?
 
<EOS>
MINE
?
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
secret
,
any
breath
of
air
could
whisper
at
its
will
.
 
<EOS>
The
stars
had
it
in
their
twinkling
,
the
water
in
its
flowing
,
the
leaves
in
their
rustling
,
the
seasons
in
their
return
.
 
<EOS>
It
lurked
in
strangers
'
faces
,
and
their
voices
.
<EOS>
Everything
had
lips
on
which
it
always
trembled
.
<EOS>
---
MY
secret
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
revealed
by
your
own
act
at
any
rate
,
"
said
the
blind
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
act
was
not
mine
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
it
,
but
it
was
not
mine
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
forced
at
times
to
wander
round
,
and
round
,
and
round
that
spot
.
<EOS>
If
you
had
chained
me
up
when
the
fit
was
on
me
,
I
should
have
broken
away
,
and
gone
there
.
 
<EOS>
As
truly
as
the
loadstone
draws
iron
towards
it
,
so
he
,
lying
at
the
bottom
of
his
grave
,
could
draw
me
near
him
when
he
would
.
 
<EOS>
Was
that
fancy
?
 
<EOS>
Did
I
like
to
go
there
,
or
did
I
strive
and
wrestle
with
the
power
that
forced
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
blind
man
shrugged
his
shoulders
,
and
smiled
incredulously
.
<EOS>
The
prisoner
again
resumed
his
old
attitude
,
and
for
a
long
time
both
were
mute
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
then
,
"
said
his
visitor
,
at
length
breaking
silence
,
"
that
you
are
penitent
and
resigned
;
that
you
desire
to
make
peace
with
everybody
(
in
particular
,
with
your
wife
who
has
brought
you
to
this
)
;
and
that
you
ask
no
greater
favour
than
to
be
carried
to
Tyburn
as
soon
as
possible
?
 
<EOS>
That
being
the
case
,
I
had
better
take
my
leave
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
good
enough
to
be
company
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
I
not
told
you
,
"
said
the
other
fiercely
,
"
that
I
have
striven
and
wrestled
with
the
power
that
brought
me
here
?
 
<EOS>
Has
my
whole
life
,
for
eight
-
and
-
twenty
years
,
been
one
perpetual
struggle
and
resistance
,
and
do
you
think
I
want
to
lie
down
and
die
?
 
<EOS>
Do
all
men
shrink
from
death
---
<EOS>
I
most
of
all
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
That
's
better
said
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
better
spoken
,
Rudge
---
<EOS>
but
I
'll
not
call
you
that
again
---
than
anything
you
have
said
yet
,
"
returned
the
blind
man
,
speaking
more
familiarly
,
and
laying
his
hands
upon
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
"
Lookye
,
---
I
never
killed
a
man
myself
,
for
I
have
never
been
placed
in
a
position
that
made
it
worth
my
while
.
 
<EOS>
Farther
,
I
am
not
an
advocate
for
killing
men
,
and
I
do
n't
think
I
should
recommend
it
<EOS>
or
like
it
---
for
it
's
very
hazardous
---
under
any
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
you
had
the
misfortune
to
get
into
this
trouble
before
I
made
your
acquaintance
,
and
as
you
have
been
my
companion
,
and
have
been
of
use
to
me
for
a
long
time
now
,
I
overlook
that
part
of
the
matter
,
and
am
only
anxious
that
you
should
n't
die
unnecessarily
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
do
not
consider
that
,
at
present
,
it
is
at
all
necessary
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
else
is
left
me
?
"
returned
the
prisoner
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
eat
my
way
through
these
walls
with
my
teeth
?
"
  
"
Something
easier
than
that
,
"
returned
his
friend
.
 
<EOS>
"
Promise
me
that
you
will
talk
no
more
of
these
fancies
of
yours
---
idle
,
foolish
things
,
quite
beneath
a
man
---
and
I
'll
tell
you
what
I
mean
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Tell
me
,
"
said
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
worthy
lady
with
the
tender
conscience
;
your
scrupulous
,
virtuous
,
punctilious
,
but
not
blindly
affectionate
wife
---
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
of
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
now
in
London
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
curse
upon
her
,
be
she
where
she
may
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
natural
enough
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
had
taken
her
annuity
as
usual
,
you
would
not
have
been
here
,
and
we
should
have
been
better
off
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
's
apart
from
the
business
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
Scared
,
as
I
suppose
,
and
have
no
doubt
,
by
my
representation
when
I
waited
upon
her
,
that
you
were
close
at
hand
(
which
I
,
of
course
,
urged
only
as
an
inducement
to
compliance
,
knowing
that
she
was
not
pining
to
see
you
)
<EOS>
,
she
left
that
place
,
and
travelled
up
to
London
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
From
my
friend
the
noble
captain
---
the
illustrious
general
---
the
bladder
,
Mr
Tappertit
.
 
<EOS>
I
learnt
from
him
the
last
time
I
saw
him
,
which
was
yesterday
,
that
your
son
who
is
called
Barnaby
---
not
after
his
father
,
I
suppose
---
"
  
"
Death
!
<EOS>
does
that
matter
now
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
---
You
are
impatient
,
"
said
the
blind
man
,
calmly
;
"
it
's
a
good
sign
,
and
looks
like
life
---
that
your
son
Barnaby
had
been
lured
away
from
her
by
one
of
his
companions
who
knew
him
of
old
,
at
Chigwell
;
and
that
he
is
now
among
the
rioters
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
is
that
to
me
?
 
<EOS>
If
father
and
son
be
hanged
together
,
what
comfort
shall
I
find
in
that
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Stay
---
stay
,
my
friend
,
"
returned
the
blind
man
,
with
a
cunning
look
,
"
you
travel
fast
to
journeys
'
ends
.
 
<EOS>
Suppose
I
track
my
lady
out
,
and
say
thus
much
:
"
<EOS>
You
want
your
son
,
ma'am
---
good
.
 
<EOS>
I
,
knowing
those
who
tempt
him
to
remain
among
them
,
can
restore
him
to
you
,
ma'am
<EOS>
---
good
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
pay
a
price
,
ma'am
,
for
his
restoration
---
good
again
.
 
<EOS>
The
price
is
small
,
and
easy
to
be
paid
---
 
<EOS>
dear
ma'am
,
that
's
best
of
all
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
mockery
is
this
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
likely
,
she
may
reply
in
those
words
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
mockery
at
all
,
"
I
answer
:
"
Madam
,
a
person
said
to
be
your
husband
(
identity
is
difficult
of
proof
after
the
lapse
of
many
years
)
is
in
prison
,
his
life
in
peril
---
the
charge
against
him
,
murder
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
ma'am
,
your
husband
has
been
dead
a
long
,
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
never
can
be
confounded
with
him
,
if
you
will
have
the
goodness
to
say
a
few
words
,
on
oath
,
as
to
when
he
died
,
and
how
;
and
that
this
person
(
who
I
am
told
resembles
him
in
some
degree
)
is
no
more
he
than
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
Such
testimony
will
set
the
question
quite
at
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Pledge
yourself
to
me
to
give
it
,
ma
"
am
,
and
I
will
undertake
to
keep
your
son
(
a
fine
lad
)
out
of
harm
's
way
until
you
have
done
this
trifling
service
,
when
he
shall
he
delivered
up
to
you
,
safe
and
sound
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
other
hand
,
if
you
decline
to
do
so
,
I
fear
he
will
be
betrayed
,
and
handed
over
to
the
law
,
which
will
assuredly
sentence
him
to
suffer
death
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
,
in
fact
,
a
choice
between
his
life
and
death
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
refuse
,
he
swings
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
comply
,
the
timber
is
not
grown
,
nor
the
hemp
sown
,
that
shall
do
him
any
harm
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
There
is
a
gleam
of
hope
in
this
!
"
cried
the
prisoner
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
gleam
!
"
returned
his
friend
,
"
a
noon
-
blaze
;
a
full
and
glorious
daylight
.
 
<EOS>
Hush
!
<EOS>
I
hear
the
tread
of
distant
feet
.
 
<EOS>
Rely
on
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
shall
I
hear
more
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
soon
as
I
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
hope
,
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
coming
to
say
that
our
time
for
talk
is
over
.
 
<EOS>
I
hear
the
jingling
of
the
keys
.
 
<EOS>
Not
another
word
of
this
just
now
,
or
they
may
overhear
us
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
said
these
words
,
the
lock
was
turned
,
and
one
of
the
prison
turnkeys
appearing
at
the
door
,
announced
that
it
was
time
for
visitors
to
leave
the
jail
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
soon
!
"
said
Stagg
,
meekly
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
it
ca
n't
be
helped
.
 
<EOS>
Cheer
up
,
friend
.
 
<EOS>
This
mistake
will
soon
be
set
at
rest
,
and
then
you
are
a
man
again
!
 
<EOS>
If
this
charitable
gentleman
will
lead
a
blind
man
(
who
has
nothing
in
return
but
prayers
)
to
the
prison
-
porch
,
and
set
him
with
his
face
towards
the
west
,
he
will
do
a
worthy
deed
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
good
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
thank
you
very
kindly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
saying
,
and
pausing
for
an
instant
at
the
door
to
turn
his
grinning
face
towards
his
friend
,
he
departed
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
officer
had
seen
him
to
the
porch
,
he
returned
,
and
again
unlocking
and
unbarring
the
door
of
the
cell
,
set
it
wide
open
,
informing
its
inmate
that
he
was
at
liberty
to
walk
in
the
adjacent
yard
,
if
he
thought
proper
,
for
an
hour
.
  
<EOS>
The
prisoner
answered
with
a
sullen
nod
;
and
being
left
alone
again
,
sat
brooding
over
what
he
had
heard
,
and
pondering
upon
the
hopes
the
recent
conversation
had
awakened
;
gazing
abstractedly
,
the
while
he
did
so
,
on
the
light
without
,
and
watching
the
shadows
thrown
by
one
wall
on
another
,
and
on
the
stone
-
paved
ground
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
dull
,
square
yard
,
made
cold
and
gloomy
by
high
walls
,
and
seeming
to
chill
the
very
sunlight
.
 
<EOS>
The
stone
,
so
bare
,
and
rough
,
and
obdurate
,
filled
even
him
with
longing
thoughts
of
meadow
-
land
and
trees
;
and
with
a
burning
wish
to
be
at
liberty
.
<EOS>
As
he
looked
,
he
rose
,
and
leaning
against
the
door
-
post
,
gazed
up
at
the
bright
blue
sky
,
smiling
even
on
that
dreary
home
of
crime
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
,
for
a
moment
,
to
remember
lying
on
his
back
in
some
sweet
-
scented
place
,
and
gazing
at
it
through
moving
branches
,
long
ago
.
  
<EOS>
His
attention
was
suddenly
attracted
by
a
clanking
sound
---
he
knew
what
it
was
,
for
he
had
startled
himself
by
making
the
same
noise
in
walking
to
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Presently
a
voice
began
to
sing
,
and
he
saw
the
shadow
of
a
figure
on
the
pavement
.
 
<EOS>
It
stopped
---
was
silent
all
at
once
,
as
though
the
person
for
a
moment
had
forgotten
where
he
was
,
but
soon
remembered
---
and
<EOS>
so
,
with
the
same
clanking
noise
,
the
shadow
disappeared
.
  
<EOS>
He
walked
out
into
the
court
and
paced
it
to
and
fro
;
startling
the
echoes
,
as
he
went
,
with
the
harsh
jangling
of
his
fetters
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
door
near
his
,
which
,
like
his
,
stood
ajar
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
taken
half
-
a
-
dozen
turns
up
and
down
the
yard
,
when
,
standing
still
to
observe
this
door
,
he
heard
the
clanking
sound
again
.
 
<EOS>
A
face
looked
out
of
the
grated
window
---
he
saw
it
very
dimly
,
for
the
cell
was
dark
and
the
bars
were
heavy
---
and
directly
afterwards
,
a
man
appeared
,
and
came
towards
him
.
  
<EOS>
For
the
sense
of
loneliness
he
had
,
he
might
have
been
in
jail
a
year
.
 
<EOS>
Made
eager
by
the
hope
of
companionship
,
he
quickened
his
pace
,
and
hastened
to
meet
the
man
half
way
---
   
<EOS>
What
was
this
!
 
<EOS>
His
son
!
  
<EOS>
They
stood
face
to
face
,
staring
at
each
other
.
 
<EOS>
He
shrinking
and
cowed
,
despite
himself
;
<EOS>
Barnahy
struggling
with
his
imperfect
memory
,
and
wondering
where
he
had
seen
that
face
before
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
uncertain
long
,
for
suddenly
he
laid
hands
upon
him
,
and
striving
to
bear
him
to
the
ground
,
cried
:
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
know
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
the
robber
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
in
reply
at
first
,
but
held
down
his
head
,
and
struggled
with
him
silently
.
 
<EOS>
Finding
the
younger
man
too
strong
for
him
,
he
raised
his
face
,
looked
close
into
his
eyes
,
and
said
,
  
"
I
am
your
father
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
God
knows
what
magic
the
name
had
for
his
ears
;
but
Barnaby
released
his
hold
,
fell
back
,
and
looked
at
him
aghast
.
 
<EOS>
Suddenly
he
sprung
towards
him
,
put
his
arms
about
his
neck
,
and
pressed
his
head
against
his
cheek
.
  
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
he
was
;
he
was
sure
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
But
where
had
he
been
so
long
,
and
why
had
he
left
his
mother
by
herself
,
or
worse
than
by
herself
,
with
her
poor
foolish
boy
?
 
<EOS>
And
had
she
really
been
as
happy
as
they
said
?
 
<EOS>
And
where
was
she
?
 
<EOS>
Was
she
near
there
?
 
<EOS>
She
was
not
happy
now
,
and
he
in
jail
?
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
no
.
  
<EOS>
Not
a
word
was
said
in
answer
;
but
Grip
croaked
loudly
,
and
hopped
about
them
,
round
and
round
,
as
if
enclosing
them
in
a
magic
circle
,
and
invoking
all
the
powers
of
mischief
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
63
    
During
the
whole
of
this
day
,
every
regiment
in
or
near
the
metropolis
was
on
duty
in
one
or
other
part
of
the
town
;
and
the
regulars
and
militia
,
in
obedience
to
the
orders
which
were
sent
to
every
barrack
and
station
within
twenty
-
four
hours
'
journey
,
began
to
pour
in
by
all
the
roads
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
disturbance
had
attained
to
such
a
formidable
height
,
and
the
rioters
had
grown
,
with
impunity
,
to
be
so
audacious
,
that
the
sight
of
this
great
force
,
continually
augmented
by
new
arrivals
,
instead
of
operating
as
a
check
,
stimulated
them
to
outrages
of
greater
hardihood
than
any
they
had
yet
committed
;
and
helped
to
kindle
a
flame
in
London
,
the
like
of
which
had
never
been
beheld
,
even
in
its
ancient
and
rebellious
times
.
  
<EOS>
All
yesterday
,
and
on
this
day
likewise
,
the
commander
-
in
-
chief
endeavoured
to
arouse
the
magistrates
to
a
sense
of
their
duty
,
and
in
particular
the
Lord
Mayor
,
who
was
the
faintest
-
hearted
and
most
timid
of
them
all
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
object
,
large
bodies
of
the
soldiery
were
several
times
despatched
to
the
Mansion
House
to
await
his
orders
:
<EOS>
but
as
he
could
,
by
no
threats
or
persuasions
,
be
induced
to
give
any
,
and
as
the
men
remained
in
the
open
street
,
fruitlessly
for
any
good
purpose
,
and
thrivingly
for
a
very
bad
one
;
these
laudable
attempts
did
harm
rather
than
good
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
crowd
,
becoming
speedily
acquainted
with
the
Lord
Mayor
's
temper
,
did
not
fail
to
take
advantage
of
it
by
boasting
that
even
the
civil
authorities
were
opposed
to
the
Papists
,
and
could
not
find
it
in
their
hearts
to
molest
those
who
were
guilty
of
no
other
offence
.
 
<EOS>
These
vaunts
they
took
care
to
make
within
the
hearing
of
the
soldiers
;
and
<EOS>
they
,
being
naturally
loth
to
quarrel
with
the
people
,
received
their
advances
kindly
enough
:
answering
,
when
they
were
asked
if
they
desired
to
fire
upon
their
countrymen
,
"
No
,
they
would
be
damned
if
they
did
;
"
and
showing
much
honest
simplicity
and
good
nature
.
 
<EOS>
The
feeling
that
the
military
were
No
-
Popery
men
,
and
were
ripe
for
disobeying
orders
and
joining
the
mob
,
soon
became
very
prevalent
in
consequence
.
 
<EOS>
Rumours
of
their
disaffection
,
and
of
their
leaning
towards
the
popular
cause
,
spread
from
mouth
to
mouth
with
astonishing
rapidity
;
and
whenever
they
were
drawn
up
idly
in
the
streets
or
squares
,
there
was
sure
to
be
a
crowd
about
them
,
cheering
and
shaking
hands
,
and
treating
them
with
a
great
show
of
confidence
and
affection
.
  
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
crowd
was
everywhere
;
all
concealment
and
disguise
were
laid
aside
,
and
they
pervaded
the
whole
town
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
man
among
them
wanted
money
,
he
had
but
to
knock
at
the
door
of
a
dwelling
-
house
,
or
walk
into
a
shop
,
and
demand
it
in
the
rioters
name
;
and
his
demand
was
instantly
complied
with
.
 
<EOS>
The
peaceable
citizens
being
afraid
to
lay
hands
upon
them
,
singly
and
alone
,
it
may
be
easily
supposed
that
when
gathered
together
in
bodies
,
they
were
perfectly
secure
from
interruption
.
 
<EOS>
They
assembled
in
the
streets
,
traversed
them
at
their
will
and
pleasure
,
and
publicly
concerted
their
plans
.
 
<EOS>
Business
was
quite
suspended
;
the
greater
part
of
the
shops
were
closed
;
most
of
the
houses
displayed
a
blue
flag
in
token
of
their
adherence
to
the
popular
side
;
and
even
the
Jews
in
Houndsditch
,
Whitechapel
,
and
those
quarters
,
wrote
upon
their
doors
or
window
-
shutters
,
"
This
House
is
a
True
Protestant
.
<EOS>
"
The
crowd
was
the
law
,
and
never
was
the
law
held
in
greater
dread
,
or
more
implicitly
obeyed
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
about
six
o'clock
in
the
evening
,
when
a
vast
mob
poured
into
Lincoln
's
Inn
Fields
by
every
avenue
,
and
divided
---
evidently
in
pursuance
of
a
previous
design
---
into
several
parties
.
 
<EOS>
It
must
not
be
understood
that
this
arrangement
was
known
to
the
whole
crowd
,
but
that
it
was
the
work
of
a
few
leaders
;
who
,
mingling
with
the
men
as
they
came
upon
the
ground
,
and
calling
to
them
to
fall
into
this
or
that
parry
,
effected
it
as
rapidly
as
if
it
had
been
determined
on
by
a
council
of
the
whole
number
,
and
every
man
had
known
his
place
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
perfectly
notorious
to
the
assemblage
that
the
largest
body
,
which
comprehended
about
two
-
thirds
of
the
whole
,
was
designed
for
the
attack
on
Newgate
.
 
<EOS>
It
comprehended
all
the
rioters
who
had
been
conspicuous
in
any
of
their
former
proceedings
;
all
those
whom
they
recommended
as
daring
hands
and
fit
for
the
work
;
all
those
whose
companions
had
been
taken
in
the
riots
;
and
a
great
number
of
people
who
were
relatives
or
friends
of
felons
in
the
jail
.
 
<EOS>
This
last
class
included
,
not
only
the
most
desperate
and
utterly
abandoned
villains
in
London
,
but
some
who
were
comparatively
innocent
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
more
than
one
woman
there
,
disguised
in
man
's
attire
,
and
bent
upon
the
rescue
of
a
child
or
brother
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
the
two
sons
of
a
man
who
lay
under
sentence
of
death
,
and
who
was
to
be
executed
along
with
three
others
,
on
the
next
day
but
one
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
great
parry
of
boys
whose
fellow
-
pickpockets
were
in
the
prison
;
and
at
the
skirts
of
all
,
a
score
of
miserable
women
,
outcasts
from
the
world
,
seeking
to
release
some
other
fallen
creature
as
miserable
as
themselves
,
or
moved
by
a
general
sympathy
perhaps
---
God
knows
---
with
all
who
were
without
hope
,
and
wretched
.
  
<EOS>
Old
swords
,
and
pistols
without
ball
or
powder
;
sledge
-
hammers
,
knives
,
axes
,
saws
,
and
weapons
pillaged
from
the
butchers
'
shops
;
a
forest
of
iron
bars
and
wooden
clubs
<EOS>
;
long
ladders
for
scaling
the
walls
,
each
carried
on
the
shoulders
of
a
dozen
men
;
lighted
torches
;
tow
smeared
with
pitch
,
and
tar
,
and
brimstone
;
staves
roughly
plucked
from
fence
and
paling
;
and
even
crutches
taken
from
crippled
beggars
in
the
streets
;
composed
their
arms
.
 
<EOS>
When
all
was
ready
,
Hugh
and
Dennis
,
with
Simon
Tappertit
between
them
,
led
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
Roaring
and
chafing
like
an
angry
sea
,
the
crowd
pressed
after
them
.
  
<EOS>
Instead
of
going
straight
down
Holborn
to
the
jail
,
as
all
expected
,
their
leaders
took
the
way
to
Clerkenwell
,
and
pouring
down
a
quiet
street
,
halted
before
a
locksmith
's
house
---
the
Golden
Key
.
  
<EOS>
"
Beat
at
the
door
,
"
cried
Hugh
to
the
men
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
want
one
of
his
craft
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
Beat
it
in
,
if
no
one
answers
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
shop
was
shut
.
 
<EOS>
Both
door
and
shutters
were
of
a
strong
and
sturdy
kind
,
and
they
knocked
without
effect
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
impatient
crowd
raising
a
cry
of
"
Set
fire
to
the
house
!
"
<EOS>
and
torches
being
passed
to
the
front
,
an
upper
window
was
thrown
open
,
and
the
stout
old
locksmith
stood
before
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
now
,
you
villains
!
"
<EOS>
he
demanded
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
my
daughter
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ask
no
questions
of
us
,
old
man
,
"
retorted
Hugh
,
waving
his
comrades
to
be
silent
,
"
but
come
down
,
and
bring
the
tools
of
your
trade
.
 
<EOS>
We
want
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Want
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
locksmith
,
glancing
at
the
regimental
dress
he
wore
:
"
<EOS>
Ay
,
and
if
some
that
I
could
name
possessed
the
hearts
of
mice
,
ye
should
have
had
me
long
ago
.
 
<EOS>
Mark
me
,
my
lad
---
<EOS>
and
you
about
him
do
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
a
score
among
ye
whom
I
see
now
and
know
,
who
are
dead
men
from
this
hour
.
 
<EOS>
Begone
!
<EOS>
and
rob
an
undertaker
's
while
you
can
!
 
<EOS>
You
'll
want
some
coffins
before
long
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
come
down
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
give
me
my
daughter
,
ruffian
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
nothing
of
her
,
"
Hugh
rejoined
.
 
<EOS>
"
Burn
the
door
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
locksmith
,
in
a
voice
that
made
them
falter
---
 
presenting
,
as
he
spoke
,
a
gun
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
an
old
man
do
that
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
spare
him
better
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
young
fellow
who
held
the
light
,
and
who
was
stooping
down
before
the
door
,
rose
hastily
at
these
words
,
and
fell
back
.
 
<EOS>
The
locksmith
ran
his
eye
along
the
upturned
faces
,
and
kept
the
weapon
levelled
at
the
threshold
of
his
house
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
no
other
rest
than
his
shoulder
,
but
was
as
steady
as
the
house
itself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
the
man
who
does
it
,
take
heed
to
his
prayers
,
"
he
said
firmly
;
"
I
warn
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
Snatching
a
torch
from
one
who
stood
near
him
,
Hugh
was
stepping
forward
with
an
oath
,
when
he
was
arrested
by
a
shrill
and
piercing
shriek
,
and
,
looking
upward
,
saw
a
fluttering
garment
on
the
house
-
top
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
another
shriek
,
and
another
,
and
then
a
shrill
voice
cried
,
"
Is
Simmun
below
!
"
<EOS>
At
the
same
moment
a
lean
neck
was
stretched
over
the
parapet
,
and
Miss
Miggs
,
indistinctly
seen
in
the
gathering
gloom
of
evening
,
screeched
in
a
frenzied
manner
,
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
dear
gentlemen
,
let
me
hear
Simmuns
's
answer
from
his
own
lips
.
 
<EOS>
Speak
to
me
,
Simmun
.
 
<EOS>
Speak
to
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Tappertit
,
who
was
not
at
all
flattered
by
this
compliment
,
looked
up
,
and
bidding
her
hold
her
peace
,
ordered
her
to
come
down
and
open
the
door
,
for
they
wanted
her
master
,
and
would
take
no
denial
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
good
gentlemen
!
"
cried
Miss
Miggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
my
own
precious
,
precious
Simmun
---
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
nonsense
,
will
you
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Mr
Tappertit
;
"
and
come
down
and
open
the
door
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
G
Varden
,
drop
that
gun
,
or
it
will
be
worse
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
mind
his
gun
,
"
screamed
Miggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Simmun
and
gentlemen
,
I
poured
a
mug
of
table
-
beer
right
down
the
barrel
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
crowd
gave
a
loud
shout
,
which
was
followed
by
a
roar
of
laughter
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
n't
go
off
,
not
if
you
was
to
load
it
up
to
the
muzzle
,
"
screamed
Miggs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Simmun
and
gentlemen
,
I
'm
locked
up
in
the
front
attic
,
through
the
little
door
on
the
right
hand
when
you
think
you
've
got
to
the
very
top
of
the
stairs
<EOS>
---
and
up
the
flight
of
corner
steps
,
being
careful
not
to
knock
your
heads
against
the
rafters
,
and
not
to
tread
on
one
side
in
case
you
should
fall
into
the
two
-
pair
bedroom
through
the
lath
and
plasture
,
which
do
not
bear
,
but
the
contrairy
.
 
<EOS>
Simmun
and
gentlemen
,
I
've
been
locked
up
here
for
safety
,
but
my
endeavours
has
always
been
,
and
always
will
be
,
to
be
on
the
right
side
---
the
blessed
side
and
to
prenounce
the
Pope
of
Babylon
,
and
all
her
inward
and
her
outward
workings
,
which
is
Pagin
.
 
<EOS>
My
sentiments
is
of
little
consequences
,
I
know
,
"
cried
Miggs
,
with
additional
shrillness
,
"
for
my
positions
is
but
a
servant
,
and
as
sich
,
of
humilities
,
still
I
gives
expressions
to
my
feelings
,
and
places
my
reliances
on
them
which
entertains
my
own
opinions
!
"
  
<EOS>
Without
taking
much
notice
of
these
outpourings
of
Miss
Miggs
after
she
had
made
her
first
announcement
in
relation
to
the
gun
,
the
crowd
raised
a
ladder
against
the
window
where
the
locksmith
stood
,
and
notwithstanding
that
he
closed
,
and
fastened
,
and
defended
it
manfully
,
soon
forced
an
entrance
by
shivering
the
glass
and
breaking
in
the
frames
.
 
<EOS>
After
dealing
a
few
stout
blows
about
him
,
he
found
himself
defenceless
,
in
the
midst
of
a
furious
crowd
,
which
overflowed
the
room
and
softened
off
in
a
confused
heap
of
faces
at
the
door
and
window
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
very
wrathful
with
him
(
for
he
had
wounded
two
men
)
,
and
even
called
out
to
those
in
front
,
to
bring
him
forth
and
hang
him
on
a
lamp
-
post
.
 
<EOS>
But
Gabriel
was
quite
undaunted
,
and
looked
from
Hugh
and
Dennis
,
who
held
him
by
either
arm
,
to
Simon
Tappertit
,
who
confronted
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
robbed
me
of
my
daughter
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
"
who
is
far
dearer
to
me
than
my
life
;
and
you
may
take
my
life
,
if
you
will
.
 
<EOS>
I
bless
God
that
I
have
been
enabled
to
keep
my
wife
free
of
this
scene
;
and
that
He
has
made
me
a
man
who
will
not
ask
mercy
at
such
hands
as
yours
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
a
wery
game
old
gentleman
you
are
,
"
said
Mr
Dennis
,
approvingly
;
"
and
you
express
yourself
like
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
odds
,
brother
,
whether
it
's
a
lamp
-
post
to
-
night
,
or
a
feather
-
bed
ten
year
to
come
,
eh
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
glanced
at
him
disdainfully
,
but
returned
no
other
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
For
my
part
,
"
said
the
hangman
,
who
particularly
favoured
the
lamp
-
post
suggestion
,
"
I
honour
your
principles
.
 
<EOS>
They
're
mine
exactly
.
 
<EOS>
In
such
sentiments
as
them
,
"
and
here
he
emphasised
his
discourse
with
an
oath
,
"
I
'm
ready
to
meet
you
or
any
man
halfway
.
<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>
Have
you
got
a
bit
of
cord
anywheres
handy
?
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
put
yourself
out
of
the
way
,
if
you
have
n't
.
 
<EOS>
A
handkecher
will
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
be
a
fool
,
master
,
"
whispered
Hugh
,
seizing
Varden
roughly
by
the
shoulder
;
"
but
do
as
you
're
bid
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
soon
hear
what
you
're
wanted
for
.
 
<EOS>
Do
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
do
nothing
at
your
request
,
or
that
of
any
scoundrel
here
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
want
any
service
from
me
,
you
may
spare
yourselves
the
pains
of
telling
me
what
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
,
beforehand
,
I
'll
do
nothing
for
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dennis
was
so
affected
by
this
constancy
on
the
part
of
the
staunch
old
man
,
that
he
protested
---
almost
with
tears
in
his
eyes
---
 
that
to
baulk
his
inclinations
would
be
an
act
of
cruelty
and
hard
dealing
to
which
he
,
for
one
,
never
could
reconcile
his
conscience
.
<EOS>
The
gentleman
,
he
said
,
had
avowed
in
so
many
words
that
he
was
ready
for
working
off
;
such
being
the
case
,
he
considered
it
their
duty
,
as
a
civilised
and
enlightened
crowd
,
to
work
him
off
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
often
,
he
observed
,
that
they
had
it
in
their
power
to
accommodate
themselves
to
the
wishes
of
those
from
whom
they
had
the
misfortune
to
differ
.
 
<EOS>
Having
now
found
an
individual
who
expressed
a
desire
which
they
could
reasonably
indulge
(
and
for
himself
he
was
free
to
confess
that
in
his
opinion
that
desire
did
honour
to
his
feelings
)
,
he
hoped
they
would
decide
to
accede
to
his
proposition
before
going
any
further
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
an
experiment
which
,
skilfully
and
dexterously
performed
,
would
be
over
in
five
minutes
,
with
great
comfort
and
satisfaction
to
all
parties
;
and
though
it
did
not
become
him
(
Mr
Dennis
)
to
speak
well
of
himself
<EOS>
he
trusted
he
might
be
allowed
to
say
that
he
had
practical
knowledge
of
the
subject
,
and
,
being
naturally
of
an
obliging
and
friendly
disposition
,
would
work
the
gentleman
off
with
a
deal
of
pleasure
.
  
<EOS>
These
remarks
,
which
were
addressed
in
the
midst
of
a
frightful
din
and
turmoil
to
those
immediately
about
him
,
were
received
with
great
favour
;
not
so
much
,
perhaps
,
because
of
the
hangman
's
eloquence
,
as
on
account
of
the
locksmith
's
obstinacy
.
 
<EOS>
Gabriel
was
in
imminent
peril
,
and
he
knew
it
;
but
he
preserved
a
steady
silence
;
and
would
have
done
so
,
if
they
had
been
debating
whether
they
should
roast
him
at
a
slow
fire
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
hangman
spoke
,
there
was
some
stir
and
confusion
on
the
ladder
;
and
directly
he
was
silent
---
<EOS>
so
immediately
upon
his
holding
his
peace
,
that
the
crowd
below
had
no
time
to
learn
what
he
had
been
saying
,
or
to
shout
in
response
---
<EOS>
some
one
at
the
window
cried
:
  
"
He
has
a
grey
head
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
an
old
man
:
Do
n't
hurt
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
turned
,
with
a
start
,
towards
the
place
from
which
the
words
had
come
,
and
looked
hurriedly
at
the
people
who
were
hanging
on
the
ladder
and
clinging
to
each
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pay
no
respect
to
my
grey
hair
,
young
man
,
"
he
said
,
answering
the
voice
and
not
any
one
he
saw
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
ask
it
.
 
<EOS>
My
heart
is
green
enough
to
scorn
and
despise
every
man
among
you
,
band
of
robbers
that
you
are
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
incautious
speech
by
no
means
tended
to
appease
the
ferocity
of
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
They
cried
again
to
have
him
brought
out
;
and
it
would
have
gone
hard
with
the
honest
locksmith
,
but
that
Hugh
reminded
them
,
in
answer
,
that
they
wanted
his
services
,
and
must
have
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
,
tell
him
what
we
want
,
"
he
said
to
Simon
Tappertit
,
"
and
quickly
.
 
<EOS>
And
open
your
ears
,
master
,
if
you
would
ever
use
them
after
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Gabriel
folded
his
arms
,
which
were
now
at
liberty
,
and
eyed
his
old
'
prentice
in
silence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lookye
,
Varden
,
"
said
Sim
,
"
we
're
bound
for
Newgate
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
you
are
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
never
said
a
truer
word
than
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
burn
it
down
,
I
mean
,
"
said
Simon
,
"
and
force
the
gates
,
and
set
the
prisoners
at
liberty
.
 
<EOS>
You
helped
to
make
the
lock
of
the
great
door
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
,
"
said
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
owe
me
no
thanks
for
that
---
as
you
'll
find
before
long
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Maybe
,
"
returned
his
journeyman
,
"
but
you
must
show
us
how
to
force
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Must
I
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
for
you
know
,
and
I
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
come
along
with
us
,
and
pick
it
with
your
own
hands
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
do
,
"
said
the
locksmith
quietly
,
"
my
hands
shall
drop
off
at
the
wrists
,
and
you
shall
wear
them
,
Simon
Tappertit
,
on
your
shoulders
for
epaulettes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
'll
see
that
,
"
cried
Hugh
,
interposing
,
as
the
indignation
of
the
crowd
again
burst
forth
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
fill
a
basket
with
the
tools
he
'll
want
,
while
I
bring
him
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
Open
the
doors
below
,
some
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
And
light
the
great
captain
,
others
!
 
<EOS>
Is
there
no
business
afoot
,
my
lads
,
that
you
can
do
nothing
but
stand
and
grumble
?
"
  
<EOS>
They
looked
at
one
another
,
and
quickly
dispersing
,
swarmed
over
the
house
,
plundering
and
breaking
,
according
to
their
custom
,
and
carrying
off
such
articles
of
value
as
happened
to
please
their
fancy
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
no
great
length
of
time
for
these
proceedings
,
for
the
basket
of
tools
was
soon
prepared
and
slung
over
a
man
's
shoulders
.
 
<EOS>
The
preparations
being
now
completed
,
and
everything
ready
for
the
attack
,
those
who
were
pillaging
and
destroying
in
the
other
rooms
were
called
down
to
the
workshop
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
about
to
issue
forth
,
when
the
man
who
had
been
last
upstairs
,
stepped
forward
,
and
asked
if
the
young
woman
in
the
garret
(
who
was
making
a
terrible
noise
,
he
said
,
and
kept
on
screaming
without
the
least
cessation
)
was
to
be
released
?
  
<EOS>
For
his
own
part
,
Simon
Tappertit
would
certainly
have
replied
in
the
negative
,
but
the
mass
of
his
companions
,
mindful
of
the
good
service
she
had
done
in
the
matter
of
the
gun
,
being
of
a
different
opinion
,
he
had
nothing
for
it
but
to
answer
,
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
,
accordingly
,
went
back
again
to
the
rescue
,
and
presently
returned
with
Miss
Miggs
,
limp
and
doubled
up
,
and
very
damp
from
much
weeping
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
young
lady
had
given
no
tokens
of
consciousness
on
their
way
downstairs
,
