.
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
<EOS>
he
answered
softly
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
I
see
glittering
behind
the
hedge
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
cried
the
hangman
,
raising
his
voice
to
its
highest
pitch
,
and
laying
hold
of
him
and
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
SOLDIERS
,
surely
!
"
  
<EOS>
That
moment
,
the
shed
was
filled
with
armed
men
;
and
a
body
of
horse
,
galloping
into
the
field
,
drew
up
before
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
Dennis
,
who
remained
untouched
among
them
when
they
had
seized
their
prisoners
;
"
it
's
them
two
young
ones
,
gentlemen
,
that
the
proclamation
puts
a
price
on
.
 
<EOS>
This
other
's
an
escaped
felon
.
<EOS>
---
I
'm
sorry
for
it
,
brother
,
"
he
added
,
in
a
tone
of
resignation
,
addressing
himself
to
Hugh
;
"
but
you
've
brought
it
on
yourself
;
you
forced
me
to
do
it
;
you
would
n't
respect
the
soundest
constitootional
principles
,
you
know
;
you
went
and
wiolated
the
wery
framework
of
society
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
sooner
have
given
away
a
trifle
in
charity
than
done
this
,
I
would
upon
my
soul
.
<EOS>
---
If
you
'll
keep
fast
hold
on
'em
,
gentlemen
,
I
think
I
can
make
a
shift
to
tie
'em
better
than
you
can
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
this
operation
was
postponed
for
a
few
moments
by
a
new
occurrence
.
 
<EOS>
The
blind
man
,
whose
ears
were
quicker
than
most
people
's
sight
,
had
been
alarmed
,
before
Barnaby
,
by
a
rustling
in
the
bushes
,
under
cover
of
which
the
soldiers
had
advanced
.
 
<EOS>
He
retreated
instantly
---
had
hidden
somewhere
for
a
minute
---
and
probably
in
his
confusion
mistaking
the
point
at
which
he
had
emerged
,
was
now
seen
running
across
the
open
meadow
.
  
<EOS>
An
officer
cried
directly
that
he
had
helped
to
plunder
a
house
last
night
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
loudly
called
on
,
to
surrender
.
 
<EOS>
He
ran
the
harder
,
and
in
a
few
seconds
would
have
been
out
of
gunshot
.
 
<EOS>
The
word
was
given
,
and
the
men
fired
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
breathless
pause
and
a
profound
silence
,
during
which
all
eyes
were
fixed
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
seen
to
start
at
the
discharge
,
as
if
the
report
had
frightened
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
neither
stopped
nor
slackened
his
pace
in
the
least
,
and
ran
on
full
forty
yards
further
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
without
one
reel
or
stagger
,
or
sign
of
faintness
,
or
quivering
of
any
limb
,
he
dropped
.
  
<EOS>
Some
of
them
hurried
up
to
where
he
lay
;
---
the
hangman
with
them
.
<EOS>
Everything
had
passed
so
quickly
,
that
the
smoke
had
not
yet
scattered
,
but
curled
slowly
off
in
a
little
cloud
,
which
seemed
like
the
dead
man
's
spirit
moving
solemnly
away
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
a
few
drops
of
blood
upon
the
grass
---
<EOS>
more
,
when
they
turned
him
over
---
 
that
was
all
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
here
!
<EOS>
Look
here
!
"
said
the
hangman
,
stooping
one
knee
beside
the
body
,
and
gazing
up
with
a
disconsolate
face
at
the
officer
and
men
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
pretty
sight
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stand
out
of
the
way
,
"
replied
the
officer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Serjeant
!
<EOS>
see
what
he
had
about
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
man
turned
his
pockets
out
upon
the
grass
,
and
counted
,
besides
some
foreign
coins
and
two
rings
,
five
-
and
-
forty
guineas
in
gold
.
<EOS>
These
were
bundled
up
in
a
handkerchief
and
carried
away
;
the
body
remained
there
for
the
present
,
but
six
men
and
the
serjeant
were
left
to
take
it
to
the
nearest
public
-
house
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
then
,
if
you
're
going
,
"
said
the
serjeant
,
clapping
Dennis
on
the
back
,
and
pointing
after
the
officer
who
was
walking
towards
the
shed
.
  
<EOS>
To
which
Mr
Dennis
only
replied
,
"
Do
n't
talk
to
me
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
repeated
what
he
had
said
before
,
namely
,
"
Here
's
a
pretty
sight
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
one
that
you
care
for
much
,
I
should
think
,
"
observed
the
serjeant
coolly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
who
,
"
said
Mr
Dennis
rising
,
"
should
care
for
it
,
if
I
do
n't
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
I
did
n't
know
you
was
so
tender
-
hearted
,
"
said
the
serjeant
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tender
-
hearted
!
"
echoed
Dennis
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tender
-
hearted
!
 
<EOS>
Look
at
this
man
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
call
THIS
constitootional
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
see
him
shot
through
and
through
instead
of
being
worked
off

?
<EOS>
Damme
,

.
 
<EOS>
You

.

<EOS>

wery

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
They

,

.
  
<EOS>
They

,
in

;
being

.
<EOS>
Hugh

among

,
and
,
without

,
that

.
 
<EOS>
For

,
he

as

,

the

that
the

would
force

wherever

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

,

the

,

,
he
saw
that
this
hope
was
gone
,
and
felt
that

was

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
70
    
Mr
Dennis
having
despatched
this
piece
of
business
without
any

or

,
and
having
now

private

,
resolved
to

with
half
an
hour

so
of
female

.
 
<EOS>
With
this
amiable
purpose
in
his

,
he
bent

towards
the
house
where
Dolly
and
Miss
Haredale
were

,
and
whither

Miggs
had
also

by
order
of
Mr

.
  
<EOS>
As

along

with

,

of

and

,
Mr
Dennis
might
have
been
likened
unto
a

ruminating
among

crops
,
and
enjoying
by

the
bountiful

of
Providence
.
 
<EOS>
Look
where
he
would
,
some
heap
of
ruins
afforded
him
rich
promise
of
a
working
off
;
the
whole
town
appeared
to
have
been
ploughed
and
sown
,
and
nurtured
by
most
genial

;
and
a
goodly
harvest
was
at

.
  
<EOS>
Having
taken
up
arms
and
resorted
to
deeds
of
violence
,
with
the
great
main
object
of
preserving
the
Old
Bailey
in
all

,
and
the

in
all

,
it

perhaps

far
to
assert
that
Mr
Dennis
had
ever

and
foreseen
this
happy
state

.
<EOS>
He
rather
looked
upon
it
as
one
of
those
beautiful
dispensations
which
are
inscrutably
brought
about
for
the
behoof
and
advantage
of
good

.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
,
as
it
were
,
personally
referred

,
in
this
prosperous
ripening
for
the
gibbet
;
and
had
never
considered
himself
so
much
the
pet

of
Destiny
,
or
loved
that

so

,
in

.
  
<EOS>
As

,

,

,

,
Mr

dismissed

from

an
idle

;
arguing
that
the
line

conduct
he
had
adopted
at
Newgate
,
and

he
had
rendered
that
day
,
would
be
more
than
a

against
any

.
 
<EOS>
That
any

which
might

,
would

.
 
<EOS>
And
that
if

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

,

,

;

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
Saving
---

.
 
<EOS>

"

,

!

,

,

!
"

Miggs
,
brightening
again
,
rejoined
,
with
many
breaks
and
pauses
from
excess
of
feeling
,
that
temptations
had
been
Simmuns
's
bane
.
 
<EOS>
That
it
was
not
his
faults
,
but
hers
(
meaning
Dolly
's
)
.
<EOS>
That
men
did
not
see
through
these
dreadful
arts
as
women
did
,
and
therefore
was
caged
and
trapped
,
as
Simmun
had
been
.
 
<EOS>
That
she
had
no
personal
motives
to
serve
---
far
from
it
---
on
the
contrary
,
her
intentions
was
good
towards
all
parties
.
 
<EOS>
But
forasmuch
as
she
knowed
that
Simmun
,
if
united
to
any
designing
and
artful
minxes
(
she
would
name
no
names
,
<EOS>
for
that
was
not
her
dispositions
)
---
to
ANY
designing
and
artful
minxes
---
must
be
made
miserable
and
unhappy
for
life
,
she
DID
incline
towards
prewentions
.
 
<EOS>
Such
,
she
added
,
was
her
free
confessions
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
this
was
private
feelings
,
and
might
perhaps
be
looked
upon
as
wengeance
,
she
begged
the
gentleman
would
say
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
he
said
,
wishing
to
do
her
duty
by
all
mankind
,
even
by
them
as
had
ever
been
her
bitterest
enemies
,
she
would
not
listen
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
With
that
she
stopped
her
ears
,
and
shook
her
head
from
side
to
side
,
to
intimate
to
Mr
Dennis
that
though
he
talked
until
he
had
no
breath
left
,
she
was
as
deaf
as
any
adder
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lookee
here
,
my
sugar
-
stick
,
"
said
Mr
Dennis
,
"
if
your
view
's
the
same
as
mine
,
and
you
'll
only
be
quiet
and
slip
away
at
the
right
time
,
I
can
have
the
house
clear
to
-
morrow
,
and
be
out
of
this
trouble
.
<EOS>
---
Stop
though
!
<EOS>
there
's
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Which
other
,
sir
?
"
asked
Miggs
---
still
with
her
fingers
in
her
ears
and
her
head
shaking
obstinately
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
tallest
one
,
yonder
,
"
said
Dennis
,
as
he
stroked
his
chin
,
and
added
,
in
an
undertone
to
himself
,
something
about
not
crossing
Muster
Gashford
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
replied
(
still
being
profoundly
deaf
)
that
if
Miss
Haredale
stood
in
the
way
at
all
,
he
might
make
himself
quite
easy
on
that
score
;
as
she
had
gathered
,
from
what
passed
between
Hugh
and
Mr
Tappertit
when
they
were
last
there
,
that
she
was
to
be
removed
alone
(
not
by
them
,
but
by
somebody
else
)
,
to
-
morrow
night
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dennis
opened
his
eyes
very
wide
at
this
piece
of
information
,
whistled
once
,
considered
once
,
and
finally
slapped
his
head
once
and
nodded
once
,
as
if
he
had
got
the
clue
to
this
mysterious
removal
,
and
so
dismissed
it
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
imparted
his
design
concerning
Dolly
to
Miss
Miggs
,
who
was
taken
more
deaf
than
before
,
when
he
began
;
and
so
remained
,
all
through
.
  
<EOS>
The
notable
scheme
was
this
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Dennis
was
immediately
to
seek
out
from
among
the
rioters
,
some
daring
young
fellow
(
and
he
had
one
in
his
eye
,
he
said
)
,
who
,
terrified
by
the
threats
he
could
hold
out
to
him
,
and
alarmed
by
the
capture
of
so
many
who
were
no
better
and
no
worse
than
he
,
would
gladly
avail
himself
of
any
help
to
get
abroad
,
and
out
of
harm
's
way
,
with
his
plunder
,
even
though
his
journey
were
incumbered
by
an
unwilling
companion
;
indeed
,
the
unwilling
companion
being
a
beautiful
girl
,
would
probably
be
an
additional
inducement
and
temptation
.
 
<EOS>
Such
a
person
found
,
he
proposed
to
bring
him
there
on
the
ensuing
night
,
when
the
tall
one
was
taken
off
,
and
Miss
Miggs
had
purposely
retired
;
and
then
that
Dolly
should
be
gagged
,
muffled
in
a
cloak
,
and
carried
in
any
handy
conveyance
down
to
the
river
's
side
;
where
there
were
abundant
means
of
getting
her
smuggled
snugly
off
in
any
small
craft
of
doubtful
character
,
and
<EOS>
no
questions
asked
.
 
<EOS>
With
regard
to
the
expense
of
this
removal
,
he
would
say
,
at
a
rough
calculation
,
that
two
or
three
silver
tea
or
coffee
-
pots
,
with
something
additional
for
drink
(
such
as
a
muffineer
,
or
toast
-
rack
)
,
would
more
than
cover
it
.
 
<EOS>
Articles
of
plate
of
every
kind
having
been
buried
by
the
rioters
in
several
lonely
parts
of
London
,
and
particularly
,
as
he
knew
,
in
St
James
's
Square
,
which
,
though
easy
of
access
,
was
little
frequented
after
dark
,
and
had
a
convenient
piece
of
water
in
the
midst
,
the
needful
funds
were
close
at
hand
,
and
could
be
had
upon
the
shortest
notice
.
 
<EOS>
With
regard
to
Dolly
,
the
gentleman
would
exercise
his
own
discretion
.
<EOS>
He
would
be
bound
to
do
nothing
but
to
take
her
away
,
and
keep
her
away
.
 
<EOS>
All
other
arrangements
and
dispositions
would
rest
entirely
with
himself
.
  
<EOS>
If
Miss
Miggs
had
had
her
hearing
,
no
doubt
she
would
have
been
greatly
shocked
by
the
indelicacy
of
a
young
female
's
<EOS>
going
away
with
a
stranger
by
night
(
for
her
moral
feelings
,
as
we
have
said
,
were
of
the
tenderest
kind
)
;
but
directly
Mr
Dennis
ceased
to
speak
,
she
reminded
him
that
he
had
only
wasted
breath
.
 
<EOS>
She
then
went
on
to
say
(
still
with
her
fingers
in
her
ears
)
that
nothing
less
than
a
severe
practical
lesson
would
save
the
locksmith
's
daughter
from
utter
ruin
;
and
that
she
felt
it
,
as
it
were
,
a
moral
obligation
and
a
sacred
duty
to
the
family
,
to
wish
that
some
one
would
devise
one
for
her
reformation
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
remarked
,
and
very
justly
,
as
an
abstract
sentiment
which
happened
to
occur
to
her
at
the
moment
,
that
she
dared
to
say
the
locksmith
and
his
wife
would
murmur
,
and
repine
,
if
they
were
ever
,
by
forcible
abduction
,
or
otherwise
,
to
lose
their
child
;
but
that
we
seldom
knew
,
in
this
world
,
what
was
best
for
us
:
<EOS>
such
being
our
sinful
and
imperfect
natures
,
that
very
few
arrived
at
that
clear
understanding
.
  
<EOS>
Having
brought
their
conversation
to
this
satisfactory
end
,
they
parted
:
Dennis
,
to
pursue
his
design
,
and
take
another
walk
about
his
farm
;
Miss
Miggs
,
to
launch
,
when
he
left
her
,
into
such
a
burst
of
mental
anguish
(
which
she
gave
them
to
understand
was
occasioned
by
certain
tender
things
he
had
had
the
presumption
and
audacity
to
say
)
,
that
little
Dolly
's
heart
was
quite
melted
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
she
said
and
did
so
much
to
soothe
the
outraged
feelings
of
Miss
Miggs
,
and
looked
so
beautiful
while
doing
so
,
that
if
that
young
maid
had
not
had
ample
vent
for
her
surpassing
spite
,
in
a
knowledge
of
the
mischief
that
was
brewing
,
she
must
have
scratched
her
features
,
on
the
spot
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
71
    
<EOS>
All
next
day
,
Emma
Haredale
,
Dolly
,
and
Miggs
,
remained
cooped
up
together
in
what
had
now
been
their
prison
for
so
many
days
,
without
seeing
any
person
,
or
hearing
any
sound
but
the
murmured
conversation
,
in
an
outer
room
,
of
the
men
who
kept
watch
over
them
.
 
<EOS>
There
appeared
to
be
more
of
these
fellows
than
there
had
been
hitherto
;
and
they
could
no
longer
hear
the
voices
of
women
,
which
they
had
before
plainly
distinguished
.
 
<EOS>
Some
new
excitement
,
too
,
seemed
to
prevail
among
them
;
for
there
was
much
stealthy
going
in
and
out
,
and
a
constant
questioning
of
those
who
were
newly
arrived
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
previously
been
quite
reckless
in
their
behaviour
;
often
making
a
great
uproar
;
quarrelling
among
themselves
,
fighting
,
dancing
,
and
singing
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
now
very
subdued
and
silent
,
conversing
almost
in
whispers
,
and
stealing
in
and
out
with
a
soft
and
stealthy
tread
,
very
different
from
the
boisterous
trampling
<EOS>
in
which
their
arrivals
and
departures
had
hitherto
been
announced
to
the
trembling
captives
.
  
<EOS>
Whether
this
change
was
occasioned
by
the
presence
among
them
of
some
person
of
authority
in
their
ranks
,
or
by
any
other
cause
,
they
were
unable
to
decide
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
they
thought
it
was
in
part
attributable
to
there
being
a
sick
man
in
the
chamber
,
<EOS>
for
last
night
there
had
been
a
shuffling
of
feet
,
as
though
a
burden
were
brought
in
,
and
afterwards
a
moaning
noise
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
had
no
means
of
ascertaining
the
truth
:
for
any
question
or
entreaty
on
their
parts
only
provoked
a
storm
of
execrations
,
or
something
worse
;
and
they
were
too
happy
to
be
left
alone
,
unassailed
by
threats
or
admiration
,
to
risk
even
that
comfort
,
by
any
voluntary
communication
with
those
who
held
them
in
durance
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
sufficiently
evident
,
both
to
Emma
and
to
the
locksmith
's
poor
little
daughter
herself
,
that
she
,
Dolly
,
was
the
great
object
of
attraction
;
and
that
so
soon
as
they
should
have
leisure
to
indulge
in
the
softer
passion
,
Hugh
and
Mr
Tappertit
would
certainly
fall
to
blows
for
her
sake
;
in
which
latter
case
,
it
was
not
very
difficult
to
see
whose
prize
she
would
become
.
 
<EOS>
With
all
her
old
horror
of
that
man
revived
,
and
deepened
into
a
degree
of
aversion
and
abhorrence
which
no
language
can
describe
;
with
a
thousand
old
recollections
and
regrets
,
and
causes
of
distress
,
anxiety
,
and
fear
,
besetting
her
on
all
sides
;
poor
Dolly
Varden
---
 
<EOS>
sweet
,
blooming
,
buxom
Dolly
---
began
to
hang
her
head
,
and
fade
,
and
droop
,
like
a
beautiful
flower
.
 
<EOS>
The
colour
fled
from
her
cheeks
,
her
courage
forsook
her
,
her
gentle
heart
failed
.
 
<EOS>
Unmindful
of
all
her
provoking
caprices
,
forgetful
of
all
her
conquests
and
inconstancy
,
with
all
her
winning
little
vanities
quite
gone
<EOS>
,
she
nestled
all
the
livelong
day
in
Emma
Haredale
's
bosom
;
and
,
sometimes
calling
on
her
dear
old
grey
-
haired
father
,
sometimes
on
her
mother
,
and
sometimes
even
on
her
old
home
,
pined
slowly
away
,
like
a
poor
bird
in
its
cage
.
  
<EOS>
Light
hearts
,
light
hearts
,
that
float
so
gaily
on
a
smooth
stream
,
that
are
so
sparkling
and
buoyant
in
the
sunshine
---
down
upon
fruit
,
bloom
upon
flowers
,
blush
in
summer
air
,
life
of
the
winged
insect
,
whose
whole
existence
is
a
day
---
<EOS>
how
soon
ye
sink
in
troubled
water
!
<EOS>
Poor
Dolly
's
heart
---
a
little
,
gentle
,
idle
,
fickle
thing
;
giddy
,
restless
,
fluttering
;
constant
to
nothing
but
bright
looks
,
and
smiles
and
laughter
---
Dolly
's
heart
was
breaking
.
  
<EOS>
Emma
had
known
grief
,
and
could
bear
it
better
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
little
comfort
to
impart
,
but
she
could
soothe
and
tend
her
,
and
she
did
so
;
and
Dolly
clung
to
her
like
a
child
to
its
nurse
.
 
<EOS>
In
endeavouring
to
inspire
her
with
some
fortitude
,
she
increased
her
own
;
and
though
the
nights
were
long
,
and
the
days
dismal
,
and
she
felt
the
wasting
influence
of
watching
and
fatigue
,
and
had
perhaps
a
more
defined
and
clear
perception
of
their
destitute
condition
and
its
worst
dangers
<EOS>
,
she
uttered
no
complaint
.
 
<EOS>
Before
the
ruffians
,
in
whose
power
they
were
,
she
bore
herself
so
calmly
,
and
with
such
an
appearance
,
in
the
midst
of
all
her
terror
,
of
a
secret
conviction
that
they
dared
not
harm
her
,
that
there
was
not
a
man
among
them
but
held
her
in
some
degree
of
dread
;
and
more
than
one
believed
she
had
a
weapon
hidden
in
her
dress
,
and
was
prepared
to
use
it
.
  
<EOS>
Such
was
their
condition
when
they
were
joined
by
Miss
Miggs
,
who
gave
them
to
understand
that
she
too
had
been
taken
prisoner
because
of
her
charms
,
and
detailed
such
feats
of
resistance
she
had
performed
(
her
virtue
having
given
her
supernatural
strength
)
,
that
they
felt
it
quite
a
happiness
to
have
her
for
a
champion
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
this
the
only
comfort
they
derived
at
first
from
Miggs
's
presence
and
society
:
for
that
young
lady
displayed
such
resignation
and
long
-
suffering
,
and
so
much
meek
endurance
,
under
her
trials
,
and
breathed
in
all
her
chaste
discourse
a
spirit
of
such
holy
confidence
and
resignation
,
and
devout
belief
that
all
would
happen
for
the
best
,
that
Emma
felt
her
courage
strengthened
by
the
bright
example
;
never
doubting
but
that
everything
she
said
was
true
,
and
that
she
,
like
them
,
was
torn
from
all
she
loved
,
and
agonised
by
doubt
and
apprehension
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
poor
Dolly
,
she
was
roused
,
at
first
,
by
seeing
one
who
came
from
home
;
but
when
she
heard
under
what
circumstances
she
had
left
it
,
and
into
whose
hands
her
father
had
fallen
,
she
wept
more
bitterly
than
ever
,
and
refused
all
comfort
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
was
at
some
trouble
to
reprove
her
for
this
state
of
mind
,
and
to
entreat
her
to
take
example
by
herself
,
who
,
she
said
,
was
now
receiving
back
,
with
interest
,
tenfold
the
amount
of
her
subscriptions
to
the
red
-
brick
dwelling
-
house
,
in
the
articles
of
peace
of
mind
and
a
quiet
conscience
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
while
on
serious
topics
,
Miss
Miggs
considered
it
her
duty
to
try
her
hand
at
the
conversion
of
Miss
Haredale
;
for
whose
improvement
she
launched
into
a
polemical
address
of
some
length
,
in
the
course
whereof
,
she
likened
herself
unto
a
chosen
missionary
,
and
that
young
lady
to
a
cannibal
in
darkness
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
she
returned
so
often
to
these
sublects
,
and
so
frequently
called
upon
them
to
take
a
lesson
from
her
,
---
<EOS>
at
the
same
time
vaunting
and
,
as
it
were
,
rioting
in
,
her
huge
unworthiness
,
and
abundant
excess
of
sin
,
---
that
,
in
the
course
of
a
short
time
,
she
became
,
in
that
small
chamber
,
rather
a
nuisance
than
a
comfort
,
and
rendered
them
,
if
possible
,
even
more
unhappy
than
they
had
been
before
.
  
<EOS>
The
night
had
now
come
;
and
for
the
first
time
(
for
their
jailers
had
been
regular
in
bringing
food
and
candles
)
,
they
were
left
in
darkness
.
 
<EOS>
Any
change
in
their
condition
in
such
a
place
inspired
new
fears
;
and
when
some
hours
had
passed
,
and
the
gloom
was
still
unbroken
,
Emma
could
no
longer
repress
her
alarm
.
  
<EOS>
They
listened
attentively
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
same
murmuring
in
the
outer
room
,
and
now
and
then
a
moan
which
seemed
to
be
wrung
from
a
person
in
great
pain
,
who
made
an
effort
to
subdue
it
,
but
could
not
.
 
<EOS>
Even
these
men
seemed
to
be
in
darkness
too
;
for
no
light
shone
through
the
chinks
in
the
door
,
nor
were
they
moving
,
as
their
custom
was
,
but
quite
still
:
the
silence
being
unbroken
by
so
much
as
the
creaking
of
a
board
.
  
<EOS>
At
first
,
Miss
Miggs
wondered
greatly
in
her
own
mind
who
this
sick
person
might
be
;
but
arriving
,
on
second

,
at
the
conclusion
that
he
was
a
part
of
the
schemes
on
foot
,
and
an
artful
device
soon
to
be
employed
with
great
success
,
she
opined
,
for
Miss
Haredale
's
comfort
,
that
it
must
be
some
misguided
Papist
who
had
been
wounded
:
and
this
happy
supposition
encouraged
her
to
say
,
under
her
breath
,
"
Ally
Looyer
!
"
<EOS>
several
times
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
possible
,
"
said
Emma
,
with
some
indignation
,
"
that
you
who
have
seen
these
men
committing
the
outrages
you
have
told
us
of
,
and
who
have
fallen
into
their
hands
,
like
us
,
can
exult
in
their
cruelties
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Personal
considerations
,
miss
,
"
rejoined
Miggs
<EOS>
,
"
sinks
into
nothing
,
<EOS>
afore
a
noble
cause
.
 
<EOS>
Ally
Looyer
!
 
<EOS>
Ally
Looyer
!
 
<EOS>
Ally
Looyer
,
good
gentlemen
!
"
  
<EOS>
It
seemed
from
the
shrill
pertinacity
with
which
Miss
Miggs
repeated
this
form
of
acclamation
,
that
she
was
calling
the
same
through
the
keyhole
of
the
door
;
but
in
the
profound
darkness
she
could
not
be
seen
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
the
time
has
come
---
Heaven
knows
it
may
come
at
any
moment
---
when
they
are
bent
on
prosecuting
the
designs
,
whatever
they
may
be
,
with
which
they
have
brought
us
here
,
can
you
still
encourage
,
and
take
part
with
them
?
"
demanded
Emma
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thank
my
goodness
-
gracious
-
blessed
-
stars
<EOS>
I
can
,
miss
,
"
returned
Miggs
,
with
increased
energy
.
<EOS>
---
"
Ally
Looyer
,
good
gentlemen
!
"
  
<EOS>
Even
Dolly
,
cast
down
and
disappointed
as
she
was
,
revived
at
this
,
and
bade
Miggs
hold
her
tongue
directly
.
  
<EOS>
"
WHICH
,
was
you
pleased
to
observe
,
Miss
Varden
?
"
said
Miggs
,
with
a
strong
emphasis
on
the
irrelative
pronoun
.
  
<EOS>
Dolly
repeated
her
request
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ho
,
gracious
me
!
"
cried
Miggs
,
with
hysterical
derision
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ho
,
gracious
me
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
to
be
sure
I
will
.
 
<EOS>
Ho
<EOS>
yes
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
abject
slave
,
and
a
toiling
,
moiling
,
constant
-
working
,
always
-
being
-
found
-
fault
-
with
,
never
-
giving
-
satisfactions
,
nor
-
having
-
no
-
time
-
to
-
clean
-
oneself
,
potter
's
wessel
---
<EOS>
an't
<EOS>
I
,
miss
!
 
<EOS>
Ho
<EOS>
yes
!
 
<EOS>
My
situations
is
lowly
,
and
my
capacities
is
limited
,
and
my
duties
is
to
humble
myself
afore
the
base
degenerating
daughters
of
their
blessed
mothers
as
is
---
fit
to
keep
companies
with
holy
saints
but
is
born
to
persecutions
from
wicked
relations
---
and
to
demean
myself
before
them
as
is
no
better
than
Infidels
---
an't
<EOS>
it
,
miss
!
 
<EOS>
Ho
<EOS>
yes
!
<EOS>
My
only
becoming
occupations
is
to
help
young
flaunting
pagins
to
brush
and
comb
and
titiwate
theirselves
into
whitening
and
suppulchres
,
and
leave
the
young
men
to
think
that
there
an't
a
bit
of
padding
in
it
nor
no
pinching
ins
nor
fillings
out
nor
pomatums
nor
deceits
nor
earthly
wanities
---
<EOS>
an't
it
,
miss
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
to
be
sure
it
is
---
<EOS>
ho
yes
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Having
delivered
these
ironical
passages
with
a
most
wonderful
volubility
,
and
with
a
shrillness
perfectly
deafening
(
especially
when
she
jerked
out
the
interjections
)
,
Miss
Miggs
,
from
mere
habit
,
and
not
because
weeping
was
at
all
appropriate
to
the
occasion
,
which
was
one
of
triumph
,
concluded
by
bursting
into
a
flood
of
tears
,
and
calling
in
an
impassioned
manner
on
the
name
of
Simmuns
.
  
<EOS>
What
Emma
Haredale
and
Dolly
would
have
done
,
or
<EOS>
how
long
Miss
Miggs
,
now
that
she
had
hoisted
her
true
colours
,
would
have
gone
on
waving
them
before
their
astonished
senses
,
it
is
impossible
to
tell
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
is
it
necessary
to
speculate
on
these
matters
,
for
a
startling
interruption
occurred
at
that
moment
,
which
took
their
whole
attention
by
storm
.
  
<EOS>
This
was
a
violent
knocking
at
the
door
of
the
house
,
and
then
its
sudden
bursting
open
;
which
was
immediately
succeeded
by
a
scuffle
in
the
room
without
,
and
the
clash
of
weapons
.
 
<EOS>
Transported
with
the
hope
that
rescue
had
at
length
arrived
,
Emma
and
Dolly
shrieked
aloud
for
help
;
nor
were
their
shrieks
unanswered
;
for
after
a
hurried
interval
,
a
man
,
bearing
in
one
hand
a
drawn
sword
,
and
in
the
other
a
taper
,
rushed
into
the
chamber
where
they
were
confined
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
some
check
upon
their
transport
to
find
in
this
person
an
entire
stranger
,
but
they
appealed
to
him
,
nevertheless
,
and
besought
him
,
in
impassioned
language
,
to
restore
them
to
their
friends
.
  
<EOS>
"
For
what
other
purpose
am
I
here
?
"
he
answered
,
closing
the
door
,
and
standing
with
his
back
against
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
With
what
object
have
I
made
my
way
to
this
place
,
through
difficulty
and
danger
,
but
to
preserve
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
With
a
joy
for
which
it
was
impossible
to
find
adequate
expression
,
they
embraced
each
other
,
and
thanked
Heaven
for
this
most
timely
aid
.
 
<EOS>
Their
deliverer
stepped
forward
for
a
moment
to
put
the
light
upon
the
table
,
and
immediately
returning
to
his
former
position
against
the
door
,
bared
his
head
,
and
looked
on
smilingly
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
news
of
my
uncle
,
sir
?
"
said
Emma
,
turning
hastily
towards
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
of
my
father
and
mother
?
"
added
Dolly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
news
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
are
alive
and
unhurt
?
<EOS>
"
they
both
cried
at
once
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
and
unhurt
,
"
he
rejoined
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
close
at
hand
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
say
close
at
hand
,
"
he
answered
smoothly
;
"
they
are
at
no
great
distance
.
 
<EOS>
YOUR
friends
,
sweet
one
,
"
he
added
,
addressing
Dolly
,
"
are
within
a
few
hours
'
journey
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
be
restored
to
them
,
I
hope
,
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
uncle
,
sir
---
"
faltered
Emma
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
uncle
,
dear
Miss
Haredale
,
happily
---
I
say
happily
,
because
he
has
succeeded
where
many
of
our
creed
have
failed
,
and
is

---
has
crossed
the
sea
,
and
is

Britain
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thank
God
for
it
,
"
said
Emma
,
faintly
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
say
well
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
reason
to
be
thankful
:
greater
reason
than
it
is
possible
for
you
,
who
have
seen
but
one
night
of
these

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Does
he
desire
,
"
said
Emma
,
"
that
I

follow

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
ask
if
he
desires
it
?
"
cried

stranger
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
IF
he
desires
it
!
 
<EOS>
But
you
do
not
know
the
danger
of
remaining
in
England
,
the

of
escape
,
or
the
price
hundreds
would
pay
to

means
,
when
you

.
 
<EOS>
Pardon
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
forgotten
that
you
could
not
,
being
prisoner
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
gather
,
sir
,
"
said
Emma
,
after

's

,
"
from
what
you
hint
at
,
but
fear
to
tell
me
,
that
I
have
witnessed
but
the

,
and
the
least
,
of
the

to

we
are

,
and
that
it
has
not

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
shrugged

,
shook

,
lifted

;
and
with
the
same
smooth

,
which
was
not
a
pleasant
one
to

,
cast
his

upon

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
venture
,
sir
,
to
speak
plain
,
"
said
Emma
,
"
and
to
tell
me
the
worst
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
undergone
some
preparation
for
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
here
Dolly
interposed
,
and
entreated
her
not
to
hear
the
worst
,
but
the
best
;
and
besought
the
gentleman
to
tell
them
the
best
,
and
to
keep
the
remainder
of
his
news
until
they
were
safe
among
their
friends
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
told
in
three
words
,
"
he
said
,
glancing
at
the
locksmith
's
daughter
with
a

of
some
