.
 
<EOS>
"
The
people
have
risen
,
to
a
man
,
against
us
;
the
streets
are
filled
with
soldiers
,
who
support
them
and
do
their
bidding
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
no
protection
but
from
above
,
and
no
safety
but
in
flight
;
and
that
is
a
poor
resource
;
for
we
are
watched
on
every
hand
,
and
detained
here
,
both
by
force
and
fraud
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Haredale
,
I
can
not
bear
---
believe
me
,
that
I
can
not
bear
---
by
speaking
of
myself
,
or
what
I
have
done
,
or
am
prepared
to
do
,
to
seem
to
vaunt
my
services
before
you
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
having
powerful
Protestant
connections
,
and
having
my
whole
wealth
embarked
with
theirs
in
shipping
and
commerce
,
I
happily
possessed
the
means
of
saving
your
uncle
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
the
means
of
saving
you
;
and
in
redemption
of
my
sacred
promise
,
made
to
him
,
I
am
here
;
pledged
not
to
leave
you
until
I
have
placed
you
in
his
arms
.
 
<EOS>
The
treachery
or
penitence
of
one
of
the
men
about
you
,
led
to
the
discovery
of
your
place
of
confinement
;
and
that
I
have
forced
my
way
here
,
sword
in
hand
,
you
see
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
bring
,
"
said
Emma
,
faltering
,
"
<EOS>
some
note
or
token
from
my
uncle
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
he
does
n't
,
"
cried
Dolly
,
pointing
at
him
earnestly
;
"
<EOS>
now
I
am
sure
he
does
n't
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
go
with
him
for
the
world
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
pretty
fool
---
be
silent
,
"
he
replied
,
frowning
angrily
upon
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
Miss
Haredale
,
I
have
no
letter
,
nor
any
token
of
any
kind
;
for
while
I
sympathise
with
you
,
and
such
as
you
,
on
whom
misfortune
so
heavy
and
so
undeserved
has
fallen
,
I
value
my
life
.
<EOS>
I
carry
,
therefore
,
no
writing
which
,
found
upon
me
,
would
lead
to
its
certain
loss
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
thought
of
bringing
any
other
token
,
nor
did
Mr
Haredale
think
of
entrusting
me
with
one
---
possibly
because
he
had
good
experience
of
my
faith
and
honesty
,
and
owed
his
life
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
reproof
conveyed
in
these
words
,
which
to
a
nature
like
Emma
Haredale
's
,
was
well
addressed
.
 
<EOS>
But
Dolly
,
who
was
differently
constituted
,
was
by
no
means
touched
by
it
,
and
still
conjured
her
,
in
all
the
terms
of
affection
and
attachment
she
could
think
of
,
not
to
be
lured
away
.
  
<EOS>
"
Time
presses
,
"
said
their
visitor
,
who
,
although
he
sought
to
express
the
deepest
interest
,
had
something
cold
and
even
in
his
speech
,
that
grated
on
the
ear
;
"
and
danger
surrounds
us
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
exposed
myself
to
it
,
in
vain
,
let
it
be
so
;
but
if
you
and
he
should
ever
meet
again
,
do
me
justice
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
decide
to
remain
(
as
I
think
you
do
)
,
remember
,
Miss
Haredale
,
that
I
left
you
with
a
solemn
caution
,
and
acquitting
myself
of
all
the
consequences
to
which
you
expose
yourself
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Emma
---
one
moment
<EOS>
,
I
beg
you
.
 
<EOS>
Can
not
we
---
and
she
drew
Dolly
closer
to
her
---
"
can
not
we
go
together
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
task
of
conveying
one
female
in
safety
through
such
scenes
as
we
must
encounter
,
to
say
nothing
of
attracting
the
attention
of
those
who
crowd
the
streets
,
"
he
answered
,
"
is
enough
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
said
that
she
will
be
restored
to
her
friends
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
accept
the
service
I
tender
,
Miss
Haredale
,
she
shall
be
instantly
placed
in
safe
conduct
,
and
that
promise
redeemed
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
decide
to
remain
?
 
<EOS>
People
of
all
ranks
and
creeds
are
flying
from
the
town
,
which
is
sacked
from
end
to
end
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
be
of
use
in
some
quarter
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
stay
,
or
go
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dolly
,
"
said
Emma
,
in
a
hurried
manner
,
"
my
dear
girl
,
this
is
our
last
hope
.
 
<EOS>
If
we
part
now
,
it
is
only
that
we
may
meet
again
in
happiness
and
honour
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
trust
to
this
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
no
-
no
!
"
cried
Dolly
,
clinging
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
pray
,
do
not
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
hear
,
"
said
Emma
,
"
that
to
-
night
---
only
to
-
night
---
within
a
few
hours
---
think
of
that
!
<EOS>
---
you
will
be
among
those
who
would
die
of
grief
to
lose
you
,
and
who
are
now
plunged
in
the
deepest
misery
for
your
sake
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
for
me
,
dear
girl
,
as
I
will
for
you
;
and
never
forget
the
many
quiet
hours
we
have
passed
together
.
 
<EOS>
Say
one
<EOS>
"
God
bless
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
Say
that
at
parting
!
"
  
<EOS>
But
Dolly
could
say
nothing
;
no
,
not
when
Emma
kissed
her
cheek
a
hundred
times
,
and
covered
it
with
tears
,
could
she
do
more
than
hang
upon
her
neck
,
and
sob
,
and
clasp
,
and
hold
her
tight
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
have
time
for
no
more
of
this
,
"
cried
the
man
,
unclenching
her
hands
,
and
pushing
her
roughly
off
,
as
he
drew
Emma
Haredale
towards
the
door
:
"
Now
!
 
<EOS>
Quick
,
outside
there
!
<EOS>
are
you
ready
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
"
cried
a
loud
voice
,
which
made
him
start
.
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
ready
!
<EOS>
Stand
back
here
,
for
your
lives
!
"
  
<EOS>
And
in
an
instant
he
was
felled
like
an
ox
in
the
butcher
's
shambles
---
struck
down
as
though
a
block
of
marble
had
fallen
from
the
roof
and
crushed
him
---
and
cheerful
light
,
and
beaming
faces
came
pouring
in
---
and
Emma
was
clasped
in
her
uncle
's
embrace
,
and
Dolly
,
with
a
shriek
that
pierced
the
air
,
fell
into
the
arms
of
her
father
and
mother
.
  
<EOS>
What
fainting
there
was
,
<EOS>
what
laughing
,
what
crying
,
what
sobbing
,
what
smiling
,
how
much
questioning
,
no
answering
,
<EOS>
all
talking
together
,
all
beside
themselves
with
joy
;
what
kissing
,
congratulating
,
embracing
,
shaking
of
hands
,
and
falling
into
all
these
raptures
,
over
and
over
and
over
again
;
no
language
can
describe
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
,
and
after
a
long
time
,
the
old
locksmith
went
up
and
fairly
hugged
two
strangers
,
who
had
stood
apart
and
left
them
to
themselves
;
and
then
they
saw
---
whom
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
Edward
Chester
and
Joseph
Willet
.
  
<EOS>
"
See
here
!
"
cried
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
See
here
!
<EOS>
where
would
any
of
us
have
been
without
these
two
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mr
Edward
,
Mr
Edward
---
<EOS>
oh
,
Joe
,
Joe
,
how
light
,
and
yet
how
full
,
you
have
made
my
old
heart
to
-
night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
Mr
Edward
that
knocked
him
down
,
sir
,
"
said
Joe
:
"
I
longed
to
do
it
,
but
I
gave
it
up
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Come
,
you
brave
and
honest
gentleman
!
 
<EOS>
Get
your
senses
together
,
for
you
have
n't
long
to
lie
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
his
foot
upon
the
breast
of
their
sham
deliverer
,
in
the
absence
of
a
spare
arm
;
and
gave
him
a
gentle
roll
as
he
spoke
.
<EOS>
Gashford
,
for
it
was
no
other
,
crouching
yet
malignant
,
raised
his
scowling
face
,
like
sin
subdued
,
and
pleaded
to
be
gently
used
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
access
to
all
my
lord
's
papers
,
Mr
Haredale
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
submissive
voice
:
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
keeping
his
back
towards
him
,
and
not
once
looking
round
:
"
there
are
very
important
documents
among
them
.
<EOS>
There
are
a
great
many
in
secret
drawers
,
and
distributed
in
various
places
,
known
only
to
my
lord
and
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
give
some
very
valuable
information
,
and
render
important
assistance
to
any
inquiry
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
have
to
answer
it
,
if
I
receive
ill
usage
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pah
!
"
cried
Joe
,
in
deep
disgust
.
 
<EOS>
"
Get
up
,
man
;
you
're
waited
for
,
outside
.
 
<EOS>
Get
up
,
do
you
hear
?
"
  
<EOS>
Gashford
slowly
rose
;
and
picking
up
his
hat
,
and
looking
with
a
baffled
malevolence
,
yet
with
an
air
of
despicable
humility
,
all
round
the
room
,
crawled
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
Joe
,
who
seemed
to
be
the
spokesman
of
the
party
,
for
all
the
rest
were
silent
;
"
the
sooner
we
get
back
to
the
Black
Lion
,
the
better
,
perhaps
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
nodded
assent
,
and
drawing
his
niece
's
arm
through
his
,
and
taking
one
of
her
hands
between
his
own
,
passed
out
straightway
;
followed
by
the
locksmith
,
Mrs
Varden
,
and
Dolly
---
who
would
scarcely
have
presented
a
sufficient
surface
for
all
the
hugs
and
caresses
they
bestowed
upon
her
though
she
had
been
a
dozen
Dollys
.
 
<EOS>
Edward
Chester
and
Joe
followed
.
  
<EOS>
And
did
Dolly
never
once
look
behind
---
not
once
?
 
<EOS>
Was
there
not
one
little
fleeting
glimpse
of
the
dark
eyelash
,
almost
resting
on
her
flushed
cheek
,
and
of
the
downcast
sparkling
eye
it
shaded
?
 
<EOS>
Joe
thought
there
was
---
and
he
is
not
likely
to
have
been
mistaken
;
for
there
were
not
many
eyes
like
Dolly
's
,
that
's
the
truth
.
  
<EOS>
The
outer
room
through
which
they
had
to
pass
,
was
full
of
men
;
among
them
,
Mr
Dennis
in
safe
keeping
;
and
there
,
had
been
since
yesterday
,
lying
in
hiding
behind
a
wooden
screen
which
was
now
thrown
down
,
Simon
Tappertit
,
the
recreant
'
prentice
,
burnt
and
bruised
,
and
with
a
gun
-
shot
wound
in
his
body
;
and
his
legs
---
his
perfect
legs
,
the
pride
and
glory
of
his
life
,
the
comfort
of
his
existence
---
crushed
into
shapeless
ugliness
.
 
<EOS>
Wondering
no
longer
at
the
moans
they
had
heard
,
Dolly
kept
closer
to
her
father
,
and
shuddered
at
the
sight
;
but
neither
bruises
,
burns
,
nor
gun
-
shot
wound
,
nor
all
the
torture
of
his
shattered
limbs
,
sent
half
<EOS>
so
keen
a
pang
to
Simon
's
breast
,
as
Dolly
passing
out
,
with
Joe
for
her
preserver
.
  
<EOS>
A
coach
was
ready
at
the
door
,
and
Dolly
found
herself
safe
and
whole
inside
,
between
her
father
and
mother
,
with
Emma
Haredale
and
her
uncle
,
quite
real
,
sitting
opposite
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
Joe
,
no
Edward
;
and
they
had
said
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
only
bowed
once
,
and
kept
at
a
distance
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
heart
!
<EOS>
what
a
long
way
it
was
to
the
Black
Lion
!
    
<EOS>
Chapter
72
    
<EOS>
The
Black
Lion
was
so
far
off
,
and
occupied
such
a
length
of
time
in
the
getting
at
,
that
notwithstanding
the
strong
presumptive
evidence
she
had
about
her
of
the
late
events
being
real
and
of
actual
occurrence
,
Dolly
could
not
divest
herself
of
the
belief
that
she
must
be
in
a
dream
which
was
lasting
all
night
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
she
quite
certain
that
she
saw
and
heard
with
her
own
proper
senses
,
even
when
the
coach
,
in
the
fulness
of
time
,
stopped
at
the
Black
Lion
,
and
the
host
of
that
tavern
approached
in
a
gush
of
cheerful
light
to
help
them
to
dismount
,
and
give
them
hearty
welcome
.
  
<EOS>
There
too
,
at
the
coach
door
,
one
on
one
side
,
one
upon
the
other
,
were
already
Edward
Chester
and
Joe
Willet
,
who
must
have
followed
in
another
coach
:
and
this
was
such
a
strange
and
unaccountable
proceeding
,
that
Dolly
was
the
more
inclined
to
favour
the
idea
of
her
being
fast
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
Mr
Willet
appeared
---
old
John
himself
---
so
heavy
-
headed
and
obstinate
,
and
with
such
a
double
chin
as
the
liveliest
imagination
could
never
in
its
boldest
flights
have
conjured
up
in
all
its
vast
proportions
---
then
she
stood
corrected
,
and
unwillingly
admitted
to
herself
that
she
was
broad
awake
.
  
<EOS>
And
Joe
had
lost
an
arm
---
<EOS>
he
---
that
well
-
made
,
handsome
,
gallant
fellow
!
 
<EOS>
As
Dolly
glanced
towards
him
,
and
thought
of
the
pain
he
must
have
suffered
,
and
the
far
-
off
places
in
which
he
had
been
wandering
,
and
wondered
who
had
been
his
nurse
,
and
hoped
that
whoever
it
was
,
she
had
been
as
kind
and
gentle
and
considerate
as
she
would
have
been
,
the
tears
came
rising
to
her
bright
eyes
,
one
by
one
,
little
by
little
,
until
she
could
keep
them
back
no
longer
,
and
so
before
them
all
,
wept
bitterly
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
all
safe
now
,
Dolly
,
"
said
her
father
,
kindly
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
shall
not
be
separated
any
more
.
 
<EOS>
Cheer
up
,
my
love
,
cheer
up
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
's
wife
knew
better
perhaps
,
than
he
,
what
ailed
her
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mrs
Varden
being
quite
an
altered
woman
<EOS>
---
for
the
riots
had
done
that
good
---
added
her
word
to
his
,
and
comforted
her
with
similar
representations
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mayhap
,
"
said
Mr
Willet
,
senior
,
looking
round
upon
the
company
,
"
she
's
hungry
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
what
it
is
,
depend
upon
it
<EOS>
---
I
am
,
myself
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Black
Lion
,
who
,
like
old
John
,
had
been
waiting
supper
past
all
reasonable
and
conscionable
hours
,
hailed
this
as
a
philosophical
discovery
of
the
profoundest
and
most
penetrating
kind
;
and
the
table
being
already
spread
,
they
sat
down
to
supper
straightway
.
  
<EOS>
The
conversation
was
not
of
the
liveliest
nature
,
nor
were
the
appetites
of
some
among
them
very
keen
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
in
both
these
respects
,
old
John
more
than
atoned
for
any
deficiency
on
the
part
of
the
rest
,
and
very
much
distinguished
himself
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
in
point
of
actual
conversation
that
Mr
Willet
shone
so
brilliantly
,
for
he
had
none
of
his
old
cronies
to
"
tackle
,
"
and
was
rather
timorous
of
venturing
on
Joe
;
having
certain
vague
misgivings
within
him
,
that
he
was
ready
on
the
shortest
notice
,
and
on
receipt
of
the
slightest
offence
,
to
fell
the
Black
Lion
to
the
floor
of
his
own
parlour
,
and
immediately
to
withdraw
to
China
or
some
other
remote
and
unknown
region
,
there
to
dwell
for
evermore
,
or
at
least
until
he
had
got
rid
of
his
remaining
arm
and
both
legs
,
and
perhaps
an
eye
or
so
,
into
the
bargain
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
with
a
peculiar
kind
of
pantomime
that
Mr
Willet
filled
up
every
pause
;
and
in
this
he
was
considered
by
the
Black
Lion
,
who
had
been
his
familiar
for
some
years
,
quite
to
surpass
and
go
beyond
himself
,
and
outrun
the
expectations
of
his
most
admiring
friends
.
  
<EOS>
The
subject
that
worked
in
Mr
Willet
's
mind
,
and
occasioned
these
demonstrations
,
was
no
other
than
his
son
's
bodily
disfigurement
,
which
he
had
never
yet
got
himself
thoroughly
to
believe
,
or
comprehend
.
 
<EOS>
Shortly
after
their
first
meeting
,
he
had
been
observed
to
wander
,
in
a
state
of
great
perplexity
,
to
the
kitchen
,
and
to
direct
his
gaze
towards
the
fire
,
as
if
in
search
of
his
usual
adviser
in
all
matters
of
doubt
and
difficulty
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
being
no
boiler
at
the
Black
Lion
,
and
the
rioters
having
so
beaten
and
battered
his
own
that
it
was
quite
unfit
for
further
service
<EOS>
,
he
wandered
out
again
,
in
a
perfect
bog
of
uncertainty
and
mental
confusion
,
and
in
that
state
took
the
strangest
means
of
resolving
his
doubts
:
such
as
feeling
the
sleeve
of
his
son
's
greatcoat
as
deeming
it
possible
that
his
arm
might
be
there
;
looking
at
his
own
arms
and
those
of
everybody
else
,
as
if
to
assure
himself
that
two
and
not
one
was
the
usual
allowance
;
sitting
by
the
hour
together
in
a
brown
study
,
as
if
he
were
endeavouring
to
recall
Joe
's
image
in
his
younger
days
,
and
to
remember
whether
he
really
had
in
those
times
one
arm
or
a
pair
;
and
employing
himself
in
many
other
speculations
of
the
same
kind
.
  
<EOS>
Finding
himself
at
this
supper
,
surrounded
by
faces
with
which
he
had
been
so
well
acquainted
in
old
times
,
Mr
Willet
recurred
to
the
subject
with
uncommon
vigour
;
apparently
resolved
to
understand
it
now
or
never
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
after
every
two
or
three
mouthfuls
,
he
laid
down
his
knife
and
fork
,
and
stared
at
his
son
with
all
his
might
---
particularly
at
his
maimed
side
;
then
,
he
looked
slowly
round
the
table
until
he
caught
some
person
's
eye
,
when
he
shook
his
head
with
great
solemnity
,
patted
his
shoulder
,
winked
,
or
as
one
may
say
---
for
winking
was
a
very
slow
process
with
him
---
went
to
sleep
with
one
eye
for
a
minute
or
two
;
and
so
,
with
another
solemn
shaking
of
his
head
,
took
up
his
knife
and
fork
again
,
and
went
on
eating
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
he
put
his
food
into
his
mouth
abstractedly
,
and
,
with
all
his
faculties
concentrated
on
Joe
,
gazed
at
him
in
a
fit
of
stupefaction
as
he
cut
his
meat
with
one
hand
,
until
he
was
recalled
to
himself
by
symptoms
of
choking
on
his
own
part
,
and
was
by
that
means
restored
to
consciousness
.
 
<EOS>
At
other
times
he
resorted
to
such
small
devices
as
asking
him
for
the
salt
,
the
pepper
,
the
vinegar
,
the
mustard
---
anything
that
was
on
his
maimed
side
---
and
watching
him
as
he
handed
it
.
 
<EOS>
By
dint
of
these
experiments
,
he
did
at
last
so
satisfy
and
convince
himself
,
that
,
after
a
longer
silence
than
he
had
yet
maintained
,
he
laid
down
his
knife
and
fork
on
either
side
his
plate
,
drank
a
long
draught
from
a
tankard
beside
him
(
still
keeping
his
eyes
on
Joe
)
,
and
leaning
backward
in
his
chair
and
fetching
a
long
breath
,
said
,
as
he
looked
all
round
the
board
:
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
been
took
off
!
"
  
"
<EOS>
By
George
!
"
said
the
Black
Lion
,
striking
the
table
with
his
hand
,
"
he
's
got
it
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Willet
,
with
the
look
of
a
man
who
felt
that
he
had
earned
a
compliment
,
and
deserved
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
where
it
is
.
<EOS>
It
's
been
took
off
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
him
where
it
was
done
,
"
said
the
Black
Lion
to
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
the
defence
of
the
Savannah
,
father
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
the
defence
of
the
Salwanners
,
"
repeated
Mr
Willet
,
softly
;
again
looking
round
the
table
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
America
,
where
the
war
is
,
"
said
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
America
,
where
the
war
is
,
"
repeated
Mr
Willet
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
took
off
in
the
defence
of
the
Salwanners
in
America
where
the
war
is
.
"
<EOS>
Continuing
to
repeat
these
words
to
himself
in
a
low
tone
of
voice
(
the
same
information
had
been
conveyed
to
him
in
the
same
terms
,
at
least
fifty
times
before
)
,
Mr
Willet
arose
from
table
,
walked
round
to
Joe
,
felt
his
empty
sleeve
all
the
way
up
,
from
the
cuff
,
to
where
the
stump
of
his
arm
remained
;
shook
his
hand
;
lighted
his
pipe
at
the
fire
,
took
a
long
whiff
,
walked
to
the
door
,
turned
round
once
when
he
had
reached
it
,
wiped
his
left
eye
with
the
back
of
his
forefinger
,
and
said
,
in
a
faltering
voice
:
"
<EOS>
My
son
's
arm
---
 
was
took
off
---
at
the
defence
of
the
---
Salwanners
---
in
America
---
where
the
war
is
"
---
with
which
words
he
withdrew
,
and
returned
no
more
that
night
.
  
<EOS>
Indeed
,
on
various
pretences
,
they
all
withdrew
one
after
another
,
save
Dolly
,
who
was
left
sitting
there
alone
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
relief
to
be
alone
,
and
she
was
crying
to
her
heart
's
content
,
when
she
heard
Joe
's
voice
at
the
end
of
the
passage
,
bidding
somebody
good
night
.
  
<EOS>
Good
night
!
 
<EOS>
Then
he
was
going
elsewhere
---
to
some
distance
,
perhaps
.
 
<EOS>
To
what
kind
of
home
<EOS>
COULD
he
be
going
,
now
that
it
was
so
late
!
  
<EOS>
She
heard
him
walk
along
the
passage
,
and
pass
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
a
hesitation
in
his
footsteps
.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
back
---
Dolly
's
heart
beat
high
---
he
looked
in
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
---
he
did
n't
say
Dolly
,
but
there
was
comfort
in
his
not
saying
Miss
Varden
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
sobbed
Dolly
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
you
take
on
so
much
,
for
what
is
past
and
gone
,
"
said
Joe
kindly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
bear
to
see
you
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
Think
of
it
no
longer
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
safe
and
happy
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Dolly
cried
the
more
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
have
suffered
very
much
within
these
few
days
---
and
yet
you
're
not
changed
,
unless
it
's
for
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
They
said
you
were
,
but
I
do
n't
see
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
---
you
were
always
very
beautiful
,
"
said
Joe
,
"
but
you
are
more
beautiful
than
ever
,
now
.
<EOS>
You
are
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
There
can
be
no
harm
in
my
saying
so
,
for
you
must
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
told
so
very
often
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
a
general
principle
,
Dolly
DID
know
it
,
and
WAS
told
so
,
very
often
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
coachmaker
had
turned
out
,
years
ago
,
to
be
a
special
donkey
;
and
whether
she
had
been
afraid
of
making
similar
discoveries
in
others
,
or
had
grown
by
dint
of
long
custom
to
be
careless
of
compliments
generally
,
<EOS>
certain
it
is
that
although
she
cried
so
much
,
she
was
better
pleased
to
be
told
so
now
,
than
ever
she
had
been
in
all
her
life
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
bless
your
name
,
"
sobbed
the
locksmith
's
little
daughter
,
"
as
long
as
I
live
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
never
hear
it
spoken
without
feeling
as
if
my
heart
would
burst
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
remember
it
in
my
prayers
,
every
night
and
morning
till
I
die
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
?
"
said
Joe
,
eagerly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
indeed
?
 
<EOS>
It
makes
me
---
 
<EOS>
well
,
it
makes
me
very
glad
and
proud
to
hear
you
say
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Dolly
still
sobbed
,
and
held
her
handkerchief
to
her
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
Joe
still
stood
,
looking
at
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
voice
,
"
said
Joe
,
"
brings
up
old
times
so
pleasantly
,
that
,
for
the
moment
,
I
feel
as
if
that
night
---
there
can
be
no
harm
in
talking
of
that
night
now
---
had
come
back
,
and
nothing
had
happened
in
the
mean
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
as
if
I
had
n't
suffered
any
hardships
,
but
had
knocked
down
poor
Tom
Cobb
only
yesterday
,
and
had
come
to
see
you
with
my
bundle
on
my
shoulder
before
running
away
.
<EOS>
---
You
remember
?
"
  
<EOS>
Remember
!
 
<EOS>
But
she
said
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
She
raised
her
eyes
for
an
instant
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
but
<EOS>
a
glance
;
a
little
,
tearful
,
timid
glance
.
 
<EOS>
It
kept
Joe
silent
though
,
for
a
long
time
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
stoutly
,
"
it
was
to
be
otherwise
,
and
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
abroad
,
fighting
all
the
summer
and
frozen
up
all
the
winter
,
ever
since
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
come
back
as
poor
in
purse
as
I
went
,
and
crippled
for
life
besides
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
Dolly
,
I
would
rather
have
lost
this
other
arm
<EOS>
---
ay
,
I
would
rather
have
lost
my
head
---
than
have
come
back
to
find
you
dead
,
or
anything
<EOS>
but
what
I
always
pictured
you
to
myself
,
and
what
I
always
hoped
and
wished
to
find
you
.
<EOS>
Thank
God
for
all
!
"
  
<EOS>
Oh
how
much
,
and
how
keenly
,
the
little
coquette
of
five
years
ago
,
felt
now
!
 
<EOS>
She
had
found
her
heart
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
Never
having
known
its
worth
till
now
,
she
had
never
known
the
worth
of
his
.
 
<EOS>
How
priceless
it
appeared
!
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
hope
once
,
"
said
Joe
,
in
his
homely
way
,
"
that
I
might
come
back
a
rich
man
,
and
marry
you
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
was
a
boy
then
,
and
have
long
known
better
than
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
poor
,
maimed
,
discharged
soldier
,
and
must
be
content
to
rub
through
life
as
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
say
,
even
now
,
that
I
shall
be
glad
to
see
you
married
,
Dolly
;
but
I
AM
glad
---
yes
,
I
am
,
and
glad
to
think
I
can
say
so
---
to
know
that
you
are
admired
and
courted
,
and
can
pick
and
choose
for
a
happy
life
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
comfort
to
me
to
know
that
you
'll
talk
to
your
husband
about
me
;
and
I
hope
the
time
will
come
when
I
may
be
able
to
like
him
,
and
to
shake
hands
with
him
,
and
to
come
and
see
you
as
a
poor
friend
who
knew
you
when
you
were
a
girl
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
His
hand
DID
tremble
;
but
for
all
that
,
he
took
it
away
again
,
and
left
her
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
73
    
<EOS>
By
this
Friday
night
---
for
it
was
on
Friday
in
the
riot
week
,
that
Emma
and
Dolly
were
rescued
,
by
the
timely
aid
of
Joe
and
Edward
Chester
---
the
disturbances
were
entirely
quelled
,
and
peace
and
order
were
restored
to
the
affrighted
city
.
 
<EOS>
True
,
after
what
had
happened
,
it
was
impossible
for
any
man
to
say
how
long
this
better
state
of
things
might
last
,
or
how
suddenly
new
outrages
,
exceeding
even
those
so
lately
witnessed
,
might
burst
forth
and
fill
its
streets
with
ruin
and
bloodshed
;
for
this
reason
,
those
who
had
fled
from
the
recent
tumults
still
kept
at
a
distance
,
and
many
families
,
hitherto
unable
to
procure
the
means
of
flight
,
now
availed
themselves
of
the
calm
,
and
withdrew
into
the
country
.
 
<EOS>
The
shops
,
too
,
from
Tyburn
to
Whitechapel
,
were
still
shut
;
and
very
little
business
was
transacted
in
any
of
the
places
of
great
commercial
resort
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
notwithstanding
,
and
in
spite
of
the
melancholy
forebodings
of
that
numerous
class
of
society
who
see
with
the
greatest
clearness
into
the
darkest
perspectives
,
the
town
remained
profoundly
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
The
strong
military
force
disposed
in
every
advantageous
quarter
,
and
stationed
at
every
commanding
point
,
held
the
scattered
fragments
of
the
mob
in
check
;
the
search
after
rioters
was
prosecuted
with
unrelenting
vigour
;
and
if
there
were
any
among
them
so
desperate
and
reckless
as
to
be
inclined
,
after
the
terrible
scenes
they
had
beheld
,
to
venture
forth
again
,
they
were
so
daunted
by
these
resolute
measures
,
that
they
quickly
shrunk
into
their
hiding
-
places
,
and
had
no
thought
but
for
their
safety
.
  
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
the
crowd
was
utterly
routed
.
 
<EOS>
Upwards
of
two
hundred
had
been
shot
dead
in
the
streets
.
 
<EOS>
Two
hundred
and
fifty
more
were
lying
,
badly
wounded
,
in
the
hospitals
;
of
whom
seventy
or
eighty
died
within
a
short
time
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
A
hundred
were
already
in
custody
,
and
more
were
taken
every
hour
.
 
<EOS>
How
many
perished
in
the
conflagrations
,
or
by
their
own
excesses
,
is
unknown
;
but
that
numbers
found
a
terrible
grave
in
the
hot
ashes
of
the
flames
they
had
kindled
,
or
crept
into
vaults
and
cellars
to
drink
in
secret
or
to
nurse
their
sores
,
and
never
saw
the
light
again
,
is
certain
.
<EOS>
When
the
embers
of
the
fires
had
been
black
and
cold
for
many
weeks
,
the
labourers
'
spades
proved
this
,
beyond
a
doubt
.
  
<EOS>
Seventy
-
two
private
houses
and
four
strong
jails
were
destroyed
in
the
four
great
days
of
these
riots
.
 
<EOS>
The
total
loss
of
property
,
as
estimated
by
the
sufferers
,
was
one
hundred
and
fifty
-
five
thousand
pounds
;
at
the
lowest
and
least
partial
estimate
of
disinterested
persons
,
it
exceeded
one
hundred
and
twenty
-
five
thousand
pounds
.
<EOS>
For
this
immense
loss
,
compensation
was
soon
afterwards
made
out
of
the
public
purse
,
in
pursuance
of
a
vote
of
the
House
of
Commons
;
the
sum
being
levied
on
the
various
wards
in
the
city
,
on
the
county
,
and
the
borough
of
Southwark
.
 
<EOS>
Both
Lord
Mansfield
and
Lord
Saville
,
however
,
who
had
been
great
sufferers
,
refused
to
accept
of
any
compensation
whatever
.
  
<EOS>
The
House
of
Commons
,
sitting
on
Tuesday
with
locked
and
guarded
doors
,
had
passed
a
resolution
to
the
effect
that
,
as
soon
as
the
tumults
subsided
,
it
would
immediately
proceed
to
consider
the
petitions
presented
from
many
of
his
Majesty
's
Protestant
subjects
,
and
would
take
the
same
into
its
serious
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
While
this
question
was
under
debate
,
Mr
Herbert
,
one
of
the
members
present
,
indignantly
rose
and
called
upon
the
House
to
observe
that
Lord
George
Gordon
was
then
sitting
under
the
gallery
with
the
blue
cockade
,
the
signal
of
rebellion
,
in
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
only
obliged
,
by
those
who
sat
near
,
to
take
it
out
;
but
offering
to
go
into
the
street
to
pacify
the
mob
with
the
somewhat
indefinite
assurance
that
the
House
was
prepared
to
give
them
"
the
satisfaction
they
sought
,
"
was
actually
held
down
in
his
seat
by
the
combined
force
of
several
members
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
the
disorder
and
violence
which
reigned
triumphant
out
of
doors
,
penetrated
into
the
senate
,
and
there
,
as
elsewhere
,
terror
and
alarm
prevailed
,
and
ordinary
forms
were
for
the
time
forgotten
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
Thursday
,
both
Houses
had
adjourned
until
the
following
Monday
se'nnight
,
declaring
it
impossible
to
pursue
their
deliberations
with
the
necessary
gravity
and
freedom
,
while
they
were
surrounded
by
armed
troops
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
that
the
rioters
were
dispersed
,
the
citizens
were
beset
with
a
new
fear
;
for
,
finding
the
public
thoroughfares
and
all
their
usual
places
of
resort
filled
with
soldiers
entrusted
with
the
free
use
of
fire
and
sword
,
they
began
to
lend
a
greedy
ear
to
the
rumours
which
were
afloat
of
martial
law
being
declared
,
and
to
dismal
stories
of
prisoners
having
been
seen
hanging
on
lamp
-
posts
in
Cheapside
and
Fleet
Street
.
 
<EOS>
These
terrors
being
promptly
dispelled
by
a
Proclamation
declaring
that
all
the
rioters
in
custody
would
be
tried
by
a
special
commission
in
due
course
of
law
,
a
fresh
alarm
was
engendered
by
its
being
whispered
abroad
that
French
money
had
been
found
on
some
of
the
rioters
,
and
that
the
disturbances
had
been
fomented
by
foreign
powers
who
sought
to
compass
the
overthrow
and
ruin
of
England
.
 
<EOS>
This
report
,
which
was
strengthened
by
the
diffusion
of
anonymous
handbills
,
but
which
,
if
it
had
any
foundation
at
all
,
probably
owed
its
origin
to
the
circumstance
of
some
few
coins
which
were
not
English
money
having
been
swept
into
the
pockets
of
the
insurgents
with
other
miscellaneous
booty
,
and
afterwards
discovered
on
the
prisoners
or
the
dead
bodies
,
---
caused
a
great
sensation
;
and
men
's
minds
being
in
that
excited
state
when
they
are
most
apt
to
catch
at
any
shadow
of
apprehension
,
was
bruited
about
with
much
industry
.
  
<EOS>
All
remaining
quiet
,
however
,
during
the
whole
of
this
Friday
,
and
on
this
Friday
night
,
and
no
new
discoveries
being
made
,
confidence
began
to
be
restored
,
and
the
most
timid
and
desponding
breathed
again
.
 
<EOS>
In
Southwark
,
no
fewer
than
three
thousand
of
the
inhabitants
formed
themselves
into
a
watch
,
and
patrolled
the
streets
every
hour
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
were
the
citizens
slow
to
follow
so
good
an
example
:
and
it
being
the
manner
of
peaceful
men
to
be
very
bold
when
the
danger
is
over
,
they
were
abundantly
fierce
and
daring
;
not
scrupling
to
question
the
stoutest
passenger
with
great
severity
,
and
carrying
it
with
a
very
high
hand
over
all
errand
-
boys
,
servant
-
girls
,
and
'
prentices
.
  
<EOS>
As
day
deepened
into
evening
,
and
darkness
crept
into
the
nooks
and
corners
of
the
town
as
if
it
were
mustering
in
secret
and
gathering
strength
to
venture
into
the
open
ways
,
Barnaby
sat
in
his
dungeon
,
wondering
at
the
silence
,
and
listening
in
vain
for
the
noise
and
outcry
which
had
ushered
in
the
night
of
late
.
 
<EOS>
Beside
him
,
with
his
hand
in
hers
,
sat
one
in
whose
companionship
he
felt
at
peace
.
<EOS>
She
was
worn
,
and
altered
,
full
of
grief
,
and
heavy
-
hearted
;
but
the
same
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
"
he
said
,
after
a
long
silence
:
"
how
long
,
---
how
many
days
and
nights
,
---
shall
I
be
kept
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
many
,
dear
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
not
many
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
hope
!
 
<EOS>
Ay
,
but
your
hoping
will
not
undo
these
chains
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
,
but
they
do
n't
mind
that
.
 
<EOS>
Grip
hopes
,
but
who
cares
for
Grip
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
raven
gave
a
short
,
dull
,
melancholy
croak
.
 
<EOS>
It
said
"
<EOS>
Nobody
,
"
as
plainly
as
a
croak
could
speak
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
cares
for
Grip
,
except
you
and
me
?
"
said
Barnaby
,
smoothing
the
bird
's
rumpled
feathers
with
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
never
speaks
in
this
place
;
he
never
says
a
word
in
jail
;
he
sits
and
mopes
all
day
in
his
dark
corner
,
dozing
sometimes
,
and
sometimes
looking
at
the
light
that
creeps
in
through
the
bars
,
and
shines
in
his
bright
eye
as
if
a
spark
from
those
great
fires
had
fallen
into
the
room
and
was
burning
yet
.
 
<EOS>
But
who
cares
for
Grip
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
raven
croaked
again
---
Nobody
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
by
the
way
,
"
said
Barnaby
,
withdrawing
his
hand
from
the
bird
,
and
laying
it
upon
his
mother
's
arm
,
as
he
looked
eagerly
in
her
face
;
"
if
they
kill
me
---
they
may
:
I
heard
it
said
they
would
---
what
will
become
of
Grip
when
I
am
dead
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
sound
of
the
word
,
or
the
current
of
his
own
thoughts
,
suggested
to
Grip
his
old
phrase
"
Never
say
die
!
"
 
<EOS>
But
he
stopped
short
in
the
middle
of
it
,
drew
a
dismal
cork
,
and
subsided
into
a
faint
croak
,
as
if
he
lacked
the
heart
to
get
through
the
shortest
sentence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
they
take
HIS
life
as
well
as
mine
?
"
said
Barnaby
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
they
would
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
and
I
and
he
could
die
together
,
there
would
be
none
to
feel
sorry
,
or
to
grieve
for
us
.
 
<EOS>
But
do
what
they
will
,
I
do
n't
fear
them
,
mother
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
will
not
harm
you
,
"
she
said
,
her
tears
choking
her
utterance
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
never
will
harm
you
,
when
they
know
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
they
never
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
too
sure
of
that
,
"
cried
Barnaby
,
with
a
strange
pleasure
in
the
belief
that
she
was
self
-
deceived
,
and
in
his
own
sagacity
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
have
marked
me
from
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
them
say
so
to
each
other
when
they
brought
me
to
this
place
last
night
;
and
I
believe
them
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
cry
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
They
said
that
I
was
bold
,
and
so
I
am
,
and
<EOS>
so
I
will
be
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
think
that
I
am
silly
,
but
I
can
die
as
well
as
another
.
<EOS>
---
I
have
done
no
harm
,
have
I
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
quickly
.
  
<EOS>
"
None
before
Heaven
,
"
she
answered
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
then
,
"
said
Barnaby
,
"
let
them
do
their
worst
.
 
<EOS>
You
told
me
once
---
you
---
when
I
asked
you
what
death
meant
,
that
it
was
nothing
to
be
feared
,
if
we
did
no
harm
---
<EOS>
Aha
!
<EOS>
mother
,
you
thought
I
had
forgotten
that
!
"
  
<EOS>
His
merry
laugh
and
playful
manner
smote
her
to
the
heart
.
 
<EOS>
She
drew
him
closer
to
her
,
and
besought
him
to
talk
to
her
in
whispers
and
to
be
very
quiet
,
for
it
was
getting
dark
,
and
their
time
was
short
,
and
she
would
soon
have
to
leave
him
for
the
night
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
come
to
-
morrow
?
"
said
Barnaby
.
  
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
And
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
And
they
would
never
part
again
.
  
<EOS>
He
joyfully
replied
that
this
was
well
,
and
what
he
wished
,
and
what
he
had
felt
quite
certain
she
would
tell
him
;
and
then
he
asked
her
where
she
had
been
so
long
,
and
why
she
had
not
come
to
see
him
when
he
had
been
a
great
soldier
,
and
ran
through
the
wild
schemes
he
had
had
for
their
being
rich
and
living
prosperously
,
and
with
some
faint
notion
in
his
mind
that
she
was
sad
and
he
had
made
her
so
,
tried
to
console
and
comfort
her
,
and
talked
of
their
former
life
and
his
old
sports
and
freedom
:
<EOS>
little
dreaming
that
every
word
he
uttered
only
increased
her
sorrow
,
and
that
her
tears
fell
faster
at
the
freshened
recollection
of
their
lost
tranquillity
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
"
said
Barnaby
,
as
they
heard
the
man
approaching
to
close
the
cells
for
the
night
,
"
when
I
spoke
to
you
just
now
about
my
father
you
cried
"
Hush
!
"
and
turned
away
your
head
.
 
<EOS>
Why
did
you
do
so
?
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
why
,
in
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
You
thought
HE
was
dead
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
not
sorry
that
he
is
alive
and
has
come
back
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
Where
is
he
?
<EOS>
Here
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
ask
any
one
where
he
is
,
or
speak
about
him
,
"
she
made
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
said
Barnaby
.
 
<EOS>
"
Because
he
is
a
stern
man
,
and
talks
roughly
?
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
him
,
or
want
to
be
with
him
by
myself
;
but
why
not
speak
about
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
am
sorry
that
he
is
alive
;
sorry
that
he
has
come
back
;
and
sorry
that
he
and
you
have
ever
met
.
 
<EOS>
Because
,
dear
Barnaby
,
the
endeavour
of
my
life
has
been
to
keep
you
two
asunder
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Father
and
son
asunder
!
 
<EOS>
Why
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
He
has
,
"
she
whispered
in
his
ear
,
"
he
has
shed
blood
.
 
<EOS>
The
time
has
come
when
you
must
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
shed
the
blood
of
one
who
loved
him
well
,
and
trusted
him
,
and
never
did
him
wrong
in
word
or
deed
.
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
recoiled
in
horror
,
and
glancing
at
his
stained
wrist
for
an
instant
,
wrapped
it
,
shuddering
,
in
his
dress
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
"
she
added
hastily
as
the
key
turned
in
the
lock
,
"
although
we
shun
him
,
he
is
your
father
,
dearest
,
and
I
am
his
wretched
wife
.
 
<EOS>
They
seek
his
life
,
and
he
will
lose
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
must
not
be
by
our
means
;
nay
,
if
we
could
win
him
back
to
penitence
,
we
should
be
bound
to
love
him
yet
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
seem
to
know
him
,
except
as
one
who
fled
with
you
from
the
jail
,
and
if
they
question
you
about
him
,
do
not
answer
them
.
 
<EOS>
God
be
with
you
through
the
night
,
dear
boy
!
 
<EOS>
God
be
with
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
tore
herself
away
,
and
in
a
few
seconds
Barnaby
was
alone
.
 
<EOS>
He
stood
for
a
long
time
rooted
to
the
spot
,
with
his
face
hidden
in
his
hands
;
then
flung
himself
,
sobbing
,
on
his
miserable
bed
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
moon
came
slowly
up
in
all
her
gentle
glory
,
and
the
stars
looked
out
,
and
through
the
small
compass
of
the
grated
window
,
as
through
the
narrow
crevice
of
one
good
deed
in
a
murky
life
of
guilt
,
the
face
of
Heaven
shone
bright
and
merciful
.
 
<EOS>
He
raised
his
head
;
gazed
upward
at
the
quiet
sky
,
which
seemed
to
smile
upon
the
earth
in
sadness
,
as
if
the
night
,
more
thoughtful
than
the
day
,
looked
down
in
sorrow
on
the
sufferings
and
evil
deeds
of
men
;
and
felt
its
peace
sink
deep
into
his
heart
.
 
<EOS>
He
,
a
poor
idiot
,
caged
in
his
narrow
cell
,
was
as
much
lifted
up
to
God
,
while
gazing
on
the
mild
light
,
as
the
freest
and
most
favoured
man
in
all
the
spacious
city
;
and
in
his
ill
-
remembered
prayer
,
and
in
the
fragment
of
the
childish
hymn
,
with
which
he
sung
and
crooned
himself
asleep
,
there
breathed
as
true
a
spirit
as
ever
studied
homily
expressed
,
or
old
cathedral
arches
echoed
.
  
<EOS>
As
his
mother
crossed
a
yard
on
her
way
out
,
she
saw
,
through
a
grated
door
which
separated
it
from
another
court
,
her
husband
,
walking
round
and
round
,
with
his
hands
folded
on
his
breast
,
and
his
head
hung
down
.
 
<EOS>
She
asked
the
man
who
conducted
her
,
if
she
might
speak
a
word
with
this
prisoner
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
but
she
must
be
quick
for
he
was
locking
up
for
the
night
,
and
there
was
but
a
minute
or
so
to
spare
.
 
<EOS>
Saying
this
,
he
unlocked
the
door
,
and
bade
her
go
in
.
  
<EOS>
It
grated
harshly
as
it
turned
upon
its
hinges
,
but
he
was
deaf
to
the
noise
,
and
still
walked
round
and
round
the
little
court
,
without
raising
his
head
or
changing
his
attitude
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
She
spoke
to
him
,
but
her
voice
was
weak
,
and
failed
her
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
she
put
herself
in
his
track
,
and
when
he
came
near
,
stretched
out
her
hand
and
touched
him
.
  
<EOS>
He
started
backward
,
trembling
from
head
to
foot
;
but
seeing
who
it
was
,
demanded
why
she
came
there
.
 
<EOS>
Before
she
could
reply
,
he
spoke
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Am
I
to
live
or
die
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
murder
too
,
or
spare
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
son
---
our
son
,
"
she
answered
,
"
is
in
this
prison
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
that
to
me
?
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
stamping
impatiently
on
the
stone
pavement
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
can
no
more
aid
me
than
I
can
aid
him
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
come
to
talk
of
him
,
begone
!
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
he
resumed
his
walk
,
and
hurried
round
the
court
as
before
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
came
again
to
where
she
stood
,
he
stopped
,
and
said
,
  
"
<EOS>
Am
I
to
live
or
die
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
repent
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
---
do
YOU
?
"
<EOS>
she
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
,
while
time
remains
?
 
<EOS>
Do
not
believe
that
I
could
save
you
,
if
I
dared
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Say
if
you
would
,
"
he
answered
with
an
oath
,
as
he
tried
to
disengage
himself
and
pass
on
.
 
<EOS>
"
Say
if
you
would
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Listen
to
me
for
one
moment
,
"
she
returned
;
"
for
but
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
but
newly
risen
from
a
sick
-
bed
,
from
which
I
never
hoped
to
rise
again
.
 
<EOS>
The
best
among
us
think
,
at
such
a
time
,
of
good
intentions
half
-
performed
and
duties
left
undone
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
ever
,
since
that
fatal
night
,
omitted
to
pray
for
your
repentance
before
death
---
if
I
omitted
,
even
then
,
anything
which
might
tend
to
urge
it
on
you
when
the
horror
of
your
crime
was
fresh
---
if
,
in
our
later
meeting
,
I
yielded
to
the
dread
that
was
upon
me
,
and
forgot
to
fall
upon
my
knees
and
solemnly
adjure
you
,
in
the
name
of
him
you
sent
to
his
account
with
Heaven
,
to
prepare
for
the
retribution
which
must
come
,
and
which
is
stealing
on
you
now
---
I
humbly
before
you
,
and
in
the
agony
of
supplication
in
which
you
see
me
,
beseech
that
you
will
let
me
make
atonement
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
meaning
of
your
canting
words
?
"
<EOS>
he
answered
roughly
.
"
<EOS>
Speak
so
that
I
may
understand
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
she
answered
,
"
I
desire
to
.
 
<EOS>
Bear
with
me
for
a
moment
more
.
 
<EOS>
The
hand
of
Him
who
set
His
curse
on
murder
,
is
heavy
on
us
now
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
not
doubt
it
.
 
<EOS>
Our
son
,
our
innocent
boy
,
on
whom
His
anger
fell
before
his
birth
,
is
in
this
place
in
peril
of
his
life
---
 
<EOS>
brought
here
by
your
guilt
;
yes
,
by
that
alone
,
as
Heaven
sees
and
knows
,
for
he
has
been
led
astray
in
the
darkness
of
his
intellect
,
and
that
is
the
terrible
consequence
of
your
crime
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
come
,
woman
-
like
,
to
load
me
with
reproaches
---
"
he
muttered
,
again
endeavouring
to
break
away
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
different
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
hear
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
not
to
-
night
,
to
-
morrow
;
if
not
to
-
morrow
,
at
another
time
.
 
<EOS>
You
MUST
hear
it
.
 
<EOS>
Husband
,
escape
is
hopeless
---
impossible
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
tell
me
so
,
do
you
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
raising
his
manacled
hand
,
and
shaking
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
she
said
,
with
indescribable
earnestness
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
why
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
make
me
easy
in
this
jail
.
 
<EOS>
To
make
the
time
'
twixt
this
and
death
,
pass
pleasantly
.
 
<EOS>
For
my
good
---
yes
,
for
my
good
,
of
course
,
"
he
said
,
grinding
his
teeth
,
and
smiling
at
her
with
a
livid
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
to
load
you
with
reproaches
,
"
she
replied
;
"
not
to
aggravate
the
tortures
and
miseries
of
your
condition
,
not
to
give
you
one
hard
word
,
but
to
restore
you
to
peace
and
hope
.
 
<EOS>
Husband
,
dear
husband
,
if
you
will
but
confess
this
dreadful
crime
;
if
you
will
but
implore
forgiveness
of
Heaven
and
of
those
whom
you
have
wronged
on
earth
;
if
you
will
dismiss
these
vain
uneasy
thoughts
,
which
never
can
be
realised
,
and
will
rely
on
Penitence
and
on
the
Truth
,
I
promise
you
,
in
the
great
name
of
the
Creator
,
whose
image
you
have
defaced
,
that
He
will
comfort
and
console
you
.
 
<EOS>
And
for
myself
,
"
she
cried
,
clasping
her
hands
,
and
looking
upward
,
"
I
swear
before
Him
,
as
He
knows
my
heart
and
reads
it
now
,
that
from
that
hour
I
will
love
and
cherish
you
as
I
did
of
old
,
and
watch
you
night
and
day
in
the
short
interval
that
will
remain
to
us
,
and
soothe
you
with
my
truest
love
and
duty
,
and
pray
with
you
,
that
one
threatening
judgment
may
be
arrested
,
and
that
our
boy
may
be
spared
to
bless
God
,
in
his
poor
way
,
in
the
free
air
and
light
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
fell
back
and
gazed
at
her
while
she
poured
out
these
words
,
as
though
he
were
for
a
moment
awed
by
her
manner
,
and
knew
not
what
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
But
anger
and
fear
soon
got
the
mastery
of
him
,
and
he
spurned
her
from
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Begone
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
Leave
me
!
 
<EOS>
You
plot
,
do
you
!
 
<EOS>
You
plot
to
get
speech
with
me
,
and
let
them
know
I
am
the
man
they
say
I
am
.
<EOS>
A
curse
on
you
and
on
your
boy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
On
him
the
curse
has
already
fallen
,
"
she
replied
,
wringing
her
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
it
fall
heavier
.
 
<EOS>
Let
it
fall
on
one
and
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
you
both
.
 
<EOS>
The
worst
has
come
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
comfort
that
I
seek
or
I
can
have
,
will
be
the
knowledge
that
it
comes
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Now
go
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
would
have
urged
him
gently
,
even
then
,
but
he
menaced
her
with
his
chain
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
go
---
I
say
it
for
the
last
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
gallows
has
me
in
its
grasp
,
and
it
is
a
black
phantom
that
may
urge
me
on
to
something
more
.
 
<EOS>
Begone
!
 
<EOS>
I
curse
the
hour
that
I
was
born
,
the
man
I
slew
,
and
all
the
living
world
!
"
  
<EOS>
In
a
paroxysm
of
wrath
,
and
terror
,
and
the
fear
of
death
,
he
broke
from
her
,
and
rushed
into
the
darkness
of
his
cell
,
where
he
cast
himself
jangling
down
upon
the
stone
floor
,
and
smote
it
with
his
ironed
hands
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
returned
to
lock
the
dungeon
door
,
and
having
done
so
,
carried
her
away
.
  
<EOS>
On
that
warm
,
balmy
night
in
June
,
there
were
glad
faces
and
light
hearts
in
all
quarters
of
the
town
,
and
sleep
,
banished
by
the
late
horrors
,
was
doubly
welcomed
.
 
<EOS>
On
that
night
,
families
made
merry
in
their
houses
,
and
greeted
each
other
on
the
common
danger
they
had
escaped
;
and
those
who
had
been
denounced
,
ventured
into
the
streets
;
and
they
who
had
been
plundered
,
got
good
shelter
.
 
<EOS>
Even
the
timorous
Lord
Mayor
,
who
was
summoned
that
night
before
the
Privy
Council
to
answer
for
his
conduct
,
came
back
contented
;
observing
to
all
his
friends
that
he
had
got
off
very
well
with
a
reprimand
,
and
repeating
with
huge
satisfaction
his
memorable
defence
before
the
Council
,
"
that
such
was
his
temerity
<EOS>
,
he
thought
death
would
have
been
his
portion
.
"
  
<EOS>
On
that
night
,
too
,
more
of
the
scattered
remnants
of
the
mob
were
traced
to
their
lurking
-
places
,
and
taken
;
and
in
the
hospitals
,
and
deep
among
the
ruins
they
had
made
,
and
in
the
ditches
,
and
fields
,
many
unshrouded
wretches
lay
dead
:
envied
by
those
who
had
been
active
in
the
disturbances
,
and
who
pillowed
their
doomed
heads
in
the
temporary
jails
.
  
<EOS>
And
in
the
Tower
,
in
a
dreary
room
whose
thick
stone
walls
shut
out
the
hum
of
life
,
and
made
a
stillness
which
the
records
left
by
former
prisoners
with
those
silent
witnesses
seemed
to
deepen
and
intensify
;
remorseful
for
every
act
that
had
been
done
by
every
man
among
the
cruel
crowd
;
feeling
for
the
time
their
guilt
his
own
,
and
their
lives
put
in
peril
by
himself
;
and
finding
,
amidst
such
reflections
,
little
comfort
in
fanaticism
,
or
in
his
fancied
call
;
sat
the
unhappy
author
of
all
---
Lord
George
Gordon
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
been
made
prisoner
that
evening
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
are
sure
it
's
me
<EOS>
you
want
,
"
he
said
to
the
officers
,
who
waited
outside
with
the
warrant
for
his
arrest
on
a
charge
of
High
Treason
,
"
I
am
ready
to
accompany
you
---
"
which
he
did
without
resistance
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
conducted
first
before
the
Privy
Council
,
and
afterwards
to
the
Horse
Guards
,
and
then
was
taken
by
way
of
Westminster
Bridge
,
and
back
over
London
Bridge
(
for
the
purpose
of
avoiding
the
main
streets
)
,
to
the
Tower
,
under
the
strongest
guard
ever
known
to
enter
its
gates
with
a
single
prisoner
.
  
<EOS>
Of
all
his
forty
thousand
men
,
not
one
remained
to
bear
him
company
.
 
<EOS>
Friends
,
dependents
,
followers
,
---
none
were
there
.
 
<EOS>
His
fawning
secretary
had
played
the
traitor
;
and
he
whose
weakness
had
been
goaded
and
urged
on
by
so
many
for
their
own
purposes
,
was
desolate
and
alone
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
74
    
Me
Dennis
,
having
been
made
prisoner
late
in
the
evening
,
was
removed
to
a
neighbouring
round
-
house
for
that
night
,
and
carried
before
a
justice
for
examination
on
the
next
day
,
Saturday
.
 
<EOS>
The
charges
against
him
being
numerous
and
weighty
,
and
it
being
in
particular
proved
,
by
the
testimony
of
Gabriel
Varden
,
that
he
had
shown
a
special
desire
to
take
his
life
,
he
was
committed
for
trial
.
 
<EOS>
Moreover
he
was
honoured
with
the
distinction
of
being
considered
a
chief
among
the
insurgents
,
and
received
from
the
magistrate
's
lips
the
complimentary
assurance
that
he
was
in
a
position
of
imminent
danger
,
and
would
do
well
to
prepare
himself
for
the
worst
.
  
<EOS>
To
say
that
Mr
Dennis
's
modesty
was
not
somewhat
startled
by
these
honours
,
or
that
he
was
altogether
prepared
for
so
flattering
a
reception
,
would
be
to
claim
for
him
a
greater
amount
of
stoical
philosophy
than
even
he
possessed
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
this
gentleman
's
stoicism
was
of
that
not
uncommon
kind
,
which
enables
a
man
to
bear
with
exemplary
fortitude
the
afflictions
of
his
friends
,
but
renders
him
,
by
way
of
counterpoise
,
rather
selfish
and
sensitive
in
respect
of
any
that
happen
to
befall
himself
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
therefore
no
disparagement
to
the
great
officer
in
question
to
state
,
without
disguise
or
concealment
,
that
he
was
at
first
very
much
alarmed
,
and
that
he
betrayed
divers
emotions
of
fear
,
until
his
reasoning
powers
came
to
his
relief
,
and
set
before
him
a
more
hopeful
prospect
.
  
<EOS>
In
proportion
as
Mr
Dennis
exercised
these
intellectual
qualities
with
which
he
was
gifted
,
in
reviewing
his
best
chances
of
coming
off
handsomely
and
with
small
personal
inconvenience
,
his
spirits
rose
,
and
his
confidence
increased
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
remembered
the
great
estimation
in
which
his
office
was
held
,
and
the
constant
demand
for
his
services
;
when
he
bethought
himself
,
how
the
Statute
Book
regarded
him
as
a
kind
of
Universal
Medicine
applicable
to
men
,
women
,
and
children
,
of
every
age
and
variety
of
criminal
constitution
;
and
how
high
he
stood
,
in
his
official
capacity
,
in
the
favour
of
the
Crown
,
and
both
Houses
of
Parliament
,
the
Mint
,
the
Bank
of
England
,
and
the
Judges
of
the
land
;
when
he
recollected
that
whatever
Ministry
was
in
or
out
,
he
remained
their
peculiar
pet
and
panacea
,
and
that
for
his
sake
England
stood
single
and
conspicuous
among
the
civilised
nations
of
the
earth
:
when
he
called
these
things
to
mind
and
dwelt
upon
them
,
he
felt
certain
that
the
national
gratitude
MUST
relieve
him
from
the
consequences
of
his
late
proceedings
,
and
would
certainly
restore
him
to
his
old
place
in
the
happy
social
system
.
  
<EOS>
With
these
crumbs
,
or
as
one
may
say
,
with
these
whole
loaves
of
comfort
to
regale
upon
,
Mr
Dennis
took
his
place
among
the
escort
that
awaited
him
,
and
repaired
to
jail
with
a
manly
indifference
.
<EOS>
Arriving
at
Newgate
,
where
some
of
the
ruined
cells
had
been
hastily
fitted
up
for
the
safe
keeping
of
rioters
,
he
was
warmly
received
by
the
turnkeys
,
as
an
unusual
and
interesting
case
,
which
agreeably
relieved
their
monotonous
duties
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
spirit
,
he
was
fettered
with
great
care
,
and
conveyed
into
the
interior
of
the
prison
.
  
<EOS>
"
Brother
,
"
cried
the
hangman
,
as
,
following
an
officer
,
he
traversed
under
these
novel
circumstances
the
remains
of
passages
with
which
he
was
well
acquainted
,
"
am
I
going
to
be
along
with
anybody
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
'd
have
left
more
walls
standing
,
you
'd
have
been
alone
,
"
was
the
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
it
is
,
we
're
cramped
for
room
,
and
you
'll
have
company
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
returned
Dennis
,
"
I
do
n't
object
to
company
,
brother
.
 
<EOS>
I
rather
like
company
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
formed
for
society
,
I
was
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
rather
a
pity
,
an't
it
?
"
said
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
answered
Dennis
,
"
I
'm
not
aware
that
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
it
be
a
pity
,
brother
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
the
man
carelessly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
that
was
what
you
meant
.
 
<EOS>
Being
formed
for
society
,
and
being
cut
off
in
your
flower
,
you
know
---
"
  
"
I
say
,
"
interposed
the
other
quickly
,
"
what
are
you
talking
of
?
<EOS>
Do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
Who
's
a
-
going
to
be
cut
off
in
their
flowers
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
nobody
particular
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
you
was
,
perhaps
,
"
said
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Dennis
wiped
his
face
,
which
had
suddenly
grown
very
hot
,
and
remarking
in
a
tremulous
voice
to
his
conductor
that
he
had
always
been
fond
of
his
joke
,
followed
him
in
silence
until
he
stopped
at
a
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
my
quarters
,
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
facetiously
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
shop
,
sir
,
"
replied
his
friend
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
walking
in
,
but
not
with
the
best
possible
grace
,
when
he
suddenly
stopped
,
and
started
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
"
said
the
officer
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
nervous
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nervous
!
"
whispered
Dennis
in
great
alarm
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
I
may
be
.
 
<EOS>
Shut
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
when
you
're
in
,
"
returned
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
ca
n't
go
in
there
,
"
whispered
Dennis
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
be
shut
up
with
that
man
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
want
me
to
be
throttled
,
brother
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
officer
seemed
to
entertain
no
particular
desire
on
the
subject
one
way
or
other
,
but
briefly
remarking
that
he
had
his
orders
,
and
intended
to
obey
them
,
pushed
him
in
,
turned
the
key
,
and
retired
.
  
<EOS>
Dennis
stood
trembling
with
his
back
against
the
door
,
and
involuntarily
raising
his
arm
to
defend
himself
,
stared
at
a
man
,
the
only
other
tenant
of
the
cell
,
who
lay
,
stretched
at
his
fall
length
,
upon
a
stone
bench
,
and
who
paused
in
his
deep
breathing
as
if
he
were
about
to
wake
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
rolled
over
on
one
side
,
let
his
arm
fall
negligently
down
,
drew
a
long
sigh
,
and
murmuring
indistinctly
,
fell
fast
asleep
again
.
  
<EOS>
Relieved
in
some
degree
by
this
,
the
hangman
took
his
eyes
for
an
instant
from
the
slumbering
figure
,
and
glanced
round
the
cell
in
search
of
some
"
vantage
-
ground
or
weapon
of
defence
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
moveable
within
it
,
but
a
clumsy
table
which
could
not
be
displaced
without
noise
,
and
a
heavy
chair
.
 
<EOS>
Stealing
on
tiptoe
towards
this
latter
piece
of
furniture
,
he
retired
with
it
into
the
remotest
corner
,
and
intrenching
himself
behind
it
,
watched
the
enemy
with
the
utmost
vigilance
and
caution
.
  
<EOS>
The
sleeping
man
was
Hugh
;
and
perhaps
it
was
not
unnatural
for
Dennis
to
feel
in
a
state
of
very
uncomfortable
suspense
,
and
to
wish
with
his
whole
soul
that
he
might
never
wake
again
.
 
<EOS>
Tired
of
standing
,
he
crouched
down
in
his
corner
after
some
time
,
and
rested
on
the
cold
pavement
;
but
although
Hugh
's
breathing
still
proclaimed
that
he
was
sleeping
soundly
,
he
could
not
trust
him
out
of
his
sight
for
an
instant
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
so
afraid
of
him
,
and
of
some
sudden
onslaught
,
that
he
was
not
content
to
see
his
closed
eyes
through
the
chair
-
back
,
but
every
now
and
then
,
rose
stealthily
to
his
feet
,
and
peered
at
him
with
outstretched
neck
,
to
assure
himself
that
he
really
was
still
asleep
,
and
was
not
about
to
spring
upon
him
when
he
was
off
his
guard
.
  
<EOS>
He
slept
so
long
and
<EOS>
so
soundly
,
that
Mr
Dennis
began
to
think
he
might
sleep
on
until
the
turnkey
visited
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
congratulating
himself
upon
these
promising
appearances
,
and
blessing
his
stars
with
much
fervour
,
when
one
or
two
unpleasant
symptoms
manifested
themselves
:
such
as
another
motion
of
the
arm
,
another
sigh
,
a
restless
tossing
of
the
head
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
just
as
it
seemed
that
he
was
about
to
fall
heavily
to
the
ground
from
his
narrow
bed
,
Hugh
's
eyes
opened
.
  
<EOS>
It
happened
that
his
face
was
turned
directly
towards
his
unexpected
visitor
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
lazily
at
him
for
some
half
-
dozen
seconds
without
any
aspect
of
surprise
or
recognition
;
then
suddenly
jumped
up
,
and
with
a
great
oath
pronounced
his
name
.
  
<EOS>
"
Keep
off
,
brother
,
keep
off
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Dennis
,
dodging
behind
the
chair
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
do
me
a
mischief
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
a
prisoner
like
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
n't
the
free
use
of
my
limbs
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
quite
an
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
hurt
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
whined
out
the
last
three
words
in
such
piteous
accents
,
that
Hugh
,
who
had
dragged
away
the
chair
,
and
aimed
a
blow
at
him
with
it
,
checked
himself
,
and
bade
him
get
up
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
get
up
certainly
,
brother
,
"
cried
Dennis
,
anxious
to
propitiate
him
by
any
means
in
his
power
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
comply
with
any
request
of
yours
,
I
'm
sure
.
 
<EOS>
There
---
I
'm
up
now
.
 
<EOS>
What
can
I
do
for
you
?
 
<EOS>
Only
say
the
word
,
and
I
'll
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
can
you
do
for
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
clutching
him
by
the
collar
with
both
hands
,
and
shaking
him
as
though
he
were
bent
on
stopping
his
breath
by
that
means
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
done
for
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
best
.
 
<EOS>
The
best
that
could
be
done
,
"
returned
the
hangman
.
  
<EOS>
Hugh
made
him
no
answer
,
but
shaking
him
in
his
strong
grip
until
his
teeth
chattered
in
his
head
,
cast
him
down
upon
the
floor
,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
If

was
n't
for
the
comfort
it
is

,
to
see

,
"
he
muttered
,
"
I
'd
have
crushed
your
head
against
it
;
I
would
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
some
time
before
Dennis
had
breath
enough
to
speak
,
but
as
soon
as
he
could
resume
his
propitiatory

,
he
did

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
the
best
that
could
be
done
,
brother
,
"
he
whined
;
"
I
did
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
forced
with
two
bayonets
<EOS>
and
I
do
n't
know
how
many
bullets
on
each
side
of
me
,
to

.
 
<EOS>
If
you
had
n't
been
taken
,
you
'd
have
been
shot
;
and
what
a
sight
that
would
have
been
---
 
a
fine
young
man
like
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
it
be
a
better
sight
now
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Hugh
,
raising
his
head
,
with
such

,
that
the
other
durst
not
answer
him
just
then
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
deal
better
,
"
said
Dennis
meekly
,
after

.
 
<EOS>
"
First
,
there
's
all
the
chances
of
the
law
,
and
they
're
five
hundred
strong
.
 
<EOS>
We
may
get
off
scot
-
free
.
 
<EOS>
Unlikelier
things
than
that
have
come
to
pass
.
 
<EOS>
Even
if
we
should
n't
,
and
the
chances
fail
,
we
can
but
be
worked
off
once
:
and
when
it
's
well
done
,
it
's
so
neat
,
<EOS>
so
skilful
,
so
captiwating
,
if
that
do
n't
seem
too
strong
a
word
,
that
you
'd
hardly
believe
it
could
be
brought
to
sich
perfection
.
<EOS>
Kill
one
's
fellow
-
creeturs
off
,
with
muskets
!
<EOS>
---
Pah
!
"
and
his
nature
so
revolted
at
the
bare
idea
,
that
he
spat
upon
the
dungeon

.
  
<EOS>
His
warming
on
this
topic
,
which
to
one
unacquainted
with
his
pursuits
and
tastes
appeared
like
courage
;
together
with
his
artful
suppression
of
his
own
secret
hopes
,
and
mention
of
himself
as
being
in
the
same
condition
with
Hugh
;
did
more
to
soothe
that
ruffian
than
the
most
elaborate
arguments
could
have
done
,
or
the
most
abject
submission
.
 
<EOS>
He
rested
his
arms
upon
his
knees
,
and
stooping
forward
,
looked
from
beneath
his
shaggy
hair
at
Dennis
,
with
something
of
a
smile
upon
his
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
fact
is
,
brother
,
"
said
the
hangman
,
in
a
tone
of
greater
confidence
,
"
that
you
got
into
bad
company
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
that
was
with
you
was
looked
after
more
than
you
,
and
it
was
him
I
wanted
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
me
,
what
have
I
got
by
it
?
 
<EOS>
Here
we
are
,
in
one
and
the
same
plight
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Lookee
,
rascal
,
"
said
Hugh
,
contracting
his
brows
,
"
I
'm
not
altogether
such
a
shallow
blade
<EOS>
but
I
know
you
expected
to
get
something
by
it
,
or
you
would
n't
have
done
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
done
,
and
you
're
here
,
and
it
will
soon
be
all
over
with
you
and
me
;
and
I
'd
as
soon
die
as
live
,
or
live
as
die
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
I
trouble
myself
to
have
revenge
on
you
?
 
<EOS>
To
eat
,
and
drink
,
and
go
to
sleep
,
as
long
as
I
stay
here
,
is
all
I
care
for
.
 
<EOS>
If
there
was
but
a
little
more
sun
to
bask
in
,
than
can
find
its
way
into
this
cursed
place
,
I
'd
lie
in
it
all
day
,
and
not
trouble
myself
to
sit
or
stand
up
once
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
the
care
I
have
for
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
I
care
for
YOU
?
"
  
<EOS>
Finishing
this
speech
with
a
growl
like
the
yawn
of
a
wild
beast
,
he
stretched
himself
upon
the
bench
again
,
and
closed
his
eyes
once
more
.
  
<EOS>
After
looking
at
him
in
silence
for
some
moments
,
Dennis
,
who
was
greatly
relieved
to
find
him
in
this
mood
,
drew
the
chair
towards
his
rough
couch
and
sat
down
near
him
---
taking
the
precaution
,
however
,
to
keep
out
of
the
range
of
his
brawny
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
said
,
brother
;
nothing
could
be
better
said
,
"
he
ventured
to
observe
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
'll
eat
and
drink
of
the
best
,
and
sleep
our
best
,
and
make
the
best
of
it
every
way
.
 
<EOS>
Anything
can
be
got
for
money
.
<EOS>
Let
's
spend
it
merrily
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
"
said
Hugh
,
coiling
himself
into
a
new
position
.
<EOS>
---
"
Where
is
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
they
took
mine
from
me
at
the
lodge
,
"
said
Mr
Dennis
;
"
but
mine
's
a
peculiar
case
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
?
 
<EOS>
They
took
mine
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
then
,
I
tell
you
what
,
brother
,
"
Dennis
began
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
look
up
your
friends
---
"
  
"
My
friends
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
starting
up
and
resting
on
his
hands
.
<EOS>
"
Where
are
my
friends
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
relations
then
,
"
said
Dennis
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
"
laughed
Hugh
,
waving
one
arm
above
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
talks
of
friends
to
me
---
talks
of
relations
to
a
man
whose
mother
died
the
death
in
store
for
her
son
,
and
left
him
,
a
hungry
brat
,
without
a
face
he
knew
in
all
the
world
!
 
<EOS>
He
talks
of
this
to
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Brother
,
"
cried
the
hangman
,
whose
features
underwent
a
sudden
change
,
"
you
do
n't
mean
to
say
---
"
  
"
I
mean
to
say
,
"
Hugh
interposed
,
"
that
they
hung
her
up
at
Tyburn
.
<EOS>
What
was
good
enough
for
her
,
is
good
enough
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
Let
them
do
the
like
by
me
as
soon
as
they
please
---
the
sooner
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
Say
no
more
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
going
to
sleep
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
want
to
speak
to
you
;
I
want
to
hear
more
about
that
,
"
said
Dennis
,
changing
colour
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
're
a
wise
man
,
"
growled
Hugh
,
raising
his
head
to
look
at
him
with
a
frown
,
"
you
'll
hold
your
tongue
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
I
'm
going
to
sleep
.
"
  
<EOS>
Dennis
venturing
to
say
something
more
in
spite
of
this
caution
,
the
desperate
fellow
struck
at
him
with
all
his
force
,
and
missing
him
,
lay
down
again
with
many
muttered
oaths
and
imprecations
,
and
turned
his
face
towards
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
After
two
or
three
ineffectual
twitches
at
his
dress
,
which
he
was
hardy
enough
to
venture
upon
,
notwithstanding
his
dangerous
humour
,
Mr
Dennis
,
who
burnt
,
for
reasons
of
his
own
,
to
pursue
the
conversation
,
had
no
alternative
but
to
sit
as
patiently
as
he
could
:
waiting
his
further
pleasure
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
75
    
A
month
has
elapsed
,
---
and
we
stand
in
the
bedchamber
of
Sir
John
Chester
.
 
<EOS>
Through
the
half
-
opened
window
,
the
Temple
Garden
looks
green
and
pleasant
;
the
placid
river
,
gay
with
boat
and
barge
,
and
dimpled
with
the
plash
of
many
an
oar
,
sparkles
in
the
distance
;
the
sky
is
blue
and
clear
;
and
the
summer
air
steals
gently
in
,
filling
the
room
with
perfume
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
town
,
the
smoky
town
,
is
radiant
.
 
<EOS>
High
roofs
and
steeple
-
tops
,
wo
nt
to
look
black
and
sullen
,
smile
a
cheerful
grey
;
every
old
gilded
vane
,
and
ball
,
and
cross
,
glitters
anew
in
the
bright
morning
sun
;
and
,
high
among
them
all
,
St
Paul
's
towers
up
,
showing
its
lofty
crest
in
burnished
gold
.
  
<EOS>
Sir
John
was
breakfasting
in
bed
.
 
<EOS>
His
chocolate
and
toast
stood
upon
a
little
table
at
his
elbow
;
books
and
newspapers
lay
ready
to
his
hand
,
upon
the
coverlet
;
and
,
sometimes
pausing
to
glance
with
an
air
of
tranquil
satisfaction
round
the
well
-
ordered
room
,
and
sometimes
to
gaze
indolently
at
the
summer
sky
,
he
ate
,
and
drank
,
and
read
the
news
luxuriously
.
  
<EOS>
The
cheerful
influence
of
the
morning
seemed
to
have
some
effect
,
even
upon
his
equable
temper
.
 
<EOS>
His
manner
was
unusually
gay
;
his
smile
more
placid
and
agreeable
than
usual
;
his
voice
more
clear
and
pleasant
.
 
<EOS>
He
laid
down
the
newspaper
he
had
been
reading
;
leaned
back
upon
his
pillow
with
the
air
of
one
who
resigned
himself
to
a
train
of
charming
recollections
;
and
after
a
pause
,
soliloquised
as
follows
:
  
"
And
my
friend
the
centaur
,
goes
the
way
of
his
mamma
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
surprised
.
 
<EOS>
And
his
mysterious
friend
Mr
Dennis
,
likewise
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
surprised
.
 
<EOS>
And
my
old
postman
,
the
exceedingly
free
-
and
-
easy
young
madman
of
Chigwell
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
quite
rejoiced
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
the
very
best
thing
that
could
possibly
happen
to
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
After
delivering
himself
of
these
remarks
,
he
fell
again
into
his
smiling
train
of
reflection
;
from
which
he
roused
himself
at
length
to
finish
his
chocolate
,
which
was
getting
cold
,
and
ring
the
bell
for
more
.
  
<EOS>
The
new
supply
arriving
,
he
took
the
cup
from
his
servant
's
hand
;
and
saying
,
with
a
charming
affability
,
"
I
am
obliged
to
you
,
Peak
,
"
dismissed
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
remarkable
circumstance
,
"
he
mused
,
dallying
lazily
with
the
teaspoon
,
"
that
my
friend
the
madman
should
have
been
within
an
ace
of
escaping
,
on
his
trial
;
and
it
was
a
good
stroke
of
chance
(
or
,
as
the
world
would
say
,
a
providential
occurrence
)
that
the
brother
of
my
Lord
Mayor
should
have
been
in
court
,
with
other
country
justices
,
into
whose
very
dense
heads
curiosity
had
penetrated
.
 
<EOS>
For
though
the
brother
of
my
Lord
Mayor
was
decidedly
wrong
;
and
established
his
near
relationship
to
that
amusing
person
beyond
all
doubt
,
in
stating
that
my
friend
was
sane
,
and
had
,
to
his
knowledge
,
wandered
about
the
country
with
a
vagabond
parent
,
avowing
revolutionary
and
rebellious
sentiments
;
I
am
not
the
less
obliged
to
him
for
volunteering
that
evidence
.
 
<EOS>
These
insane
creatures
make
such
very
odd
and
embarrassing
remarks
,
that
they
really
ought
to
be
hanged
for
the
comfort
of
society
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
country
justice
had
indeed
turned
the
wavering
scale
against
poor
Barnaby
,
and
solved
the
doubt
that
trembled
in
his
favour
.
<EOS>
Grip
little
thought
how
much
he
had
to
answer
for
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
will
be
a
singular
party
,
"
said
Sir
John
,
leaning
his
head
upon
his
hand
,
and
sipping
his
chocolate
;
"
a
very
curious
party
.
<EOS>
The
hangman
himself
;
the
centaur
;
and
the
madman
.
 
<EOS>
The
centaur
would
make
a
very
handsome
preparation
in
Surgeons
'
Hall
,
and
would
benefit
science
extremely
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
they
have
taken
care
to
bespeak
him
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Peak
,
I
am
not
at
home
,
of
course
,
to
anybody
but
the
hairdresser
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
reminder
to
his
servant
was
called
forth
by
a
knock
at
the
door
,
which
the
man
hastened
to
open
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
prolonged
murmur
of
question
and
answer
,
he
returned
;
and
as
he
cautiously
closed
the
room
-
door
behind
him
,
a
man
was
heard
to
cough
in
the
passage
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
it
is
of
no
use
,
Peak
,
"
said
Sir
John
,
raising
his
hand
in
deprecation
of
his
delivering
any
message
;
"
I
am
not
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
possibly
hear
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
you
I
was
not
at
home
,
and
my
word
is
sacred
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
never
do
as
you
are
desired
?
"
  
<EOS>
Having
nothing
to
oppose
to
this
reproof
,
the
man
was
about
to
withdraw
,
when
the
visitor
who
had
given
occasion
to
it
,
probably
rendered
impatient
by
delay
,
knocked
with
his
knuckles
at
the
chamber
-
door
,
and
called
out
that
he
had
urgent
business
with
Sir
John
Chester
,
which
admitted
of
no
delay
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
him
in
,
"
said
Sir
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
good
fellow
,
"
he
added
,
when
the
door
was
opened
,
"
how
come
you
to
intrude
yourself
in
this
extraordinary
manner
upon
the
privacy
of
a
gentleman
?
 
<EOS>
How
can
you
be
so
wholly
destitute
of
self
-
respect
as
to
be
guilty
of
such
remarkable
ill
-
breeding
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
business
,
Sir
John
,
is
not
of
a
common
kind
,
I
do
assure
you
,
"
returned
the
person
he
addressed
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
have
taken
any
uncommon
course
to
get
admission
to
you
,
I
hope
I
shall
be
pardoned
on
that
account
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Well
!
we
shall
see
;
we
shall
see
,
"
returned
Sir
John
,
whose
face
cleared
up
when
he
saw
who
it
was
,
and
whose
prepossessing
smile
was
now
restored
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
we
have
met
before
,
"
he
added
in
his
winning
tone
,
"
but
really
I
forget
your
name
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
Gabriel
Varden
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Varden
,
of
course
,
Varden
,
"
returned
Sir
John
,
tapping
his
forehead
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
how
very
defective
my
memory
becomes
!
 
<EOS>
Varden
to
be
sure
---
<EOS>
Mr
Varden
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
a
charming
wife
,
Mr
Varden
,
and
a
most
beautiful
daughter
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
well
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Gabriel
thanked
him
,
and
said
they
were
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
rejoice
to
hear
it
,
"
said
Sir
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
Commend
me
to
them
when
you
return
,
and
say
that
I
wished
I
were
fortunate
enough
to
convey
,
myself
,
the
salute
which
I
entrust
you
to
deliver
.
 
<EOS>
And
what
,
"
he
asked
very
sweetly
,
after
a
moment
's
pause
,
"
can
I
do
for
you
?
 
<EOS>
You
may
command
me
freely
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
,
Sir
John
,
"
said
Gabriel
,
with
some
pride
in
his
manner
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
have
come
to
ask
no
favour
of
you
,
though
I
come
on
business
.
<EOS>
---
Private
,
"
he
added
,
with
a
glance
at
the
man
who
stood
looking
on
,
"
and
very
pressing
business
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
say
you
are
the
more
welcome
for
being
independent
,
and
having
nothing
to
ask
of
me
,
"
returned
Sir
John
,
graciously
,
"
<EOS>
for
I
should
have
been
happy
to
render
you
a
service
;
still
,
you
are
welcome
on
any
terms
.
 
<EOS>
Oblige
me
with
some
more
chocolate
,
Peak
,
and
do
n't
wait
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
man
retired
,
and
left
them
alone
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
John
,
"
said
Gabriel
,
"
I
am
a
working
-
man
,
and
have
been
so
,
all
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
do
n't
prepare
you
enough
for
what
I
have
to
tell
;
if
I
come
to
the
point
too
abruptly
;
and
give
you
a
shock
,
which
a
gentleman
could
have
spared
you
,
or
at
all
events
lessened
very
much
;
I
hope
you
will
give
me
credit
for
meaning
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
to
be
careful
and
considerate
,
and
I
trust
that
in
a
straightforward
person
like
me
,
you
'll
take
the
will
for
the
deed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Varden
,
"
returned
the
other
,
perfectly
composed
under
this
exordium
;
"
I
beg
you
'll
take
a
chair
.
 
<EOS>
Chocolate
,
perhaps
,
you
do
n't
relish
?
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
it
IS
an
acquired
taste
,
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
John
,
"
said
Gabriel
,
who
had
acknowledged
with
a
bow
the
invitation
to
be
seated
,
but
had
not
availed
himself
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sir
John
"
<EOS>
---
he
dropped
his
voice
and
drew
nearer
to
the
bed
---
"
I
am
just
now
come
from
Newgate
---
"
  
"
Good
Gad
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Sir
John
,
hastily
sitting
up
in
bed
;
"
from
Newgate
,
Mr
Varden
!
 
<EOS>
How
could
you
be
so
very
imprudent
as
to
come
from
Newgate
!
 
<EOS>
Newgate
,
where
there
are
jail
-
fevers
,
and
ragged
people
,
and
bare
-
footed
men
and
women
,
and
a
thousand
horrors
!
<EOS>
Peak
,
bring
the
camphor
,
quick
!
 
<EOS>
Heaven
and
earth
,
Mr
Varden
,
my
dear
,
good
soul
<EOS>
,
how
COULD
you
come
from
Newgate
?
"
  
<EOS>
Gabriel
returned
no
answer
,
but
looked
on
in
silence
while
Peak
(
who
had
entered
with
the
hot
chocolate
)
ran
to
a
drawer
,
and
returning
with
a
bottle
,
sprinkled
his
master
's
dressing
-
gown
and
the
bedding
;
and
besides
moistening
the
locksmith
himself
,
plentifully
,
described
a
circle
round
about
him
on
the
carpet
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
done
this
,
he
again
retired
;
and
Sir
John
,
reclining
in
an
easy
attitude
upon
his
pillow
,
once
more
turned
a
smiling
face
towards
his
visitor
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
forgive
me
,
<EOS>
Mr
Varden
,
I
am
sure
,
for
being
at
first
a
little
sensitive
both
on
your
account
and
my
own
.
 
<EOS>
I
confess
<EOS>
I
was
startled
,
notwithstanding
your
delicate
exordium
.
 
<EOS>
Might
I
ask
you
to
do
me
the
favour
not
to
approach
any
nearer
?
<EOS>
---
You
have
really
come
from
Newgate
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
inclined
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
-
deed
!
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
Mr
Varden
,
all
exaggeration
and
embellishment
apart
,
"
said
Sir
John
Chester
,
confidentially
,
as
he
sipped
his
chocolate
,
"
what
kind
of
place
IS
Newgate
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
strange
place
,
Sir
John
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
,
"
of
a
sad
and
doleful
kind
.
 
<EOS>
A
strange
place
,
where
many
strange
things
are
heard
and
seen
;
but
few
more
strange
than
that
I
come
to
tell
you
of
.
<EOS>
The
case
is
urgent
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sent
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
---
<EOS>
no
,
no
---
not
from
the
jail
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Sir
John
;
from
the
jail
.
"
  
"
And
my
good
,
credulous
,
open
-
hearted
friend
,
"
said
Sir
John
,
setting
down
his
cup
,
and
laughing
,
---
"
by
whom
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
a
man
called
Dennis
---
for
many
years
the
hangman
,
and
to
-
morrow
morning
the
hanged
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
Sir
John
had
expected
---
had
been
quite
certain
from
the
first
---
that
he
would
say
he
had
come
from
Hugh
,
and
was
prepared
to
meet
him
on
that
point
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
answer
occasioned
him
a
degree
of
astonishment
,
which
,
for
the
moment
,
he
could
not
,
with
all
his
command
of
feature
,
prevent
his
face
from
expressing
.
 
<EOS>
He
quickly
subdued
it
,
however
,
and
said
in
the
same
light
tone
:
  
"
<EOS>
And
what
does
the
gentleman
require
of
me
?
 
<EOS>
My
memory
may
be
at
fault
again
,
but
I
do
n't
recollect
that
I
ever
had
the
pleasure
of
an
introduction
to
him
,
or
that
I
ever
numbered
him
among
my
personal
friends
<EOS>
,
I
do
assure
you
,
Mr
Varden
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
John
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
,
gravely
,
"
I
will
tell
you
,
as
nearly
as
I
can
,
in
the
words
he
used
to
me
,
what
he
desires
that
you
should
know
,
and
what
you
ought
to
know
without
a
moment
's
loss
of
time
.
"
  
<EOS>
Sir
John
Chester
settled
himself
in
a
position
of
greater
repose
,
and
looked
at
his
visitor
with
an
expression
of
face
which
seemed
to
say
,
"
This
is
an
amusing
fellow
!
 
<EOS>
I
'll
hear
him
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
have
seen
in
the
newspapers
,
sir
,
"
said
Gabriel
,
pointing

the
one

lay

,
"
that
I
was
a

against
this
man
upon
his
trial
some
days

;
and
that
it
was
not
his
fault
<EOS>
I
was
alive
,
and
able
to
speak
to
what
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
MAY
have
seen
!
"
cried
Sir
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mr
Varden
,
you
are
quite
a
public

,
and
live
in
all
men
's

most

.
<EOS>
Nothing
can
exceed
the
interest
with

I
read
your
testimony
,
and
remembered
that
I
had
the

with
you
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
-I
hope
we
shall
have
your
portrait
published
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
morning
,
sir
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
taking
no
notice
of
these

,
"
early
this
morning
,
a
message
was
brought
to
me
from
Newgate
,
at
this
man
's
request
,
desiring
that
I
would
go
and

,
for

.
 
<EOS>
I
need
n't

you
that
he
is
no
friend
of
mine
,
and
that
I
had
never
seen
him
,
until
the
rioters
beset

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Sir
John
fanned
himself
gently
with
the

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
knew
,
however
,
from
the

,
"
resumed

,
"
that
the
order
for
his
execution
to
-
morrow
,
went
down
to
the
prison
last
night
;
and
looking

,
I

with

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
a
Christian
,
Mr
Varden
,
"
said

John
;
"
and
in
that
amiable
capacity
,
you
increase
my

that
you
should
take

chair
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
said
,
"
continued

,
looking

knight
,
"
that
he
had
sent
to
me
,
because
he
had
no
friend
or

in
the
whole
world
(
being

common

)
,
and
because
he
believed
,
from
the

I
had
given

,
that
I
was
an
honest
man
,
and
would

by

.
 
<EOS>
He
said
that
,
being
shunned
by
every
one
who
knew
his
calling
,
even

people
of
the
lowest
and
most

,
and
finding
,
when
he
joined
the
rioters
,
that

men
he
acted
with
had
no

of
it
(
which
I
believe

true
enough
,
for
a
poor
fool
of

old
'
prentice
of
mine
was
one
of

)
,
he
had
kept
his
own
counsel
,
up
to
the

of
his
being
taken
and
put
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
discreet
of
Mr
Dennis
,
"
observed
Sir
John
with

,
though
still
with

,
"
but
---
except
for
your
admirable
and
lucid
manner
of
telling
it
,
which
is
perfect
---
not
very
interesting
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
,
"
pursued
the
locksmith
,
quite

and
wholly

of
these

,
"
when
he
was
taken
to
the
jail
,
he
found
that
his
fellow

prisoner
,
in

,
was
a

man
,
Hugh
by

,
a

,
who
had

.
 
<EOS>
From
something

fell
from
this
unhappy

in

the
angry

they
had
at

,
he
discovered
that
his
mother
had

the
death
to
which
they
both
are
now

.
<EOS>
---
The
time
is
very
short
,
Sir
John
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
knight
laid
down
his
paper
fan
,
replaced
his

upon
the
table
at
his
side
,
and
,
saving
for

smile
that
lurked
about

mouth
,
looked
at
the
locksmith
with
as
much

as
the
locksmith
looked
at
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
have
been
in
prison
now
,
a
month
.
 
<EOS>
One
conversation
led
to
many
more
;
and
the
hangman
soon
found
,
from
a
comparison
of
time
,
and
place
,
and
dates
,
that
he
had
executed
the
sentence
of
the
law
upon
this
woman
,
himself
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
been
tempted
by
want
---
as
so
many
people
are
---
into
the
easy
crime
of
passing
forged
notes
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
young
and
handsome
;
and
the
traders
who
employ
men
,
women
,
and
children
in
this
traffic
,
looked
upon
her
as
one
who
was
well
adapted
for
their
business
,
and
who
would
probably
go
on
without
suspicion
for
a
long

.
 
<EOS>
But
they
were
mistaken
;
for
she
was
stopped
in
the
commission
of
her
very
first
offence
,
and
died
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
of
gipsy
blood
,
Sir
John
---
<EOS>
"
  
It
might
have
been
the
effect
of
a
passing
cloud
which
obscured
the
sun
,
and
cast
a
shadow
on
his
face
;
but
the
knight
turned
deadly
pale
.
 
<EOS>
Still
he
met
the
locksmith
's
eye
,
as
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
was
of
gipsy
blood
,
Sir
John
,
"
repeated
Gabriel
,
"
and
had
a
high
,
free
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
and
her
good
looks
,
and
her
lofty

,
interested
some
gentlemen
who
were
easily
moved
by
dark

;
and
efforts
were
made
to
save

.
 
<EOS>
They
might
have
been

,
if
she
would
have
given

any
clue
to
her
history
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
never
would
,
or
did
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
reason
to
suspect
that
she
would
make
an
attempt
upon
her
life
.
 
<EOS>
A
watch
was
set
upon
her
night
and
day
;
and
from
that
time
she
never
spoke
again
---
"
  
Sir
John
stretched
out
his
hand
towards
his
cup
.
 
<EOS>
The
locksmith
going
on
,
arrested
it
half
-
way
.
   
<EOS>
---
"
<EOS>
Until
she
had
but
a
minute
to
live
.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
broke
silence
,
and
said
,
in
a
low

which
no
one

but
this
executioner
,
for

other

had
retired

her
to
her

,
"
If
I
had

dagger

and

,
I

strike

dead
before
me
,
even

!
"
 
<EOS>
The
man

"
Who
?
"
 
<EOS>
She

,
"
The
father

her
boy
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
Sir
John
drew

,

seeing

,
signed
to

with

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

first
word
she
had

,
from

that
she

.
 
<EOS>
"
Was

child
alive
?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
 
<EOS>
He

where

,
its

,
and
whether

had

respecting

.
 
<EOS>
She
had
<EOS>
but
one
<EOS>
,
she
said
.
<EOS>
It
was
that
the
boy
might
live
and

,
in
utter

of

father
,
so
that
no
arts
might

.
 
<EOS>
When

,
she

to
bring

father
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,
but
she

.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
says
,
she
scarcely

this
much
,
to
him
,
but
stood
with
her
face

upwards
to
the

,
and
never

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Sir
John
took

;

,

"
Nature
,
"

,

"
You
were

,
Mr

---
<EOS>
"
  
"
That
she
never
,
"
returned

locksmith
,
who
was
not

from
his

,
"
that

never

towards

once
,
Sir
John
;
and
so

,
and

forgot

.
 
<EOS>
But
,
some
years
afterwards
,
a
man
was
sentenced
to
die
the
same
death
,
who
was
a
gipsy
too
;
a

,

fellow
,
almost

;
and
while

lay
in

,
under

,
he
,
who
had
seen
the
hangman
more
than
once
while
he
was
free
,
cut
an
image
of
him
on

stick
,
by
way
of
braving
death
,
and
showing
those
who
attended

him
,
how
little
he
cared
or
thought
about

.
 
<EOS>
He
gave
this
stick
into
his
hands
at
Tyburn
,
and
told
him
then
,
that
the
woman
I
have
spoken
of
had
left
her
own
people
to
join
a
fine
gentleman
,
and
that
,
being
deserted
by
him
,
and
cast
off
by
her
old
friends
,
she
had
sworn
within

own

,
that
whatever
her
misery
might
be
,
she
would
ask
no
help
of
any

.
 
<EOS>
He
told
him
that
she
had
kept
her
word
to
the
last
;
and
that
,
meeting
even
him
in
the
streets
---
he
had
been
fond
of
her
once
<EOS>
,
it
seems
---
she
had
slipped
from
him
by
a
trick
,
and
he
never
saw
her
again
,
until
,
being
in
one
of
the
frequent

at
Tyburn
,
with

rough

,
he
had
been
driven

mad
by
seeing
,
in
the
criminal
under
another
name
,
whose
death
he
had
come
to

,
herself
.
 
<EOS>
Standing

same

in

she

,
he

this
,
and
told

,

,
her
real

,
which
only
her

,

.
 
<EOS>
That
name
he
will
tell
again
,
Sir
John
,
to
none
but

.
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
none
but
me
!
"
exclaimed

,
pausing

raising
his
cup
to
his

with

,
and
curling

little
finger
for
the
better

:
"
but
me
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
My
dear
Mr
Varden
,
how
very

,
to
select
me
