confidence
!
 
<EOS>
With
you
at
his

,

,
who
are
so
perfectly

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
John
,
Sir
John
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
,
"
at
twelve
tomorrow
,
these
men
die
.
 
<EOS>
Hear
the
few
words
I
have
to
add
,
and
do
not

deceive
me
;
for
though
I
am
a
plain
man
of
humble
station
,
and
you
are
a
gentleman
of
rank
and
learning
,
the
truth
raises
me
to
your
level
,
and
I
KNOW
that
you
anticipate
the
disclosure
with
which
I
am
about
to
end
,
and
that
you
believe
this
doomed
man
,
Hugh
,
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nay
,
"
said
Sir
John
,
bantering
him
with

;
"
the
wild
gentleman
,
who
died
so

,
scarcely
went
as
far
as
that
,
I
think
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
did
not
,
"
returned

,
"
for
she
had
bound

by
some

,
known

these

,
and
which
the
worst

them
respect
,
not
to

:
but
,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
place
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Chester
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
knight
finished
his
cup
of
chocolate
with
an
appearance
of
infinite
relish
,
and
carefully

his

upon

.
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
John
,
"
said
the
locksmith
,
"
this
is
all
that
has
been
told

me
;
but

these

men
have
been

,

conferred

.
 
<EOS>
See

,

they
can

.
<EOS>
See
this
Dennis
,
and
learn
from
him
what
he
has
not

.
<EOS>
If

,
who
hold

clue

,
want

(
which

)
,
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
to
what
,
"
said
Sir
John
Chester
,
rising
on
his
elbow
,
after
smoothing
the
pillow
for
its
reception
;
"
my
dear
,
good
-
natured
,
estimable
Mr
Varden
---
with
whom
I
can
not
be
angry
if
I
would
---
to
what
does
all
this
tend
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
take
you
for
a
man
,
Sir
John
,
and
I
suppose
it
tends
to
some
pleading
of
natural
affection
in
your
breast
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
to
the
straining
of
every
nerve
,
and
the
exertion
of
all
the
influence
you
have
,
or
can
make
,
in
behalf
of
your
miserable
son
,
and
the
man
who
has
disclosed
his
existence
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
worst
,
I
suppose
to
your
seeing
your
son
,
and
awakening
him
to
a
sense
of
his
crime
and
danger
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
no
such
sense
now
.
 
<EOS>
Think
what
his
life
must
have
been
,
when
he
said
in
my
hearing
,
that
if
I
moved
you
to
anything
,
it
would
be
to
hastening
his
death
,
and
ensuring
his
silence
,
if
you
had
it
in
your
power
!
"
  
"
And
have
you
,
my
good
Mr
Varden
,
"
said
Sir
John
in
a
tone
of
mild
reproof
,
"
have
you
really
lived
to
your
present
age
,
and
remained
so
very
simple
and
credulous
,
as
to
approach
a
gentleman
of
established
character
with
such
credentials
as
these
,
from
desperate
men
in
their
last
extremity
,
catching
at
any
straw
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
dear
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
fie
,
fie
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
locksmith
was
going
to
interpose
,
but
he
stopped
him
:
  
"
On
any
other
subject
,
Mr
Varden
,
I
shall
be
delighted
<EOS>
---
I
shall
be
charmed
---
to
converse
with
you
,
but
I
owe
it
to
my
own
character
not
to
pursue
this
topic
for
another
moment
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Think
better
of
it
,
sir
,
when
I
am
gone
,
"
returned
the
locksmith
;
"
think
better
of
it
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Although
you
have
,
thrice
within
as
many
weeks
,
turned
your
lawful
son
,
Mr
Edward
,
from
your
door
,
you
may
have
time
,
you
may
have
years
to
make
your
peace
with
HIM
,
Sir
John
:
but
that
twelve
o'clock
will
soon
be
here
,
and
soon
be
past
for
ever
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
very
much
,
"
returned
the
knight
,
kissing
his
delicate
hand
to
the
locksmith
,
"
for
your
guileless
advice
;
and
I
only
wish
,
my
good
soul
,
although
your
simplicity
is
quite
captivating
,
that
you
had
a
little
more
worldly
wisdom
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
so
much
regretted
the
arrival
of
my
hairdresser
as
I
do
at
this
moment
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
!
 
<EOS>
Good
morning
!
 
<EOS>
You
'll
not
forget
my
message
to
the
ladies
,
Mr
Varden
?
 
<EOS>
Peak
,
show
Mr
Varden
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Gabriel
said
no
more
,
but
gave
the
knight
a
parting
look
,
and
left
him
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
quitted
the
room
,
Sir
John
's
face
changed
;
and
the
smile
gave
place
to
a
haggard
and
anxious
expression
,
like
that
of
a
weary
actor
jaded
by
the
performance
of
a
difficult
part
.
 
<EOS>
He
rose
from
his
bed
with
a
heavy
sigh
,
and
wrapped
himself
in
his
morning
-
gown
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
she
kept
her
word
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
was
constant
to
her
threat
!
<EOS>
I
would
I
had
never
seen
that
dark
face
of
hers
,
---
I
might
have
read
these
consequences
in
it
,
from
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
This
affair
would
make
a
noise
abroad
,
if
it
rested
on
better
evidence
;
but
,
as
it
is
,
and
by
not
joining
the
scattered
links
of
the
chain
,
I
can
afford
to
slight
it
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Extremely
distressing
to
be
the
parent
of
such
an
uncouth
creature
!
 
<EOS>
Still
,
I
gave
him
very
good
advice
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
he
would
certainly
be
hanged
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
have
done
no
more
if
I
had
known
of
our
relationship
;
and
there
are
a
great
many
fathers
who
have
never
done
as
much
for
THEIR
natural
children
.
<EOS>
---
The
hairdresser
may
come
in
,
Peak
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
hairdresser
came
in
;
and
saw
in
Sir
John
Chester
(
whose
accommodating
conscience
was
soon
quieted
by
the
numerous
precedents
that
occurred
to
him
in
support
of
his
last
observation
)
,
the
same
imperturbable
,
fascinating
,
elegant
gentleman
he
had
seen
yesterday
,
and
many
yesterdays
before
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
76
    
<EOS>
As
the
locksmith
walked
slowly
away
from
Sir
John
Chester
's
chambers
,
he
lingered
under
the
trees
which
shaded
the
path
,
almost
hoping
that
he
might
be
summoned
to
return
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
turned
back
thrice
,
and
still
loitered
at
the
corner
,
when
the
clock
struck
twelve
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
solemn
sound
,
and
not
merely
for
its
reference
to
to
-
morrow
;
for
he
knew
that
in
that
chime
the
murderer
's
knell
was
rung
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
seen
him
pass
along
the
crowded
street
,
amidst
the
execration
of
the
throng
;
and
marked
his
quivering
lip
,
and
trembling
limbs
;
the
ashy
hue
upon
his
face
,
his
clammy
brow
,
the
wild
distraction
of
his
eye
---
the
fear
of
death
that
swallowed
up
all
other
thoughts
,
and
gnawed
without
cessation
at
his
heart
and
brain
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
marked
the
wandering
look
,
seeking
for
hope
,
and
finding
,
turn
where
it
would
,
despair
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
seen
the
remorseful
,
pitiful
,
desolate
creature
,
riding
,
with
his
coffin
by
his
side
,
to
the
gibbet
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
that
,
to
the
last
,
he
had
been
an
unyielding
,
obdurate
man
;
that
in
the
savage
terror
of
his
condition
he
had
hardened
,
rather
than
relented
,
to
his
wife
and
child
;
and
that
the
last
words
which
had
passed
his
white
lips
were
curses
on
them
as
his
enemies
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
had
determined
to
be
there
,
and
see
it
done
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
but
the
evidence
of
his
own
senses
could
satisfy
that
gloomy
thirst
for
retribution
which
had
been
gathering
upon
him
for
so
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
The
locksmith
knew
this
,
and
when
the
chimes
had
ceased
to
vibrate
,
hurried
away
to
meet
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
For
these
two
men
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
went
,
"
I
can
do
no
more
.
<EOS>
Heaven
have
mercy
on
them
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
I
say
I
can
do
no
more
for
them
,
but
whom
can
I
help
?
 
<EOS>
Mary
Rudge
will
have
a
home
,
and
a
firm
friend
when
she
most
wants
one
;
but
Barnaby
---
poor
Barnaby
<EOS>
---
willing
Barnaby
---
what
aid
can
I
render
him
?
 
<EOS>
There
are
many
,
many
men
of
sense
,
God
forgive
me
,
"
cried
the
honest
locksmith
,
stopping
in
a
narrow
count
to
pass
his
hand
across
his
eyes
,
"
I
could
better
afford
to
lose
than
Barnaby
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
always
been
good
friends
,
but
I
never
knew
,
till
now
,
how
much
I
loved
the
lad
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
were
not
many
in
the
great
city
who
thought
of
Barnaby
that
day
,
otherwise
than
as
an
actor
in
a
show
which
was
to
take
place
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
But
if
the
whole
population
had
had
him
in
their
minds
,
and
had
wished
his
life
to
be
spared
,
not
one
among
them
could
have
done
so
with
a
purer
zeal
or
greater
singleness
of
heart
than
the
good
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
was
to
die
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
hope
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
the
least
evil
attendant
upon
the
frequent
exhibition
of
this
last
dread
punishment
,
of
Death
,
that
it
hardens
the
minds
of
those
who
deal
it
out
,
and
makes
them
,
though
they
be
amiable
men
in
other
respects
,
indifferent
to
,
or
unconscious
of
,
their
great
responsibility
.
 
<EOS>
The
word
had
gone
forth
that
Barnaby
was
to
die
.
<EOS>
It
went
forth
,
every
month
,
for
lighter
crimes
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
thing
so
common
,
that
very
few
were
startled
by
the
awful
sentence
,
or
cared
to
question
its
propriety
.
 
<EOS>
Just
then
,
too
,
when
the
law
had
been
so
flagrantly
outraged
,
its
dignity
must
be
asserted
.
 
<EOS>
The
symbol
of
its
dignity
,
---
stamped
upon
every
page
of
the
criminal
statute
-
book
,
---
was
the
gallows
;
and
Barnaby
was
to
die
.
  
<EOS>
They
had
tried
to
save
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
locksmith
had
carried
petitions
and
memorials
to
the
fountain
-
head
,
with
his
own
hands
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
well
was
not
one
of
mercy
,
and
Barnaby
was
to
die
.
  
<EOS>
From
the
first
his
mother
had
never
left
him
,
save
at
night
;
and
with
her
beside
him
,
he
was
as
usual
contented
.
 
<EOS>
On
this
last
day
,
he
was
more
elated
and
more
proud
than
he
had
been
yet
;
and
when
she
dropped
the
book
she
had
been
reading
to
him
aloud
,
and
fell
upon
his
neck
,
he
stopped
in
his
busy
task
of
folding
a
piece
of
crape
about
his
hat
,
and
wondered
at
her
anguish
.
 
<EOS>
Grip
uttered
a
feeble
croak
,
half
in
encouragement
,
it
seemed
,
and
half
in
remonstrance
,
but
he
wanted
heart
to
sustain
it
,
and
lapsed
abruptly
into
silence
.
  
<EOS>
With
them
who
stood
upon
the
brink
of
the
great
gulf
which
none
can
see
beyond
,
Time
,
so
soon
to
lose
itself
in
vast
Eternity
,
rolled
on
like
a
mighty
river
,
swollen
and
rapid
as
it
nears
the
sea
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
morning
but
now
;
they
had
sat
and
talked
together
in
a
dream
;
and
here
was
evening
.
 
<EOS>
The
dreadful
hour
of
separation
,
which
even
yesterday
had
seemed
so
distant
,
was
at
hand
.
  
<EOS>
They
walked
out
into
the
courtyard
,
clinging
to
each
other
,
but
not
speaking
.
 
<EOS>
Barnaby
knew
that
the
jail
was
a
dull
,
sad
,
miserable
place
,
and
looked
forward
to
to
-
morrow
,
as
to
a
passage
from
it
to
something
bright
and
beautiful
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
vague
impression
too
,
that
he
was
expected
to
be
brave
---
that
he
was
a
man
of
great
consequence
,
and
that
the
prison
people
would
be
glad
to
make
him
weep
.
 
<EOS>
He
trod
the
ground
more
firmly
as
he
thought
of
this
,
and
bade
her
take
heart
and
cry
no
more
,
and
feel
how
steady
his
hand
was
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
call
me
silly
,
mother
.
 
<EOS>
They
shall
see
to
-
morrow
!
"
  
<EOS>
Dennis
and
Hugh
were
in
the
courtyard
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
came
forth
from
his
cell
as
they
did
,
stretching
himself
as
though
he
had
been
sleeping
.
 
<EOS>
Dennis
sat
upon
a
bench
in
a
corner
,
with
his
knees
and
chin
huddled
together
,
and
rocked
himself
to
and
fro
like
a
person
in
severe
pain
.
  
<EOS>
The
mother
and
son
remained
on
one
side
of
the
court
,
and
these
two
men
upon
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
strode
up
and
down
,
glancing
fiercely
every
now
<EOS>
and
then
at
the
bright
summer
sky
,
and
looking
round
,
when
he
had
done
so
,
at
the
walls
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
reprieve
,
no
reprieve
!
 
<EOS>
Nobody
comes
near
us
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
only
the
night
left
now
!
"
<EOS>
moaned
Dennis
faintly
,
as
he
wrung
his
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
they
'll
reprieve
me
in
the
night
,
brother
?
 
<EOS>
I
've
known
<EOS>
reprieves
come
in
the
night
,
afore
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
known
<EOS>
'em
come
as
late
as
five
,
six
,
and
seven
o'clock
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
there
's
a
good
chance
yet
,
---
do
n't
you
?
 
<EOS>
Say
you
do
.
 
<EOS>
Say
you
do
,
young
man
,
"
whined
the
miserable
creature
,
with
an
imploring
gesture
towards
Barnaby
,
"
or
I
shall
go
mad
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Better
be
mad
than
sane
,
here
,
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
GO
mad
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
tell
me
what
you
think
.
 
<EOS>
Somebody
tell
me
what
he
thinks
!
"
cried
the
wretched
object
,
---
so
mean
,
and
wretched
,
and
despicable
,
that
even
Pity
's
self
might
have
turned
away
,
at
sight
of
such
a
being
in
the

of
a
man
---
"
is
n't
there
a
chance
for
me
,
---
 
is
n't
there
a
good
chance
for
me
?
 
<EOS>
Is
n't
it
likely
they
may
be
doing
this
to
frighten
me
?
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
it
is
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
"
<EOS>
he
almost
shrieked
,
as
he
wrung
his
hands
,
"
wo
n't
anybody
give
me
comfort
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
ought
to
be
the
best
,
instead
of
the
worst
,
"
said
Hugh
,
stopping
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
 
See
the
hangman
,
when
it
comes
home
to
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
know
what
it
is
,
"
cried
Dennis
,
actually
writhing
as
he
spoke
:
"
I
do
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
should
come
to
be
worked
off
!
 
<EOS>
I
!
 
<EOS>
I
!
 
<EOS>
That
I
should
come
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
not
?
"
said
Hugh
,
as
he
thrust
back
his
matted
hair
to
get
a
better
view
of
his
late
associate
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
often
,
before
I
knew
your
trade
,
did
I
hear
you
talking
of
this
as
if
it
was
a
treat
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
an't
unconsistent
,
"
screamed
the
miserable
creature
;
"
I
'd
talk
so
again
,
if
I
was
hangman
.
 
<EOS>
Some
other
man
has
got
my
old
opinions
at
this
minute
.
 
<EOS>
That
makes
it
worse
.
 
<EOS>
Somebody
's
longing
to
work
me
off
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
by
myself
that
somebody
must
be
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
'll
soon
have
his
longing
,
"
said
Hugh
,
resuming
his
walk
.
<EOS>
"
Think
of
that
,
and
be
quiet
.
"
  
<EOS>
Although
one
of
these
men
displayed
,
in
his
speech
and
bearing
,
the
most
reckless
hardihood
;
and
the
other
,
in
his
every
word
and
action
,
testified
such
an
extreme
of
abject
cowardice
that
it
was
humiliating
to
see
him
;
it
would
be
difficult
to
say
which
of
them
would
most
have
repelled
and
shocked
an
observer
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
's
was
the
dogged
desperation
of
a
savage
at
the
stake
;
the
hangman
was
reduced
to
a
condition
little
better
,
if
any
,
than
that
of
a
hound
with
the
halter
round
his
neck
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
,
as
Mr
Dennis
knew
and
could
have
told
them
,
these
were
the
two
commonest
states
of
mind
in
persons
brought
to
their
pass
.
 
<EOS>
Such
was
the
wholesome
growth
of
the
seed
sown
by
the
law
,
that
this
kind
of
harvest
was
usually
looked
for
,
as
a
matter
of
course
.
  
<EOS>
In
one
respect
they
all
agreed
.
 
<EOS>
The
wandering
and
uncontrollable
train
of
thought
,
suggesting
sudden
recollections
of
things
distant
and
long
forgotten
and
remote
from
each
other
---
the
vague
restless
craving
for
something
undefined
,
which
nothing
could
satisfy
---
the
swift
flight
of
the
minutes
,
fusing
themselves
into
hours
,
as
if
by
enchantment
---
the
rapid
coming
of
the
solemn
night
---
the
shadow
of
death
always
upon
them
,
and
yet
so
dim
and
faint
,
that
objects
the
meanest
and
most
trivial
started
from
the
gloom
beyond
,
and
forced
themselves
upon
the
view
---
the
impossibility
of
holding
the
mind
,
even
if
they
had
been
so
disposed
,
to
penitence
and
preparation
,
or
of
keeping
it
to
any
point
while
one
hideous
fascination
tempted
it
away
---
these
things
were
common
to
them
all
,
and
varied
only
in
their
outward
tokens
.
  
<EOS>
"
Fetch
me
the
book
I
left
within
---
upon
your
bed
,
"
she
said
to
Barnaby
,
as
the
clock
struck
.
 
<EOS>
"
Kiss
me
first
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
in
her
face
,
and
saw
there
,
that
the
time
was
come
.
<EOS>
After
a
long
embrace
,
he
tore
himself
away
,
and
ran
to
bring
it
to
her
;
bidding
her
not
stir
till
he
came
back
.
 
<EOS>
He
soon
returned
,
for
a
shriek
recalled
him
,
---
but
she
was
gone
.
  
<EOS>
He
ran
to
the
yard
-
gate
,
and
looked
through
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
carrying
her
away
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
said
her
heart
would
break
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
better
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
think
,
"
whimpered
Dennis
,
creeping
up
to
him
,
as
he
stood
with
his
feet
rooted
to
the
ground
,
gazing
at
the
blank
walls
<EOS>
---
"
do
n't
you
think
there
's
still
a
chance
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
dreadful
end
;
it
's
a
terrible
end
for
a
man
like
me
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
there
's
a
chance
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mean
for
you
,
I
mean
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
HIM
hear
us
(
meaning
Hugh
)
;
"
he
's
so
desperate
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Now
then
,
"
said
the
officer
,
who
had
been
lounging
in
and
out
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
and
yawning
as
if
he
were
in
the
last
extremity
for
some
subject
of
interest
:
"
it
's
time
to
turn
in
,
boys
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
yet
,
"
cried
Dennis
,
"
not
yet
.
 
<EOS>
Not
for
an
hour
yet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
---
your
watch
goes
different
from
what
it
used
to
,
"
returned
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Once
upon
a
time
it
was
always
too
fast
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
got
the
other
fault
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
friend
,
"
cried
the
wretched
creature
,
falling
on
his
knees
,
"
my
dear
friend
<EOS>
---
you
always
were
my
dear
friend
---
there
's
some
mistake
.
<EOS>
Some
letter
has
been
mislaid
,
or
some
messenger
has
been
stopped
upon
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
He
may
have
fallen
dead
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
a
man
once
,
fall
down
dead
in
the
street
,
myself
,
and
he
had
papers
in
his
pocket
.
<EOS>
Send
to
inquire
.
 
<EOS>
Let
somebody
go
to
inquire
.
 
<EOS>
They
never
will
hang
me
.
 
<EOS>
They
never
can
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Yes
,
they
will
,
"
he
cried
,
starting
to
his
feet
with
a
terrible
scream
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
'll
hang
me
by
a
trick
,
and
keep
the
pardon
back
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
plot
against
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
lose
my
life
!
"
<EOS>
And
uttering
another
yell
,
he
fell
in
a
fit
upon
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
"
See
the
hangman
when
it
comes
home
to
him
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
again
,
as
they
bore
him
away
---
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Courage
,
bold
Barnaby
,
what
care
we
?
 
<EOS>
Your
hand
!
 
<EOS>
They
do
well
to
put
us
out
of
the
world
,
for
if
we
got
loose
a
second
time
,
we
would
n't
let
them
off
<EOS>
so
easy
,
eh
?
<EOS>
Another
shake
!
 
<EOS>
A
man
can
die
but
once
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
wake
in
the
night
,
sing
that
out
lustily
,
and
fall
asleep
again
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
<EOS>
"
  
Barnaby
glanced
once
more
through
the
grate
into
the
empty
yard
;
and
then
watched
Hugh
as
he
strode
to
the
steps
leading
to
his
sleeping
-
cell
.
 
<EOS>
He
heard
him
shout
,
and
burst
into
a
roar
of
laughter
,
and
saw
him
flourish
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
turned
away
himself
,
like
one
who
walked
in
his
sleep
;
and
,
without
any
sense
of
fear
or
sorrow
,
lay
down
on
his
pallet
,
listening
for
the
clock
to
strike
again
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
77
    
<EOS>
The
time
wore
on
.
 
<EOS>
The
noises
in
the
streets
became
less
frequent
by
degrees
,
until
silence
was
scarcely
broken
save
by
the
bells
in
church
towers
,
marking
the
progress
---
softer
and
more
stealthy
while
the
city
slumbered
---
of
that
Great
Watcher
with
the
hoary
head
,
who
never
sleeps
or
rests
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
brief
interval
of
darkness
and
repose
which
feverish
towns
enjoy
,
all
busy
sounds
were
hushed
;
and
those
who
awoke
from
dreams
lay
listening
in
their
beds
,
and
longed
for
dawn
,
and
wished
the
dead
of
the
night
were
past
.
  
<EOS>
Into
the
street
outside
the
jail
's
main
wall
,
workmen
came
straggling
at
this
solemn
hour
,
in
groups
of
two
or
three
,
and
meeting
in
the
centre
,
cast
their
tools
upon
the
ground
and
spoke
in
whispers
.
 
<EOS>
Others
soon
issued
from
the
jail
itself
,
bearing
on
their
shoulders
planks
and
beams
:
these
materials
being
all
brought
forth
,
the
rest
bestirred
themselves
,
and
the
dull
sound
of
hammers
began
to
echo
through
the
stillness
.
  
<EOS>
Here
and
there
among
this
knot
of
labourers
,
one
,
with
a
lantern
or
a
smoky
link
,
stood
by
to
light
his
fellows
at
their
work
;
and
by
its
doubtful
aid
,
some
might
be
dimly
seen
taking
up
the
pavement
of
the
road
,
while
others
held
great
upright
posts
,
or
fixed
them
in
the
holes
thus
made
for
their
reception
.
 
<EOS>
Some
dragged
slowly
on
,
towards
the
rest
,
an
empty
cart
,
which
they
brought
rumbling
from
the
prison
-
yard
;
while
others
erected
strong
barriers
across
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
All
were
busily
engaged
.
 
<EOS>
Their
dusky
figures
moving
to
and
fro
,
at
that
unusual
hour
,
so
active
and
so
silent
,
might
have
been
taken
for
those
of
shadowy
creatures
toiling
at
midnight
on
some
ghostly
unsubstantial
work
,
which
,
like
themselves
,
would
vanish
with
the
first
gleam
of
day
,
and
leave
but
morning
mist
and
vapour
.
  
<EOS>
While
it
was
yet
dark
,
a
few
lookers
-
on
collected
,
who
had
plainly
come
there
for
the
purpose
and
intended
to
remain
:
even
those
who
had
to
pass
the
spot
on
their
way
to
some
other
place
,
lingered
,
and
lingered
yet
,
as
though
the
attraction
of
that
were
irresistible
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
the
noise
of
saw
and
mallet
went
on
briskly
,
mingled
with
the
clattering
of
boards
on
the
stone
pavement
of
the
road
,
and
sometimes
with
the
workmen
's
voices
as
they
called
to
one
another
.
 
<EOS>
Whenever
the
chimes
of
the
neighbouring
church
were
heard
---
and
that
was
every
quarter
of
an
hour
---
a
strange
sensation
,
instantaneous
and
indescribable
,
but
perfectly
obvious
,
<EOS>
seemed
to
pervade
them
all
.
  
<EOS>
Gradually
,
a
faint
brightness
appeared
in
the
east
,
and
the
air
,
which
had
been
very
warm
all
through
the
night
,
felt
cool
and
chilly
.
 
<EOS>
Though
there
was
no
daylight
yet
,
the
darkness
was
diminished
,
and
the
stars
looked
pale
.
 
<EOS>
The
prison
,
which
had
been
a
mere
black
mass
with
little
shape
or
form
,
put
on
its
usual
aspect
;
and
ever
and
anon
a
solitary
watchman
could
be
seen
upon
its
roof
,
stopping
to
look
down
upon
the
preparations
in
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
This
man
,
from
forming
,
as
it
were
,
a
part
of
the
jail
,
and
knowing
or
being
supposed
to
know
all
that
was
passing
within
,
became
an
object
of
as
much
interest
,
and
was
as
eagerly
looked
for
,
and
as
awfully
pointed
out
,
as
if
he
had
been
a
spirit
.
  
<EOS>
By
and
by
,
the
feeble
light
grew
stronger
,
and
the
houses
with
their
signboards
and
inscriptions
,
stood
plainly
out
,
in
the
dull
grey
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Heavy
stage
waggons
crawled
from
the
inn
-
yard
opposite
;
and
travellers
peeped
out
;
and
as
they
rolled
sluggishly
away
,
cast
many
a
backward
look
towards
the
jail
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
the
sun
's
first
beams
came
glancing
into
the
street
;
and
the
night
's
work
,
which
,
in
its
various
stages
and
in
the
varied
fancies
of
the
lookers
-
on
had
taken
a
hundred
shapes
,
wore
its
own
proper
form
---
a
scaffold
,
and
a
gibbet
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
warmth
of
the
cheerful
day
began
to
shed
itself
upon
the
scanty
crowd
,
the
murmur
of
tongues
was
heard
,
shutters
were
thrown
open
,
and
blinds
drawn
up
,
and
those
who
had
slept
in
rooms
over
against
the
prison
,
where
places
to
see
the
execution
were
let
at
high
prices
,
rose
hastily
from
their
beds
.
 
<EOS>
In
some
of
the
houses
,
people
were
busy
taking
out
the
window
-
sashes
for
the
better
accommodation
of
spectators
;
in
others
,
the
spectators
were
already
seated
,
and
beguiling
the
time
with
cards
,
or
drink
,
or
jokes
among
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
Some
had
purchased
seats
upon
the
house
-
tops
,
and
were
already
crawling
to
their
stations
from
parapet
and
garret
-
window
.
 
<EOS>
Some
were
yet
bargaining
for
good
places
,
and
stood
in
them
in
a
state
of
indecision
:
gazing
at
the
slowly
-
swelling
crowd
,
and
at
the
workmen
as
they
rested
listlessly
against
the
scaffold
---
 
affecting
to
listen
with
indifference
to
the
proprietor
's
eulogy
of
the
commanding
view
his
house
afforded
,
and
the
surpassing
cheapness
of
his
terms
.
  
<EOS>
A
fairer
morning
never
shone
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
roofs
and
upper
stories
of
these
buildings
,
the
spires
of
city
churches
and
the
great
cathedral
dome
were
visible
,
rising
up
beyond
the
prison
,
into
the
blue
sky
,
and
clad
in
the
colour
of
light
summer
clouds
,
and
showing
in
the
clear
atmosphere
their
every
scrap
of
tracery
and
fretwork
,
and
every
niche
and
loophole
.
 
<EOS>
All
was
brightness
and
promise
,
excepting
in
the
street
below
,
into
which
(
for
it
yet
lay
in
shadow
)
<EOS>
the
eye
looked
down
as
into
a
dark
trench
,
where
,
in
the
midst
of
so
much
life
,
and
hope
,
and
renewal
of
existence
,
stood
the
terrible
instrument
of
death
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
as
if
the
very
sun
forbore
to
look
upon
it
.
  
<EOS>
But
it
was
better
,
grim
and
sombre
in
the
shade
,
than
when
,
the
day
being
more
advanced
,
it
stood
confessed
in
the
full
glare
and
glory
of
the
sun
,
with
its
black
paint
blistering
,
and
its
nooses
dangling
in
the
light
like
loathsome
garlands
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
better
in
the
solitude
and
gloom
of
midnight
with
a
few
forms
clustering
about
it
,
than
in
the
freshness
and
the
stir
of
morning
:
<EOS>
the
centre
of
an
eager
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
better
haunting
the
street
like
a
spectre
,
when
men
were
in
their
beds
,
and
influencing
perchance
the
city
's
dreams
,
than
braving
the
broad
day
,
and
thrusting
its
obscene
presence
upon
their
waking
senses
.
  
<EOS>
Five
o'clock
had
struck
---
six
---
seven
---
and
eight
.
 
<EOS>
Along
the
two
main
streets
at
either
end
of
the
cross
-
way
,
a
living
stream
had
now
set
in
,
rolling
towards
the
marts
of
gain
and
business
.
 
<EOS>
Carts
,
coaches
,
waggons
,
trucks
,
and
barrows
,
forced
a
passage
through
the
outskirts
of
the
throng
,
and
clattered
onward
in
the
same
direction
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
these
which
were
public
conveyances
and
had
come
from
a
short
distance
in
the
country
,
stopped
;
and
the
driver
pointed
to
the
gibbet
with
his
whip
,
though
he
might
have
spared
himself
the
pains
,
for
the
heads
of
all
the
passengers
were
turned
that
way
without
his
help
,
and
the
coach
-
windows
were
stuck
full
of
staring
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
In
some
of
the
carts
and
waggons
,
women
might
be
seen
,
glancing
fearfully
at
the
same
unsightly
thing
;
and
even
little
children
were
held
up
above
the
people
's
heads
to
see
what
kind
of
a
toy
a
gallows
was
,
and
learn
how
men
were
hanged
.
  
<EOS>
Two
rioters
were
to
die
before
the
prison
,
who
had
been
concerned
in
the
attack
upon
it
;
and
one
directly
afterwards
in
Bloomsbury
Square
.
 
<EOS>
At
nine
o'clock
,
a
strong
body
of
military
marched
into
the
street
,
and
formed
and
lined
a
narrow
passage
into
Holborn
,
which
had
been
indifferently
kept
all
night
by
constables
.
 
<EOS>
Through
this
,
another
cart
was
brought
(
the
one
already
mentioned
had
been
employed
in
the
construction
of
the
scaffold
)
,
and
wheeled
up
to
the
prison
-
gate
.
 
<EOS>
These
preparations
made
,
the
soldiers
stood
at
ease
;
the
officers
lounged
to
and
fro
,
in
the
alley
they
had
made
,
or
talked
together
at
the
scaffold
's
foot
;
and
the
concourse
,
which
had
been
rapidly
augmenting
for
some
hours
,
and
still
received
additions
every
minute
,
waited
with
an
impatience
which
increased
with
every
chime
of
St
Sepulchre
's
clock
,
for
twelve
at
noon
.
  
<EOS>
Up
to
this
time
they
had
been
very
quiet
,
comparatively
silent
,
save
when
the
arrival
of
some
new
party
at
a
window
,
hitherto
unoccupied
,
gave
them
something
new
to
look
at
or
to
talk
of
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
the
hour
approached
,
a
buzz
and
hum
arose
,
which
,
deepening
every
moment
,
soon
swelled
into
a
roar
,
and
seemed
to
fill
the
air
.
<EOS>
No
words
or
even
voices
could
be
distinguished
in
this
clamour
,
nor
did
they
speak
much
to
each
other
;
though
such
as
were
better
informed
upon
the
topic
than
the
rest
,
would
tell
their
neighbours
,
perhaps
,
that
they
might
know
the
hangman
when
he
came
out
,
by
his
being
the
shorter
one
:
and
that
the
man
who
was
to
suffer
with
him
was
named
Hugh
:
and
that
it
was
Barnaby
Rudge
who
would
be
hanged
in
Bloomsbury
Square
.
  
<EOS>
The
hum
grew
,
as
the
time
drew
near
,
so
loud
,
that
those
who
were
at
the
windows
could
not
hear
the
church
-
clock
strike
,
though
it
was
close
at
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
had
they
any
need
to
hear
it
,
either
,
for
they
could
see
it
in
the
people
's
faces
.
 
<EOS>
So
surely
as
another
quarter
chimed
,
there
was
a
movement
in
the
crowd
---
as
if
something
had
passed
over
it
---
as
if
the
light
upon
them
had
been
changed
---
in
which
the
fact
was
readable
as
on
a
brazen
dial
,
figured
by
a
giant
's
hand
.
  
<EOS>
Three
quarters
past
eleven
!
 
<EOS>
The
murmur
now
was
deafening
,
yet
every
man
seemed
mute
.
 
<EOS>
Look
where
you
would
among
the
crowd
,
you
saw
strained
eyes
and
lips
compressed
;
it
would
have
been
difficult
for
the
most
vigilant
observer
to
point
this
way
or
that
,
and
say
that
yonder
man
had
cried
out
.
 
<EOS>
It
were
as
easy
to
detect
the
motion
of
lips
in
a
sea
-
shell
.
  
<EOS>
Three
quarters
past
eleven
!
 
<EOS>
Many
spectators
who
had
retired
from
the
windows
,
came
back
refreshed
,
as
though
their
watch
had
just
begun
.
 
<EOS>
Those
who
had
fallen
asleep
,
roused
themselves
;
and
every
person
in
the
crowd
made
one
last
effort
to
better
his
position
---
 
which
caused
a
press
against
the
sturdy
barriers
that
made
them
bend
and
yield
like
twigs
.
 
<EOS>
The
officers
,
who
until
now
had
kept
together
,
fell
into
their
several
positions
,
and
gave
the
words
of
command
.
 
<EOS>
Swords
were
drawn
,
muskets
shouldered
,
and
the
bright
steel
winding
its
way
among
the
crowd
,
gleamed
and
glittered
in
the
sun
like
a
river
.
 
<EOS>
Along
this
shining
path
,
two
men
came
hurrying
on
,
leading
a
horse
,
which
was
speedily
harnessed
to
the
cart
at
the
prison
-
door
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
a
profound
silence
replaced
the
tumult
that
had
so
long
been
gathering
,
and
a
breathless
pause
ensued
.
 
<EOS>
Every
window
was
now
choked
up
with
heads
;
the
house
-
tops
teemed
with
people
---
clinging
to
chimneys
,
peering
over
gable
-
ends
,
and
holding
on
where
the
sudden
loosening
of
any
brick
or
stone
would
dash
them
down
into
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
The
church
tower
,
the
church
roof
,
the
church
yard
,
the
prison
leads
,
the
very
water
-
spouts
and
lampposts
---
every
inch
of
room
---
swarmed
with
human
life
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
first
stroke
of
twelve
the
prison
-
bell
began
to
toll
.
 
<EOS>
Then
the
roar
---
mingled
now
with
cries
of
"
Hats
off
!
"
and
"
Poor
fellows
!
"
<EOS>
and
,
from
some
specks
in
the
great
concourse
,
with
a
shriek
or
groan
---
burst
forth
again
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
terrible
to
see
---
if
any
one
in
that
distraction
of
excitement
could
have
seen
---
the
world
of
eager
eyes
,
all
strained
upon
the
scaffold
and
the
beam
.
  
<EOS>
The
hollow
murmuring
was
heard
within
the
jail
as
plainly
as
without
.
 
<EOS>
The
three
were
brought
forth
into
the
yard
,
together
,
as
it
resounded
through
the
air
.
 
<EOS>
They
knew
its
import
well
.
  
<EOS>
"
D'ye
hear
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Hugh
,
undaunted
by
the
sound
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
expect
us
!
<EOS>
I
heard
them
gathering
when
I
woke
in
the
night
,
and
turned
over
on
t'other
side
and
fell
asleep
again
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
see
how
they
welcome
the
hangman
,
now
that
it
comes
home
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
Ordinary
coming
up
at
this
moment
,
reproved
him
for
his
indecent
mirth
,
and
advised
him
to
alter
his
demeanour
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
why
,
master
?
"
said
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Can
I
do
better
than
bear
it
easily
?
 
<EOS>
YOU
bear
it
easily
enough
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
never
tell
me
,
"
he
cried
,
as
the
other
would
have
spoken
,
"
for
all
your
sad
look
and
your
solemn
air
,
you
think
little
enough
of
it
!
 
<EOS>
They
say
you
're
the
best
maker
of
lobster
salads
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
I
've
heard
that
,
you
see
,
before
now
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
a
good
one
<EOS>
,
this
morning
---
is
your
hand
in
?
 
<EOS>
How
does
the
breakfast
look
?
 
<EOS>
I
hope
there
's
enough
,
and
to
spare
,
for
all
this
hungry
company
that
'll
sit
down
to
it
,
when
the
sight
's
over
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
fear
,
"
observed
the
clergyman
,
shaking
his
head
,
"
that
you
are
incorrigible
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
,
"
rejoined
Hugh
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
no
hypocrite
,
master
!
 
<EOS>
You
make
a
merry
-
making
of
this
,
every
month
;
let
me
be
merry
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
want
a
frightened
fellow
there
's
one
that
'll
suit
you
.
 
<EOS>
Try
your
hand
upon
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
pointed
,
as
he
spoke
,
to
Dennis
,
who
,
with
his
legs
trailing
on
the
ground
,
was
held
between
two
men
;
and
who
trembled
so
,
that
all
his
joints
and
limbs
seemed
racked
by
spasms
.
 
<EOS>
Turning
from
this
wretched
spectacle
,
he
called
to
Barnaby
,
who
stood
apart
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
cheer
,
Barnaby
?
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
downcast
,
lad
.
 
<EOS>
Leave
that
to
HIM
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Bless
you
,
"
cried
Barnaby
,
stepping
lightly
towards
him
,
"
I
'm
not
frightened
,
Hugh
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
quite
happy
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
desire
to
live
now
,
if
they
'd
let
me
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
me
!
 
<EOS>
Am
I
afraid
to
die
?
 
<EOS>
Will
they
see
ME
tremble
?
"
  
<EOS>
Hugh
gazed
for
a
moment
at
his
face
,
on
which
there
was
a
strange
,
unearthly
smile
;
and
at
his
eye
,
which
sparkled
brightly
;
and
interposing
between
him
and
the
Ordinary
,
gruffly
whispered
to
the
latter
:
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
n't
say
much
to
him
,
master
,
if
I
was
you
.
 
<EOS>
He
may
spoil
your
appetite
for
breakfast
,
though
you
ARE
used
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
the
only
one
of
the
three
who
had
washed
or
trimmed
himself
that
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
of
the
others
had
done
so
,
since
their
doom
was
pronounced
.
 
<EOS>
He
still
wore
the
broken
peacock
's
feathers
in
his
hat
;
and
all
his
usual
scraps
of
finery
were
carefully
disposed
about
his
person
.
 
<EOS>
His
kindling
eye
,
his
firm
step
,
his
proud
and
resolute
bearing
,
might
have
graced
some
lofty
act
of
heroism
;
some
voluntary
sacrifice
,
born
of
a
noble
cause
and
pure
enthusiasm
;
rather
than
that
felon
's
death
.
  
<EOS>
But
all
these
things
increased
his
guilt
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
mere
assumptions
.
 
<EOS>
The
law
had
declared
it
so
,
and
so
it
must
be
.
 
<EOS>
The
good
minister
had
been
greatly
shocked
,
not
a
quarter
of
an
hour
before
,
at
his
parting
with
Grip
.
 
<EOS>
For
one
in
his
condition
,
to
fondle
a
bird
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
The
yard
was
filled
with
people
;
bluff
civic
functionaries
,
officers
of
justice
,
soldiers
,
the
curious
in
such
matters
,
and
guests
who
had
been
bidden
as
to
a
wedding
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
looked
about
him
,
nodded
gloomily
to
some
person
in
authority
,
who
indicated
with
his
hand
in
what
direction
he
was
to
proceed
;
and
clapping
Barnaby
on
the
shoulder
,
passed
out
with
the
gait
of
a
lion
.
  
<EOS>
They
entered
a
large
room
,
so
near
to
the
scaffold
that
the
voices
of
those
who
stood
about
it
,
could
be
plainly
heard
:
some
beseeching
the
javelin
-
men
to
take
them
out
of
the
crowd
:
others
crying
to
those
behind
,
to
stand
back
,
for
they
were
pressed
to
death
,
and
suffocating
for
want
of
air
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
middle
of
this
chamber
,
two
smiths
,
with
hammers
,
stood
beside
an
anvil
.
 
<EOS>
Hugh
walked
straight
up
to
them
,
and
set
his
foot
upon
it
with
a
sound
as
though
it
had
been
struck
by
a
heavy
weapon
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
with
folded
arms
,
he
stood
to
have
his
irons
knocked
off
:
<EOS>
scowling
haughtily
round
,
as
those
who
were
present
eyed
him
narrowly
and
whispered
to
each
other
.
  
<EOS>
It
took
so
much
time
to
drag
Dennis
in
,
that
this
ceremony
was
over
with
Hugh
,
and
nearly
over
with
Barnaby
,
before
he
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
He
no
sooner
came
into
the
place
he
knew
so
well
,
however
,
and
among
faces
with
which
he
was
so
familiar
,
than
he
recovered
strength
and
sense
enough
to
clasp
his
hands
and
make
a
last
appeal
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
good
gentlemen
,
"
cried
the
abject
creature
,
grovelling
down
upon
his
knees
,
and
actually
prostrating
himself
upon
the
stone
floor
:
"
Governor
,
dear
governor
---
honourable
sheriffs
---
worthy
gentlemen
---
have
mercy
upon
a
wretched
man
that
has
served
His
Majesty
,
and
the
Law
,
and
Parliament
,
for
so
many
years
,
and
do
n't
---
 
<EOS>
do
n't
let
me
die
---
because
of
a
mistake
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dennis
,
"
said
the
governor
of
the
jail
,
"
you
know
what
the
course
is
,
and
that
the
order
came
with
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
that
we
could
do
nothing
,
even
if
we
would
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
I
ask
,
sir
,
---
all
I
want
and
beg
,
is
time
,
to
make
it
sure
,
"
cried
the
trembling
wretch
,
looking
wildly
round
for
sympathy
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
King
and
Government
ca
n't
know
it
's
me
;
I
'm
sure
they
ca
n't
know
it
's
me
;
or
they
never
would
bring
me
to
this
dreadful
slaughterhouse
.
 
<EOS>
They
know
my
name
,
but
they
do
n't
know
it
's
the
same
man
.
 
<EOS>
Stop
my
execution
---
for
charity
's
sake
stop
my
execution
,
gentlemen
---
till
they
can
be
told
that
I
've
been
hangman
here
,
nigh
thirty
year
.
 
<EOS>
Will
no
one
go
and
tell
them
?
"
<EOS>
he
implored
,
clenching
his
hands
and
glaring
round
,
and
round
,
and
round
again
---
"
will
no
charitable
person
go
and
tell
them
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Akerman
,
"
said
a
gentleman
who
stood
by
,
after
a
moment
's
pause
,
"
since
it
may
possibly
produce
in
this
unhappy
man
a
better
frame
of
mind
,
even
at
this
last
minute
,
let
me
assure
him
that
he
was
well
known
to
have
been
the
hangman
,
when
his
sentence
was
considered
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
---
But
perhaps
they
think
on
that
account
that
the
punishment
's
not
so
great
,
"
cried
the
criminal
,
shuffling
towards
this
speaker
on
his
knees
,
and
holding
up
his
folded
hands
;
"
whereas
it
's
worse
,
it
's
worse
a
hundred
times
,
to
me
than
any
man
.
 
<EOS>
Let
them
know
that
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Let
them
know
that
.
 
<EOS>
They
've
made
it
worse
to
me
by
giving
me
so
much
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
Stop
my
execution
till
they
know
that
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
governor
beckoned
with
his
hand
,
and
the
two
men
,
who
had
supported
him
before
,
approached
.
 
<EOS>
He
uttered
a
piercing
cry
:
  
"
<EOS>
Wait
!
 
<EOS>
Wait
.
 
<EOS>
Only
a
moment
---
only
one
moment
more
!
 
<EOS>
Give
me
a
last
chance
of
reprieve
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
us
three
is
to
go
to
Bloomsbury
Square
.
<EOS>
Let
me
be
the
one
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
come
in
that
time
;
it
's
sure
to
come
.
<EOS>
In
the
Lord
's
name
let
me
be
sent
to
Bloomsbury
Square
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
hang
me
here
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
murder
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
took
him
to
the
anvil
:
but
even
then
he
could
he
heard
above
the
clinking
of
the
smiths
'
hammers
,
and
the
hoarse
raging
of
the
crowd
,
crying
that
he
knew
of
Hugh
's
birth
---
that
his
father
was
living
,
and
was
a
gentleman
of
influence
and
rank
---
that
he
had
family
secrets
in
his
possession
---
that
he
could
tell
nothing
unless
they
gave
him
time
,
but
must
die
with
them
on
his
mind
;
and
he
continued
to
rave
in
this
sort
until
his
voice
failed
him
,
and
he
sank
down
a
mere
heap
of
clothes
between
the
two
attendants
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
at
this
moment
that
the
clock
struck
the
first
stroke
of
twelve
,
and
the
bell
began
to
toll
.
 
<EOS>
The
various
officers
,
with
the
two
sheriffs
at
their
head
,
moved
towards
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
All
was
ready
when
the
last
chime
came
upon
the
ear
.
  
<EOS>
They
told
Hugh
this
,
and
asked
if
he
had
anything
to
say
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
say
!
<EOS>
"
he
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
I.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
ready
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Yes
,
"
he
added
,
as
his
eye
fell
upon
Barnaby
,
"
I
have
a
word
to
say
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
Come
hither
,
lad
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
,
for
the
moment
,
something
kind
,
and
even
tender
,
struggling
in
his
fierce
aspect
,
as
he
wrung
his
poor
companion
by
the
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
say
this
,
"
he
cried
,
looking
firmly
round
,
"
that
if
I
had
ten
lives
to
lose
,
and
the
loss
of
each
would
give
me
ten
times
the
agony
of
the
hardest
death
,
I
'd
lay
them
all
down
---
<EOS>
ay
,
I
would
,
though
you
gentlemen
may
not
believe
it
---
to
save
this
one
.
 
<EOS>
This
one
,
"
he
added
,
wringing
his
hand
again
,
"
that
will
be
lost
through
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
through
you
,
"
said
the
idiot
,
mildly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
say
that
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
not
to
blame
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
always
been
very
good
to
me
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Hugh
,
we
shall
know
what
makes
the
stars
shine
,
NOW
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
took
him
from
her
in
a
reckless
mood
,
and
did
n't
think
what
harm
would
come
of
it
,
"
said
Hugh
,
laying
his
hand
upon
his
head
,
and
speaking
in
a
lower
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ask
her
pardon
;
and
his
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Look
here
,
"
he
added
roughly
,
in
his
former
tone
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
see
this
lad
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
murmured
"
Yes
,
"
and
seemed
to
wonder
why
he
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
gentleman
yonder
---
"
pointing
to
the
clergyman
---
"
has
often
in
the
last
few
days
spoken
to
me
of
faith
,
and
strong
belief
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
what
I
am
---
more
brute
than
man
,
as
I
have
been
often
told
---
<EOS>
but
I
had
faith
enough
to
believe
,
and
did
believe
as
strongly
as
any
of
you
gentlemen
can
believe
anything
,
that
this
one
life
would
be
spared
.
 
<EOS>
See
what
he
is
!
<EOS>
---
Look
at
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
had
moved
towards
the
door
,
and
stood
beckoning
him
to
follow
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
this
was
not
faith
,
and
strong
belief
!
"
cried
Hugh
,
raising
his
right
arm
aloft
,
and
looking
upward
like
a
savage
prophet
whom
the
near
approach
of
Death
had
filled
with
inspiration
,
<EOS>
"
where
are
they
!
 
<EOS>
What
else
should
teach
me
---
me
,
born
as
I
was
born
,
and
reared
as
I
have
been
reared
---
to
hope
for
any
mercy
in
this
hardened
,
cruel
,
unrelenting
place
!
 
<EOS>
Upon
these
human
shambles
,
I
,
who
never
raised
this
hand
in
prayer
till
now
,
call
down
the
wrath
of
God
!
 
<EOS>
On
that
black
tree
,
of
which
I
am
the
ripened
fruit
,
I
do
invoke
the
curse
of
all
its
victims
,
past
,
and
present
,
and
to
come
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
head
of
that
man
,
who
,
in
his
conscience
,
owns
me
for
his
son
,
I
leave
the
wish
that
he
may
never
sicken
on
his
bed
of
down
,
but
die
a
violent
death
as
I
do
now
,
and
have
the
night
-
wind
for
his
only
mourner
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
I
say
,
Amen
,
amen
!
"
  
<EOS>
His
arm
fell
downward
by
his
side
;
he
turned
;
and
moved
towards
them
with
a
steady
step
,
the
man
he
had
been
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
more
?
"
said
the
governor
.
  
<EOS>
Hugh
motioned
Barnaby
not
to
come
near
him
(
though
without
looking
in
the
direction
where
he
stood
)
and
answered
,
"
There
is
nothing
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Move
forward
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
---
Unless
,
"
said
Hugh
,
glancing
hurriedly
back
,
---
"
unless
any
person
here
has
a
fancy
for
a
dog
;
and
not
then
,
unless
he
means
to
use
him
well
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
one
,
belongs
to
me
,
at
the
house
I
came
from
,
and
it
would
n't
be
easy
to
find
a
better
.
 
<EOS>
He
'll
whine
at
first
,
but
he
'll
soon
get
over
that
.
<EOS>
---
You
wonder
that
I
think
about
a
dog
just
now
,
he
added
,
with
a
kind
of
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
any
man
deserved
it
of
me
half
as
well
,
I
'd
think
of
HIM
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
spoke
no
more
,
but
moved
onward
in
his
place
,
with
a
careless
air
,
though
listening
at
the
same
time
to
the
Service
for
the
Dead
,
with
something
between
sullen
attention
,
and
quickened
curiosity
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
had
passed
the
door
,
his
miserable
associate
was
carried
out
;
and
the
crowd
beheld
the
rest
.
  
<EOS>
Barnaby
would
have
mounted
the
steps
at
the
same
time
---
indeed
he
would
have
gone
before
them
,
but
in
both
attempts
he
was
restrained
,
as
he
was
to
undergo
the
sentence
elsewhere
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
the
sheriffs
reappeared
,
the
same
procession
was
again
formed
,
and
they
passed
through
various
rooms
and
passages
to
another
door
---
that
at
which
the
cart
was
waiting
.
 
<EOS>
He
held
down
his
head
to
avoid
seeing
what
he
knew
his
eyes
must
otherwise
encounter
,
and
took
his
seat
sorrowfully
,
---
and
yet
with
something
of
a
childish
pride
and
pleasure
,
---
in
the
vehicle
.
 
<EOS>
The
officers
fell
into
their
places
at
the
sides
,
in
front
and
in
the
rear
;
the
sheriffs
'
carriages
rolled
on
;
a
guard
of
soldiers
surrounded
the
whole
;
and
they
moved
slowly
forward
through
the
throng
and
pressure
toward
Lord
Mansfield
's
ruined
house
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
sad
sight
---
all
the
show
,
and
strength
,
and
glitter
,
assembled
round
one
helpless
creature
---
and
sadder
yet
to
note
,
as
he
rode
along
,
how
his
wandering
thoughts
found
strange
encouragement
in
the
crowded
windows
and
the
concourse
in
the
streets
;
and
how
,
even
then
,
he
felt
the
influence
of
the
bright
sky
,
and
looked
up
,
smiling
,
into
its
deep
unfathomable
blue
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
had
been
many
such
sights
since
the
riots
were
over
---
<EOS>
some
so
moving
in
their
nature
,
and
so
repulsive
too
,
that
they
were
far
more
calculated
to
awaken
pity
for
the
sufferers
,
than
respect
for
that
law
whose
strong
arm
seemed
in
more
than
one
case
to
be
as
wantonly
stretched
forth
now
that
all
was
safe
,
as
it
had
been
basely
paralysed
in
time
of
danger
.
  
<EOS>
Two
cripples
---
both
mere
boys
---
one
with
a
leg
of
wood
,
one
who
dragged
his
twisted
limbs
along
by
the
help
of
a
crutch
,
were
hanged
in
this
same
Bloomsbury
Square
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
cart
was
about
to
glide
from
under
them
,
it
was
observed
that
they
stood
with
their
faces
from
,
not
to
,
the
house
they
had
assisted
to
despoil
;
and
<EOS>
their
misery
was
protracted
that
this
omission
might
be
remedied
.
<EOS>
Another
boy
was
hanged
in
Bow
Street
;
other
young
lads
in
various
quarters
of
the
town
.
 
<EOS>
Four
wretched
women
,
too
,
were
put
to
death
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
those
who
suffered
as
rioters
were
,
for
the
most
part
,
the
weakest
,
meanest
,
and
most
miserable
among
them
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
most
exquisite
satire
upon
the
false
religious
cry
which
had
led
to
so
much
misery
,
that
some
of
these
people
owned
themselves
to
be
Catholics
,
and
begged
to
be
attended
by
their
own
priests
.
  
<EOS>
One
young
man
was
hanged
in
Bishopsgate
Street
,
whose
aged
grey
-
headed
father
waited
for
him
at
the
gallows
,
kissed
him
at
its
foot
when
he
arrived
,
and
sat
there
,
on
the
ground
,
till
they
took
him
down
.
 
<EOS>
They
would
have
given
him
the
body
of
his
child
;
but
he
had
no
hearse
,
no
coffin
,
nothing
to
remove
it
in
,
being
too
poor
---
and
walked
meekly
away
beside
the
cart
that
took
it
back
to
prison
,
trying
,
as
he
went
,
to
touch
its
lifeless
hand
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
crowd
had
forgotten
these
matters
,
or
cared
little
about
them
if
they
lived
in
their
memory
:
<EOS>
and
while
one
great
multitude
fought
and
hustled
to
get
near
the
gibbet
before
Newgate
,
for
a
parting
look
,
another
followed
in
the
train
of
poor
lost
Barnaby
,
to
swell
the
throng
that
waited
for
him
on
the
spot
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
78
    
<EOS>
On
this
same
day
,
and
about
this
very
hour
,
Mr
Willet
the
elder
sat
smoking
his
pipe
in
a
chamber
at
the
Black
Lion
.
 
<EOS>
Although
it
was
hot
summer
weather
,
Mr
Willet
sat
close
to
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
in
a
state
of
profound
cogitation
,
with
his
own
thoughts
,
and
it
was
his
custom
at
such
times
to
stew
himself
slowly
,
under
the
impression
that
that
process
of
cookery
was
favourable
to
the
melting
out
of
his
ideas
,
which
,
when
he
began
to
simmer
,
sometimes
oozed
forth
so
copiously
as
to
astonish
even
himself
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
had
been
several
thousand
times
comforted
by
his
friends
and
acquaintance
,
with
the
assurance
that
for
the
loss
he
had
sustained
in
the
damage
done
to
the
Maypole
,
he
could
"
come
upon
the
county
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
as
this
phrase
happened
to
bear
an
unfortunate
resemblance
to
the
popular
expression
of
"
coming
on
the
parish
,
"
it
suggested
to
Mr
Willet
's
mind
no
more
consolatory
visions
than
pauperism
on
an
extensive
scale
,
and
ruin
in
a
capacious
aspect
.
<EOS>
Consequently
,
he
had
never
failed
to
receive
the
intelligence
with
a
rueful
shake
of
the
head
,
or
a
dreary
stare
,
and
had
been
always
observed
to
appear
much
more
melancholy
after
a
visit
of
condolence
than
at
any
other
time
in
the
whole
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
.
  
<EOS>
It
chanced
,
however
,
that
sitting
over
the
fire
on
this
particular
occasion
---
perhaps
because
he
was
,
as
it
were
,
done
to
a
turn
;
perhaps
because
he
was
in
an
unusually
bright
state
of
mind
;
perhaps
because
he
had
considered
the
subject
so
long
;
perhaps
because
of
all
these
favouring
circumstances
,
taken
together
---
it
chanced
that
,
sitting
over
the
fire
on
this
particular
occasion
,
Mr
Willet
did
,
afar
off
and
in
the
remotest
depths
of
his
intellect
,
perceive
a
kind
of
lurking
hint
or
faint
suggestion
,
that
out
of
the
public
purse
there
might
issue
funds
for
the
restoration
of
the
Maypole
to
its
former
high
place
among
the
taverns
of
the
earth
.
<EOS>
And
this
dim
ray
of
light
did
so
diffuse
itself
within
him
,
and
did
so
kindle
up
and
shine
,
that
at
last
he
had
it
as
plainly
and
visibly
before
him
as
the
blaze
by
which
he
sat
;
and
,
fully
persuaded
that
he
was
the
first
to
make
the
discovery
,
and
that
he
had
started
,
hunted
down
,
fallen
upon
,
and
knocked
on
the
head
,
a
perfectly
original
idea
which
had
never
presented
itself
to
any
other
man
,
alive
or
dead
,
he
laid
down
his
pipe
,
rubbed
his
hands
,
and
chuckled
audibly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
father
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Joe
,
entering
at
the
moment
<EOS>
,
"
you
're
in
spirits
to
-
day
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
nothing
partickler
,
"
said
Mr
Willet
,
chuckling
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
nothing
at
all
partickler
,
Joseph
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
something
about
the
Salwanners
.
"
 
<EOS>
Having
preferred
this
request
,
Mr
Willet
chuckled
a
third
time
,
and
after
these
unusual
demonstrations
of
levity
,
he
put
his
pipe
in
his
mouth
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
shall
I
tell
you
,
father
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Joe
,
laying
his
hand
upon
his
sire
's
shoulder
,
and
looking
down
into
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
I
have
come
back
,
poorer
than
a
church
mouse
?
 
<EOS>
You
know
that
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
have
come
back
,
maimed
and
crippled
?
 
<EOS>
You
know
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
took
off
,
"
muttered
Mr
Willet
,
with
his
eyes
upon
the
fire
,
"
at
the
defence
of
the
Salwanners
,
in
America
,
where
the
war
is
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
right
,
"
returned
Joe
,
smiling
,
and
leaning
with
his
remaining
elbow
on
the
back
of
his
father
's
chair
;
"
the
very
subject
I
came
to
speak
to
you
about
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
with
one
arm
,
father
,
is
not
of
much
use
in
the
busy
world
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
one
of
those
vast
propositions
which
Mr
Willet
had
never
considered
for
an
instant
,
and
required
time
to
"
tackle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wherefore
he
made
no
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
all
events
,
"
said
Joe
,
"
he
ca
n't
pick
and
choose
his
means
of
earning
a
livelihood
,
as
another
man
may
.
 
<EOS>
He
ca
n't
say
"
I
will
turn
my
hand
to
this
,
"
or
"
I
wo
n't
turn
my
hand
to
that
,
"
but
must
take
what
he
can
do
,
and
be
thankful
<EOS>
it
's
no
worse
.
<EOS>
---
What
did
you
say
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
had
been
softly
repeating
to
himself
,
in
a
musing
tone
,
the
words
"
defence
of
the
Salwanners
:
"
but
he
seemed
embarrassed
at
having
been
overheard
,
and
answered
"
Nothing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
look
here
,
father
.
---
<EOS>
Mr
Edward
has
come
to
England
from
the
West
Indies
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
was
lost
sight
of
(
I
ran
away
on
the
same
day
,
father
)
,
he
made
a
voyage
to
one
of
the
islands
,
where
a
school
-
friend
of
his
had
settled
;
and
,
finding
him
,
was
n't
too
proud
to
be
employed
on
his
estate
,
and
---
and
in
short
,
got
on
well
,
and
is
prospering
,
and
has
come
over
here
on
business
of
his
own
,
and
is
going
back
again
speedily
.
 
<EOS>
Our
returning
nearly
at
the
same
time
,
and
meeting
in
the
course
of
the
late
troubles
,
has
been
a
good
thing
every
way
;
for
it
has
not
only
enabled
us
to
do
old
friends
some
service
,
but
has
opened
a
path
in
life
for
me
which
I
may
tread
without
being
a
burden
upon
you
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
plain
,
father
,
he
can
employ
me
;
I
have
satisfied
myself
that
I
can
be
of
real
use
to
him
;
and
I
am
going
to
carry
my
one
arm
away
with
him
,
and
to
make
the
most
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
mind
's
eye
of
Mr
Willet
,
the
West
Indies
,
and
indeed
all
foreign
countries
,
were
inhabited
by
savage
nations
,
who
were
perpetually
burying
pipes
of
peace
,
flourishing
tomahawks
,
and
puncturing
strange
patterns
in
their
bodies
.
 
<EOS>
He
no
sooner
heard
this
announcement
,
therefore
,
than
he
leaned
back
in
his
chair
,
took
his
pipe
from
his
lips
,
and
stared
at
his
son
with
as
much
dismay
as
if
he
already
beheld
him
tied
to
a
stake
,
and
tortured
for
the
entertainment
of
a
lively
population
.
 
<EOS>
In
what
form
of
expression
his
feelings
would
have
found
a
vent
,
it
is
impossible
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
is
it
necessary
:
for
,
before
a
syllable
occurred
to
him
,
<EOS>
Dolly
Varden
came
running
into
the
room
,
in
tears
,
threw
herself
on
Joe
's
breast
without
a
word
of
explanation
,
and
clasped
her
white
arms
round
his
neck
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dolly
!
"
cried
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dolly
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
call
me
that
;
call
me
that
always
,
"
exclaimed
the
locksmith
's
little
daughter
;
"
never
speak
coldly
to
me
,
never
be
distant
,
never
again
reprove
me
for
the
follies
I
have
long
repented
,
or
I
shall
die
,
Joe
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
reprove
you
!
"
said
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
---
for
every
kind
and
honest
word
you
uttered
,
went
to
my
heart
.
<EOS>
For
you
,
who
have
borne
so
much
from
me
---
for
you
,
who
owe
your
sufferings
and
pain
to
my
caprice
---
for
you
to
be
so
kind
---
so
noble
to
me
,
Joe
---
"
  
He
could
say
nothing
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
syllable
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
odd
sort
of
eloquence
in
his
one
arm
,
which
had
crept
round
her
waist
:
but
his
lips
were
mute
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
reminded
me
by
a
word
---
only
by
one
short
word
,
"
sobbed
Dolly
,
clinging
yet
closer
to
him
,
"
how
little
I
deserved
that
you
should
treat
me
with
so
much

;
if
you
had
exulted
only
for
one
moment
in
your
triumph
,
I
could
have
borne
it
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Triumph
!
"
repeated
Joe
,
with
a
smile
which
seemed
to
say
,
"
I
am
a
pretty
figure
for
that
.
"
  
"
Yes
,
triumph
,
"
she
cried
,
with
her
whole

and
soul
in
her
earnest
voice
,
and
gushing

;
"
for
it
is
one
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
to
think
and
know
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
be
less
humbled
,
dear
<EOS>
---
I
would
n't
be
without
the
recollection

that

spoke
together
in
this
place
---
<EOS>
no
,
not
if
I
could
recall
the
past
,
and
make
our
parting
,
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
  
Did
ever
lover
look
as
Joe
looked
now
!
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Joe
,
"
said
Dolly
,
"
I
always
loved
you
---
<EOS>
in
my
own
heart
I
always
did
,
although
I
was
so

and

.
 
<EOS>
I
hoped
you
would
come
back
that

.
 
<EOS>
I
made
quite

you
would
.
 
<EOS>
I
prayed
for

on

.
 
<EOS>
Through
all
these
long
,
long
years
,
I
have
never
once
forgotten
you
,
or
left
off
hoping
that
this
happy
time
might
come
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
eloquence
of
Joe
's
arm
surpassed
the
most
impassioned
language
;
and
so
did
that
of
his
lips
---
yet
he
said
nothing
,
either
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
at
last
,
"
cried
Dolly
,
trembling

the

her

,
"
if
you
were
sick
,
and
shattered
in
your
every

;
if
you
were

,
weak
,
and

;
if
,

you

,
you
were
in
everybody
's
eyes
but
mine
the
wreck

of

man
;
I
would

your
wife
,
dear
love
,
with
greater

,

if

were
the
stateliest

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
have
I
done
,
"
cried
Joe
,
"
what
have
I
done
to
meet
with
this

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
taught
me
,
"
said
Dolly
,
raising
her
pretty
face
to
his
,
"
to
know
myself
,
and
your
worth
;
to
be
something
better
than
I
was
;
to
be
more

of
your
true
and

.
 
<EOS>
In
years
to
come
,
dear
Joe
,
you
shall
find
that
you
have
done
so
;
for
I
will
be
,
not
only
now
,
when
we
are
young
and
full
of
hope
,
but
when
we
have
grown
old
and

,
your
patient
,
gentle
,
never
-

wife
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
never
know
a
wish
or

beyond
our
home
and
you
,
and
I
will
always
study
how
to
please
you
with
my
best

and
my
most
devoted
love
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
:
indeed
I
will
!
"
  
<EOS>
Joe
could
only
repeat
his
former
eloquence
---
but
it
was
very
much
to
the
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
know
of
this
,
at
home
,
"
said
Dolly
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
your
sake
,
I
would
leave
even
them
;
but
they
know
it
,
and
are
glad

it
,
and
are
as

as
I

,
and

.
<EOS>
---
You
'll
not
come
and
see
me
as
a
poor
friend
who
knew
me
when
I
was
a
girl
,
will
you
,
dear
Joe
?
"
  
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
 
<EOS>
It
do
n't
matter
what
Joe
said
in
answer
,
but
he
said
a
great
deal
;
and
Dolly
said
a
great
deal
too
:
and
he
folded
Dolly
in
his
one
arm
pretty
tight
,
considering
that
it
was
but
one
;
and
Dolly
made
no
resistance
:
and
if
ever
two
people
were
happy
in
this
world
---
which
is
not
an
utterly
miserable
one
,
with
all
its
faults
---
 
we
may
,
with
some
appearance
of
certainty
,
conclude
that
they
were
.
  
<EOS>
To
say
that
during
these
proceedings
Mr
Willet
the
elder
underwent
the
greatest
emotions
of
astonishment
of
which
our
common
nature
is
susceptible
---
to
say
that
he
was
in
a
perfect
paralysis
of
surprise
,
and
that
he
wandered
into
the
most
stupendous
and
theretofore
unattainable
heights
of
complicated
amazement
---
would
be
to
shadow
forth
his
state
of
mind
in
the
feeblest
and
lamest
terms
.
 
<EOS>
If
a
roc
,
an
eagle
,
a
griffin
,
a
flying
elephant
,
a
winged
sea
-
horse
,
had
suddenly
appeared
,
and
,
taking
him
on
its
back
,
carried
him
bodily
into
the
heart
of
the
"
Salwanners
,
"
it
would
have
been
to
him
as
an
everyday
occurrence
,
in
comparison
with
what
he
now
beheld
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
sitting
quietly
by
,
seeing
and
hearing
these
things
;
to
be
completely
overlooked
,
unnoticed
,
and
disregarded
,
while
his
son
and
a
young
lady
were
talking
to
each
other
in
the
most
impassioned
manner
,
kissing
each
other
,
and
making
themselves
in
all
respects
perfectly
at
home
;
was
a
position
so
tremendous
,
so
inexplicable
,
so
utterly
beyond
the
widest
range
of
his
capacity
of
comprehension
,
that
he
fell
into
a
lethargy
of
wonder
,
and
could
no
more
rouse
himself
than
an
enchanted
sleeper
in
the
first
year
of
his
fairy
lease
,
a
century
long
.
  
<EOS>
"
Father
,
"
said
Joe
,
presenting
Dolly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
who
this
is
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
looked
first
at
her
,
then
at
his
son
,
then
back
again
at
Dolly
,
and
then
made
an
ineffectual
effort
to
extract
a
whiff
from
his
pipe
,
which
had
gone
out
long
ago
.
  
<EOS>
"
Say
a
word
,
father
,
if
it
's
only
"
how
d'ye
do
,
"
"
urged
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
Joseph
,
"
answered
Mr
Willet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
!
 
<EOS>
Why
not
?
"
  
"
To
be
sure
,
"
said
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
replied
his
father
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
<EOS>
and
with
this
remark
,
which
he
uttered
in
a
low
voice
as
though
he
were
discussing
some
grave
question
with
himself
,
he
used
the
little
finger
---
if
any

his

can
be
said
to
have
come
under
that
denomination
---
of
his
right
hand
as
a
tobacco
-

,
and
was
silent
again
.
  
<EOS>
And
so
he
sat
for
half
an
hour
at
least
,
although
Dolly
,
in
the
most
endearing
of
manners
,
hoped
,
a
dozen
times
,
that
he
was
not
angry
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
sat
for
half
an
hour
,
quite
motionless
,
and
looking
all
the
while
<EOS>
like
nothing
so
much
as
a
great
Dutch
Pin
or
Skittle
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
expiration
of
that
period
,
he
suddenly
,
and
without
the
least
notice
,
burst
(
to
the
great

of
the
young
people
)
into
a
very
loud
and
very
short
