;
and
repeating
,
"
Certainly
,
Joseph
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
yes
!
 
<EOS>
Why
not
?
"
went
out
for
a
walk
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
79
    
Old
John
did
not
walk
near
the
Golden
Key
,
for
between
the
Golden
Key
and
the
Black
Lion
there
lay
a
wilderness
of
streets
---
as
everybody
knows
who
is
acquainted
with
the
relative
bearings
of
Clerkenwell
and
Whitechapel
---
and
he
was
by
no
means
famous
for
pedestrian
exercises
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
Golden
Key
lies
in
our
way
,
though
it
was
out
of
his
;
so
to
the
Golden
Key
this
chapter
goes
.
  
<EOS>
The
Golden
Key
itself
,
fair
emblem
of
the
locksmith
's
trade
,
had
been
pulled
down
by
the
rioters
,
and
roughly
trampled
under
foot
.
<EOS>
But
,
now
,
it
was
hoisted
up
again
in
all
the
glory
of
a
new
coat
of
paint
,
and
shewed
more
bravely
even
than
in
days
of
yore
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
the
whole
house
-
front
was
spruce
and
trim
,
and
so
freshened
up
throughout
,
that
if
there
yet
remained
at
large
any
of
the
rioters
who
had
been
concerned
in
the
attack
upon
it
,
the
sight
of
the
old
,
goodly
,
prosperous
dwelling
,
so
revived
,
must
have
been
to
them
as
gall
and
wormwood
.
  
<EOS>
The
shutters
of
the
shop
were
closed
,
however
,
and
the
window
-
blinds
above
were
all
pulled
down
,
and
in
place
of
its
usual
cheerful
appearance
,
the
house
had
a
look
of
sadness
and
an
air
of
mourning
;
which
the
neighbours
,
who
in
old
days
had
often
seen
poor
Barnaby
go
in
and
out
,
were
at
no
loss
to
understand
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
stood
partly
open
;
but
the
locksmith
's
hammer
was
unheard
;
the
cat
sat
moping
on
the
ashy
forge
;
all
was
deserted
,
dark
,
and
silent
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
threshold
of
this
door
,
Mr
Haredale
and
Edward
Chester
met
.
<EOS>
The
younger
man
gave
place
;
and
both
passing
in
with
a
familiar
air
,
which
seemed
to
denote
that
they
were
tarrying
there
,
or
were
well
-
accustomed
to
go
to
and
fro
unquestioned
,
shut
it
behind
them
.
  
<EOS>
Entering
the
old
back
-
parlour
,
and
ascending
the
flight
of
stairs
,
abrupt
and
steep
,
and
quaintly
fashioned
as
of
old
,
they
turned
into
the
best
room
;
the
pride
of
Mrs
Varden
's
heart
,
and
erst
the
scene
of
Miggs
's
household
labours
.
  
<EOS>
"
Varden
brought
the
mother
here
last
evening
,
he
told
me
?
"
said
Mr
Haredale
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
above
-
stairs
now
---
in
the
room
over
here
,
"
Edward
rejoined
.
"
<EOS>
Her
grief
,
they
say
,
is
past
all
telling
.
 
<EOS>
I
need
n't
add
---
for
that
you
know
beforehand
,
sir
---
that
the
care
,
humanity
,
and
sympathy
of
these
good
people
have
no
bounds
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
Heaven
repay
them
for
it
,
and
for
much
more
!
<EOS>
Varden
is
out
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
returned
with
your
messenger
,
who
arrived
almost
at
the
moment
of
his
coming
home
himself
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
out
the
whole
night
---
but
that
of
course
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
with
you
the
greater
part
of
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
was
.
 
<EOS>
Without
him
,
I
should
have
lacked
my
right
hand
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
an
older
man
than
I
;
but
nothing
can
conquer
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
cheeriest
,
stoutest
-
hearted
fellow
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
a
right
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
right
to
he
.
 
<EOS>
A
better
creature
never
lived
.
 
<EOS>
He
reaps
what
he
has
sown
---
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
all
men
,
"
said
Edward
,
after
a
moment
's
hesitation
,
"
who
have
the
happiness
to
do
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
More
than
you
imagine
,
"
returned
Mr
Haredale
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
note
the
harvest
more
than
the
seed
-
time
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
so
in
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
truth
his
pale
and
haggard
face
,
and
gloomy
bearing
,
had
so
far
influenced
the
remark
,
that
Edward
was
,
for
the
moment
,
at
a
loss
to
answer
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Tut
,
tut
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
'
<EOS>
twas
not
very
difficult
to
read
a
thought
so
natural
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
are
mistaken
nevertheless
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
had
my
share
of
sorrows
---
more
than
the
common
lot
,
perhaps
,
but
I
have
borne
them
ill
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
broken
where
I
should
have
bent
;
and
have
mused
and
brooded
,
when
my
spirit
should
have
mixed
with
all
God
's
great
creation
.
 
<EOS>
The
men
who
learn
endurance
,
are
they
who
call
the
whole
world
,
brother
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
turned
FROM
the
world
,
and
I
pay
the
penalty
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Edward
would
have
interposed
,
but
he
went
on
without
giving
him
time
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
too
late
to
evade
it
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
sometimes
think
,
that
if
I
had
to
live
my
life
once
more
,
I
might
amend
this
fault
---
not
so
much
,
I
discover
when
I
search
my
mind
,
for
the
love
of
what
is
right
,
as
for
my
own
sake
.
 
<EOS>
But
even
when
I
make
these
better
resolutions
,
I
instinctively
recoil
from
the
idea
of
suffering
again
what
I
have
undergone
;
and
in
this
circumstance
I
find
the
unwelcome
assurance
that
I
should
still
be
the
same
man
,
though
I
could
cancel
the
past
,
and
begin
anew
,
with
its
experience
to
guide
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
you
make
too
sure
of
that
,
"
said
Edward
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
think
so
,
"
Mr
Haredale
answered
,
"
and
I
am
glad
you
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
myself
better
,
and
therefore
distrust
myself
more
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
leave
this
subject
for
another
---
not
so
far
removed
from
it
as
it
might
,
at
first
sight
,
seem
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
,
you
still
love
my
niece
,
and
she
is
still
attached
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
that
assurance
from
her
own
lips
,
"
said
Edward
,
"
and
you
know
---
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
know
---
that
I
would
not
exchange
it
for
any
blessing
life
could
yield
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
frank
,
honourable
,
and
disinterested
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
;
"
you
have
forced
the
conviction
that
you
are
so
,
even
on
my
once
-
jaundiced
mind
,
and
I
believe
you
.
 
<EOS>
Wait
here
till
I
come
back
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
left
the
room
as
he
spoke
;
but
soon
returned
with
his
niece
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On
that
first
and
only
time
,
"
he
said
,
looking
from
the
one
to
the
other
,
"
when
we
three
stood
together
under
her
father
's
roof
,
I
told
you
to
quit
it
,
and
charged
you
never
to
return
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
only
circumstance
arising
out
of
our
love
,
"
observed
Edward
,
"
that
I
have
forgotten
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
own
a
name
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
I
had
deep
reason
to
remember
.
<EOS>
I
was
moved
and
goaded
by
recollections
of
personal
wrong
and
injury
,
I
know
,
but
,
even
now
I
can
not
charge
myself
with
having
,
then
,
or
ever
,
lost
sight
of
a
heartfelt
desire
for
her
true
happiness
;
or
with
having
acted
---
however
much
I
was
mistaken
---
with
any
other
impulse
than
the
one
pure
,
single
,
earnest
wish
to
be
to
her
,
as
far
as
in
my
inferior
nature
lay
,
the
father
she
had
lost
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Dear
uncle
,
"
cried
Emma
,
"
I
have
known
no
parent
but
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
loved
the
memory
of
others
,
but
I
have
loved
you
all
my
life
.
<EOS>
Never
was
father
kinder
to
his
child
than
you
have
been
to
me
,
without
the
interval
of
one
harsh
hour
,
since
I
can
first
remember
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
speak
too
fondly
,
"
he
answered
,
"
<EOS>
and
yet
I
can
not
wish
you
were
less
partial
;
for
I
have
a
pleasure
in
hearing
those
words
,
and
shall
have
in
calling
them
to
mind
when
we
are
far
asunder
,
which
nothing
else
could
give
me
.
 
<EOS>
Bear
with
me
for
a
moment
longer
,
Edward
,
for
she
and
I
have
been
together
many
years
;
and
although
I
believe
that
in
resigning
her
to
you
I
put
the
seal
upon
her
future
happiness
,
I
find
it
needs
an
effort
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
pressed
her
tenderly
to
his
bosom
,
and
after
a
minute
's
pause
,
resumed
:
  
"
I
have
done
you
wrong
,
sir
,
and
I
ask
your
forgiveness
---
in
no
common
phrase
,
or
show
of
sorrow
;
but
with
earnestness
and
sincerity
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
same
spirit
,
I
acknowledge
to
you
both
that
the
time
has
been
when
I
connived
at
treachery
and
falsehood
---
which
if
I
did
not
perpetrate
myself
,
I
still
permitted
---
to
rend
you
two
asunder
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
judge
yourself
too
harshly
,
"
said
Edward
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
these
things
rest
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
rise
in
judgment
against
me
when
I
look
back
,
and
not
now
for
the
first
time
,
"
he
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
part
from
you
without
your
full
forgiveness
;
for
busy
life
<EOS>
and
I
have
little
left
in
common
now
,
and
I
have
regrets
enough
to
carry
into
solitude
,
without
addition
to
the
stock
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
bear
a
blessing
from
us
both
,
"
said
Emma
.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
mingle
thoughts
of
me
---
of
me
who
owe
you
so
much
love
and
duty
---
with
anything
but
undying
affection
and
gratitude
for
the
past
,
and
bright
hopes
for
the
future
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
future
,
"
returned
her
uncle
,
with
a
melancholy
smile
,
"
is
a
bright
word
for
you
,
and
its
image
should
be
wreathed
with
cheerful
hopes
.
 
<EOS>
Mine
is
of
another
kind
,
but
it
will
be
one
of
peace
,
and
free
,
I
trust
,
from
care
or
passion
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
quit
England
I
shall
leave
it
too
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
cloisters
abroad
;
and
now
that
the
two
great
objects
of
my
life
are
set
at
rest
,
I
know
no
better
home
.
 
<EOS>
You
droop
at
that
,
forgetting
that
I
am
growing
old
,
and
that
my
course
is
nearly
run
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
we
will
speak
of
it
again
---
 
not
once
or
twice
,
but
many
times
;
and
you
shall
give
me
cheerful
counsel
,
Emma
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
will
take
it
?
"
asked
his
niece
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
listen
to
it
,
"
he
answered
,
with
a
kiss
,
"
and
it
will
have
its
weight
,
be
certain
.
 
<EOS>
What
have
I
left
to
say
?
 
<EOS>
You
have
,
of
late
,
been
much
together
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
better
and
more
fitting
that
the
circumstances
attendant
on
the
past
,
which
wrought
your
separation
,
and
sowed
between
you
suspicion
and
distrust
,
should
not
be
entered
on
by
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Much
,
much
better
,
"
whispered
Emma
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
avow
my
share
in
them
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
though
I
held
it
,
at
the
time
,
in
detestation
.
 
<EOS>
Let
no
man
turn
aside
,
ever
so
slightly
,
from
the
broad
path
of
honour
,
on
the
plausible
pretence
that
he
is
justified
by
the
goodness
of
his
end
.
 
<EOS>
All
good
ends
<EOS>
can
he
worked
out
by
good
means
.
 
<EOS>
Those
that
can
not
,
are
bad
;
and
may
be
counted
so
at
once
,
and
left
alone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
from
her
to
Edward
,
and
said
in
a
gentler
tone
:
  
"
<EOS>
In
goods
and
fortune
you
are
now
nearly
equal
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
her
faithful
steward
,
and
to
that
remnant
of
a
richer
property
which
my
brother
left
her
,
I
desire
to
add
,
in
token
of
my
love
,
a
poor
pittance
,
scarcely
worth
the
mention
,
for
which
I
have
no
longer
any
need
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
you
go
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
Let
our
ill
-
fated
house
remain
the
ruin
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
return
,
after
a
few
thriving
years
,
you
will
command
a
better
,
and
a
more
fortunate
one
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
friends
?
"
  
<EOS>
Edward
took
his
extended
hand
,
and
grasped
it
heartily
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
neither
slow
nor
cold
in
your
response
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
doing
the
like
by
him
,
"
and
when
I
look
upon
you
now
,
and
know
you
,
I
feel
that
I
would
choose
you
for
her
husband
.
 
<EOS>
Her
father
had
a
generous
nature
,
and
you
would
have
pleased
him
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
give
her
to
you
in
his
name
,
and
with
his
blessing
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
world
and
I
part
in
this
act
,
we
part
on
happier
terms
than
we
have
lived
for
many
a
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
placed
her
in
his
arms
,
and
would
have
left
the
room
,
but
that
he
was
stopped
in
his
passage
to
the
door
by
a
great
noise
at
a
distance
,
which
made
them
start
and
pause
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
loud
shouting
,
mingled
with
boisterous
acclamations
,
that
rent
the
very
air
.
 
<EOS>
It
drew
nearer
and
nearer
every
moment
,
and
approached
so
rapidly
,
that
,
even
while
they
listened
,
it
burst
into
a
deafening
confusion
of
sounds
at
the
street
corner
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
must
be
stopped
---
quieted
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
hastily
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
should
have
foreseen
this
,
and
provided
against
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
go
out
to
them
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
,
before
he
could
reach
the
door
,
and
before
Edward
could
catch
up
his
hat
and
follow
him
,
they
were
again
arrested
by
a
loud
shriek
from
above
-
stairs
:
and
<EOS>
the
locksmith
's
wife
,
bursting
in
,
and
fairly
running
into
Mr
Haredale
's
arms
,
cried
out
:
  
"
<EOS>
She
knows
it
all
,
dear
sir
!
<EOS>
---
she
knows
it
all
!
 
<EOS>
We
broke
it
out
to
her
by
degrees
,
and
she
is
quite
prepared
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Having
made
this
communication
,
and
furthermore
thanked
Heaven
with
great
fervour
and
heartiness
,
the
good
lady
,
according
to
the
custom
of
matrons
,
on
all
occasions
of
excitement
,
fainted
away
directly
.
  
<EOS>
They
ran
to
the
window
,
drew
up
the
sash
,
and
looked
into
the
crowded
street
.
 
<EOS>
Among
a
dense
mob
of
persons
,
of
whom
not
one
was
for
an
instant
still
,
the
locksmith
's
ruddy
face
and
burly
form
could
be
descried
,
beating
about
as
though
he
was
struggling
with
a
rough
sea
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
he
was
carried
back
a
score
of
yards
,
now
onward
nearly
to
the
door
,
now
back
again
,
now
forced
against
the
opposite
houses
,
now
against
those
adjoining
his
own
:
now
carried
up
a
flight
of
steps
,
and
greeted
by
the
outstretched
hands
of
half
a
hundred
men
,
while
the
whole
tumultuous
concourse
stretched
their
throats
,
and
cheered
with
all
their
might
.
 
<EOS>
Though
he
was
really
in
a
fair
way
to
be
torn
to
pieces
in
the
general
enthusiasm
,
the
locksmith
,
nothing
discomposed
,
echoed
their
shouts
till
he
was
as
hoarse
as
they
,
and
in
a
glow
of
joy
and
right
good
-
humour
,
waved
his
hat
until
the
daylight
shone
between
its
brim
and
crown
.
  
<EOS>
But
in
all
the
bandyings
from
hand
to
hand
,
and
strivings
to
and
fro
,
and
sweepings
here
and
there
,
which
---
saving
that
he
looked
more
jolly
and
more
radiant
after
every
struggle
---
troubled
his
peace
of
mind
no
more
than
if
he
had
been
a
straw
upon
the
water
's
surface
,
he
never
once
released
his
firm
grasp
of
an
arm
,
drawn
tight
through
his
.
 
<EOS>
He
sometimes
turned
to
clap
this
friend
upon
the
back
,
or
whisper
in
his
ear
a
word
of
staunch
encouragement
,
or
cheer
him
with
a
smile
;
but
his
great
care
was
to
shield
him
from
the
pressure
,
and
force
a
passage
for
him
to
the
Golden
Key
.
<EOS>
Passive
and
timid
,
scared
,
pale
,
and
wondering
,
and
gazing
at
the
throng
as
if
he
were
newly
risen
from
the
dead
,
and
felt
himself
a
ghost
among
the
living
,
Barnaby
---
not
Barnaby
in
the
spirit
,
but
in
flesh
and
blood
,
with
pulses
,
sinews
,
nerves
,
and
beating
heart
,
and
strong
affections
---
clung
to
his
stout
old
friend
,
and
followed
where
he
led
.
  
<EOS>
And
thus
,
in
course
of
time
,
they
reached
the
door
,
held
ready
for
their
entrance
by
no
unwilling
hands
.
 
<EOS>
Then
slipping
in
,
and
shutting
out
the
crowd
by
main
force
,
Gabriel
stood
between
Mr
Haredale
and
Edward
Chester
,
and
Barnaby
,
rushing
up
the
stairs
,
fell
upon
his
knees
beside
his
mother
's
bed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Such
is
the
blessed
end
,
sir
,
"
cried
the
panting
locksmith
,
to
Mr
Haredale
,
"
of
the
best
day
's
work
we
ever
did
.
 
<EOS>
The
rogues
!
<EOS>
it
's
been
hard
fighting
to
get
away
from
'em
.
 
<EOS>
I
almost
thought
,
once
or
twice
,
they
'd
have
been
too
much
for
us
with
their
kindness
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
had
striven
,
all
the
previous
day
,
to
rescue
Barnaby
from
his
impending
fate
.
 
<EOS>
Failing
in
their
attempts
,
in
the
first
quarter
to
which
they
addressed
themselves
,
they
renewed
them
in
another
.
<EOS>
Failing
there
,
likewise
,
they
began
afresh
at
midnight
;
and
made
their
way
,
not
only
to
the
judge
and
jury
who
had
tried
him
,
but
to
men
of
influence
at
court
,
to
the
young
Prince
of
Wales
,
and
even
to
the
ante
-
chamber
of
the
King
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Successful
,
at
last
,
in
awakening
an
interest
in
his
favour
,
and
an
inclination
to
inquire
more
dispassionately
into
his
case
,
they
had
had
an
interview
with
the
minister
,
in
his
bed
,
so
late
as
eight
o'clock
that
morning
.
<EOS>
The
result
of
a
searching
inquiry
(
in
which
they
,
who
had
known
the
poor
fellow
from
his
childhood
,
did
other
good
service
,
besides
bringing
it
about
)
was
,
that
between
eleven
and
twelve
o'clock
,
a
free
pardon
to
Barnaby
Rudge
was
made
out
and
signed
,
and
entrusted
to
a
horse
-
soldier
for
instant
conveyance
to
the
place
of
execution
.
 
<EOS>
This
courier
reached
the
spot
just
as
the
cart
appeared
in
sight
;
and
Barnaby
being
carried
back
to
jail
,
Mr
Haredale
,
assured
that
all
was
safe
,
had
gone
straight
from
Bloomsbury
Square
to
the
Golden
Key
,
leaving
to
Gabriel
the
grateful
task
of
bringing
him
home
in
triumph
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
need
n't
say
,
"
observed
the
locksmith
,
when
he
had
shaken
hands
with
all
the
males
in
the
house
,
and
hugged
all
the
females
,
five
-
and
-
forty
times
,
at
least
,
"
that
,
except
among
ourselves
,
I
did
n't
want
to
make
a
triumph
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
directly
we
got
into
the
street
we
were
known
,
and
this
hubbub
began
.
 
<EOS>
Of
the
two
,
"
he
added
,
as
he
wiped
his
crimson
face
,
"
and
after
experience
of
both
,
I
think
I
'd
rather
be
taken
out
of
my
house
by
a
crowd
of
enemies
,
than
escorted
home
by
a
mob
of
friends
!
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
plain
enough
,
however
,
that
this
was
mere
talk
on
Gabriel
's
part
,
and
that
the
whole
proceeding
afforded
him
the
keenest
delight
;
for
the
people
continuing
to
make
a
great
noise
without
,
and
to
cheer
as
if
their
voices
were
in
the
freshest
order
,
and
good
for
a
fortnight
,
he
sent
upstairs
for
Grip
(
who
had
come
home
at
his
master
's
back
,
and
had
acknowledged
the
favours
of
the
multitude
by
drawing
blood
from
every
finger
that
came
within
his
reach
)
,
and
with
the
bird
upon
his
arm
presented
himself
at
the
first
-
floor
window
,
and
waved
his
hat
again
until
it
dangled
by
a
shred
,
between
his
finger
and
thumb
.
 
<EOS>
This
demonstration
having
been
received
with
appropriate
shouts
,
and
silence
being
in
some
degree
restored
,
he
thanked
them
for
their
sympathy
;
and
taking
the
liberty
to
inform
them
that
there
was
a
sick
person
in
the
house
,
proposed
that
they
should
give
three
cheers
for
King
George
,
three
more
for
Old
England
,
and
three
more
for
nothing
particular
,
as
a
closing
ceremony
.
 
<EOS>
The
crowd
assenting
,
substituted
Gabriel
Varden
for
the
nothing
particular
;
and
giving
him
one
over
,
for
good
measure
,
dispersed
in
high
good
-
humour
.
  
<EOS>
What
congratulations
were
exchanged
among
the
inmates
at
the
Golden
Key
,
when
they
were
left
alone
;
what
an
overflowing
of
joy
and
happiness
<EOS>
there
was
among
them
;
how
incapable
it
was
of
expression
in
Barnaby
's
own
person
;
and
how
he
went
wildly
from
one
to
another
,
until
he
became
so
far
tranquillised
,
as
to
stretch
himself
on
the
ground
beside
his
mother
's
couch
and
fall
into
a
deep
sleep
;
are
matters
that
need
not
be
told
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
is
well
<EOS>
they
happened
to
be
of
this
class
,
for
they
would
be
very
hard
to
tell
,
were
their
narration
ever
so
indispensable
.
  
<EOS>
Before
leaving
this
bright
picture
,
it
may
be
well
to
glance
at
a
dark
and
very
different
one
which
was
presented
to
only
a
few
eyes
,
that
same
night
.
  
<EOS>
The
scene
was
a
churchyard
;
the
time
,
midnight
;
the
persons
,
Edward
Chester
,
a
clergyman
,
a
grave
-
digger
,
and
the
four
bearers
of
a
homely
coffin
.
 
<EOS>
They
stood
about
a
grave
which
had
been
newly
dug
,
and
one
of
the
bearers
held
up
a
dim
lantern
,
---
the
only
light
there
---
which
shed
its
feeble
ray
upon
the
book
of
prayer
.
 
<EOS>
He
placed
it
for
a
moment
on
the
coffin
,
when
he
and
his
companions
were
about
to
lower
it
down
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
inscription
on
the
lid
.
  
<EOS>
The
mould
fell
solemnly
upon
the
last
house
of
this
nameless
man
;
and
the
rattling
dust
left
a
dismal
echo
even
in
the
accustomed
ears
of
those
who
had
borne
it
to
its
resting
-
place
.
 
<EOS>
The
grave
was
filled
in
to
the
top
,
and
trodden
down
.
 
<EOS>
They
all
left
the
spot
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
never
saw
him
,
living
?
"
<EOS>
asked
the
clergyman
,
of
Edward
.
  
<EOS>
"
Often
,
years
ago
;
not
knowing
him
for
my
brother
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
since
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
.
 
<EOS>
Yesterday
,
he
steadily
refused
to
see
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
urged
upon
him
,
many
times
,
at
my
desire
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Still
he
refused
?
 
<EOS>
That
was
hardened
and
unnatural
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
infer
that
you
do
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
.
 
<EOS>
We
hear
the
world
wonder
,
every
day
,
at
monsters
of
ingratitude
.
 
<EOS>
Did
it
never
occur
to
you
that
it
often
looks
for
monsters
of
affection
,
as
though
they
were
things
of
course
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
had
reached
the
gate
by
this
time
,
and
bidding
each
other
good
night
,
departed
on
their
separate
ways
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
80
    
<EOS>
That
afternoon
,
when
he
had
slept
off
his
fatigue
;
had
shaved
,
and
washed
,
and
dressed
,
and
freshened
himself
from
top
to
toe
;
when
he
had
dined
,
comforted
himself
with
a
pipe
,
an
extra
Toby
,
a
nap
in
the
great
arm
-
chair
,
and
a
quiet
chat
with
Mrs
Varden
on
everything
that
had
happened
,
was
happening
,
or
about
to
happen
,
within
the
sphere
of
their
domestic
concern
;
the
locksmith
sat
himself
down
at
the
tea
-
table
in
the
little
back
-
parlour
:
the
rosiest
,
cosiest
,
merriest
,
heartiest
,
best
-
contented
old
buck
,
in
Great
Britain
or
out
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
There
he
sat
,
with
his
beaming
eye
on
Mrs
V
,
and
his
shining
face
suffused
with
gladness
,
and
his
capacious
waistcoat
smiling
in
every
wrinkle
,
and
his
jovial
humour
peeping
from
under
the
table
in
the
very
plumpness
of
his
legs
;
a
sight
to
turn
the
vinegar
of
misanthropy
into
purest
milk
of
human
kindness
.
 
<EOS>
There
he
sat
,
watching
his
wife
as
she
decorated
the
room
with
flowers
for
the
greater
honour
of
Dolly
and
Joseph
Willet
,
who
had
gone
out
walking
,
and
for
whom
the
tea
-
kettle
had
been
singing
gaily
on
the
hob
full
twenty
minutes
,
chirping
as
never
kettle
chirped
before
;
for
whom
the
best
service
of
real
undoubted
china
,
patterned
with
divers
round
-
faced
mandarins
holding
up
broad
umbrellas
,
was
now
displayed
in
all
its
glory
;
to
tempt
whose
appetites
a
clear
,
transparent
,
juicy
ham
,
garnished
with
cool
green
lettuce
-
leaves
and
fragrant
cucumber
,
reposed
upon
a
shady
table
,
covered
with
a
snow
-
white
cloth
;
for
whose
delight
,
preserves
and
jams
,
crisp
cakes
and
other
pastry
,
short
to
eat
,
with
cunning
twists
,
and
cottage
loaves
,
and
rolls
of
bread
both
white
and
brown
,
were
all
set
forth
in
rich
profusion
;
in
whose
youth
Mrs
V
 
herself
had
grown
quite
young
,
and
stood
there
in
a
gown
of
red
and
white
:
symmetrical
in
figure
,
buxom
in
bodice
,
ruddy
in
cheek
and
lip
,
faultless
in
ankle
,
laughing
in
face
and
mood
,
in
all
respects
delicious
to
behold
---
there
sat
the
locksmith
among
all
and
every
these
delights
,
the
sun
that
shone
upon
them
all
:
the
centre
of
the
system
:
the
source
of
light
,
heat
,
life
,
and
frank
enjoyment
in
the
bright
household
world
.
  
<EOS>
And
when
had
Dolly
ever
been
the
Dolly
of
that
afternoon
?
 
<EOS>
To
see
how
she
came
in
,
arm
-
in
-
arm
with
Joe
;
and
how
she
made
an
effort
not
to
blush
or
seem
at
all
confused
;
and
how
she
made
believe
she
did
n't
care
to
sit
on
his
side
of
the
table
;
and
how
she
coaxed
the
locksmith
in
a
whisper
not
to
joke
;
and
how
her
colour
came
and
went
in
a
little
restless
flutter
of
happiness
,
which
made
her
do
everything
wrong
,
and
yet
so
charmingly
wrong
that
it
was
better
than
right
!
<EOS>
---
why
,
the
locksmith
could
have
looked
on
at
this
(
as
he
mentioned
to
Mrs
Varden
when
they
retired
for
the
night
)
for
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
at
a
stretch
,
and
never
wished
it
done
.
  
<EOS>
The
recollections
,
too
,
with
which
they
made
merry
over
that
long
protracted
tea
!
 
<EOS>
The
glee
with
which
the
locksmith
asked
Joe
if
he
remembered
that
stormy
night
at
the
Maypole
when
he
first
asked
after
Dolly
---
the
laugh
they
all
had
,
about
that
night
when
she
was
going
out
to
the
party
in
the
sedan
-
chair
---
the
unmerciful
manner
in
which
they
rallied
Mrs
Varden
about
putting
those
flowers
outside
that
very
window
---
the
difficulty
Mrs
Varden
found
in
joining
the
laugh
against
herself
,
at
first
,
and
the
extraordinary
perception
she
had
of
the
joke
when
she
overcame
it
---
the
confidential
statements
of
Joe
concerning
the
precise
day
and
hour
when
he
was
first
conscious
of
being
fond
of
Dolly
,
and
Dolly
's
blushing
admissions
,
half
volunteered
and
half
extorted
,
as
to
the
time
from
which
she
dated
the
discovery
that
she
"
did
n't
mind
"
Joe
---
here
was
an
exhaustless
fund
of
mirth
and
conversation
.
  
<EOS>
Then
,
there
was
a
great
deal
to
be
said
regarding
Mrs
Varden
's
doubts
,
and
motherly
alarms
,
and
shrewd

;
and
it
appeared
that
from
Mrs
Varden
's
penetration
and
extreme
sagacity
nothing
had
ever
been
hidden
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
known
it
all
along
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
seen
it
from
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
always
predicted
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
been
aware
of
it
before
the
principals
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
said
within
herself
(
for
she
remembered
the

)
"
that
young
Willet
is
certainly
looking
after
our
Dolly
,
and
I
must
look
after
HIM
.
"
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
she
had
looked
after
him
,
and
had
observed
many
little
circumstances
(
all
of
which
she
named
)
<EOS>
so
exceedingly
minute
that
nobody
else
could
make
anything
out
of
them
even
now
;
and
had
<EOS>
,
it
seemed
from
first
to
last
,
displayed
the
most

and
most

.
  
<EOS>
Of
course
the
night

Joe
WOULD

by

,
and
when
Mrs
Varden
WOULD

,
was

---
nor
the

Dolly
fainted
on

---
nor
the

upon

when
Mrs
Varden
,

,
had

in

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
nothing
was

;
and
everything
by

other
brought
them
back
to
the

,
that
that
was
the
happiest
hour
in
all

;
consequently
,
that
everything
must
have
occurred
for
the
best
,
and
nothing
could
be
suggested
which
would
have
made

.
  
<EOS>
While

were
in

of
such

as

,
there

a

,
opening
from

into
the

,
which
had
been

all

that

might

more

.
 
<EOS>
Joe
,
as
in
duty

,
would
hear
of
nobody
but
himself
going
to
open

;
and
accordingly
left
the
room
for
that
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
odd
enough
,
certainly
,
if
Joe

forgotten

this
door
;
and
even

had
,
as

a

one
and

,

not

.
<EOS>
But
Dolly
,
perhaps

before
mentioned
,

---

---
 
<EOS>
hurried

;
and
they

so
long
in

---
no

owing
to

that

which

---
that

<EOS>
"
Is

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Or

?
"
  
<EOS>
Upon

,
all

and
Joe

with

,

<EOS>
"
Well
,
"

"
what

?
 
<EOS>
eh

?

<EOS>

<EOS>

Nothing

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs

,

<EOS>
Damme

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
The
old
story
!
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
She

<EOS>
nothing

Ho

,

,

<EOS>

no
!
 
<EOS>
He
he
he
!
 
<EOS>
Nor
master
<EOS>
neither
---
ho
no
!
 
<EOS>
He
he
he
!
 
<EOS>
I
HAVE
heerd
the
neighbours
make
remark
as
some
one
as
they
was
acquainted
with
<EOS>
,
was
a
poor
good
-
natur'd
mean
-
spirited
creetur
,
as
went
out
fishing
for
a
wife
one
day
,
and
caught
a
Tartar
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
I
never
to
my
knowledge
see
the
poor
person
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
did
you
neither
,
mim
---
<EOS>
ho
<EOS>
no
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
who
it
can
be
---
do
n't
you
,
mim
?
 
<EOS>
No
doubt
you
do
,
mim
.
 
<EOS>
Ho
<EOS>
yes
.
 
<EOS>
He
he
he
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Again
Miggs
paused
for
a
reply
;
and
none
being
offered
,
was
so
oppressed
with
teeming
spite
and
spleen
,
that
she
seemed
like
to
burst
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
glad
Miss
Dolly
can
laugh
,
"
cried
Miggs
with
a
feeble
titter
.
<EOS>
"
I
like
to
see
folks
a
-
laughing
---
so
do
you
,
mim
,
do
n't
you
?
 
<EOS>
You
was
always
glad
to
see
people
in
spirits
,
was
n't
you
,
mim
?
 
<EOS>
And
you
always
did
your
best
to
keep
'em
cheerful
,
did
n't
you
,
mim
?
<EOS>
Though
there
an't
such
a
great
deal
to
laugh
at
now
either
;
is
there
,
mim
?
 
<EOS>
It
an't
<EOS>
so
much
of
a
catch
,
after
looking
out
so
sharp
ever
since
she
was
a
little
chit
,
and
costing
such
a
deal
in
dress
and
show
,
to
get
a
poor
,
common
soldier
,
with
one
arm
,
is
it
,
mim
?
<EOS>
He
he
!
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
a
husband
with
one
arm
,
anyways
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
have
two
arms
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
have
two
arms
,
if
it
was
me
,
though
instead
of
hands
<EOS>
they
'd
only
got
hooks
at
the
end
,
like
our
dustman
!
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
was
about
to
add
,
and
had
,
indeed
,
begun
to
add
,
that
,
taking
them
in
the
abstract
,
dustmen
were
far
more
eligible
matches
than
soldiers
,
though
,
to
be
sure
,
when
people
were
past
choosing
they
must
take
the
best
they
could
get
,
and
think
themselves
well
off
too
;
but
her
vexation
and
chagrin
being
of
that
internally
bitter
sort
which
finds
no
relief
in
words
,
and
is
aggravated
to
madness
by
want
of
contradiction
,
she
could
hold
out
no
longer
,
and
burst
into
a
storm
of
sobs
and
tears
.
  
<EOS>
In
this
extremity
she
fell
on
the
unlucky
nephew
,
tooth
and
nail
,
and
plucking
a
handful
of
hair
from
his
head
,
demanded
to
know
how
long
she
was
to
stand
there
to
be
insulted
,
and
whether
or
no
he
meant
to
help
her
to
carry
out
the
box
again
,
and
if
he
took
a
pleasure
in
hearing
his
family
reviled
:
with
other
inquiries
of
that
nature
;
at
which
disgrace
and
provocation
,
the
small
boy
,
who
had
been
all
this
time
gradually
lashed
into
rebellion
by
the
sight
of
unattainable
pastry
,
walked
off
indignant
,
leaving
his
aunt
and
the
box
to
follow
at
their
leisure
.
 
<EOS>
Somehow
or
other
,
by
dint
of
pushing
and
pulling
,
they
did
attain
the
street
at
last
;
where
Miss
Miggs
,
all
blowzed
with
the
exertion
of
getting
there
,
and
with
her
sobs
and
tears
,
sat
down
upon
her
property
to
rest
and
grieve
,
until
she
could
ensnare
some
other
youth
to
help
her
home
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
thing
to
laugh
at
,
Martha
,
not
to
care
for
,
"
whispered
the
locksmith
,
as
he
followed
his
wife
to
the
window
,
and
good
-
humouredly
dried
her
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
does
it
matter
?
 
<EOS>
You
had
seen
your
fault
before
.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Bring
up
Toby
again
,
my
dear
;
Dolly
shall
sing
us
a
song
;
and
we
'll
be
all
the
merrier
for
this
interruption
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
81
    
<EOS>
Another
month
had
passed
,
and
the
end
of
August
had
nearly
come
,
when
Mr
Haredale
stood
alone
in
the
mail
-
coach
office
at
Bristol
.
<EOS>
Although
but
a
few
weeks
had
intervened
since
his
conversation
with
Edward
Chester
and
his
niece
,
in
the
locksmith
's
house
,
and
he
had
made
no
change
,
in
the
mean
time
,
in
his
accustomed
style
of
dress
,
his
appearance
was
greatly
altered
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
much
older
,
and
more
care
-
worn
.
 
<EOS>
Agitation
and
anxiety
of
mind
scatter
wrinkles
and
grey
hairs
with
no
unsparing
hand
;
but
deeper
traces
follow
on
the
silent
uprooting
of
old
habits
,
and
severing
of
dear
,
familiar
ties
.
 
<EOS>
The
affections
may
not
be
so
easily
wounded
as
the
passions
,
but
their
hurts
are
deeper
,
and
more
lasting
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
now
a
solitary
man
,
and
the
heart
within
him
was
dreary
and
lonesome
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
not
the
less
alone
for
having
spent
so
many
years
in
seclusion
and
retirement
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
no
better
preparation
than
a
round
of
social
cheerfulness
:
perhaps
it
even
increased
the
keenness
of
his
sensibility
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
so
dependent
upon
her
for
companionship
and
love
;
she
had
come
to
be
so
much
a
part
and
parcel
of
his
existence
;
they
had
had
so
many
cares
and
thoughts
in
common
,
which
no
one
else
had
shared
;
that
losing
her
was
beginning
life
anew
,
and
being
required
to
summon
up
the
hope
and
elasticity
of
youth
,
amid
the
doubts
,
distrusts
,
and
weakened
energies
of
age
.
  
<EOS>
The
effort
he
had
made
to
part
from
her
with
seeming
cheerfulness
and
hope
---
and
they
had
parted
only
yesterday
---
left
him
the
more
depressed
.
 
<EOS>
With
these
feelings
,
he
was
about
to
revisit
London
for
the
last
time
,
and
look
once
more
upon
the
walls
of
their
old
home
,
before
turning
his
back
upon
it
,
for
ever
.
  
<EOS>
The
journey
was
a
very
different
one
,
in
those
days
,
from
what
the
present
generation
find
it
;
but
it
came
to
an
end
,
as
the
longest
journey
will
,
and
he
stood
again
in
the
streets
of
the
metropolis
.
<EOS>
He
lay
at
the
inn
where
the
coach
stopped
,
and
resolved
,
before
he
went
to
bed
,
that
he
would
make
his
arrival
known
to
no
one
;
would
spend
but
another
night
in
London
;
and
would
spare
himself
the
pang
of
parting
,
even
with
the
honest
locksmith
.
  
<EOS>
Such
conditions
of
the
mind
as
that
to
which
he
was
a
prey
when
he
lay
down
to
rest
,
are
favourable
to
the
growth
of
disordered
fancies
,
and
uneasy
visions
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
this
,
even
in
the
horror
with
which
he
started
from
his
first
sleep
,
and
threw
up
the
window
to
dispel
it
by
the
presence
of
some
object
,
beyond
the
room
,
which
had
not
been
,
as
it
were
,
the
witness
of
his
dream
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
a
new
terror
of
the
night
;
it
had
been
present
to
him
before
,
in
many
shapes
;
it
had
haunted
him
in
bygone
times
,
and
visited
his
pillow
again
and
again
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
had
been
but
an
ugly
object
,
a
childish
spectre
,
haunting
his
sleep
,
its
return
,
in
its
old
form
,
might
have
awakened
a
momentary
sensation
of
fear
,
which
,
almost
in
the
act
of
waking
,
would
have
passed
away
.
 
<EOS>
This
disquiet
,
however
,
lingered
about
him
,
and
would
yield
to
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
closed
his
eyes
again
,
he
felt
it
hovering
near
;
as
he
slowly
sunk
into
a
slumber
,
he
was
conscious
of
its
gathering
strength
and
purpose
,
and
gradually
assuming
its
recent
shape
;
when
he
sprang
up
from
his
bed
,
the
same
phantom
vanished
from
his
heated
brain
,
and
left
him
filled
with
a
dread
against
which
reason
and
waking
thought
were
powerless
.
  
<EOS>
The
sun
was
up
,
before
he
could
shake
it
off
.
 
<EOS>
He
rose
late
,
but
not
refreshed
,
and
remained
within
doors
all
that
day
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
fancy
for
paying
his
last
visit
to
the
old
spot
in
the
evening
,
for
he
had
been
accustomed
to
walk
there
at
that
season
,
and
desired
to
see
it
under
the
aspect
that
was
most
familiar
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
At
such
an
hour
as
would
afford
him
time
to
reach
it
a
little
before
sunset
,
he
left
the
inn
,
and
turned
into
the
busy
street
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
gone
far
,
and
was
thoughtfully
making
his
way
among
the
noisy
crowd
,
when
he
felt
a
hand
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
,
turning
,
recognised
one
of
the
waiters
from
the
inn
,
who
begged
his
pardon
,
but
he
had
left
his
sword
behind
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
have
you
brought
it
to
me
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
stretching
out
his
hand
,
and
yet
not
taking
it
from
the
man
,
but
looking
at
him
in
a
disturbed
and
agitated
manner
.
  
<EOS>
The
man
was
sorry
to
have
disobliged
him
,
and
would
carry
it
back
again
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
had
said
that
he
was
going
a
little
way
into
the
country
,
and
that
he
might
not
return
until
late
.
 
<EOS>
The
roads
were
not
very
safe
for
single
travellers
after
dark
;
and
,
since
the
riots
,
gentlemen
had
been
more
careful
than
ever
,
not
to
trust
themselves
unarmed
in
lonely
places
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
thought
you
were
a
stranger
,
sir
,
"
he
added
,
"
and
that
you
might
believe
our
roads
to
be
better
than
they
are
;
but
perhaps
you
know
them
well
,
and
carry
fire
-
arms
---
"
  
He
took
the
sword
,
and
putting
it
up
at
his
side
,
thanked
the
man
,
and
resumed
his
walk
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
long
remembered
that
he
did
this
in
a
manner
so
strange
,
and
with
such
a
trembling
hand
,
that
the
messenger
stood
looking
after
his
retreating
figure
,
doubtful
whether
he
ought
not
to
follow
,
and
watch
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
long
remembered
that
he
had
been
heard
pacing
his
bedroom
in
the
dead
of
the
night
;
that
the
attendants
had
mentioned
to
each
other
in
the
morning
,
how
fevered
and
how
pale
he
looked
;
and
that
when
this
man
went
back
to
the
inn
,
he
told
a
fellow
-
servant
that
what
he
had
observed
in
this
short
interview
lay
very
heavy
on
his
mind
,
and
that
he
feared
the
gentleman
intended
to
destroy
himself
,
and
would
never
come
back
alive
.
  
<EOS>
With
a
half
-
consciousness
that
his
manner
had
attracted
the
man
's
attention
(
remembering
the
expression
of
his
face
when
they
parted
)
,
Mr
Haredale
quickened
his
steps
;
and
arriving
at
a
stand
of
coaches
,
bargained
with
the
driver
of
the
best
to
carry
him
so
far
on
his
road
as
the
point
where
the
footway
struck
across
the
fields
,
and
to
await
his
return
at
a
house
of
entertainment
which
was
within
a
stone's
-
throw
of
that
place
.
 
<EOS>
Arriving
there
in
due
course
,
he
alighted
and
pursued
his
way
on
foot
.
  
<EOS>
He
passed
so
near
the
Maypole
,
that
he
could
see
its
smoke
rising
from
among
the
trees
,
while
a
flock
of
pigeons
---
some
of
its
old
inhabitants
,
doubtless
---
sailed
gaily
home
to
roost
,
between
him
and
the
unclouded
sky
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
old
house
will
brighten
up
now
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
looked
towards
it
,
"
and
there
will
be
a
merry
fireside
beneath
its
ivied
roof
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
some
comfort
to
know
that
everything
will
not
be
blighted
hereabouts
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
be
glad
to
have
one
picture
of
life
and
cheerfulness
to
turn
to
,
in
my
mind
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
resumed
his
walk
,
and
bent
his
steps
towards
the
Warren
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
clear
,
calm
,
silent
evening
,
with
hardly
a
breath
of
wind
to
stir
the
leaves
,
or
any
sound
to
break
the
stillness
of
the
time
,
but
drowsy
sheep
-
bells
tinkling
in
the
distance
,
and
,
at
intervals
,
the
far
-
off
lowing
of
cattle
,
or
bark
of
village
dogs
.
 
<EOS>
The
sky
was
radiant
with
the
softened
glory
of
sunset
;
and
on
the
earth
,
and
in
the
air
,
a
deep
repose
prevailed
.
 
<EOS>
At
such
an
hour
,
he
arrived
at
the
deserted
mansion
which
had
been
his
home
so
long
,
and
looked
for
the
last
time
upon
its
blackened
walls
.
  
<EOS>
The
ashes
of
the
commonest
fire
are
melancholy
things
,
for
in
them
there
is
an
image
of
death
and
ruin
,
---
of
something
that
has
been
bright
,
and
is
but
dull
,
cold
,
dreary
dust
,
---
with
which
our
nature
forces
us
to
sympathise
.
 
<EOS>
How
much
more
sad
the
crumbled
embers
of
a
home
:
<EOS>
the
casting
down
of
that
great
altar
,
where
the
worst
among
us
sometimes
perform
the
worship
of
the
heart
;
and
where
the
best
have
offered
up
such
sacrifices
,
and
done
such
deeds
of
heroism
,
as
,
chronicled
,
would
put
the
proudest
temples
of
old
Time
,
with
all
their
vaunting
annals
,
to
the
blush
!
  
<EOS>
He
roused
himself
from
a
long
train
of
meditation
,
and
walked
slowly
round
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
by
this
time
almost
dark
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
nearly
made
the
circuit
of
the
building
,
when
he
uttered
a
half
-
suppressed
exclamation
,
started
,
and
stood
still
.
 
<EOS>
Reclining
,
in
an
easy
attitude
,
with
his
back
against
a
tree
,
and
contemplating
the
ruin
with
an
expression
of
pleasure
,
---
a
pleasure
<EOS>
so
keen
that
it
overcame
his
habitual
indolence
and
command
of
feature
,
and
displayed
itself
utterly
free
from
all
restraint
or
reserve
,
---
before
him
,
on
his
own
ground
,
and
triumphing
then
,
as
he
had
triumphed
in
every
misfortune
and
disappointment
of
his
life
,
stood
the
man
whose
presence
,
of
all
mankind
,
in
any
place
,
and
least
of
all
in
that
,
he
could
the
least
endure
.
  
<EOS>
Although
his
blood
so
rose
against
this
man
,
and
his
wrath
so
stirred
within
him
,
that
he
could
have
struck
him
dead
,
he
put
such
fierce
constraint
upon
himself
that
he
passed
him
without
a
word
or
look
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
he
would
have
gone
on
,
and
not
turned
,
though
to
resist
the
Devil
who
poured
such
hot
temptation
in
his
brain
,
required
an
effort
scarcely
to
be
achieved
,
if
this
man
had
not
himself
summoned
him
to
stop
:
and
that
,
with
an
assumed
compassion
in
his
voice
which
drove
him
well
-
nigh
mad
,
and
in
an
instant
routed
all
the
self
-
command
it
had
been
anguish
---
acute
,
poignant
anguish
---
to
sustain
.
  
<EOS>
All
consideration
,
reflection
,
mercy
,
forbearance
;
everything
by
which
a
goaded
man
can
curb
his
rage
and
passion
;
fled
from
him
as
he
turned
back
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
he
said
,
slowly
and
quite
calmly
---
far
more
calmly
than
he
had
ever
spoken
to
him
before
:
  
<EOS>
"
Why
have
you
called
to
me
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
remark
,
"
said
Sir
John
Chester
with
his
wonted
composure
,
"
what
an
odd
chance
it
is
,
that
we
should
meet
here
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
IS
a
strange
chance
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Strange
?
 
<EOS>
The
most
remarkable
and
singular
thing
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
ride
in
the
evening
;
I
have
not
done
so
for
years
.
 
<EOS>
The
whim
seized
me
,
quite
unaccountably
,
in
the
middle
of
last
night
.
<EOS>
---
How
very
picturesque
this
is
!
"
<EOS>
---
He
pointed
,
as
he
spoke
,
to
the
dismantled
house
,
and
raised
his
glass
to
his
eye
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
praise
your
own
work
very
freely
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Sir
John
let
fall
his
glass
;
inclined
his
face
towards
him
with
an
air
of
the
most
courteous
inquiry
;
and
slightly
shook
his
head
as
though
he
were
remarking
to
himself
,
"
I
fear
this
animal
is
going
mad
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
you
praise
your
own
work
very
freely
,
"
repeated
Mr
Haredale
.
  
<EOS>
"
Work
!
"
echoed
Sir
John
,
looking
smilingly
round
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mine
!
---
<EOS>
I
beg
your
pardon
,
I
really
beg
your
pardon
---
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
see
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
those
walls
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
those
tottering
gables
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
on
every
side
where
fire
and
smoke
have
raged
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
the
destruction
that
has
been
wanton
here
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
good
friend
,
"
returned
the
knight
,
gently
checking
his
impatience
with
his
hand
,
"
of
course
I
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
everything
you
speak
of
,
when
you
stand
aside
,
and
do
not
interpose
yourself
between
the
view
and
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
sorry
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
not
had
the
pleasure
to
meet
you
here
,
I
think
I
should
have
written
to
tell
you
so
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
do
n't
bear
it
as
well
as
I
had
expected
---
 
<EOS>
excuse
me
---
<EOS>
no
,
you
do
n't
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
pulled
out
his
snuff
-
box
,
and
addressing
him
with
the
superior
air
of
a
man
who
,
by
reason
of
his
higher
nature
,
has
a
right
to
read
a
moral
lesson
to
another
,
continued
:
  
"
<EOS>
For
you
are
a
philosopher
,
you
know
---
one
of
that
stern
and
rigid
school
who
are
far
above
the
weaknesses
of
mankind
in
general
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
removed
,
a
long
way
,
from
the
frailties
of
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
You
contemplate
them
from
a
height
,
and
rail
at
them
with
a
most
impressive
bitterness
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
heard
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
---
"
<EOS>
And
shall
again
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
returned
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
walk
as
we
talk
?
 
<EOS>
The
damp
falls
rather
heavily
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
---
as
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
grieve
to
say
that
I
can
spare
you
only
a
very
few
moments
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
would
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
,
"
you
had
spared
me
none
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
,
with
all
my
soul
,
you
had
been
in
Paradise
(
if
such
a
monstrous
lie
could
be
enacted
)
,
rather
than
here
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
"
returned
the
other
---
"
really
---
you
do
yourself
injustice
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
rough
companion
,
but
I
would
not
go
so
far
to
avoid
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Listen
to
me
,
"
said
Mr
Haredale
.
 
<EOS>
"
Listen
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
While
you
rail
?
"
inquired
Sir
John
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
While
I
deliver
your
infamy
.
 
<EOS>
You
urged
and
stimulated
to
do
your
work
a
fit
agent
,
but
one
who
in
his
nature
---
in
the
very
essence
of
his
being
---
is
a
traitor
,
and
who
has
been
false
to
you
(
despite
the
sympathy
you
two
should
have
together
)
as
he
has
been
to
all
others
.
 
<EOS>
With
hints
,
and
looks
,
and
crafty
words
,
which
told
again
are
nothing
,
you
set
on
Gashford
to
this
work
---
this
work
before
us
now
.
 
<EOS>
With
these
same
hints
,
and
looks
,
and
crafty
words
,
which
told
again
are
nothing
,
you
urged
him
on
to
gratify
the
deadly
hate
he
owes
me
<EOS>
---
I
have
earned
it
,
I
thank
Heaven
---
by
the
abduction
and
dishonour
of
my
niece
.
 
<EOS>
You
did
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
denial
in
your
looks
,
"
he
cried
,
abruptly
pointing
in
his
face
,
and
stepping
back
,
"
and
denial
is
a
lie
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
his
hand
upon
his
sword
;
but
the
knight
,
with
a
contemptuous
smile
,
replied
to
him
as
coldly
as
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
take
notice
,
sir
---
if
you
can
discriminate
sufficiently
---
 
that
I
have
taken
the
trouble
to
deny
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Your
discernment
is
hardly
fine
enough
for
the
perusal
of
faces
,
not
of
a
kind
as
coarse
as
your
speech
;
nor
has
it
ever
been
,
that
I
remember
;
or
,
in
one
face
that
I
could
name
,
you
would
have
read
indifference
,
not
to
say
disgust
,
somewhat
sooner
than
you
did
.
 
<EOS>
I
speak
of
a
long
time
ago
,
---
<EOS>
but
you
understand
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Disguise
it
as
you
will
,
you
mean
denial
.
 
<EOS>
Denial
explicit
or
reserved
,
expressed
or
left
to
be
inferred
,
is
still
a
lie
.
 
<EOS>
You
say
you
do
n't
deny
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
admit
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
You
yourself
,
"
returned
Sir
John
,
suffering
the
current
of
his
speech
to
flow
as
smoothly
as
if
it
had
been
stemmed
by
no
one
word
of
interruption
,
"
publicly
proclaimed
the
character
of
the
gentleman
in
question
(
I
think
it
was
in
Westminster
Hall
)
in
terms
which
relieve
me
from
the
necessity
of
making
any
further
allusion
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
have
been
warranted
;
you
may
not
have
been
;
I
ca
n't
say
.
 
<EOS>
Assuming
the
gentleman
to
be
what
you
described
,
and
to
have
made
to
you
or
any
other
person
any
statements
that
may
have
happened
to
suggest
themselves
to
him
,
for
the
sake
of
his
own
security
,
or
for
the
sake
of

,
or
for
his
own
amusement
,
or
for
any
other

,
---
I
have
nothing
to
say
of
him
,
except
that
his
extremely
degrading
situation
appears
to
me
to
be
shared
with
his
employers
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
so
very
plain
yourself
,
that
you
will
excuse
a
little
freedom
in
me
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Attend
to
me
again
,
Sir
John
<EOS>
but
once
,
"
cried
Mr
Haredale
;
"
in
your
every
look
,
and
word
,
and
gesture
,
you
tell
me
this
was
not
your
act
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
that
it
was
,
and
that
you
tampered
with
the
man
I
speak
of
,
and
with
your
wretched
son
(
whom
God
forgive
!
)
<EOS>
to
do
this
deed
.
 
<EOS>
You
talk
of
degradation
and
character
.
 
<EOS>
You
told
me
once
that
you
had
purchased
the
absence
of
the
poor
idiot
and
his
mother
,
when
(
as
I
have
discovered
since
,
and
then
suspected
)
<EOS>
you
had
gone
to
tempt
them
,
and
had
found
them
flown
.
 
<EOS>
To
you
I
traced
the
insinuation
that
I
alone
reaped
any
harvest
from
my
brother
's
death
;
and
all
the
foul
attacks
and
whispered
calumnies
that
followed
in
its
train
.
 
<EOS>
In
every
action
of
my
life
,
from
that
first
hope
which
you
converted
into
grief
and
desolation
,
you
have
stood
,
like
an
adverse
fate
,
between
me
and
peace
.
 
<EOS>
In
all
,
you
have
ever
been
the
same
cold
-
blooded
,
hollow
,
false
,
unworthy
villain
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
second
time
,
and
for
the
last
,
I
cast
these
charges
in
your
teeth
,
and
spurn
you
from
me
as
I
would
a
faithless
dog
!
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
he
raised
his
arm
,
and
struck
him
on
the
breast
so
that
he
staggered
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
John
,
the
instant
he
recovered
,
drew
his
sword
,
threw
away
the
scabbard
and
his
hat
,
and
running
on
his
adversary
<EOS>
made
a
desperate
lunge
at
his
heart
,
<EOS>
which
,
but
that
his
guard
was
quick
and
true
,
would
have
stretched
him
dead
upon
the
grass
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
act
of
striking
him
,
the
torrent
of
his
opponent
's
rage
had
reached
a
stop
.
 
<EOS>
He
parried
his
rapid
thrusts
,
without
returning
them
,
and
called
to
him
,
with
a
frantic
kind
of
terror
in
his

,
to
keep
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
to
-
night
!
<EOS>
not
to
-
night
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
God
's
name
,
not
tonight
!
"
  
<EOS>
Seeing
that
he
lowered
his
weapon
,
and
that
he
would
not
thrust
in
turn
,
Sir
John
lowered
his
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
to
-
night
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
his
adversary
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
warned
in
time
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
told
me
---
it
must
have
been
in
a
sort

---
"
said
Sir
John
,
quite
deliberately
,
though
now
he
dropped
his
mask
,
and
showed
his
hatred
in
his
face
,
"
that
this
was
the
last
time
.
 
<EOS>
Be
assured
it
is
!
 
<EOS>
Did
you
believe
our
last
meeting
was
forgotten
?
<EOS>
Did
you
believe
that
your
every
word
and
look
was
not
to
be
accounted
for
,
and
was
not
well
remembered
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
believe
that
I
have
waited
your
time
,
or
you
mine
?
 
<EOS>
What
kind
of
man
is
he
who
entered
,
with
all
his
sickening
ca
nt
of
honesty
and
truth
,
into
a
bond
with
me
to
prevent
a
marriage
he
affected
to
dislike
,
and
when
I
had
redeemed
my
part
to
the
spirit
and
the
letter
,
skulked
from
his
,
and
brought
the
match
about
in
his
own
time
,
to
rid
himself
of
a
burden
he
had
grown
tired
of
,
and
cast
a
spurious
lustre
on
his
house
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
acted
,
"
cried
Mr
Haredale
,
"
with
honour
and
in
good
faith
.
<EOS>
I
do
so
now
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
force
me
to
renew
this
duel
to
-
night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
said
my
"
wretched
"
son
,
I
think
?
"
said
Sir
John
,
with
a
smile
.
"
<EOS>
Poor
fool
!
 
<EOS>
The
dupe
of
such
a
shallow
knave
---
trapped
into
marriage
by
such
an
uncle
and
by
such

---
he

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
is
no

son
of
mine
<EOS>
:
you
are
welcome
to
the
prize
your
craft
has
made
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Once
more
,
"
cried
his
opponent
,
wildly
stamping

the

,
"
although
you
tear
me
from
my
better
angel
,
I
implore

not
to
come

to
-

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
why
were
you
here

!
 
<EOS>
Why
have

!
 
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
would
have
cast

for

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
being

,
"
returned
Sir
John
,
without

least

,
"
it
is
very
fortunate
<EOS>
we
have
met
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
Haredale
,
I
have
always
despised
you
,
as
you

,
but
I
have
given

for
a
species

.
 
<EOS>
For
the
honour
of
my
judgment
,
which
I
had
thought
a
good
one
,
I
am
sorry
to
find
you
a
coward
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Not
another
word
was
spoken
on
either
side
.
 
<EOS>
They
crossed
swords
,
though
it
was
now
quite
dusk
,
and
attacked
each
other
fiercely
.
<EOS>
They
were
well
matched
,
and
each
was
thoroughly
skilled
in
the
management
of
his
weapon
.
  
<EOS>
After
a
few
seconds
they
grew
hotter
and
more
furious
,
and
pressing
on
each
other
inflicted
and
received
several
slight
wounds
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
directly
after
receiving
one
of
these
in
his
arm
,
that
Mr
Haredale
,
making
a
keener
thrust
as
he
felt
the
warm
blood
spirting
out
,
plunged
his
sword
through
his
opponent
's
body
to
the
hilt
.
  
<EOS>
Their
eyes
met
,
and
were
on
each
other
as
he
drew
it
out
.
 
<EOS>
He
put
his
arm
about
the
dying
man
,
who
repulsed
him
,
feebly
,
and
dropped
upon
the
turf
.
 
<EOS>
Raising
himself
upon
his
hands
,
he
gazed
at
him
for
an
instant
,
with
scorn
and
hatred
in
his
look
;
but
,
seeming
to
remember
,
even
then
,
that
this
expression
would
distort
his
features
after
death
,
he
tried
to
smile
,
and
,
faintly
moving
his
right
hand
,
as
if
to
hide
his
bloody
linen
in
his
vest
,
fell
back
dead
---
the
phantom
of
last
night
.
   
<EOS>
Chapter
the
Last
 
<EOS>
A
parting
glance
at
such
of
the
actors
in
this
little
history
as
it
has
not
,
in
the
course
of
its
events
,
dismissed
,
will
bring
it
to
an
end
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Haredale
fled
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
Before
pursuit
could
be
begun
,
indeed
before
Sir
John
was
traced
or
missed
,
he
had
left
the
kingdom
.
<EOS>
Repairing
straight
to
a
religious
establishment
,
known
throughout
Europe
for
the
rigour
and
severity
of
its
discipline
,
and
for
the
merciless
penitence
it
exacted
from
those
who
sought
its
shelter
as
a
refuge
from
the
world
,
he
took
the
vows
which
thenceforth
shut
him
out
from
nature
and
his
kind
,
and
after
a
few
remorseful
years
was
buried
in
its
gloomy
cloisters
.
  
<EOS>
Two
days
elapsed
before
the
body
of
Sir
John
was
found
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
it
was
recognised
and
carried
home
,
the
faithful
valet
,
true
to
his
master
's
creed
,
eloped
with
all
the
cash
and
movables
he
could
lay
his
hands
on
,
and
started
as
a
finished
gentleman
upon
his
own
account
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
career
he
met
with
great
success
,
and
would
certainly
have
married
an
heiress
in
the
end
,
but
for
an
unlucky
check
which
led
to
his
premature
decease
.
 
<EOS>
He
sank
under
a
contagious
disorder
,
very
prevalent
at
that
time
,
and
vulgarly
termed
the
jail
fever
.
  
<EOS>
Lord
George
Gordon
,
remaining
in
his
prison
in
the
Tower
until
Monday
the
fifth
of
February
in
the
following
year
,
was
on
that
day
solemnly
tried
at
Westminster
for
High
Treason
.
 
<EOS>
Of
this
crime
he
was
,
after
a
patient
investigation
,
declared
Not
Guilty
;
upon
the
ground
that
there
was
no
proof
of
his
having
called
the
multitude
together
with
any
traitorous
or
unlawful
intentions
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
so
many
people
were
there
,
still
,
to
whom
those
riots
taught
no
lesson
of
reproof
or
moderation
,
that
a
public
subscription
was
set
on
foot
in
Scotland
to
defray
the
cost
of
his
defence
.
  
<EOS>
For
seven
years
afterwards
he
remained
,
at
the
strong
intercession
of
his
friends
,
comparatively
quiet
;
saving
that
he
,
every
now
and
then
,
took
occasion
to
display
his
zeal
for
the
Protestant
faith
in
some
extravagant
proceeding
which
was
the
delight
of
its
enemies
;
and
saving
,
besides
,
that
he
was
formally
excommunicated
by
the
Archbishop
of
Canterbury
,
for
refusing
to
appear
as
a
witness
in
the
Ecclesiastical
Court
when
cited
for
that
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
year
1788
he
was
stimulated
by
some
new
insanity
to
write
and
publish
an
injurious
pamphlet
,
reflecting
on
the
Queen
of
France
,
in
very
violent
terms
.
 
<EOS>
Being
indicted
for
the
libel
,
and
(
after
various
strange
demonstrations
in
court
)
found
guilty
,
he
fled
into
Holland
in
place
of
appearing
to
receive
sentence
:
from
whence
,
as
the
quiet
burgomasters
of
Amsterdam
had
no
relish
for
his
company
,
he
was
sent
home
again
with
all
speed
.
 
<EOS>
Arriving
in
the
month
of
July
at
Harwich
,
and
going
thence
to
Birmingham
,
he
made
in
the
latter
place
,
in
August
,
a
public
profession
of
the
Jewish
religion
;
and
figured
there
as
a
Jew
until
he
was
arrested
,
and
brought
back
to
London
to
receive
the
sentence
he
had
evaded
.
 
<EOS>
By
virtue
of
this
sentence
he
was
,
in
the
month
of
December
,
cast
into
Newgate
for
five
years
and
ten
months
,
and
required
besides
to
pay
a
large
fine
,
and
to
furnish
heavy
securities
for
his
future
good
behaviour
.
  
<EOS>
After
addressing
,
in
the
midsummer
of
the
following
year
,
an
appeal
to
the
commiseration
of
the
National
Assembly
of
France
,
which
the
English
minister
refused
to
sanction
,
he
composed
himself
to
undergo
his
full
term
of
punishment
;
and
suffering
his
beard
to
grow
nearly
to
his
waist
,
and
conforming
in
all
respects
to
the
ceremonies
of
his
new
religion
,
he
applied
himself
to
the
study
of
history
,
and
occasionally
to
the
art
of
painting
,
in
which
,
in
his
younger
days
,
he
had
shown
some
skill
.
 
<EOS>
Deserted
by
his
former
friends
,
and
treated
in
all
respects
like
the
worst
criminal
in
the
jail
,
he
lingered
on
,
quite
cheerful
and
resigned
,
until
the
1st
of
November
1793
,
when
he
died
in
his
cell
,
being
then
only
three
-
and
-
forty
years
of
age
.
  
<EOS>
Many
men
with
fewer
sympathies
for
the
distressed
and
needy
,
with
less
abilities
and
harder
hearts
,
have
made
a
shining
figure
and
left
a
brilliant
fame
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
his
mourners
.
 
<EOS>
The
prisoners
bemoaned
his
loss
,
and
missed
him
;
for
though
his
means
were
not
large
,
his
charity
was
great
,
and
in
bestowing
alms
among
them
he
considered
the
necessities
of
all
alike
,
and
knew
no
distinction
of
sect
or
creed
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
wise
men
in
the
highways
of
the
world
who
may
learn
something
,
even
from
this
poor
crazy
lord
who
died
in
Newgate
.
  
<EOS>
To
the
last
,
he
was
truly
served
by
bluff
John
Grueby
.
 
<EOS>
John
was
at
his
side
before
he
had
been
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
in
the
Tower
,
and
never
left
him
until
he
died
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
one
other
constant
attendant
,
in
the
person
of
a
beautiful
Jewish
girl
;
who
attached
herself
to
him
from
feelings
half
religious
,
half
romantic
,
but
<EOS>
whose
virtuous
and
disinterested
character
appears
to
have
been
beyond
the
censure
even
of
the
most
censorious
.
  
<EOS>
Gashford
deserted
him
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
He
subsisted
for
a
time
upon
his
traffic
in
his
master
's
secrets
;
and
,
this
trade
failing
when
the
stock
was
quite
exhausted
,
procured
an
appointment
in
the
honourable
corps
of
spies
and
eavesdroppers
employed
by
the
government
.
 
<EOS>
As
one
of
these
wretched
underlings
,
he
did
his
drudgery
,
sometimes
abroad
,
sometimes
at
home
,
and
long
endured
the
various
miseries
of
such
a
station
.
 
<EOS>
Ten
or
a
dozen
years
ago
---
not
more
---
a
meagre
,
wan
old
man
,
diseased
and
miserably
poor
,
was
found
dead
in
his
bed
at
an
obscure
inn
in
the
Borough
,
where
he
was
quite
unknown
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
taken
poison
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
clue
to
his
name
;
but
it
was
discovered
from
certain
entries
in
a
pocket
-
book
he
carried
,
that
he
had
been
secretary
to
Lord
George
Gordon
in
the
time
of
the
famous
riots
.
  
<EOS>
Many
months
after
the
re
-
establishment
of
peace
and
order
,
and
even
when
it
had
ceased
to
be
the
town
-
talk
,
that
every
military
officer
,
kept
at
free
quarters
by
the
City
during
the
late
alarms
,
had
cost
for
his
board
and
lodging
four
pounds
four
per
day
,
and
every
private
soldier
two
and
twopence
halfpenny
;
many
months
after
even
this
engrossing
topic
was
forgotten
,
and
the
United
Bulldogs
were
to
a
man
all
killed
,
imprisoned
,
or
transported
,
Mr
Simon
Tappertit
,
being
removed
from
a
hospital
to
prison
,
and
thence
to
his
place
of
trial
,
was
discharged
by
proclamation
,
on
two
wooden
legs
.
 
<EOS>
Shorn
of
his
graceful
limbs
,
and
brought
down
from
his
high
estate
to
circumstances
of
utter
destitution
,
and
the
deepest
misery
,
he
made
shift
to
stump
back
to
his
old
master
,
and
beg
for
some
relief
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
locksmith
's
advice
and
aid
,
he
was
established
in
business
as
a
shoeblack
,
and
opened
shop
under
an
archway
near
the
Horse
Guards
.
 
<EOS>
This
being
a
central
quarter
,
he
quickly
made
a
very
large
connection
;
and
on
levee
days
,
was
sometimes
known
to
have
as
many
as
twenty
half
-
pay
officers
waiting
their
turn
for
polishing
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
his
trade
increased
to
that
extent
,
that
in
course
of
time
he
entertained
no
less
than
two
apprentices
,
besides
taking
for
his
wife
the
widow
of
an
eminent
bone
and
rag
collector
,
formerly
of
MilIbank
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
lady
(
who
assisted
in
the
business
)
he
lived
in
great
domestic
happiness
,
only
chequered
by
those
little
storms
which
serve
to
clear
the
atmosphere
of
wedlock
,
and
brighten
its
horizon
.
 
<EOS>
In
some
of
these
gusts
of
bad
weather
,
Mr
Tappertit
would
,
in
the
assertion
of
his
prerogative
,
so
far
forget
himself
,
as
to
correct
his
lady
with
a
brush
,
or
boot
,
or
shoe
;
while
she
(
but
only
in
extreme
cases
)
would
retaliate
by
taking
off
his
legs
,
and
leaving
him
exposed
to
the
derision
of
those
urchins
who
delight
in
mischief
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
,
baffled
in
all
her
schemes
,
matrimonial
and
otherwise
,
and
cast
upon
a
thankless
,
undeserving
world
,
turned
very
sharp
and
sour
;
and
did
at
length
become
so
acid
,
and
did
so
pinch
and
slap
and
tweak
the
hair
and
noses
of
the
youth
of
Golden
Lion
Court
,
that
she
was
by
one
consent
expelled
that
sanctuary
,
and
desired
to
bless
some
other
spot
of
earth
,
in
preference
.
 
<EOS>
It
chanced
at
that
moment
,
that
the
justices
of
the
peace
for
Middlesex
proclaimed
by
public
placard
that
they
stood
in
need
of
a
female
turnkey
for
the
County
Bridewell
,
and
appointed
a
day
and
hour
for
the
inspection
of
candidates
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Miggs
attending
at
the
time
appointed
,
was
instantly
chosen
and
selected
from
one
hundred
and
twenty
-
four
competitors
,
and
at
once
promoted
to
the
office
;
which
she
held
until
her
decease
,
more
than
thirty
years
afterwards
,
remaining
single
all
that
time
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
observed
of
this
lady
that
while
she
was
inflexible
and
grim
to
all
her
female
flock
,
she
was
particularly
so
to
those
who
could
establish
any
claim
to
beauty
:
and
it
was
often
remarked
as
a
proof
of
her
indomitable
virtue
and
severe
chastity
,
that
to
such
as
had
been
frail
<EOS>
she
showed
no
mercy
;
always
falling
upon
them
on
the
slightest
occasion
,
or
on
no
occasion
at
all
,
with
the
fullest
measure
of
her
wrath
.
 
<EOS>
Among
other
useful
inventions
which
she
practised
upon
this
class
of
offenders
and
bequeathed
to
posterity
,
was
the
art
of
inflicting
an
exquisitely
vicious
poke
or
dig
with
the
wards
of
a
key
in
the
small
of
the
back
,
near
the
spine
.
 
<EOS>
She
likewise
originated
a
mode
of
treading
by
accident
(
in
pattens
)
on
such
as
had
small
feet
;
also
very
remarkable
for
its
ingenuity
,
and
previously
quite
unknown
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
very
long
,
you
may
be
sure
,
before
Joe
Willet
and
Dolly
Varden
were
made
husband
and
wife
,
and
with
a
handsome
sum
in
bank
(
for
the
locksmith
could
afford
to
give
his
daughter
a
good
dowry
)
,
reopened
the
Maypole
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
very
long
,
you
may
be
sure
,
before
a
red
-
faced
little
boy
was
seen
staggering
about
the
Maypole
passage
,
and
kicking
up
his
heels
on
the
green
before
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
very
long
,
counting
by
years
,
before
there
was
a
red
-
faced
little
girl
,
another
red
-
faced
little
boy
,
and
a
whole
troop
of
girls
and
boys
:
so
that
,
go
to
Chigwell
when
you
would
,
there
would
surely
be
seen
,
either
in
the
village
street
,
or
on
the
green
,
or
frolicking
in
the
farm
-
yard
<EOS>
---
for
it
was
a
farm
now
,
as
well
as
a
tavern
---
more
small
Joes
and
small
Dollys
than
could
be
easily
counted
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
very
long
time
before
these
appearances
ensued
;
but
it
WAS
a
VERY
long
time
before
Joe
looked
five
years
older
,
or
Dolly
either
,
or
the
locksmith
either
,
or
his
wife
either
:
for
cheerfulness
and
content
are
great
beautifiers
,
and
are
famous
preservers
of
youthful
looks
,
depend
upon
it
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
long
time
,
too
,
before
there
was
such
a
country
inn
as
the
Maypole
,
in
all
England
:
indeed
it
is
a
great
question
whether
there
has
ever
been
such
another
to
this
hour
,
or
ever
will
be
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
long
time
too
---
for
Never
<EOS>
,
as
the
proverb
says
,
is
a
long
day
---
 
before
they
forgot
to
have
an
interest
in
wounded
soldiers
at
the
Maypole
,
or
before
Joe
omitted
to
refresh
them
,
for
the
sake
of
his
old
campaign
;
or
before
the
serjeant
left
off
looking
in
there
,
now
and
then
;
or
before
they
fatigued
themselves
,
or
each
other
,
by
talking
on
these
occasions
of
battles
and
sieges
,
and
hard
weather
and
hard
service
,
and
a
thousand
things
belonging
to
a
soldier
's
life
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
the
great
silver
snuff
-
box
which
the
King
sent
Joe
with
his
own
hand
,
because
of
his
conduct
in
the
Riots
,
what
guest
ever
went
to
the
Maypole
without
putting
finger
and
thumb
into
that
box
,
and
taking
a
great
pinch
,
though
he
had
never
taken
a
pinch
of
snuff
before
,
and
almost
sneezed
himself
into
convulsions
even
then
?
 
<EOS>
As
to
the
purple
-
faced
vintner
,
where
is
the
man
who
lived
in
those
times
and
never
saw
HIM
at
the
Maypole
:
to
all
appearance
as
much
at
home
in
the
best
room
,
as
if
he
lived
there
?
 
<EOS>
And
as
to
the
feastings
and
christenings
,
and
revellings
at
Christmas
,
and
celebrations
of
birthdays
,
wedding
-
days
,
and
all
manner
of
days
,
both
at
the
Maypole
and
the
Golden
Key
,
---
if
they
are
not
notorious
,
what
facts
are
?
  
<EOS>
Mr
Willet
the
elder
,
having
been
by
some
extraordinary
means
possessed
with
the
idea
that
Joe
wanted
to
be
married
,
and
that
it
would
be
well
for
him
,
his
father
,
to
retire
into
private
life
,
and
enable
him
to
live
in
comfort
,
took
up
his
abode
in
a
small
cottage
at
Chigwell
;
where
they
widened
and
enlarged
the
fireplace
for
him
,
hung
up
the
boiler
,
and
furthermore
planted
in
the
little
garden
outside
the
front
-
door
,
a
fictitious
Maypole
;
so
that
he
was
quite
at
home
directly
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
,
his
new
habitation
,
Tom
Cobb
,
Phil
Parkes
,
and
Solomon
Daisy
went
regularly
every
night
:
and
in
the
chimney
-
corner
,
they
all
four
quaffed
,
and
smoked
,
and
prosed
,
and
dozed
,
as
they
had
done
of
old
.
 
<EOS>
It
being
accidentally
discovered
after
a
short
time
that
Mr
Willet
still
appeared
to
consider
himself
a
landlord
by
profession
,
Joe
provided
him
with
a
slate
,
upon
which
the
old
man
regularly
scored
up
vast
accounts
for
meat
,
drink
,
and
tobacco
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
grew
older
this
passion
increased
upon
him
;
and
it
became
his
delight
to
chalk
against
the
name
of
each
of
his
cronies
a
sum
of
enormous
magnitude
,
and
impossible
to
be
paid
:
and
such
was
his
secret
joy
in
these
entries
,
that
he
would
be
perpetually
seen
going
behind
the
door
to
look
at
them
,
and
coming
forth
again
,
suffused
with
the
liveliest
satisfaction
.
  
<EOS>
He
never
recovered
the
surprise
the
Rioters
had
given
him
,
and
remained
in
the
same
mental
condition
down
to
the
last
moment
of
his
life
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
like
to
have
been
brought
to
a
speedy
termination
by
the
first
sight
of
his
first
grandchild
,
which
appeared
to
fill
him
with
the
belief
that
some
alarming
miracle
had
happened
to
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
Being
promptly
blooded
,
however
,
by
a
skilful
surgeon
,
he
rallied
;
and
although
the
doctors
all
agreed
,
on
his
being
attacked
with
symptoms
of
apoplexy
six
months
afterwards
,
that
he
ought
to
die
,
and
took
it
very
ill
that
he
did
not
<EOS>
,
he
remained
alive
---
possibly
on
account
of
his
constitutional
slowness
---
 
for
nearly
seven
years
more
,
when
he
was
one
morning
found
speechless
in
his
bed
.
 
<EOS>
He
lay
in
this
state
,
free
from
all
tokens
of
uneasiness
,
for
a
whole
week
,
when
he
was
suddenly
restored
to
consciousness
by
hearing
the
nurse
whisper
in
his
son
's
ear
that
he
was
going
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
-
going
,
Joseph
,
"
said
Mr
Willet
,
turning
round
upon
the
instant
,
"
to
the
Salwanners
"
---
and
immediately
gave
up
the
ghost
.
  
<EOS>
He
left
a
large
sum
of
money
behind
him
;
even
more
than
he
was
supposed
to
have
been
worth
,
although
the
neighbours
,
according
to
the
custom
of
mankind
in
calculating
the
wealth
that
other
people
ought
to
have
saved
,
had
estimated
his
property
in
good
round
numbers
.
 
<EOS>
Joe
inherited
the
whole
;
so
that
he
became
a
man
of
great
consequence
in
those
parts
,
and
was
perfectly
independent
.
  
<EOS>
Some
time
elapsed
before
Barnaby
got
the
better
of
the
shock
he
had
sustained
,
or
regained
his
old
health
and
gaiety
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
recovered
by
degrees
:
<EOS>
and
although
he
could
never
separate
his
condemnation
and
escape
from
the
idea
of
a
terrific
dream
,
he
became
,
in
other
respects
,
more
rational
.
 
<EOS>
Dating
from
the
time
of
his
recovery
,
he
had
a
better
memory
and
greater
steadiness
of
purpose
;
but
a
dark
cloud
overhung
his
whole
previous
existence
,
and
never
cleared
away
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
not
the
less
happy
for
this
,
for
his
love
of
freedom
and
interest
in
all
that
moved
or
grew
,
or
had
its
being
in
the
elements
,
remained
to
him
unimpaired
.
 
<EOS>
He
lived
with
his
mother
on
the
Maypole
farm
,
tending
the
poultry
and
the
cattle
,
working
in
a
garden
of
his
own
,
and
helping
everywhere
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
known
to
every
bird
and
beast
about
the
place
,
and
had
a
name
for
every
one
.
<EOS>
Never
was
there
a
lighter
-
hearted
husbandman
,
a
creature
more
popular
with
young
and
old
,
a
blither
or
more
happy
soul
than
Barnaby
;
and
though
he
was
free
to
ramble
where
he
would
,
he
never
quitted
Her
,
but
was
for
evermore
her
stay
and
comfort
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
remarkable
that
although
he
had
that
dim
sense
of
the
past
,
he
sought
out
Hugh
's
dog
,
and
took
him
under
his
care
;
and
that
he
never
could
be
tempted
into
London
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
Riots
were
many
years
old
,
and
Edward
and
his
wife
came
back
to
England
with
a
family
almost
as
numerous
as
Dolly
's
,
and
one
day
appeared
at
the
Maypole
porch
,
he
knew
them
instantly
,
and
wept
and
leaped
for
joy
.
 
<EOS>
But
neither
to
visit
them
,
nor
on
any
other
pretence
,
no
matter
how
full
of
promise
and
enjoyment
,
could
he
be
persuaded
to
set
foot
in
the
streets
:
nor
did
he
ever
conquer
this
repugnance
or
look
upon
the
town
again
.
  
<EOS>
Grip
soon
recovered
his
looks
,
and
became
as
glossy
and
sleek
as
ever
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
profoundly
silent
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
he
had
forgotten
the
art
of
Polite
Conversation
in
Newgate
,
or
had
made
a
vow
in
those
troubled
times
to
forego
,
for
a
period
,
the
display
of
his
accomplishments
,
is
matter
of
uncertainty
;
but
certain
it
is
that
for
a
whole
year
he
never
indulged
in
any
other
sound
than
a
grave
,
decorous
croak
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
expiration
of
that
term
,
the
morning
being
very
bright
and
sunny
,
he
was
heard
to
address
himself
to
the
horses
in
the
stable
,
upon
the
subject
of
the
Kettle
,
so
often
mentioned
in
these
pages
;
and
before
the
witness
who
overheard
him
could
run
into
the
house
with
the
intelligence
,
and
add
to
it
upon
his
solemn
affirmation
the
statement
that
he
had
heard
him
laugh
,
the
bird
himself
advanced
with
fantastic
steps
to
the
very
door
of
the
bar
,
and
there
cried
,
"
I
'm
a
devil
,
I
'm
a
devil
,
I
'm
a
devil
!
"
<EOS>
with
extraordinary
rapture
.
  
<EOS>
From
that
period
(
although
he
was
supposed
to
be
much
affected
by
the
death
of
Mr
Willet
senior
)
,
he
constantly
practised
and
improved
himself
in
the
vulgar
tongue
;
and
,
as
he
was
a
mere
infant
for
a
raven
when
Barnaby
was
grey
,
he
has
very
probably
gone
on
talking
to
the
present
time
.
     
<EOS>
